The Roman Senate, along with Attalus II Philadelphus of Pergamum and Ptolemy VI Philometor of Egypt, support Alexander Balas and he becomes the ruler of the Seleucid Empire. Demetrius I Soter's son, Demetrius, goes into exile in Crete.

title: India
event: The enlargement of the Great Stupa of Sanchi, Madhya Pradesh, India begins, taking about 100 years.

title: County Longford
event: Corlea Trackway built in County Longford

title: Carthage
event: Carthage recalled from exile an able general, named Hasdrubal, who organized their solid defences. Against the 45-foot (13.7 m) city walls, the Romans made slow progress.

title: Judea
event: Simon Maccabaeus succeeds his brother Jonathan as High Priest of Judea until 135 BC.

title: Judea
event: The Seleucid garrison negotiates the surrender of Jerusalem. Simon Maccabaeus assumes control of that city. He becomes prince (ruler) of Judea until 135 BC.

title: Judea
event: Simon Maccabaeus crowned king of Judea.

title: China
event: Han Wudi becomes emperor of China.

title: China
event: Zhang Qian begins his explorations in central Asia for Chinese emperor Han Wu Di.

title: China
event: The first Chinese diplomatic mission to the Ferghana valley, led by Chang Chien, is sent.

title: China
event: Confucianism is adopted as the state religion in China by the emperor Wu Di.

title: Numantia
event: Scipio Aemilianus, victor of Carthage, takes command in Spain against the Numantians. He recruits 20,000 men and 40,000 allies, including Numidian cavalry under Jugurtha. Scipio, an expert in sieges, builds a ring of seven forts and a ditch palisade before beginning the Siege of Numantia. The perimeter of the circumvallations is twice as long as that of the city. The river Durius (Douro), enables the defenders to be supplied by small boats.

title: Delos
event: Caius Fulvius Flaccus, as consul, is sent against the slaves. Uprising of 4,000 slaves crushed at Sinuessa, in Campania. Slave uprisings repressed in Attic silver mines and on the island of Delos.

title: Judea
event: John Hyrcanus becomes high priest and prince (ruler) of Judea, until 104 BC, following the murder of his father Simon Maccabaeus by Ptolemy the son of Abubus in 135 BC.

title: Numantia
event: Lucius Calpurnius Piso Frugi, as consul, is sent against the slaves in Italy. Gaius Marius serves under Publius Cornelius Scipio Aemilianus at Numantia.

title: Han Dynasty
event: June—A large army of the Han Dynasty, under commanders such as Li Guang, attempt to ambush the Xiongnu leader in the Battle of Mayi. The plot fails, and the battle is determined a draw.

title: Pergamon
event: Aristonicus of Pergamon leads an uprising against Rome, and consul Publius Licinius Crassus Mucianius is killed in the fighting.

title: Tarpeian Rock
event: The Roman censor Quintus Caecilius Metellus Macedonicus attempts to remove the tribune Gaius Atinius Labeo Macerio from the Senate, the angry Atinius drags him to be thrown off the Tarpeian Rock, and Metellus is only saved by the intervention of other senators.

title: Hierapolis
event: Kingdom of Pergamon, including Hierapolis, becomes the Roman Province of Asia upon death of last Attalid king, Attalos III, and after the defeat of the pretender Aristonicus by M. Perperna, with Cappadocian assistance.

title: Carthage
event: Scipio Aemilianus, victor of Carthage was assassinated by his enemies in Rome.

title: China
event: Led by General Ho Chu-ping, the Chinese defeat the Hsiung-nu.

title: Gobi Desert
event: January-June—the Han Chinese army under the commanders Wei Qing (d. 106 BC) and Huo Qubing (140 BC–117 BC) are victorious over the Xiongnu in the Battle of Mobei, taken place in the Orkhon Valley of the Gobi Desert, modern Mongolia.

title: China
event: Parthia makes a trade treaty with China.

title: Bosporan Kingdom
event: Mithridates VI Eupator becomes king of Bosporus.

title: Shijiazhuang
event: Incense burner, from the tomb of Prince Liu Sheng, Mancheng, Hebei, is made. Han dynasty. It is now kept at Hebei Provincial Museum, Shijiazhuang.

title: North Vietnam
event: The Han Empire annexes the Vietnamese kingdom of Nam Viet, and thereby extends its territory to modern-day North Vietnam.

title: Han Dynasty
event: During the reign of Emperor Wu of the Han Dynasty, Guilin is named Shi An Prefecture.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Han Dynasty of China annexed Minyue.

title: Han Dynasty
event: December—The Han Dynasty Chinese under commander Zhao Ponu are victorious in the Battle of Loulan in the Tarim Basin, resulting in the submission of Dayuan and the Wusun in Central Asia.

title: Bosporan Kingdom
event: The uprising of Saumachus against Mithridates VI in the Bosporan Kingdom.

title: Iran
event: The Chinese and the Persians establish diplomatic ties.

title: Battle of Cannae
event: October 6—The Battle of Arausio, where the Cimbri destroy two Roman armies on the Rhône, is the most severe defeat of Roman forces since the Battle of Cannae.

title: Segesta
event: Athenion starts a slave rebellion in Segesta.

title: Italy
event: In Rome exist a state of emergency, the way to Italy lays open to the Germanic invaders. Gaius Marius, the conqueror of Jugurtha, is elected consul for the second time.

title: Judea
event: Aristobulus I succeeds John Hyrcanus, becoming king and high priest of Judea, until 103 BC.

title: Judea
event: Alexander Jannaeus succeeds his brother Aristobulus I as king and high priest of Judea, until 76 BC.

title: Adige
event: The Cimbri defeat the Consul Quintus Lutatius Catulus in the Adige Valley.

title: Kokand
event: The Chinese under Emperor Wu of Han besiege and capture Kokand of Dayuan in the Hellenistic Ferghana Valley, during a 2 year war with the Yuezhi.

title: Rhodes
event: Lucius Appuleius Saturninus, a tribune, passes a law to redistribute land to military veterans. The law requires that all senators swear to abide by it. Quintus Caecilus Metellus Numidicus refuses and is exiled. He goes to Rhodes to study philosophy.

title: Roman Forum
event: December: Saturninus stands for consul for the following year. A rival candidate, Gaius Memmius, is found murdered by agents of Saturninus, who is declared a public enemy by the Senate. Marius, as consul, defeats his former ally in battle in the Forum. Saturninus and his followers surrender on condition that their lives are spared, but they are stoned to death with roof tiles by renegade senators.

title: Naples National Archaeological Museum
event: The building of the Sanctuary of Fortuna Primigenia, Palestrina, Italy, is begun. The model of it is now kept at the Museo Archeologico Nazionale, Italy (approximate date).

title: Gobi Desert
event: Peasant revolts under Emperor Wu of Han. The Great Wall is extended out into the Gobi Desert, sections of the wall are detached with signalling towers.

title: Cappadocia
event: Ariarathes VIII is forced out of Cappadocia by Mithridates, and dies soon afterwards.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Start of the Taishi era in the Han Dynasty.

title: India
event: Shakas start to control northwest India.

title: Cappadocia
event: Ariobarzanes I Philoromanus becomes king of Cappadocia with Roman backing.

title: Cappadocia
event: Sulla repulses Tigranes of Armenia from Cappadocia.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Liu Ju, crown prince of the Han Dynasty, revolts against his father, Emperor Wu, and his witchcraft trials. After his rebellion fails, he hangs himself.

title: Italy
event: Corfinium in south-central Italy is the center of a rebellion against Rome.

title: Cappadocia
event: Mithridates VI of Pontus invades Bithynia and Cappadocia, thus the First Mithridatic War begins.

title: Greece
event: Mithridates VI of Pontus invades Greece.

title: Greece
event: Sulla arrives in Greece and besieges Athens. He orders Lucius Licinius Lucullus to raise a fleet from Rome's allies around the eastern Mediterranean.

title: Italy
event: Sulla returns to Italy from his campaigns in Greece, defeats the popular forces of Gaius Norbanus in the Battle of Mount Tifata.

title: Hispania Citerior
event: Battle of the Baetis River—A force of Democratic exiles under Sertorius defeat the legal Roman army of Lucius Fulfidias in Hispania, starting the Sertorian War, Quintus Metellus Pius takes command on behalf of Sulla.

title: Rhodes
event: Cicero travels to Athens and then to Rhodes to continue his studies of philosophy and oratory.

title: Judea
event: Salome Alexandra becomes queen of Judea, after the death of her husband, Alexander Jannaeus, until 67 BC.

title: Cappadocia
event: Nicomedes IV of Bithynia bequeaths his kingdom to Rome on his death (75/4 BC), angry by the arrangement, Mithridates VI of Pontus declares war on Rome and invaded Bithynia, Cappadocia and Paphlagonia, thus starting the Third Mithridatic War.

title: Pergamon
event: Julius Caesar travels to Rhodes to study under Apollonius Molon. On his way across the Aegean Sea, he is kidnapped by Cilician pirates and held prisoner in the Dodecanese islet of Pharmacusa. The young Caesar is held for ransom of twenty talents, he insists they ask for fifty. After his release Caesar raises a fleet at Miletus, pursues and crucifies the pirates in Pergamon.

title: Cyrene Libya
event: Cyrene becomes a Roman province.

title: Great Britain
event: Traditional date that Lud became King of Britain, according to Geoffrey of Monmouth.

title: Cumae
event: Third Servile War begins with gladiators, led by the Thracian Spartacus, breaking out of a gladiatorial training school in Capua and forming an army, made up of runaway slaves and others with little to lose. With some 70,000 men, Spartacus rampages throughout Campania, assaulting the prosperous cities of Cumae, Nola and Nuceria.

title: Crete
event: Kydonia, an ancient city on the island of Crete falls to Roman military forces.

title: Delos
event: Rhodes becomes a bulwark against pirates, the Rhodians are unable to suppress piracy in the Aegean Sea. Delos gets the status of a free port.

title: Ostia Antica
event: Ostia, the harbour city of Rome, is sacked by pirates. The port is set on fire and the consular war fleet is destroyed.

title: Judea
event: Hyrcanus II becomes king of Judea, for first time (until 66 BC), on death of his mother, Salome Alexandra.

title: Sea of Marmara
event: Mithridates VI invades Pontus. He besieged the Romans in Chalcedon (opposite Byzantium) and pressed westward along the south shores of the Sea of Marmara to attack Cyzicus.

title: Han Dynasty
event: December—The army of the Han Dynasty Chinese commander Zheng Ji is victorious over the Xiongnu in the Battle of Jushi.

title: Judea
event: Aristobulus II becomes king and high priest of Judea, until 63 BC.

title: Judea
event: Pompey first annexed Syria, then captured Jerusalem, annexing Judea.

title: Judea
event: Pompey conquers Phonecia, Coele-Syria, and Judea for Rome.

title: Mount Nemrut
event: King Antiochus I Theos of Commagene builds his mountain-top tomb-sanctuary at Mount Nemrut.

title: Han Dynasty
event: The Han Dynasty government establishes the Protectorate of the Western Regions, the highest military position of a military commander on the Western frontier (Tarim Basin)

title: Lake Geneva
event: Caesar builts an 19-mile earthwork, complete with fortifications and watchtowers, between Lake Geneva and the Jura Mountains.

title: India
event: Base year of the Vikrama Era, founded by Vikrama, king of Ujjain in India.

title: Switzerland
event: Julius Caesar sent Servius Sulpicius Galba with Legio XII Fulminata into the country of the Nantuates, Seduni and the Veragri. He occupies the oppidum '''Octodurus''' (modern Martigny) in Switzerland.

title: Gwangju
event: The city of Gwangju (the sixth largest city in South Korea) is founded.

title: Brittany
event: Decimus Junius Brutus Albinus defeats the Veneti of Brittany: The Gallics lost most of their swanships to the Romans at the battle in modern-day Quiberon Bay. The strongholds on the coast are stormed and the population is slaughtered or sold into slavery.

title: Theatre of Pompey
event: Pompey's Theater, the first permanent (non-wooden) theatres in Rome. Built of stone on the Field of Mars, it included a temple to Venus Victorious, a public courtyard, and a meeting hall or ''curia'' in the far end near the Sacred Area.

title: Rhine
event: May—Julius Caesar defeats a Germanic army then massacres the women and children, totalling 430,000 people, somewhere near the Meuse and Rhine Rivers.

title: Great Britain
event: July—Julius Caesar's second expedition to Britain: receives nominal submission from the chieftain Cassivellaunus and installs Mandubracius as a friendly king.

title: Hierapolis
event: Crassus sacks the Temple of Hierapolis and the Temple of Jerusalem on his way to engage the Parthians.

title: Battle of Carrhae
event: Battle of Carrhae: Romans defeated, and Crassus killed, by Parthians led by Surena.

title: Battle of Alesia
event: October—Romans defeat Gauls led by Vercingetorix at the Battle of Alesia, thus breaking the back of the Gallic insurrection. The final pacification of Gaul is complete the following year.

title: China
event: The Hsiung-nu split into two hordes. The Eastern horde is subject to China.

title: Pompeii
event: Initiation Rites of the Cult of Bacchus (?), detail of a wall painting in the Villa of the Mysteries, Pompeii, is made. (approximate date)

title: Judea
event: The Roman Republic takes control over Judea.

title: Rubicon
event: January 10—Julius Caesar leads his army across the Rubicon, which separates his jurisdiction (Cisalpine Gaul) from that of the Senate (Italy), and thus initiates a civil war. In response, the Roman senate invokes the  ''senatus consultum ultimum''.

title: Pyrenees
event: June—Caesar arrives in Spain; seizes the Pyrenees passes against the Pompeians L. Afranius and Marcus Petreius.

title: Battle of Ilerda
event: July 30—Caesar surrounds Afranius and Petreius's army in Ilerda.

title: Krk
event: September—Decimus Brutus, a Caesarian, defeats the combined Pompeian-Massilian naval forces in the naval Battle of Massilia, while the Caesarian fleet in the Adriatic is defeated near Curicta (Krk).

title: Alexandria
event: October—Julius Caesar reached Alexandria, city founded by Alexander the Great. He is met by an Egyptian delegation from Ptolemy XIII. The Egyptians offered him gifts: the ring of Pompey and his head.

title: Bosporan Kingdom
event: Pharnaces, King of Bosporus defeats the Caesarian Gnaeus Domitius Calvinus in the Battle of Nicopolis (or Nikopol).

title: Library of Alexandria
event: December—Battle in Alexandria, Egypt between the forces of Caesar and his ally Cleopatra VII and those of rival King Ptolemy XIII of Egypt and Queen Arsinoe IV. The latter two are defeated and flee the city, but during the battle part of the Library of Alexandria catches fire and is burned down.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Yuan becomes emperor of the Han Dynasty.

title: Alexandria
event: February—Roman general Julius Caesar and his ally Cleopatra VII of Egypt defeat the forces of the rival Egyptian Queen Arsinoe IV in the Battle of the Nile. Ptolemy is killed; Caesar then relieves his besieged forces in Alexandria.

title: Judea
event: Battle at Mount Tabor in Judea: Roman troops, commanded by Gabinius, defeat the forces of Alexander, son of Aristobulus II of Judea, attempting to re-establish Judean independence. Some 10,0000 Jews died at the hands of the Romans.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Feng Yuan becomes consort to Emperor Yuan of the Han Dynasty.

title: Roman Forum
event: April 20—Cicero, in Rome, writes to Varro If our voices are no longer heard in the Senate and in the Forum, let us follow the example of the ancient sages and serve our country through our writings, concentrating on questions of ethics and constitutional law.

title: Roman Forum
event: March 20—Caesar's funeral is held. Marcus Antony gives a eulogy and in his ''Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears'' speech he makes accusations of murder and ensures a permanent breach with the conspirators against Caesar. He snatches Caesar's purple toga to show the crowd the stab wounds, the citizens tear apart the forum and cremate their Caesar on a makeshift pyre. Antony becomes the first man in Rome.

title: France
event: June—Antony is granted a five-year governorship of northern and central Transalpine Gaul (France) and Cisalpine Gaul (Northern Italy).

title: New York
event: A Denarius with a portrait of Julius Caesar is made. It is now kept at the American Numismatic Society in New York.

title: Latakia
event: Gaius Antonius is defeated by Marcus Junius Brutus at Dyrrachium, Brutus proceeds to secure his position in Thrace and Macedonia. Gaius Cassius Longinus campaigns in Syria and defeats the army of Publius Cornelius Dolabella at Laodicea.

title: Ligurian Alps
event: Antony marched to Parma (which is sacked) and Placentia. He then crossed the Ligurian Alps to Vada Sabatia, 50 km south-west of Genoa. Antony joints with Aemilius Lepidus, soon after Decimus Brutus is killed by brigands.

title: Rostra
event: 7 December—Marcus Tullius Cicero is killed in Formiae in a litter going to the seaside, by a party led by a military tribune, Popilius Laenas. His head and hands were displayed on the Rostra in the Forum Romanum.

title: Lugdunum
event: Lugdunum (Lyon) is founded.

title: India
event: According to legend, Nagasena creates the Emerald Buddha figurine in Patna, India.

title: Xanthos
event: Marcus Brutus begins to plunder the cities of Asia Minor, in order to obtain money and soldiers. The inhabitants of Lycia refused to submit to Rome, and Brutus besieged Xanthus. After destroying their suburbs, the Xanthians withdrew into the heavily fortified city. The Roman legionaries (2,000 men) forced the gate and fight their way into the forum. The citizens made an heroic stand by the tempel of Sarpedon, as night falls the Roman army conquers the city. The Xanthians preferred to perish in the flames rather than to yield.

title: Rhodes
event: The confederation of Lycia sent ambassadors to Brutus, promising to form a militairy league and contribute money for building ships. Gaius Cassius Longinus occupies Rhodes, and ordered all the other cities of Asia to pay a tribute for 10 years.

title: Adriatic Sea
event: July—Mark Antony lands with a army (28 legions) in Illyria, left Octavian ill at Dyrrachium and marched to Amphipolis. Admiral Ahenobarbus blokkades with the Republican fleet (130 ships) the Adriatic Sea.

title: Philippi
event: Brutus and Cassius advance to Philippi and built fortifications. Antony links up with Norbanus and Saxa at Amphipolis, Octavian arrives on a litter 10 days later.

title: Thasos
event: October 3—First Battle of Philippi: The Triumvirs Mark Antony and Octavian Caesar fight an indecisive battle with Caesar's assassins Marcus Brutus and Cassius. The Roman forces including 2,000 Spartans who just arrived are routed, Octavian takes refuge in the marsh. Cassius' camp is captured by Antony's men, wrongly fearing that Brutus is dead Cassius commits suicide. He ordered his freedman Pindarus to kill him, Brutus feared the impact on morale and secretly buried his beheaded body on Thasos. The Republican navy in the Adriatic, intercept and destroy the supply ships with two legions of the Triumvirs.

title: Italy
event: Gaius Julius Caesar Octavian returns to Rome and arranged for ± 40.000 veterans settlements in Campania, Etruria, Picenum, Samnium, Umbria and in northern Italy.

title: Italy
event: Perusine War: A armed resistance breaks out across Italy, the Umbrian city of Sentinum is captured and destroyed by Quintus Salvidienus Rufus.

title: Ephesus
event: Mark Antony meets Cleopatra VII in Tarsus (Cilicia) and formed an alliance. He returned to Alexandria with her and they become lovers in the winter of 41 BC - 40 BC. To safeguard herself and Caesarion, she had Antony order the execution of her (half) sister Arsinoe IV, who is living at the temple of Artemis in Ephesus.

title: Sicyon
event: Siege of Perusia: After a last attempt to break the siege, which failed; Lucius Antonius surrenders to Octavian. His life is spared, but the citizens are executed or sold in slavery. Fulvia fled with her children and is exiled to Sicyon, where she died of a sudden illness.

title: Corsica
event: Sextus Pompey dispatched Menas with four legions and captured Sardinia, driving out Octavian's governor Marcus Lurius. He seized the capital, Caralis and occupied Corsica. Sextus besieged Cosenza in Bruttium and Thurii in Lucania, ravaging the territory with his cavalry.

title: Roman Forum
event: Sextus' fleet raides the ports of Puteoli and Ostia. The populace hold the Triumvirs responsible for prolonging the war, they provoked a riot on the Forum. Octavian with the Praetorian Guard went to intercept, he escaped with his life because Antony summoned troops to rescue his junior colleague.

title: Alabanda
event: Quintus Labienus occupied Cilicia and marched with a army into Anatolia. Most cities surrendered without resistance, except for Alabanda and Mylasa. The Parthians restored their territory to nearly the limits of the old Achaemenid Empire, Labienus proclaimed himself Parthian Emperor of Asia Minor.

title: Italy
event: Mark Antony leaves Alexandria; after receiving news of the outcome at Perusia while en route to Phoenicia, he sets sail for Italy meeting the ambassadors of Sextus Pompey in Athens.

title: Tyre Lebanon
event: Pacorus crosses with help of Quintus Labienus the Euphrates and invades  Syria. The capital Antioch surrenders, the Parthians takes Phoenicia and Judea, the fortified city of Tyre can not besiege because they have no fleet.

title: Judea
event: Parthians conquer Jerusalem. Hyrcanus II is removed from power, while Antigonus the Hasmonean becomes king of Judea under Parthian rule. Herod the Great flees Jerusalem to Rome. There he is titled king of Judea by Mark Antony.

title: Han Dynasty
event: The ''Ji Jiu Pian'' dictionary published in this year during the Han Dynasty is the earliest known reference to the hydraulic-powered trip hammer device.

title: Taurus Mountains
event: Marcus Antonius dispatched Publius Ventidius Bassus with 11 legions to the East and drives Quintus Labienus out of Asia Minor, he retreats  into Syria, where he received Parthian reinforcements. Ventidius finally defeats him in the battle at the Taurus Mountains.

title: Judea
event: Publius Ventidius defeats Pharnastanes with his cataphracts at the Amanus Gates, and goes on to reclaim Syria, Phoenicia and Judea. Labienus flees to Cilicia, where he is captured and executed.

title: Italy
event: Sextus Pompey, styled himself son of Neptune, controlled Sicily, Sardinia, Corsica and the Peloponnesus is recognized by the Triumvirate in the Pact of Misenum. The pact helped to assure Rome's grain supply, the blockade on Italy is lifted.

title: Rhine
event: Octavian appointed Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa governor of Transalpine Gaul, where he put down a uprising of the Aquitanians. He also fought successfully against the Germanic tribes, and becoming the next Roman general to cross the Rhine after Julius Caesar.

title: Cappadocia
event: Antony reorganized Asia Minor under strongmen loyal to him. He raised troops from his allies Amyntas and Archelaus, kings of Galatia and Cappadocia. The old kingdom of Pontus is restored, from Armenia to the River Halys under Polemon I.

title: Judea
event: Romans conquer Jerusalem from the Parthians. Herod the Great becomes king of Judea and Ananelus is installed as High Priest, both positions seized from Antigonus II Mattathias after a five-month siege. Thousands of Jews slaughtered by Roman troops supporting Herod.

title: Korea
event: The kingdom of Goguryeo in Korea is founded by the king Dongmyeong. (traditional date)

title: Anatolia
event: June—Mark Antony launches a major offensive against the Parthians, he marches with 10 legions and 10,000 cavalry to Carana in Anatolia.

title: Iran
event: October—Antony abandons the siege of Phraaspa (near Maragheh, Iran). He retreats, loses many men to disease and starvation in the subsequent retreat to Egypt, marries Cleopatra VII and is still married to Octavia.

title: Judea
event: Judea: Aristobulus III, the last of the Hasmoneans, becomes High Priest in Jerusalem, replacing Ananelus, who had only held the position for one year.

title: Han Dynasty
event: October–December—the Han Dynasty Chinese army under General Chen Tang and General Gan Yanshou defeat the Xiongnu leader Zhizhi Chanyu in the Battle of Zhizhi. This led to half a century of peace between the Han Dynasty and the Xiongnu until Wang Mang enraged them in the year 10, resuming hostilities between both sides.

title: Sisak
event: Pannonia is attacked by Octavian Caesar; who conquered and sacked the stronghold Siscia (Sisak) of the Segestani, which is taken after a 30-day siege. The country is however, definitely subdued until 9 BC.

title: Nicomedia
event: Sextus Pompeius defeats with three legions Gaius Furnius, the governor of Asia, and seized Nicaea and Nicomedia (modern Izmit).

title: Miletus
event: Marcus Titius arrived in Syria with a large army and marched to Asia Minor, Sextus is caught in Miletus and executed without trial.

title: India
event: Azes I, Indo-Scythian ruler, completed the domination of the Scythians in northern India.

title: Alexandria
event: Autumn—The Donations of Alexandria: Antony distributes the eastern kingdoms as a gift to the children of Cleopatra VII of Egypt; he declared Caesarion, Caesar's legitimate son as co-ruler of Egypt and Cyprus.  Alexander Helios received Armenia and Media, to Cleopatra Selene he gives the kingdoms of Cyrenaica and Libya. His youngest son Ptolemy Philadelphus received the Egyptian possessions in Phoenicia, Syria and Cilicia. Antony established Cleopatra as a Hellenistic monarch at Alexandria and gives her the title of Queen of Kings.

title: Samos
event: Spring—Final War of the Roman Republic: Mark Antony transferred his headquarters from Samos to Athens, he assembled a fleet of 500 combat vessels and 300 transport ships, crewed by 150,000 men.

title: Crete
event: Sparta under Eurycles, whose father Antony had ordered to be executed for piracy, declared his support for Octavian. Lappa (modern Argyroupoli) in Attica and Kydonia in Crete revolts against Cleopatra.

title: Alexandria
event: July—The Roman Senate declares war upon Mark Antony and Cleopatra VII. Octavian Caesar is proclaimed dux and the West: Gallic and Spanish provinces, Africa, Sicily and Sardinia swears an oath (''sacramentum'') of loyalty to him. In order to assure this oath, Octavian forced the  high priest of the Vestal Virgins in Rome to hand over Antony's will, which give information over the Roman-conquered territories as kingdoms and plans to built a tomb in Alexandria for him and Cleopatra.

title: Actium
event: Winter—Antony distributes garrisons along the west coast of Greece, stations the fleet at Actium and establishes his headquarters at Patrae.

title: Messenia
event: Zacynthos is held by Gaius Sosius, Methone (Messenia) by Bogud of the royal house of Mauretania, driven into exile by his brother Bocchus II.

title: Strait of Otranto
event: Octavian crosses the Strait of Otranto and lands with a army (15 legions) at Panormus in Dalmatia. He marched to Toryne in the south, and established a bridgehead at the Gulf of Ambracia.

title: Gulf of Corinth
event: Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa sailed with 300 war galleys to the western Peloponnese, and occupied strategic positions around the Gulf of Corinth to cut off Antony's line of communication.

title: Actium
event: Antony alerted by Octavian's presence, sets up camp on the southern shore, at the promontory of Actium. He dispatches a force to isolate the camp of Octavian in the valley of Louros.

title: Lefkada
event: Agrippa stormed Leucas, given Octavian a anchorage and a second depot for his land supplies. He seized the garrison at Patrae, and taking Antony's headquarters.

title: Greece
event: September 2—Roman Civil War: Battle of Actium—Off the western coast of Greece, Octavian Caesar defeats the naval forces under Mark Antony and Cleopatra VII.

title: Nicopolis
event: Winter—Octavian (thirty-two years old) takes court at Samos. After his decisive victory at Actium he builts Nicopolis, the city is populated by Greeks from settlements further inland.

title: Masada
event: In the Judean Desert on an isolated rock plateau, fortress Masada is completed. Herod the Great builts an armory, barracks, storehouses and a palace.

title: Syria (Roman province)
event: Spring—Octavian led his army to the Dardanelles; he shipped them across to Asia Minor and marched into Syria, where Herod the Great send him vows of loyalty and thousands of his own troops in support.

title: Cyrene Libya
event: Summer—Gaius Cornelius Gallus lands in Cyrene and occupied Paraetonium, Mark Antony stormed the city walls and blokkades the harbour.

title: Pelusium
event: Antony retreats his army (7 legions) to Egypt and receive the news that Pelusium, has opened its gates to Octavian without resistance.

title: Red Sea
event: Cleopatra evacuates her court and treasury to Berenice on the west coast of the Red Sea, but king Malchus of Nabatea attacks from the desert and burned the Egyptian ships.

title: Italy
event: Octavian claimed Cleopatra's treasure in the mausoleum at the Temple of Isis; he pays the salaries of his veteran legionaries and gives them land in Italy.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First possible date for the invention of the wheelbarrow in history; as the 5th century ''Book of Later Han'' stated, that the wife of the once poor and youthful imperial censor Bao Xuan of the Chinese Han Dynasty helped him push a ''lu che'' back to his village during their feeble wedding ceremony, around 30 BC.

title: Alexandria
event: August 1—Octavian Caesar captures Alexandria. This marks the official annexation of Ancient Egypt to the Roman Republic.

title: Temple of Janus (Roman Forum)
event: Octavian Caesar becomes Roman Consul for the fifth time. His partner is Sextus Appuleius. He is granted the title of imperator, and for the third time in Roman history the doors of the Temple of Janus are closed, signaling peace.

title: Portus Julius
event: Augustus formed the Classis Misenensis, based in the harbour of Portus Julius at Misenum.

title: Hispania Citerior
event: Agrippa divides Hispania Ulterior into Baetica and Lusitania, and enlarges Hispania Citerior.

title: Colossi of Memnon
event: Northern statue of the Colossi of Memnon is shattered by an earthquake in Egypt (according to Strabo).

title: Pantheon Rome
event: 27 BC–25 BC—Marcus Agrippa builds the old Pantheon.

title: India
event: The Andhra dynasty replaces the Kanva dynasty, and rules over the eastern part of India.

title: China
event: Estimation: Rome, capital of the Roman Empire becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Chang'an, capital of China.

title: Nicopolis
event: Augustus founds the city of Nicopolis in Egypt to commemorate his final victory over Mark Antony.

title: Elephantine
event: The Nubians, led by queen Candace Amanirenas, take the initiative against the Roman Empire, and attack the Roman province of Egypt moving towards Elephantine.

title: Judea
event: Herod the Great builds a palace in Jerusalem and the fortress Herodian in Judaea. He also marries his third wife, named Mariamne, the daughter of high priest Simon.

title: Nile
event: The Roman governor of Egypt, Gaius Petronius, marchs the Nile with legions XXII ''Deiotariana'' and III ''Cyrenaica'', and destroys the Nubian capital of Napata.

title: Alexandria
event: Based on the scenes and the style of the work, the Portland Vase is believed to have been made in Alexandria some time between this year and 100 AD.

title: Temple in Jerusalem
event: King Herod the Great begins renovation of the Temple in Jerusalem.

title: France
event: Maison Carrée, Nîmes, France, is built (approximate date).

title: India
event: Shakas end to control northwest India.

title: Korea
event: Onjo becomes the first ruler of the Korean kingdom of Baekje (traditional date).

title: Switzerland
event: Chur (Switzerland) becomes the capital of the Roman province Rhaetia.

title: Italy
event: Nero Claudius Drusus decides to improve the passage through the Alps for military control to Noricum and Rhaetia (modern Austria). He builds the Via Claudia Augusta through Italy.

title: Vindobona
event: Vienna becomes a frontier city (Vindobona) guarding the Roman Empire against the German tribes.

title: Lake Constance
event: Roman triremes on Lake Constance destroy fleet of the Vindelici during Rhaetia campaign.

title: Beirut
event: Caesar Augustus makes Beeroth (modern Beirut) a colonia, named '''''Colonia Julia Augusta Felix Berytus'''''.

title: Syria (Roman province)
event: Winter—The Roman Legio X Fretensis is stationed in Syria, the legionaries are settled at the ancient city of Beirut.

title: North Sea
event: Drusus is granted governor of Gaul and mobilized a Roman army to beat the Germans back across the Rhine. He traveled to the North Sea and pays tribute to the Frisians.

title: Rhine
event: Roman armies based at Xanten, Cologne and Mainz campaign beyond the Rhine.

title: India
event: King Azes II dies. The rule of the Indo-Scythians crumbles as the Kushans, one of the five tribes of the Yuezhi who lives in Bactria expand into India to create a Kushan Empire.

title: Rhine
event: Drusus builds a wooden military camp '''''Castellum Bonna''''' near the Rhine, the Roman fortress is eventually rebuilt in stone.

title: Rhine
event: The Romans build a bridge across the Rhine near Bonn.

title: Ara Pacis
event: The Ara Pacis (Altar of Augustan Peace), voted by the Senate four years earlier, is dedicated.

title: Rhodes
event: Tiberius Claudius Nero is sent to Armenia, then retires to Rhodes.

title: Judea
event: After the death of Herod the Great, there is unrest in his kingdom. His sons, Herod Archelaus becomes the new ruler of Judea. Herod Antipas becomes tetrarch of Galilee and Perea.

title: Antioch
event: The Governor of Syria, Publius Quintilius Varus, assembles three of his four legions, including Legio X Fretensis, and marched down to Jerusalem from Antioch to restore order. He crucifies 2,000 Jewish rebels.

title: Rhine
event: Lucius Domitius Ahenobarbus commands the Roman army in Germania and crossed the Elbe. He builds the '''''pontes longi''''' over the marshes between the Rhine and the Ems.

title: Parthian Empire
event: Phraates V becomes king of the Parthian Empire, after he and his mother the goddess Musa have murdered his father Phraates IV.

title: Han Dynasty
event: The ''Yuanshi'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty begins.

title: Teotihuacan
event: The Teotihuacan culture in Mesoamerica begins (approximate date).

title: China
event: Buddhism is introduced into China.

title: Rhodes
event: Following the death of Lucius Caesar, Livia Drusilla persuades Augustus to allow her son Tiberius back into Rome as a private citizen, after six years in enforced retirement on Rhodes.

title: Judea
event: Juba II of Mauretania joins Gaius Caesar in Armenia as a military advisor.  It is during this period that he meets Glaphyra, a Cappadocian princess and the former wife of Alexandros of Judea, a brother of Herod Archelaus, ethnarch of Judea, and falls for her.

title: China
event: The first census is concluded in China after having begun the year before: final numbers show a population of nearly 60 million (59,594,978 people in slightly more than 12 million households). The census is one of the most accurate surveys in Chinese history.

title: Baker Airport
event: '''0O2''' - Baker Airport

title: Nervino Airport
event: '''O02''' - Nervino Airport

title: Korea
event: Namhae Chachaung succeeds Bak Hyeokgeose as king of the Korean kingdom of Silla (traditional date).

title: Lauda Air Flight 004
event: Lauda Air Flight 004

title: Corning Municipal Airport (California)
event: 0O4, Corning Municipal Airport (California)

title: Great Britain
event: Rome acknowledges Cunobelinus, King of the Catuvellauni, as King of Britain.

title: Judea
event: Herod Archelaus, ethnarch of Samaria, Judea, and Idumea, is deposed and banished to Vienne in Gaul.

title: Syria (Roman province)
event: Iudaea and Moesia become Roman provinces destroying the Dardani; Syria is guarded by legions X ''Fretensis'', III ''Gallica'', VI ''Ferrata'', and XII ''Fulminata''.

title: Carnuntum
event: Tiberius makes Carnuntum his base of operations against Maroboduus; The Roman legion XX ''Valeria Victrix'' fights with Tiberius against the Marcomanni.

title: Judea
event: Publius Sulpicius Quirinius becomes Governor of Syria and nominally of Judea.

title: Han Dynasty
event: February 3—The boy emperor, Ping Di dies of unexpected causes at age 14; Wang Mang alone selects the new emperor, the Ruzi Ying, age 2,Han Dynasty.

title: Judea
event: Roman Emperor Caesar Augustus dismisses the Judean ethnarch Herod Archelaus.

title: Rhine
event: Tiberius Quinctilius Varus, legate, is charged with organizing Germania between the Rhine and Elbe rivers.  He carries out a census, devises tributes and recruits soldiers, all of which create dissension among the Germanic tribes.

title: Temple of Concord
event: Construction of the Temple of Concord begins.

title: Shandong
event: Zhai Yi, Governor of the Commandery of Dong (modern Puyang, Henan) declares Liu Zin, Marquess of Yang Xiang (modern Tai'an, Shandong), emperor.  This proves to be the largest of the rebellions against Emperor Ruzi of Han.

title: Black Sea
event: Roman poet Ovid is banished from Rome and exiled to the Black Sea near Tomis (present-day Constanţa).

title: Great Britain
event: Tincomarus, deposed king of the Atrebates, flees Britain for Rome; Eppillus becomes king.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Start of Chushi era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: China
event: In China, Wang Mang crushes a rebellion by Chai I, and on the winter solstice (which has been dated January 10 of the following year) officially assumes the title emperor, establishing the short-lived Xin Dynasty.

title: Balls 8
event: Balls 8, NASA NB-52B mothership, tail number 52-008

title: Colusa County Airport
event: O08, Colusa County Airport

title: Battle of the Teutoburg Forest
event: The Rhine River is established as the boundary between the Latin and German speaking worlds, following the defeat of the Roman army, under the command of Varus, at the Battle of the Teutoburg Forest.

title: Round Valley Airport
event: O09 — Round Valley Airport

title: Greece
event: The Greek dynasty in Bactria is extinguished.

title: Rhine
event: Germania Inferior and the Rhine are secured by Germanicus.

title: India
event: In India, Satakarni begins his reign as Emperor of the Andhra Empire (11–29).

title: Judea
event: Annius Rufus is appointed Prefect of Judea.

title: Rhine
event: Augustus orders a major invasion of Germany beyond the Rhine.

title: Judea
event: Quirinius returns from Judea to become a counselor to Tiberius.

title: Rhine
event: Legions on the Rhine revolt after the death of Augustus; Germanicus and Drusus put down the revolt.

title: Ruhr (river)
event: Germanicus led a brutal raid against the Marsi, a German tribe on the upper Ruhr river, who were massacred.

title: Emona
event: Emona (currently Ljubljana) is founded by Legio XV Apollinaris.

title: Teutoburg Forest
event: Germanicus fights a drawn battle with Arminius in the Teutoburg Forest.

title: Rhine
event: Germanicus employs North Sea fleet to avoid dangerous rivers, embarking a army in the Rhine delta aboard circa 1,000 ships. He defeats the Germans at Amisius river estuary and the Weser, but during its return the Roman fleet is partially destroyed by storms.

title: Anatolia
event: Cappadocia (Asia Minor) becomes a Roman province.

title: Sea of Galilee
event: Herod Antipas, son of Herod the Great, builds on the western shore of the Sea of Galilee, the city Tiberias in honor of Tiberius.

title: Sardis
event: An earthquake in Anatolia destroys the city of Sardis.

title: Yellow River
event: After flooding of the Yellow River farmers are forced to rebel. Emperor Wang Mang reacted by sending a Chinese army (± 100,000 men) against the agrarian rebels. The rebel leaders, concerned that during battle it would become impossible to tell friend from foe, ordered that their men color their eyebrows red—and this is where the name Chimei (the '''Red Eyebrows''') came from.

title: Taxila
event: In India, the Indo-Parthians control Taxila.

title: Antioch
event: Agrippina the Elder accuses Gnaeus Calpurnius Piso of having assassinated her husband Germanicus Julius Caesar in Antioch.

title: China
event: Beginning of Later Han Dynasty in China.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Liu Xuan, a descendant of the Han Dynasty royal family and leader of insurgents against the Xin Dynasty, proclaims himself emperor against Wang Mang.

title: Han Dynasty
event: July—After being under siege for 2 months, about 19,000 insurgents under Liu Xiu defeat 450,000 of Wang Mang's troops in the Battle of Kunyang, ushering in the fall of Wang Mang and restoration of the Han Dynasty in China.

title: Korea
event: King Yuri ascends to the Silla (Korea) throne.

title: Carthage
event: End of the Masinissa line of the rulers of Carthage.

title: Sparta
event: Emperor Tiberius settles a dispute between Messenia and Sparta over the Ager Dentheliales on Mount Taygetus, awarding the land to Messenia.

title: Judea
event: Pontius Pilate is appointed as prefect of Judea.

title: Capri
event: Emperor Tiberius retires to Capri, leaving the Praetorian Guard under Lucius Aelius Sejanus in charge of the Roman Empire and the city of Rome.

title: Fidenae
event: A poorly built amphitheatre in Fidenae collapses, killing 20,000 of the 50,000 spectators.

title: Rhine
event: Roman legions in Germania are transported by fleet to fortress of Flevum on the Rhine to operate against the rebellious Frisians.

title: Capri
event: Tiberius returns to Rome from Capri.

title: Yangtze River
event: Although the usurpation of Wang Mang and the Chimei Rebellion are behind him, Emperor Guangwu now faces a new threat to the Han Dynasty: the Rebellion of Gongsun Shu in the Sichuan province. Gongsun's naval forces are unsuccessful against Han General Cen Peng, so Gongsun decides to fortify his position by blockading the entire Yangtze River with a large floating pontoon bridge, complete with floating fortified posts. He erects forts on both banks of the river for further missile fire and protects his barrier with a large boom. After Cen Peng is unable to break through, he constructs several castle ships with high ramparts and ramming vessels known as colliding swoopers, which break through Gongsun's lines and allow Cen to quell his rebellion. Gongsun Shu is totally defeated three years later.

title: Syria (Roman province)
event: Herod Antipas suffers major losses in a war with Aretas IV of Nabatea, provoked partly by Antipas' divorce of Aretas' daughter. According to Josephus, Herod's defeat was popularly believed to be divine punishment for his execution of John the Baptist. Emperor Tiberius orders his governor of Syria, Vitellius, to capture or kill Aretas, but he is reluctant to support Herod and abandons his campaign upon Tiberius' death in 37.Josephus, ''Antiquities of the Jews'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=J.+AJ+18.113 18.113–126]; {{cite journal last=Bruce first=F. F. authorlink=F. F. Bruce year=1963/1965 title=Herod Antipas, Tetrarch of Galilee and Peraea journal=Annual of Leeds University Oriental Society volume=5 pages=6–23, pp. 17–18 url=http://www.biblicalstudies.org.uk/pdf/herod_bruce.pdf format=PDF accessdate=2007-10-21 }}<

title: Samaria
event: Marcellus becomes governor of Judaea and Samaria.

title: Antioch
event: An earthquake destroys Antioch.

title: Alexandria
event: Apion heads a deputation to Caligula to complain about the Jews in Alexandria.

title: Alexandria
event: Anti-Jewish riot breaks out in Alexandria during a visit by Agrippa I: the mob wants to place statues of Caligula in every synagogue.

title: Baiae
event: Domitius Afer secures a consulship. Caligula ordering a floating bridge to be built using ships as pontoons, stretching for two miles from Baiae to the neighboring port of Puteoli.

title: Judea
event: Agrippa I, king of Judaea, successfully accuses Herod Antipas, tetrarch of Galilee and Perea, of conspiracy against Caligula. Antipas is exiled and Agrippa receives his territory.Josephus, ''Antiquities of the Jews'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=J.+AJ+18.247 18.247–252]; {{cite journal last=Bruce first=F. F. authorlink=F. F. Bruce year=1963/1965 title=Herod Antipas, Tetrarch of Galilee and Peraea journal=Annual of Leeds University Oriental Society volume=5 pages=6–23, p. 21 url=http://www.biblicalstudies.org.uk/pdf/herod_bruce.pdf format=PDF accessdate=2007-10-21 }}<

title: Alexandria
event: Philo leads a Jewish delegation to Rome to protest the anti-Jewish conditions in Alexandria.

title: China
event: The Trung Sisters resist the Chinese influences in Vietnam.

title: Great Britain
event: Caligula starts on a campaign to conquer Britain, which fails miserably. He declares himself victorious regardless.

title: China
event: The Vietnamese Trung sisters rebel against the rule of the Chinese Emperor Guangwu of Han.

title: Alexandria
event: Christianity comes to Egypt as a church is founded in Alexandria. Mark the Evangelist founds the Coptic Orthodox Church as the first pope.

title: Judea
event: Claudius makes Agrippa king of Judea.

title: Corsica
event: Messalina, wife of Claudius, persuades Claudius to have Seneca the Younger banished to Corsica on a charge of adultery with Julia Livilla.

title: Rhine
event: An attack across the Rhine by the Germans is stopped by the Romans.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Emperor Guangwu of the Han Dynasty deposes his wife, Guo Shentong, as empress, and creates his consort Yin Lihua empress in her place.

title: Antioch
event: The disciples of Jesus form communities after the Diaspora, especially in Damascus and Antioch.  For the first time they are called Christians.

title: Strait of Gibraltar
event: Romans take control of Ceuta, a port city on the North African side of the Strait of Gibraltar.

title: Portus
event: Claudius begins construction of Portus, the harbour bears a lighthouse and is sited on the right bank of the Tiber.

title: China
event: The Chinese General Ma Yuan represses the rebellion of the Trung sisters in Tonkin.

title: Ermine Street
event: The Roman conquest of Britain begins. Aulus Plautius lands with four legions (20,000 men) and an same number of auxiliaries at Rutupiae (modern Richborough, on the east coast of Kent) and defeats the Britons, led by Caratacus and Togodumnus, in battles on the rivers Medway and Thames. He halts at the Thames and sends for emperor Claudius, who leads the march on Camulodunum. Eleven British kings, probably including those of the Iceni and Brigantes, submit without a fight. Meanwhile, the future emperor Vespasian begins to subdue the south-west. The Romans begin to construct forts such as at Peterborough, and begin to construct a road that later becomes Ermine Street.

title: China
event: Vietnam is designated a province of China.

title: Rhodes
event: The Isle of Rhodes returns to the Roman Empire.

title: Judea
event: Judaea is controlled by Roman governors.

title: Judea
event: Cuspius Fadus, governor of Judea (44–46 AD), suppress the revolt of Theudas who is decapitated.

title: Szombathely
event: Emperor Claudius founds Savaria, today the Hungarian city of Szombathely.

title: China
event: Expedition of Chinese general Ma Yuan against the Xiongnu and the Xianbei (in Manchuria).

title: Celje
event: The settlement at Celje gets municipal rights and is named ''municipium Claudia Celeia''.

title: Rhine
event: Romans build the ''Traiectum'' fortification near the mouth of the Rhine, which will later grow to be the city of Utrecht.

title: Switzerland
event: Claudius founds the city '''Forum Claudii Vallensium''' (modern Martigny) in the Alpes Poeninae (Switzerland).

title: Voorburg
event: Corbulo orders the construction of the canal '''Fossa Corbulonis''', between the Rhine and Meuse in the Netherlands, which connects the city Forum Hadriani (Voorburg).

title: Judea
event: Ananias becomes high priest in Judaea.

title: Temple in Jerusalem
event: The emperor Claudius invests Agrippa II with the office of superintendent of the Temple in Jerusalem.

title: Inner Mongolia
event: The emperor of China, Guang Wudi (Kouang Wou-Ti), restores Chinese domination of Inner Mongolia.  The Xiongnu are made confederates and guard the Northern border of the empire.

title: Avignon
event: According to Christian legend, Martha travels to Avignon.

title: South Wales
event: In Britain, governor Publius Ostorius Scapula founds a ''colonia'' for Roman veterans at Camulodunum (Colchester). Verulamium (St Albans) is probably established as a ''municipium'' the same year. A legion is stationed on the borders of the Silures of South Wales in preparation for invasion.

title: Philippi
event: Christianity spreads into Europe, especially at Rome and at Philippi (probable date according to chronology derived from the ''Acts of the Apostles'').

title: Judea
event: In Judea a Roman soldier seized and burned a Torah-scroll. Procurator Cumanus had the culprit beheaded, calming down the Jews and delaying for two decades the outbreak of their  revoltFlavius Josephus, Ant. xx. 5, § 4; B. J. ii. 12, § 2.<

title: Atherstone
event: In Britain, governor Publius Ostorius Scapula begins his campaign against the recalcitrant Silures of south Wales, who are led by the former Catuvellaunian prince Caratacus. London (''Londinium''), Exeter (''Isca Dumnoniorum''), Tripontium (near modern Rugby) and the fort of Manduessedum (near modern Atherstone) are founded (approximate date).

title: London Bridge
event: Romans built a wooden bridge across the Thames in the London area.

title: African Great Lakes
event: Diogenes, the Greek explorer, discovers the African Great Lakes.

title: Parthian Empire
event: Vonones II died after a few months he ascended to the throne, his son Vologases I of Parthia becomes ruler of the Parthian Empire.

title: Fucine Lake
event: Emperor Claudius attempts to control the Fucine Lake by digging a 5,6 km tunnel through ''Monte Salviano'', requiring 30,000 workers and eleven years.

title: Han Dynasty
event: The ''Yuejue Shu'', the first known gazetteer of China, is written during the Han Dynasty.

title: India
event: Saint Thomas, one of the twelve disciples of Jesus, is believed to have landed in Kodungallur, India to preach the Gospel; the Marthoma Church, the Syro-Malabar Catholic Church, the Indian Orthodox Church, and the Assyrian Church of the East claim descent from him.

title: Alexandria
event: Under Nero, Rome annexes Aden to protect the maritime route between Alexandria and Asia.

title: Nile
event: Two centurions are sent to the south of Egypt to find the sources of the Nile, and possible new provinces. They report that while there are many cities in the desert, the area seems too poor to be worthy of conquest.

title: Cappadocia
event: Winter—Domitius Corbulo marched his legions (Legio VI Ferrata and Legio X) into the mountains of Cappadocia and made camp. He gives the men a harsh training, twenty-five-mile marches and weapons drills.

title: Judea
event: Judea is returned piecemeal to Agrippa I's son Marcus Julius Agrippa between 48 and 54.

title: Ephesus
event: Apollos, a later assistant of Paul, is converted to Christianity in  Ephesus.

title: Han Dynasty
event: The ''Jianwu'' era of the Eastern Han Dynasty changes to the ''Jianwuzhongyuan'' era.

title: China
event: A Japanese king sends an ambassador to China.{{Citation neededdate=June 2008}}

title: Aras River
event: Corbulo marched to Artaxata crossing the Aras River, along the valley he is shadowed by tens of thousands of mounted Parthian archers led by king Tiridates I. The city opened its gates to Corbulo, just as it had to Germanicus four decades before. When he takes the 250-year-old Armenian capital, Corbulo gives the residents a few hours to collect their valuables and burns the city to the ground.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Start of ''Yongping'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: China
event: Ming-Ti, new emperor of China, introduces Buddhism to China and the West Indus Valley.

title: Cappadocia
event: Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo, Roman commander in the east, captures Tigranocerta in Mesopotamia. He installed Tigranes VI, a Cappadocian prince, as ruler of Armenia. For the next four years, a cohort from Legio VI Ferrata and Legio X Fretensis is stationed in the capital as bodyguard to the king, supported by fifteen hundred auxiliaries.

title: London Bridge
event: Romans build the first London Bridge.

title: East Anglia
event: The Icenian chiefs are deprived of their hereditary estates, the Roman army annexed East Anglia.

title: Isle of Anglesey
event: Gaius Suetonius Paulinus, governor of Britannia, leads a campaign on the island of '''Mona''' (Anglesey).

title: Verulamium
event: Boudica sacks Londinium (London) and Verulamium (St Albans). Thousands of civilians are killed.

title: Sudan
event: Nero send an expedition to explore the historical city Meroë (Sudan).

title: Judea
event: Herod Agrippa II rules the northeast of Judea.

title: Malta
event: Paul of Tarsus journeys to Rome, but is shipwrecked at Malta. He stays for three months and converts Publius, the first Bishop of Malta.

title: Pompeii
event: 60–79 AD – House of the Vettii, Pompeii, is rebuilt.

title: Bermuda
event: Bermuda, country code 060 (ISO 3166-1 numeric)

title: Isle of Anglesey
event: The Druidic stronghold of Anglesey in north Wales is attacked and destroyed by Suetonius Paulinus (Tacitus, Annals xiv 30).

title: Verulamium
event: Verulamium (St Alban) is sacked and burnt by the Britons. Roman citizens are molested and killed.

title: Pompeii
event: A great earthquake damages cities in Campania, including Pompeii.

title: Portus
event: A violent storm destroys 200 ships in the port of Portus.

title: Naples National Archaeological Museum
event: The making of ''Still Life'', a detail of a wall painting from Herculaneum, begins (finished in 79). It is now kept at Museo Nazionale in Naples.

title: Pompeii
event: Pompeii the city at the foot of Mount Vesuvius, is heavily damaged by a strong earthquake. Fearing an eruption of the volcano, many of the 20,000 inhabitants leave their homes in a panicked flight.

title: Great Britain
event: According to legend, Joseph of Arimathea goes to Glastonbury on the first Christian mission to Britain.

title: Taxila
event: The Kushan sack the town of Taxila (in present-day Pakistan).

title: Syria (Roman province)
event: Cestius Gallus becomes legate of Syria.

title: Ephesus
event: Paul of Tarsus ordains Timothy as bishop of Ephesus (traditional date).

title: China
event: In China, the first official reference to Buddhism is made.

title: Dead Sea
event: The Sicarii capture the fortress of Masada overlooking the Dead Sea.

title: Judea
event: Cestius Gallus, legate of Syria, marched into Judea and leads a Roman army of 28,000 soldiers to put down the Jewish rebellion. Among the units are Legio III Gallica, Legio XII Fulminata and Legio XXII Primigenia.

title: Temple in Jerusalem
event: November—Gallus succeeds in conquering Beit She'arim the new city, but is unable to take the Temple in Jerusalem. He retreats to the coast, but is surrounded at Beth-Horon and nearly wiped out by the Zealots.

title: Judea
event: Province of Iudaea (Judea): Titus Flavius Vespasianus arrives in Ptolemais, along with Legio X Fretensis and Legio V Macedonica to put down the Jewish Revolt.

title: Alexandria
event: Vespasian is joined by his son Titus, who brings Legio XV Apollinaris from Alexandria. By late spring the Roman army numbers more than 60,000 soldiers, including auxiliaries and troops of king Agrippa II.

title: Greece
event: Nero travels to Greece, where he participates in the Olympic Games and other festivals.

title: Judea
event: Roman Empire. The Jewish Revolt in Judea (66–70).

title: Qumran
event: Trajan moves to Scythopolis and crosses the Jordan River with Legio X Fretensis. He lays siege to Jericho and destroys the monastery of Qumran, where the Dead Sea Scrolls are originated.

title: China
event: An iron chain suspension bridge is constructed in China.

title: Judea
event: Roman Empire: The Jewish Revolt in Judea (66–70)

title: White Horse Temple
event: Buddhism officially arrives in China with the building of the White Horse Temple.

title: Antioch
event: Ignatius of Antioch becomes the third bishop of Antioch.

title: Qumran
event: The Essenes place the Dead Sea Scrolls in the caves at Qumran.

title: Deva Victrix
event: Marcus Trebellius Maximus, governor of Britannia, is forced the flee to Gaul after a mutiny of Legio XX ''Valeria Victrix'' at Deva Victrix (Chester).

title: Fectio
event: The Batavians attack Roman forts on the Rhine frontier; Fectio and Traiectum (modern Utrecht) are destroyed.

title: Judea
event: Judea—The Jewish Revolt – Vespasian lays siege to Jerusalem, the city is captured the following year by his son Titus.

title: Judea
event: Roman Empire: The Jewish Revolt in Judea (66–70).

title: Roman Forum
event: January 15—Galba and his adopted son Piso are murdered by the Praetorian Guard on the Roman Forum.

title: Alexandria
event: July 1—Tiberius Julius Alexander orders his legions in Alexandria to swear allegiance to Vespasian as emperor.

title: Gemonian stairs
event: December 22—Vitellius is captured and murdered by the Gemonian stairs. Vespasian becomes emperor.

title: Colosseum
event: Vespasian starts the building of the Colosseum; the amphitheatre is used for gladiatorial games and public spectacles, such as sea battles, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas of Classical mythology.

title: Alexandria
event: Panic strikes Rome as adverse winds delay grain shipments  from Africa and Egypt, producing a bread shortage. Ships laden with wheat from North Africa sail 300 miles to Rome's port of Ostia in 3 days, and the 1,000 mile voyage from Alexandria averages 13 days. The vessels often carry 1,000 tons each to provide the city with 8,000 tons per week it normally consumes.

title: Rhine
event: Naval clashes on the Rhine during the Batavian Revolt; crew of a captured Roman flagship is imprisoned at Augusta Treverorum (modern Trier).

title: Samothrace
event: Annexation of the island of Samothrace by the Empire under Vespasian.

title: Sudan
event: Expedition by the Roman Septimius Flaccus to southern Egypt. He probably reaches Sudan.

title: Avignon
event: Avignon becomes the seat of a bishopric.

title: Mount of Olives
event: April 14—Siege of Jerusalem: Titus surrounds the Jewish capital, with three legions (V ''Macedonica'', XII ''Fulminata'' and XV ''Apollinaris'') on the western side and a fourth (X ''Fretensis'') on the Mount of Olives to the east. He puts pressure on the food and water supplies of the inhabitants by allowing pilgrims to enter the city to celebrate Passover and then refusing them egress.

title: Antonia Fortress
event: July 20—Titus storms the Fortress of Antonia north of the Temple Mount. The Romans are drawn into street fighting with the Zealots.

title: Yavne
event: August 4—Titus destroys the Jewish Temple in Jerusalem. Roman troops are stationed in Jerusalem and abolish the Jewish high priesthood and Sanhedrin. This becomes known as the Fall of Jerusalem, a conclusive event in the First Jewish-Roman War (the Jewish Revolt), which began in 66 AD. Following this event, the Jewish religious leadership moves from Jerusalem to Jamnia (present day Yavne), and this date is mourned annually as the Jewish fast of Tisha B'Av.

title: Great Britain
event: Battle of Stanwick: Quintus Petillius Cerialis, governor of Britain, puts down a revolt by the Brigantes.

title: Roman Forum
event: Titus is awarded with a triumph, accompanied by Vespasian and his brother Titus Flavius Domitian. In the parade are Jewish prisoners and treasures of the Temple of Jerusalem, including the Menorah and the Pentateuch. The leader of the Zealots, Simon Bar Giora, is lashed and strangled in the Forum.

title: Masada
event: Herodium, Jewish fortress south of Jerusalem, is conquered and destroyed by ''Legio X Fretensis'' on their way to Masada.

title: Dead Sea
event: First Jewish-Roman War—The Roman army (''Legio X Fretensis'') under Lucilius Bassus lay siege to the Jewish garrison of Machaerus at the Dead Sea. After they capitulate the Zealots are allowed to leave the fortress, before it is destroyed.

title: Masada
event: The Romans lay siege to Masada, a desert fortress held by Jewish victims of the Sicarii.

title: Masada
event: Spring—The Roman governor Lucius Flavius Silva lays siege to Masada, the last outpost of the Jewish rebels following the end in 70 of the First Jewish-Roman War (Jewish Revolt). The Roman army (''Legio X Fretensis)'' surrounds the mountain fortress with a 7-mile long siege wall (circumvallation) and built a rampart of stones and beaten earth against the western approach. After the citadel is conquered, 960 Zealots under the leadership of Eleazar ben Ya'ir commit mass suicide when defeat becomes imminent.

title: Main
event: Emperor Vespasian begins conquest of territory east of the upper Rhine and south of the Main. In addition, he reorganizes the defenses of the upper and lower Danube.

title: Han Dynasty
event: February—The Chinese Han Dynasty launches a major campaign against the Xiongnu, whom they confront in the Battle of Yiwulu in the Kumul oasis, an ultimate Han military victory led by General Dou Gu (d. 88).

title: Turpan
event: Chinese generals Dou Gu (Teou Kou) and Geng Bing (Keng Ping) take control of Turpan.

title: Armazi
event: Vespasian fortified Armazi (Georgia) for the Iberian king Mithridates I. The Alans raid the Roman frontier in Armenia.

title: Isca Augusta
event: Sextus  Julius Frontinus becomes governor of Britannia and make his headquarters in Isca Augusta (Wales).

title: River Usk
event: Frontinus begins his conquest of Wales, ''Legio II Augusta'' is moved to the border of the River Usk.

title: Venta Silurum
event: Caerwent is founded by the Romans as the market town of ''Venta Silurum'', a settlement of the Silures.

title: Ganzhou
event: Revolt against the Chinese in Tarim: Cachera and Turpan are besieged. Luoyang orders the evacuation of Tarim. Ban Chao makes the rebels retreat towards Khotan. At the same time, the Chinese army of Ganzhou reconquers Turpan in Northern Xiongnu. Ban Chao convinces the emperor of the need to control Central Asia in the fight against Xiongnu.

title: Isca Augusta
event: Governor Sextus Julius Frontinus subdues the Silures and other hostile tribes of Wales, establishing a fortress at Caerleon or Isca Augusta for Legio II ''Augusta'' and makes a network of smaller forts for his auxiliary forces.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of ''Jianchu'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Isle of Anglesey
event: Agricola subdues the Ordovices in Wales and pursues the remnants of the tribe to Anglesey, the holy island of the Druids.

title: Shetland
event: A Roman squadron, sent by Agricola, explores the north of Scotland for the first time, discovering the Orkney and Shetland Islands.

title: India
event: Indian Prince Aji Caka introduces the Sanskrit language and Pallawa script, used to inscribe Javanese words and phrases, to the Indonesian islands.

title: India
event: Kanishka (78–144), reigns over the Tocharian Empire of Kusana (Afghanistan and Northern India). He is a renowned conqueror and wise administrator.

title: Colosseum
event: Emperor Titus dedicates the famous Roman Colosseum.

title: Deva Victrix
event: Chester is founded as a ''castrum'' or Roman fort with the name Deva Victrix. The fortress is built by Legio II Adiutrix and contains barracks, granaries, military baths and headquarters.

title: Manchester
event: Agricola founds Mamucium, a frontier fort and settlement in the North West of England.  This was the first Manchester.

title: China
event: In China, a commission of scholars canonizes the text of works of Confucius and his school.

title: Oplontis
event: August 24—Mount Vesuvius erupts, destroying Pompeii, Herculaneum, Stabiae and Oplontis. The Roman fleet based at Misenum, commanded by Pliny the Elder, evacuates refugees but he dies after inhaling volcanic fumes.

title: Colosseum
event: Emperor Titus inaugurates the Colosseum with 100 days of games.

title: Lullingstone
event: The earliest stage of Lullingstone Roman villa is built.

title: Solway Firth
event: The Roman occupation of Britain reaches the River Tyne–Solway Firth frontier area. Gnaeus Julius Agricola creates a fleet for conquest of Caledonia, he finally proves that Britannia is an island.

title: Lindum Colonia
event: Legio II Adiutrix is stationed at Lindum Colonia (modern Lincoln). The city is an important settlement for retired Roman legionaries.

title: Pantheon Rome
event: The original Roman Pantheon is destroyed in a fire, together with many other buildings.

title: Siberia
event: Some 30,000 Asian tribespeople migrate from the steppes to the west with 40,000 horses and 100,000 cattle, joining with Iranian tribespeople and with Mongols from the Siberian forests to from a group that will be known in Europe as the Huns.

title: Arch of Titus
event: The Arch of Titus is constructed.

title: Firth of Forth
event: Gnaeus Julius Agricola raises a fleet and encircles the Celtic tribes beyond the Forth, the Caledonians rise in great numbers against the Romans. They attack the camp of Legio IX ''Hispana'' at night, but Agricola sends his cavalry in and put them to flight.

title: Italy
event: Dio Chrysostom is banished from Rome, Italy, and Bithynia after advising one of the Emperor's conspiring relatives.

title: Rhine
event: Roman emperor Domitian fights the Chatti, a Germanic tribe.  His victory allows the construction of fortifications (Limes) along the Rhine-frontier.

title: Inchtuthil
event: Inchtuthil, Roman fort built in Scotland.

title: Rhine
event: The construction of the Limes, a line of Roman fortifications from the Rhine to the Danube, is begun.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of ''Jianchu'' era to ''Yuanhe'' era of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.

title: China
event: Ban Gu (Pan Kou) and his sister Ban Zhao (Pan Tchao) compose a History of China.

title: Óbuda
event: Aquincum (old Budapest, Óbuda) is founded.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of ''Yongyuan'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Han Dynasty
event: June—The Han Chinese army under Dou Xian (d. 92), allied with the southern Xiongnu, is victorious over the Northern Xiongnu in the Battle of Ikh Bayan.

title: Capitoline Museums
event: Young Flavian Woman is made. It is now kept at Musei Capitolini, Rome (approximate date).

title: Tropaeum Traiani
event: The Iazyges, in alliance with the Quadi, crossed the Danube into Pannonia and destroyed Legio XXI ''Rapax'' at Tropaeum Traiani (Romania).

title: Curia Julia
event: Emperor Domitian rebuilds and rededicates the Curia Julia (meeting place of the Roman Senate), which had burned down in 64.

title: Colosseum
event: Manius Acilius Glabrio is commanded by Domitian to descend into the arena of the Colosseum to fight an lion. After he kills the animal, the crowd greets him with applause, but the emperor banished and put him to death.

title: Arch of Titus
event: The Arch of Titus is completed in Rome.

title: India
event: A schism in Buddhism creates a new, popular religion in India, mahâyâna (Grand Vehicle).

title: Gardens of Sallust
event: Emperor Nerva suffers a stroke during a private audience. Shortly after he dies of a fever at his villa in the Gardens of Sallust.

title: Italica
event: Trajan is the first Roman Emperor born in Italica, near Seville. A brilliant soldier and administrator, he enters Rome without ceremony and wins over the public.  Continuing the policies of Augustus, Vespasian and Nerva, he restores the Senate to its full status in the government.  He has a specific vision of the Empire, and keeps a close watch on finances. Taxes, without any increase, are sufficient during his reign to pay the considerable costs of the budget.

title: Red Sea
event: In order to maintain the Port of Alexandria, Trajan reopens the canal between the Nile and the Red Sea.

title: Timgad
event: Timgad (Thamugas), a Roman colonial town in North Africa is founded by Trajan.

title: Italy
event: Trajan creates a policy intended to restore the former economic supremacy of Italy.

title: Ohio
event: The Hopewell tradition begins in what is now Ohio circa this date.

title: Teotihuacan
event: Teotihuacan, at the center of Mexico, reaches a population of 50,000.

title: China
event: The Temple of the God of Medicine is built in Anguo, China.

title: Portus
event: The port of Portus is enlarged.

title: China
event: Having organised the territories of the Tarim basin, Chinese general Ban Chao retires to Luoyang, and dies shortly thereafter.

title: India
event: The presence of sugar in the urine is interpreted as a sign of illness in India.

title: Vienna
event: Legio X ''Gemina'' moves to Vienna, where it remains until the 5th century.

title: Tagus
event: Trajan gives the order to have the Alcántara Bridge built over the Tagus River at Alcántara (Hispania), constructed by the architect '''Lacer'''.

title: Trajan's Bridge
event: Apollodorus of Damascus builds a stone bridge over the Danube more than 1,000 meters (3,280 ft) long, almost 20 meters high (65 ft) and 15 meters wide (49 ft). The bridge connects what is now Serbia with Romania (at the time known as Dacia).

title: India
event: In India, figures of Buddha replace abstract motifs on decorative items.

title: Aquincum
event: Emperor Trajan starts the second expedition against Dacia, he leaves with the Imperial Roman fleet from Brundusium. Permanent ''castrum'' of Legio II Adiutrix at Aquincum (modern Budapest) in Pannonia.

title: Kerak
event: The Romans conquer Kerak from the Nabateans.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Emperor He Di dies after a 17-year reign in which court eunuchs and the emperor's in-laws have regained influence. Empress Deng Sui placed her son Shang Di (barely 3 months old) on the throne, as the fifth emperor of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.

title: China
event: Papermaking is refined by the Chinese eunuch Cai Lun, who receives official praise from the emperor for his methods of making paper from tree bark, hemp, remnant rags and fishnets. Paper had been made in China from the 2nd century BC, but Cai Lun's paper provides a far superior writing surface than pure silk and is much less costly to produce. Bamboo and wooden slips, will remain the usual materials for books and scrolls in most of the world for another 200 years, and paper will remain a Chinese secret for 500 years.

title: Constantine's Bridge (Danube)
event: The Trajan Bridge is finished. For more than a thousand years, it is the longest arch bridge in the world to have been built, in terms of both total and span length.Constantine's Bridge, a little-known structure whose length is given with 2437 m ({{harvnbTudor1974bp=139}}; {{harvnbGalliazzo1994p=319}}).<

title: Sarmizegetusa Regia
event: Emperor Trajan conquers the Dacian Fortresses of the Orăştie Mountains and surrounds the capital, Sarmisegetusa. The Dacians are defeated in the Battle of Sarmisegetusa, the city is encircled with a circumvallation line. When the Romans destroyed the water pipes, king Decebalus flees and commits suicide. Dacia (Romania) becomes a Roman province, the veterans of the legions are given land for their service in the Roman army.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of Han Hedi to Han Shangdi of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty. First and the only year of ''yanping'' era.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of Han Shangdi to Han Andi of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.

title: India
event: An Indian ambassador is received by Trajan.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of ''yongchu'' era of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.

title: China
event: Han Andi (An-ti, Ngan-ti), a young man, becomes emperor of China, giving power to Empress Deng Sui.

title: Burma
event: Bagan (in present-day Burma) is founded by Thamudarit.

title: Domus Aurea
event: The Baths of Trajan built by the architect Apollodorus of Damascus are dedicated during the ''Kalends''. The ''thermae'' are constructed on the platform of the Palace of Nero (Domus Aurea).

title: Parthian Empire
event: Osroes I of Parthia succeeds his brother Pacorus II and rules over the western Parthian Empire.

title: Lake Bracciano
event: June 24—The Aqua Traiana is inaugurated by emperor Trajan, the aqueduct channels water from Lake Bracciano, 40 kilometers (25 miles) north-west of Rome.

title: Trajan's Forum
event: The Forum of Trajan is constructed in Rome by the Syrian architect Apollodorus of Damascus.

title: Wallace Collection
event: Arno & Plastic Wallace Collection

title: Anatolia
event: Publius Cornelius Tacitus is Governor of the Roman province of Asia, Anatolia.

title: Colosseum
event: Trajan builds Trajan's Column near the Colosseum in Rome to commemorate his victory over the Dacians in the Second Dacian War.

title: Basilica Ulpia
event: Basilica Ulpia is dedicated.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Last (7th) year of ''Yongchu'' era of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of ''Yuanchu'' era of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.

title: Ctesiphon
event: Trajan captures the Parthian capital of Ctesiphon.

title: Judea
event: Jews in Egypt and Cyrene ignite a revolt (Kitos War) against the rule of the Roman Empire, which spreads to Cyprus, Judea, and the Roman province of Mesopotamia.

title: Memphis Egypt
event: Alexandria in Egypt is destroyed during the Jewish-Greek civil wars. Marcus Rutilius Lupus, the Roman governor, sends Legio XXII Deiotariana to protect the inhabitants of Memphis.

title: Eboracum
event: A revolt breaks out in Britain; the garrison at Eboracum (York) is massacred.

title: Antioch
event: An earthquake destroys Apamea and Antioch in Syria. The local bishop is held responsible (he will be martyred and remembered as St. Ignatius).

title: Susa
event: Emperor Trajan completes his invasion of Parthia by capturing the cities of Seleucia, Babylon, Ctesiphon and Susa, marking the high-water mark of the Roman Empire's eastern expansion.

title: Persian Gulf
event: Trajan makes Syria a province of Rome and crosses the Tigris to annex Adiabene. He proceeds with his army to the Persian Gulf and conquers territory that becomes the province of Parthia.

title: Judea
event: Trajan sends two expeditionary forces. One, consisting of elements of Legio III Cyrenaica, to suppress the revolt in Judea and the other Legio VII Claudia to restore order on Cyprus.

title: Alexandria
event: Quintus Marcius Turbo sailes to Alexandria and defeates the Jews in several pitched battles.

title: Pantheon Rome
event: Construction begins on the Pantheon in Rome.

title: Italy
event: August 9—Emperor Trajan dies of a stroke at Selinus in Cilicia, age 63, while en route from Mesopotamia to Italy. Leaving the Roman Empire at its maximal territorial extent.

title: Basilica Ulpia
event: The Roman Forum commissioned by the late Emperor Trajan is completed with triumphal arches, columns, a market complex, and an enormous basilica that all of which replace hundreds of dwellings.

title: Pantheon Rome
event: Pantheon, in Rome, is started to built (approximate date).

title: Hadrian's Villa
event: 118–128 – Battle of Centaurs and Wild Beasts, from Hadrian's Villa, Tivoli, Italy, is made (approximate date). It may be a copy of painting done by the late-5th century BC Greek artist Zeuxis. It is now kept at Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Preussischer Kulturbesitz, Antikensammlung.

title: Sichuan
event: The oldest known painted depiction of a wheelbarrow is found in a Chinese tomb of Chengde, Sichuan province, dated to this year.

title: Eboracum
event: Emperor Hadrian stations Legio VI ''Victrix'' in Roman Britain, to assist in quelling the resistance of a local rebellion. The legion is a key in securing the victory, and eventually replaced Legio IX ''Hispana'' at Eboracum.

title: India
event: Reign in Northern India by Nahapana, Scythian king. He attacks the kingdom of Andhra and annexes Southern Rajputana.

title: Foss Dyke
event: Foss Dyke is constructed in Britain.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of era name from ''Yuanchu'' (7th year) to ''Yongning'' of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.

title: India
event: The Scythians dominate western India: Punjab, Sind, the north of Gujerat and a portion of central India.

title: Solway Firth
event: Emperor Hadrian fixes the border between Roman Britain and Caledonia on a line running from the River Tyne to the Solway Firth.

title: Temple of Venus and Roma
event: Construction of the Temple of Venus and Roma begins in Rome.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Era name changes from ''Yongning'' (2nd year) to ''Jianguang'' in the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.

title: Hadrian's Wall
event: Emperor Hadrian orders that a 73-mile (117-kilometer) wall be built to mark the northern Roman Empire. Hadrian's Wall, as it comes to be known, is intended to keep the Caledonians, Picts and other tribes at bay.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of era name from ''Jianguang'' (2nd year) to ''Yanguang'' of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.

title: Hadrian's Wall
event: Housesteads Fort is constructed on Hadrian's Wall north of Bardon Mill.

title: Hadrian's Villa
event: Hadrian's Villa at Tivoli is built.

title: China
event: In China, Ban Yong, son of Ban Chao, reestablishes the Chinese control over the Tarim Basin.

title: Greece
event: During a voyage to Greece, Hadrian is initiated in the ancient rites known as the  Eleusinian Mysteries.

title: India
event: In northern India, Nahapana, king of the Scythians, is defeated and dies in battle while fighting against King Andhra Gautamiputra Satakarni. This defeat destroys the Scythian dynasty of Ksaharâtas.

title: Pantheon Rome
event: The Pantheon is constructed in (Rome) as it stands today by Hadrian.

title: Hadrian's Villa
event: Hadrian's Villa, Tivoli, Italy, is started to be built (approximate date).

title: Italy
event: Plague sweeps North Africa in the wake of a locust invasion that destroys large areas of cropland. The plague kills as many as 500,000 in Numidia and possibly 150,000 on the coast before moving to Italy, where it takes so many lives that villages and towns are abandoned.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Last (4th) year of the ''Yanguang'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: India
event: Gautamiputra Satakarni, a king of the Andhra dynasty, destroys the kingdom of Maharashtra near Bombay. He now controls central India from coast to coast.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of the ''Yongjian'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Aurès Mountains
event: Emperor Hadrian visits the Roman province of North Africa, in order to inspect Legio III ''Augusta'' stationed at Lambaesis. For strategic reasons the legionnaires are located in the Aurès Mountains.

title: Hadrian's Wall
event: Hadrian's Wall is completed in Britain. Built mostly of stone in the east and with a wooden  palisade in the west.
