They construct at least 16 forts, about 15,000 legionaries digging ditches, quarrying rock and cutting stone, preventing idleness which led to unrest and rebellions in the ranks.

title: Greece
event: Hadrian begins his inspection of the provinces of Greece, Asia Minor and Egypt.

title: Pantheon Rome
event: Pantheon, Rome is finished.

title: Cappadocia
event: Emperor Hadrian continues his voyages, now inspecting Caria, Cappadocia and Syria.

title: Temple of Olympian Zeus (Athens)
event: The Temple of Olympian Zeus is completed at Athens.

title: Hadrian's Villa
event: Canopus, Hadrian's Villa, Tivoli, Italy, is started to be built.

title: Hadrian's Gate
event: The Hadrian's Gate in Antalya (Turkey) is constructed, Hadrian visits the city.

title: India
event: Huviska becomes king of the Kushan Empire in India.

title: Basra
event: Basra becomes the capital of Arabia.

title: Arch of Constantine
event: c. 130–138 – Hadrian Hunting Boar and Sacrificing to Apollo, sculptural reliefs on the Arch of Constantine, Rome, are made.

title: Hadrian's Villa
event: c. 130–138 – Antinous, from Hadrian's Villa at Tivoli, Italy, is made. It is now kept at Museo Gregoriano Egizio, Rome.

title: Aelia Capitolina
event: Emperor Hadrian builds the city Aelia Capitolina on the location of Jerusalem.

title: Italy
event: Italy is divided into legal districts managed by consuls, a direct blow to the power and prestige of the Senate.

title: Temple of Olympian Zeus (Athens)
event: The Temple of Olympian Zeus (Athens) is completed using Cossutius' design.

title: Judea
event: The messianic, charismatic Jewish leader Simon bar Kokhba starts a war of liberation for Judea (Bar Kokhba revolt) against the Romans, which is eventually crushed (in 135) by emperor Hadrian. Rabbi Akiva is supportive of the rebellion.

title: Hadrian's Wall
event: Merchants in Britain build structures outside the forts of Hadrian's Wall and offer goods and services (including brothels) to Roman soldiers, who receive salaries in a region that otherwise has virtually no ready money.

title: Castel Sant'Angelo
event: Construction begins on the Mausoleum of Hadrian in Rome, today known as Castel Sant'Angelo.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of era name from ''Yongjian'' (7th year) to ''Yangjia'' of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Judea
event: Sextus Julius Severus, governor of Britain, is sent to Judea (from 136 renamed Syria Palaestina) to quell a revolt.

title: Judea
event: Roman Empire. The Bar Kokhba revolt in Judea (132–135).

title: Cappadocia
event: Arrianus, Roman governor of Cappadocia, repulses an attack of the Alani, a nomadic tribe from southeastern Russia.

title: Judea
event: Sextus Julius Severus, governor of Judea, begins in the summer an campaign against the Jewish rebel strongholds in the mountains.

title: Aelia Capitolina
event: The Romans retake Jerusalem. The largely destroyed city is renamed Aelia Capitolina.

title: Hadrian's Villa
event: Hadrian's Villa in Tivoli, Italy is completed.

title: Judea
event: The Bar Kokhba revolt ends and, with it, Judean independence. Simon bar Kokhba is killed after 13 December in Betar, the fortress in which he had taken refuge. Resistance continues in Galilee.

title: Mediterranean Sea
event: A Jewish ''diaspora'' begins as emperor Hadrian bars Jews from Jerusalem and has survivors of the massacre dispersed across the Roman Empire. Many pour into Mediterranean ports, to be sold into slavery.

title: Calvary
event: Jerusalem is renamed ''Colonia Aelia Capitolina'', in honor of Hadrian. Legio VI ''Ferrata'' rebuilts the legionary fortress in the city and constructs a Roman temple at Golgotha.

title: Temple in Jerusalem
event: An altar to Jupiter is erected on the site of the Temple in Jerusalem.

title: Hadrian's Villa
event: Canopus, Hadrian's Villa, Tivoli, Italy, is finished.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Last (4th) year of ''Yangjia'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Judea
event: The Roman province of Iudaea (plus Galilee) becomes Syria Palaestina, the first use of the name Palestine as a designation for Judea.

title: Hadrian's Villa
event: Hadrian dictates his memoirs at his villa near Tivoli (Tibur) outside Rome.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of ''Yonghe'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Mediterranean Sea
event: Tax laws are passed for trade in Palmyra.  The caravan city grows rich by importing rare products from the Persian Gulf, and by exporting items manufactured by the Mediterranean world to the East.

title: Amman
event: Construction begins on the Theater of Philadelphia (Amman).

title: Hadrian's Villa
event: Hadrian's Villa, Tivoli, Italy, is finished.

title: Baiae
event: July 10—Hadrian dies after a heart failure at Baiae, he is buried at Rome in the Gardens of Domitia beside his wife, Vibia Sabina.

title: Castel Sant'Angelo
event: The Tomb of Hadrian in Rome is completed, emperor Antoninus Pius cremates the body of Hadrian and placed his ashes together with that of his wife Vibia Sabina and his adopted son, Lucius Aelius in the mausoleum.

title: Parthian Empire
event: King Mithridates IV dies, Vologases III claims the throne and extened his rule through the Parthian Empire.

title: Temple of Antoninus and Faustina
event: The Temple of Antoninus and Faustina is constructed in Rome, the temple is dedicated to Faustina the Elder.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Last (6th) year of ''Yonghe'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Firth of Forth
event: Emperor Antoninus Pius  orders the construction of the Antonine Wall. The wall stretch 39 miles (63 km) from Old Kilpatrick in West Dunbartonshire on the Firth of Clyde to Carriden near Bo'ness on the Firth of Forth (Scotland). The Romans built nineteen forts and smaller fortlets (milecastles), to protect the border against the Caledonians.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of the ''Hanan'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of era name from ''Hanan'' (3rd year) to Jiankang era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of emperor from Han Shundi to Han Chongdi of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of era name from Jiankang (1st year) to ''Yongxi'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of emperor from Han Chongdi to Han Zhidi of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: India
event: Ajmere, India is founded.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of era name from ''Yongxi'' (1st year) to ''Benchu'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of emperor from Han Zhidi to Han Huandi of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Parthian Empire
event: King Vologases IV, son of Mithridates IV of Parthia,  unites under his rule the Parthian Empire.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of ''Jianhe'' of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: China
event: An Shih Kao arrives in China.

title: Voorburg
event: The Roman town Forum Hadriani (Voorburg) receives the title of ''Municipium Aelium Cananefatium'', the town of the Cananefates (modern Netherlands). The town is awarded with rights to organize markets.

title: Black Sea
event: The Germans of the east move south, into the Carpathians and Black Sea area.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First and only year of ''Heping''{{Clarifydate=June 2010}} of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Teotihuacan
event: The Great Pyramid of the Sun is constructed in Teotihuacan.  It is the tallest pre-Columbian building in the Americas.

title: China
event: Paper, made in China, arrives in Turkestan.

title: İzmir
event: Mytilene and Smyrna are destroyed by an earthquake.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of Yuanjia of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Shandong
event: Detail from a rubbing of a stone relief in Wu family shrine (Wuliangci), Jiaxiang, Shandong, is made. Han dynasty.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of era name from ''Yuanjia'' (3rd year) to ''Yongxing'' of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Bosporan Kingdom
event: The king of Bosphorus, Eupator, pays tribute to Rome due to the threat posed by the Alani.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Last (2nd) year of ''Yongxing'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Hadrian's Wall
event: The Romans begin to abandon Hadrian's Wall.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of ''Yongshou'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of era name from ''Yongshou'' to ''Yangxi'' of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: India
event: In India, the reign of Shivashri Satakarni as King Satavahana of Andhra begins.

title: China
event: The first Buddhist monks arrive in China.

title: India
event: Arrian publishes Indica, a work on India and its people.

title: Ctesiphon
event: Ctesiphon is captured by the Romans, but returned to the Parthians after the end of the war.

title: Antonine Wall
event: The Antonine Wall in Scotland is abandoned by the Romans.

title: Ctesiphon
event: A Roman military operation under Avidius Cassius is successful against Parthia, capturing Artaxata, Seleucia on the Tigris, and Ctesiphon. The Parthians sue for peace.

title: Persian Gulf
event: The Romans establish a garrison at Doura Europos on the Euphrates, a control point for the commercial route to the Persian Gulf.

title: Han Dynasty
event: A Roman envoy arrives by sea in Rinan commandery in southern China (central Vietnam). He travels to the Chinese capital Luoyang and is greeted by Emperor Huan of the Han Dynasty.

title: China
event: Scholars who have denounced eunuchs are arrested, killed or banished from the capital and official life in Han Dynasty China. This was the first of the Disasters of Partisan Prohibitions, which ended in 184.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of era name from ''Yanxi'' to ''Yongkang'' of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Carnuntum
event: The Roman army crosses the Alps into Pannonia and subdue the Marcomanni at Carnuntum north of the Danube.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Change of Han Huandi to Han Lingdi of Han Dynasty; first year of ''Jianning'' era.

title: Carnuntum
event: The Suebian tribes of the Marcomanni cross the Danube and invade northern Italy. The Roman army (20,000 men) is destroyed near Carnuntum.

title: Sirmium
event: Emperor Marcus Aurelius writes in Sirmium (Pannonia) his first of 12 books of the ''Meditations'' in Koine Greek.

title: Equestrian Statue of Marcus Aurelius
event: An Equestrian Statue of Marcus Aurelius is erected in Rome.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Last (5th) year of ''Jianning'' era and start of ''Xiping'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: India
event: Reign in India of Yajnashri Satakarni, Satavahana king of the Andhra. He extends his empire from the center to the north of India.

title: Heerlen
event: M. Sattonius Iucundus, decurio in Colonia Ulpia Traiana, restores the Thermae of Coriovallum (modern Heerlen ) there are sources that state this happened in the 3rd century.

title: China
event: Confucian scholars try to ensure their capacity in the royal court of China.  They are massacred by the eunuchs.

title: Capitoline Museums
event: Equestrian Statue of Marcus Aurelius is made. It is now kept at Museo Capitolini in Rome (approximate date).

title: Carnuntum
event: Emperor Marcus Aurelius and his son Commodus arrive at Carnuntum in Pannonia, and travel to the Danube to fight against the Marcomanni.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Last (7th) year of ''Xiping'' era and start of ''Guanghe'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: Abgar IX the Great becomes King of Edessa.

title: Goguryeo
event: Gogukcheon succeeds his father Shindae as King of Goguryeo.

title: China
event: Han Dynasty China – the full title of the ''Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art'' appears on two bronze standard measures dated to this year, yet there is speculation that the same book existed beforehand only under different titles. In the 3rd century, Liu Hui would provide commentary on this important early Chinese mathematical treatise.

title: Column of Marcus Aurelius
event: Work begins in Rome on the building of the Column of Marcus Aurelius.

title: Porta Nigra
event: Porta Nigra is built in Germanian Trier.

title: Black Sea
event: The Goths reach the banks of the Black Sea.

title: China
event: This year is often suggested as the first year of the Three Kingdoms period of China.

title: Lake Taupo
event: Lake Taupo erupts, forming ash clouds as far as China and Europe.

title: Vienna
event: March 17—Emperor Marcus Aurelius dies after a week's illness at his camp in Vindobona (modern Vienna). He is succeeded by his son Commodus (age 18).

title: Carthage
event: July 17—Twelve inhabitants of Scillium in Numidia are executed in Carthage (also in North Africa) for being Christians (known as the Scillitan Martyrs)—they had refused to swear an oath to the Emperor.

title: Antonine Wall
event: The Antonine Wall is overrun in Britannia.

title: China
event: The volcano associated with Lake Taupo in New Zealand erupts, one of the largest on Earth in the last 5,000 years. The effects of this eruption are seen as far away as Rome and China.

title: Capri
event: Emperor Commodus escapes death at the hands of assassins, who have attacked him at the instigation of his sister Lucilla and a large group of senators. He puts many distinguished Romans to death on charges of being implicated in the conspiracy, Lucilla is exiled to Capri.

title: Antonine Wall
event: The Antonine Wall in Britannia is permanently abandoned.

title: China
event: The Yellow Turban Rebellion and Liangzhou Rebellion break out in China.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Zhang Jiao leads the peasant revolt against Emperor Lingdi of the Han Dynasty. Heading for the capital of Luoyang, his massive and undisciplined army (360,000 men), burns and destroys government offices and outposts.

title: Yellow River
event: June—Emperor Lingdi placed his brother-in-law, He Jin, in command of the imperial army and sends Liu Bei to defeat the rebel forces in Runan. The army surrounds the rebels near the Yellow River and around Nanyang.

title: China
event: King Gogukcheon of Goguryeo repels Han Dynasty China's invasion force, sent by the governor of Liaodong.

title: Circus (building)
event: Emperor Commodus drains Rome's treasury to put on gladiatorial spectacles and confiscates property to support his pleasures. He participated as a gladiator and boasts of victory in 1,000 matches in the Circus Maximus.

title: India
event: Reign in India of Vasudeva, Kushan emperor.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Zhi Yao, a Kushan Buddhist monk of Yuezhi ethnicity, translates Buddhist texts into the Chinese language during the Han Dynasty.

title: Hebei
event: February—The rebels of the Yellow Turban are defeated by the imperial army, but only two months later, the rebellion breaks out again. It spreads to the Taihang Mountains on the western border of Hebei Province.

title: Lake Taupo
event: The Hatepe volcanic eruption extends Lake Taupo and makes skies red across the world.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Zhang Ju and Zhang Chun are defeated by Han forces under Liu Yu.

title: Han Dynasty
event: The Prince of Hongnong succeeds Emperor Ling as Chinese emperor of the Han Dynasty.

title: India
event: Pantaenus, who was sent by the bishop of Alexandria to India to preach Christianity, meets with little success.

title: Simplon Pass
event: A Roman road crosses the Alps by the Simplon Pass.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of the ''Chuping'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Xi'an
event: Luoyang is burned and plundered by the forces of Dong Zhuo. The court is moved to Xi'an.

title: Parthian Empire
event: Osroes II controlling Media claims the throne of the Parthian Empire. King Vologases IV of Parthia puts down the rebellion and restores order.

title: Xi'an
event: Chinese warlords formes a coalition force and launches a punitive campaign against Chancellor Dong Zhuo. He forced Emperor Xian to move to Chang'an (modern Xi'an) and burns the capital Luoyang.

title: Esquiline Hill
event: c. 191–192 – Commodus as Hercules, from Esquiline Hill, Rome, is made. It is now kept at Palazzo dei Conservatori, Rome.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Lü Bu murders his stepfather Dong Zhuo, Chancellor of the Han Dynasty.

title: India
event: Syrian Christians establish a Christian community in Kerala, India.

title: Hadrian's Wall
event: British tribes take advantage of the disorder by the civil war and damage Hadrian's Wall. Extensive repairs to the defence work is carried out by the legionaries.

title: Battle of Nicaea
event: Septimius Severus defeats the army under Pescennius at the Battle of Cyzicus and Battle of Nicaea (Asia Minor).

title: Han Dynasty
event: Last (4th) year of ''Chuping'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Antioch
event: Battle of Issus: Emperor Septimius Severus marches with his army (12 legions) to Cilicia and defeats Pescennius Niger, governor of Syria. He retreats to Antioch and  is executed by Severus' troops.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of ''Xingping'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Parthian Empire
event: King Vologases V and other eastern princes support the claims of Pescennius Niger. The province of Mesopotamia rises in revolt with Parthian support. Severus travels to Mesopotamia to battle the Parthians.

title: Nusaybin
event: The province of Syria is divided and the role of Antioch is diminished. The Romans annexed the Syrian city's Edessa and Nisibis (modern Turkey). Severus re-establish his headquarters and colonies there.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Last (2nd) year of ''Xingping'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Shanxi
event: In China, the Xiongnu Federation crosses the Great Wall and establishes itself in Shanxi province.

title: Han Dynasty
event: First year of ''Jianan'' era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

title: Lugdunum
event: 19 February—Battle of Lugdunum: Emperor Septimius Severus defeats the self-proclaimed emperor Decimus Clodius Albinus at Lugdunum (modern Lyon). Albinus commits suicide, legionaries sack the town.

title: Tigris
event: Septimius Severus forms new naval units, manning all the triremes in Italy with heavily armed troops for war in the East. Soldiers embarked on a artificial canal between the Tigris and Euphrates.

title: Ctesiphon
event: The Roman army marched east to repel a Parthian invasion of Mesopotamia, they loot the royal palace at Ctesiphon and captures an enormous number of its inhabitants as slaves.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: A Christian council is held in Edessa.

title: Hatra
event: Emperor Septimius Severus captures the city-state Hatra in Central-Mesopotamia.

title: Korea
event: Geodeung succeeds Suro as king of the Korean kingdom of Gaya (traditional date).

title: India
event: Rudrasena I, Saka ruler of the Western Satrap dynasty, becomes king of Malwa in ancient India.

title: Korea
event: Empress Jingu sends a Japanese fleet to invade Korea. The Koreans capitulate at sight of the huge multi-oared ships and offer tribute.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: November—A flood in Edessa destroys a Christian church, killing over 2,000 people.

title: Biskra
event: Severus launches a campaign in Africa, Legio III ''Augusta'' under Quintus Anicius Faustus fights a guerrilla war against the Garamantes along the Limes Tripolitanus. They capture several settlements such as Cydamus, Gholaia and their capital Garama, 600 km south of Lepcis Magna. The province of Numidia is enlarged: the Romans annexed Castellum Dimmidi, Gemellae and Vescera.

title: Pantheon Rome
event: The Pantheon is restored.

title: Cappadocia
event: In order to avoid Septimus Severus' persecution of Christians, Clement of Alexandria seeks refuge with Alexander in Cappadocia.

title: Roman Forum
event: An arch dedicated to Severus is erected near the Forum.

title: India
event: Reign in India of Vijaya, Satavahana king of the Andhra.

title: Alexandria
event: Origen of Alexandria replaces Clement as the head of the Christian school in Alexandria.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: The Daysan River floods Edessa.

title: Korea
event: Gongsun Kang, a Chinese warlord of Liaodong, establishes the Daifang Commandery in northern Korea.

title: Hadrian's Wall
event: Hadrian's Wall is restored, after heavy raids by Caledonian tribes had overrun much of northern Britain.

title: Antonine Wall
event: Emperor Septimius Severus leads an expedition (20,000 men) in Britannia, crosses Hadrian's Wall and moves through eastern Scotland. The Roman army pushes the Caledonians back to the River Tay and Severus signs an peace treaty. He repairs the Antonine Wall (his repairs are sometimes called the Severan Wall).

title: London
event: Britain is divided in the north, Lower Britain (Britannia Inferior) administered from the fortress at Eburacum (modern York), and in the south, Upper Britain (Britannia Superior) controlled by the legions at Deva Victrix and Isca Augusta, with its capital at Londinium (London).

title: Estakhr
event: Ardashir I, ruler of Istakhr (Persia), revolts against his brother and founds the Sassanid dynasty.

title: Battle of Red Cliffs
event: Zhou Yu and Liu Bei defeat Cao Cao at the Battle of Red Cliffs; along with the Battle of Yamen and Battle of Lake Poyang, this is one of the largest naval battles in China's history.

title: India
event: In India, beginning of the reign of Chandashri, Satavahana king of the Andhra.

title: Eboracum
event: Eboracum (modern York) becomes the capital of Britannia Inferior, a northern province of the Roman Empire.

title: Baths of Caracalla
event: Baths of Caracalla are started to be built (approximate date).

title: Baths of Caracalla
event: Construction begins on the Baths of Caracalla in Rome.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: Edessa becomes a Roman province.

title: Main
event: Emperor Caracalla leaves Rome and expels some German marauders from Gaul. He defends the northern Rhine frontier against the Alamanni and the Chatti. Caracalla wins a victory over the German tribes on the banks of the River Main, and gives himself the title Germanicus. It is probably while campaigning in Germania that he takes a liking to the ''caracalla'', a Celtic or German tunic from which he acquire the name by which he is known.

title: Korea
event: The Korean kingdom of Baekje attacks the Mohe tribes.

title: Baths of Caracalla
event: The Baths of Caracalla in Rome are completed with public baths (''Thermae''), reading rooms, auditoriums, running tracks, and public gardens that cover 20 acres.

title: Tigris
event: Caracalla provokes a war with Artabanus IV of Parthia to imitate his idol Alexander the Great. He crosses the Tigris, destroyes towns and spoiles the tombs of Arbela. The Roman army annexed Armenia.

title: Nusaybin
event: Summer—Battle of Nisibis: The Roman army under command of Macrinus, is defeated in an three days battle by the Parthians at Nisibis (southern Turkey).

title: Colosseum
event: The Colosseum is badly damaged by fire (lightning) which destroyes the wooden upper levels of the amphitheater.

title: Zeugma (city)
event: Diadumenianus, son of Macrinus, escapes to the Parthian court, but is captured at Zeugma and also put to death.

title: Cappadocia
event: June 8—Battle of Antioch: Elagabalus defeats with support of the Syrian legions the forces of Macrinus. He flees, but is captured near Chalcedon and later executed in Cappadocia.

title: India
event: The reign of Pulona, Satavahana king of Andhra, begins in India.

title: Battle of Mount Dingjun
event: The Battle of Mount Dingjun ends with Liu Bei emerging victorious. He declares himself king of Hanzhong afterwards.

title: Sichuan
event: General Cao Cao controls the Huang He basin and north of the country. General Sun Quan seizes southernmost China.  Liu Bei controls the province of Sichuan.

title: India
event: An Indian delegation visits the Roman emperor Elagabalus.

title: Persepolis
event: King Ardashir I, founder of the Sassanid Dynasty, gains support from some Parthian sub-kings and revolts against the rule of Vologases VI. Ardashir, a grandson of Sasan, rules Persis since 208 and six years ago gained control of the region surrounding of Persepolis.

title: Han Dynasty
event: Three Kingdoms: The northern part of China is under the control of Cao Cao, Imperial Chancellor and ruler of the Kingdom of Wei. When he dies his son Cao Pi succeeds to the throne and proclaims himself emperor of Wei. This symbolizing the end of the Han Dynasty, former emperor Han Xiandi is renamed Duke of Shanyang.

title: Sichuan
event: Liu Bei, Chinese warlord and descendant of the royal family of the Han Dynasty, proclaims himself emperor in Sichuan and establish the Kingdom of Shu Han. Three kingdoms arise – the Wei in the north, the Wu in the south and the Shu Han in the west.

title: China
event: Three Kingdoms: Kingdom of Wu is established in China. Emperor Liu Bei invades with a army (100,000 men) the border of Eastern Wu in the Battle of Yiling to retake the Jing province. However, because of a tactical mistake, Liu Bei's military camps are destroyed by forces of Sun Quan.

title: Trastevere
event: October 14—Pope Callixtus I is killed by a mob in Rome's Trastevere after a 5-year reign in which he has stabilized the Saturday fast three times per year, with no food, oil, or wine to be consumed on those days. Callixtus is succeeded by cardinal Urban I.

title: Baidicheng
event: Three Kingdoms: Emperor Liu Bei of the Shu Han becomes ill and dies at Baidicheng. He is succeeded by his son, Liu Shan. Imperial Chancellor, Zhuge Liang, makes peace with the Wu Empire.

title: Shushtar
event: King Ardashir I defeats Artabanus IV at Hormizdegan (modern Shushtar), destroying the Parthian Empire and establishing the Sassanid dynasty. Artabanus's brother Vologases VI will continue to rule with Armenian and Kushan support over outlying parts of Parthia.

title: China
event: A merchant from the Roman Empire called Qin Lun by the Chinese, arrives in Jiaozhi (modern Hanoi) and is taken to see Sun Quan, king of Eastern Wu, who requests him to make a report on his native country and people. He is given an escort for the return trip including a present of ten male and ten female blackish-coloured dwarfs. However, the officer in charge of the Chinese escort dies and Qin Lun has to continue his journey home alone.

title: Ireland
event: Ireland—The rule of High King Cormac mac Airt begins (approximate).

title: Libya
event: Roman Empire—Seius Sallustius is executed for the attempted murder of his son-in-law Emperor Alexander Severus. Sallustius' daughter, as well Alexander's wife, Sallustia Orbiana, is exiled in Libya.

title: Persian Gulf
event: King Ardashir I, ruler of Persia, annexes his new empire from the east to the northwest. He conquers with his army the provinces of Chorasmia, Sistan and the island Bahrain in the Persian Gulf. The kings of the Kushan Empire and Turan recognise Ardashir as their overlord.

title: China
event: The Battle of Jieting and the Battle of Shiting are fought in China.

title: Nanjing
event: Sun Quan formally declares himself emperor of the Kingdom of Wu. Jiankang (modern Nanjing) is founded, the independent kingdoms in Cambodia and Laos become Eastern Wu vassals.

title: Taiwan
event: Wu merchants reached Vietnam, ocean transport is improved to an extent that sea journeys are made to Manchuria and the island of Taiwan.

title: Cappadocia
event: King Ardashir I, ruler of the Persia, invades the Roman province of Mesopotamia and unsuccessfully besiege the fortress town of Nisibis (Turkey). His army threatens the border outposts of Syria and Cappadocia.

title: Antioch
event: Alexander Severus assembled the Roman army and establish his headquarters at Antioch. He makes an attempt for diplomatic solutions, but the Persians decline and choose for war.

title: Ctesiphon
event: Roman–Persian Wars: Emperor Alexander Severus launches a three-pronged counterattack against the Persian forces of king Ardashir I, who have invaded Mesopotamia. However, the Roman army advancing through Armenia is halted. Alexander gives the order to march to the capital at Ctesiphon, but the Romans are defeated and withdraw to Syria. The result is a acceptance of the ''status quo'' and after heavy losses on both sides, a truce is signed.

title: India
event: Relics of St. Thomas are brought to Edessa from India.

title: Rhine
event: Emperor Alexander Severus celebrates a triumph in Rome to observe his victory last year over the Persians. He is soon summoned to the Rhine frontier, where the Alamanni invades Swabia. German tribes destroying Roman forts and plunder the countryside at the ''Limes Germanicus''.

title: Rhine
event: Emperor Alexander Severus and his mother Julia Mamaea move to Moguntiacum (modern Mainz), the capital of Germania Superior. His generals planned an military offensive and built a bridge across the Rhine. Alexander prefers to negotiates for peace by buying off the Alemanni. This policy outrage the Roman legions and he lost his trust by the troops.

title: Sirmium
event: Maximinus campaigns against Dacians and Sarmatians from his supply depot at Sirmium.

title: Rhine
event: Emperor Maximinus Thrax campaings on the rivers Danube and Rhine in Germania, defeating the Alemanni and never visits Rome. He is accepted by the Roman Senate, but taxes the rich aristocracy heavily and engenders such hostility among them that they plot against him.

title: Italy
event: Maximinus advances to the town Aquileia in northern Italy, his army suffers from famine and disease, while the city is besieged. Soldiers of Legio II ''Parthica'' killed him in his tent, along with his son Maximinus (who is appointed co-emperor). Their corpses are decapitated and their heads carried to Rome.

title: Colosseum
event: The Colosseum is restored after being damaged.

title: Anatolia
event: The Goths, coming from Ukraine, cross the Danube and devastate the Roman Empire up to the border with Anatolia.

title: Taiwan
event: A Chinese expeditionary force discovers the island of Taiwan.

title: Rhine
event: The Roman Empire is threatned on several fronts at the same time.  Africa revolts and tribes in northwest Germania, under the name of the Franks, are raiding the Rhine frontier.

title: Hatra
event: Ardashir I, Sassanid king of Persia, destroys Hatra.

title: Ctesiphon
event: At the court of Ardashir I, Mani, a young mystic of Ctesiphon, proclaims himself a prophet and preaches his doctrine, Manichaeism, throughout the Persian Empire.

title: Antioch
event: Winter—Emperor Gordian III reaches Antioch and prepares with his army a offensive against the Persians.

title: Ireland
event: November 1—The Battle of Samhain is fought in Ireland.

title: India
event: Emperor Gordian III begins a campaign against king Shapur I, the Greek philosopher Plotinus joins him and hopes to obtain first-hand knowledge of Persian and Indian philosophies.

title: Bosporan Kingdom
event: Gordian III evacuates the Cimmerian cities in the Bosphorus (Crimea), as the territory is now controlled by the Goths.

title: Nusaybin
event: Shapur I makes a pre-emptive attack on Antioch to drive out the Romans. Gordian's father-in-law, Timesitheus, leads a Roman army to defeat the Persians at Carrhae and Nisibis.

title: Iraq
event: Battle of Misiche: King Shapur I delivers a counter-attack near Fallujah (Iraq) and defeats the Roman army upstream of the Euphrates.

title: Shahba
event: Philip the Arab constructs the city of Shahba (Syria), the province of his birth. The Persians occupied Armenia.

title: Goguryeo
event: Guanqiu Jian of Cao Wei invades Goguryeo, devastating their capital.

title: Antioch
event: Plotinus, Greek philosopher, escapes the bloodshed that accompanies the murder of Gordianus III and makes his way to Antioch. Back to Rome he founds his Neoplatonist school and attracts students like Porphyry, Castricius Firmus and Eustochius of Alexandria.

title: National Museum of Damascus
event: 244–245 – House-synagogue, Dura-Europos, Syria, is built. It is reconstructed in the National Museum of Damascus (Syria).

title: Carchemish
event: February 11—Emperor Gordian III is murdered by mutinous soldiers in Zaitha (Mesopotamia). A mound is raised at Carchemish in his memory.

title: Lincolnshire
event: In Britain many thousands of acres of what is now Lincolnshire are inundated by a great flood.

title: China
event: Trieu Thi Trinh, a Vietnamese warrior, begins her three year resistance against the invading Chinese.

title: Korea
event: The Korean Baekje kingdom, under King Goi, attacks the Chinese command of Daifang.

title: Syria (Roman province)
event: The revolts of Pacatianus in Moesia and Iotapianus in Syria are put down by senator Decius, by order of emperor Philip the Arab.

title: Carthage
event: Cyprian becomes bishop of Carthage.

title: Italy
event: Trajan Decius puts down a revolt in Moesia and Pannonia. Loyal legionaries proclaim him emperor and he leads them into Italy. At a battle at Verona, he defeats and kills Philip the Arab.

title: Alexandria
event: In Alexandria, the populace pillages the homes of Christians.

title: Plovdiv
event: The Goths under king Cniva invade Moesia. They cross the Danube and lay siege to Philippopolis (modern Plovdiv). After a long resistance, Cniva conquers the city and slaying one hundred thousand inhabitants.

title: Donau-Ries
event: The Alamanni drive the Romans from the modern area of Donau-Ries.

title: Red Sea
event: The Kingdom of Aksum (Axum) takes control of commerce on the Red Sea.

title: Oaxaca
event: Teotihuacán is rebuilt as a four-quartered cosmogram by Zapotec architects brought from Monte Albán in Oaxaca.

title: Antioch
event: The Sassanid king, Shapur I, orders an invasion of the Roman East with the intent of finally capturing the jewel of Syria, Antioch (251–254).

title: Battle of Abrittus
event: July 1—In the Battle of Abrittus, the Goths defeat emperor Decius and his son Herennius Etruscus on swampy ground in the Dobrudja (Moesia).

title: Iran
event: Shapur I, king of Persia, puts the revolt in Khorasan (Iran) down and rejoines with his army. He invades Armenia and appoints his son Hormizd Ardashir as the new Armenian king. Georgia submits peacefully to Shapur I, and is made an special province in the Persian Empire.

title: Rhine
event: Aemilianus is murdered at Spoletium and Publius Valerianus, age 60, is recognised as new emperor by the Rhine legions. He gives his son Publius Licinius Egnatius Gallienus the title ''Augustus''. Valerianus I dispatches him to the Danube where the Goths are violating the treaty signed with Rome and invade Moesia.

title: British Isles
event: Cyprian, bishop of Carthage, describes in ''De Mortalitate'' a pandemic which starts in Ethiopia. Symptoms include diarrhea and vomiting, an ulcerated sore throat, high fever, and gangrenous hands and feet. The pandemic passes through Egypt and extends through Europe to the British Isles.

title: Rhine
event: The Franks cross the Rhine, the Alamanni reach Milan.

title: Antioch
event: King Shapur I invades Mesopotamia and Syria. He conquers and plunders Antioch.

title: China
event: Peace and unity are finally restored in China with the victories of the Wei Kingdom in the north. The ruling dynasty is worn out by war, and the kingdom is ruled by ministers on their behalf.

title: Alexandria
event: The great pandemic of the Roman world strikes violently in Pontus on the Black Sea and causes enormous loss of life in Alexandria, encouraging thousands to embrace Christianity.

title: Carthage
event: Pope Stephen I threatens to excommunicate Cyprian, bishop of Carthage, and other bishops in Africa and Asia Minor unless they stop rebaptizing heretics. Cyprian attacks the pope in a treatise which gains support from the Council of Carthage. He sends envoys to Rome, raising the specter of a schism between the Roman and Carthaginian Churches.

title: Iller
event: In Bavaria the ''Limes Germanicus'' (Upper Raetian Limes) along the river Iller is abandoned by the Romans.

title: Sirmium
event: Valerian, under guardianship of Ingenuus, is established at Sirmium (Pannonia) to represent the Roman  government in the troubled Illyrian provinces.

title: Antioch
event: Emperor Valerian recovers Antioch in Syria from the Persian king Shapur I.

title: Black Sea
event: The Goths build a fleet on the Black Sea.

title: Trabzon
event: The Goths ravage Asia Minor and Trabzon.

title: Carthage
event: Cyprian, the bishop of Carthage, is martyred (decapitation).

title: China
event: Nanjing University is founded in Nanjing, China.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: Emperor Valerian leads an army (70,000 men) to relieve Edessa, besieged by the forces of king Shapur I. An outbreak of a   plague kills many legionaries, weakening the Roman position in Syria.

title: Mediolanum
event: Battle of Mediolanum: A Germanic confederation, the Alamanni (300,000 warriors), who crossed the Alps are defeated by Roman legions under Gallienus near Mediolanum (modern Milan).

title: Nehardea
event: Mesopotania: Odaenathus, the ruler of the kingdom of Palmyra, sacks the city of Nehardea, destroying its great yeshiva.

title: Band-e Kaisar
event: Shapur I sends Valerian to Bishapur and used the captured Roman army for engineering plans. They constructed the ''Band-e Kaisar'' (Bridge of Valerian).

title: Rhine
event: Gallienus established himself at Mediolanum (modern Milan), he reorganizes the army supported by elite cavalry and dispatch troops to the Rhine frontier.

title: Scheldt
event: The Franks take control over the Scheldt estuary (approximate date).

title: Palmyrene Empire
event: Syria, Egypt and Palestine break off from the Roman Empire to form the Persian-supported Palmyrene Empire.

title: Palmyra
event: Gallienus usurpers: The rebellion of Macrianus Major, Macrianus Minor, and Quietus against Gallienus comes to an end. They march from Asia to Europe but are defeated in Thrace by Gallienus' general Aureolus, and both are killed. Quietus flees to Emesa, where he is killed by Odaenathus of Palmyra.

title: Ephesus
event: The Goths invade Asia Minor and destroy the Temple of Artemis in Ephesus.

title: Aegean Sea
event: The Heruls accompanied the Goths ravaging the coasts of the Black Sea and the Aegean.

title: Palmyra
event: King Odenathus of Palmyra declares himself ruler of the area west of the  River Euphrates and is declared ''Dux Orientalis'' by the Roman emperor Gallienus.

title: China
event: The Wei Kingdom conquers the kingdom of Shu Han, one of the Chinese Three Kingdoms.

title: China
event: Three Kingdoms: Sima Yan forced emperor Cao Huan to abdicate the  throne to him, ending the Kingdom of Wei in China.

title: Ctesiphon
event: King Odaenathus of Palmyra invades Persia to conquer the capital Ctesiphon. After his victories in the East he pronouns himself with the title king of kings.

title: Greece
event: First Gothic invasion: The Goths, originally from Scandinavia, with the Sarmatians (from modern Iran), invade the Balkans and Greece. They ravaging  Moesia and Thrace.

title: Skyros
event: The Heruli invade the Black Sea coast, they unsuccessfully attack Byzantium and Cyzicus. The Romano-Byzantine fleet defeats the Herulian fleet (500 ships) but escapes into Aegean Sea, where they ravaging the islands of Lemnos and Skyros.

title: Macedonia (Greece)
event: The Goths sacked several cities of southern Greece including Athens, Corinth, Argos and Sparta. An Athenian militia force (2,000 men) under the historian Dexippus, pushed the invaders to the north where the are intercepted by the Roman army under emperor Gallienus. He wins an important victory near the Nestos River, on the boundary between Macedonia and Thrace.

title: Italy
event: Aureolus, charged with defending Italy, defeats Victorinus (co-emperor of Gaul), is proclaimed emperor by his troops, and begins his march on Rome.

title: Palmyrene Empire
event: King Odaenathus of Palmyra makes plans for a campaign in Cappadocia against the Goths. He is assassinated along with his eldest son, evidently on orders from emperor Gallienus. His wife Zenobia succeeds him, and rules with her young son Vaballathus the Palmyrene Empire.

title: Niš
event: September – Battle of Naissus: Emperor Gallienus, aided by Aurelian, defeats a Gothic coalition (50,000 warriors) near Naissus (Niš, modern Serbia).

title: Mediolanum
event: Gallienus is killed by his own senior officers at Mediolanum (Milan) while besieging his rival Aureolus, one of the Thirty Tyrants. He is murdered in turn by the Praetorian guard.

title: Po (river)
event: The Alamanni invade Italy north of the Po River.

title: Lake Garda
event: November – Battle of Lake Benacus: A Roman army (35,000 men) under emperor Claudius II defeats the Germanic tribes of the Alamanni along the banks of Lake Garda.

title: Black Sea
event: Second Gothic invasion: The Goths and other German tribes attack Bosphorean towns on the coast of the Black Sea. Some 2,000 ships and 320,000 men from the Danube enter Roman territory. Emperor Claudius II defeats the invaders and receives the title Gothicus for his triumph. Many of the prisoners will serve in the Roman legions and settle in vacant lands in the Danubian provinces.

title: Sirmium
event: Claudius II travels to Sirmium and prepares a war against the Vandals, who raid Pannonia.

title: Rhodes
event: The Heruli capture Athens and ravaging the Aegean Islands as far as Crete and Rhodes.

title: Alexandria
event: Queen Zenobia conquers Syria, Palestine, Lebanon and Egypt, giving her control of Rome's grain supply. The library at Alexandria is partly burned during a raid by Zabdas, general of Zenobia.

title: Battle of Naissus
event: Quintillus commits suicide and is succeeded by an associate of his brother Lucius Domitius Aurelianus, the military leader who distinguished himself last year at the Battle of Naissus (Serbia).

title: China
event: The Chinese invent gunpowder (black powder), a mixture of sulfur, charcoal and potassium nitrate. At first, it appears to have been used only for fireworks.

title: Italy
event: January—Battle of Placentia: The Alamanni invade Italy and sack the city of Piacenza. A Roman army (15,000 men) under Emperor Aurelian is ambushed and defeated.

title: Metauro
event: January—Battle of Fano: The Alamanni move towards a defenceless Rome. Aurelian rallies his men and defeats the Germanic tribes on the Metauro River, just inland of Fano.

title: Caelian Hill
event: Felicissimus, financial minister of the state treasury, leads an uprising of mint workers against Aurelian. He is defeated and killed on the Caelian Hill.

title: Aurelian Walls
event: Aurelian begins construction of a new defensive wall to protect Rome. The Aurelian Walls, 19 kilometers (12 miles), enclose the city with fortifications.

title: Iran
event: King Shapur I builts the Academy of Gundishapur (Iran), it becomes the intellectual center of the Sassanid Empire. The Nestorians fleeing religious persecution, seek protection. He commissioned the refugees to translate Greek an Syriac works on astronomy, medicine and philosophy.

title: China
event: A magnetic compass is first used in China.

title: Homs
event: Battle of Immae: Aurelian defeats the forces of the Palmyrene Empire near Antioch. Queen Zenobia flees under cover of darkness to Emesa (Syria).

title: Tyana
event: During the Siege of Tyana, Emperor Aurelian has a dream of Apollonius of Tyana and spares the city.

title: Palmyra
event: Battle of Emesa: Aurelian destroys the Palmyrene heavy cavalry (''clibanarii'') and conquers Palmyra. Zenobia escapes to Persia but is captured on the Euphrates.

title: Lutetia
event: Saint Denis, first Bishop of Paris, and two of his disciples are beheaded on the road to the Temple of Mercury that stands atop a hill outside of the city. The hill will later be called Montmartre (Mountain of Martyrs) in Lutetia (modern Paris).

title: Italy
event: Administrative reorganization of Italy: Aurelian adopts as permanent the reforms instituted by Caracalla.

title: India
event: An Indian delegation visits Aurelian.

title: Palmyra
event: Battle of Châlons: Emperor Aurelian reconquers the Gallic Empire (Gaul and Britain). Tetricus I surrenders his army near Châlons-sur-Marne, France. With the conquests of the Palmyran Empire and the Gallic Empire, the Roman Empire is united again.

title: Rhine
event: Germanic tribes take advantage of the destroyed Roman forces of the Rhine. They pillage and depopulate large areas of Gaul, including Paris. The Rhine border is lost for 20 years. Franks live in the area of present southern Netherlands, northern Belgium and Rhineland from now on.

title: Red Sea
event: The Kingdom of Aksum attains great prosperity thanks to its control of Red Sea trade.

title: Bosphorus
event: Emperor Aurelian prepares a campaign against the Sassanids in Asia-Minor. In Thrace, while waiting to cross the Bosporus with his army, he hands out severe punishments to corrupt soldiers and makes a list of high-raking officers marked for execution.

title: Cappadocia
event: Marcus Annius Florianus defeats the Goths and Alans who have invaded Asia Minor. Emperor Tacitus dies of illness or is murdered at Tyana in Cappadocia.

title: Italy
event: Florianus becomes Roman Emperor; he breaks off his campaign against the Heruli and marches from the Bosporus with support from the Roman legions in Britain,  Gaul, Spain and Italy to fight a indecisive battle with Marcus Aurelius Probus in Cilicia.

title: Iran
event: King Bahram I of Persia dies after a 3-year reign in which the Zoroastrian priests at Ctesiphon (Iran) put pressure on him to persecute Buddhists, Christians and Manichaeans. He is succeeded by his son Bahram II.

title: China
event: Mani, a sage from Persia, dies at Gundeshapur after 30 years of preaching his heresy at the court of the late Sassanian king Shapur I and on long journeys to Turkestan, India and China. He is executed or allowed to die in prison, and claimes to be a prophet of God. Mani combines Zoroastrian dualism with Christian theology and his disciples gain wide support for Manichaeism despite opposition from Byzantine and Roman Emperors.

title: Rhine
event: Probus reorganizes the defenses on the Rhine.

title: Rhine
event: The commander of the Roman fleet on the Rhine, Bonosus, proclaims himself emperor.  Defeated by Probus' troops, Bonosus hangs himself.

title: Fuzhou
event: A new city is constructed in Fuzhou slightly south of the original city Ye (the main street of the city has remained unchanged since that time).

title: Ctesiphon
event: Carus conquers Ctesiphon, capital of the Persian kingdom.

title: Tigris
event: Carus is a victim of a military conspiracy, and is killed near the Tigris.

title: China
event: Jin Hui Di succeeds Jin Wu Di as emperor of China.

title: China
event: The War of the Eight Princes begins in China.

title: Alexandria
event: The Roman General Achilleus is proclaimed emperor in Alexandria.  For two years he resists Diocletian's army, but in the end the rebellion is crushed.

title: Iran
event: Narseh becomes co-ruler of Persia.

title: Rhine
event: Constantius Chlorus restores the northern Rhine border after defeating the Franks. Franks keep living in the north, because the Roman population has fled.

title: China
event: Tuoba Lu Guan succeeds Tuoba Fu as chieftain of the Chinese Tuoba tribe.

title: Ctesiphon
event: Galerius is defeated in combat by the Persians under Narseh outside Ctesiphon.

title: Ctesiphon
event: Galerius conquers Ctesiphon from the Persians; however, as part of the peace treaty, it is returned in exchange for Armenia.

title: Rhine
event: Constantius Chlorus defeats the Alamanni in the territory of the Lingones (Langres) and strengthens the border along the Rhine.

title: Korea
event: The manufacture of cultured silk becomes popular from Korea to Japan.

title: Palmyra
event: Diocletian's wall is built in Palmyra.

title: Anderitum
event: A Romano-Celtic{{Citation neededdate=January 2010}} temple-mausoleum complex is constructed in what is now Lullingstone, and also in Anderitum (approximate date).

title: Tikal
event: The Mayan civilization reaches its most prolific period, the classic period, in what is now Guatemala, Belize and parts of southern Mexico adjacent to the former two. During most of this period, Tikal dominates the Mayan world.

title: China
event: The magnetic compass for navigation is invented in China (approximate date).

title: India
event: The Panchatantra, a Sanskrit collection of fables and fairy tales, is written in India.

title: Constantinople
event: The Tetrarchs are probably made in Egypt. After 330 the are moved to Constantinople and in 1204 they are installed at the corner of the facade of the St Mark's Basilica, Venice (approximate date).

title: Diocletian's Palace
event: Diocletian's Palace, Split, Croatia, is built. Its model is nowadays kept at the Museo della Civilta Romana, Rome.

title: Cambridge University Press
event: Armenia becomes the first nation to accept Christianity as a state religion.Cambridge University Press, Gale Group, C.W. Dugmore<

title: San Marino
event: September 3—The republic of San Marino is established (traditional date).

title: France
event: September 25—On a voyage preaching the gospel, Saint Fermin of Pamplona is beheaded in Amiens, France.

title: Teotihuacan
event: In Mexico the civilization of Teotihuacan flourishes.

title: China
event: Major Wu Hu (barbarian) uprising in China: the Hun Liu Yuan establish the Han kingdom, beginning the Sixteen Kingdoms era in China.

title: China
event: Sichuan earns its independence from China.

title: Solfatara (volcano)
event: Patron of Pozzuoli, Saint Proculus, and patron of Naples, Saint Januarius are thrown to wild beasts in Pozzuoli's Flavian Amphitheater, then beheaded at Solfatara.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: The Daysan River floods Edessa.

title: Lisbon
event: Santa Maria Maior de Lisboa is built in Lisbon.

title: Rhine
event: The Franks cross the Rhine, but are repulsed by Constantine I.

title: China
event: The War of the Eight Princes ends in China.

title: Italy
event: Galerius unsuccessfully invades Italy and names Licinius as Augustus.

title: China
event: Jin Huai Di becomes emperor of China.

title: Carnuntum
event: November 11—The Congress of Carnuntum: Attempting to keep peace within the Roman Empire, the leaders of the Tetrarchy declare Maxentius and Licinius to be Augusti, while rival contender Constantine I is declared Caesar of Britain and Gaul.

title: Rhine
event: Under Constantine I, the Romans defeat the Germans along the Rhine.

title: Roman Forum
event: Maxentius starts the construction of the basilica bearing his name, the largest building in the Roman Forum.

title: China
event: Kingdom of Xiongnu established in northern China.

title: Rhine
event: The construction of a stone bridge across the Rhine near Cologne is completed.

title: China
event: Luoyang, the Jin Dynasty (265-420) capital of China, is sacked by groups of barbarians under the leadership of Huns. Jin Huai Di, emperor of China, is captured.

title: Arch of Constantine
event: Construction begins on the Arch of Constantine in Rome.

title: Roman Forum
event: c. 312–315 – Constantine Addresses the People in the Roman Forum, sculptural relief on the Arch of Constantine, Rome, is made.

title: Arch of Constantine
event: July 25 – The Arch of Constantine is dedicated (approximate date).

title: Caesarea Maritima
event: Eusebius becomes bishop of Caesarea (approximate date).

title: Battle of Mardia
event: December—Constantine I defeats Licinius in the Battle of Mardia, and gains some of his colleague's territory.

title: Chang'an
event: The Xiongnu sack Chang'an, capital of the Chinese Western Jin Dynasty. Jin Mindi, the emperor, surrenders.

title: China
event: China loses its territories to the north of Yang-tsé-kiang, to the benefit of the Xiongnu and the Xianbei.

title: Nicomedia
event: Arius travels to Nicomedia at the invitation of Eusebius, after having been accused of heresy and condemned by Alexander, the Patriarch of Alexandria. This gives rise to the Arian Controversy.

title: India
event: Chandragupta I founds the Gupta dynasty in northern India.

title: Alexandria
event: A synod in Alexandria condemns Arianism.

title: China
event: Jin Ming Di succeeds Jin Yuan Di as emperor of China.

title: China
event: Jin Cheng Di succeeds Jin Ming Di as emperor of China.

title: Bethlehem
event: The Church of the Nativity is built in Bethlehem.

title: Constantinople
event: Constantine I founds Constantinople and incorporates Byzantium into the new city.

title: Vatican City
event: The first church is built on the site of Vatican City, traditional place of Saint Peter's tomb.

title: Antioch
event: Construction begins on the cathedral of Antioch.

title: Meroë
event: Ezana, king of Axum, extends his area of control to the west. He defeats the Nobates, and destroys the kingdom of Meroë.

title: Constantinople
event: May 11—Constantine I refounds Byzantium, renames it ''New Rome'', and moves the capital of the Roman Empire there from Rome. It is later known as Constantinople.

title: China
event: The barbarian king Che Hou reigns in China. His sons try to assassinate him, but are caught and executed.

title: Church of the Holy Sepulchre
event: Emperor Constantine I begins construction of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre.

title: Constantinople
event: November 7—Athanasius is banished to Trier, on the charge that he prevented the corn fleet from sailing to Constantinople.

title: Palmyra
event: The first recorded customs tariff is in use in Palmyra.

title: Constantinople
event: Constantinople, capital of Emperor Constantius II, becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Rome, capital of Emperor Constans.

title: Caesarea Maritima
event: Acacius succeeds Eusebius as bishop in the see of Caesarea.

title: Antioch
event: The Council of Encaenia is held in Antioch.

title: Goguryeo
event: Goguryeo is invaded by Murong Huang of the Xianbei.

title: China
event: Jin Kang Di succeeds Jin Cheng Di as emperor of China.

title: Constantinople
event: February 15—The original Hagia Sophia is dedicated in Constantinople.

title: Constantinople
event: Bishop Eustorgius I brings relics of the Three Magi from Constantinople to Milan, according to a 12th century legend.

title: China
event: Emperor Mu succeeds Emperor Kang as emperor of China.

title: London
event: The making of a detail of ''Admonitions of the Imperial Instructress to Court Ladies'' (attributed to Gu Kaizhi and being from the Six Dynasties period) begins (approximate year) and is completed in 406. It is now kept at the British Museum, London.

title: Korea
event: In Korea, the Puyo tribes are absorbed by the Koguryŏ.

title: India
event: In India, Samudragupta defeats Rudrasena in battle.

title: China
event: The Mou-jong (proto-Mongols) take control of North China.

title: Jewish revolt against Gallus
event: The Jewish revolt against Gallus breaks out.

title: India
event: In India, a new process makes possible the extraction of sugar from sugar cane.

title: Rhine
event: The Alamanni and the Franks defeat the Roman army, taking control of 40 towns between the Moselle and the Rhine.

title: Jewish revolt against Gallus
event: The Jewish revolt against Gallus is put down.

title: China
event: The earliest sighting of a supernova occurs in China.

title: Rhine
event: The Alemanni cross the upper Rhine and invade the lands of the Helvetians.

title: Shanxi
event: Fu Sheng (Fou Cheng), king of the Shanxi (Chen-si), reigns in North China.

title: Mediolanum
event: November 6—In Mediolanum, Roman Emperor Constantius II raises his cousin Julian to the rank of Caesar of the West.

title: Pantheon Rome
event: Ammianus Marcellinus describes the Pantheon as being rounded like the boundary of the horizon and vaulted with a beautiful loftiness.

title: China
event: The reign of Fu Jiān, the emperor of Former Qin, commences in China.

title: Constantinople
event: December 11—The first known Prefect of the City of Constantinople, Honoratus, takes office.

title: China
event: Emperor Ai succeeds Emperor Mu as emperor of China.

title: London
event: 361–363 – Julian the Apostate, coin is issued. It is now kept at The British Museum, London.

title: Ctesiphon
event: Julian gathers an army of 60,000 men, a fleet of fifty warships and a thousand transport boats. He secures the co-operation of the king of Armenia, Arsacès, and goes on Persia. Achieving success after success, he pushes on to Ctesiphon. Shapur II sues for peace, but Julian refuses. Soon, harassed by Persian guerrillas, the Roman army is forced to retreat.

title: Alexandria
event: February 21—Athanasius returns to Alexandria.

title: Antioch
event: October 22—The temple of Apollo at Daphne, outside Antioch, is destroyed in a mysterious fire.

title: Antioch
event: March 5—Emperor Julian moves from Antioch with an army of 90,000 against the Sassanid Empire.

title: Battle of Ctesiphon (363)
event: May 29—Battle of Ctesiphon:  Julian arrives under the walls of the Sassanid capital and defeats the Sassanid army of Shapur II of Persia, but is unable to put the city under siege.

title: Caspian Sea
event: The Huns reach the Caspian Sea.

title: Tyana
event: February 17—Jovian dies at Tyana, in Asia Minor.

title: Greece
event: July 21—An earthquake and tsunami devastates Crete and Alexandria and affects Italy, Greece, and Palestine.The Journal of Roman Studies volume=94 issue= pages=141–167 doi=10.2307/4135013 }}.<

title: Constantinople
event: September 28—Procopius bribes two legions passing by Constantinople, proclaims himself Roman emperor, and takes control of Thrace and Bithynia.

title: Alexandria
event: Emperor Valens exiles Athanasius from Alexandria.

title: China
event: Emperor Fei succeeds Emperor Ai as emperor of China.

title: Rhine
event: January 2—The Alamanni cross the frozen Rhine in large numbers, invading the Roman Empire.

title: Mogao Caves
event: Buddhist monk Lo-tsun has a vision of golden rays of light shining down on one thousand Buddhas, resulting in the creation of the Mogao Caves.

title: Hadrian's Wall
event: Great Conspiracy: A general assault of Saxons, Irish, and Attacotti, combined with a general revolt of the garrison on Hadrian's Wall, devastates Roman Britain.

title: Korea
event: The first Korean envoy arrives in Japan, emissary of the government of Kudara.

title: Salamis Cyprus
event: Epiphanius of Salamis becomes bishop of Salamis, Cyprus.

title: Rhine
event: Valentinian I, based in Trier, defeats the Alemanni along the border at the Rhine.

title: Goguryeo
event: Goguryeo invades Baekje.

title: Betuwe
event: The presence of the Saxons in Batavia is noted by Ammianus Marcellinus.

title: China
event: Former Qin conquers Former Yan in China.

title: Sirmium
event: The fortified cities of the Danube, with Sirmium at the forefront, contribute to stop an invasion of the Quadi.

title: Goguryeo
event: Baekje forces storm the Goguryeo capital in P'yongyang.

title: Rhine
event: The Roman poet Ausonius writes of a voyage on the Rhine and the Moselle in his work 'Mosella'.

title: China
event: Emperor Fei is dethroned as emperor of China. Emperor Jianwen is installed.

title: China
event: Emperor Xiaowu succeeds Emperor Jianwen as emperor of China.

title: Korea
event: The first diplomatic ties are established between the Korean kingdom of Baekje and the court of Eastern Jin.

title: Goguryeo
event: The national academy of Chinese learning, called Taehak, is established in the kingdom of Goguryeo.

title: Teotihuacan
event: May 4—Spearthrower Owl becomes emperor of Teotihuacan.

title: Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milan
event: December 7—Ambrose becomes bishop of Milan.

title: Chalcis Syria
event: Saint Jerome retires to the desert of Chalcis, Syria.

title: India
event: Chandragupta II begins his reign as king of India.

title: Caucasus
event: Persian king Shapur II pushes the Huns back across the Caucasus.

title: China
event: Chinese painter Gu Kaizhi paints his work, ''The Goddess of the Lo River''.

title: Constantinople
event: Valens completes the aqueduct of Constantinople begun by Constantine I.

title: Teotihuacan
event: Siyah K'ak' begins to replace Mayan kings with relatives of Spearthrower Owl, emperor of Teotihuacan.

title: Constantinople
event: Gregory Nazianzus is ordained bishop of Constantinople.

title: Battle of Adrianople
event: August 9 – Battle of Adrianople: A large Roman army led by Emperor Valens is defeated by the Visigoths. Valens is killed along with two-thirds of his army.

title: Sirmium
event: January 19—Theodosius I is elevated as Roman Emperor at Sirmium.

title: China
event: The War of the Feishui is fought in China.

title: Tikal
event: September 13—Yax Nuun Ayiin (I) becomes ruler of Tikal.

title: Constantinople
event: February 27 – Theodosius I, with co-emperors Gratianus and Valentinian II, declare their wish that all their peoples convert to trinitarian Christianity, in accordance with the patriarchs of Rome and Alexandria, implicitly rejecting the Arianism of the patriarch of Constantinople as heretical.

title: Constantinople
event: November 24 – Theodosius I makes his ''adventus'', or formal entry, into Constantinople.

title: Rock of Cashel
event: The Rock of Cashel is built in Ireland. {{Factdate=February 2007}}

title: Easter Island
event: Approximate (C14) date of the first signs of a human presence on Easter Island.

title: Mediolanum
event: Gratian officially moves the capital of the Western Empire from Rome to Mediolanum.

title: Anhui
event: Battle of Feishui: The Jin Dynasty defeats the Former Qin dynasty in Anhui.

title: Iran
event: Shapur III becomes king of Persia.

title: Constantinople
event: The Forum of Theodosius I is built in Constantinople.

title: Nile
event: An edict of Theodosius closes pagan temples in the Nile Valley.

title: Alexandria
event: The Serapeum in Alexandria is destroyed.

title: Alexandria
event: Theophilus of Alexandria becomes patriarch of Alexandria.

title: Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls
event: Theodosius I begins to rebuild the present-day Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls.

title: Constantinople
event: A column is constructed in Constantinople to celebrate of a victory of Theodosius I.

title: China
event: The Northern Wei Dynasty begins in China when Dao Wu Di becomes its first king (see Northern dynasties).

title: Iran
event: Bahram IV becomes king of Persia.

title: Portugal
event: Paternus becomes bishop of the Episcopal see of Braga (in modern Portugal).

title: Hippodrome of Constantinople
event: Theodosius brings an obelisk from Egypt to the Hippodrome of Constantinople.

title: India
event: Rudrasena becomes emperor of Vakataka in the Deccan Plateau of India. In the same year he marries Prabhavatigupta, daughter of Chandragupta II.

title: London
event: c. 390–401 – Priestess of Bacchus (?), right panel of a diptych, is made. It is now kept at Victoria and Albert Museum, London.

title: Roman Forum
event: All non-Christian temples in the Empire are closed, as Theodosius establishes Christianity as the official state religion. The eternal fire in the Temple of Vesta in the Roman Forum was extinguished, and the Vestal Virgins were disbanded.

title: China
event: Gao Zu succeeds Tai Zu as Emperor of the Later Qin Empire in China.

title: Constantinople
event: An obelisk, taken from Egypt, is erected near the hippodrome in Constantinople.

title: Philae
event: The last known Hieroglyph is written in Philae, Egypt.

title: Battle of the Frigidus
event: September 6—Battle of the Frigidus: Emperor Theodosius I defeats and kills the usurper Eugenius and his Frankish magister militum Arbogast.

title: Constantinople
event: After the death of emperor Theodosius I, the Empire is re-divided into an eastern and a western half. The eastern half is centered in Constantinople under Arcadius, son of Theodosius I, and the western half in Rome under Honorius, his brother.

title: Hippo Regius
event: Saint Augustine becomes Bishop of Hippo Regius. His assignment is the reunification of the Roman Catholic Church in Africa, primarily focusing on the Donatist movement led by Primianus.

title: Rhine
event: The Romans enlist the Franks and the Alemanni to defend the Rhine border.

title: Sparta
event: The Visigoths plundered Corinth, Argos and Sparta then withdrew to Epirus before the Roman army under Stilicho.

title: Greece
event: The Eleusinian Mysteries come to an end, as Alaric I destroys the ancient sites in Greece.

title: China
event: Emperor An succeeds Emperor Xiaowu as ruler of the Chinese Jin Dynasty.

title: Hippo Regius
event: Augustine is appointed bishop of Hippo in North Africa.

title: China
event: The Xiongnu occupy the Gansu area in China.

title: Constantinople
event: John Chrysostom becomes archbishop of Constantinople.

title: Constantinople
event: Forming an alliance with deserters of Tribigild along the Bosphorus, Gothic leader Gainas devastates the outlying areas near Constantinople.

title: India
event: Fa-Hien, a Chinese Buddhist monk, travels to India.

title: Italy
event: Italy is first invaded by Alaric (probable date).

title: Holland
event: The Franks establish themselves in Northern Holland.

title: Constantinople
event: While taking refuge along the Danube, Gainas and his Goths are attacked by the Huns, who kill him and his army. Gainas' head is sent as a gift to Constantinople by the Hun chieftain Uldin.

title: Great Zimbabwe
event: Construction at Great Zimbabwe begins (approximate date).

title: Italy
event: The Visigoths begin to attack the northernmost reaches of Italy, causing destruction in the countryside.

title: Black Sea
event: The ''Chronicon Pachale'' (Paschale Chronicle) reports that the Black Sea is completely frozen.

title: Italy
event: Visigoths under Alaric I leave Italy for Illyricum after being defeated at the hands of Roman army led by Stilicho in the Battle of Verona in June.

title: Constantinople
event: The Synod of the Oak deposes and banishes John Chrysostom, bishop of Constantinople, but shortly afterward he is recalled only to be banished again.

title: China
event: The Chinese Buddhist monk Huiyuan, who founded the Pure Land Buddhism sect and the monastery on Mount Lushan, writes the book ''On Why Monks Do Not Bow Down Before Kings'' in this year. In his book he argues that although the Buddhist clergy should remain independent and undisturbed by politics, the Buddhist laymen nonetheless make good subjects under monarchs, due to their fear of retribution of karma and desire to be reborn in paradise.

title: Colosseum
event: The Emperor Honorius abolishes gladiator combat in the Colosseum.

title: China
event: The Khitan are first mentioned in Chinese chronicles. They wander along the boundaries of Kara-muren, and form part of the Donghu (Tong-hou) confederation.

title: India
event: Approximate date of Chinese traveler Fa Xian's arrival in India.

title: Castra martis
event: Under Uldin, the Huns attack the Eastern Empire, setting fire to various frontier forts and taking control of the Castra Martis.  The Romans try to negotiate, but Uldin demands an exorbitant gold tribute in return for his withdrawal. This demand is rejected and the Romans begin to push the Huns back across the Danube.

title: Portugal
event: The Vandals, Alans and Suevi break through Constantine III's garrisons into Hispania. They share the Iberian Peninsula by drawing lots {{Citation neededdate=February 2007}}, with the Vandals getting Hispania Baetica (modern Andalusia), the Suevi Gallaecia (modern Galicia and northern Portugal) and the Alans Lusitania (the rest of modern Portugal and Spanish Extremadura).

title: China
event: Ming Yuan Di succeeds Dao Wu Di as ruler of the Chinese Northern Wei Dynasty (see Northern dynasties).

title: Great Britain
event: Emperor Honorius tells Britain to look to its own defences, effectively ending Roman rule in Britain.

title: Corsica
event: The city of Alalia in the island of Corsica is devastated by a huge fire, destroying its port and most of the city.

title: Deccan Plateau
event: Prithivisena becomes king of the Vakataka in the Deccan.

title: Portugal
event: The Alans establish their rule in the Roman province of Lusitania (modern Portugal south of the Duero River and Spanish Extremadura).

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: Rabbula becomes bishop of Edessa.

title: Italy
event: May 8—Honorius signs an edict providing tax relief for the provinces of Italy that have been plundered by the Visigoths.

title: India
event: Faxian returns from India and begins translating Buddhist works into Chinese.

title: Susa
event: Abdas, bishop of Susa, burns down a Zoroastrian temple; in retaliation, King Yazdegerd of Persia orders the destruction of Christian churches.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: 18 March—The Daysan River floods Edessa.

title: Antioch
event: The Eustathian schism in Antioch is healed.

title: Alexandria
event: The Jews are expelled from Alexandria.

title: Krakatoa
event: Reports of the eruption of Krakatoa are recorded in the Javanese ''Book of Kings''.

title: Aquitaine
event: The Visigoths are granted Aquitaine, and Wallia establishes a capital at Toulouse.

title: China
event: Emperor Gong succeeds Emperor An as ruler of the Chinese Jin Dynasty.

title: Rhine
event: The legendary Pharamond leads the Franks across the Rhine.

title: China
event: The Jin Dynasty ends in China. Liu Yu (Emperor Wu of Liu Song) is the first ruler of the Song Dynasty.

title: China
event: The Southern Dynasties begin in China.

title: China
event: Song Wen Di succeeds Song Shao Di as ruler of the Chinese Song Dynasty.

title: Italy
event: Aëtius leads an army into Italy to support the self-proclaimed emperor Joannes.

title: Italy
event: c. 425–426 – Mausoleum of Galla Placidia, Ravenna, Italy, is built.

title: Goguryeo
event: Pyongyang is declared the capital of Goguryeo by king Jangsu.

title: Portugal
event: Hydatius becomes bishop of ''Aquae Flaviae'' in Gallaecia (modern Chaves in Portugal).

title: Iberian Peninsula
event: Vandals under Geiseric cross from the Iberian Peninsula into Roman North Africa.

title: Great Britain
event: Pope Celestine I dispatches bishops Germanus of Auxerre and Lupus of Troyes to Britain to combat the Pelagian heresy.

title: China
event: Feng Ba abdicates as emperor of the Northern Yan, one of the states vying for control of China. He is succeeded by Feng Hong.

title: Ireland
event: Saint Patrick reaches Ireland on his missionary expedition (approximate date).

title: Bethlehem
event: Peter the Iberian founds a Georgian monastery near Bethlehem.

title: Hippo Regius
event: Hippo Regius becomes the capital of the Vandal kingdom.

title: Palenque
event: K'uk' B'alam I, the first known ruler of the Mayan city of Palenque, comes to power.

title: Ireland
event: Pope Celestine I dispatches Palladius to serve as bishop to the Irish.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: Ibas becomes bishop of Edessa.

title: Palenque
event: August 10 – A figure known to Mayanist scholars as Casper begins a 52-year reign in Palenque.

title: Constantinople
event: October 29—Valentinian III, Western Emperor, marries Licinia Eudoxia, daughter of his cousin Theodosius II, Eastern Emperor in Constantinople. This unifies the two branches of the House of Theodosius.

title: Colosseum
event: The last known Gladiator combat in the Colosseum is held.

title: Constantinople
event: Relics of John Chrysostom are transported to Constantinople.

title: Bethlehem
event: The monastery of Mar Saba is founded near Bethlehem, Palestine.

title: Carthage
event: October 19—Carthage falls to the Vandals.

title: China
event: Northern China is unified by the Northern Wei.

title: Iran
event: The Hepthalites move south from the Altay Mountains region into Transoxiana, Bactria, Khurasan and eastern Persia.

title: Niš
event: Attila destroys Naissus.

title: Ireland
event: The Irish city of Armagh is founded by St. Patrick.

title: Ireland
event: Ireland: The Diocese of Armagh is created.

title: Thermopylae
event: Battle of the Utus: Attila the Hun meets the Romans in an indecisive battle. The Huns invade the Balkans as far as Thermopylae. Serdica (Sofia) was destroyed during their invasion.

title: Kent
event: The first English kingdom in Britain is created when Vortigern grants Thanet in Kent to the Saxon leader Hengist.

title: Constantinople
event: Eutyches is accused of heresy at a council held in Constantinople.

title: Great Britain
event: Vortigern forms an alliance with Hengest and Horsa, by tradition chieftains of the Jutes, who led the Anglo-Saxon invasion of Britain (traditional date).

title: Second Council of Ephesus
event: August 3—The Second Council of Ephesus opens, chaired by Dioscorus, Patriarch of Alexandria. Flavian, Patriarch of Constantinople, and Domnus II, Patriarch of Antioch, are deposed on August 8.

title: Great Britain
event: Angles, Saxons and Jutes invade Britain (traditional date), marking the beginning of the usage period of Old English.

title: Italy
event: Dome of Baptistry of Neon, Ravenna, Italy, is started to be remodeled (approximate date).

title: Italy
event: Attila, king of the Huns, invades Italy.

title: Emona
event: The city of Emona is destroyed by the Huns, led by Attila, and deserted by most of its inhabitants.

title: China
event: Tai Wu Di is succeeded by Nan An Wang, then by Wen Cheng Di as ruler of the Northern Wei Dynasty in China.

title: Ireland
event: Ireland: The Diocese of Clogher is erected.

title: Chichen Itza
event: Earliest recorded date at Chichen Itza.

title: Corsica
event: Ricimer beats the Vandals in a sea battle near Corsica.

title: Ireland
event: St. Patrick returns to Ireland as a missionary Bishop.

title: India
event: The Hepthalites conquer the Kushans and enter India.

title: Italy
event: The remodeling of the dome of Baptistry of Neon, Ravenna, Italy, is finished.

title: Shanxi
event: Seated Buddha, Cave 20, Yungang, Datong, Shanxi, is made. Northern Wei dynasty (approximate date).

title: Constantinople
event: The Statue of Zeus, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, is destroyed by fire after being moved to Constantinople.

title: China
event: The ''Daming'' calendar is introduced in China by mathematician Zu Chongzhi (425–500).

title: Constantinople
event: Olybrius becomes a consul in Constantinople.

title: China
event: Song Qian Fei Di, then Song Ming Di become ruler of the Song Dynasty in China.

title: China
event: Xiao Wen Di succeeds Xian Wen Di as ruler of the Chinese Northern Wei Dynasty.

title: India
event: A statue of a ''Standing Buddha'' from Sarnath, Uttar Pradesh, India (of the Gupta period) is made. Gupta period. It is now kept at the Sarnath Museum, Sarnath.

title: Constantinople
event: 9 January—Byzantine Emperor Zeno is forced to flee from Constantinople.

title: China
event: Bodhidharma travels to China (approximate date).

title: Goguryeo
event: Gongju becomes the capital of Baekje, after Baekje loses the Han River valley to Goguryeo.

title: India
event: A ''Bodhisattva'' (detail of a wall painting in Cave I in Ajanta, Maharashtra, India) of the Gupta period is made (approximate date).

title: China
event: Emperor Xianwen, Retired Emperor of the Chinese/Xianbei Northern Wei dynasty, is murdered by Empress Feng, who then assumes regency over young Emperor Xiaowen

title: China
event: Song Shun Di succeeds Song Hou Fei Di as ruler of the Chinese Liu Song Dynasty.

title: Sacred Mountains of China
event: Shaolin Temple founded (according to the ''Continued Biographies of Eminent Monks'' (AD 645) by Dàoxuān, the Shaolin Monastery was built on the north side of Shaoshi, the western peak of Mount Song, one of the four Sacred Mountains of China, by Emperor Xiaowen of the Northern Wei Dynasty in AD 477. Yang Xuanzhi, in the ''Record of the Buddhist Monasteries of Luoyang'' (AD 547), and Li Xian, in the ''Ming Yitongzh''i (AD 1461), concur with Daoxuan's location and attribution. For alternate founding date, see AD 497).

title: Dunhuang
event: This year is the earliest date for the oldest known painted depiction of a horse collar, on a cave mural of Dunhuang, China, Northern Wei Dynasty.

title: China
event: The Song Dynasty ends in China.

title: China
event: Chinese chronicles record a memorial sent by the King of Japan (possibly Emperor Yūryaku), who describes himself as Supreme Director of Military Affairs in Japan and Korea to the Court of the Northern Wei Dynasty. The Chinese Emperor responds by confirming the Japanese dynasty in those titles. This is the earliest verifiable date in Japanese history.

title: China
event: The Song Dynasty ends and the Southern Qi Dynasty begins in southern China. Qi Gao Di is the first ruler of the Qi Dynasty.

title: Italy
event: Odoacer defeats an attempt by Julius Nepos to recapture Italy, and has Julius killed.

title: Ireland
event: Ireland: The Diocese of Connor is erected.

title: Goguryeo
event: Baekje, Silla, and Daegaya form an alliance against Goguryeo.

title: China
event: Qi Gao Di becomes ruler of the Chinese Southern Qi Dynasty.

title: Iran
event: The Hephthalites invade Persia, and Peroz I is killed in battle; Balash becomes king of Persia.

title: Italy
event: Theodoric, king of the Ostrogoths, continues his invasion of Italy with the approval of Byzantine emperor Zeno.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: Flavius Zeno (emperor) closes the Nestorian academy in Edessa.

title: Qufu
event: The first Confucian Temple is constructed in north China (outside the ancestral temple at Qufu).

title: Italy
event: August 28—Theodoric defeats Odoacer at the Battle of Isonzo, forcing his way into Italy.

title: Anderitum
event: Aelle of Sussex besieges and conquers the fortified town of Anderitum in southern Britain.

title: Isaurian War
event: Isaurian War: beginning of the revolt of the Isaurians against Anastasius I in Isauria.

title: Isaurian War
event: Isaurian War: the Roman general Diogenianus besieges Claudiopolis, but his army is blocked by the Isaurians. In his help comes John ''Gibbo'', who wins an overwhelming victory against the Isaurians.

title: Latakia
event: An earthquake devastates Latakia.

title: Datong
event: Under Emperor Xiaowen the capital of Northern Wei, a state in China, is moved from Datong to Luoyang.

title: Shaolin Monastery
event: Emperor Xiaowen of the Northern Wei Dynasty builds the Shaolin temple for the monk Batuo.

title: Battle of Tolbiac
event: Battle of Tolbiac: Clovis I defeats the Alamanni, and is baptized into the  Catholic faith at Rheims.

title: China
event: The ruling Tuoba family in the Chinese Northern Wei Dynasty change their family name to Yuan.

title: Isaurian War
event: Isaurian War: the Isaurian rebels are defeated.

title: India
event: Aryabhata, an Indian astronomer and mathematician, calculates pi (π) as ≈ 62832/20000 = 3.1416, correct to four rounded-off decimal places.

title: Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore
event: Antipope Laurentius is elected pope in Santa Maria Maggiore.

title: Lateran Palace
event: November 22—Pope Symmachus succeeds Pope Anastasius II as the 51st pope, in the official papal selection in the Lateran Palace.

title: Ale's Stones
event: The monument of Ale's Stones is built in Sweden (approximate date).

title: Uxmal
event: Uxmal is founded (approximate date).

title: Palenque
event: Ahkal Mo' Naab' I comes to power in the Maya city of Palenque.

title: Iran
event: War breaks out between the Byzantine Empire and Persia.

title: China
