event: The Southern Qi Dynasty ends and the Liang Dynasty begins in southern China. Liang Wu Di succeeds Qi He Di.

title: Iran
event: The Persian philosopher Mazdak declares private property to be the source of all evil.

title: Basilica of Sant'Apollinare Nuovo
event: Theodoric the Great builds Basilica of Sant'Apollinare Nuovo, originally dedicated to Christ the Redeemer.

title: Dara (Mesopotamia)
event: The city of Dara in Mesopotamia is fortified by emperor Anastasius I as a frontier against Persia.

title: China
event: The town of Guilin, China, is renamed Guizhou.

title: Buddhas of Bamyan
event: The first and smaller of the two Buddhas of Bamyan is erected in central Afghanistan.Cohen, Roger. Return to Bamiyan, ''The New York Times'', October 29, 2007. Accessed October 29, 2007.<

title: Lutetia
event: Clovis I establishes Paris (''Lutetia'') as his capital. He also makes Roman Catholicism the official religion of the Frankish Kingdom.

title: Antioch
event: Riots erupt in Antioch between supporters of Patriarch Flavian II and emperor Anastasius I.

title: First Council of Orléans
event: King Clovis I of the Franks convenes the First Council of Orléans.

title: Korea
event: The island nation of Usan-guk is conquered by the Korean Silla Dynasty general Lee Sabu.

title: Ireland
event: In Ireland, the Diocese of Kildare is erected.

title: Mausoleum of Theodoric
event: Ostrogothic ruler Theodoric the Great builds the Mausoleum of Theodoric as his future tomb in Ravenna.

title: East Anglia
event: The kingdom of East Anglia is formed (approximate date).

title: China
event: Bodhidharma arrives in China.

title: Italy
event: The construction of Basilica of San Vitale, Ravenna, Italy, is started (approximate date).

title: Brittany
event: Samson of Dol is ordained as a bishop in Brittany.

title: Yemen
event: Yusuf dhu-Nuwas captures power in Yemen.

title: China
event: Completion of the Songyue Pagoda tower in China during the Northern Wei era; the circular-based tower is still 40 m (131 ft) in height.

title: Palenque
event: December 1 – Ahkal Mo' Naab' I, ruler of the Maya city of Palenque, dies. The city enters a interregnum which lasts a little over four years.

title: Anazarbus
event: Byzantine emperor Justin I rebuilds Anazarbus and renames it Justinopolis.

title: Yemen
event: Caleb of Abyssinia conquers Yemen.

title: Shroud of Turin
event: The Daisan river, a tributary of the Euphrates, floods Edessa, and within a couple of hours fills the entire city, except for the highest parts. Eventually the pent-up waters break through the city walls. The Shroud of Turin is allegedly discovered during the rebuilding of the city (see Image of Edessa).

title: Italy
event: c. 526–547 – Sanctuary apse's mosaic showing Christ enthroned and flanked by Saint Vitalis and Bishop Ecclesius, Basilica of San Vitale, Ravenna, Italy, is made.

title: Antioch
event: Late May (probably between the 20th and the 29th)—An earthquake kills approximately 250,000 in Syria and Antioch.

title: London
event: The Kingdom of Essex is founded when the Saxons land north of the Thames and take control of the land between what is now London and St Albans. This is the last Saxon group to form a settlement here (approximate date).

title: Antioch
event: Natural disaster: An earthquake strikes Antioch, killing thousands, and causing a fire that destroys the Great Church built by Constantine I.

title: India
event: Yasodharman of Malwa defeats the Hun invaders in India.

title: Korea
event: Bulguksa, a Buddhist temple, is built in Korea.

title: Church of the Nativity
event: The Samaritans revolt and are defeated; the Church of the Nativity is burnt down during the revolt.

title: Italy
event: Saint Benedict of Nursia founds the monastery of Monte Cassino in Italy.

title: Palenque
event: February 25—K'an Joy Chitam I comes to power in the Maya city of Palenque, ending a interregnum of a little over four years.

title: Mount Brandon
event: St. Brendan climbs to the top of Mount Brandon, to look for The Americas.

title: Israel Museum
event: Mosaic synagogue floor, from Maon (Menois) is made. It is now kept at the Israel Museum, Jerusalem (approximate date).

title: India
event: Vishnu Temple at Deogarh, Uttar Pradesh, India, is built. Post-Gupta period (approximate date).

title: Constantinople
event: Some members of the Blue and Green chariot racing factions in Constantinople are imprisoned for murder, precipitating the Nika riots the next year.

title: Hippodrome of Constantinople
event: January 11—Nika riots in Constantinople: The cathedral is destroyed. They are put down a week later by Belisarius and Mundus; up to 30,000 people are killed in the Hippodrome.

title: Hagia Sophia
event: February 23—Justinian I orders the building of a new cathedral in Constantinople — the Hagia Sophia.

title: Constantinople
event: June 21—Belisarius sails from Constantinople to attack the Vandals in North Africa.

title: Carthage
event: September 13—Battle of Ad Decimum: Belisarius defeats the Vandals under Gelimer. Gelimer, forced to flee, leaves Carthage unprotected.

title: Italy
event: Justinian I orders Belisarius to start the reconquest of Italy; Mundus simultaneously invades Dalmatia.

title: Krakatoa
event: Reports of the eruption of Krakatoa, which possibly lead to several years of climate change (see Climate changes of 535–536), are recorded in the Javanese ''Book of Kings''.

title: Italy
event: April—Belisarius, a general in the service of Justinian I, lands in Italy

title: Constantinople
event: December 27—The construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople is completed.

title: Antioch
event: The Persians led by Khosrau I sack the city of Antioch.

title: Antioch
event: November 29—Antioch is struck by an earthquake.

title: Antioch
event: The Sassanids attack Dara and capture Antioch.

title: Greece
event: The Huns and Bulgars raid Greece.

title: Great Britain
event: High King Custennin ap Cado of Britain is deposed and returns to Dumnonia.

title: Italy
event: The former Roman senator Cassiodorus establishes a monastery, the Vivarium, on his estate in Italy. He enlists highly educated and sophisticated men to copy both sacred and secular manuscripts, intending this to be their sole occupation (approximate date).

title: Constantinople
event: The plague appears suddenly in the Egyptian port of Pelusium, spreading the following year to Constantinople as the Justinianic plague. This was the beginning of a 200-year long pandemic that would devastate Europe, the Middle East, and northern Africa.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: Jacob Baradaeus becomes bishop of Edessa.

title: Constantinople
event: January 1—Anicius Faustus Albinus Basilius is appointed as consul in Constantinople, the last person to hold this office.

title: Hagia Sophia
event: An outbreak of the plague kills at least 230,000 in Constantinople (before they stopped counting) and perhaps two million or more in the rest of the Empire. This was the Justinianic plague. Emperor Justinian, the renewer of the greatness of Rome's empire and patron of the world's greatest religious building, the Hagia Sophia, contracted the disease and recovered.

title: Italy
event: Ostrogoth king Totila reconquers Naples, Benevento, and other parts of Italy.

title: Constantinople
event: Pope Vigilius is ordered to Constantinople.

title: Dara (Mesopotamia)
event: Khosrau I of Persia unsuccessfully attacks the Byzantine fortress of Dara.

title: Clonmacnoise
event: The monastery of Clonmacnoise is built on the River Shannon.

title: Constantinople
event: Pope Vigilius arrives in Constantinople to meet with Justinian I; future pope Pelagius is sent by Totila to negotiate with Justinian.

title: Italy
event: c. 546–548 – Mosaics of Basilica of San Vitale, Ravenna, Italy, are made (approximate date)

title: Saint Catherine's Monastery Mount Sinai
event: c. 549–564—Transfiguration of Christ, mosaic in the apse, Church of the Virgin, Saint Catherine's Monastery, Mount Sinai, Egypt, is made.

title: Ireland
event: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Ossory (which still exists) is founded in Ireland.

title: Basilica of Sant'Apollinare in Classe
event: Archbishop Maximianus of Ravenna consecrates the Basilica of Sant'Apollinare in Classe.

title: China
event: Emperor Jinwen succeeds Emperor Wu as ruler of the Liang Dynasty in China.

title: Constantinople
event: Silk-producing technology reaches Constantinople (approximate date).

title: China
event: The Eastern Wei Dynasty ends and the Northern Qi Dynasty begins in northern China. Wen Xuan Di is the first ruler of the Northern Qi Dynasty.

title: Constantinople
event: Two Christian missionaries smuggle a few silkworm larvae to Constantinople from China (approximate date).

title: Quiriguá
event: Construction of Quiriguá (in modern Guatemala) begins (approximate date).

title: Ireland
event: In Ireland, the Diocese of Tuam is erected.

title: Beirut
event: Beirut is destroyed by an earthquake and tsunami.

title: China
event: Liang Yu Zhang Wang succeeds Liang Jian Wen Di as ruler of the Chinese Liang Dynasty.

title: Old Sarum
event: Cynric, king of Wessex, captures the fort at Old Sarum.

title: Ireland
event: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Meath is established in Ireland.

title: Goguryeo
event: King Seong of Baekje attacks Goguryeo and Silla.

title: Jiangling County
event: Jiangling is captured; 100,000 inhabitants are enslaved and distributed to generals and officials.

title: Buddhas of Bamyan
event: The second and larger of the two Buddhas of Bamyan is erected in central Afghanistan.Cohen, Roger. Return to Bamiyan, ''The New York Times'', October 29, 2007. Accessed October 29, 2007.<

title: Latakia
event: An earthquake devastates Latakia.

title: China
event: The Northern Zhou Dynasty begins in northern China; its first ruler is Northern Zhou Xiao Min Di.

title: Hagia Sophia
event: May 7—In Constantinople, the dome of the Hagia Sophia collapses. Justinian I orders the dome rebuilt.

title: Constantinople
event: The Kutrigurs and Huns under Zabergan invade and raid Byzantine territory, but are driven back near Constantinople by Belisarius.

title: Kent
event: Æthelbert succeeds his father Eormenric as king of Kent (traditional date).

title: Constantinople
event: Belisarius stands trial for corruption in Constantinople, possibly with Procopius acting as urban prefect.

title: Tikal
event: The Maya state of Caracol defeats Tikal in battle.

title: Hagia Sophia
event: Justinian I re-consecrates Hagia Sophia after its dome is rebuilt.

title: Iona
event: Saint Columba, the Irish missionary, founds his mission to the Picts and his monastery on Iona.

title: Loch Ness
event: August 22—St. Columba reports seeing a monster in Loch Ness, Scotland.

title: Italy
event: Invasion by the Lombards of northern Italy under Alboin.

title: Constantinople
event: Estimation: Ctesiphon, capital of the Sassanid Empire, becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Constantinople, capital of the Byzantine Empire.

title: Kaaba
event: Abraha failed attack on the Kaaba in Mecca.

title: Iran
event: The Byzantine Empire begins a war with Persia.

title: Battle of Arfderydd
event: The Battle of Arfderydd is fought between Gwenddoleu ap Ceidio and the sons of Eliffer, Gwrgi and Peredur. The forces of Gwenddolau are killed, and Myrddin Wyllt goes mad watching this defeat.

title: Dara (Mesopotamia)
event: Dara is captured by Khosrau I of Persia.

title: Battle of Deorham
event: Battle of Deorham: The Anglo-Saxons under Ceawlin of Wessex defeat the British Celts.

title: Reccopolis
event: Reccopolis founded by king Liuvigild.

title: Greece
event: The Slavs begin to migrate into the Balkans and Greece.

title: China
event: The Northern Qi Dynasty ends in China.

title: Kent
event: Ethelbert becomes king of Kent.

title: Constantinople
event: The Roman Senate sends an embassy to Constantinople; this is its last recorded act.

title: China
event: The Sui Dynasty replaces the Northern Zhou Dynasty, the last of the Northern Dynasties in China. First ruler of the Sui Dynasty is Sui Wen Di.

title: China
event: The Great City of Helu is renamed Suzhou under the Sui dynasty in China.

title: Sirmium
event: The avars take over the city of Sirmium.

title: Constantinople
event: April—Fire devastates Constantinople.

title: Constantinople
event: May—An earthquake strikes Constantinople.

title: Constantinople
event: The Eurasian Avars, a mounted people who have swept across Russia and southeastern Europe, seize Byzantine forts along the Danube and reach the walls of Constantinople.

title: Palenque
event: Yohl Iknal succeeds K'an B'alam as queen of the Mayan city of Palenque (in present-day Chiapas).

title: Monte Cassino
event: The Lombards sack Monte Cassino.

title: Constantinople
event: The Avars sack Singidunum and Slavs raid near Constantinople.

title: Mercia
event: Creoda becomes king of Mercia.

title: China
event: In China, Emperor Xiaojing succeeds Emperor Xiaoming as ruler of the Nan Liang Dynasty.

title: Daraa
event: The Byzantines defeat the Persians at Battle of Solachon, near Daraa.

title: Thessaloniki
event: The Avars besiege Thessaloniki, failing to take it.

title: Northumbria
event: Æthelric becomes first King of Northumbria, after the kingdom is formed from the union of the two small Anglian kingdoms of Bernicia and Deira.

title: Nepal
event: Shivadeva ascends the throne of the Lichchhavi dynasty in Nepal.

title: China
event: A large meteorite impact kills 10 people in rural China.

title: Ireland
event: The Skellig Michael monastery is founded on a steep rocky island off the coast of Ireland.

title: Nanjing
event: China: The Chen Dynasty ends; Jiankang (Nanjing), the last of the Southern dynasties, is completely destroyed; China is reunited under the Sui Dynasty.

title: Ctesiphon
event: February 20—Bahram Chobin and Khosrau confront each other near Ctesiphon.

title: Italy
event: A locust swarm destroys the harvest in Italy.

title: Chinkultic
event: 21 May—A Mesoamerican ballgame court is dedicated at the Mayan city of Chinkultic.

title: Singidunum
event: The Byzantine Empire regains Singidunum from the Avars.

title: Mercia
event: Pybba becomes king of Mercia.

title: Wallachia
event: The Byzantine commander-in-chief Priscus defeats the Slavs, Avars and Gepids on Roman territory south of the Danube, before he crosses the Danube into modern-day Wallachia to continue his series of victories.

title: Iran
event: The Persian usurper Hormizd V is defeated by Khosrau II.

title: Museum of Fine Arts Boston
event: Altar to Amitabha Buddha is made. Sui dynasty. It is now kept at Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

title: Italy
event: The Lombards sack Terracina in Italy.

title: China
event: Construction begins on Zhaozhou Bridge in Hebei Province, China.

title: Kent
event: Augustine of Canterbury is sent on a mission to Kent by Pope Gregory I.

title: Canterbury
event: The King's School is founded in Canterbury.

title: China
event: The Chinese win the war at Ordos.

title: Iran
event: Yemen is finally conquered by Sassanian Iran (approximate date).

title: Palenque
event: The Maya city of Palenque is defeated by Kalakmul.

title: Estonia
event: King Ingvar of Sweden invades Estonia but is killed by the locals.

title: Joya de Cerén
event: Loma Caldera in El Salvador erupts, burying the Maya village of Joya de Cerén.

title: North America
event: The Hopewell tradition of North America ceases to be the dominant culture.

title: Mount Sinai
event: Construction on the monastery of St. Catherine is begun on Mount Sinai.

title: Ireland
event: Irish missionaries preach in Scotland and Germany.

title: China
event: Chinese-influenced sculptures of Buddha begin to be created in Japan.

title: Sumatra
event: Sumatra, Java, and the surrounding islands are converted to Buddhism.

title: Chalcedon
event: Maurice, at war with the Avars and always dealing with the lack of money, decrees that the army should stay for winter beyond the Danube, which proves to be a serious mistake. The exhausted troops mutiny against the Emperor. Maurice and his family flee to Chalcedon, and Phocas is proclaimed emperor. Maurice and his sons are executed.

title: Constantinople
event: The future Pope Boniface III is appointed papal legate to Constantinople.

title: Dara (Mesopotamia)
event: The Sassanids destroy the Byzantine fortress of Dara.

title: Chang'an
event: Emperor Yang Guang of the Sui Dynasty orders the capital to be transferred from Chang'an to Luoyang, and orders the Grand Canal to be built.

title: Trajan's Bridge
event: The Chinese Zhaozhou Bridge is completed under the Sui Dynasty, the earliest known fully stone open-spandrel segmental arch bridge in the world. Although the earlier Roman era Trajan's Bridge featured segmental arches, they were built of wood on top of stone piers.

title: Palenque
event: Aj Ne' Yohl Mat becomes ruler of Palenque.

title: Mercia
event: Cearl becomes king of Mercia.

title: Bengal
event: Shashanka is the first recorded independent king of Bengal (approximate date).

title: Pantheon Rome
event: The Pantheon in Rome is converted into a church.

title: Ikaruga Nara
event: Construction begins on the Hōryū-ji Buddhist temple in Ikaruga, near Nara.

title: Chalcedon
event: Khosrau II of Persia attacks Chalcedon.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: Edessa is taken by the Sassanids.

title: China
event: The tax census of the Sui Dynasty government in China records roughly 9 million registered households in the empire, a population size of roughly 50 million people.

title: Pantheon Rome
event: The Pantheon is consecrated to the Virgin Mary and all saints by Pope Boniface IV (or 610).

title: Italy
event: The Avars try to invade Italy.

title: Constantinople
event: October 4—Heraclius arrives by ship from Africa at Constantinople, overthrows East Roman Emperor Phocas and becomes Emperor. His first major act is to change the official language of the East Roman Empire from Latin to Greek (already the language of the vast majority of the population).  Because of this, after AD 610 the East Roman Empire is customarily referred to as the Byzantine Empire (the term Byzantine is a modern term invented by historians in the 18th century; the people of the Empire itself always referred to themselves as Ρωμιούς – in English, Romious).

title: Goguryeo
event: Battle of Salsu River: A Sui force attacks Goguryeo with a much larger force of over 300,000, but is thwarted by General Ulji Moonduk and only 2,700 Sui troops survive.

title: Palenque
event: Sak K'uk' succeeds Aj Ne' Yohl Mat as ruler of Palenque.

title: Italy
event: Saint Columbanus moves to Italy to establish the monastery of Bobbio (approximate date).

title: Constantinople
event: The Holy Sponge is brought to Constantinople from Palestine.

title: Damascus
event: Shahrbaraz of Persia captures Damascus.

title: Chenla
event: Isanapura becomes the capital of the Cambodian kingdom of Chenla.

title: Devon
event: Cynegils of Wessex invades Dumnonia (now known as Devon).

title: Church of the Holy Sepulchre
event: The Persian Empire under general Shahrbaraz captures and sacks Jerusalem; the Church of the Holy Sepulchre is damaged by fire and the True Cross is captured.

title: East Anglia
event: Edwin of Northumbria takes refuge in East Anglia; he marries Cwenburga, daughter of Cearl of Mercia.

title: China
event: The Turks invade China.

title: Palenque
event: Sak K'uk' is succeeded by Pacal the Great as ruler of Palenque.

title: River Idle
event: Aethelfrith meets Rædwald and the army of East Anglia in the Battle of the River Idle, and is slain by Raedwald, which establishes his claim as Bretwalda.

title: Northumbria
event: Edwin becomes king of Northumbria.

title: Iona
event: Oswald of Northumbria flees to Iona.

title: Battle of Chester
event: The Battle of Chester (Old Welsh: '''Guaith Caer Legion'''; Welsh: '''Brwydr Caer''') which separated the (West) Welsh from the 'North' Welsh of Cumbria - marking the formation of Wales.

title: Alexandria
event: Alexandria is captured by Khosrau II of Persia.

title: Sardis
event: Persians destroy the Asia Minor city of Sardis, including its synagogue.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: A shrine on the site of the future Westminster Abbey is founded.

title: Kent
event: Heathens revolt in Kent under king Eadbald. Justus, Bishop of Rochester, flees to Gaul.

title: China
event: Sui Gong Di succeeds Sui Yang Di as emperor of China.

title: Chalcedon
event: The Persian Army, under the command of General Spahbodh Shaahin, conquers Chalcedon after a long siege.

title: China
event: The Sui Dynasty ends and the Tang Dynasty begins in China. The first emperor of the Tang Dynasty is Tang Gao Zu.

title: Constantinople
event: The Avars attack Constantinople.

title: Thessaloniki
event: The Slavs attack Thessaloniki.

title: Lower Austria
event: Samo, reputedly a Frankish merchant, is elected King of the Slavs in Moravia, Slovakia and Lower Austria.

title: Battle of Badr
event: March 17—The Battle of Badr is fought.

title: Battle of Uhud
event: March 23—Battle of Uhud (Muhammad retreats against the inhabitants of Mecca), which they consider a victory.

title: Constantinople
event: 7 August—The Byzantines defeat the Avars and Slavs, who were besieging Constantinople for the first time.

title: Mercia
event: Penda becomes king of Mercia (traditional date).

title: Chang'an
event: July 2—In the early morning, Li Shimin, the future Emperor Tang Taizong of China, eliminates two of his brothers, Li Yuanji and the crown prince Li Jiancheng, in a coup d'état at the Xuanwu Gate in Chang'an.

title: Derbent
event: Third Perso-Turkic War: Tong Yabghu of the Western Gokturks storms and sacks the Caspian Gates at Derbent.

title: Tbilisi
event: January—Third Perso-Turkic War: Emperor Heraclius ravages the environs of Ctesiphon; Tong Yabghu of the Western Gokturks storms and sacks Tbilisi.

title: Jordan River
event: The Battle of Mu'tah, the first Muslim expedition outside Arabia, fails to take the lands east of the Jordan River.

title: Dos Pilas
event: The Maya military outpost of Dos Pilas is founded.

title: India
event: The Chinese Buddhist monk Xuan Zang reaches India.

title: Korea
event: Queen Seondeok is crowned in Korea.

title: Battle of Hatfield Chase
event: Battle of Hatfield Chase: Penda of Mercia and Cadwallon ap Cadfan of Gwynedd defeat and kill Edwin of Northumbria.

title: Iraq
event: Arab armies invade Syria and Iraq.

title: Northumbria
event: Oswald of Northumbria defeats Cadwallon ap Cadfan of Gwynedd in the Battle of Heavenfield and reunites Northumbria.

title: China
event: The Xianbei/Tibetan state of Tuyuhun is invaded by Tang Dynasty China during Emperor Taizong's campaign against Tuyuhun, led by commander Li Jing, resulting in the assassination of their leader (Busabuo Khan Murong Fuyun) in 635 and the dissolving of their state in 672.

title: Northumbria
event: Saint Aidan founds Lindisfarne in Northumbria, England.

title: China
event: Nestorian Christianity reaches China.

title: Iraq
event: The city of Basra, Iraq is founded on a canal by Caliph Omar.

title: China
event: The Xumi Pagoda of Zhengding, China, is built during the reign of Emperor Taizong of Tang.

title: China
event: The historical texts of the ''Book of Northern Qi'', ''Book of Chen'', and ''Book of Sui'' are compiled in China during the Tang Dynasty.

title: Battle of al-Qādisiyyah
event: November 16–November 19—Battle of al-Qādisiyyah: Muslim Arab victory against the Sassanid army.

title: Ctesiphon
event: Following the victory in the Battle of al-Qādisiyyah, the Rashidun Caliphate takes the Persian capital of Ctesiphon.

title: Ctesiphon
event: Chang'an, capital of China, becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Ctesiphon, capital of the Sassanid Empire.

title: Hafar Al-Batin
event: Abu-Musa al-Asha'ari establishes Hafar Al-Batin City while digging out new wells.

title: Susa
event: During the Islamic conquest of Persia, the city of Susa is destroyed.

title: Goguryeo
event: The Xueyantuo assaults the Chinese-conquered vassal of Eastern Tujue. Although simultaneously fighting in Korea against Goguryeo, the Chinese Tang Dynasty nonetheless initiates Emperor Taizong's campaign against Xueyantuo, where the famous general Li Shiji is deployed to fend off attacks in Tujue. By 646 the Xueyantuo state is destroyed.

title: France
event: The French city of Lille is founded by Lyderic.

title: Gaochang
event: Emperor Taizong's campaign against Xiyu states, or the Western Regions in the Tarim Basin, commences in this year, as the Tang Dynasty Chinese commander Hou Junji captures Gaochang to solidify Chinese rule in Central Asia.

title: Caesarea Maritima
event: Caesarea surrenders to the Arabs.

title: Cairo
event: The city of Fostat (later Cairo) is founded in Egypt.

title: Alexandria
event: November 8—Alexandria is formally surrendered to Amr ibn al-As by a treaty.

title: Alexandria
event: Arabs conquer Alexandria.

title: Goguryeo
event: Yeon Gaesomun seizes power over the Goguryeo kingdom and places King Bojang on the throne.

title: China
event: Emperor Taizong of Tang issues a decree throughout China that increases the punishment for men who deliberately inflict injuries upon themselves (most commonly breaking their own legs) in order to avoid military conscription. This decree is an effort to eradicate this practice that has grown as a trend since the time of the rebellion against the Sui Dynasty.

title: Winchester Cathedral
event: A monastic settlement is founded in Hampshire, England, which later becomes Winchester Cathedral.

title: Mercia
event: August 5—In the Battle of Maserfield, Penda, king of Mercia defeats and kills Oswald, king of Bernicia.

title: Tripoli
event: Arab armies win their first North African victory in Tripoli.

title: China
event: Pirooz, the son of the last Sassanid king of Persia, flees to Tang Dynasty China.

title: Chang'an
event: When the Chinese prefectural government officials travel to the Tang Dynasty's capital of Chang'an in this year to give the annual report of the affairs in their districts, Emperor Taizong of Tang discovers that many have no proper quarters to rest in, and are renting rooms with merchants. Therefore, Emperor Taizong orders the government agencies in charge of municipal construction to build every visiting official his own private mansion in the capital.

title: China
event: The Tang dynasty of China begins the invasion of Goguryo.

title: Goguryeo
event: Goguryeo general Yang Man-chun resists the Emperor Taizong of Tang.

title: Shanxi
event: Great Wild Goose Pagoda at Ci'en Temple, Xi'an, Shanxi, is first erected. Tang dynasty.

title: Alexandria
event: Alexandria is recaptured by the Arabs after a Byzantine attempt to retake Egypt fails, ending nearly 10 centuries of Greaco-Roman civilization in Egypt.

title: Korea
event: A stone tower astronomical observatory named Cheomseongdae is constructed in Silla (southern Korea) around this time.

title: China
event: The ''Book of Jin'' is compiled in China during the Tang Dynasty. Its chief editor is the Chancellor Fang Xuanling, who dies in this year as well.

title: Caucasus
event: Khazars defeat Abd ar-Rahman ibn Rabiah of Rashidun Arabs in Caucasus

title: Sichuan
event: The first Chinese paper money is issued, yet these banknotes will not become government-issued until the Song Dynasty era Sichuan province issues them in the year 1024, with the central government of China following suit in the 12th century.

title: Sumatra
event: The Hindu Empire comes to power in Sumatra.

title: Canterbury
event: St. Martin's Church is built in Canterbury, England.

title: India
event: First surgical developments in India, with bladder, peristalsis and plastic operations.

title: Merv
event: Yazdegerd III of Persia is killed in Merv by his followers, ending both Persian resistance to Arab conquest, and the Sassanid dynasty.

title: Xi'an
event: Construction of the Giant Wild Goose Pagoda in Chang'an (modern Xi'an), Tang Dynasty China, is completed in this year during the reign of Emperor Gaozong of Tang.

title: Asuka Yamato
event: Naka no Ōe no Ōji changes his residence to Asuka with Empress Hashibito and other Imperial family members and ministers. Only the Emperor stays in the Naniwa Palace.

title: Colossus of Rhodes
event: Rhodes is invaded by an Arab force; remains of the Colossus of Rhodes are sold off.

title: Constantinople
event: September 17—Martin I arrives in Constantinople, where he is eventually deposed as pope by the emperor Constans II.

title: Mercia
event: November 15—Northumbrian king Oswiu defeats Mercian king Penda in the Battle of Winwaed.

title: Mercia
event: Oswiu of Northumbria annexes Mercia.

title: Iraq
event: The Battle of Bassorah (also known as Battle of the Camel) between Ali and Aisha, part of the first civil war in Islam, takes place in modern-day Basra, Iraq.

title: Asuka Yamato
event: Empress Saimei of Japan builds a new palace at Asuka, because her former residences took fire. This canal is called the Mad Canal by the people of that day, wasting the labor of tens of thousand workers and a large amount of money.

title: Chang'an
event: When a Chinese prince (later to be Emperor Zhongzong of Tang) is made crown prince, his lavish palatial mansion in Chang'an is converted into a Daoist abbey.

title: Yorkshire
event: Saint Hilda founds an abbey on the Yorkshire coast at Whitby.

title: Great Britain
event: Cadwaladr launches the last Welsh offensive against the Saxons in Britain.

title: Northumbria
event: Ealdormen in Mercia rebel against Northumbrian rule and proclaim Wulfhere king.

title: Asuka Yamato
event: Naka no Ōe no Ōji of Japan for the first time makes a clepsydra at Asuka, by which he causes the people to know the hours.

title: Italy
event: Byzantine Emperor Constans II invades south Italy.

title: Great Britain
event: A brief outbreak of plague hits Britain.

title: Northumbria
event: September—The Synod of Whitby is held in Northumbria.

title: Seongnam
event: The city of Seongnam is renamed Hansanju.

title: Barking Abbey
event: Barking Abbey is founded.

title: China
event: Chinese Buddhist monks Zhi Yu and Zhi You craft more South Pointing Chariot vehicles for Emperor Tenji of Japan, as recorded in the ''Nihon Shoki'' (the South Pointing Chariot is a non-magnetic, mechanical-driven directional-compass vehicle that incorporates the use of a differential gear).

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: The Daysan River floods Edessa in Asia.

title: Korea
event: The ancient Korean kingdom of Goguryeo, in southern Manchuria and northern Korea, is overthrown by the alliance of Tang China and Silla. Unified Silla period starts.

title: Kairouan
event: The city of Kairouan is founded in what is now Tunisia.

title: Korea
event: A Goguryeo restoration movement, led by Geom Mojam in northern Korea, places Anseung on the throne.

title: Hōryū-ji
event: Hōryū-ji, the Buddhist temple in Japan, burns down; its reconstruction is immediately begun.

title: Diocese of Winchester
event: The diocese of Dorchester-on-Thames in England is replaced by the Diocese of Winchester.

title: China
event: Chinese Buddhist pilgrim I-Ching visits the capital of the partly Buddhist kingdom of Srivijaya, Palembang, Indonesia, and stays for 6 months to study Sanskrit grammar. He reports over 1,000 buddhist monks in residence.

title: Kent
event: Hlothhere becomes king of Kent.

title: Anapji
event: In Korea, Anapji was constructed by order of King Munmu.

title: Monkwearmouth-Jarrow Abbey
event: Monkwearmouth monastery founded by Benedict Biscop in the Kingdom of Northumbria.

title: Constantinople
event: The first Arab siege of Constantinople begins.

title: Mercia
event: Æthelred succeeds his brother Wulfhere as king of Mercia.

title: Surrey
event: Frithuwold of Surrey is baptised and so is his son; Surrey becomes Christian.

title: Bath Abbey
event: The abbeys of Abingdon, England and Bath are founded.

title: Malmesbury Abbey
event: Aldhelm is made abbot of Malmesbury Abbey.

title: Kent
event: Æthelred invades Kent.

title: Iona
event: Adamnan becomes abbot of the monastery on Iona.

title: Asuka Yamato
event: In Japan, Empress-consort Uno Sarara is unwell and her husband begins the erection of the Temple of Yakushiji in Asuka, Yamato, and makes 100 persons enter religion as priests, wishing her recovering her health.

title: Constantinople
event: November 12—The Sixth Ecumenical Council opens in Constantinople and ends September 16, 681.

title: Northumbria
event: Wilfrid of York is expelled from Northumbria by Ecgfrith, and retires into Sussex.

title: Constantinople
event: September 16—The Sixth Ecumenical Council (opened on November 12, 680 in Constantinople) concludes.

title: Chang'an
event: Due to a culmination of major droughts, floods, locust plagues, and epidemics, a widespread famine breaks out in the dual Chinese capital cities of Chang'an (primary capital) and Luoyang (secondary capital). The scarcity of food drives the price of grain to unprecedented heights, ending a once prosperous era under emperors Taizong and Gaozong on a sad note.

title: Palenque
event: The reign of Pacal the Great, ruler of Maya state of Palenque, comes to an end.

title: Palenque
event: 10 January—K'inich Kan B'alam II accedes to the rulership of the Maya polity of Palenque.

title: Surrey
event: Surrey takes Wessex as its overlord.

title: Northumbria
event: Plague kills almost all the monks in a Northumbrian monastery, aside from the abbot and one small boy – future scholar Bede.

title: Northumbria
event: May 20—Battle of Dunnichen ''or'' Nechtansmere: Picts defeat Northumbrians.

title: Isle of Wight
event: Caedwalla exterminates the Jutes of the Isle of Wight and kills King Arwald.

title: France
event: King Theuderic III of Neustria is defeated by Pepin of Herstal, Mayor of the Palace of Austrasia, at the Battle of Tertry near Péronne in modern France. Austrasia and Neustria are combined again; Pepin becomes ''de facto'' ruler of both areas.

title: Ireland
event: Adamnan visits the Northumbrian court of Ecgfrith to ransom Irish captives.

title: Dome of the Rock
event: Construction of the Dome of the Rock is started in Jerusalem.

title: Rhine
event: Battle of Dorestad: The Frisians of king Radbod are defeated by the Frankish mayor of the palace, Pippin of Herstal. The Rhine delta becomes Frankish.

title: China
event: Beginning of Wu Zetian's Zhou Dynasty in China. She was China's first and only female emperor, ruling on her own accord.

title: Dome of the Rock
event: Building of the Dome of the Rock

title: Dome of the Rock
event: The building of the Dome of the Rock is completed in Jerusalem.

title: Kent
event: Ine of Wessex makes peace with Kent.

title: Fujiwara-kyō
event: Japan's capital is moved from Asuka to Fujiwara-kyō.

title: Ireland
event: Approximate date of the Council of Birr, where the northern part of Ireland accepts the Roman calculations for celebrating Easter. At this synod, Adamnan promulgates his ''Cáin Adomáin'' (Law of the Innocents).

title: Constantinople
event: Spring–summer—Arabs under Hassan ibn al-Nu'man capture Carthage from the Byzantine Empire, and destroy it completely. The defeated Byzantine fleet revolts and proclaims Tiberius III, who deposes Leontius after a brief siege of Constantinople and becomes Byzantine Emperor.Stanford, CA  isbn = 0-8047-2630-2  url = http://books.google.com/books?id=nYbnr5XVbzUC  pages=337–339}}<

title: Antioch
event: Autumn–winter—The Byzantine general Heraclius, brother of Tiberius III, launches a campaign into Syria, defeats an army from Antioch and raids as far as Samosata.Stanford, CA  isbn = 0-8047-2630-2  url = http://books.google.com/books?id=nYbnr5XVbzUC  page=339}}<

title: Saikū
event: Princess Taki is sent to the Saikū as a Saiō of the Ise Shrine, Japan.

title: British Columbia
event: The Mount Edziza volcanic complex erupts in northern British Columbia, Canada.

title: Basra
event: Iraq: January – The rebel Umayyad general Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn al-Ash'ath takes Basra, but is subsequently defeated by Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf and his rebellion fails.

title: Fortress Marienberg
event: Franconian Duke Hetan II completes the circular Marienkirche in Fortress Marienberg near Würzburg.

title: Jeddah
event: Ethiopian (Axumite) raiders occupy the port of Jeddah in modern-day Saudi Arabia.

title: Damascus
event: The Umayyad Mosque at Damascus is completed.

title: Bardney
event: Britain: Cenred succeeds to the throne of Mercia, after his uncle Æthelred abdicates to become abbot of Bardney.

title: Valens Aqueduct
event: Byzantine Empire: August – Justinian II and his ally, the Bulgar khan Tervel, by-pass the Byzantine forces under Heraclius awaiting them and reach Constantinople. After three days, Justinian's men enter through the disused Valens Aqueduct. Tiberius III flees the city to his brother's army in Thrace, but when the soldiers begin to desert, he surrenders. Tervel is rewarded by Justinian for his assistance with rich gifts and the title of ''Caesar''.Stanford, CA  isbn = 0-8047-2630-2  url = http://books.google.com/books?id=nYbnr5XVbzUC  page=340}}<

title: Umayyad Mosque
event: Work begins on the Grand Mosque of Damascus.

title: China
event: February 20 – China: In a coup d'état, Chinese Chancellor Zhang Jianzhi executes the Zhang brothers and restores Emperor Zhongzong. This marks the end of the short-lived Zhou Dynasty in China.

title: Hippodrome of Constantinople
event: 15 February—The restored Byzantine emperor Justinian II presides over the public humiliation of his predecessors Leontius and Tiberius III and their chief associates in the Hippodrome of Constantinople, after which they are executed. Patriarch Callinicus I is also deposed, blinded and exiled, and succeeded by Cyrus.

title: Damascus
event: Umayyad Caliph al-Walid I begins the Great Mosque of Damascus.

title: Qianling Mausoleum
event: July 2—Emperor Zhongzong of Tang had the remains of his mother and recently deceased ruling empress Wu Zetian, her son Li Xian, her grandson Li Chongrun, and granddaughter Li Xianhui all interred in at the same tomb complex as his father and Wu Zetian's husband Emperor Gaozong (d. 683) outside Chang'an known as the Qianling Mausoleum, located on Mount Liang.

title: Damascus
event: The first bimaristan (Islamic hospital) is founded in Damascus.

title: Tyana
event: A large Umayyad army under Maslamah ibn Abd al-Malik invades Asia Minor and lays siege to Tyana. The city resists, dragging the siege through the winter and into 708.Stanford, CA  isbn = 0-8047-2630-2  url = http://books.google.com/books?id=nYbnr5XVbzUC  page=341}}<

title: Amorium
event: Byzantine Empire: March—The Umayyads under Maslamah ibn Abd al-Malik capture and sack the Byzantine city of Tyana after a prolonged siege, and following a victory over a Byzantine relief army. Maslamah also leads another expedition in the summer, and defeats a Byzantine force near Amorium.Stanford, CA  isbn = 0-8047-2630-2  url = http://books.google.com/books?id=nYbnr5XVbzUC  page=341}}<

title: Battle of Anchialus (708)
event: Bulgaria: The Byzantine emperor Justinian II is defeated by a Bulgar army at the Battle of Anchialus.

title: Mercia
event: Ceolred becomes king of Mercia, after his cousin Cenred abdicates to become a monk in Rome.

title: Herm
event: A storm separates the Channel Islands of Jethou and Herm.

title: Italy
event: Byzantine emperor Justinian II sends a fleet to Italy under the ''patrikios'' Theodore, to intervene in the dispute between Pope Constantine and the archbishop Felix of Ravenna, who claimed to be independent of the pope's authority. Theodore arrests Felix and other Italian leaders and deports them to Constantinople, from where they were exiled to Cherson.Stanford, CA  isbn = 0-8047-2630-2  url = http://books.google.com/books?id=nYbnr5XVbzUC  page=938}}<

title: Chang'an
event: April 5—During the Cold Food Festival, Chinese Emperor Zhongzong of Tang has his chief ministers of court, sons-in-law, and high ranking military officers engage in the festive game of tug of war within a palace of Chang'an City. The Emperor purportedly laughs when two older ministers fall over during the game.

title: India
event: After pirates plunder an Arab ship near the mouth of the Indus River, Arabs led by Muhammad bin Qasim invade India with 6,000 horses, establishing a sultanate in Sind.

title: Al-Andalus
event: April 30—Ummayad troops led by Tariq ibn Ziyad land at Gibraltar, and begin their invasion of the Iberian peninsula and conquest of the Visigothic Kingdom (See Moors, Al-Andalus, and Umayyad conquest of Hispania).

title: China
event: Emperor Xuanzong of Tang China succeeds Emperor Ruizong of Tang China as emperor of China. The plot of Princess Taiping's coup fails.

title: China
event: Construction begins on the Leshan Giant Buddha near Leshan, Sichuan province, China. Upon its completion in 803, it will become the largest stone carved Buddha in the world.

title: Chang'an
event: Emperor Xuanzong of Tang starts to rule in Ancient China. He liquidates the highly lucrative Inexhaustible Treasury, which is run by a prominent Buddhist monastery in Chang'an. This monastery collects vast amounts of money, silk, and treasures through multitudes of rich people's repentances, left on the premises anonymously. Although the monastery is generous in donations, Emperor Xuanzong issues a decree abolishing their treasury on the grounds that their banking practices were fraudulent, collects their riches, and distributes the wealth to various other Buddhist monasteries, Daoist abbeys, and to repair statues, halls, and bridges in the city.

title: Chang'an
event: Emperor Xuanzong of Tang forbids all commercial vendors and shops in the Chinese capital city of Chang'an to copy and sell Buddhist sutras, so that the emperor can give the clergy of the Buddhist monasteries the sole right to distribute written sutras to the laity.

title: Umayyad Mosque
event: The Grand Mosque of Damascus is built over the Cathedral of St. John the Baptist.

title: River Garnock
event: Saint Winnin, an Irish monk, lands at the mouth of the River Garnock, where he establishes a community or cell of monks, termed cella or Kil in Gaelic.

title: Lisbon
event: The Ummayads conquer Lisbon.

title: Mercia
event: Æthelbald returns from exile to succeed Ceolred as king of Mercia.

title: Iona
event: April 19—The monastery on the Island of Iona celebrates Easter on the Roman date.

title: Hoshi Ryokan
event: Hoshi Ryokan, world's longest running business, formed in Japan.

title: Iona
event: King Nechtan IV of the Picts expels the monks from the Scottish island of Iona.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: December 24—An earthquake shakes many places in northern Syria, and destroys the Old Church of Edessa.

title: Constantinople
event: Emperor Leo III and Khan Tervel defeat Arab forces besieging Constantinople, stopping a large Arab incursion towards Europe.

title: Ishikawa Prefecture
event: The world's oldest hotel, Hoshi Ryokan, is founded in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan.

title: Vlie
event: Charles Martel defeats king Radbod of the Frisians. Frisia to the banks of the river Vlie become  part of the Frankish Empire.

title: Chang'an
event: July 30—In the Tang Dynasty Chinese capital of Chang'an, the walls of a gated city ward collapse during the night, which unexpectedly form a large pool out in the open. This is most likely caused by a sinkhole created when ground water eroded the limestone bedrock beneath. As a consequence of this, more than 500 homes are destroyed (Benn, 50).

title: Al-Andalus
event: Anbasa ibn Suhaim Al Kalbi is appointed governor of Al-Andalus.

title: Palenque
event: 3 January—K'inich Ahkal Mo' Naab III takes the throne of the Maya state of Palenque.

title: Hill of Allen
event: The Battle of Allen was fought in close proximity to the Hill of Allen, between the Laigin, led by Murchad mac Brain Mut, and the forces of Fergal mac Máele Dúin.

title: China
event: The world's first mechanical clock is allegedly built in China (See celestial globe).

title: Quiriguá
event: K'ak' Tiliw Chan Yopaat becomes king of the Maya city of Quiriguá.

title: China
event: In China, the Tang Dynasty Buddhist monk, astronomer, and mechanical engineer Yi Xing applies a clockwork escapement mechanism to provide rotating motion to his astronomical armillary sphere.

title: Jerash
event: Seismic activity in the Mediterranean: The volcanic island of Thera erupts, while the city of Jerash (in present-day Jordan) suffers a major earthquake.

title: Mercia
event: King Æthelbald becomes King of Mercia.

title: Rhine
event: Charles Martel defeats the last independent dukedom of the Alamanni, and launches raids on the Saxons beyond the Rhine.

title: Chang'an
event: Chinese Emperor Xuanzong of Tang has four palace walls in the northeast sector of the capital city Chang'an torn down and reassembled to construct a new Daoist abbey, the grounds of which were formerly a large garden for the governmental Bureau of Agriculture.

title: France
event: October 10—Battle of Tours: Near Poitiers, France, leader of the Franks  Charles Martel and his men, defeat a large army of Moors under the governor of Cordoba, Abdul Rahman Al Ghafiqi, who is killed during the battle.  The Battle of Tours halts the advance of Islam into Western Europe and establishes a balance of power between Western Europe, Islam and the Byzantine Empire.

title: Khöshöö Tsaidam Monuments
event: Khöshöö Tsaidam Monuments of Bilge Khan of Turkish Khanate his brother Kül Tigin. (Bilge's has already erected Kül Tigin's monument and Bilge's son erects Bilge's monument.) In 2004 the monuments are included in List of World Heritage Sites in Asia and Australasia.

title: Tōdai-ji
event: The scholar-priest Rōben invites Shinshō to give lectures on the ''Avatamsaka Sutra'' at Kinshōsen-ji (later Tōdai-ji); this event is considered to be the roots of the Kegon school of Buddhism founded in Japan.

title: Hallertau
event: The first instance is documented of hop cultivation in the Hallertau region of present-day Germany (which is today the most important production centre with about 25% of the worldwide production).{{Factdate=February 2007}}

title: Calakmul
event: Yik'in Chan K'awiil, ruler of the leading Maya city state of Tikal, conquers rival power Calakmul.

title: Kingdom of Asturias
event: Favila becomes king of Asturias after Pelayo's death.

title: Denmark
event: The Danevirke fortification system is started in Denmark.

title: Quiriguá
event: The powerful Mayan city-state Xukpi (Copán) is defeated by a rival city-state, Quiriguá. Xukpi leader Uaxaclajuun Ub'aah K'awiil (Eighteen Rabbit) is deposed thereafter.

title: France
event: Charles Martel drives the Moors out of France.

title: Kingdom of Asturias
event: Alfonso I becomes king of Asturias.

title: Anatolia
event: Battle of Akroinon in Anatolia, a significant Byzantine victory over the Umayyads, halts the impetus of Arab attacks into Anatolia.

title: Chang'an
event: Much to the delight of the citizens of Chang'an City, the Chinese Tang Dynasty government orders fruit trees to be planted along every main avenue of the city, which enriches not only the diets of the people but also the surroundings.

title: Black Sea
event: The Khazars, a nation of the Black Sea steppe, though not ethnically Jewish, voluntarily convert to Judaism.

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: September—The Daysan River floods Edessa.

title: Constantinople
event: October 26—An earthquake strikes Constantinople and the surrounding countryside, causing destruction to the city's land walls and buildings, and many deaths.

title: York Minster
event: The York Minster Church is burned.

title: Einsiedeln Abbey
event: A nunnery given by the Alamannic noblewoman Beata on Lützelau island is first mentioned. In 744, the nunnery was sold to Einsiedeln Abbey.

title: Ufenau
event: Ufenau island in Switzerland is first mentioned in 741 as «Hupinauia», and in 744 as «Ubinauvia».

title: Chang'an
event: For the municipal census of the Chinese capital city Chang'an and its metropolitan area of Jingzhou Fu (including small towns in the vicinity), the New Book of Tang records that in this year there are 362,921 registered families with 1,960,188 persons.

title: Einsiedeln Abbey
event: A nunnery given by the Alamannic noblewoman Beata on Lützelau island is first mentioned in 741. In 744, the nunnery was sold to Einsiedeln Abbey.

title: Ufenau
event: Ufenau island in Switzerland is first mentioned in 741 as «Hupinauia», and in 744 as «Ubinauvia»

title: Constantinople
event: Bubonic plague in Constantinople subsequently sweeps through Europe.

title: India
event: Jayshikhari Chavda establishes the Chavda Dynasty in Gujarat, India.

title: China
event: Emperor Xuanzong of Tang China abolishes the death penalty.

title: Shin-Yakushi-ji
event: The ''Shin-Yakushi-ji'' Buddhist temple is founded.

title: Constantinople
event: The plague breaks out in Constantinople.

title: China
event: The first printed newspaper appears in Beijing, China.

title: Baghdad
event: After the defeat of his army in the Battle of the Zab the last Umayyad Caliph, Marwan II, is overthrown and killed. Al-Saffah is proclaimed the first Abbasid Caliph. The capital of the Caliphate will later moved from Damascus to Baghdad, within the territory of the former Persian Empire; this transfer will prove to be a momentous event for Baghdad, which develops into a centre of international trade and culture.

title: Ghana Empire
event: The Ghana Empire begins.

title: Teotihuacan
event: Teotihuacan in Mexico is destroyed.

title: Gansu
event: The Western Paradise of Amitabha Buddha, detail of a wall painting in Cave 217, Dunhuang, Gansu, is made. Tang dynasty (approximate date).

title: Romagna
event: The Lombard king Aistulf captures Ravenna and the Romagna, ending the Byzantine Exarchate of Ravenna.

title: Samarkand
event: Arabian armies defeat Chinese Tang troops in the Battle of Talas near Samarkand.

title: Gyeongju
event: Silla minister Gim Daeseong orders construction to begin on the Bulguksa and Seokguram temples at Gyeongju.

title: Yaxchilan
event: Yaxun B'alam IV becomes king of Yaxchilan after a ten year struggle for the throne.

title: Tōdai-ji
event: Retired Emperor Shōmu takes part in the dedication ceremony of the great statue of Vairocana Buddha at the Tōdai-ji, and declares himself a Buddhist.

title: Samarkand
event: Samarkand is conquered by Arabs.

title: Canterbury
event: Fire breaks out in Canterbury.

title: Italy
event: Pepin the Short sends his armies into Italy to aid the pope against the Lombards.

title: Mercia
event: Offa deposes king Bernred of Mercia and takes the kingdom.

title: China
event: 16 December – An Lushan begins the Anshi Rebellion against the Tang Dynasty state of China.

title: Papal States
event: Pepin the Short defeats the Lombards of northern Italy, who have threatened Pope Stephen II.  The Donation of Pepin is a cession of lands including Ravenna that will become the basis of the Papal States.

title: Chang'an
event: The army of An Lushan captures Chang'an in rebellion against the Tang Dynasty.

title: Sichuan
event: Emperor Suzong of Tang China ascends to the throne, after his father Emperor Xuanzong abdicates while fleeing to Sichuan during the An Lushan rebellion.

title: Offa's Dyke
event: Offa becomes king of Mercia (to 796).  He is noted for Offa's Dyke, built as a defence against Welsh marauders.

title: Iran
event: During the turmoil of the An Shi Rebellion, the Chinese seaport Guangzhou is sacked by Arab and Persian raiders. The port is shut down for the next five decades while foreign vessels dock at Hanoi instead, yet Guangzhou thrives again once it is reopened to foreign trade in the early 9th century.

title: Chang'an
event: June 11—Abbasid Arabs and Uyghur Turks arrive simultaneously at Chang'an, the Tang Chinese capital, in order to offer tribute to the imperial court. The Arabs and Turks bicker and fight over diplomatic prominence at the gate, in order to present tribute before the other. A settlement was reached when both were allowed to enter at the same time, but through two different gates to the palace.

title: France
event: The Franks capture Narbonne; the Saracens are completely driven out of France.

title: Battle of the Rishki Pass
event: Battle of the Rishki Pass: Byzantine Emperor Constantine V invades Bulgaria again, but this time his army is ambushed in the mountain passes of the Stara Planina.

title: Tōshōdai-ji
event: The Tōshōdai-ji Buddhist Temple is founded in Nara, Japan.

title: Dos Pilas
event: The Maya city of Dos Pilas is abandoned.

title: China
event: In China, Emperor Xuanzong is placed under house arrest by Li Fuguo with the support of Emperor Suzong.

title: Kailash Temple
event: The Kailash Temple is built on the orders of Krishna I of the Rashtrakutas.

title: Castello di Lunghezza
event: Construction is completed on the 108-room Castello di Lunghezza outside of Rome, Italy.

title: Iraq
event: July 30—Abbasid caliph al-Mansur founds a new capital at Baghdad, Iraq.

title: Chang'an
event: November 18—Tibetan forces occupy the Chinese capital Chang'an of the Tang Dynasty for 16 days.

title: Chang'an
event: Near the end of the An Shi rebellion, Tibetan troops occupy Chang'an, the capital of the Chinese Tang Dynasty, for fifteen days.

title: Constantinople
event: According to the historian Theophanes, the Black Sea melts and ice bergs float past Constantinople.

title: Kent
event: Offa of Mercia conquers Kent, and installs Egbert II on the Kentish throne.

title: Aral
event: Karluks, defeat Turgesh. Most of Turkestan (former Onak territory) under Karluk rule except west of Lake Aral where a loose confederation named Oguz is about to emerge.

title: Deventer
event: Deventer (in the present day Netherlands) is founded (approximate date).

title: Kingdom of Asturias
event: Aurelio succeeds Fruela I as king of Asturias.

title: China
event: Beginning of the Eastern Zhou Dynasty in China under King Ping of Zhou.

title: Hedeby
event: Hedeby is founded.

title: Baghdad
event: The concept of the number zero is introduced to the city of Baghdad.

title: Kingdom of Asturias
event: Silo succeeds Aurelio as king of Asturias.

title: China
event: Estimation: Baghdad, capital of the Abbasid Empire, becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Chang'an, capital of China.

title: Bengal
event: Dharampala begins his reign of Bengal.

title: Kent
event: The Battle of Otford is fought between Mercia and Kent.

title: Denmark
event: Charlemagne defeats the Saxons; their leader Widukind flees to Denmark.

title: Denmark
event: Widukind returns to Saxony from Denmark.

title: Battle of Roncevaux Pass
event: August 15—Battle of Roncevaux Pass (Roncesvalles): Charlemagne's army suffers a terrible defeat at the hand of the Basques.  Among those killed is Roland, lord of the Breton March; the 11th-century ''Song of Roland'' is loosely based on the events of this battle.

title: Offa's Dyke
event: Offa's Dyke is constructed.

title: China
event: Tang Dezong becomes emperor of China.

title: Papal States
event: Charlemagne defines the Papal territory (see Papal States).

title: Constantinople
event: Defection of the Byzantine general Tatzates allows Harun al-Rashid to advance to within sight of Constantinople and impose a harsh truce on Empress Irene of Athens.

title: Shanxi
event: Nanchan Temple, Wutaishan, Shanxi, is built. Tang dynasty.

title: Greece
event: Campaigns of the Byzantine general Staurakios against the ''Sclaviniae'' of Greece.

title: Constantinople
event: A council is organized in Constantinople, but is disturbed by soldiers.

title: Baghdad
event: September 14—Harun al-Rashid becomes the Abbasid Caliph in Baghdad upon the death of his brother al-Hadi, and appoints Salim Yunisi as the Abbasid governor of Sindh and the Indus Valley. Harun al-Rashid rules until 809.

title: Kingdom of Asturias
event: Bermudo I succeeds Mauregato as king of Asturias.

title: Kingdom of Asturias
event: Alfonso II becomes king of Asturias.

title: Northumbria
event: June 8—Vikings sack the monastery of Lindisfarne, Northumbria, their first major viking attack in England.

title: Monkwearmouth-Jarrow Abbey
event: Vikings sack the Monkwearmouth-Jarrow Abbey.

title: Iona
event: In the earliest recorded Viking raid on Ireland, they attack Iona, Inisbofin and Inismurray.

title: Mercia
event: December—Coenwulf becomes king of Mercia.

title: Tō-ji
event: Tō-ji is established in Kyoto, Japan.

title: Kent
event: Coenwulf of Mercia invades Kent, deposes and imprisons King Eadbert Praen, and makes his own brother Cuthred king.

title: Al-Andalus
event: Bahlul Ibn Marzuq revolted in Zaragoza against the central government of Muslim Al-Andalus.

title: Iona
event: The Vikings sack Iona.

title: Angkor
event: Jayavarman II declares the Khmer Empire independent and establishes the kingdom of Angkor.

title: Korea
event: The Haeinsa Temple is established in Korea.

title: China
event: 804–805—Priest Saicho, patriarch of Tendai Buddhism, visits China and reportedly brings back tea seeds.

title: China
event: Tang Shunzong succeeds Tang Dezong as emperor of China, but does not last till the end of the year.

title: Yamanashi Prefecture
event: Hōzen-ji is founded in Wakakusa, Nakakoma District, Japan (now Minami-Alps, Yamanashi Prefecture).

title: Italy
event: The Saracens sack Nola, Italy.

title: United Kingdom
event: Vikings kill all the inhabitants on the religious island of Iona, Scotland, UK.

title: Kent
event: After the death of Cuthred, king Coenwulf of Mercia takes control over Kent himself.

title: Cornwall
event: The Christianized Vikings (Danes) land on the Cornish coast, and form an alliance with the Cornish to fight against the 'heathen' West Saxons.

title: China
event: Li Ji Pu  becomes Prime Minister to Emperor Xian Zong in China.

title: Qazvin
event: The Jame' Atiq Mosque of Qazvin is constructed in Qazvin by the orders of Harun al-Rashid.

title: Samarra
event: The Abbasid capital is moved north from Baghdad to Samarra.

title: India
event: Nagabhatta is defeated in India.

title: Denmark
event: Forces from today's Denmark attack today's Vestfold due to insubordination.

title: Constantinople
event: The Bulgarians lay siege before Constantinople.

title: Constantinople
event: Bulgaria and the Byzantine Empire sign the Treaty of 815 in Constantinople.

title: Cornwall
event: Egbert of Wessex ravages the territories of the west Welsh (Cornwall).

title: Constantinople
event: The Bulgarian siege of Constantinople ends.

title: Samarra
event: The Abbasid capital is moved back to Baghdad (it was moved from Baghdad to Samarra in 808).

title: Brittany
event: Nominoe becomes earl of Vannes, Brittany.

title: Baghdad
event: Tahir, the son of a slave, is rewarded with the governorship of Khurasan for supporting the caliphate. He rules independently of Baghdad, not even mentioning the caliph's name in Friday prayers in recognition of caliphal authority.

title: Munster
event: Fedelmid mac Crimthainn assumes the kingship of Munster.

title: China
event: Tang Mu Zong becomes emperor of China.

title: Crete
event: Crete is conquered from the Byzantines by the Saracens.

title: Battle of Roncevaux Pass
event: Third Battle of Roncevaux Pass: The Basques and Banu Qasi defeat counts Eblo and Aznar, Frankish vassals.

title: East Anglia
event: Egbert of Wessex defeats Beornwulf of Mercia at Ellandun. Kent, Surrey, Sussex and Essex submit to Wessex and East Anglia acknowledges Egbert as overlord.

title: Copán
event: The royal ceremonial centre at Copán is abandoned.

title: Alexandria
event: Relics of Saint Mark are brought to Venice from Alexandria.

title: Chang'an
event: In the Tang Dynasty Chinese capital of Chang'an, a powerful court eunuch orders 50 wrestlers to arrest 300 commoners over a land property dispute in Northwest Chang'an, whereupon a riot breaks out in the streets between the grapplers and the citizens.

title: Mercia
event: Egbert of Wessex conquers Mercia and is recognized as Bretwalda.

title: China
event: The Bai kingdom of Nanzhao captures the city of Chengdu in Sichuan province, China.

title: Birka
event: Christian missionary Ansgar visits Birka, trade city of the Swedes

title: China
event: In this year, an Uyghur Turk sues the son of a Chinese Tang Dynasty grand general who had failed to repay a debt of 11 million government-issued copper coins. Emperor Wenzong of Tang soon hears the news, and is so upset that he not only banishes the general, but attempts to ban all trade between Chinese and foreigners except for goods and livestock. This ban is unsuccessful, and trade with foreigners resumes, especially in maritime affairs overseas.

title: Birka
event: Saint Ansgar founds the first church in Sweden, at Birka.

title: Ireland
event: Clondalkin, Ireland is sacked by Vikings.

title: St Mark's Basilica
event: The second St Mark's Basilica in Venice (replacing an older church at a different location) is built.

title: Dorestad
event: The Vikings first raid Dorestad (present-day Netherlands).

title: Switzerland
event: Jona River in Switzerland was first mentioned

title: Dorestad
event: The Vikings raid Dorestad.

title: Chang'an
event: December 14—Ganlu Incident: In the northeast sector of the Chinese capital Chang'an, after a failure by the chancellor Li Xun to slaughter the powerful eunuchs, troops under the eunuchs' command slaughter many court officials and Li Xun's associates.

title: Iraq
event: Abbasid caliph al-Mutasim establishes a new capital at Samarra, Iraq.

title: Kairouan
event: The construction of Mosque of Uqba, Kairouan, Tunisia, begins.

title: Italy
event: Saracens from Egypt attack the Italian city of Naples.

title: Constantinople
event: Vikings from Scandinavia attack Constantinople.

title: Hingston Down
event: At Hingston Down, Egbert of Wessex beats the Danish and the West Welsh.

title: Scone Palace
event: The Stone of Destiny is placed at Scone Palace, Scotland.

title: Ireland
event: According to the ''Annals of Inisfallen'', a royal meeting between Feidlimid mac Cremthanin, King of Cashel and Niall, King of the Southern Uí Neill and Tara at Cluain-Conaire-Tommain, results in Feidlimid becoming High-King of Ireland.

title: Amorium
event: The Byzantine emperor Theophilos is heavily defeated at the Battle of Anzen by the Abbasids. Caliph al-Mu'tasim then proceeds to capture and raze Amorium, the native city of the Byzantine Empire's reigning Amorian dynasty.

title: China
event: Tang Wu Zong succeeds Tang Wen Zong as emperor of China.

title: County Kildare
event: Battle of Magh-Ochtar (Kildare, Ireland): Feidlimid mac Cremthanin is defeated by the Southern Uí Neill.

title: Chang'an
event: In the Chinese capital of Chang'an, the West Market and East Market are closed every night 1 hour and three quarters before dusk (by government-ordered curfew), yet night markets thrive in residential areas. The local government attempt to shut the night markets down in this year, but with the decline of the government's authority by the mid 9th century, this edict (like many others) is largely ignored as urban dwellers keep attending the night markets regardless.

title: Kingdom of Asturias
event: Ramiro I succeeds Alfonso II as king of Asturias.

title: Chang'an
event: In the Tang Dynasty Chinese capital of Chang'an, a large fire consumes 4,000 homes, warehouses, and other buildings in the East Market, yet the rest of the city is at a safe distance from the blaze (which is largely quarantined in East Central Chang'an thanks to the large width of roads in Chang'an that produce fire breaks).

title: Dorestad
event: Dorestad is raided by the Vikings.

title: Brittany
event: Nominoe occupies Nantes and Rennes, he makes raids in Anjou and threatens Bayeux. Charles the Bald recognizes him as Duke of Brittany after being defeated three times.

title: China
event: Xuanzong II succeeds Wuzong as emperor of China.

title: Brittany
event: According to the Annales Bertiniani, Nominoe, king of Brittany, makes war on the Vikings.

title: Ireland
event: Máel Sechnaill mac Maíl Ruanaid, King of Mide, defeats a Norse army at Sciath Nechtain, in Ireland.

title: Chang'an
event: In the Tang Dynasty Chinese capital city of Chang'an, an imperial prince was impeached from his position by officials at court for erecting a building that obstructed a street in the northwesternmost ward in South Central Chang'an.

title: Deventer
event: Vikings of Rorik conquer Utrecht and keep the city for 70 years. The bishop of Utrecht takes refuge in Deventer.

title: Canterbury
event: Vikings plunder London and Canterbury.

title: Battle of Jengland
event: 22 August—Battle of Jengland. Erispoe, king of Brittany and son of Nominoe, defeats the Franc king Charles the Bald in Jengland-Beslé near Grand-Fougeray in Brittany. This is considered as the birth of the Breton state.

title: Brittany
event: September—Treaty of Angers. Charles the Bald acknowledges Erispoë as king of Brittany. He lets him have the County of Nantes, the County of Rennes and the County of Retz which become part of the Breton nation. The King of Brittany takes the oath to the King of France (but not an ''hommage lige'' which would be an allegiance). To mark the sovereignty of the Breton state, the Dukes of Brittany are since then crowned as Duke, king in their lands.Annales Bertiniani<

title: Andaman Islands
event: Oldest known mention of the Andaman Islands.

title: Guangzhou
event: The Arab merchant Suleiman al-Tajir visits Tang Dynasty China, observing the manufacturing of Chinese porcelain at Guangzhou and writes of his admiration for its transparent quality. He also describes the mosque at Guangzhou, its granaries, its local government administration, some of its written records, and the treatment of travellers, along with the use of ceramics, rice-wine, and tea.

title: Damietta
event: A Byzantine fleet destroys Damietta, Egypt.

title: China
event: Tuan Ch'eng-Shih publishes ''Miscellaneous Offerings from Yu-yang'' in China.

title: Denmark
event: Horik II succeeds Horik I as king of Denmark.

title: Iran
event: December 22—Another deadly earthquake strikes Damghan, Iran, killing 200,000 people.

title: Dorestad
event: The Vikings raid Dorestad.

title: Aquitaine
event: Louis the German invades West Francia, hoping to secure Aquitaine from his brother Charles the Bald, but fails.

title: North China Plain
event: An enormous flood along the Grand Canal of China inundates large tracts of the North China Plain, killing tens of thousands of people and adding to the further decline of the Tang Dynasty.

title: Kairouan
event: Lusterware tiles, decorated the mihrab of the Mosque of Uqba at Kairouan, are made (approximate date).

title: Alexandria
event: Michael I succeeds Sophronius I as Patriarch of Alexandria.

title: Devín Castle
event: First written reference to Devín Castle, when Louis the German besieges Great Moravian prince Rastislav there.

title: Constantinople
event: A Russian expedition for the first time threatens Constantinople.

title: Kingdom of Asturias
event: Alfonso III succeeds as king of Asturias.

title: Italy
event: Louis II beats the Saracen invaders in Italy.

title: Malta
event: The Aghlabid dynasty of Tunisia takes Malta.

title: Portugal
event: The First County of Portugal is established by Vímara Peres, after the reconquest from the Moors of the region north of the Douro River.

title: Tikal
event: Stela 11, the last monument ever erected at Tikal, was dedicated by Jasaw Chan K'awiil II.

title: Hagia Sophia
event: Repairs are made in Hagia Sophia.

title: Prague Castle
event: Prague Castle is founded.

title: Peterborough
event: The Great Summer Army invades England led by Bagsecg and conquers East Anglia; the buildings destroyed by the Danish invaders include the abbey of Ely and the monastery of Peterborough.

title: Malta
event: Malta is conquered by Arabs from Sicily.

title: Berkshire
event: December 31—The Danes are defeated by a Saxon army at Englefield, Berkshire. It is the first of a series of battles between Wessex and the Danes.

title: Nordic countries
event: Tønsberg, the oldest surviving town in the Nordic countries, is founded.

title: Hafrsfjord
event: Battle of Hafrsfjord: Harald Fairhair becomes the first king of Norway.

title: Gascony
event: Gascony becomes an independent kingdom, with Sancho I Mitarra as its first king.

title: Dorestad
event: The Vikings raid Dorestad.

title: China
event: A widespread failure of the agricultural harvest in Tang Dynasty China leads to a widespread famine; in the previous century the central government was able to curb famine with large grain stores, but this time the central government is already in decline and too weak to properly face the disaster.

title: Reykjavík
event: Ingólfur Arnarson arrives as the first permanent Viking settler in Iceland, settling in Reykjavík (probable date).

title: Mercia
event: The Danes invade Mercia.

title: China
event: The rebellion of Huang Chao in China begins, weakening the strength of the already declining Tang Dynasty.

title: Constantinople
event: March 13—The bones of Saint Nicephorus are interred in the Church of the Apostles, Constantinople.

title: Cambridge
event: The Danes capture Lindisfarne and arrive in Cambridge.

title: Shetland
event: Harald Fairhair subdues the rovers on Orkney and Shetland and adds them to his kingdom.

title: Kairouan
event: The construction of Mosque of Uqba, Kairouan, Tunisia, is ended.

title: Swanage
event: A flotilla of 120 Danish ships is lost in a storm off Swanage.

title: Danelaw
event: Between May 6 and 12 May—Battle of Ethandun (probably either at Edington, Somerset, or Edington, Wiltshire): Alfred the Great of Wessex defeats the Danes of the Danelaw under Guthrum.

title: Ifriqiya
event: May 21—After a siege of eight months, Syracuse is captured by the Aghlabids of Ifriqiya.

title: Guangzhou
event: The Chinese rebel Huang Chao besieges the southern Chinese seaport at Guangzhou and slaughters much of its inhabitants of native Chinese and foreigners from around the world. His rebellion is suppressed by 884.

title: Constantinople
event: A synod convened at Constantinople (often considered by Eastern churches as the Fourth Council of Constantinople) reinstates Patriarch Photius I of Constantinople.

title: Schnütgen Museum
event: St. Cecilia, Cäcilienstraße, Cologne is founded as a college for women. It is now kept at the Schnütgen Museum.

title: Mercia
event: Anarawd ap Rhodri defeats the Mercians in a battle described as God's vengeance for Rhodri, who had been killed in battle a few years earlier.

title: Monte Cassino
event: Monte Cassino is sacked and burned down by the Saracens.

title: Denmark
event: Frodo becomes King of Denmark.

title: Lobith
event: Godfrith, the Sea King is killed in Lobith. The Vikings lose control of most of the modern Netherlands.

title: Azerbaijan
event: Oldest known mention of Baky, Azerbaijan.

title: Constantinople
event: The Glagolitic alphabet, devised by Cyril and Methodius, missionaries from Constantinople, is  adopted in the Bulgarian Empire.

title: London Bridge
event: Alfred the Great captures London and renames it Lundenburgh. Slightly upstream from London Bridge he builds a small harbour called Queenhythe. Control of London is given to Earl Aethelred who marries Alfred's daughter Ethelfleda.

title: Ohrid Literary School
event: Khan Boris I of Bulgaria establishes the Preslav and Ohrid Literary Schools.

title: Anjou
event: Odo, Count of Paris becomes Count of Anjou on the death of Hugh the Abbot.

title: France
event: Odo, Count of Paris ascends to the throne of Western Francia (modern France).

title: Korea
event: Bongwon Temple is founded in present-day Korea.

title: Forlì
event: In Italy, Forlì becomes a republic for the first time.

title: Kirby Muxloe
event: Kirby Muxloe is founded (approximate date).

title: Gwangju
event: The former Silla general Gyeonhwon attacks the city of Gwangju and declares himself king.

title: Northumbria
event: Northumbrians and East Angles swear allegiance to Alfred the Great, but promptly break their truce by attacking the south-west of England.

title: Italy
event: The Eastern Franks invade and conquer Italy under the leadership of Arnulf of Carinthia.

title: London
event: Alfred the Great restores the city walls of London.

title: Yemen
event: Yahya al-Hadi ila'l Haqq founds the rule of Zaidi Shiite Imams in Yemen, which will endure until the second half of the 20th century.

title: Italy
event: Bologna joins the Italian Kingdom.

title: Nepal
event: Bhaktapur is founded in Nepal.

title: Korea
event: Gyeonhwon formally establishes the kingdom of Hubaekje in southwestern Korea.

title: Shetland
event: Harald Fairhair (of the Yngling or Scilfing Dynasty) subdues the petty kings of Norway and conquers the Orkney and Shetland Islands.

title: New Mexico
event: c. 900–1230—Pueblo Bonito, Chaco Canyon, New Mexico, is built. Anasazi culture.

title: Philippines
event: April 21—Namwaran and his children, Lady Angkatan and Bukah, are granted pardon by the Datu of Tondo, as represented Jayadewa, Lord Minister of Pila, which released them of all their debts as inscribed in the Laguna Copperplate Inscription, Philippines.

title: Uxmal
event: The Mesoamerican ballgame court is dedicated at Uxmal.

title: Fuzhou
event: Fuzhou City is expanded with construction of a new city wall (Luo City).

title: Majorca
event: The island of Majorca is conquered by the Caliph of Córdoba.

title: China
event: The Wu State is founded in southern China by Yang Xingmi in present-day Yangzhou.

title: Chang'an
event: Chang'an, the capital of Tang Dynasty China and the largest city in the ancient world, is destroyed.

title: Aegean Sea
event: Himerius, the Logothete of the Drome, wins a victory over the Arab fleet in the Aegean Sea.

title: Lake Ohrid
event: Naum of Preslav founds a monastery at Lake Ohrid.

title: Constantinople
event: Oleg leads the Kievan Rus' in a campaign against Constantinople (see Rus'-Byzantine War (907)).

title: Chengdu
event: The Former Shu Kingdom is founded by Wang Jian in Chengdu.

title: China
event: The short-lived Qi State is founded in northwest China.

title: Changle
event: The Min Kingdom is established in today's Fujian Province, with Fuzhou (then known as Changle) as its capital, by Wang Shenzhi.

title: Battle of Tettenhall
event: August 5—The allied forces of Mercia and Wessex defeat an army of Northumbrian Vikings in the Battle of Tettenhall

title: Constantinople
event: Nicholas I Mysticus becomes the Patriarch of Constantinople.

title: Beijing
event: The Yan State at present-day Beijing falls.

title: Ireland
event: The Vikings conquer much of Ireland.

title: River Suir
event: Ireland's first city{{Citation neededdate=March 2009}}, Waterford, is founded on the River Suir.

title: Nanjing
event: Nanjing is reconstructed after a long desertion, marking the beginning of contemporary Nanjing City.

title: Mahdia
event: The city of Mahdia is founded in Tunisia.

title: Guangdong
event: The Great Yue Kingdom, later renamed Southern Han, is founded by Liu Yan in Guangdong and Guangxi.

title: Battle of Achelous (917)
event: August 20—Battle of Achelous:  A large-scale Byzantine expedition against Bulgaria is routed by Tsar Simeon I of Bulgaria.

title: Korea
event: Wang Kon moves the Korean capital from Ch'orwon to Songdo.

title: New Mexico
event: The Pueblo Bonito is built by the Anasazi in present day New Mexico's Chaco Canyon.

title: Ghana Empire
event: The golden age of the Ghana Empire begins in Africa.

title: Katla
event: The Icelandic volcano Katla erupts.

title: Deventer
event: German king Henry the Fowler conquers Utrecht, which had been in possession of the Vikings for 70 years. The Bishop of Utrecht moves his seat back from Deventer to Utrecht.

title: Baghdad
event: Ahmad ibn Fadlan is sent from Baghdad to the king of the Volga Bulgars, on behalf of the Abbasid Caliph al-Muqtadir.

title: China
event: The Later Liang Dynasty of China reports that all barbarian tribes have been pacified by the Khitan.

title: China
event: The Khitan Empire, led by Abaoji, raids  Hebei, China.

title: China
event: The Later Liang Dynasty falls to the Later Tang Dynasty (founded by Li Cunxu) in China.

title: Mercia
event: King Athelstan succeeds to the throne of Mercia.

title: Orkhon River
event: Emperor Taizu of Liao leads another campaign to the west, reaching the former Uyghur capital on the Orkhon River. The Zubu begin to offer tribute to the Khitans.

title: China
event: The Nanping State is founded by Gao Jichang in central China.

title: China
event: The Qi State in northwest China falls to the Later Tang Dynasty.

title: Tomislavgrad
event: Tomislav, duke of the Croatian duchies of Pannonia and Dalmatia, is crowned King of Croatia at Duvno Field.

title: Gyeongju
event: Korea: Hubaekje sacks the Silla capital of Gyeongju and places King Gyeongsun on the throne.

title: Daegu
event: Hubaekje and Goryeo forces fight near Daegu; the Goryeo army is routed.

title: Kingdom of England
event: 12 July—After a long process of annexations, the various small kingdoms within what is now England are unified by King Aethelstan, creating the Kingdom of England.

title: Italy
event: 15 August—The ancient city of Taranto, in southern Italy, is destroyed by the Saracens.

title: China
event: Dao Kang Di succeeds Gong Hui Di and is followed in the same year by Tai Zu, all of the Dali Gu Dynasty in southeast China.

title: Angkor
event: Jayavarman IV succeeds Isanavarman II in the Khmer Empire, and moves the capital north from Angkor to Koh Ker.

title: Nin Croatia
event: During reign of Croatian king Trpimir II, Pope Leo VI abolished the Nin Bishopric and transferred Bishop Gregory ({{lang-hrGrgur Ninski}}) to Skradin. That was the end of the long running dispute between the Split and Nin Bishoprics.

title: Korea
event: The independent Korean island state of Usanguk becomes a protectorate of Goryeo.

title: China
event: Prince Bei, elder brother of the Khitan Emperor, leaves for China.

title: Dinavar
event: Mardavij captured and killed Asfar and in rapid succession conquered Hamadan, Dinavar and Isfahan from the governors of the caliph. Then he turned against Makan with whom he had at first concluded a treaty after having received his support against Asfar.

title: Kingdom of León
event: Ramiro II of Leon becomes the King of León.

title: Jersey
event: Cotentin and Jersey are seized by William Longsword, Duke of Normandy.

title: Hedeby
event: The German king Henry I, the Fowler and his Christian forces defeat a heathen army under King Gnupa and conquer Hedeby.

title: Baghdad
event: Estimation: Córdoba, capital of Al-Andalus, becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Baghdad, capital of Abbasid caliph Ar-Radi.

title: Chengdu
event: The Later Shu Kingdom is founded by Meng Zhixiang in Chengdu.

title: China
event: The Later Tang Dynasty falls to the Later Jin Dynasty, founded by Shi Jingtang (posthumously known as Gaozu of Later Jin) in China.

title: Beijing
event: The Sixteen Prefectures, which includes the area around modern-day Beijing, are absorbed by the Khitan Empire.

title: Baghdad
event: Ibn Muqlah, Islamic calligrapher, is disgraced and imprisoned in Baghdad.

title: Strathclyde
