event: Battle of Brunanburh: King Athelstan of England defeats the Viking king of Dublin, the Scots, and Strathclyde.

title: Nanjing
event: The Liao Dynasty takes over Peking; they name Nanjing as their South Palace.

title: China
event: Battle of Bach Dang: Vietnam wins its independence from China.

title: China
event: Vietnam, under the name Dai Co Viet, gains independence from China.

title: Madrid
event: The Arabs lose Madrid to the Kingdom of Leon.

title: Iraq
event: Saadia Gaon compiles his siddur (Jewish prayer book) in Iraq.

title: Chiba Prefecture
event: Narita-san Temple is founded in Chiba, Japan.

title: Gniezno
event: Beginning of construction of the main forts in Greater Poland: Giecz, Bnin, Lad, Gniezno, Poznan, Grzybowo. All the forts were constructed rapidly between 939 and 942.

title: India
event: The Chavda Kingdom is overthrown in Gujarat, India.

title: Powys
event: Hywel Dda, king of Deheubarth, annexes Gwynedd and Powys to become ruler of most of Wales.

title: Barda Azerbaijan
event: Caspian expeditions of the Rus: The city of Barda, Azerbaijan is captured.

title: Iraq
event: The Al-Askari Mosque is built in Samarra (present-day Iraq).

title: London
event: Great storm sweeps England.  Many houses destroyed, 1500 in London alone (a significant proportion of the town).

title: Northumbria
event: King Edmund I of England takes Northumbria from the Vikings.

title: Baghdad
event: The Buwayhid Dynasty takes control of Baghdad (it does not supplant the local caliphate).

title: Strathclyde
event: Edmund I of England conquers Strathclyde.

title: Westmorland
event: Cumberland and Westmorland are annexed by the Scots.

title: China
event: The Later Jin Dynasty falls to the Later Han Dynasty (founded by Gaozu of Later Han) in China.

title: Nigeria
event: The Nri Kingdom in what is now Southeastern Nigeria is started by Eri.

title: Jaffna
event: The Nallur Kandaswamy temple, one of the most significant Hindu temples in the Jaffna district of Sri Lanka, is built.

title: Bishopric of Brandenburg
event: Otto I the Great founds the missionary dioceses of Brandenburg, Havelberg, Ribe, Aarhus, and Schleswig.

title: Antioch
event: Sayf al-Daula raids into the Byzantine theme of Lykandos but is defeated. The Byzantines counter-attack and seize Germanikeia, defeating an army from Tarsus, and the raiding as far south as Antioch. Theophilos Kourkouas captures Theodosiopolis for Byzantium.Stanford, CA  isbn = 978-0-8047-2630-2  url = http://books.google.com/?id=nYbnr5XVbzUC  page = 489}}<

title: Constantinople
event: Page with Joshua Leading the Israelites, from the Joshua Roll, is made in Constantinople. It is now kept at Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, Rome (approximate date).

title: Pacific Ocean
event: The Tu'i Tonga Empire begins to form in the Pacific Ocean.

title: China
event: The Later Han Dynasty in China falls.

title: Anatolia
event: Sayf al-Daula leads 30,000 men in a raid into Byzantine Anatolia. He defeats Bardas Phokas, but is then ambushed on his return and heavily defeated by Leo Phokas.Stanford, CA  isbn = 978-0-8047-2630-2  url = http://books.google.com/?id=nYbnr5XVbzUC  pages = 489}}<

title: China
event: The Later Zhou Dynasty is founded by Guo Wei in China.

title: China
event: The Chu State is absorbed by the Southern Tang Kingdom in China.

title: China
event: The Northern Han Kingdom is founded by Liu Min in northern China.

title: Portugal
event: Póvoa de Varzim, Portugal appears, for the first time, as a Portuguese town under the name Villa Euracini.

title: India
event: The Chandra Hindu Dynasty ends, thus beginning a time of chaos in areas belonging to modern-day India.

title: Kashmir
event: King Kshemgupta of Kashmir dies, and is succeeded by his young son Abhimanyu. Didda, widow of the former and mother of the latter, becomes de facto ruler.

title: London
event: Dunstan becomes bishop of Worcester, England and London.

title: China
event: The Song Dynasty comes to power in China when Zhao Kuangyin usurps the Later Zhou Dynasty throne.

title: Leaning Tower of Pisa
event: The Huqiu Tower is built in China (often called the Chinese Leaning Tower of Pisa).

title: Crete
event: The Byzantine Empire recaptures Crete from Muslim control.

title: London
event: St Paul's Cathedral in London is destroyed by fire.

title: Aleppo
event: December—A Byzantine army under Nikephoros Phokas captures and plunders Aleppo.

title: Constantinople
event: Nikephoros II Phokas is proclaimed emperor by his troops in Caesarea on 2 July. After street fighting in Constantinople between his supporters and the men of the chief minister Joseph Bringas, he enters the city and is crowned emperor on 16 August. In September, he marries the empress Theophano, widow of Romanos II.

title: Mount Athos
event: The Monastery of Great Lavra at Mount Athos is founded by Athanasius the Athonite.

title: Sarkel
event: The Khazar fortress of Sarkel falls to the Kievan Rus.

title: Amber India
event: Amber, India is founded as a settlement.

title: Iraq
event: 'Izz al-Daula becomes the Buyid emir of Iraq.

title: Poznań
event: The first Polish bishopric is founded in Poznań. Jordan becomes the first bishop.

title: Cairo
event: The Fatimids conquer Egypt and move their capital from Kairouan (in modern Tunisia) to Fustat, subsequently founding a new capital city just north of Fustat, and naming it Cairo.

title: Antioch
event: 28 October—Byzantine general Michael Bourtzes seizes part of Antioch's fortifications. The capture of the city from the Arabs is completed three days later, when reinforcements under Peter Phokas arrive.

title: France
event: A devastating decade-long famine begins in France.

title: Styria
event: Oldest preserved document (by Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor) mentioning Leibnitz in Styria (Austria)

title: Cairo
event: Construction is completed on Al-Azhar Mosque in Cairo (the world's oldest Islamic university).

title: China
event: January 23—In China, the war elephant corps of the Southern Han are soundly defeated at Shao by crossbow fire from Song Dynasty troops. The Southern Han state is forced to submit to the Song Dynasty, ending not only Southern Han rule, but also the first regular war elephant corps employed in a Chinese army that had gained the Southern Han victories throughout the 10th century.

title: Saaremaa
event: A battle between Estonian and Icelandic Vikings in Saaremaa is described in ''Njál's saga''.

title: Ifriqiya
event: Buluggin ibn Ziri is appointed viceroy in Ifriqiya, starting the Zirid Dynasty.

title: Cairo
event: The Fatimids move their capital to Cairo.

title: Aleppo
event: The Byzantine Empire retakes Syria (including Aleppo) from the Abbasids.

title: Baghdad
event: Al-Ta'i succeeds Al-Muti as Abbasid caliph of Baghdad.

title: Fuzhou
event: Fuzhou builds new city walls.

title: Hunan
event: Emperor Taizu of Song China conquers Hunan Province.

title: Munster
event: Brian Boru is inaugurated as King of Munster.

title: China
event: The Yuelu Academy is founded during the early Song Dynasty of China.

title: Old Minster Winchester
event: Saint Æthelwold of Winchester, Bishop of Winchester, rebuilds the western end of the Old Minster, Winchester, with twin towers and no apses.

title: Brussels
event: German emperor Otto II grants Lower Lorraine, where modern-day Brussels is located, to Charles, Duke of Lower Lorraine, illegitimate son of King Louis IV of France.

title: Iran
event: The original Imam Ali Mosque is built at Najaf, Iraq by the Daylamite Iranian ruler Fannakhosraw Azod ad Dowleh.

title: Italy
event: Badìa Fiorentina, an abbey in Florence, Italy, is founded by Willa, Margravine of Tuscany.

title: Isle of Man
event: The Tynwald (parliament) of the Isle of Man is founded.

title: Brussels
event: Foundation of the city of Brussels: a 'castrum' on an island on the river Senne (Brabant, Belgium).

title: Beijing
event: August 1—Battle of Gaoliang River: The Liao Dynasty defeats Song Dynasty forces near present-day Beijing.

title: Denmark
event: The Viking ring castle of Trelleborg is constructed in Denmark.

title: Prince-Bishopric of Liège
event: Foundation by Notger of the Prince-Bishopric of Liège which will remain an independent state inside the Holy Roman Empire for more than 800 years, and where the Walloon language will develop.

title: Bengal
event: Kamboja rule in Bengal is deposed by resurgent Palas.

title: Tula Hidalgo
event: Tula, Hidalgo becomes the Toltec capital.

title: India
event: The majestic Gommateshwara statue is built by Chavundaraya of the Western Ganga Dynasty in India.

title: North America
event: Greenland is discovered by Erik the Red (the first known European contact with North America).

title: China
event: Wood carvers commissioned by China's Song Dynasty complete a carving of the entire Buddhist canon for printing (130,000 total blocks are produced).

title: Wolverhampton
event: Lady Wulfruna founds the town that later becomes the city of Wolverhampton.

title: Battle of Hjörungavágr
event: Håkon Sigurdsson of Norway defeats the Danish invasion force at Hjørungavåg

title: North America
event: Explorer Bjarni Herjólfsson becomes the first inhabitant of the Old World to sight North America.

title: France
event: Hugh Capet, Count of Paris, is crowned King of France.

title: Chichen Itza
event: Kukulcan conquers Chichen Itza.

title: Cairo
event: Al-Azhar University is founded in Cairo, Egypt (the second oldest university in the world).

title: Denmark
event: The city of Odense, Denmark is founded.

title: Kievan Rus'
event: Kievan Rus' accepts Christianity.

title: Hagia Sophia
event: Repairs are made on the Hagia Sophia.

title: Cairo
event: Construction of the Al-Hakim Mosque begins in Cairo.

title: Denmark
event: The city of Lund, Sweden (then Denmark) is founded.

title: France
event: The ''Pax Ecclesiae'', an edict by the church in southern France attempting to outlaw acts of war against non-combatants and the clergy, is promulgated.

title: Battle of Maldon
event: Battle of Maldon: The Anglo-Saxons are defeated by Viking invaders led by Olaf Tryggvason, later Olaf I of Norway.

title: Aoudaghost
event: The Ghana Empire captures the Berber town of Awdaghost.

title: Anatolia
event: Basil II lifts the siege of Aleppo by mounting his entire army and transferring it across Anatolia in sixteen days.

title: Beijing
event: The Niujie Mosque is constructed in Beijing.

title: Gdańsk
event: First documented reference to the City of Gdańsk.

title: Sherborne Abbey
event: A Benedictine abbey is founded at Sherborne.

title: Faroe Islands
event: Sigmundur Brestisson introduces Christianity in the Faroe Islands.

title: Rwanda
event: The Hutu arrive in present-day Rwanda and Burundi, soon outnumbering the native Twa.

title: North America
event: Leif Ericson lands in North America, calling it Vinland.

title: Bangladesh
event: Dhaka, Bangladesh, is founded.

title: Denmark
event: Sweyn I establishes Danish control over part of Norway.

title: San Bartolomeo all'Isola
event: Emperor Otto III makes a pilgrimage from Rome to Aachen and Gniezno (Gnesen), stopping at Regensburg, Meissen, Magdeburg, and Gniezno. The Congress of Gniezno (with Bolesław I Chrobry) is part of his pilgrimage. In Rome, he builds the basilica of San Bartolomeo all'Isola, to host the relics of St. Bartholomew.

title: France
event: The Château de Goulaine vineyard is founded in France.

title: India
event: Kandariya Mahadeva temple, Khajuraho, Madhya Pradesh, India, is built. Chandela dynasty, Early Medieval period (approximate date).

title: Kołobrzeg
event: The Diocese of Kołobrzeg is founded.

title: Gniezno
event: The archdiocese in Gniezno is founded; the first archbishop is Gaudentius (Radim), from Slavník's dynasty.

title: Cairo
event: Arab Muslim polymath and scientist, Ibn al-Haytham (Alhacen), who is considered the father of optics, the pioneer of the scientific method, and the first scientist, moves from Baghdad to Cairo, where he invents the camera obscura, and writes his influential ''Book of Optics'', which introduces the scientific method, and drastically transforms the understanding of light, optics, vision, and science in general.

title: Al-Andalus
event: Arab Muslim physician, Abu al-Qasim (Abulcasis), the father of modern surgery, publishes his influential 30-volume medical encyclopedia in Al-Andalus, the ''Al-Tasrif'', which remained a standard textbook in the Islamic world and medieval Europe for centuries.

title: Cairo
event: Arab Muslim mathematician and astronomer, Ibn Yunus, publishes his astronomical treatise ''Al-Zij al-Hakimi al-Kabir'' in Cairo.

title: Pontificia Fonderia Marinelli
event: The Bell foundry is founded in Italy by Pontificia Fonderia Marinelli.

title: China
event: Gunpowder is invented in China.

title: Viking Age
event: September 9—Battle of Svolder: King Olaf Tryggvason is defeated by an alliance of his enemies, in this notable naval battle of the Viking Age.

title: Aachen Cathedral
event: Otto III, Holy Roman Emperor has Charlemagne's vault opened (see Aachen Cathedral).

title: Denmark
event: The First Battle of Alton: Danish invaders defeat the British.

title: Devon
event: Battle of Pinhoe: Vikings defeat Anglo-Saxons in Devon.

title: Khotyn
event: First reference to Khotyn, Ukrainian town  and to Nyalka, Hungarian village, as to ''Chimudi''.

title: Liaodi Pagoda
event: Construction begins on the Liaodi Pagoda, the tallest pagoda in Chinese history (completed in 1055).

title: Philippines
event: The Buddhist ruler of Butuan in the Philippines (''P’u-tuan'' in the Sung Dynasty records), ''Sari Bata Shaja'', makes the first tributary mission to China.

title: Tripoli
event: Khazrun ben Falful from Maghrawa family Banu Khazrun begins ruling Tripoli.

title: Huntingdonshire
event: A tomb of saint Ivo (possibly) is uncovered in Huntingdonshire.

title: Old Dongola
event: Rafael of Makuria constructs a red brick building in Old Dongola.

title: Denmark
event: Sweyn I of Denmark begins his first invasion of England.

title: Deutz Abbey
event: Deutz Abbey is founded at Deutz by Heribert of Cologne.

title: India
event: The construction of Brihadeeswarar temple, Thanjavur, Tamil Nadu, India, starts. Chola Dynasty, Early Medieval period.

title: Vyšehrad
event: February 9 – Boleslaus III of Bohemia is restored to authority with armed support from Bolesław I the Brave of Poland. In the following months Boleslav's brothers Jaromir and Oldrich flee to Germany and place themselves under the protection of Henry II, Holy Roman Emperor, while Boleslaus III of Bohemia orders massacre of his leading nobles at Vyšehrad.

title: Kingdom of Aragon
event: Sancho III becomes king of Navarre, Aragon and Castille.

title: Ireland
event: Brian Boru makes a second expedition to the north to take hostages from the northern states: during this expeidion, he visited Armagh, making an offering of twenty ounces of gold to the church and confirming to the apostolic see of Saint Patrick, ecclesiastical supremacy over the whole of Ireland (as recorded in the Book of Armagh).

title: Kent
event: Ælfric of Abingdon leaves ships to the people of Wiltshire and Kent in his will, with his best one, equipped for sixty men, going to King Ethelred.

title: Pomerania
event: Pomerania revolts against the church.

title: China
event: Granaries for famine relief are set up across China.

title: China
event: May 1—The brightest supernova ever recorded, SN 1006, occurs in the constellation of Lupus.  It is observed and described in China, Japan, the Middle East, Europe, and elsewhere.

title: Shanghai
event: Songjiang County, the later city of Shanghai, is founded (approximate date).

title: Estonia
event: Olav Haraldsson, the future king of Norway, lands on Saaremaa Island in Estonia, wins a battle there and forces the inhabitants to pay tribute.

title: China
event: The Egyptian Fatimid Empire under Al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah sends the sea captain Domiyat on a tributary mission to Emperor Zhenzong of the Song Dynasty, in order to reestablish trade relations between Egypt and China.

title: Korea
event: The provinces of Goryeo (modern-day Korea) are redistributed.

title: Mainz Cathedral
event: August 29 - Mainz Cathedral suffers extensive damage from a fire on the day of its inauguration.

title: Church of the Holy Sepulchre
event: October 18—The Church of the Holy Sepulchre is destroyed by Caliph al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah.

title: Thanjavur
event: The construction of Brihadeeswarar temple, Thanjavur, Tamil Nadu, India, ends. Chola Dynasty, Early Medieval period.

title: Iraq
event: Ibn al-Haytham (Alhacen), a famous Iraqi scientist working in Egypt, feigns madness in fear of angering Al-Hakim, and is kept under house arrest until 1021. During this time he begins writing his influential ''Book of Optics''.

title: Ireland
event: Mael Morda starts a rebellion against Brian Boru in Ireland, which eventually ends in 1014 at the Battle of Clontarf.

title: Denmark
event: April 19—Archbishop Alphege of Canterbury is murdered by his Danish captors.

title: Pomerania
event: The Poles withdraw from Pomerania (approximate date).

title: Al-Andalus
event: Estimation: Kaifeng, capital of China becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Córdoba in Al-Andalus.

title: Cairo
event: The Al-Hakim Mosque is completed in Cairo.

title: Denmark
event: December – King Sweyn I leads a Danish invasion of England. King Ethelred flees to Normandy, and Sweyn becomes King of England.

title: Kashmir
event: In Kashmir, Abhinavagupta, the teacher of the poet Ksemendra, circulates his Greater commentary on the ''Pratyabhijna Darshana''.

title: Ireland
event: April 23—Battle of Clontarf: Gaelic Irish forces under Brian Boru defeat several allied Viking forces in Ireland, ending their power there but losing Brian in the battle.

title: Battle of Kleidion
event: July 29—Battle of Kleidion: Basil II inflicts not only a decisive defeat on the Bulgarian army, but his subsequent blinding of 15,000 prisoners reportedly causes Tsar Samuil of Bulgaria to die of shock, and earns Basil II the sobriquet 'Boulgaroktonos' (Bulgar-slayer).

title: Kievan Rus'
event: Sviatopolk succeeds Vladimir as prince of Kiev.

title: Kashmir
event: The Ghaznavid army invades Kashmir, but is defeated.

title: Kievan Rus'
event: George Tsul, ruler of Khazaria, is captured by a combined Byzantine–Rus' force, which effectively ends Khazaria's existence.

title: Battle of Brentford (1016)
event: Battle of Brentford: Edmund II gains a temporary victory over Canute the Great.

title: Denmark
event: Canute of Denmark and Edmund II divide England.

title: Dome of the Rock
event: Earthquakes partly destroy the Dome of the Rock.

title: Northumbria
event: England is divided into the earldoms of Wessex, Mercia, East Anglia and Northumbria.

title: Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev
event: The construction of Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev is started (approximate date).

title: Lothian
event: Battle of Carham: The Scots conquer Lothian.

title: Denmark
event: Canute the Great becomes king of Denmark (or 1019), succeeding Harald II.

title: Buckfast Abbey
event: Buckfast Abbey is founded.

title: Kievan Rus'
event: Yaroslav the Wise becomes prince of Kievan Rus', succeeding Sviatopolk I.

title: Italy
event: Henry II of Germany conducts his third Italian military campaign .

title: Lahore
event: Mahmud appoints Ayaz to the throne, making Lahore the capital of the Ghaznavid Empire.

title: China
event: The Song Dynasty Chinese capital city of Kaifeng has some half a million residents by this year; including all those present in the nine designated suburbs, the population is over a million people.

title: Bengal
event: The Chola Empire invades Bengal.

title: Ifriqiya
event: Al-Muizz ibn Badis begins to rule Ifriqiya in his own right.

title: China
event: The world's first paper-printed money, which later greatly benefits the economy of the Song Dynasty, originates in the Sichuan province of China.

title: Sumatra
event: Srivijaya, a partly Buddhist kingdom based in Sumatra, is attacked by the Chola Empire of southern India in a dispute over trading rights in South-east Asia. It survives, but declines in importance.

title: France
event: May 14—Henri I is crowned king of France at Reims Cathedral.

title: Estonia
event: The cities of Kaunas in Lithuania and Tartu in Estonia are founded.

title: China
event: The Song Dynasty Chinese historian and scholar Ouyang Xiu obtains his ''jinshi'' degree at the age of only 22 by passing the highest level examinations in the country (his third attempt), leading him into a distinguished path as a scholar-official.

title: Battle of Stiklestad
event: July 29—Battle of Stiklestad (Norway): Olav Haraldsson loses to his pagan vassals and is killed in the battle. He is later canonized and becomes the patron saint of Norway and ''Rex perpetuum Norvegiae'' ('the eternal king of Norway').

title: Edessa Mesopotamia
event: Byzantine general George Maniaces captures Edessa.

title: Franche-Comté
event: Franche-Comté becomes subject to the Holy Roman Empire.

title: Denmark
event: Harthacanute becomes king of Denmark.

title: Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev
event: Construction of the Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev is ended.

title: China
event: The Western Xia declare their independence from Liao China.

title: Weihenstephan
event: The oldest brewery still active is founded at Weihenstephan.

title: China
event: Printing using woodblocks is invented in China (approximate date).

title: Battle of Dandanaqan
event: May 23—Battle of Dandanaqan: Seljuk Turks defeat the Ghaznavids.

title: Italy
event: The Normans in Italy move their capital to Melfi.

title: Winchester Cathedral
event: Edward the Confessor is crowned King of England at Winchester Cathedral.

title: China
event: In Song Dynasty China, the statesmen Ouyang Xiu and Fan Zhongyan put forth the Qingli Reforms, which are halted by 1045.

title: China
event: The Chinese military treatise of the ''Wujing Zongyao'' is written and compiled by scholars Zeng Gongliang (曾公亮), Ding Du (丁度), and Yang Weide (楊惟德) during the Song Dynasty. It is the first book in history to include formulas for gunpowder and its use for various bombs (thrown by sling or trebuchet catapult). It also describes the double-piston pump flamethrower and a thermoremanence compass, a few decades before Shen Kuo wrote of the first known magnetic mariners compass. Although emphasizing the importance of many weapons, it reserves high respect for the crossbow and ability of crossbowmen to fell charging units of nomadic cavalrymen.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: Edward the Confessor marries Edith of Wessex and begins construction of Westminster Abbey.

title: China
event: Movable type printing is invented by Bi Sheng in China.

title: China
event: The famous Song Dynasty Chinese judge and magistrate Bao Qingtian writes a memorial to the throne, warning about governmental corruption and a foreseeable bankruptcy of the Chinese iron industry, if increasingly poorer families continued to be listed on the register for iron-smelting households (while more rich households avoid being listed for fear of financial calamity). Apparently the government heeds the warning, and produces more iron product by the year 1078 than China ever had before.

title: Denmark
event: Sweyn II is crowned king of Denmark.

title: China
event: Construction of the large Iron Pagoda in Kaifeng, China, is completed in this year during the Song Dynasty.

title: Hedeby
event: Hedeby is sacked by King Harald Hardråde of Norway during the course of a conflict with Sweyn II of Denmark.

title: Finland
event: Swedish forces attack Finland.

title: Missouri
event: Punitavati (Karaikkalammaiyar), Shiva saint, from Karaikka, India, is made. It is now kept at The Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, Kansas City, Missouri (approximate date).

title: Weltenburg Abbey
event: The brewery of Weltenburg Abbey is first mentioned, thus making it one of the oldest still operating breweries in the world.

title: Kyoto Prefecture
event: Byodo-in, Uji, Kyoto Prefecture, is built. Heian period (approximate date).

title: China
event: July 4—The SN 1054 supernova is recorded by the Chinese, Arab and possibly Native Americans near the star ζ Tauri. For 23 days it remains bright enough to be seen in daylight. Its remnants form the Crab Nebula (NGC 1952).

title: Constantinople
event: July 16—Cardinal Humbertus, a representative of Pope Leo IX, and Michael Cerularius, Patriarch of Constantinople, decree each other's excommunication. Most historians look to this act as the final step in the initiation of the Great Schism between the Roman Catholic and Orthodox Christian Churches.  In 1965, those excommunications are rescinded by Pope Paul VI and Patriarch Athenagoras when they meet in the Second Vatican Council.  However, to this day each church claims to be the One Holy Catholic and Apostolic Church and each denies the other's right to that name. (See East-West Schism)

title: Hebei
event: Construction on the Liaodi Pagoda in Hebei is complete, the tallest pagoda in Chinese history standing at a height of 84 m (275 ft) tall.

title: Aoudaghost
event: The Almoravids conquer Aoudaghost (present-day Mauritania).

title: Lake Balaton
event: An abbey was set up at Tihany, Hungary by András (Andrew) I. The foundation charter was drawn up on the northern shore of Lake Balaton. This is the earliest written record extant in the Hungarian language.

title: Baghdad
event: December 18 – The Seljuk Turks capture Baghdad; Al-Malik al-Rahim is taken prisoner.

title: Italy
event: Anselm leaves Italy.

title: Shandong
event: The Pagoda of Fugong Temple of Shanxi in northern China is built during the Liao Dynasty. Work begins on the Pizhi Pagoda of Lingyan Temple, Shandong, China, under the opposing Song Dynasty.

title: Burma
event: King Anawrahta of Burma captures Thanton in northern Thailand, strengthening Theravada Buddhism in the country.

title: China
event: Chinese poet, calligrapher, and official Cai Xiang publishes his ''Cha Lu'' (Record of Tea).

title: Sennar
event: Spanish Jew Benjamin of Tudela reports that Constantinople has merchant communities from Babylon, Canaan, Egypt, Hungary, Persia, Russia, Sennar, and Spain as well as 2,000 Jews (approximate date).

title: Speyer Cathedral
event: Erection of the Speyer Cathedral in Speyer, Germany, begins.

title: Holland
event: Most of West Frisia (later known as Holland) is conquered by imperial German armies and given to the Bishop of Utrecht.

title: Marrakech
event: Marrakech is founded by the Almoravid dynasty.

title: Affligem Abbey
event: Affligem Abbey, of the Order of St. Benedict, is founded in Affligem, Belgium.

title: China
event: The Pizhi Pagoda of Lingyan Temple, Shandong, China is completed, standing at a height of 54 m (177 ft) tall.

title: St Mark's Basilica
event: The construction of present building of St Mark's Basilica is begun.

title: Arizona
event: Sunset Crater Volcano (present-day Arizona) first erupts.

title: Anatolia
event: The Seljuk Turks storm Anatolia, taking Caesarea and Ani, marking the beginning of Turkish incursions into Anatolia.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: 28 December—Westminster Abbey is consecrated.

title: Portugal
event: The kingdoms of Galicia and Portugal become independent under the rule of Garcia.

title: China
event: Sima Guang, high chancellor of the Chinese Song Dynasty, heads a team of scholars in initiating the compilation of an enormous written universal history of China, known as the ''Zizhi Tongjian''.

title: Hedeby
event: Hedeby is destroyed by a Slavic army and permanently abandoned.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: January 5—Harold II is crowned King of England at Westminster Abbey.

title: Battle of Fulford
event: September 20—Battle of Fulford: King Harald III of Norway (Harald Hardrada) defeats the northern English earls  Edwin and Morcar.

title: Battle of Stamford Bridge
event: September 25—Battle of Stamford Bridge: King Harold II of England defeats the Vikings under Harald Hardrada.

title: Battle of Hastings
event: October 14—Battle of Hastings, fought between King Harold II of England and Duke William of Normandy: Harold is killed and William is victorious. In England this is the traditional end of the Dark Ages and the start of the Middle Ages.

title: Cappadocia
event: The Seljuk Turks take Caesarea in Cappadocia.

title: Tower of London
event: Construction begins on the Tower of London.

title: Winchester Castle
event: Winchester Castle is built.

title: Orsha
event: Minsk and Orsha  are first mentioned in the chronicles.

title: China
event: The poet Wang Anshi campaigns against corruption in China.

title: Durham
event: Harrying of the North: King William of England (William the Conqueror) reacts to rebellions made by his people against him. He rides through the north of England with his army and burns houses, crops, cattle and land from York to Durham, which results in the deaths of over 100,000 people, mainly from starvation and winter cold.

title: Selby Abbey
event: William the Conqueror founds the Norman Selby Abbey.

title: Italy
event: Lanfranc, an Italian lawyer, becomes William's formidable Archbishop of Canterbury.

title: Temple of Literature
event: The Temple of Literature is established in the capital of Vietnam.

title: North Yorkshire
event: Construction of Richmond Castle in North Yorkshire, England begins.

title: Mercia
event: Edwin, Earl of Mercia rebels against William I and is killed, leading to the re-distribution of land within Mercia to William's subjects.

title: Battle of Manzikert
event: August 26—Battle of Manzikert: The Byzantine Empire loses to a Turkish army led by Alp Arslan. Byzantine civil war results in Turkish invasions.

title: Dunfermline Abbey
event: Dunfermline Abbey is founded – later to become the burial place of several Kings of Scots, including Robert the Bruce. The associated royal palace will be the birth place of King Charles I.

title: Kingdom of León
event: Alfonso VI becomes king of Leon and Castile following the assassination of his brother Sancho.

title: Ankara
event: The Seljuk Turks conquer Ankara.

title: China
event: Chancellor Wang Anshi of Song Dynasty China creates a new bureau of the central government called the Directorate of Weapons, which supervises the manufacture of military armaments and ensures quality control.

title: Tower of London
event: William the Conqueror orders the White Tower to be built.

title: Hebei
event: The Song Dynasty Chinese polymath scientist and statesman Shen Kuo solves a heated border dispute with the Liao Dynasty by dredging up old diplomatic records; he refutes Emperor Daozong of Liao's bluffs point for point during a meeting at Mt. Yongan (near modern Pingquan in Hebei), and reestablishes the Song's rightful borders.

title: Koumbi Saleh
event: The Almoravids capture the Ghanaian capital of Kumbi.

title: Gniezno
event: December 25—Polish King Bolesław II the Bold (Polish: ''Bolesław Śmiały'') is crowned in Gniezno.

title: Kievan Rus'
event: Vsevolod of Kiev becomes the prince of Kievan Rus'.

title: Ghana Empire
event: The Almoravids complete the conquest of the Ghana Empire, and reach Spain.

title: Friuli
event: April 3—Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor granted the county of Friuli, with ducal status, to Sigaerd, Patriarch of Aquileia.

title: Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela
event: The Romanesque church is begun at Santiago de Compostela, Galicia, Spain.

title: China
event: By this year, the iron industry in Song Dynasty China is producing a total weight of 127,000,000 kg (125,000 t) of iron product per year.

title: Greece
event: c. 1080–1100 – Christ Pantokrator, mosaic in the central dome, church of the Dormition, Daphni, Greece, is made.

title: Italy
event: Corfu is taken from the Byzantine Empire by Robert Guiscard, Norman King of Southern Italy.

title: İzmir
event: Turkish emir Chaka Bey conquers İzmir and founds a short lived principality and emerges as the first sea power in Turkish history.

title: Battle of Dyrrhachium (1081)
event: October 18 – Alexius I helps defend Albania from the Normans (the first recorded mention of Albania), but is defeated at the Battle of Dyrrhachium (Durazzo). The Normans govern Albania from Italy until around 1100.

title: Graus
event: Sancho I of Aragon conquers Graus.

title: Castel Sant'Angelo
event: June—Pope Gregory VII is besieged in Castel Sant'Angelo by Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor.

title: Burma
event: Kyanzittha begins his reign in Burma.

title: Antioch
event: Antioch is captured by the Seljuk Turks from the Byzantines.

title: China
event: Chancellor Sima Guang and a group of scholars of the Chinese Song Dynasty complete the compilation of the ''Zizhi Tongjian'', an enormous written universal history of China in 294 volumes of 3 million written Chinese characters.

title: Denmark
event: The Domesday survey is commissioned by William I of England, apparently prompted by the abortive invasion of Canute IV of Denmark, to ensure proper taxation and levies.

title: Katedralskolan Lund
event: Katedralskolan, Lund, the oldest school in Scandinavia, is founded.

title: China
event: By this year, the annual output of copper currency for the Chinese Song Dynasty reaches 6 billion coins a year, prompting the Chinese government to adopt the world's first paper-printed money later in the 1120s.

title: France
event: May 25—Alfonso VI of Castile enters the Islamic city of Toledo, Spain, and invites French knights to settle the central plateau of Spain.

title: Najaf
event: The Imam Ali Mosque in Najaf is rebuilt by the Seljuk Malik Shah I after being destroyed by fire.

title: Kingdom of León
event: October 23 – Battle of az-Zallaqah: Alfonso VI of León and Castile is defeated by the Almoravids, who had been called into Spain by Abbad III of Sevilla.

title: London
event: A fire in London destroys St Paul's Cathedral.

title: University of Bologna
event: The oldest extant university, the University of Bologna, is founded.

title: China
event: The Chinese polymath statesman and scientist Su Song has the successful pilot model for his astronomical clock tower constructed in Kaifeng, China. It features an escapement mechanism and the world's oldest known endless power-transmitting chain drive to operate the armillary sphere, opening doors, and mechanical-driven manikins that would rotate in shifts to announce the time on plaques.

title: Lancashire
event: Northumbria is divided by the Normans into the counties of Northumberland, County Durham, Yorkshire, Westmorland and Lancashire.

title: Kerala
event: Rama Varma Kulashekhara is crowned in Kerala.

title: Palmyra
event: Palmyra is destroyed by an earthquake.

title: Great Britain
event: August 11 – A powerful earthquake is recorded in Britain.

title: Malta
event: Roger Guiscard takes Malta.

title: Slavonia
event: Ladislaus I of Hungary occupies Slavonia.

title: Constantinople
event: April 29 – Battle of Levounion: The Pechenegs besiege Constantinople, but are defeated so decisively by Emperor Alexius I that they fade into oblivion.

title: London Bridge
event: October 23—London Tornado of 1091: A T8/F4 tornado is recorded in St Mary-le-Bow of London, England, which destroys London Bridge.

title: Goodwin Sands
event: High tides cause great flooding in England and Scotland.  The Kentish lands of Earl Godwin inundated and are now known as the Goodwin Sands

title: Portugal
event: Henry of Burgundy becomes Count of Portugal.

title: Durham
event: The building of Durham Cathedral begins in Durham, England.

title: Carlisle Castle
event: Construction begins on Carlisle Castle, England.

title: Denmark
event: Saint Canute's Cathedral is built in Odense, Denmark.

title: Battle of Alnwick (1093)
event: November 13—Battle of Alnwick: Malcolm III of Scotland is defeated and killed by the forces of William II of England.

title: St Mark's Basilica
event: October 8 – St Mark's Basilica is consecrated in Venice.

title: France
event: Overpopulation in France, according to Pope Urban II.

title: Portugal
event: The County of Portugal is established for the second time by Count Henry of Burgundy.

title: Pembroke Castle
event: Pembroke Castle is built in Wales.

title: France
event: The cathedral in Valence, France is consecrated.

title: France
event: November 27—Pope Urban II preaches the First Crusade at the Council of Clermont; Peter the Hermit begins to preach throughout France.

title: Bishopric of Brandenburg
event: Bernard becomes Bishop of Brandenburg.

title: Ireland
event: In Ireland, the Diocese of Waterford is erected.

title: University of Oxford
event: The first documented teaching at the University of Oxford occurs.

title: Constantinople
event: The First Crusade reaches Constantinople.

title: Latakia
event: July 1—Crusaders besiege Nicaea, win the Battle of Dorylaeum, capture Latakia from the Seljuk Turks, and begin the siege of Antioch.

title: Sardis
event: The Byzantine Empire retakes Smyrna, Ephesus and Sardis.

title: Isle of Man
event: King Magnus III of Norway (Magnus Barefoot) conquers the Orkney Islands, the Hebrides and the Isle of Man.

title: Arizona
event: Oraibi becomes and remains the first and oldest populated settlement in the USA and what is now Arizona.

title: Cusco
event: The city of Cusco, Peru is founded.

title: China
event: Emperor Huizong of Song starts to rule in China.

title: Ankara
event: Raymond IV of Toulouse, count of Tripoli, takes Ankara from the Seljuk Turks.

title: Caesarea Maritima
event: King Baldwin I of Jerusalem captures Arsuf (in April) and Caesarea (in May).

title: Denmark
event: Canute II of Denmark is canonized.

title: Korea
event: A vast compilation of Liao, Korean, and Song Buddhist writings is completed.

title: Kingdom of Hungary
event: Kingdom of Croatia loses its full independence while joining in the union with Kingdom of Hungary under the rule of king Coloman.Pacta conventa (Croatia).<

title: Arundel Castle
event: Henry I of England takes possession of Arundel Castle.

title: Caesarea Maritima
event: The Crusaders capture Caesarea Maritima.

title: Tripoli Lebanon
event: Raymond IV of Toulouse begins to besiege Tripoli, and takes the nominal title of Count of Tripoli.

title: China
event: Chinese architect and government minister Li Jie (1065–1110) publishes his ''Yingzao Fashi'' technical treatise on Chinese architecture during the reign of Emperor Huizong of Song.

title: Hekla
event: The volcano Hekla erupts in Iceland, destroying settlements.

title: Durham Cathedral
event: September 3—St. Cuthbert is reburied in Durham Cathedral.

title: Korea
event: The Tamna Kingdom is annexed by the Korean Goryeo Dynasty.

title: China
event: Chinese money is printed in 3 colours to stymie counterfeiting.

title: Orkney
event: Saint Magnus becomes the first Earl of Orkney.

title: Italy
event: In Pistoia, Italy, the Cathedral of San Zeno burns to the ground.

title: Beirut
event: The Crusaders capture Tripoli and Beirut.

title: Kingdom of Hungary
event: The Principality of Nitra ceases to exist, after the Coloman of Hungary deposes its last ruler.

title: Battle of Głogów
event: August 14 – Battle of Głogów: The Poles again defeat the Holy Roman Empire.

title: Italy
event: Henry V, Holy Roman Emperor invades Italy.

title: France
event: Construction begins on Fontevraud Abbey in France.

title: Sidon
event: Beirut and Sidon are captured by the Crusaders.

title: Mosul
event: Mawdud of Mosul captures all land belonging to the Crusader County of Edessa east of the Euphrates.

title: Sidon
event: December 4—First Crusade: The Crusaders conquer Sidon.

title: Portugal
event: Santarém is captured by Portuguese troops.

title: Portugal
event: Afonso I becomes Count of Portugal.

title: Burma
event: Alaungsithu succeeds Kyanzittha as king of Burma.

title: Bridlington Priory
event: Bridlington Priory is founded.

title: Ibiza
event: Ramon Berenguer III of Barcelona conquers Ibiza and Mallorca.

title: Clairvaux Abbey
event: Clairvaux Abbey is founded by St. Bernard.

title: Notre Dame de Paris
event: Pierre Abélard becomes canon of Notre Dame de Paris.

title: China
event: The Jurchen establish the Jin Dynasty of China.

title: Montreal (Crusader castle)
event: The Crusader castle of Montreal is built by Baldwin I of Jerusalem.

title: China
event: The modern book of separate pages stitched together is invented in China.

title: India
event: Construction starts on the Chennakesava Temple in India.

title: Pelusium
event: Pelusium is razed by Baldwin I of Jerusalem.

title: Merton Priory
event: May 3—Merton Priory (Thomas Becket School) is consecrated.

title: Montlhéry
event: Montlhéry Castle is dismantled by Louis VI of France.

title: Santa Maria in Cosmedin
event: The restoration of Santa Maria in Cosmedin begins.

title: Reichenbach Abbey (Bavaria)
event: Reichenbach Abbey is founded.

title: Zbraslav
event: Zbraslav, now part of Prague, is founded.

title: Sardis
event: The Byzantine general Philocales captures Sardis from the Seljuk Sultanate of Rûm.

title: Azaz
event: June 11—Roger of Salerno, Prince of Antioch, captures Azaz from the Seljuk Turks.

title: Battle of Ager Sanguinis
event: June 28 – Battle of Ager Sanguinis: Ilghazi, the ruler of Aleppo, wipes out a Crusader army from the Principality of Antioch.

title: Antioch
event: August 14 – Battle of Hab: Baldwin II of Jerusalem's Crusaders defeat Ilghazi's army, saving Antioch.

title: Battle of Bremule
event: August 20—Battle of Bremule: Henry I of England routs Louis VI.

title: Warwickshire
event: September 19: Severe Earthquake in Gloucestershire & Warwickshire, England.

title: Llandaff Cathedral
event: Construction begins on Llandaff Cathedral in Wales.

title: China
event: The Song Dynasty governor of the bustling seaport of Quanzhou, Fujian, China, reports that the population of his city has reached 500,000 residents.

title: English Channel
event: November 25—The White Ship is wrecked in the English Channel, resulting in the death of the son of King Henry I of England.

title: Reading Abbey
event: Reading Abbey is founded in England.

title: Cluny Abbey
event: Completion of the third and largest church at Cluny Abbey.

title: Battle of Beroia
event: Battle of Beroia: Byzantine Emperor John II Komnenos defeats and destroys the Pechenegs.

title: London
event: St. Bartholomew's Hospital (Barts) is founded in London, England.

title: Dunfermline Abbey
event: Gaufrid is consecrated as the first Abbot of Dunfermline Abbey.

title: Ireland
event: In Ireland, St. Malachy, the great reformer of the Church, is made a bishop.

title: Östergötland
event: King Inge the Younger is murdered in Vreta, Östergötland, instigated by his wife Ulfhild. Her cousin Magnus the Strong proclaims himself ruler of Gothenland, whereas Ragnvald Knaphövde, in opposition to him, proclaims himself king of Sweden in Svealand.

title: Chios
event: The Venetians pillage Rhodes, ravage Samos and Lesbos, and occupy Chios.

title: Reading School
event: Reading School founded.

title: Battle of Azaz
event: June 11—Battle of Azaz: The Crusaders defeat the Seljuk Turks.

title: China
event: The Jin Dynasty is established in the north of China, following the Song Dynasty's loss at the Huang He River valley. Remnants of the court flee south, including much of the populace and communities such as the Kaifeng Jews.

title: China
event: The rule of Emperor Huizong of Song ends in China.

title: Kingdom of León
event: Alfonso VII is crowned king of Castile and León in Spain.

title: Bukhara
event: The minaret of Kalyan is completed in Bukhara (present day Uzbekistan).

title: Flanders
event: Count Charles the Good of Flanders is assassinated.

title: China
event: Estimation: Constantinople, capital of the Byzantine Empire, becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Kaifeng, capital of China.

title: China
event: January 9 – Jurchen forces sack the Song Chinese capital of Kaifeng (the Jingkang Incident, 靖康事變), and begin more than a century of political division between northern and southern China.

title: Holyrood Abbey
event: Holyrood Abbey is founded in Edinburgh by David I, King of Scotland.

title: Flanders
event: King Louis VI of France agrees to the accession of Thierry of Alsace as Count of Flanders.

title: Portugal
event: June 24—Battle of São Mamede:  King Afonso I of Portugal (then Count of Portugal) defeats his mother, Teresa of León, and gains control of the county, which thus becomes ''de facto'' independent.

title: France
event: An antipope schism occurs when Roger II of Sicily supports Anacletus II as pope instead of Innocent II, who flees to France.

title: Tintern Abbey
event: May 9—Tintern Abbey is founded.

title: Ireland
event: Dermot MacMurrough has the abbey of Kildare in Ireland burned and the abbess raped.{{Citation neededdate=April 2009}} He becomes king of the province of Leinster.

title: Ireland
event: St. Malachy is made bishop of Armagh in Ireland, to impose the Roman liturgy on the independent Irish Church.

title: Basingwerk Abbey
event: Fountains Abbey and Rievaulx Abbey are founded in Yorkshire, Basingwerk Abbey is founded in Wales.

title: Iraq
event: Tughril II starts his rule of Iraq.

title: Durham Cathedral
event: Durham Cathedral is completed.

title: Norton Priory
event: The Augustinian Runcorn Priory is transferred to Norton Priory.

title: France
event: Much of Chartres, France is destroyed by fire.

title: North Sea
event: The Zeeland archipelago is created by a massive storm in the North Sea.

title: France
event: Robert of Ketton and Herman of Carinthia travel throughout France, the Byzantine Empire, and the Crusader States.

title: Baghdad
event: Abdul Qadir Jilani becomes principal of the Hanbali school in Baghdad.

title: Zhejiang
event: Wu Ge, the Chinese Song Dynasty Deputy Transport Commissioner of Zhejiang, has paddle wheel warships constructed with a total of nine wheels and others with thirteen wheels.

title: Baghdad
event: The domination of Baghdad by the Seljuk Turks ends.

title: Buildwas Abbey
event: The Cistercian Abbey of St. Mary and St. Chad is founded by Roger de Clinton, bishop of Coventry (1129–48).

title: London Bridge
event: A fire in London seriously damages St Paul's Cathedral and London Bridge.

title: Yue Fei
event: Song Dynasty Chinese general Yue Fei defeats the rebel forces of Yang Yao by entangling his swift paddle-wheel ships with rotten logs and other debris precariously placed in the river. Yue Fei's forces easily board their ships and win a victory.

title: Byland Abbey
event: January—Byland Abbey is founded.

title: Cumberland
event: 5 February—Treaty of Durham: Stephen I of England concedes Cumberland to David I of Scotland.

title: Battle of Crug Mawr
event: Battle of Crug Mawr: Owain Gwynedd of Wales defeats the Normans.

title: China
event: In Song Dynasty China, a fire breaks out in the new capital of Hangzhou; the government suspends the requirement of rent payments, alms of 108,840 kg (120 tons) of rice are distributed to the poor, and items such as bamboo, planks, and rush-matting are exempt from government taxation.

title: Battle of the Standard
event: August 22—Battle of the Standard: David I of Scotland is defeated by the English.

title: 1138 Aleppo earthquake
event: October 11—A deadly earthquake in Aleppo, Syria kills about 230,000 people. See 1138 Aleppo earthquake.

title: Portugal
event: July 25—Battle of Ourique: The independence of Portugal from the Kingdom of León declared after the Almoravids, led by Ali ibn Yusuf, are defeated by Prince Afonso Henriques. He then becomes Afonso I, King of Portugal, after calling the first assembly of the estates-general of Portugal at Lamego, where he is given the Crown from the Bishop of Bragança, to confirm the independence.

title: Rhine
event: Henry Jasomirgott is made count palatine of the Rhine.

title: Marburg
event: Marburg becomes a town.

title: France
event: June 3 – Pierre Abelard is condemned for heresy by a church court in Sens, France.

title: Battle of Lincoln (1141)
event: February 2—Battle of Lincoln: Robert, 1st Earl of Gloucester and Empress Matilda wrest control of the English throne from King Stephen.

title: Battle of Wilton (1143)
event: July 1 – Battle of Wilton in England.

title: Portugal
event: October 5—Treaty of Zamora: Portugal is recognized by the Kingdom of Leon as an independent kingdom, although it has functioned as one since the Battle of São Mamede.

title: France
event: The city of Montauban, France, is founded.

title: Lesmahagow
event: The Priory in Lesmahagow is founded by Benedictine monks.

title: Mosul
event: December 24—The County of Edessa falls to Zengi of Mosul (see Siege of Edessa).

title: Constantinople
event: Estimation: Merv in the Seljuk Empire becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Constantinople, capital of the Byzantine Empire.

title: Azerbaijan
event: Ildeniz, atabeg of Azerbaijan founds an dynasty, being the first independent Turkish dynasty of Azerbaijan

title: Marrakech
event: April – Abd al-Mu'min destroys the Almoravid Empire after capturing Marrakech.

title: Dore Abbey
event: Dore Abbey is founded.

title: Rupertsberg
event: Hildegard of Bingen founds the convent of Rupertsberg near Bingen.

title: Corfu
event: Roger II of Sicily takes Corfu from the Byzantine Empire, and pillages Corinth, Athens and Thebes.

title: Siege of Lisbon
event: July 1—October 25 – Afonso I of Portugal and a contingent of Crusaders invade Lisbon and drive out the Moors in the Siege of Lisbon. The assistance of English Crusaders will result in friendly relations between England & Portugal for decades.

title: Damascus
event: June – The Second Crusade reaches Jerusalem. They meet at the Council of Acre and decide to attack Damascus.

title: Susa
event: Roger II of Sicily takes Susa and Sfax in Tunisia.

title: Denmark
event: Åhus, Denmark gains city privileges.

title: Wyre Orkney
event: Cubbie Roo's Castle is built on Wyre, Orkney.

title: Mersey Ferry
event: A Benedictine priory is founded at Birkenhead, England, resulting in the first recorded Mersey Ferry.

title: Christchurch Priory
event: Christchurch Priory is founded in Dorset, England.

title: Castle Rising (castle)
event: Castle Rising is built in Norfolk, England by William d'Aubigny, 1st Earl of Arundel.

title: University of Paris
event: The University of Paris, now known as the Sorbonne, is founded.

title: Ireland
event: The Tuam is promoted to a Metropolitan Archdiocese in Ireland.

title: Constantinople
event: The earliest textual reference is made to Gypsies working as musicians in Constantinople.

title: Angkor Wat
event: The temple at Angkor Wat is completed in Khmer (present-day Cambodia).

title: North Yorkshire
event: Bolton Abbey is founded in North Yorkshire, England.

title: Ireland
event: The Church of Ireland acknowledges the Pope's authority.

title: Gorodets
event: The town of Gorodets (modern Russia) is founded by Prince Yuri Dolgoruki.

title: Touraine
event: May 18—Eleanor of Aquitaine marries Henry of Anjou after getting her previous marriage to Louis VII annulled.  Henry had claimed the County of Anjou, the County of Maine, and the province of Touraine upon the death of his protector Geoffrey Plantagenet, Count of Anjou, the previous year.  With the addition of Eleanor's lands, he now controls territory stretching unbroken from Cherbourg to Bayonne.

title: Switzerland
event: The city of Oberglatt (present-day Switzerland) is first mentioned in written literature.

title: Merv
event: Estimation: Constantinople, capital of the Byzantine Empire becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Merv in the Seljuk Empire.

title: Maldives
event: Islam is introduced to the Maldives.

title: Birmingham
event: Birmingham, England, and the Birmingham Bull Ring are founded.

title: Estonia
event: Tallinn, the capital of Estonia, is first marked on the world map by Al Idrisi.

title: Damascus
event: April 23 – Nur ad-Din Zangi gains control of Damascus, uniting Syria under one ruler.

title: Pope Adrian IV
event: December 14—Pope Adrian IV (also known as Hadrian IV) succeeds Pope Anastasius IV as the 169th pope. Born Nicholas Breakspear, he is the only English pope in history.

title: Bristol
event: The City of Bristol, UK (Brigstow) given Royal Charter.

title: Ireland
event: The Papal bull ''Laudabiliter'' gives the King of England lordship over Ireland.

title: Apulia
event: A rebellion breaks out against William II of Sicily, and the Byzantine Empire, encouraged by Pope Hadrian, invades Apulia.   William II crushes the rebellion, defeats the Byzantine armies at Brindisi, and humbles the Pope at Benevento.

title: Finland
event: January 20—According to legend, freeholder Lalli slays English crusader Bishop Henry with an axe on the ice of lake Köyliönjärvi in Finland.

title: Baghdad
event: January 12–March 16 – Caliph Al-Muqtafi Successfully defended Baghdad against the coalition forces of Sultan Muhammad of Hamadan,and Atabeg Qutb-adin of Mosul

title: Denmark
event: October 23—Battle of Grathe Heath: A civil war in Denmark ends with the death of King Sweyn III. Valdemar I of Denmark becomes king of all Denmark and restores and rebuilds the country.

title: University of Bologna
event: The University of Bologna is granted its first privileges by Emperor Frederick Barbarossa.

title: Ireland
event: The Diocese of Derry is founded in Ireland.

title: Pope Adrian IV
event: September 7—Pope Alexander III succeeds Pope Adrian IV as the 170th pope.

title: Portugal
event: The city of Tomar is founded in Portugal by Gualdim Pais.

title: Derby
event: Derby School is founded at Derby, England.

title: Italy
event: February 3 – Emperor Frederick Barbarossa takes Crema, Italy following a cruel siege, as part of his campaign against the independent Italian city-states.

title: Yue Fei
event: July 25—Emperor Xiaozong announces he will posthumously rehabilitate Yue Fei.

title: Loccum Abbey
event: Loccum Abbey in Hanover is founded as a Cistercian house by Cornwall.

title: Lam Tin
event: The Guanfuchang salt-fields (官富場) in Hong Kong, nowadays To Kwa Wan, Kowloon Bay, Kwun Tong and Lam Tin districts, are first officially operated by the Song Dynasty.

title: Notre Dame de Paris
event: The first stone of Paris's Notre Dame Cathedral is set by Pope Alexander III.

title: China
event: Construction of the Liuhe Pagoda of Hangzhou, China, is completed in this year during the Song Dynasty.

title: Denmark
event: Absalon, archbishop of Denmark, leads the first Danish synod at Lund.

title: University of Oxford
event: University of Oxford is founded.

title: Aquitaine
event: Prince Richard of England becomes duke of Aquitaine. He later becomes King Richard I of England.

title: Rügen
event: King Valdemar I of Denmark conquers Arkona on the Island of Rügen, the strongest pagan fortress and temple in Northern Europe.

title: Cairo
event: December 22—Afraid that the Egyptian capital Fustat (in today's Old Cairo) will be captured by the Crusaders, its Fatimid vizier, Shawar, orders the city set afire. The city burns for 54 days.

title: Cairo
event: Nur ad-Din Zangi invades Egypt, and names his nephew Saladin sultan as well as vizier of Cairo.

title: Kievan Rus'
event: Prince Andrey Bogolyubskiy sacks Kiev and makes Vladimir the capital of Kievan Rus'

title: North America
event: According to folklore, the Welsh prince Madoc sailes to North America and founds a colony.

title: Constantinople
event: Estimation: Fes in the Almohad Empire becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Constantinople, capital of the Byzantine Empire.

title: Estonia
event: The Danes attack Estonia.

title: Ireland
event: Henry II of England invades Ireland with the aid of the ousted King of Leinster, Diarmait MacMurrough.  As is usual at this time, Henry commandeers merchant ships as part of his invasion.  Henry claims the ports of Dublin, Waterford, and Wexford for himself and promises the Irish chieftains protection if they will acknowledge him as their overlord.  This begins eight centuries of conflict between Ireland and England.

title: Aquitaine
event: Duke Richard of Aquitaine becomes Duke of Poitiers (later King Richard I of England).

title: Canterbury
event: Saint Thomas Becket is buried at Canterbury and canonized.

title: Abergavenny Castle
event: Abergavenny Castle is seized by the Welsh.

title: Leaning Tower of Pisa
event: The Leaning Tower of Pisa is built.

title: Aden
event: Saladin seizes Aden in Arabia.

title: Battle of Alnwick (1174)
event: William I of Scotland is captured by Ranulf de Glanvill at the Battle of Alnwick, and Henry II of England occupies part of Scotland.

title: Italy
event: Fire destroys most of Padua, Italy.

title: Portugal
event: The city of Pombal, Portugal is founded by Gualdim Pais.

title: London
event: The first known race track of the post-classical era opens at Newmarket in London.

title: Damascus
event: Saladin captures Damascus.

title: China
event: Vietnam is given the official name of Annam by China.

title: Luzon
event: The Kingdom of Namayan reaches its peak on Luzon.

title: Ireland
event: Treaty of Windsor: Ruaidri Ua Conchobair (Rory O'Conner), the last High King of Ireland, submits to Henry II as vassal of Ireland.

title: Vordingborg Castle
event: Vordingborg Castle is completed.

title: Visoko Bosnia and Herzegovina
event: The high academy of Bosnian religious organization in Moštre, Visoko, is first mentioned in Vatican archives.

title: Qift
event: Al-Adil I, the Muslim ruler of Egypt, suppresses a revolt by the Christian Copts in the city of Qift, hanging nearly 3,000 of them on the trees around the city.

title: Aleppo
event: Raynald of Chatillon is released from prison in Aleppo.

title: London Bridge
event: Construction begins on the London Bridge.

title: Aleppo
event: May 22—The Hashshashin attempt to murder Saladin near Aleppo.

title: Peterborough
event: Benedictus Abbas becomes abbot of Peterborough.

title: Yorkshire
event: Byland Abbey is founded in Yorkshire by the Cistercians.

title: Angkor Wat
event: The Cham sack the Khmer capital of Angkor Wat.

title: California
event: The Sung Document is written, detailing the discovery of Mu-Lan-Pi (suggested by some to be California) by Muslim sailors.

title: Leaning Tower of Pisa
event: The Leaning Tower of Pisa begins to lean as the third level is completed.

title: Angkor Wat
event: The Cham sack the Khmer capital near Angkor Wat.

title: Canterbury
event: June 18—Five Canterbury monks see what is possibly the Giordano Bruno crater being formed.

title: Portugal
event: Afonso I is recognized as the true King of Portugal by Pope Alexander III, bringing Portugal the protection of the Catholic Church against the Castilian monarchy.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: Westminster School is founded by the monks of Westminster Abbey (by papal command).

title: Chichen Itza
event: The Maya city of Chichen Itza is sacked and burned by Hunac Ceel, the Mayapan king.

title: France
event: Artois is annexed by France.

title: China
event: Estimation: Hangzhou, capital of Southern Song China, becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Fes in the Almohad Empire.

title: Arizona
event: The last major volcanic eruption occurs of Sunset Crater, in Arizona.

title: France
event: November 18—Philip II becomes King of France.

title: France
event: The word Albigensians is first used by chronicler Geoffroy du Breuil of Vigeois to describe the inhabitants of Albi, France.

title: Denmark
event: Canute VI is crowned king of Denmark.

title: Łęczyca
event: The first Sejm, or Polish Parliament, convenes at Łęczyca.

title: Constantinople
event: Massacre of the Latins in Constantinople.

title: Red Sea
event: Raynald of Chatillon has seven ships freighted over the isthmus of Suez, which he then uses to pillage the shores of the Red Sea, as far as the gates of Mecca.

title: India
event: Battle of Palnadu: The Kalachuri civil war ends in victory for the Palanati Kalachuris of India, and their leader, Nalagama Raju.

title: Pomerania
event: Archbishop Absalon of Lund wins a naval victory over Bogislav, duke of Pomerania.

title: Glastonbury Abbey
event: A great fire at Glastonbury Abbey destroys  several  buildings.

title: Ireland
event: Henry II of England knights his heir John of England and sends him to Ireland to enforce English control.  According to Gerald of Wales, the only witness to chronicle the expedition, it is a disaster in which money is wasted on alcohol & the Irish chieftains are scorned into uniting against a common enemy.  By the end of the year, John has returned to England in defeat.  Nonetheless, Henry gets him named King of Ireland by Pope Urban III and procures a golden crown with peacock feathers.

title: London
event: Templars settle in London and begin building the New Temple Church.

title: Denmark
event: The Katedralskolan, the oldest school in northern Europe, and one of the oldest in Europe, is founded in Lund, Denmark.

title: Vardzia
event: August 15—The cave city of Vardzia is consecrated by Queen Tamar of Georgia.

title: Constantinople
event: Alexius Branas attempts to seize Constantinople in defiance of his master Isaac II Angelus.

title: Pomerania
event: The Cathedral of St. Jacob is consecrated in Szczecin, Pomerania.

title: Chichen Itza
event: The Toltecs are deposed at Chichen Itza.

title: Corsica
event: Genoa takes Bonifacio (in Corsica) from Pisa.

title: Battle of Hattin
event: July 4—Battle of Hattin: Saladin defeats Guy of Lusignan, King of Jerusalem.

title: Krak des Chevaliers
event: Saladin unsuccessfully besieges the Hospitaller fortress of Krak des Chevaliers in modern Syria.

title: London
event: Newgate Prison is built in London.

title: Basilica of San Isidoro
event: Alfonso IX of León convened at the Basilica of San Isidoro the Cortes of León with representatives of the nobility, clergy and towns. These Cortes are  considered as the first parliament in Europe.

title: Kerak
event: The Crusader castles of Montreal and Kerak are captured by Saladin.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: The town of Dundalk in the Republic of Ireland gains its charter.

title: Switzerland
event: Duke Berthold V of Zähringen founds the city of Bern (present-day Switzerland).

title: China
event: The first reference to the windmill in Europe is made by a Dean Herbert of East Anglia, whose mills are supposedly in competition with the abbey of Bury St Edmunds.  This is probably an invention imported from interaction with the Muslim world, since the first windmills were most likely innovated from the Bana Musa brothers in the Islamic Middle East during the middle 9th century.  The windmill will spread in the other direction, to be introduced to China by as early as 1219.

title: Tusculum
event: April 17—Tusculum is destroyed by the Commune of Rome's army.

title: Battle of Arsuf
event: September 7—Richard I of England defeats Saladin at the Battle of Arsuf during the Third Crusade.

title: Beijing
event: Marco Polo Bridge, or Lugouqiao, is completed in Beijing.

title: Estonia
event: Prince Yaroslav Vladimirovich of Novgorod burns down Tartu and Otepää Castles in Estonia.

title: Delhi
event: Qutb-ud-din Aybak, a Ghurid slave commander, captures Delhi.

title: Portsmouth
event: The city of Portsmouth is awarded its Royal Charter.

title: Huai River
event: The Yellow River of China experiences a major course change, taking over the Huai River drainage system for the next 700 years.

title: Estonia
event: The Danes attack Estonia.

title: Chartres Cathedral
event: June 10 – A fire at Chartres Cathedral leads to the start of its rebuilding.

title: China
event: July 5 – Emperor Guangzong of Song China is forced to give up his throne.

title: Battle of Alarcos
event: July 18—Battle of Alarcos: Almohad ruler Abu Yusuf Ya'qub al-Mansur decisively defeats Castilian King Alfonso VIII.

title: London
event: Spring—In London, a popular uprising of the poor against the rich is led by William Fitz Osbern.

title: Alabama
event: According to a popular legend, Prince Madog of Gwynedd reaches North America in what is present-day Alabama.

title: Arbroath Abbey
event: Arbroath Abbey is consecrated, and dedicated to St. Thomas Becket.

title: Corfu
event: Corfu is occupied by the Genoese.

title: Estonia
event: The Danes attack Estonia.

title: Devon
event: John of England captures a party of eighteen French knights & many men-at-arms in the ongoing conflict against France.  King Richard I of England introduces a new Great Seal in an attempt to keep the war against France funded.  The government proclaims that charters previously struck with the old seal are no longer valid and must be renewed with a fresh payment.  The office of Lord Warden of the Stannaries is also introduced to tax the produce of tin mines in Cornwall and Devon.

title: France
event: January 8—Pope Innocent III succeeds Pope Celestine III as the 176th pope.  He immediately lays an interdict on Laon in an attempt to stamp out independent beliefs there.  This will be followed by interdicts against France in 1199 and Normandy in 1203.

title: Ohio
event: The Iroquois invade modern-day Ohio from the north.

title: University of Paris
event: The University of Paris receives its charter from Philip II of France.

title: Aquitaine
event: August 24 – After touring an army through Aquitaine to assert his right to it, John of England weds 13 year old Isabella of Angoulême at Bordeaux.

title: Flanders
event: John of England puts an embargo on wheat exported to Flanders in an attempt to force an allegiance between the states.  He also puts a levy of a fifteenth on the value of cargo exported to France, and disallows the export of wool to France without a special license.  The levies are enforced in each port by at least six men, including one churchman and one knight.  John also affirms this year that judgements made by the court of Westminster are as valid as those made before the king himself or his chief justice.

title: Rueda Abbey
event: The Real Monasterio de Nuestra Senora de Rueda is founded in Aragon Province, Spain.

title: 1202 Syria earthquake
event: May 20 – An earthquake occurs in Syria.

title: India
event: The Temple of Nataraja is completed by Chidanbaram of India.

title: France
event: April 16 – Philip II of France enters Rouen, leading to the eventual unification of Normandy and France.

title: Bosphorus
event: June 23 – The Fleet of the Fourth Crusade enters the Bosphorus.

title: Constantinople
event: July 17 – The armies of the Fourth Crusade capture Constantinople by assault; the Byzantine emperor Alexius III flees from his capital into exile.

title: Kingdom of Thessalonica
event: Boniface of Montferrat, a leader of the Fourth Crusade, founds the Kingdom of Thessalonica.

title: University of Paris
event: The writings of French theologian Amalric of Bena are condemned by the University of Paris and Pope Innocent III.

title: Cham (district)
event: The district of Cham becomes subject to Bavaria.

title: Beaulieu Abbey
event: Beaulieu Abbey is founded.

title: Jersey
event: Guernsey and Jersey decide, after a plebiscite of wealthy land owners, to remain with the English crown after Normandy was recaptured by Philip II of France.

title: Constantinople
event: April 13 – Fourth Crusade: The Crusaders take Constantinople by storm, and pillage the city for 3 days.

title: Flanders
event: May 16 – Baldwin, Count of Flanders is crowned emperor of the Latin Empire a week after his election by the members of the Fourth Crusade.

title: Anjou
event: Anjou is conquered by Philip II of France.  Fearing a French invasion of England itself, John of England requires every English male over 12 to enter an association for the general defence of the realm and the preservation of peace.

title: Diocese of Bath and Wells
event: William of Wrotham, Lord Warden of the Stannaries of England, oversees a reform of English currency.  In keeping with other high-ranking bureaucrats of his time and place, this is just one of Wrotham's many offices: he is also Keeper of the King's Ports & Galleys, supervisor of the mints of Canterbury and London, ward of the vacant Diocese of Bath and Wells, an archdeacon of Taunton, a canon of Wells, and will serve the following year as a circuit judge.

title: Estonia
event: King Valdemar II and Archbishop Andreas Sunonis raid Saaremaa Island, Estonia, forcing the islanders to submit. The Danes build a fortress,  but finding no volunteers to man it, they burn it down themselves and leave the island.

title: Liverpool
event: King John issues letters patent creating the new Borough of Liverpool.

title: Leeds
event: November – Leeds, then a market town, received its first charter.

title: Estonia
event: With the help of the newly converted local tribes of Livs and Letts, the Crusaders initiate raids into part of what is present-day Estonia; the resulting ancient fight for independence lasts until 1227.

title: Denmark
event: January 31 – Battle of Lena: Inferior Swedish forces defeat the invading Danes and king Sverker the Younger is deposed as king of Sweden. He is succeeded by his rival Erik Knutsson.

title: West Lake
event: April 15 – A fire breaks out in the Song Chinese capital city of Hangzhou, raging for 4 days and nights, destroying 58,097 over an area of more than 3 miles, killing 59 people, and an unrecorded amount of other people who are trampled while attempting to flee. The government provides temporary lodging for 5,345 people in nearby Buddhist and Taoist monasteries. The collective victims of the disaster are given 160,000 strings of cash, along with 400 tons of rice. Some of the government officials who lost their homes take up residence in rented boathouses on the nearby West Lake.

title: London Bridge
event: London Bridge is completed.

title: Iran
event: The army of the Kingdom of Georgia raids the Muslim principalities in north Iran.

title: London
event: St Helen's Bishopsgate in London is founded.

title: Smithsonian Institution
event: 1210–1211 – Shazi makes Pen box, from Persia (Iran) or Afghanistan. It is now kept at Freer Gallery of Art, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C..

title: Battle of Gestilren
event: July 17 – Former king Sverker the Younger of Sweden is defeated and killed by present king Erik Knutsson of Sweden in the Battle of Gestilren.

title: Estonia
event: Troops led by Estonian resistance fighter Lembitu of Lehola destroy a garrison of missionaries in the historical Estonian region of Sakala, and raid the Russian town of Pskov.

title: Beijing
event: Mongol forces under Genghis Khan invade Jin China, aiming at this stage simply to loot the countryside. A Chinese army is defeated and slaughtered at the Badger's Mount Campaign near Zhangjiakou and another is beaten at Mukden, where the city is taken. Beijing is also besieged by the Mongol hordes.

title: France
event: The Children's Crusade, led by 12-year-old Stephen of Cloyes, sets out for the Holy Land from France.

title: Bran Castle
event: Bran Castle is erected by the Teutonic Knights.

title: Beijing
event: Jin China is overrun by the Mongols under Genghis Khan, who plunder the countryside and cities, until only Beijing remains free, despite two bloody palace coups and a lengthy siege.

title: Battle of Damme
event: May 30 – Battle of Damme: The English fleet under William Longespée, 3rd Earl of Salisbury destroys a French fleet off the Belgian port, in the first major victory for the fledgling Royal Navy.

title: Battle of Muret
event: September 12 – Battle of Muret: The Toulousain and Aragonese forces of Raymond VI of Toulouse and Peter II of Aragon are defeated by the Albigensian Crusade under Simon de Montfort.

title: Bielefeld
event: The German city of Bielefeld is founded.

title: Beijing
event: The Emperor of Jin China surrenders to the Mongols under Genghis Khan, who have besieged Beijing for a year. He pays a huge ransom and then abandons Northern China, heading for Kaifeng.

title: University of Oxford
event: June 20 – The University of Oxford receives its charter.

title: France
event: July 27 – Battle of Bouvines:  In France, Philip II of France defeats John of England.

title: Beijing
event: Beijing is captured and torched by the Mongols under Genghis Khan, initiating the Yuan Dynasty in China. Beijing burns for more than a month.

title: New York
event: 1215–1216 – The Macy Jug, from Iran, is made. It is now kept at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.

title: Ireland
event: Ballintubber Abbey is founded by King Cathal Crovdearg O'Connor of Connaught in Ireland.

title: Constantinople
event: April 9 – Peter of Courtenay is crowned emperor of the Latin Empire of Constantinople at Rome, by Pope Honorius III.

title: Battle of Sandwich (1217)
event: August 24 – First Barons' War: In the Battle of Sandwich between English and French soldiers in the English Channel, mercenary Eustace the Monk, working for the French side, is captured and beheaded.

title: Ireland
event: England decrees that only Englishman can be clergy of Ireland.

title: Damietta
event: Damietta is besieged by the knights of the Fifth Crusade.

title: Estonia
event: The Livonian Brothers of the Sword begin to conquer Estonia.

title: University of Salamanca
event: Alfonso IX of Castile founds the University of Salamanca.

title: Denmark
event: June 15 – Battle of Lyndanisse: Danish crusaders led by King Waldemar II conquer Tallinn. The Flag of Denmark allegedly falls from the sky during that battle.

title: Damietta
event: November 5 – Damietta, Egypt falls to the Crusaders after a siege.

title: Estonia
event: August 8 – Battle of Lihula: The Estonians defeat the invading Swedes.

title: Samarkand
event: The Mongols first invade the Abbasid Caliphate; Bukhara and Samarkand are taken.

title: Caspian Sea
event: The Islamic lands of Central Asia are overrun by the armies of the Mongol invader Genghis Khan (ca. 1155–1227), who lays waste to many civilizations and creates an empire that stretches from China to the Caspian Sea.  However, he fails to destroy the strength of Islam in Central Asia.

title: Amiens Cathedral
event: Rebuilding of Amiens Cathedral begins.

title: York Minster
event: Rebuilding of York Minster begins.

title: Salisbury Cathedral
event: Building of the Salisbury Cathedral begins.

title: Chichen Itza
event: The Maya of the Yucatán revolt against the rulers of Chichen Itza.

title: Tbilisi
event: A large and highly efficient Mongol army, dispatched under Subutai by Genghis Khan to Georgia, defeats two Georgian armies around Tbilisi, but lacks the will or equipment to besiege the city.

title: Italy
event: Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II founds the University of Padua in Italy.

title: Damietta
event: Sultan Kamil, Saladin's son and successor, offers Palestine to the Crusaders in return for Damietta, which the Crusaders eventually give up in exchange for a safe retreat from the Nile Delta.

title: Merv
event: February – Merv is sacked by the Mongols under Tolui at the orders of Genghis Khan. Contemporary scholars report over a million people are systematically killed in the aftermath.

title: 1222 Cyprus earthquake
event: May 11 – 1222 Cyprus earthquake.

title: Battle of the Kalka River
event: May 31 – Battle of the Kalka River: The Mongol armies of Genghis Khan defeat the Russian warriors.

title: Tula Hidalgo
event: The Chichimecas capture Tula, Hidalgo.

title: New York
event: September 14 (approximately) — St. Francis of Assisi, while praying on the mountain of Verna, during a 40-day fast, is said to have had a vision, as a result of which he received the stigmata. Brother Leo, who had been with Francis at the time, left a clear and simple account of the event, the first definite account of the phenomenon of stigmata.New York  date = 09/01/1909  url = http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/06221a.htm  accessdate = 2008-01-21}}<

title: Delhi
event: Iltutmish, the sultan of Delhi, repels  a Mongol attack.

title: Gąsawa
event: November 23 – Polish Prince Leszek I the White is assassinated at an assembly of Piast dukes at Gąsawa.

title: Finland
event: According to Russian chronicles, Novgorod attacks Finland with devastating results.

title: Estonia
event: The Estonian ancient fight for independence ends with foreign rule in the country for next 700 years.

title: Constantinople
event: Baldwin II becomes emperor of the Latin Empire in Constantinople, with John of Brienne as regent.

title: Sukaphaa
event: Sukaphaa, the first Ahom king, establishes his rule in Assam. The Ahom kings reign for close to 600 years.

title: Majorca
event: King James I of Aragon decides to launch a major offensive against the Muslims in Majorca.

title: Gloucestershire
event: Beverston Castle, Gloucestershire, England is founded.

title: France
event: The University of Toulouse is founded in France.

title: Finland
event: The city of Turku, Finland is founded.

title: Bethlehem
event: February 18 – Sixth Crusade: Frederick II signs a ten-year truce with al-Kamil, regaining Jerusalem, Nazareth, and Bethlehem with neither military engagements nor support from the papacy.

title: Majorca
event: September 12 – The Aragonese army under the command of James I of Aragon disembarks at Santa Ponça, Majorca, with the purpose of conquering the island.

title: Siby
event: In the West African village of Siby, Sundiata Keita, founder of the Mali Empire, forces the Malinkés to bind themselves to each other by oath.

title: Klokotnitsa
event: March 9 – Bulgarian tsar Ivan Asen II defeats Theodore of Epirus near the village of Klokotnitsa.

title: China
event: April 9 – After a bizarre weather phenomena of yellowish clouds and dust chokes the air around Hangzhou, Song Dynasty, China, obscuring the sky and sun, a fire breaks out at night in the southeast of the city, which continues into the next day. Fighting the flames is difficult due to limited visibility. When the fires are extinguished, it is discovered that an entire district of some 10,000 houses in the southeast of the city were consumed by the flames.

title: Korea
event: Mongol troops cross the Yalu River into Korea, then under the Goryeo Kingdom.

title: Tripitaka Koreana
event: The first edition of ''Tripitaka Koreana'' is destroyed by Mongol invaders.

title: Elburg
event: Elburg gets its city-rights.

title: Baghdad
event: Mustansiriya School is founded in Baghdad.

title: Runan County
event: February 9 – Song Dynasty Chinese and Mongolian armies occupy the Jurchen capital at Caizhou, marking the collapse of the Jin Dynasty (1115–1234).

title: Lancaster Royal Grammar School
event: The Lancaster Royal Grammar School is founded.

title: Battle of Kirina
event: Prince Sogolon Djata leads the Mandinka to victory at the Battle of Kirina against the Susu marking the birth of the Mali Empire.

title: Chengdu
event: Only 4 of 58 districts in Sichuan, China, are captured from the Southern Song by the Mongols under Ögedei. The population of Chengdu, roughly one million inhabitants, is summarily slaughtered after the Mongols take the city with little effort.

title: Elbląg
event: Elbląg, Poland is founded.

title: Caucasus
event: After turning aside south for 15 years to invade the Caucasus, Asia Minor and Persia{{mdash

title: Italy
event: Gualdo Tadino, Italy, is destroyed by fire.

title: France
event: The County of Artois is founded in France.

title: Constantinople
event: Baldwin II becomes Latin Emperor of Constantinople.

title: Kingdom of England
