event: England and Scotland sign the Treaty of York, establishing the location of their common border.

title: Bhutan
event: Thowadra Monastery is founded in Bhutan.

title: Kievan Rus'
event: Batu Khan and the Golden Horde sack the Ruthenian city of Kiev.

title: Battle of Kirina
event: Battle of Kirina: Mandinka prince Sundiata Keita defeats Sosso king Soumaoro Kanté, beginning the Mali Empire.

title: Battle of the Neva
event: July 15 – Battle of the Neva: Russian prince Alexander Nevsky defeats the Swedes, saving Russia from a full-scale enemy invasion from the North.

title: Sulu Archipelago
event: Tuan Mash'ika, an Arab, travels and introduces Islam to Sulu.

title: Korea
event: Emperor Lizong of Song China accepts the Neo-Confucian teachings of the late Zhu Xi, including his commentary on the Four Books. This will have an impact upon the philosophical schools of surrounding countries as well, including Korea, Japan, and Vietnam.

title: Battle of Mohi
event: April 11 – Battle of Mohi: Batu Khan and Subutai defeat Béla IV of Hungary. The battle is the last major event in the Mongol Invasion of Europe.

title: Lake Peipus
event: April 5 – During a battle on the ice of Lake Peipus, Russian forces, led by Alexander Nevsky, rebuff an invasion attempt by the Teutonic Knights.

title: Karakorum
event: A French goldsmith working in Budapest named Guillaume Boucher is captured by the Mongols and taken to Karakorum.

title: Gradec Zagreb
event: The golden bull issued by King Béla IV to inhabitants of Gradec (today's Zagreb) and Samobor in Croatia, during Mongol invasion of Europe. By this golden bull King Bela IV proclaimed a Free Royal Borough (free and royal city).

title: Crown of Castile
event: Castile captures the city of Murcia from the Moors.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: The rebuilding of Westminster Abbey is started.

title: Chapultepec
event: The Mexicans settle Chapultepec, a former Toltec stronghold.

title: Sainte-Chapelle
event: The Gothic chapel of Sainte-Chapelle is built.

title: Beaulieu Abbey
event: Beaulieu Abbey is dedicated.

title: London
event: Romford, London, England is chartered as a market town.

title: Bethlem Royal Hospital
event: Bedlam becomes part of London.

title: France
event: April 26 – The Gothic chapel Sainte-Chapelle is consecrated in Paris, France.

title: Ommen
event: The Dutch city of Ommen receives city rights and fortification rights from Otto III, Archbishop of Utrecht on August 25.

title: Ireland
event: August 15 – The First Battle of Athenry is fought in Galway, Ireland.

title: Al-Andalus
event: The Moors lose possession of Alicante in Al-Andalus (Islamic Spain).

title: Portugal
event: King Afonso III of Portugal recaptures Faro in the Algarve from the Moors, thus ending the Portuguese Reconquista.

title: Greece
event: The city of Mystras, Greece is fortified and a palace is constructed there by William II Villehardouin.

title: Finland
event: Swedish statesman Birger Jarl subjugates the province of Tavastia in Finland, securing Swedish power in Finland.

title: France
event: Alphonse of Toulouse orders the expulsion of Jews from Poitou, France.

title: France
event: Jean Mouflet makes an agreement with the abbot of Saint-Pierre-le-Vif in the Senonais region in France: in return for an annual payment, the monastery will recognize Jean as a citizen of Sens. He is a leather merchant, has a leather shop that he leases for the rent of 50 shillings a year. The agreement is witnessed by Jean's wife, Douce, daughter of a wealthy and prominent citizen of Sens, Felis Charpentier.

title: Buda
event: The Hungarian capital is moved from Esztergom to Buda.

title: Damietta
event: King Louis IX of France captures Damietta in Egypt, the first major military engagement of the Seventh Crusade.

title: Damietta
event: April 30 – King Louis IX of France is released by his Egyptian captors, after paying a ransom of one million dinars and turning over the city of Damietta.

title: Romney Marsh
event: October 12 – A great storm shifts the mouth of the River Rother 12 miles (20 km) to the west; a battering series of strong storms significantly alter other coastal geography as well (''see Romney Marsh'').

title: Portugal
event: King Afonso III of Portugal captures the Algarve from the Moors, thus completing the expulsion of the Moors from Portugal.

title: University of Valladolid
event: The University of Valladolid is founded in Spain.

title: Rialto Bridge
event: The Rialto Bridge in Venice, Italy is converted from a pontoon bridge to a permanent, raised wooden structure.

title: France
event: The Parlement law courts of ''ancien régime'' France are established.

title: Siberia
event: A kurultai is called by Batu Khan in Siberia as part of maneuverings to eventually elect Möngke Khan as khan of the Mongol empire in 1251.

title: Quanzhou
event: Starting in this year and ending in 1275, the foreign-born Muslim Kuwabara serves as the Commissioner of Merchant Shipping for the Song Dynasty Chinese seaport at Quanzhou, where he writes a monograph on the Chinese shipping industry and maritime economy.

title: Kievan Rus'
event: Alexander Nevsky signs the first peace treaty between Kievan Rus' and Norway.

title: Italy
event: King Conrad IV of Germany invades Italy, but fails to subdue the supporters of Pope Innocent IV.

title: Tripitaka Koreana
event: The carving of the ''Tripitaka Koreana'', a collection of Buddhist scriptures recorded on some 81,000 wooden blocks, is completed.

title: France
event: April – The first Shepherds' Crusade, a domestic French uprising in response to events in Egypt during the Seventh Crusade, occurs.

title: Denmark
event: December 25 – Christopher I of Denmark is crowned King of Denmark in Lund Cathedral

title: Italy
event: The first European gold coins are minted in the Italian city of Florence, and are known as florins.

title: University of Paris
event: Thomas Aquinas travels to the University of Paris to begin his studies there for a masters degree.

title: Flanders
event: July – William II, Count of Holland defeats the Flemish army at Westkapelle.

title: Italy
event: A series of naval wars begins between the Italian city-states of Genoa and Venice, which will continue sporadically until 1371.

title: Italy
event: The Basilica of San Francesco, the earliest important structure in the Italian Gothic style of architecture, is completed in Assisi, Italy.

title: Ireland
event: Sligo Abbey is built in Sligo, Ireland.

title: London
event: The Domus Conversorum, a building and institution in London for Jews who had converted to Christianity, is established by King Henry III of England.

title: Cairo
event: The Mongol Empire launches attacks on the Muslim cities of Baghdad and Cairo.

title: Yunnan
event: The Mongol Empire destroys the Kingdom of Dali in modern Yunnan and incorporates the region into their empire.

title: China
event: The Chinese era ''Baoyou'' begins in the Southern Song Dynasty of China.

title: Constantinople
event: May – King Louis IX of France dispatches William of Rubruck from Constantinople on a missionary journey to convert the Tatars of central and eastern Asia. Later that year, William records the first meeting between European Christians and Buddhists.

title: France
event: King Louis IX of France, having exhausted his funds and being needed at home, abandons the Seventh Crusade (which he had conducted first in Egypt and then Syria) and returns to France.

title: Portugal
event: King Afonso III of Portugal holds the first session of the ''Cortes'' (Portugal's general assembly composed of nobles, members of the middle class, and representatives from all municipalities) in Leiria.

title: Denmark
event: The Danish city of Copenhagen receives its city charter.

title: St Mark's Basilica
event: The Horses of Saint Mark, once supposed to have adorned the Arch of Trajan in ancient Rome, are installed at Saint Mark's Basilica in Venice.

title: Malmö
event: The Swedish city of Malmö is founded.

title: Yunnan
event: The Mongols destroy the Kingdom of Dali in modern Yunnan.

title: Lisbon
event: Lisbon becomes the capital of the Kingdom of Portugal.

title: UNESCO
event: The Gothic cathedral at Bourges, France, is completed. It is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

title: Constantinople
event: May – William of Rubruck from Constantinople returns to Cyprus from his missionary journey to convert the Tatars of central and eastern Asia, his efforts having been unsuccessful.

title: France
event: August – The final Cathar stronghold in southern France falls, eliminating their last refuge since the Roman Catholic Church began the Albigensian Crusade to crush the sect in 1209.

title: Iran
event: December 15 – Hulagu Khan captures and destroys the Hashshashin stronghold at Alamut in present-day Iran.

title: Iran
event: Hulagu Khan establishes the Ilkhanate dynasty of Persia, which will become one of four main divisions of the Mongol Empire.

title: Anatolia
event: October – Mongol commander Baiju (operating under Hulagu Khan's command) leads his forces in a victory over Kay Ka'us II of the Sultanate of Rüm, thereby capturing Anatolia.

title: France
event: Robert de Sorbon founds the ''Collège de Sorbonne'' at Paris, giving a formal college (and still-common name) to the already existing University of Paris in France.

title: Kraków
event: The city of Kraków is rebuilt by Boleslaus V of Poland after being nearly destroyed in the Tatar invasions in 1241.

title: Baghdad
event: February 10 – Battle of Baghdad (1258) – Hulagu Khan's Mongol forces overrun Baghdad, then the leading center of Islamic culture and learning and capital of the Abbasid Caliphate. They burn the imperial city to the ground, killing as many as 1,000,000 citizens.

title: China
event: The Chinese era ''Baoyou'' ends in the Northern Song Dynasty of China.

title: Italy
event: Civil unrest in northern Italy spawns the medieval musical form of Geisslerlieder, penitential songs sung by wandering bands of Flagellants.

title: Korea
event: Korea surrenders to the Mongols, ending the effective resistance of the Choe faction within Korea.

title: Iraq
event: January – One of the largest volcanic eruptions of the Holocene epoch occurs, possibly from a tropical location such as El Chichón, Mexico or Quilotoa, Ecuador.Geophysical Research Letters'', 321, XXXX, doi:10.1029/2006JAXYZW, Mar 2006. (available [http://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/~julieneg/docs/1258_enso_grl.pdf online], pdf file)<  Observed effects of the eruption include the following anecdotal accounts: dry fog in France; lunar eclipses in England; severe winter in Europe; a harsh spring in Northern Iceland; famine in England, Western Germany, France, and Northern Italy; and pestilence in London, parts of France, Austria, Iraq, Syria, and South-East Turkey.

title: France
event: December 4 – Kings Louis IX of France and Henry III of England agree to the Treaty of Paris, in which Henry renounces his claims to French-controlled territory on continental Europe (including Normandy) in exchange for Louis withdrawing his support for English rebels.

title: UNESCO
event: The famous frescoes of the Boyana Church in Bulgaria are completed (the church and its murals are now a UNESCO World Heritage Site).

title: Baltic Sea
event: The German cities of Lübeck, Wismar, and Rostock enter into a pact to defend against pirates of the Baltic Sea, laying the groundwork for the Hanseatic League.

title: China
event: August 11 – While conducting a siege against the Song Dynasty city known as Fishing Town in the province of Chongqing, China, the Mongol Khagan, Mongke Khan, dies in the nearby hills. Persian, Chinese, and Mongol records have different accounts of how he died, including succumbing to an arrow wound received by a Chinese archer in the siege, dysentery, and even a cholera epidemic. His death sparks a succession crisis in the Mongol Empire, while his brothers Ariq Böke and Kublai soon convene their own kuriltai to elect themselves as the next Khan of Khans, opening the path to a four–year-long civil war from 1260 to 1264. In the end, Ariq Böke surrenders to Kublai.

title: Qingzhou
event: While engaged in a war with the Mongols, the Song Chinese official Li Zengbo writes in his ''Kozhai Zagao, Xugaohou'' that the city of Qingzhou is manufacturing one to two thousand strong iron-cased gunpowder bomb shells a month, dispatching to Xiangyang and Yingzhou about ten to twenty thousand such bombs at a time.

title: Korea
event: The Goryeo kingdom in Korea surrenders to invading Mongol forces.

title: China
event: The Chinese era ''Kaiqing'' begins and ends in the Northern Song Dynasty of China.

title: Constantinople
event: September – Battle of Pelagonia: The Empire of Nicaea defeats the Principality of Achaea, ensuring the eventual reconquest of Constantinople in 1261.

title: Switzerland
event: War breaks out in the Valais (today in Switzerland) as the Bishopry of Sion defends against an invasion by the County of Savoy.

title: UNESCO
event: October 24 – The Cathedral of Chartres is dedicated in the presence of King Louis IX of France (the cathedral is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site).

title: Perthshire
event: Construction on the Dunkeld Cathedral begins in Perthshire, Scotland.

title: China
event: May 21 –  Kublai sends his envoy Hao Jing to negotiate with Song Dynasty Chancellor Jia Sidao, after the small force left by Kublai south of the Yangzi River is destroyed by a Chinese army of the Southern Song Dynasty. Chancellor Jia Sidao imprisons the entire embassy of Kublai. This slight will not be forgotten by Kublai, but he is unable to assault the Song due to the civil war with his rival brother Ariq Böke.

title: Bengal
event: The Sena Dynasty of Bengal falls.

title: China
event: The Chinese era ''Jingding'' begins and ends in the Southern Song Dynasty of China.

title: Constantinople
event: July 25 – The city of Constantinople is recaptured by Nicaean forces under the command of Alexios Strategopoulos, thus re-establishing the Byzantine Empire.

title: Switzerland
event: The Convent of Wurmsbach is established in Switzerland.

title: Cairo
event: Baibars establishes a puppet caliphate in Cairo.

title: China
event: Kublai Khan, who became a Khagan claimant in the previously year, releases 75 Song Dynasty Chinese merchants from captivity after they had been captured along the border of his Empire and the Southern Song Dynasty of China. This is an act to increase his reputation amongst the Chinese, shore up his legitimacy as a just ruler, and to gain more defectors from the Southern Song Dynasty.

title: China
event: The earliest extant Chinese illustration of 'Pascal's Triangle' is from Yang Hui's book ''Xiangjie Jiuzhang Suanfa'', published in this year, although knowledge of Pascal's Triangle existed in China by at least 1100.

title: Battle of Largs
event: October 2 – Battle of Largs: King Alexander III of Scotland defeats the Viking armada of King Haakon IV of Norway.

title: Crete
event: Genoa captures the city of Chania on Crete from the Venetians.

title: Caucasus
event: Hulagu Khan is defeated in an attempted invasion north of the Caucasus.

title: Żnin
event: Based on Magdeburg Law, Żnin (Poland) is given city rights.

title: London
event: The Savoy Palace is constructed in London by Count Peter II of Savoy.

title: Battle of Lewes
event: May 12 to May 14 – The Battle of Lewes of the Second Barons' War is fought between Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester and King Henry III of England in Sussex.  By the end of the battle, de Montfort's forces capture both King Henry and his son, future King Edward I, making de Montfort the uncrowned king of England for 15 months before Edward escapes captivity and recaptures the throne.

title: Ireland
event: June 18 – The Parliament of Ireland meets at Castledermot in County Kildare, the first definitively known meeting of this Irish legislature.

title: University of Oxford
event: September 14 – Walter de Merton formally completes the foundation of the House of Scholars of Merton (later Merton College, Oxford) to provide education in Malden and the University of Oxford.

title: Beijing
event: Kublai Khan decides to move his capital from Shangdu in Inner Mongolia to the Chinese city of Dadu (now Beijing).

title: Canterbury
event: April – Gilbert de Clare, 6th Earl of Hertford leads a massacre of the Jews at Canterbury.

title: Palace of Westminster
event: January 20 – In Westminster, the first elected English parliament (De Montfort's Parliament) conducts its first meeting in the Palace of Westminster, now also known as the Houses of Parliament.

title: Worcestershire
event: August 4 – The Battle of Evesham of the Second Barons' War is fought in Worcestershire, with the army of Edward defeating the forces of rebellious barons led by Simon de Montfort and killing de Montfort and many of his allies.  This is sometimes considered the death of chivalry in England.

title: Isle of Man
event: The Isle of Man comes under Scottish rule.

title: Sichuan
event: In the first major battle in 5 years since the Song Dynasty Chinese pushed the forces of Kublai Khan back across the Yangzi River after Mongke Khan's failed invasion in 1259, Kublai Khan engages the Chinese in Sichuan province. Kublai gains a preliminary victory and war booty of 146 captured Song Dynasty naval ships.

title: Czech Republic
event: The brewing of Budweiser Budvar beer begins in Bohemia (now part of the Czech Republic); Budweiser Budvar has been produced continuously there to this day.

title: Caesarea Maritima
event: The Mamluk Bahri dynasty of Egypt captures several cities and towns from Crusader states in the Middle East, including the cities of Haifa, Arsuf, and Caesarea Maritima; these events eventually precipitate the Eighth Crusade in 1267.

title: Cairo
event: Fire destroys parts of Old Cairo.

title: Anjou
event: February 26 – Battle of Benevento: The army of Charles, Count of Anjou, defeats a combined German and Sicilian force led by King Manfred of Sicily.  Manfred is killed in the battle and Pope Clement IV invests Charles as king of Sicily and Naples.

title: Isle of Man
event: The war between Scotland and Norway ends as King Alexander III of Scotland and King Magnus VI of Norway agree to the Treaty of Perth, which cedes the Western Isles and Isle of Man to Scotland in exchange for a large monetary payment.

title: France
event: In France, the gold écu and silver grosh coins are minted for the first time.

title: China
event: Niccolo and Maffeo Polo, father and uncle of Marco Polo, reach Kublai Khan's capital Khanbaliq (now Beijing) in China, setting the stage for Marco's famous expedition 5 years later.  Kublai Khan sends the Polos back with a message requesting that the Pope dispatch western scholars to teach in the Mongol Empire; however, this request is largely ignored.

title: Toron
event: The Mamluk sultan Baibars expands his domain, capturing the city of Byblos (in present-day Lebanon) and the important castle of Toron from the crusader states, and defeating the Armenians at Cilicia.

title: University of Oxford
event: Roger Bacon completes his work ''Opus Majus'' and sends it to Pope Clement IV, who had requested it be written; the work contains wide-ranging discussion of mathematics, optics, alchemy, astronomy, astrology, and other topics, and includes what some believe to be the first description of a magnifying glass. Bacon also completes ''Opus Minus'', a summary of ''Opus Majus'', later in the same year. The only source for his date of birth is his statement in the ''Opus Tertium'', written in 1267, that ''forty years have passed since I first learned the alphabet''. The 1214 birth date assumes he was not being literal, and meant 40 years had passed since he matriculated at Oxford at the age of 13. If he had been literal, his birth date was more likely to have been around 1220.

title: Vienna
event: The leadership of Vienna forces Jews to wear ''Pileum cornutum'',a cone-shaped head dress, in addition to the yellow badges Jews are already forced to wear.

title: Beijing
event: The Grand Capital is constructed in Khanbaliq (present-day Beijing) by Kublai Khan, having moved the capital of the Mongol Empire there three years prior.

title: France
event: In France, the use of hops as the exclusive flavoring agent used in the manufacture of beer is made compulsory.

title: Antioch
event: May 18 – The Principality of Antioch, a crusader state, falls to the Mamluk Sultan Baibars in the Battle of Antioch; Baibars' destruction of the city of Antioch is so great as to permanently negate the city's importance.

title: Hubei
event: The Battle of Xiangyang, a 6-year battle between the Chinese Song Dynasty and the Mongol forces of Kublai Khan, begins in what is today Hubei.

title: Blair Castle
event: The construction of Blair Castle in Scotland is begun by John Comyn.

title: Al-Andalus
event: The Almohad dynasty of caliphs (not universally accepted), that once ruled most of North Africa and Al-Andalus (Moorish Spain), is extinguished when Idris II is murdered in the dynasty's last remaining possession, Marrakesh.

title: Antioch
event: The Eastern Orthodox Patriarchy of Antioch returns to Antioch after a 171-year exile, during which it had been replaced by the Latin Patriarch of Antioch.

title: Korea
event: In Korea, the Sambyeolcho Rebellion begins against the Goryeo Dynasty, a puppet government of the Mongol Empire.

title: Iran
event: The city of Tabriz, in present-day Iran, is made capital of the Mongol Ilkhanate Empire (approximate date).

title: India
event: The independent state of Kutch is founded in present-day India.

title: Ireland
event: The cathedral on the Rock of Cashel in Ireland is completed.

title: University of Paris
event: December – Crucial aspects of the philosophy of Averroism (itself based on Aristotle's works) are banned by the Roman Catholic church in a condemnation enacted by papal authority at the University of Paris.

title: Italy
event: September 1 – Pope Gregory X succeeds Pope Clement IV as the 184th pope, as the compromise candidate between French and Italian cardinals, ending a 3-year conclave, the longest ever.

title: France
event: The County of Toulouse is returned to the crown of France.

title: China
event: Marco Polo departs from Venice with his father and uncle on his famous journey to Kublai Khan's China.

title: Caerphilly Castle
event: The construction of Caerphilly Castle, the largest in Wales, is completed.

title: Krak des Chevaliers
event: April 8 – Mamluk sultan Baibars continues his territorial expansion, capturing the strategically important castle Krak des Chevaliers from the Knights Hospitaller in present-day Syria.

title: Tripoli
event: Mamluk sultan Baibars conducts an unsuccessful siege of the city of Tripoli, and also fails in an attempted naval invasion of Cyprus.

title: China
event: December 18 – Kublai Khan renames his empire Yuan (元 yuán), officially marking the start of the Yuan Dynasty of China.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: The Nakhi kingdom of the northern Himalayan foothills is annexed by the Yuan Dynasty.

title: Albania
event: Charles I of Anjou, King of Naples, occupies Durrës in Albania and establishes an Albanian kingdom.

title: Portugal
event: King Alphonso III of Portugal eliminates the last Moorish community in Portugal at Faro.

title: London
event: The Worshipful Company of Cordwainers receives the right to regulate the leather trade in London, England.

title: Parliament of Croatia
event: The ''Congregatio Regni tocius Sclavonie Generalis'' with its decisions ''(statuta et constitutiones)'', is the oldest surviving document written by the Croatian parliament.

title: Haghpat
event: The Holy Redeemer khachkar, believed to be one of the finest examples of the art form, is carved in Haghpat, Armenia, by Vahram.

title: Beyoğlu
event: The Constantinople suburb of Beyoğlu (then known as Pera) is given to the Republic of Genoa by the Byzantine Emperor Michael VIII Palaeologus, in return for Genoa's support of the Empire after the Fourth Crusade and the sacking of Constantinople.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: January 31 – The 6-year-long battle of Xiangyang ends as the commander of the Song Dynasty's forces surrender to Kublai Khan's Yuan Dynasty.  The battle is the first in which firearms are used in combat.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: In Korea, the Sambyeolcho Rebellion against the Goryeo Dynasty (a puppet government of the Yuan Dynasty) ends as rebel forces are defeated by combined Yuan and Goryeo forces.

title: Italy
event: Bonvesin de la Riva writes the didactic-allegoric poemet ''Libro de le tre scritture'' (Negra, Rubra, Aurea), the first text in ancient Western Lombard language (still similar to other Gallo-Italian languages), and one of the first great literary works in Italy. It tells about Hell, Christ's Passion and Paradise; this plot suggests Dante in his ''Comedia''.

title: Korea
event: November 20 – Kublai Khan's Yuan Dynasty attempts the first of several invasions of Japan (30,000 soldiers and support personnel sails from Korea); after the Mongols capture outlying islands, they are repulsed on the main island at the Battle of Bun'ei by amassed Japanese warriors and a strong storm which batters their forces and fleet.  Credit for the storm — called a ''kamikaze'', or divine wind — is given by the Japanese to the god Raiden.

title: Minobu Yamanashi
event: Nichiren, founder of Nichiren Buddhism, enters a voluntary exile on Mount Minobu.

title: Isle of Man
event: October 8 – Battle of Ronaldsway: Scottish forces defeat the Manx of the Isle of Man in a decisive battle, firmly establishing Scottish rule of the island.* Eleanor de Montfort is captured by pirates in the employ of Edward I of England to prevent her marriage to Llywelyn the Last, prince of Wales; she is used as a bargaining chip over the coming years in Edward's attempts to subjugate Llywelyn and Wales.

title: Wallonia
event: Around Ciney, in the future Wallonia, begins the fratricid war of the cow which will last until 1278.

title: France
event: Jean de Meun completes the French allegorical work of fiction, ''Roman de la Rose'', with a second section; the first section was written by Guillaume de Lorris in 1230.

title: Majorca
event: Ramon Llull establishes a school in Majorca to teach Arabic to preachers in an attempt to aid proselytizing to Moors.  He also discovers diethyl ether.

title: China
event: March 4 – Chinese astronomers observe a total eclipse of the Sun in China.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: The invading forces of the Yuan Dynasty capture the Song Dynasty city of Suzhou.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: Marco Polo purportedly visits Xanadu, Kublai Khan's summer capital of the Yuan Dynasty.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: The city of Kunming is made capital of the Yunnan province of the Mongol Yuan Dynasty.

title: China
event: Nestorian monk Rabban Bar Sauma begins his pilgrimage from China towards Jerusalem.

title: Fujian
event: March – The 200,000 multiethnic troops of the Mongol-led Yuan Dynasty, headed by the Turkish commander Bayan, face a Chinese Song Dynasty army of 130,000 led by the Song Chancellor Jia Sidao. The result is a decisive victory for the Yuan Dynasty, and soon after the much-vilified Jia Sidao is stripped of rank and title, and killed by one of his own guards as he is sent to exile in Fujian by the Song court.

title: Fuzhou
event: June 14 – Remnants of the Song Chinese court in Fuzhou province conduct the coronation ceremony for the Prince Zhao Shi to become Emperor Duanzong of Song.

title: Vienna
event: The foundation stone of the Minoritenkirche in Vienna is laid by King Otakar II of Bohemia.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: February – The court of the Southern Song Dynasty of China and hundreds of thousands of its citizens flee from Hangzhou to Fujian and then Guangdong in an effort to escape an invasion by Kublai Khan's Yuan Dynasty.

title: China
event: Battle of Ngasaunggyan: Burma's Pagan Empire begins to disintegrate after being defeated by Kublai Khan at Yunnan near the Chinese border.

title: Sung Wong Toi
event: Some 50,000 leaders and citizens of the Southern Song Dynasty of China become the first recorded inhabitants of Macau, as they seek refuge from the invading armies of the Yuan Dynasty. They also stay for a short period in Kowloon. Some hundred years later the place where they stayed becomes Sung Wong Toi.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: In Japan, a 20 kilometer stone wall defending the coast of Hakata Bay in Fukuoka is completed; it is built in response to the attempted invasion by the Yuan Dynasty in 1274.

title: China
event: May 8 – Emperor Duanzong of Song China dies of illness and is succeeded by his brother Zhao Bing, who becomes Emperor Huaizong of Song. Meanwhile, armed forces under the control of Mongol leader Kublai Khan draw closer to the remnants of the Song imperial court. A year later at the Battle of Yamen the Song Dynasty will cease to exist, becoming incorporated into the Yuan Dynasty of China.

title: France
event: The independence, boundaries, and political structure of Andorra are agreed to by the Spanish Bishop of Urgell and the French Count of Foix.

title: Wallonia
event: End of the so-called War of the Cow in what will become Wallonia (it had begun in 1275).

title: Iran
event: The earliest known written copy of the ''Avesta'', a collection of ancient sacred Persian Zoroastrian texts previously passed down orally, is produced.

title: Tower of London
event: The Royal Mint of England moves into the Tower of London.

title: Estonia
event: The town of Haapsalu, Estonia is founded.

title: China
event: March 19 – Battle of Yamen:  Kublai Khan's Yuan Dynasty defeats and ends the Song Dynasty, and becomes the emperor of all China.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: A Yuan diplomatic party sent by Kublai Khan to Japan is killed by Japan's regent Hōjō Tokimune, leading to a second invasion attempt by the Mongols in 1281.

title: France
event: Pope Martin IV authorizes a Crusade against the newly re-established Byzantine Empire in Constantinople; French and Venetian expeditions set out toward Constantinople but are forced to turn back in the following year.

title: Anatolia
event: Osman I, founder of the Ottoman Empire, becomes ''bey'' of the Sögüt tribe in central Anatolia; in 1299 he will declare independence from the Seljuk Turks, marking the birth of the Ottoman Empire.

title: Korea
event: August 12 – Battle of Kōan (Hakata Bay): The second Mongol invasion of Japan is foiled, as a large typhoon — famously called a ''kamikaze'', or divine wind — destroys much of the combined Chinese and Korean fleet and forces, numbering over 140,000 men and 4,000 ships.

title: Constantinople
event: March 30 – The Sicilian rebellion known as the Sicilian Vespers begins against the rule of Angevin King Charles I of Sicily; over the next 6 weeks, thousands of French are killed.  The rebellion forces Charles to abandon the Ninth Crusade while still en route to the target city of Constantinople, and allows King Peter III of Aragon to take over rule of the island from Charles (which in turn leads to Peter's excommunication by Pope Martin IV).

title: Forlì
event: May 15 – Battle of Forlì between Guelphs and Ghibellines: the French army under Pope Martin IV is defeated by Guido I da Montefeltro.

title: Battle of Orewin Bridge
event: December 11 – At the Battle of Orewin Bridge in mid-Wales, Llywelyn the Last is killed and the Welsh suffer their final decisive defeat at the hands of the English.

title: Italy
event: The technology of watermarks is introduced by paper manufacturers of Bologna, Italy.

title: University of Oxford
event: Hertford College is founded at the University of Oxford.

title: London
event: The Archbishop of Canterbury orders all synagogues of London to close, and forbids Jewish doctors from practicing on non-Jews.

title: Larderello
event: The most recent eruption of Larderello, a volcano in southern Tuscany, is observed.

title: Malta
event: July 8 – At the naval Battle of Malta at Valletta, an Angevin fleet sent to help put down a rebellion on Malta is defeated by the fleet of Roger of Lauria.

title: France
event: King Philip III of France causes a mass migration of Jews when he outlaws their residence in the small villages and rural localities of France.

title: Portugal
event: The E. codex of the ''Cantigas de Santa Maria'', a collection of Portuguese musical manuscripts, is dated to between 1280 and 1283.

title: Gniezno
event: Jakub Swinka becomes archbishop of Gniezno.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: Kublai Khan's Yuan Dynasty invades the Khmer Empire of present-day Cambodia; King Jayavarman VIII decides to pay tribute rather than fight the invasion, buying peace and preserving the empire.

title: China
event: The city of Guiyang is founded in China.

title: Vardzia
event: An earthquake destroys two thirds of the cave city of Vardzia, Georgia.

title: Italy
event: Battle of Meloria: The Italian city-state of Genoa defeats its rival Pisa, ending Pisa's marine power and hastening the city's decline in power.

title: Syrmia
event: King Stefan Dragutin of Serbia receives Belgrade, Syrmia, and other territories from Hungary, when his son marries the king of Hungary's cousin.

title: Peterhouse Cambridge
event: Peterhouse, the oldest college at the University of Cambridge, is founded by Hugo de Balsham.

title: France
event: Construction on the Cathédrale Saint-Pierre de Beauvais is interrupted by a partial collapse of the choir; the event unnerves French masons working in the Gothic style.

title: Margat
event: April 25 – Mamluk sultan Qalawun begins a siege of the Crusader fortress of Margat (in present-day Syria), a major stronghold of the Knights Hospitaller thought to be impregnable; he captures the fortress a month later.

title: China
event: In the Lao kingdom of Muang Sua, King Panya Leng is overthrown in a coup d'etat led by his son Panya Khamphong, which is likely to have been supported by the regionally dominant Mongol Yuan dynasty of China.

title: Sambia
event: Prussians resettled in Sambia stage a famous uprising.

title: Minorca
event: January 17 – The Treaty of San Agayz is signed. King Alfonso III of Aragon conquers the island of Minorca from the Moors.

title: Hastings
event: December 14 – A huge storm and associated storm tide in the North Sea and English Channel, known as St. Lucia's flood in the Netherlands, kills thousands and reshapes the coastal life of the Netherlands and England forever. In the Netherlands, a fringing barrier between the North Sea and a shallow lake in Holland collapses, causing the fifth largest flood in recorded history which creates the Zuider Zee inlet and kills over 50,000 people; it also gives sea access to Amsterdam, allowing its development as an important port city. In England, the city of Winchelsea on Romney Marsh is destroyed; nearby Broomhill also destroyed; course of the nearby river Rother diverted to  Rye; cliff collapses at Hastings, blocking the harbour; parts of Norfolk are flooded; the port of Dunwich in Suffolk begins its decline.

title: Italy
event: The Altar of St. James at the Cathedral of San Zeno in Pistoia, Italy — a masterwork of the silversmithing trade containing nearly a ton of silver — is begun; it will not be completed for nearly 200 years.

title: Uppsala Cathedral
event: Construction on the Cathedral of Uppsala is begun; it will not be completed until 1435.

title: Kraków
event: The Mongol Golden Horde, led by khan Talabuga and Nogai Khan, attacks Poland for the third time. Lublin, Mazovia, Sandomierz and Sieradz are ravaged by the invaders, who are defeated in Kraków.

title: Latakia
event: Mamluk sultan Qalawun captures the port city of Latakia in present-day Syria.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: Battle of Pagan: The Theravada Buddhist kingdom at Pagan, Myanmar falls to the invading armies of the Yuan Dynasty.

title: Newcastle Emlyn Castle
event: January 20 – Newcastle Emlyn Castle in Wales is recaptured by English forces, bringing Rhys ap Maredudd's revolt to an end.

title: Battle of Worringen
event: June 5 – Battle of Worringen: John I of Brabant defeats the duchy of Guelders in one of the largest battles in Europe of the Middle Ages, thus winning possession of the duchy of Limburg.  The battle also liberates the city of Cologne from rule by the Archbishopric of Cologne; it had previously been one of the major ecclesiastical principalities of the Holy Roman Empire.

title: Parliament of Scotland
event: The Scots Parliament creates a law allowing women to propose marriage to men during leap years; men who refuse such proposals are required to pay a fine to the spurned bride-to-be.

title: St. Peter's Basilica
event: The oldest surviving bell in the clocks atop the dome of St. Peter's Basilica in Rome is built.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: Vietnamese general Tran Hung Dao sinks the entire fleet of an invading army of the Yuan Dynasty, by placing steel-tipped bamboo stakes in the Bach Dang River, near Halong Bay.

title: Acheng District
event: The oldest known bronze handgun in the world is dated to this year, a Chinese gun found in Acheng District that was once used to suppress the rebellion of the Christian Mongol Prince Nayan in 1287–1288.

title: France
event: Pope Nicholas IV formally constitutes the University of Montpellier in France by papal bull, combining various existing schools under the mantle of a single university.

title: France
event: Jews are expelled from Gascony and Anjou in France.

title: China
event: Franciscan friars begin missionary work in China.

title: Battle of Campaldino
event: June 11 – The Italian Guelph and Ghibelline factions fight in the Battle of Campaldino; the Guelph victory secures their position of power in Florence.

title: Llandaff Cathedral
event: Construction of Llandaff Cathedral is completed in Cardiff, Wales, 170 years after it was begun.

title: Bessarabia
event: The Mongol Golden Horde invades the Bessarabia region of Moldavia.

title: Portugal
event: King Denis of Portugal decrees that Portuguese be the official language of Portugal, replacing classical Latin in that capacity.

title: Akershus Fortress
event: Construction on the Akershus Fortress of Oslo, Norway is begun.

title: Portugal
event: March 1 – The University of Coimbra is founded in Lisbon, Portugal by King Denis of Portugal; it moves to Coimbra in 1308.

title: Wallachia
event: August 1 – The country of Wallachia is founded (traditional date).

title: China
event: September 27 –  An earthquake in the Gulf of Chili, province of Hebei, China, kills an estimated 100,000.

title: London
event: December – The twelve Eleanor crosses are erected between Lincolnshire and London in England as King Edward I mourns the death of his queen consort Eleanor of Castile.

title: India
event: Spring: Vandino and Ugolino Vivaldi set sail from Genoa with the goal of reaching India; they never return.

title: Switzerland
event: The Habsburgs acquire the Swiss city of Lucerne.

title: San Marino
event: Pope Nicholas IV confirms the independence of San Marino via papal bull.

title: Murano
event: All glassmakers in Venice are forced to move to the island of Murano in order to contain the risk of fire, thus establishing the glass industry there.

title: China
event: The artificial Kunming Lake is constructed as a reservoir for Beijing in Yuan Dynasty China by famous engineer and astronomer Guo Shoujing.

title: Unterwalden
event: August – According to tradition, the Swiss Confederation is formed by Uri, Schwyz, and Unterwalden, the three forest cantons when they enact the Federal Charter of 1291.

title: Daulatabad
event: The Vaghela dynasty in Gujarat is subjugated by the Deccan Yadava dynasty of Daulatabad.

title: Kastamonu Province
event: The Turkish emirate of Candaroglu is founded in the Kastamonu Province.

title: Java
event: The Mongols land on Java, taking the capital, but it proves impossible to hold.

title: Isle of Wight
event: The Isle of Wight was sold to King Edward I by Countess Isabella De Fortibus for six thousand marks.

title: Complutense University of Madrid
event: May 20 – King Sancho IV of Castile creates the ''Studium General'', forerunner to the modern Complutense University of Madrid.

title: China
event: The death of Kublai Khan allows the 4 khanates of the Mongol Empire (the Chagatai Khanate, the Golden Horde, the Ilkhanate, and the Yuan Dynasty of China) to formally become independent; they each had already been moving toward independence during Kublai's reign.

title: Strata Florida Abbey
event: The Strata Florida Abbey is rebuilt; it had been destroyed some years earlier in King Edward I of England's conquest of Wales.

title: China
event: Marco Polo returns to Italy from his travels to China.

title: Beaumaris Castle
event: Work begins on construction of Beaumaris Castle on Anglesey, last of the ring of castles built by Edward I of England to subdue Wales.

title: Kingdom of England
event: 23 October – The first treaty forming the Auld Alliance between Scotland and France against England is signed in Paris.

title: Angkor
event: The Chinese diplomat Zhou Daguan spends a year at the court of the Khmer King Indravarman III at Angkor and pens a journal setting forth his observations.

title: Battle of Dunbar (1296)
event: April 27 –  Battle of Dunbar: The Scots are defeated by Edward I of England.

title: Monaco
event: January 8 – Monaco gains independence.

title: Flanders
event: August 28 – Edward I of England unsuccessfully invades Flanders.

title: Battle of Stirling Bridge
event: September 11 – Battle of Stirling Bridge: The Scottish armies of Andrew Moray and William Wallace defeat the English.

title: Portugal
event: September 12 – King Denis of Portugal and King Ferdinand IV of Castile sign the Treaty of Alcanizes. The geographic limits of Portugal are fixed permanently, with the exception of São Félix de Galegos, lost in 1640 and Olivenza, lost in 1801.

title: Battle of Falkirk (1298)
event: July 22 – Battle of Falkirk: King Edward I of England defeats a Scottish army led by William Wallace.

title: Marco Polo
event: September 9 – Battle of Curzola: the Genoese fleet defeats the Venetians.  Marco Polo is one of the prisoners taken, and while in prison in Genoa, he begins dictating his ''Travels'' to a local writer.

title: Chapultepec
event: Year eight reed the Aztec settled in Chapultepec.

title: Stirling Castle
event: April – Scots take Stirling Castle from the English after a siege.

title: Holland
event: The House of Holland becomes extinct. The County of Holland becomes  part of a personal union with the County of Hainaut.

title: Delhi
event: A Mongol khan launches a campaign into India with 200,000 men, but the sultan of Delhi defeats them.

title: Kingston upon Hull
event: April 1 – Kings Towne on the River Hull(Kingston upon Hull) is granted city status by Royal Charter of King Edward I of England.

title: Italy
event: Money from Florence, Italy becomes the first international currency.

title: Flanders
event: Philip IV of France begins his attempt to annex Flanders.

title: China
event: A census in Imperial China finds that it has roughly 60 million inhabitants (having lost 20 million after nearly a century of Mongolian conquests).

title: Agadez
event: The Tuareg establish a state centered on Agadez.

title: Kent
event: March 10 – Wardrobe accounts of King Edward I of England (aka Edward Longshanks) include a reference to a game called ''creag'' being played at the town of Newenden in Kent. It is generally agreed that ''creag'' was an early form of cricket (see also History of cricket to 1696).

title: Crown of Castile
event: Castile occupies the harbor of Algiers.

title: Beijing
event: Confucian Temple erected in Beijing.

title: Estonia
event: June 12 – Rakvere, Estonia, receives Lübeck city rights.

title: France
event: July 11 – Battle of the Golden Spurs (''Guldensporenslag'' in Dutch): Flanders gains a major victory over the French.

title: Battle of Roslin
event: 24 February – Battle of Roslin: The Scots defeat the English.

title: 1303 Crete earthquake
event: 8 August – An earthquake destroys the Lighthouse of Alexandria in Egypt, one of the seven wonders of the world.

title: India
event: The Khilji Dynasty under Alauddin Khilji conquers Chittorgarh in northern India, after taking the massive Chittorgarh Fort.

title: Zeeland
event: Holland and Zeeland are occupied by John II, Duke of Brabant and Guy of Dampierre. John II, Count of Hainaut recovers the counties.

title: London
event: In London, a city ordinance decrees that heating with coal is forbidden when parliament is in session (the ordinance is not particularly effective).

title: India
event: The Mongols raid India.

title: Battle of Methven
event: June 19 – Battle of Methven: The forces of the Earl of Pembroke defeat Bruce's Scottish rebels.

title: Rhodes
event: July – The Knights Hospitaller begin their conquest of Rhodes.

title: India
event: The Mongol raid of India ends.

title: Ireland
event: The use of The Scottish Maiden is first documented in Ireland.

title: Rhodes
event: September 5 – Pope Clement V confirms the Knights Hospitaller possession of Rhodes, although only Feracle had fallen to their attacks.

title: France
event: October 13 – ''Friday the 13th'': All Knights Templar in France are simultaneously arrested by agents of Phillip the Fair, to be later tortured into confessing  heresy.

title: Portugal
event: March 8 – Póvoa de Varzim (then Varazim), Portugal gains a foral from Denis of Portugal.

title: Avignon
event: March 9 –  Pope Clement V settles the papal seat in Avignon, following a visit.

title: Rhodes
event: August 15 – The city of Rhodes surrenders to the forces of the Knights of St. John, completing their conquest of Rhodes. The knights establish their headquarters on the island, and rename themselves as the Knights of Rhodes.

title: Hama
event: Abu al-Fida becomes governor of Hama.

title: Wallachia
event: Basarab I, after the battle against the Tatars, is named big prince of Wallachia by the feudal lords of the region. The country remains under Hungarian domination until the Battle of Posada on 12 October, 1330.

title: France
event: May 11 – In France, 54 members of the Knights Templar are burned at the stake for heresy.

title: Bolingbroke Castle
event: Bolingbroke Castle passes to the House of Lancaster.

title: Battle of Halmyros
event: March 15 – Battle of Halmyros: The Catalan Company defeats Walter V of Brienne to take control of the Duchy of Athens.

title: Lateran Palace
event: 29 June – Henry VII, Holy Roman Emperor is crowned in the Lateran Palace due to St Peter's Basilica being occupied by Romans hostile to him.

title: Canary Islands
event: Lancelotto Malocello, a Genoese navigator, sails to the island of Lanzarote, one of the Canary Islands, and remains there for almost two decades.

title: Banjska monastery
event: Stefan Uroš II Milutin of Serbia founds the Banjska monastery.

title: Battle of Bannockburn
event: June 24 – Battle of Bannockburn: Scottish forces led by Robert the Bruce defeat Edward II of England, regaining Scotland's independence.

title: Akershus
event: August 31 – King Håkon V Magnusson moves the capital of Norway from Bergen to Oslo, where he builds Akershus Fortress. Norway is ruled from this fortress the next 500 years.

title: Flushing Netherlands
event: Flushing is granted city rights.

title: Rügen
event: Witzlaw III, prince of Rügen, builds a castle at Barth.

title: Greece
event: The Kos Fortress is erected in Greece.

title: Dongola
event: A Muslim prince of Nubian royal blood ascends the throne of Dongola as king (History of Sudan (Coming of Islam to the Turkiyah)).

title: China
event: Estimation: Cairo, capital of Mamluk Egypt becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Hangzhou in Mongolian China.

title: France
event: August – Louis X is crowned King of France at Reims.

title: Au peninsula
event: Au peninsula in Switzerland is first mentioned as Owe belonging to the commandry of the Knights Hospitaller in Bubikon.

title: Ireland
event: August 10 – Second Battle of Athenry ends with over 5,000 dead, and Norman rule retained in Ireland.

title: Cairo
event: Qala'un Mosque, Cairo, Egypt is founded by Al-Nasr Muhammad.

title: Ireland
event: May 11 – Battle of Dysert O'Dea: The Irish armies of Conor O'Dea defeat the Normans under Richard de Clare.

title: Venetian Arsenal
event: The Venetian Arsenal is rebuilt as the Arsenal Nuovo.

title: Battle of Boroughbridge
event: March 16 – Battle of Boroughbridge: Edward II of England defeats several rebellious barons.

title: Vilnius
event: Lithuania: In the  ''Letters of Gediminas'', Vilnius is named as the capital city.

title: Cairo
event: Emperor Kankan Musa I of the Mali Empire arrives in Cairo on his hajj to Mecca, accompanied by an entourage numbering in the thousands and hundreds of pounds of gold.  This fantastic display of wealth garners Mali a place on European maps in 1395.

title: Ibn Battuta
event: Ibn Battuta begins his travels.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: March 18 – Recognized date for the founding of Tenochtitlan on a small island in Lake Texcoco by the Mexica empire at the dawn of the day. The Aztec capital becomes Mexico City in 1521.

title: Finnmark
event: 3 June – The Treaty of Novgorod delineates the border between Russia and Norway in Finnmark.

title: Clare College Cambridge
event: Formation of the University of Cambridge's second oldest (still surviving) college, Clare College, Cambridge.

title: Ibn Battuta
event: October – Ibn Battuta reaches Mecca.

title: Avignon
event: May 26 – William of Ockham secretly leaves Avignon under threat from Pope John XXII.

title: France
event: August 23 – Battle of Cassel: French troops stop an uprising of Flemish farmers.

title: Frombork
event: Construction begins on the cathedral of Frombork, Poland.

title: Aquitaine
event: Edward III of England pays homage to Philip VI of France for Aquitaine.

title: Vilnius
event: Vilnius, Lithuania receives its coat-of-arms, granted to the city in the seventh year of its existence.

title: Ibn Battuta
event: Ibn Battuta visits Kilwa.

title: Târgu Mureş
event: The city of Târgu Mureş (Romania) is first documented in the papal registry under the name Novum Forum Siculorum.

title: Battle of Dupplin Moor
event: August 10–11 – Battle of Dupplin Moor: The Balliol rebels and the English defeat the loyalists of David II in Scotland.

title: Unterwalden
event: November 7 – Lucerne joins the Swiss Confederation with Uri, Schwyz, and Unterwalden.

title: Battle of Annan
event: December 16 – Battle of Annan: The loyalists of David II defeat Edward Balliol in Scotland.

title: China
event: 1333–1337 – A famine in China kills six million.

title: Ireland
event: June 6 – William Donn de Burgh, 3rd Earl of Ulster is murdered and the Burke Civil War begins in Ireland.

title: Battle of Halidon Hill
event: July 19 – Battle of Halidon Hill: Edward III defeats Sir Archibald Douglas, during the last of the Wars of Scottish Independence.

title: Hubei
event: The first recorded outbreak of the Black Death occurs in the Chinese province of Hubei.

title: China
event: 1333–1337 – A famine in China kills six million.

title: Florence Cathedral
event: July 18 – The bishop of Florence blesses the first foundational stone laid for the new ''campanile'' (bell tower) of the Florence Cathedral. The tower was designed by the artist Giotto di Bondone.

title: Battle of Culblean
event: 30 November – Battle of Culblean: David Bruce defeats Edward Balliol in Scotland.

title: Joseon Dynasty
event: 11 October – Yi Seong-gye, founder of the Joseon Dynasty, is born in Korea.

title: China
event: 1333–1337 – A famine in China kills six million.

title: Avignon
event: Construction begins on the papal palace in Avignon.

title: India
event: Vijayanagara is founded on the southern part of the Deccan plateau in India, by the brothers Harihara and Bukka Raya.

title: China
event: 1333–1337 – A famine in China kills six million.

title: France
event: The Hundred Years' War (c. 1337–1453) begins between France and England.

title: Aquitaine
event: Philip VI of France confiscates Aquitaine.

title: Bisham Abbey
event: Bisham Priory is founded in England.

title: China
event: 1333–1337 – A famine in China kills six million.

title: Portsmouth
event: Philip VI of France besieges Guienne in Southwest France and his navy attacks Portsmouth in England.

title: Nicomedia
event: Nicomedia is captured by the Ottoman Empire.

title: France
event: January 26 – King Edward III of England is declared King of France.

title: France
event: June 24 – The Battle of Sluys is fought between the naval fleets of the Kingdom of England and the Kingdom of France. The former is under the command of Edward III of England and the latter under that of admiral Hugues Quiéret and treasurer Nicholas Béhuchet assisted by Genoese mercenary galleys under Egidio Bocanegra. The French fleet is virtually destroyed and both commanders are among the casualties.

title: University of Oxford
event: The Queen's College, a constituent college of the University of Oxford, is founded.

title: Tbilisi
event: Tbilisi becomes a capital of European Christian Cathedra after city Smirna. George V (the brilliant) returns Jerusalem and Grave of Christ from Muslims.

title: Lublin
event: Casimir III of Poland build a masonry castle in Lublin and encircles the city with defensive walls.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: The sultan of Delhi chooses Ibn Battuta to lead a diplomatic mission to Yuan Dynasty China.

title: India
event: The great flood in the river Periyar in what is now Kerala India which lead to the river changing its course, closing of the Kodungalloor (Muziris) harbour, opening up of Cochin (Kochi) harbour submersion of some islands and birth of some new islands.

title: Damascus
event: The Patriarch of Antioch is transferred to Damascus under Ignatius II.

title: Vijayanagara Empire
event: The Vijayanagara Empire is established in South India.

title: Estonia
event: April 23 – The St. George's Night Uprising occurs in Estonia (-1345).

title: Estonia
event: Vesse, the rebel King of Saaremaa Island in Estonia, is hanged.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: Tenochtitlan, the capital of the Aztec civilization, is founded.

title: Coventry
event: Bablake School was founded in Coventry, England by Queen Isabella.

title: China
event: Famine in China.

title: Kingdom of Aragon
event: King Peter IV of Aragon defeats and deposes his second-cousin once removed, James III of Majorca, thereby absorbing the Balearic Kingdom of Majorca into the Crown of Aragon, under the House of Barcelona.

title: Zeeland
event: September – Holland, Hainaut and Zeeland are inherited by Louis IV, Holy Roman Emperor and remain part of the imperial crown domain until 1347.

title: Holland
event: September 26 – Battle of Warns: The Frisians defeat the forces of Holland under William IV, Count of Hainaut, in the midst of the Friso-Hollandic Wars.

title: Gascony
event: 21 October – English victory at the Battle of Auberoche in Gascony.

title: Gascony
event: December – English take Aiguillon in Gascony.

title: France
event: July – Edward III orders closing of English ports to stop information reaching France.

title: University of Valladolid
event: The University of Valladolid is founded.

title: Hagia Sophia
event: Repairs are made in the Hagia Sophia.

title: English Channel
event: March 18 – French prepare to defend Channel coasts.

title: Portsmouth
event: May-June – An English invasion fleet assembles at Portsmouth.

title: Brittany
event: June 9 – Battle of St Pol de Leon: English army defeats Charles of Blois in Brittany.

title: Portsmouth
event: July 3 – English fleet attempts to sail from Portsmouth to Normandy but is forced back by contrary winds.

title: France
event: July 11 – July 12 – Edward III and the English army cross the English Channel and begin an invasion of France.

title: Battle of Crécy
event: August 26 – Battle of Crécy, in which the English defeat the French

title: Battle of Neville's Cross
event: October 17 – Battle of Neville's Cross: English army defeats the Scots.

title: Constantinople
event: 2 February – The Byzantine civil war between John VI Kantakouzenos and the regency for John V Palaiologos ends with Kantakouzenos entering Constantinople.

title: Majorca
event: December – Plague hits the island of Majorca

title: Bristol Channel
event: June – Two ships enter the Bristol Channel bringing the bubonic plague to England.

title: Cairo
event: The Black Death breaks out in Cairo.

title: Cairo
event: Estimation: Hangzhou in Mongolian China becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Cairo, capital of Mamluk Egypt.

title: France
event: A truce is observed between England and France until 1532.

title: Gonville and Caius College Cambridge
event: Gonville Hall, the forerunner of Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge is founded.

title: Charles University in Prague
event: April 7 – Charles University is founded in Prague.

title: Weymouth Dorset
event: June 24 – The Black Death outbreak goes into full swing in Melcombe Regis (modern-day Weymouth, Dorset in England).

title: Ibn Battuta
event: Ibn Battuta arrives in Fez in Morocco.

title: Colosseum
event: An earthquake in Rome causes extensive damage, including the collapse of the southern exterior facade of the Colosseum.

title: Switzerland
event: January 9 – The Jewish population of Basel, Switzerland is rounded up and incinerated, believed by the residents to be the cause of the ongoing Black Death.

title: Ireland
event: May – The Black Death ceases in Ireland.

title: Elbląg
event: August 24 – The Black Death breaks out in Elbing (Poland).

title: Holland
event: 5 September – conservative noblemen in Holland found the Hook league

title: Finland
event: Vantaa, Finland is first mentioned.

title: China
event: The Mongolian-run Yuan Dynasty of China is permanently weakened by an uprising known as the Red Turban Rebellion.

title: Samma Dynasty
event: The Samma Dynasty in Sindh (now part of Pakistan) breaks away from the Delhi Sultanate.

title: Dardanelles
event: The Turks cross the Dardanelles into Europe for the first time.

title: Switzerland
event: May 1 – Zürich joins the Swiss Confederation.

title: Ibn Battuta
event: Moroccan traveller Ibn Battuta reports the existence of the ngoni and balafon instruments at the court of Mansa Musa.

title: Corpus Christi College Cambridge
event: Corpus Christi College is founded as a College of the University of Cambridge, by the Guilds of Corpus Christi and the Blessed Virgin Mary.

title: Bern
event: The town of Biel/Bienne, Switzerland finalizes its alliance with the city of Bern.

title: Halych
event: The Metropolitan of the Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church, the Metropolitan of Halych, begins to relocate back to Kiev, after having moved to Halych in 1299.  Thereafter, the Metropolitan will hold the title of Metropolitan of Kiev-Halych and All Rus.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: After years of begging and being a Buddhist monk, the penniless Chinese peasant Zhu Yuanzhang joins the Red Turban Rebellion against the Mongol-led Yuan Dynasty of China; he will later become the first emperor of the Ming Dynasty.

title: Switzerland
event: June 4 – Glarus joins the Swiss Confederation.

title: Switzerland
event: June 27 – Zug joins the Swiss Confederation.

title: Switzerland
event: March 3 – Bern signs an alliance with the Swiss Confederation.

title: Kashmir
event: Sahab-ud-Din becomes Sultan of Kashmir.

title: Gallipoli
event: The Turks capture the cities of Kallipolis and Didymoteicho from the Byzantine Empire.

title: Ibn Battuta
event: The sultan of Morocco appoints a scribe to write an account of the travels of Ibn Battuta.

title: Pomerania
event: February 12 –  The Treaty of Stralsund settles border disputes between the duchies of Mecklenburg and Pomerania.

title: Northumberland
event: A small Scottish and French force invades Northumberland, loots the city of Berwick-upon-Tweed and defeats a small English force in a skirmish at Nisbet, Berwickshire.

title: Portugal
event: January 7 – Portuguese king Afonso IV sends three men to kill Ines de Castro, beloved of his son prince Pedro – Pedro revolts and incites a civil war.

title: Oxford
event: February 10 – The St. Scholastica's Day riot broke out in Oxford, England, leaving 63 scholars and perhaps 30 locals dead in two days.

title: Anjou
event: April – Philip of Anjou marries Mary of Naples, daughter of Charles of Valois, duke of Calabria, and Mary of Valois.

title: Cairo
event: The majority of the Great Pyramid of Giza's limestone casing stones are removed by Bahri Sultan An-Nasir Nasir-ad-Din al-Hasan to build fortresses and mosques in the nearby city of Cairo, leaving the first of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World in the step-stone condition in which it remains today.

title: Lothian
event: Burnt Candlemas: Edward III of England burns down every town and village in Lothian, Scotland.

title: China
event: Zhu Yuanzhang, one of the leaders in the Red Turban Rebellion, captures the city of Nanjing from the Mongol-led Yuan Dynasty in China; from then on it becomes his base of power and the capital of a new dynasty he will establish in 1368, the Ming Dynasty.

title: Switzerland
event: October 18 – The Basel earthquake destroys the city of Basel in Switzerland.

title: Bengal
event: Sikandar I becomes Sultan of Bengal.

title: India
event: Rao Kanhadev becomes Rathore ruler of Marwar (now part of India).

title: Shroud of Turin
event: The first public exhibition of the Shroud of Turin is recorded.

title: France
event: In France, the States-General passes Étienne Marcel's Great Ordinance in an attempt to impose limits on the monarchy, in particular in fiscal and monetary matters.

title: Portugal
event: May 28 – Peter I becomes King of Portugal after the death of his father, Alfonso IV.

title: Charles Bridge
event: July 9 – Charles Bridge in Prague is founded.

title: China
event: Estimation: Nanjing in Mongolian China becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Hangzhou in Mongolian China. [http://geography.about.com/library/weekly/aa011201a.htm]

title: India
event: Mohammed Shah I becomes Bahmani Sultan of Deccan (now part of southern India) after the death of Sultan Aladdin Hassan Bahman Shah.

title: France
event: May 28 – The Jacquerie: A peasant rebellion begins in France during the Hundred Year's War, which consumes the Beauvais and allies with Etienne Marcel's seizure of Paris.

title: Republic of Ragusa
event: June 27 – The Republic of Ragusa is founded.

title: France
event: The Second Treaty of London is signed between England and France.

title: Kingdom of Hungary
event: Bogdan I becomes Prince of Moldavia (now Moldova) after freeing it from Hungarian control.

title: Grenada
event: Ismail II overthrows his uncle, Muhammed V, as King of Grenada (in present-day Spain).

title: Denmark
event: King Valdemar Atterdag of Denmark reconquers Scania, which has been in Swedish possession since 1332.

title: Grenada
event: Muhammed VI overthrows his brother-in-law, Ismail II, as King of Grenada (in present-day Spain); he is in turn overthrown this same year by the former king, Muhammed V.

title: Gascony
event: October 24 – The Treaty of Brétigny is ratified at Calais, marking the end of the first phase of the Hundred Years' War. Under its terms, Edward III gives up his claim to the French throne and releases King John II of France in return for French land, including Calais & Gascony.

title: Italy
event: The University of Pavia is founded in Italy.

title: China
event: Chinese rebels capture the Koryo capital.

title: English College Rome
event: The English Hospice of the Most Holy Trinity and St Thomas was founded in Rome. It went on to become the English College, a centre for training English priests in Rome.

title: Constantinople
event: The Ottomans capture Philippopolis and Adrianopole (now the city of Edirne) from the Byzantine Empire, reducing it to the city of Constantinople.

title: Kashmir
event: Shahabuddin succeeds his brother, Alauddin Ali Sher, as Sultan of Kashmir.

title: Algirdas
event: Grand Duke of Lithuania Algirdas defeats the Tatars at the Battle of Blue Waters and takes over Kiev.

title: Kensington Runestone
event: Purported date of the inscription of the Kensington Runestone.

title: Öræfajökull
event: Eruption of the Öræfajökull volcano in Iceland, resulting in the destruction of the district of Litlahérað by flood and tephra fall

title: Nordfriesland
event: January 16 – The Grote Mandrenke storm tide strikes Holland, England, Germany and Denmark, destroying the city of Rungholt in Nordfriesland, Germany.

title: Cairo
event: The Mosque-Madrassa of Sultan Hassan is completed in Cairo, Egypt.

title: Yemen
event: Al-Afdal al-Abbas succeeds Al-Mujahid Ali as Rasulid Sultan of Yemen.

title: Greece
event: The Byzantine Empire wins a naval battle over the Ottoman Empire near Megara, Greece.

title: Crete
event: An uprising occurs against the Venetian rulers in Crete.

title: China
event: August 30 to October 4 – the Battle of Lake Poyang is fought between the Dahan rebel forces of Chen Youliang and the Red Turban Rebel forces of Zhu Yuanzhang on Lake Poyang, during the final decade of Yuan Dynasty control over China. Zhu's naval forces of 200,000 are pitted against Chen's naval forces of 650,000 troops in what is not only the largest naval battle of the medieval age, but also one of the largest naval battles in history.

title: India
event: Rana Kshetra Singh succeeds Rana Hamir Singh as ruler of Mewar (now part of western India).

title: India
event: Anavema Reddy succeeds Anavota Reddy as ruler of the Reddy Dynasty in Andhra Pradesh (now part of southern India).

title: Burma
event: The Ava Dynasty establish rule in present-day northern Burma.

title: France
event: April 8 – Charles V becomes King of France.

title: Kraków
event: May 12 – The Jagiellonian University is founded in Kraków.

title: Anjou
event: September 10 – Philip of Anjou becomes Titular Emperor of Constantinople and Prince of Taranto.

title: Alexandria
event: October – Alexandrian Crusade: The city of Alexandria in Egypt is sacked by an allied force of Peter I of Cyprus and the knights of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem.

title: University of Vienna
event: The University of Vienna is founded.

title: Edirne
event: Adrianopole (now Edirne) becomes the capital city of the Ottoman Empire.

title: Crete
event: A revolt against the Venetian rulers in Crete fails.

title: Java
event: Mpu Prapanca writes the epic poem ''Nagarakretagama'', about the Majapahit Empire in Java.

title: Vijayanagara Empire
event: In present-day southern India, Bahmani Sultan Mohammed Shah I invades the Vijayanagara Empire.

title: Muchalls Castle
event: Thomas Fraser obtains lands in Aberdeenshire, upon which he starts the building of a towerhouse that will later be known as Muchalls Castle.

title: Crown of Castile
event: Henry II deposes his half-brother, Pedro of Castile, to become King of Castile.

title: India
event: War continues between the Hindu Vijayanagar Empire and the Muslim Bahmani Sultanate in present-day southern India. Tens of thousands of civilians are massacred by each side.

title: Ireland
event: The Statutes of Kilkenny are passed in Ireland.

title: Nanjing
event: Zhu Yuanzhang, leader of the Red Turban Rebellion that will overthrow the Yuan Dynasty and establish the Ming Dynasty 2 years later, begins building the walls for a new capital city at Nanjing.

title: Portugal
event: January 18 – Ferdinand I becomes King of Portugal after the death of his father, Peter I.

title: France
event: April 3 – Battle of Nájera: Pedro of Castile is restored as King of Castile (now in Spain) after defeating his half-brother, Henry II. Pedro is aided in the battle by the English and Henry by the French.

title: Avignon
event: October 16 – Pope Urban V makes the first attempt to move the Papacy back to Rome from Avignon. This move is reversed in 1370 when he is forced to return to Avignon and shortly afterwards dies.

title: Samarkand
event: Timur ascends to the throne of Samarkand (now in Uzbekistan).

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: Hongwu (also known as Zhu Yuanzhang) establishes the Ming Dynasty in China after the disintegration of the Mongol Yuan Dynasty. He immediately orders every county magistrate to set up four granaries, and halts government taxation on books.

title: Eastern Settlement
event: The King of Norway sends the last Royal Ship from Norway to the Greenland Eastern Settlement. This event is part of both the Norse colonization of the Americas and of the History of Greenland.

title: Bibliothèque nationale de France
event: The Bibliothèque nationale de France (National Library of France) is established in Paris.

title: Aquitaine
event: May – King Charles V of France renounces the Treaty of Brétigny and war is declared between France and England. The French recapture most of Aquitaine.

title: Kingdom of Hungary
event: Venice repels a Hungarian invasion.

title: Bastille
event: Hugues Aubriot founds the Bastille in Paris.

title: Samarkand
event: Tamerlane names the city of Samarkand as the capital of his empire.

title: China
event: The Hongwu Emperor of the Chinese Ming Dynasty issues a decree ordering every country magistrate in the empire to open a Confucian school of learning.

title: France
event: March 14 – Pedro of Castile loses the Battle of Montiel to an alliance between the French and his half-brother Henry II.

title: London
event: Carthusian monks build the Charterhouse in London.

title: Denmark
event: May 24 – The Treaty of Stralsund ends the war between Denmark and the Hanseatic League.

title: Anjou
event: October 20 – Philip of Anjou, Titular Emperor of Constantinople, marries Elisabeth of Slavonia, daughter of Stephen, duke of Transylvania and Slavonia, and Margareta of Bavaria.

title: London
event: Charterhouse Carthusian Monastery is founded in Aldersgate, London.

title: Aquitaine
event: Edward, the Black Prince, gives up the administration of Aquitaine because of his poor health and heavy debts.

title: Constantinople
event: Byzantine co-emperor John V Palaiologos pledges loyalty to the Ottoman Empire to prevent the Turks from invading Constantinople.

title: China
event: The Hongwu Emperor of the Ming Dynasty in China introduces the census registration system of ''lijia'', or the hundreds-and-tithing system, throughout the Yangzi valley. This system groups households into units of ten and groups of one hundred, whereupon their capacities for paying taxes and providing the state with corvée labor service can be assessed. The system becomes fully operational in 1381, when it counts 59,873,305 people living in China (the historian Timothy Brook asserts that the number was much higher, somewhere between 65 million and 75 million).

title: House of Stuart
event: February 22 – Robert II becomes the first Stuart king of Scotland after the death of his uncle, David II.

title: Guernsey
event: May – Owain Lawgoch makes a second attempt to take the throne of Wales. Whilst attacking the island of Guernsey, Owain abandons the invasion in order to fight for France at La Rochelle.

title: China
event: The Kingdom of Chūzan (now in southern Japan) enters tributary relations with Ming Dynasty China.

title: English Channel
event: June 22 – Battle of La Rochelle: The French & the Castilians defeat the English. The French gain control of the English Channel for the first time since 1340.

title: Bristol
event: Bristol is made an independent county.

title: Phnom Penh
event: The city of Phnom Penh (now the capital city of Cambodia) is founded.

title: Greece
event: Philip II of Taranto & Achaea hand over the rule of Achaea (now southern Greece) to his cousin Joan I of Naples.

title: Crown of Castile
event: A city wall is built around Lisbon, Portugal to resist invasion by Castile.

title: Constantinople
event: Byzantine co-emperor Andronikos IV Palaiologos rebels against his father, John V Palaiologos, for agreeing to let Constantinople become a vassal of the Ottoman Empire. After the rebellion fails, Ottoman Emperor Murad I commands John V Palaiologos to blind his son.

title: Oxford
event: Merton College Library is built in Oxford, England.

title: Bengal
event: The Adina Mosque is built in Bengal.

title: Crown of Castile
event: March 24 – The Treaty of Santarém is signed between D. Fernando of Portugal and Henrique II of Castile, ending the second war between the two countries.

title: India
event: Rao Biram Dev succeeds Rao Kanhadev as ruler of Marwar (now the Jodhpur district of India).

title: Iran
event: Hasan succeeds his father, Shaikh Uvais, as ruler of the Jalayirid sultanate in present-day Iraq and western Iran. Hasan proves to be an unpopular ruler and is executed in the same year. Hasan's brother, Husain, succeeds him as ruler.

title: Mansa
event: Musa II succeeds his father, Mari Djata II, as Mansa of the Mali Empire (now Mali & Senegal).

title: Marrakech
event: Princes from the Kingdom of Grenada choose Abu al-Abbas Ahmad to succeed Muhammad as-Said as Sultan of the Marinid Empire in Morocco. The Empire is split into the Kingdom of Fez and the Kingdom of Marrakech.

title: France
event: The Château de Compiègne royal residence is built in France.

title: Greece
event: November 25 – James of Baux succeeds his uncle, Philip II, as Prince of Taranto (now eastern Italy) and titular ruler of the Latin Empire (now northern Greece and western Turkey).

title: Tokyo
event: Heirin-ji Temple is built near Tokyo.

title: France
event: Hundred Years' War: The English, weakened by the plague, lose so much ground to the French that they agree to sign the Treaty of Bruges, leaving them with only the coastal towns of Calais, Bordeaux and Bayonne.

title: India
event: Mujahid Shah succeeds his father, Mohammad Shah I, as Sultan of the Bahmanid Empire in Deccan, southern India.

title: China
event: In Nanjing, capital of the Ming Dynasty of China, a bureau secretary of the Ministry of Justice, Ru Taisu, sends a 17,000 character-long memorial to the throne, to be read aloud to the Hongwu Emperor. By the 16,370th character, the emperor has been offended by several passages, and has Ru Taisu summoned to court and flogged for the perceived insult. The next day, having had the remaining characters read to him, he likes four of Ru's recommendations, and instates these in reforms. Ru is nevertheless castigated for having forced the emperor to hear thousands of characters before getting to the part with true substance. The last 500 characters are elevated in court as the model-type memorial that all officials should aspire to create while writing their own.

title: Cairo
event: April 14 – The Mamluks from Egypt complete their conquest of the Armenian Kingdom of Cilicia. Levon V Lusignan of Armenia is imprisoned for several years in Cairo until a ransom is paid by King John I of Castile.

title: France
event: March – The peace treaty between England and France is extended until April of 1377.

title: Avignon
event: Catherine of Siena visits Pope Gregory XI in Avignon to attempt to persuade him to make peace with Florence and move the Papacy back to Rome.

title: Kashmir
event: Qutbuddin succeeds his brother, Shahabuddin, as Sultan of Kashmir.

title: Constantinople
event: August 12 – With the help of the Genoese, Byzantine co-emperor Andronicus IV Palaeologus invades Constantinople and dethrones his father, John V Palaeologus, as co-emperor. John V Palaeologus is taken prisoner.

title: Avignon
event: Continuous riots in Rome induce Pope Gregory XI to move temporarily back to Avignon.

title: Algirdas
event: Władysław II Jagiello succeeds his father, Algirdas, as Grand Duke of Lithuania. Jagiello removes his uncle, Kęstutis, as co-ruler.

title: China
event: August – the Hongwu Emperor of the Ming Dynasty of China scraps the Office of Reports Inspection established in 1370 for a new Office of Transmission, in his efforts to create a more efficient communicatory system in the empire. A month before this he noted that anyone could send petitions to the throne; commoners often did, although the only times their petitions were read aloud to the emperor was when they called for the impeachment of local officials that were not up to par with their official duties.

title: Trezzo sull'Adda Bridge
event: The Trezzo sull'Adda Bridge is completed, and becomes the longest arch bridge in the world to be built for four centuries

title: India
event: Harihara II succeeds Bukka as ruler of the Vijayanagara Empire (now in southern India).

title: Sumatra
event: A rebellion against the Majapahit Empire is quashed in Sumatra.

title: Avignon
event: January 17 – Pope Gregory XI moves the Papacy back from Avignon to Rome.

title: Avignon
event: The Papacy makes a permanent move back from Avignon to Rome, ending the Avignon Papacy.

title: Ireland
event: France, Aragon, Castile and León, Cyprus, Burgundy, Savoy, Naples and Scotland choose to recognise Antipope Clement VII. Denmark, England, Flanders, the Holy Roman Empire, Hungary, northern Italy, Ireland, Norway, Poland and Sweden continue to recognise Pope Urban VI.

title: Diyarbakır
event: Kara Osman establishes the Turkomans of the White Sheep dynasty at Diyarbakır in present-day southeast Turkey.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: Uskhal Khan succeeds his father, Biligtü Khan, as ruler of the Yuan Dynasty in Mongolia.

title: India
event: Da'ud Shah succeeds his assassinated nephew, Aladdin Mujahid Shah, as Bahmani Sultan in present-day southern India. Da'ud Shah is assassinated in the same year and is succeeded by Mohammed Shah II.

title: Great Sphinx of Giza
event: Sa'im al-Dahr is hanged for blowing the nose off the Sphinx.

title: Avignon
event: September 20 – Unhappy with Pope Urban's critical attitude towards them, the majority of the cardinals meet at Fondi and elect Clement VII as antipope and establish a rival papal court at Avignon. This split within the Catholic Church becomes known as the Western Schism.

title: Silivri
event: The Venetians and Ottomans invade Constantinople and restore John V Palaiologos as Byzantine co-emperor. Andronikos IV Palaiologos is allowed to remain as Byzantine co-emperor but is confined to the city of Silivri for the remainder of his life.

title: Estonia
event: Dmitri Donskoi of Moscow raids Estonia.

title: Kingdom of León
event: May 29 – John I succeeds his father, Henry II, as King of Castile and King of León.

title: Denmark
event: February – Olaf II of Denmark becomes Olaf IV of Norway, with his mother Margaret as regent.  Iceland and the Faroe Islands, as parts of Norway, pass under the Danish crown.

title: Jolo
event: Karim Al-Makhdum arrives in Jolo and builds a Mosque.

title: Arundel Castle
event: July 27 – Henry Bolingbroke marries Mary de Bohun at Arundel Castle.

title: Battle of Kulikovo
event: September 8 – Battle of Kulikovo: Russian forces under Grand Prince Dmitri Donskoi of Moscow resist a large invasion by the Blue Horde, Lithuania and Ryazan, stopping their advance at Kulikovo.

title: Guizhou
event: The Ming Dynasty of China annexes the areas of the old Kingdom of Dali, in what is now modern-day Yunnan and Guizhou provinces, inhabited by the Miao and Yao people. Hundreds of thousands of Chinese (including military colonists) will migrate there from the rest of China.

title: China
