event: In Ming Dynasty China, the ''lijia'' census registration system begun in 1371 is now universally imposed during the reign of the Hongwu Emperor. The census counts 59,873,305 people living in China in this year. This depicts a drastic drop in population since the Song Dynasty, which counted 100 million people at its height in the early 12th century. The historian Timothy Brook, in his ''The Confusions of Pleasure: Commerce and Culture in Ming China'', states that the Ming census was inaccurate, as China in the late 14th century had at least 65,000,000 inhabitants, if not 75,000,000.

title: Kent
event: June 12 – Peasants' Revolt: In England, rebels from Kent and Essex, led by Wat Tyler and Jack Straw, meet at Blackheath. There the rebels are encouraged by a sermon, by renegade priest John Ball.

title: Tower of London
event: June 14 – Peasants' Revolt: Rebels destroy John of Gaunt's Savoy Palace and storm the Tower of London, killing the Archbishop of Canterbury and the Lord Chancellor. King Richard II of England meets the leaders of the revolt and agrees to reforms such as fair rents and the abolition of serfdom.

title: Azerbaijan
event: Ibrahim I is selected to succeed Husheng as Shah of Shirvan (now Azerbaijan).

title: India
event: Rana Lakha succeeds Rana Kshetra Singh as ruler of Mewar (now part of western India).

title: Albania
event: Balša II of Zeta (now Montenegro) conquers Albania.

title: Italy
event: September 30 – The inhabitants of Trieste (now in northern Italy) donate their city to Duke Leopold III of Austria.

title: India
event: Rao Chanda succeeds Rao Biram Dev as Rathore ruler of Marwar (now in western India).

title: Wat Phrathat Doi Suthep
event: Wat Phrathat Doi Suthep Temple is built in present-day Thailand by King Kuena of Lanna.

title: Bastille
event: Construction of the Bastille is completed in Paris.

title: Kingdom of León
event: May 17 – King John I of Castile and Leon marries Beatrice of Portugal

title: Greece
event: Charles III of Naples becomes ruler of Achaea (now southern Greece).

title: Italy
event: Otto, Duke of Brunswick-Grubenhagen, the widower of Joan I of Naples, becomes ruler of Taranto (now eastern Italy).

title: Kingdom of León
event: October 22 – King Fernando I of Portugal dies and is succeeded by his daughter, Beatrice of Portugal. A period of civil war and anarchy, known as the 1383-1385 Crisis, begins in Portugal due to Beatrice being married to the King John I of Castile and Leon.

title: Iraq
event: Qara Muhammad succeeds Bairam Khawaja as ruler of the Turkomans of the Black Sheep Empire in present day Armenia and northern Iraq.

title: Gloucestershire
event: Katharine Lady Berkeley's School is founded in Gloucestershire, England.

title: Crown of Castile
event: May / September 3 – Lisbon is besieged by the Castilian army, during the 1383-1385 Crisis.

title: Italy
event: Castello Estense in Ferrara (present-day Italy)

title: East Sussex
event: Bodiam Castle (East Sussex, England)

title: China
event: The Hongwu Emperor of China's Ming Dynasty relents after eighteen tribute missions over the previous eight years and agrees to invest King U of Goryeo.

title: Portugal
event: August 14—Battle of Aljubarrota: John of Aviz defeats John I of Castile in the decisive battle of the 1383-1385 Crisis. John of Aviz is crowned King John I of Portugal, ending Queen Beatrice's rule, and Portugal's independence from Castile is secured.

title: Portugal
event: October 15—The Battle of Valverde is fought between the armies of Portugal and Castile.

title: Crown of Castile
event: John of Gaunt leaves England to make good his claim to the throne of Castile by right of his second marriage to Constanza of Castile in 1371.

title: Crown of Castile
event: Hundred Years War – Battle of Margate: The English defeat an invading French and Castilian naval force.

title: Corfu
event: The Venetians take control of the island of Corfu.

title: Brancacci Chapel
event: Construction begins on the Brancacci Chapel in Florence.

title: Switzerland
event: July 9 – Battle of Sempach: The Swiss safeguard independence from Habsburg rule.

title: Mansa
event: Magha II succeeds his brother, Musa II, as Mansa of the Mali Empire.

title: Kingdom of Navarre
event: January 1 – Charles III ascends to the throne of Navarre after the death of his father, Charles II.

title: Kingdom of Aragon
event: January 5 – John I succeeds his father, Peter IV, as King of Aragon and Valencia, and forms an alliance with France and Castile.

title: Italy
event: March 11 – Battle of Castagnaro between the Italian cities of Verona and Padua: Padua, led by John Hawkwood, is victorious over Giovanni Ordelaffi of Verona.

title: Denmark
event: August 22 – Olaf, King of Norway and Denmark and claimant to the throne of Sweden, dies. The vacant thrones come under the regency of his mother Margaret I of Denmark, who will soon become Queen in her own right.

title: Battle of Otterburn
event: August – Battle of Otterburn: A Scottish army, led by James Douglas, defeats an English army, capturing the their leader, Harry Hotspur. Douglas is killed during the battle.

title: Crown of Castile
event: John of Gaunt, the uncle of Richard II of England, makes peace with Castile and gives up his claim to the Castilian throne by allowing his daughter Katherine of Lancaster to marry Prince Henry, the eldest son of John I of Castile.

title: China
event: Goryeo Revolution: General Yi Seonggye begins a four year revolution in Goryeo (now Korea) after being ordered by King U of Goryeo to attack the superior Chinese army.

title: Yuan Dynasty
event: A Chinese invasion force under General Lan Yu defeats a large Mongolian army under Khan Toghus Temur and captures 100 members of the Yuan royal family. Toghus Temur is killed whilst trying to escape and is succeeded as Khan of Mongolia by his rival, Jorightu.

title: Karakorum
event: An invading Chinese army destroys Karakorum, the capital city of the Mongolian Empire.

title: Nigeria
event: Omar I is succeeded by Sa'id as King of the Kanem-Bornu Empire (now east Chad and Nigeria). Sa'id is succeeded in the same year by Kade Alunu. Omar and Sa'id are both killed by Bilala invaders from the west.

title: University of Cologne
event: The University of Cologne is established (now the largest university in Germany).

title: Cozia Monastery
event: Cozia Monastery is built in Wallacia.

title: Ljubostinja
event: Ljubostinja Monastery is built in Serbia.

title: France
event: Hundred Years' War: England and France sign a truce, ending the second phase of the war.

title: Nigeria
event: Biri II succeeds Kade Alunu as King of the Kanem-Bornu Empire (now eastern Chad and Nigeria) and the Empire loses its land in present-day Chad to the Bilala.

title: Mansa
event: Sandaki overthrows Magha II as Mansa of the Mali Empire.

title: Lisbon
event: Carmo Convent is built in Lisbon.

title: Denmark
event: February 24 – Queen Margaret of Norway and Denmark defeats Albert of Sweden in battle and becomes ruler of all three kingdoms. Albert is deposed from the Swedish throne and taken prisoner.

title: Anatolia
event: The Ottomans take Philadelphia, the last Byzantine enclave of any significance in Anatolia.

title: Vilnius
event: The Earl of Derby (the future King Henry IV of England) supports the Teutonic Knights at the siege of Vilnius.

title: Kashmir
event: Sikandar But-shikan succeeds Sikandar Shah as Sultan of Kashmir.

title: Mansa
event: Mahmud succeeds Sandaki as Mansa of the Mali Empire.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: Templo Mayor, the main temple of the Aztec capital of Tenochtitlan (now Mexico City), is built.

title: Candi Surawana
event: The Candi Surawana Temple is built in the Majapahit Kingdom (now Indonesia).

title: San Petronio Basilica
event: Construction begins on San Petronio Basilica in Bologna.

title: Kingdom of León
event: October 9 – Henry III succeeds his father, John I, as King of Castile and León.

title: India
event: A group of Muzaffarids under Zafar Khan Muzaffar establish a new Sultanate at Gujarat in western India.

title: China
event: The Chinese invent toilet paper for use by their emperors.

title: Faroe Islands
event: Henry I Sinclair, Earl of Orkney, takes control of the Shetland Islands and the Faroe Islands.

title: Italy
event: The University of Ferrara is founded in present-day Italy.

title: Nanjing
event: Ming government orders 50 million trees planted in Nanjing area.

title: Joseon Dynasty
event: Goryeo Revolution 1388–1392: In present-day Korea, rebel leader General Yi Seonggye with the support of the Ming overthrows King Gongyang and crowns himself King Taejo, ending the Goryeo Dynasty and establishing the Joseon Dynasty. King Gongyang is exiled and later secretly murdered.

title: Ireland
event: Seoan mac Pilib succeeds Tomas mor mac Mathghamhna as King of East Breifne in present day north-central Ireland.

title: Anhui
event: Each family holding colonized land in Anhui province has to plant 200 each of mulberry, jujube and persimmon trees

title: China
event: Entire military force of China – 1.2 million men, with 531,000 on the northern frontier in China.

title: Italy
event: Raimondo del Balzo Orsini succeeds Otto of Brunswick as Prince of Taranto (now south-eastern Italy).

title: Beijing
event: A Ming Dynasty Chinese record states that 720,000 sheets of toilet paper (two by three ft. in size) alone have been produced for the various members of the imperial court at Beijing, while the Imperial Bureau of Supplies also reports that 15,000 sheets of toilet paper alone have been designated for the royal family (made of fine soft yellow tissue and perfumed).

title: Ireland
event: Maelruanaidh MacDermot succeeds Aedh MacDermot as King of Moylurg in north-central Ireland.

title: Wallachia
event: Battle of Karanovasa – Wallachia (now southern Romania) resists an invasion by the Ottomans and their Serb and Bulgarian vassals.

title: Constantinople
event: The Ottomans begin an eight-year siege of Constantinople in the Byzantine Empire.

title: Anadoluhisarı
event: The Anadoluhisarı fortress is built by the Ottomans to defend themselves during the siege.

title: Korea
event: The capital city of the Joseon Dynasty in present-day Korea is moved from Gaegyeong (now Gaeseong) to Hanseong (now Seoul).

title: Jongmyo
event: Gyeongbokgung Palace and the Jongmyo royal ancestral shrine are built in Hanseong (now Seoul).

title: Greece
event: The Ottomans conquer Thessaly (now eastern Greece).

title: China
event: The Hongwu Emperor of the Ming Dynasty in China orders the Ministry of Public Works to issue a public notice that every 100 households in the ''lijia'' system are to set aside 2 ''mu'' (1,390 m<sup>2</sup>) of land for planting mulberry and jujube trees.

title: France
event: September 17 – King Charles VI of France orders the expulsion of all Jews from France.

title: Wallachia
event: Sultan Bayezid I of the Ottoman Empire beheads Emperor Ivan Shishman of Ottoman-occupied eastern Bulgaria after Shishman is accused of collaborating with the Wallachians during the 1394 Battle of Karanovasa.

title: Monaco
event: The Principality of Monaco expels their Genoese occupiers and Jean I and Louis are crowned as joint Lords of Monaco. Later in the year, the Genoese regain control and depose the Lords.

title: Ireland
event: Battle of Cruachain: The Kingdom of Ui Falighe (now in Ireland) resists an English invasion.

title: Okinawa Prefecture
event: Bunei succeeds his father, Satto, as King of Chūzan (now central Okinawa, Japan).

title: Jogyesa
event: The Gwanghwamun gate and the Jogyesa temple are built in present-day Seoul.

title: Oxford
event: John Rykener, known also as Johannes Richer and Eleanor, was a transvestite prostitute working mainly in London (near Cheapside), but also active in Oxford. He was arrested in 1395 for cross-dressing and interrogated. The records have survived, the only surviving legal records from that age which mentions same-sex intercourse.

title: Wallachia
event: May 17 – Battle of Rovine: With the help of the Hungarians, Wallachia resists an invasion by the Ottomans and their Serb and Bulgarian vassals.

title: France
event: Temporary peace is declared between England and France with the marriage of Richard II of England and Isabella of Valois, the daughter of Charles VI of France.

title: France
event: France conquers the Republic of Genoa.

title: Greece
event: After a 14-year period of interregnum, Peter of Saint Superan is declared as ruler of the Principality of Achaea (now southern Greece).

title: Azerbaijan
event: Timur appoints his son Miran Shah as Timurid viceroy of present-day Azerbaijan.

title: Burma
event: The Ming Dynasty court of China sends two envoys, Qian Guxun and Li Sicong, to the Ava Kingdom of Burma and the Tai polity of the Mong Mao in order to resolve a dispute between these two. The travels of the Chinese ambassadors are recorded in the historical text of the ''Bai Yi Zhuan''.

title: Hunan
event: Peasants in the present-day provinces of Hunan and Hupeh in the east plant 84 million fruit trees.

title: University of Zadar
event: University of Zadar founded, first University in Croatia

title: Denmark
event: July 23 – Queen Margaret of Norway, Denmark and Sweden makes her adopted son Eric of Pomerania joint ruler of Sweden. Eric had already been made joint ruler of Norway.

title: Battle of the North Inch
event: September – The Battle of the North Inch takes place in Perth, Scotland.

title: France
event: September 25 – Battle of Nicopolis: The Ottomans defeat a joint crusade by Hungary, France, the Holy Roman Empire, England and Wallacia, led by King Sigismund of Hungary. This is the last large-scale crusade of the Middle Ages.

title: Kirillo-Belozersky Monastery
event: Kirillo-Belozersky Monastery is founded in north-west Russia.

title: Somerset
event: February 10 – John Beaufort becomes Earl of Somerset.

title: Finland
event: July 20 – Queen Margaret forms the Kalmar Union, uniting the three kingdoms of Denmark, Norway (with Iceland and Greenland) and Sweden (including Finland).

title: Delhi
event: Timur conquers the Delhi Sultanate, which had been weakened after 4 years of civil war. Timur's Islamic troops sack the city of Delhi and proceed to massacre hundreds of thousands of the state's Hindu inhabitants.

title: China
event: Jianwen succeeds his grandfather, Hongwu, as Emperor of Ming Dynasty China.

title: France
event: France withdraws its support for Antipope Benedict XIII.

title: Palais des Papes
event: An army led by Geoffrey Boucicaut occupies Avignon and starts a 5-year siege of the papal palace.

title: Gotland
event: The Teutonic Knights conquer the island of Gotland, near Sweden, which had previously been run by a group of pirates.

title: Korea
event: Yi Bangsuk, heir to the throne of the Joseon Dynasty in present-day Korea, is murdered during a coup by his older half-brother, Yi Bangwon.

title: Ireland
event: Glendalough monastery in Wicklow, Ireland is destroyed by English troops.

title: Ferapontov Monastery
event: Ferapontov Monastery is built in present-day north-west Russia.

title: Sungkyunkwan University
event: The Munmyo Confucian shrine and Sungkyunkwan University are built in present-day Seoul.

title: Yorkshire
event: Mount Grace Priory is established in Yorkshire, England.

title: North America
event: According to some historians, the Scottish explorer Henry I Sinclair, Earl of Orkney reaches North America.

title: Ireland
event: After regaining his power, Henry Bolingbroke is urged to take the crown from the unpopular Richard II. Richard is taken prisoner upon his returns from Ireland and eventually forced to abdicate. Parliament then charges Richard with committing crimes against his subjects.

title: Greece
event: The Principality of Achaea (now southern Greece) resists an invasion by the Ottoman Empire.

title: Ireland
event: While Richard II is away on a military campaign in Ireland, Henry Bolingbroke, with exiled former Archbishop of Canterbury Thomas Arundel as an advisor, returns to England and begins a military campaign to reclaim his confiscated land.

title: Pontefract Castle
event: 14 February – Richard II of England dies by means unknown in Pontefract Castle. It is likely that King Henry IV ordered the death of Richard by starvation to prevent further uprisings.

title: Damascus
event: Timur defeats both the Ottoman Empire and the Mamluk Sultanate of Egypt to capture the city of Damascus in present-day Syria. Much of the city's inhabitants are subsequently massacred by Timur's troops.

title: Iraq
event: Timur conquers the Empire of The Black Sheep Turkomans, in present-day Armenia, and the Jalayirid Dynasty in present-day Iraq. Black Sheep ruler Qara Yusuf and Jalayirid Sultan Ahmad flee and take refuge with the Ottoman Sultan Bayezid I.

title: Korea
event: In present-day Korea, King Jeongjong of Joseon abdicates in fear of an attack by his ambitious younger brother, Taejong. Taejong succeeds to the throne.

title: Sumatra
event: Prince Parameswara establishes the Malacca Sultanate in present-day western Malaysia and northern Sumatra.

title: Wallachia
event: Wallachia (now southern Romania) resists an invasion by the Ottomans.

title: France
event: Jean Froissart completes his ''Chronicles'' detailing the events of the 14th Century in France.

title: Rhine
event: 21 August – Rupert, Count Palatine of the Rhine, is elected as Holy Roman Emperor.

title: Baghdad
event: Timur raids the city of Baghdad in the Jalayirid Empire.

title: India
event: Dilawar Khan establishes the Malwa Sultanate in present-day northern India.

title: Korea
event: The Joseon Dynasty in present-day Korea officially enters into a tributary relationship with Ming Dynasty China.

title: Bodrum Castle
event: The Knights of Saint John subsequently begin building Bodrum Castle in Bodrum to defend against future attacks.

title: Monaco
event: The Genoese regain control of Monaco.

title: Greece
event: Maria II Zaccaria succeeds Peter of Saint Superan as ruler of the Principality of Achaea (now southern Greece).

title: Korea
event: The Kangnido map of the world is completed in Joseon Dynasty Korea.

title: Ireland
event: Conchobar an Abaidh mac Maelsechlainn O Cellaigh succeeds Maelsechlainn mac William Buidhe O Cellaigh as King of Hy-Many in present day County Galway and County Roscommon in Ireland.

title: University of Würzburg
event: The University of Würzburg, Germany is founded.

title: Diyarbakır
event: The White Sheep Turkmen Empire, in present-day northern Iraq and Iran, moves its capital from Amida to Diyarbakır.{{Citation neededdate=March 2010}}

title: Battle of Bryn Glas
event: June 22 – Battle of Bryn Glas: The Welsh rebels defeat the English on the England/Wales border.

title: Shenyang
event: July 12 – The rebel army of Zhu Di occupies the Ming Dynasty China capital Fengtian. Emperor Jianwen is either lost or killed and Zhu Di is crowned as Emperor Hongwu. This marked the end of Jingnan campaign.

title: Beijing
event: Ming Emperor Yongle moves the capital of China from Nanjing to Beijing.

title: Gur-e Amir
event: The Gur-e Amir Mausoleum is built by Timur after the death of his grandson Muhammad-Sultan, and eventually becomes the family mausoleum of the Timurid dynasty.

title: Sea of Marmara
event: While the Ottomans are at civil war, the Byzantine Empire reclaims the European coast of the Sea of Marmara and Thessalonica. The emperor's son Andronikos Palaiologos is given the title of Lord of Thessalonike.

title: Ireland
event: Tadgh Ruadh mac Maelsechlainn O Cellaigh succeeds Conchobar an Abaidh mac Maelsechlainn O Cellaigh as King of Hy-Many in present-day County Galway and County Roscommon in Ireland.

title: Ireland
event: Maolmhordha mac Con Connacht succeeds Giolla Iosa mac Pilib as King of East Breifne, in present-day County Leitrim and County Cavan, Ireland.

title: China
event: The Temple of a City God is constructed in Shanghai, China.

title: Samarkand
event: Ruy Gonzalez de Clavijo, an ambassador from the king of Castile, arrives in Samarkand.

title: Nanjing
event: Yongle orders his coastal provinces to build a vast fleet of ships, with construction centered at Longjiang near Nanjing; the inland provinces are to provide wood and float it down the Yangzi River.

title: Avignon
event: March 12 – As King Martin I of Aragon helps to end the siege by the French of the papal palace in Avignon, Antipope Benedict XIII flees to Aragon.

title: Battle of Shrewsbury
event: July 21 – Battle of Shrewsbury:  King Henry IV of England defeats a rebel army led by Hotspur Percy, who is killed in the battle by an arrow in his face.

title: University of Turin
event: The University of Turin is founded.

title: China
event: Timur is hit by a fever while preparing to invade China.

title: India
event: Virupaksha Raya succeeds Harihara Raya II as ruler of the Vijayanagara Empire in  present-day southern India.

title: Ireland
event: Ruaidri Caech MacDermot succeeds Conchobair Og MacDermot as King of Moylurg in present-day north-east Connacht, Ireland.

title: Holland
event: November 19 – St. Elizabeth's flood devastates parts of Flanders, Zeeland and Holland.

title: Bath Abbey
event: Bath Abbey is built in England.

title: Beijing
event: Construction of the Forbidden City begins in Beijing during the Chinese Ming Dynasty.

title: Italy
event: Rudolfo Belenzani leads a revolt against Bishop Georg von Liechtenstein in Trento, Italy.

title: China
event: The Ming Dynasty of China under the Yongle Emperor invades and conquers Vietnam, after ditching its support effort for reestablishing the Tran Dynasty over the Ho Dynasty; yet a rebel movement will push the Chinese out by 1428, during the establishment of the Le Dynasty.

title: Nanjing
event: April 10 – After several invitations by the Yongle Emperor of China since 1403, the fifth Karmapa of the Karma Kagyu sect of Tibetan Buddhism, the lama Deshin Shekpa, finally visits the Ming Dynasty capital, then at Nanjing. In his twenty-two day visit, he thrilled the Ming court with alleged miracles that were recorded in a gigantic scroll translated into five different languages. In a show of mystical prowess, Deshin Shekpa added legitimacy to a questionable succession to the throne by Yongle, who had killed his nephew the Jianwen Emperor in the culmination of a civil war. For his services to the Ming court, including his handling of the ceremonial rites of Yongle's deceased parents, Deshin Shekpa was awarded with the title Great Treasure Prince of Dharma (大寶法王).

title: Aberystwyth
event: Henry, Prince of Wales (later Henry V of England) retakes Aberystwyth from Owain Glyndŵr.

title: Denmark
event: Gotland passes under Danish rule.

title: Korea
event: Zheng He delivers 300 virgins from Korea to the Chinese emperor.

title: Samarkand
event: Ulugh Beg becomes governor of Samarkand.

title: University of Leipzig
event: December 2 – The University of Leipzig opens.

title: Czech Republic
event: The Prague Astronomical Clock (also known as Prague Orloj) was built by Mikuláš of Kadaň and Jan Šindel in Prague, the capital of the Czech Republic.

title: Kingdom of Aragon
event: March 29 – The Aragonese capture Oristano, capital of the Giudicato di Arborea in Sardinia.

title: Battle of Grunwald
event: July 15 – Battle of Grunwald (also known as Tannenberg or Žalgiris):  Polish and Lithuanian forces under cousins Jogaila and Vytautas the Great decisively defeat the forces of the Teutonic Knights, whose power is broken.

title: Shandong
event: Under the Yongle Emperor of Ming China, work begins to reinstate the ancient Grand Canal of China, which fell into disuse and dilapidation during the previous Yuan Dynasty. Between 1411 and 1415, a total of 165,000 laborers dredge the canal bed in Shandong, build new channels, embankments, and canal locks. Four large reservoirs in Shandong are also dug in order to regulate water levels instead of resorting to pumping water from local tables. A large dam is also constructed to divert water from the Wen River southwest into the Grand Canal.

title: Toruń
event: February 11 – The First Peace of Thorn is signed in Thorn, Monastic State of the Teutonic Knights

title: Battle of Harlaw
event: July 24 – The Battle of Harlaw is fought between Donald of Islay, Lord of the Isles and an army commanded by Alexander Stewart, Earl of Mar.

title: Tyr Russia
event: Yishiha builds a Buddhist temple at Tyr, Russia, and puts up a stele describing his expedition to the lower Amur

title: Beijing
event: The Tibetan lama Je Tsongkhapa of the Gelug Buddhist sect declined the offer of the Yongle Emperor of China to appear in the capital at Nanjing, although he sent his disciple Chosrje Shākya Yeshes, who was given the title State Teacher. The later Xuande Emperor granted Yeshes the title of a king upon a return visit to China, only he traveled to the new capital at Beijing.

title: Council of Constance
event: November 16 – The Council of Constance begins.

title: Beijing
event: The Grand Canal of China is reinstated by this year after it had fallen out of use; restoration began in 1411, and was a response by the Yongle Emperor of the Ming Dynasty to improve the grain shipment system of tribute traveling from south to north towards his new capital at Beijing. Hence, the problem with lack of food supply is sufficed by this year.

title: Council of Constance
event: July 4 –  Pope Gregory XII officially opens the Council of Constance and then abdicates.

title: France
event: July 31 – Henry V of England is informed of the Southampton Plot against him; he has the leaders arrested and executed before invading France.

title: Portugal
event: August 14 – Portugal conquers the city of Ceuta from the Moors, initiating the Portuguese Empire and European expansion and colonialism.

title: Battle of Agincourt
event: October 25 – Battle of Agincourt: Archers of Henry V of England are instrumental in defeating a massed army of French knights.

title: Trezzo sull'Adda Bridge
event: Trezzo sull'Adda Bridge (the longest arch bridge in the world at the time) is destroyed.

title: Republic of Ragusa
event: January 27 – The Republic of Ragusa is the first state in Europe to outlaw slavery.

title: London
event: The use of street lighting is first recorded in London, when Sir Henry Barton, the mayor, orders lanterns with lights to be hung out on the winter evenings between Hallowtide and Candlemas.

title: Tynwald
event: June 24 – The Isle of Man holds the first known Tynwald Day; the annual meeting of its parliament (Tynwald) which has continued every year until the present.

title: Portugal
event: The first Portuguese settlers move to the Madeira Islands.

title: Council of Constance
event: The Council of Constance ends.

title: Portugal
event: Portuguese sea captains João Gonçalves Zarco and Tristão Vaz Teixeira, at the service of Prince Henry the Navigator, discover the Madeira islands.

title: China
event: The Timurid ruler of Persia, Mirza Shahrukh (r. 1404–1447), sends a large embassy to the Ming Dynasty of China during the reign of the Yongle Emperor (r. 1402–1424). One of the Persian envoys, Ghiyasu'd-Din Naqqah, keeps a diary of his travels throughout China, some of the contents of which are preserved in court documents thanks to the court historian Hafiz Abru. Naqqah writes about China's wealthy economy and huge urban markets, its efficient courier system as compared to that in Persia, the hospitality of his hosts at the courier stations in providing comfortable lodging and food, and the fine luxurious goods and craftsmenship of the Chinese.

title: Korea
event: June 20 – The Oei Invasion of Tsushima Island in Japan by Joseon Korea begins.

title: Grace Dieu (ship)
event: Henry V of England commences construction of ''Grace Dieu (ship)''.

title: Nanjing
event: Construction begins on the Temple of Heaven in Beijing, China while the palace complex of the Forbidden City is completed. In this year the Yongle Emperor confers the title Beijing (Northern Capital) for the Ming Dynasty's new capital city, replacing Nanjing.

title: Yellow River
event: October 22 – Ghiyasu'd-Din Naqqah, an envoy of the embassy sent by the Timurid ruler of Persia, Mirza Shahrukh (r. 1404–1447), to the Ming Dynasty of China during the reign of the Yongle Emperor (r. 1402–1424), records his sight and travel over a large floating pontoon bridge at Lanzhou (constructed earlier in 1372) as he crosses the Yellow River on this day. He writes that it was: ...composed of twenty three boats, of great excellence and strength attached together by a long chain of iron as thick as a man's thigh, and this was moored on each side to an iron post as thick as a man's waist extending a distance of ten cubits on the land and planted firmly in the ground, the boats being fastened to this chain by means of big hooks. There were placed big wooden planks over the boats so firmly and evenly that all the animals were made to pass over it without difficulty.

title: Republic of Florence
event: The first patent is issued by the Republic of Florence.

title: North Sea
event: November 17–November 19 – St. Elizabeth flood: The coastal area near Dordrecht in the Netherlands is flooded due to the extremely high tide of the North Sea; 72 villages are drowned, killing about 10,000 people.

title: Poland during the Jagiellon dynasty
event: September 27 – the Teutonic Knights sign the Treaty of Melno with the Kingdom of Poland and Grand Duchy of Lithuania after the brief Gollub War. The Prussian–Lithuanian border established by the treaty remained unchanged until World War I.

title: China
event: According to the 1421 theory, Zheng He's fleets return to China.

title: France
event: July 31 –  Hundred Years' War- Battle of Cravant: The French army is defeated at Cravant on the banks of the river Yonne.

title: Nanjing
event: Beijing, capital of China, becomes the largest city in the world, taking the lead from Nanjing (estimated date).

title: Italy
event: ''Castello Orsini-Odescalchi'' is built in Bracciano, Italy by the Orsini family.

title: China
event: Eunuch-dominated secret police start to control the palace guards and imperial workshops, infiltrate the civil service and head all foreign missions in China.

title: Brittany
event: March 6 – Battle of St. James (near Avranches):  An English army under John, Duke of Bedford defeats the French under Arthur de Richemont, forcing the Duke of Brittany to recognize English suzerainty.

title: University of Oxford
event: Lincoln College, a constituent college of the University of Oxford, is founded.

title: Nepal
event: Bhaktapur Royal Palace in Nepal is built by King Yaksa Malla.

title: Ava
event: Minrekyansa becomes King of Ava (''ancient Burma'').

title: Sutherland
event: The Conflict of Druimnacour occurs in Sutherland, Scotland.

title: Switzerland
event: The first witch hunts begin, in Switzerland.

title: France
event: Celestine Order established in France.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: Itzcóatl becomes ruler of the Aztecs. He eventually begins the construction of Tenochtitlan.

title: Valley of Mexico
event: The Aztec Triple Alliance (also known as ''The Aztec Empire'') forms with the alliance of three Aztec city-states—Tenochtitlán, Texcoco, and Tlacopán—and defeats Azcapotzalco to win control of the Valley of Mexico.

title: London
event: A serious fire occurs at Baynard's Castle in London.

title: France
event: Voices tell Joan of Arc that Charles VII of France must be crowned and the English expelled from France.

title: Loire Valley
event: June 18 – Battle of Patay: French forces under Joan of Arc smash the English forces under Lord Talbot and Sir John Fastolf, forcing the withdrawal of the English from the Loire Valley.

title: Thessaloniki
event: The Ottoman Empire captures Thessalonica from the Venetians.

title: Bratislava Castle
event: Bratislava Castle is converted to a fortress under Sigismund of Luxemburg.

title: Angkor Thom
event: The Thai sack the Khmer capital of Angkor Thom.

title: Texcoco (altepetl)
event: Nezahualcoyotl is crowned Tlatoani of the Kingdom of Texcoco.

title: France
event: January 9 – Pretrial investigations for Joan of Arc begin in Rouen, France under English occupation.

title: Battle of Inverlochy (1431)
event: September – Battle of Inverlochy: Donald Balloch defeats the Royalists.

title: Albania
event: Gjergj Arianit Komneni: In the spring of 1432 an Albanian revolt erupted which spread to much of Albania against the Ottoman Empire.

title: Ashmyany
event: December 8 – the first battle between the forces of Švitrigaila and Sigismund Kęstutaitis is fought near the town of Oszmiana (Ashmyany), launching the most active phase of the civil war in the Grand Duchy of Lithuania.

title: Northumbria
event: Winter – Much of the English town of Alnwick in Northumbria is burnt by a Scottish raiding party.

title: Portugal
event: The Ming Dynasty in China disbands their naval fleet after the last great maritime expedition led by Admiral Zheng He, altering the balance of power in the Indian Ocean and making it easier for Portugal and other Western naval powers to gain dominance over the seas.

title: Kingdom of León
event: 10 July to 9 August, Suero de Quiñones and his companions stage the ''Passo Honroso'' in León.

title: Western Sahara
event: Explorer Gil Eanes reaches Cape Bojador in Western Sahara, thus destroying the legends of the ‘Dark Sea’.

title: Portugal
event: Portuguese traders deliver their first cargo of African slaves to Lisbon.

title: China
event: In Ming Dynasty China, a long episode of drought, flood, locust infestation, and famine cripple agriculture and commerce in areas throughout China, a bad spell that will last until 1448.

title: France
event: April 14 – The foundation stone of Cathedral St. Peter and St. Paul in Nantes, France is laid.

title: Battle of Lipany
event: May 30 – Hussite Wars – Battle of Lipany: The Catholics and Ultraquists defeat the Taborites, ending the Hussite Wars.

title: France
event: Treaty of Arras brings an end to the Armagnac-Burgundian Civil War, allowing Charles VII of France to concentrate his forces against English influence in France

title: China
event: China returns to a policy of isolation.

title: Battle of Pabaiskas
event: September 1 – Battle of Pabaiskas ends a civil war between Grand Dukes Švitrigaila and Sigismund Kęstutaitis in the Grand Duchy of Lithuania

title: Newcastle upon Tyne
event: 25 June – The Incorporated Guild of Smiths is founded in Newcastle upon Tyne.

title: China
event: In the Ming Empire of China, the inauguration of the Zhengtong Emperor takes place.

title: Malmö
event: 23 April – Malmö in Sweden receives its current coat of arms.

title: University of Oxford
event: All Souls College, University of Oxford is founded.

title: Holyrood Abbey
event: In a ceremony in Holyrood Abbey, James II of Scotland is crowned at the age of six by Pope Eugene IV.

title: Cusco
event: Pachacuti (who will later create Tahuantinsuyu, or the Inca Empire) becomes the ruler of Cuzco.

title: Italy
event: In Italy, the siege of Brescia by the condottieri troops of Niccolò Piccinino is raised after the arrival of Scaramuccia da Forlì.

title: Fujian
event: Just 2 years after the Ming Dynasty court of China allowed landowners paying the grain tax to pay their tax in silver instead, the Ming court now decides to close all silver mines and to ban all private silver mining in Zhejiang and Fujian provinces. This is a concerted effort to halt the increase of silver circulating into the market. Illegally mining silver is now an offense punishable by death; although illegal mining became a dangerous affair, the high demand for illegal mining also made it very lucrative, and so many chose to defy the government and continued to mine silver.

title: Logabirum
event: Logabirum is mentioned for the first time.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: Itzcóatl, Aztec ruler of Tenochtitlan, dies and is succeeded by Moctezuma I ''(Moctezuma Ilhuicamina)''.

title: China
event: The Ming Dynasty government of China begins a decade-long series of issuing harsh edicts towards those who illegally mine silver, the latter known as 'miner bandits' (''kuangzei''), a trend begun in 1438. The government wants to cap the amount of silver circulating into the market as more grain taxes are converted into silver taxes. The government establishes community night watches known as 'watches and tithings' (''baojia'') who ensure that illegal mining activities are brought to a halt. However, these are desperate measures, as illegal silver mining continues to thrive as a dangerous but lucrative venture.

title: King's College Cambridge
event: King's College, University of Cambridge, is founded by King Henry VI.

title: Mayapan
event: A revolt occurs in the Yucatán capital Mayapan; the Maya civilization splits into warring city-states.

title: Finland
event: The municipality of Juva, Finland was founded.

title: Wallachia
event: Vlad II Dracul is temporarily replaced as ruler of Wallachia by his son Mircea.

title: Sibiu
event: Battle of Sibiu: John Hunyadi defeats an Ottoman army of 80,000 strong, led by Mezid the Bey of Vidin, near Sibiu.

title: Nuno Tristão
event: Nuno Tristão penetrates the Arguim Gulf.

title: Beijing
event: The Zhihua Si Buddhist Temple (智化寺) is built in Beijing, China at the order of Wang Zhen, the chief eunuch at the court of the Zhengtong Emperor of the Ming Dynasty.

title: Battle of St. Jakob an der Sihl
event: July 22 – Battle of St. Jakob an der Sihl: Zürich is barely defeated.

title: Rhodes
event: Forces of the Sultan of Egypt fail to take Rhodes from the Knights of Rhodes.

title: Italy
event: The Iguvine Tables are discovered at Gubbio, Italy.

title: Portugal
event: Portuguese explorers reach the mouth of the rivers Senegal and Gambia.

title: London
event: A serious fire occurs at St Paul's Cathedral in London.

title: Laurentian Library
event: June 15 – Cosimo de' Medici founds the Laurentian Library.

title: Kingdom of Hungary
event: August 15 – Treaty of Szeged between Ottoman (Turkish) Empire and Kingdom of Hungary.

title: Battle of Varna
event: November 10 – Battle of Varna: The crusading forces of King Ladislas of Poland and Hungary are crushed by the Turks under Sultan Murad II.  Ladislas is killed.

title: Cape Verde
event: Senegal and Cape Verde are discovered by Dinas Diaz.

title: Geba River
event: Portuguese navigator Álvaro Fernandes reaches the mouth of the Geba River in Guinea-Bissau.

title: Precious Belt Bridge
event: The Precious Belt Bridge in China is fully reconstructed.

title: Italy
event: In Italy, the siege of Cremona by the condottieri troops of Francesco Piccinino and Luigi dal Verme is raised after the arrival of Scaramuccia da Forlì.

title: Ireland
event: The Blarney Stone is set into a tower of Blarney Castle in Blarney, County Cork in Ireland.

title: Korea
event: October 9 – The hangul alphabet is created in Korea by King Sejong the Great of Joseon. The ''Hunmin Jeongeum'' published during the year is considered the start of this brand new scientific writing system.

title: Wallachia
event: December – Vlad II Dracul, ruler of Wallachia, and his eldest son Mircea are assassinated. Vladislav II succeeds him with the assistance of John Hunyadi.

title: Albania
event: The Battle of Oronichea:  Peace between Albania and Venice is established.

title: Queens' College Cambridge
event: Queens' College, Cambridge is founded by Margaret of Anjou.

title: Vatican Library
event: The Vatican Library is founded by Pope Nicholas V.

title: Wallachia
event: Vlad III the Impaler becomes reigning Prince of Wallachia for two months before being deposed by Vladislav II.

title: China
event: After a long episode of drought, flood, locust infestation, and famine in Ming Dynasty China since the year 1434, these natural afflictions finally wane and agriculture and commerce return to a state of normality.

title: Wallachia
event: October 17 – Battle of Kosovo: Hungarian forces under John Hunyadi are defeated by the Turks due to the treachery of Prince Dan of Wallachia and George Brankovic of Serbia.

title: China
event: September 8 – Battle of Tumu Fortress: The Oirat Mongols defeat the  Ming Dynasty army and capture the Zhengtong Emperor of China; the latter is officially deposed while his brother ascends as the Jingtai Emperor the next year.

title: UNESCO
event: Machu Picchu (Quechua: Machu Pikchu, Old mountain) a pre-Columbian Inca site located 2,400 meters (7,875 ft) above sea level believed to be under construction.UNESCO}}<

title: France
event: March – French troops under Guy de Richemont besiege the English commander in France, Edmund Beaufort, 1st Duke of Somerset, in Caen.

title: France
event: April 15 – Battle of Formigny: French troops under the Comte de Clermont defeat an English army under Sir Thomas Kyriel and Sir Matthew Gough which was attempting to relieve Caen.

title: Kent
event: May 8 – Jack Cade's Rebellion: Kentishmen revolt against King Henry VI.

title: London
event: June 18 – Battle of Seven Oaks: Jack Cade's rebels are driven from London by loyal troops, bringing about the collapse of the rebellion.

title: France
event: July 6 – Caen surrenders to the French.

title: France
event: August 12 – Cherbourg, the last English territory in Normandy, surrenders to the French.

title: University of Barcelona
event: November 3 – The University of Barcelona is founded.

title: Albania
event: November 23 – First Siege of Krujë: Albanian victory; Ottoman army of approximately 100,000 men retreats from Albania.

title: University of Glasgow
event: The University of Glasgow is founded.

title: Celje
event: April 11 – Celje acquires market-town status and town rights by orders from Count Frederic II of Celje.

title: Guyenne
event: June 30 – French troops under the Comte de Dunois invade Guyenne and capture Bordeaux.

title: Kuwae
event: A major eruption of the South Pacific volcano Kuwae in Vanuatu has a subsequent global cooling effect (the eruption released more sulfate than any other event in the past 700 years).

title: Battle of Bealach nam Broig
event: Battle of Bealach nam Broig, a Scottish clan battle.

title: Stirling Castle
event: Murder of William Douglas, 8th Earl of Douglas by James II of Scotland at Stirling Castle.

title: Guyenne
event: October – English troops under John Talbot, 1st Earl of Shrewsbury, land in Guyenne, France, and retake most of the province without a fight.

title: Princes' Islands
event: April – Therapia and Studius are taken by the Ottomans in preparation for the assault on Constantinople, as are the Princes' Islands, by the Ottoman fleet under Admiral Baltoghlu.

title: Constantinople
event: May–June: Epibatos and Selymbria also fall to the Turks after the final fall of Constantinople.

title: Istanbul
event: April 2–May 29– Siege and Fall of Constantinople (now Istanbul): The Ottoman Sultan Mehmed II the Conqueror ends the Byzantine Empire by capturing the capital, Constantinople.

title: France
event: July 17 – Battle of Castillon: The French under Jean Bureau defeat the English under the Earl of Shrewsbury, who is killed.

title: France
event: October 19 – The Hundred Years' War comes to a close with the French recapture of Bordeaux, leaving the English retaining only Calais on French soil.

title: Battle of Arkinholm
event: May 18 – Battle of Arkinholm: King James II of Scotland defeats the Earl of Douglas.

title: First Battle of St Albans
event: May 22 – First Battle of St Albans: Richard, Duke of York, defeats and captures King Henry VI of England.

title: Cape Verde
event: Luigi de Cadamosto discovers the Cape Verde Islands.

title: Debre Berhan
event: Emperor Zara Yaqob of Ethiopia founds the city of Debre Berhan.

title: Albania
event: May 18 – Second Battle of Oronichea (1456): Ottoman forces of 15,000 went to capture Albania but was met and swiftly defeated by Skanderbeg's smaller force.

title: Wallachia
event: August 20 – Vladislav II, reigning Prince of Wallachia, is killed in battle by Vlad III Dracula, who succeeds him.

title: University of Greifswald
event: October 17 – The University of Greifswald is established, making it the second oldest university in northern Europe (also for a period the oldest in Sweden and Prussia).

title: Tokyo
event: Edo Castle is built by Ōta Dōkan in what is now Tokyo.

title: China
event: After years of captivity and absence from the Ming throne, the Zhengtong Emperor of China is reinstated as the Tianshun Emperor.

title: University of Oxford
event: Magdalen College, University of Oxford is founded.

title: Cape Verde
event: Luis Cadamosto discovers the first Cape Verde Islands.

title: Bucharest
event: The Wallachian town of Bucharest is first mentioned.

title: India
event: The city of Jodhpur, in western India, is founded by Rao Jodha of Marwar.

title: Battle of Blore Heath
event: September 23 – Battle of Blore Heath: Yorkists under the Earl of Salisbury defeat a Lancastrian force.

title: Sierra Leone
event: The first Portuguese navigators reach the coast of modern Sierra Leone.

title: London
event: June – The Earl of Warwick and Edward, Earl of March, eldest son of the Duke of York, land in England with an army and seize London.

title: Cape Verde
event: May 4 – Portuguese navigators Diogo Gomes and António da Nola discover the islands of Cape Verde.

title: Tower of London
event: July 4 – The cannon of the Tower of London, still in Lancaster hands, are fired on the city of London, which is mostly in Yorkist hands.

title: Battle of Northampton (1460)
event: July 10 – Battle of Northampton: Warwick and March defeat a Lancastrian army and seize King Henry.  It is agreed that York will be Henry's heir, disinheriting the King's son Edward of Westminster, Prince of Wales.

title: Battle of Wakefield
event: December 30 – Battle of Wakefield: A Lancastrian army under Henry Beaufort, Duke of Somerset and Henry Percy, Earl of Northumberland defeats a Yorkist army under the Duke of York and his son, Edmund, Earl of Rutland.  Both York and Rutland are killed, the latter murdered after the battle.  York's son Edward becomes leader of the Yorkist faction.

title: Cirencester Grammar School
event: Cirencester Grammar School is founded in south-west England by the Bishop of Durham.

title: Sarajevo
event: Sarajevo, capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina, is founded by the Ottomans.

title: Battle of Mortimer's Cross
event: February 2 – Battle of Mortimer's Cross: Yorkist troops led by Edward, Duke of York defeat Lancastrians under Owen Tudor and his son Jasper Tudor, Earl of Pembroke in Wales.

title: Second Battle of St Albans
event: February 17 – Second Battle of St Albans: The Earl of Warwick's army is defeated by a Lancastrian force under Queen Margaret, who recovers control of her husband.

title: Battle of Towton
event: March 29 – Battle of Towton: Edward IV defeats Queen Margaret to make good his claim to the English throne (thought to be the bloodiest battle ever fought in England).

title: Beijing
event: August 7 – The Ming Dynasty Chinese military general Cao Qin stages a coup against the Tianshun Emperor; after setting fire to the eastern and western gates of the Imperial City (which were doused by pouring rains during the day-long uprising), Cao Qin finds himself hemmed in on all sides by imperial forces, loses three of his own brothers in the fight, and instead of facing execution he flees to his house and commits suicide by jumping down a well located within the walled compound of his urban Beijing home.

title: Cape Verde
event: Settlers from Portugal begin to settle the Cape Verde islands.

title: Wallachia
event: June 17 – Vlad III Dracula attempts to assassinate Mehmed II in The Night Attack, forcing Mehmed to retreat from Wallachia.

title: China
event: In China, a small rebellion occurs in the interior province of Huguang, during the Ming Dynasty; a subsequent rebellion springs up in Guangxi, where a rebellion of the Miao people and Yao people forces the Ming throne to respond by sending 30,000 troops (including 1,000 Mongol cavalry) to aid the 160,000 local troops stationed in the region to crush the rebellion that will end in 1466.

title: Ohrid
event: Pope Pius II himself shoulders the cross of the Crusader. Pope Pius II named Skanderbeg general captain of the Holy See. Skanderbeg was given the title Athleta Christi. This plan forced Skanderbeg to break his 10 year peace treaty with the Ottomans signed in 1463, by attacking the Turkish forces near Ohrid.

title: Battle of Hedgeley Moor
event: April 25 – Battle of Hedgeley Moor: Yorkist forces under Lord Montague defeat Lancastrians under Sir Ralph Percy, who is killed.

title: Battle of Hexham
event: May 15 – Battle of Hexham: Montague defeats another Lancastrian army, this one led by King Henry and Queen Margaret themselves. This marks the end of organized Lancastrian resistance for several years.

title: France
event: Former King Henry VI of England is captured by Yorkist forces and imprisoned in the Tower of London. Queen consort Margaret of Anjou and the Prince of Wales Edward of Westminster had fled to France.

title: China
event: Massive flooding in central and southern China motivates the initial construction of hundreds of new bridges under the Ming Dynasty.

title: Albania
event: June – Second Siege of Krujë (1466):  Mehmed II led an army of 150,000 to attempt squash the Albanian resistance by taking Krujë. Albanian victory; Ottoman army retreats from Albania.

title: Albania
event: Third Siege of Krujë (1467): A few months after the failure of the second siege, Mehmed II led an army into Albania in 1467. Albanian victory.

title: Metz Cathedral
event: Metz Cathedral is completed.

title: Switzerland
event: Sigismund of Austria sells Upper-Elsass (Alsace) to Charles the Bold in exchange for aid in a war against the Swiss.

title: Iran
event: Uzun Hassan wins in Persia and defeats Abu Sa'id.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: Moctezuma I, Aztec ruler of Tenochtitlan, dies and is succeeded by Axayacatl.

title: Shetland
event: James III of Scotland acquires the Orkney and Shetland Islands from Denmark.

title: Battle of Edgecote Moor
event: July 26 – Battle of Edgecote Moor: The House of Lancaster defeats the House of York.

title: Crown of Castile
event: October 19 – Infante Ferdinand of Aragon marries Infanta Isabella of Castile. This event will lead to a unified Spain in 1492.

title: Elmina
event: The first contact occurs between Europeans and the Fante nation of the Gold Coast, when a party of Portuguese land and meet with the King of Elmina (see also History of Ghana).

title: France
event: Johann Heynlin introduces the printing press into France and prints his first book that same year.

title: Equator
event: João de Santarém and Pedro Escobar crossed the Equator. The southern hemisphere was discovered and the sailors began to be guided by a new constellation, the Southern Cross.

title: Ghana
event: Portuguese sailors reach Mina de Ouro on the Gold Coast (present-day Ghana) and explore Cape St. Catherine, two degrees south of the equator. Mina de Ouro becomes the chief center for the gold trade and a major source of revenue for the crown.

title: Chefchaouen
event: Moorish exiles from Spain, led by Moulay Ali Ben Moussa Ben Rached El Alami, found the city of Chefchaouen in the north of Morocco.

title: Battle of Barnet
event: April 14 – Battle of Barnet: Edward defeats the Lancastrian army under Warwick, who is killed.

title: Battle of Tewkesbury
event: May 4 – Battle of Tewkesbury: King Edward defeats a Lancastrian army under Queen Margaret and her son, Edward of Westminster the Prince of Wales, who is killed.  Later in the month, King Henry VI of England is murdered, eliminating all  Lancastrian opposition.

title: Newfoundland (island)
event: Possible discovery of Bacalao (possibly Newfoundland, North America) by João Vaz Corte-Real.

title: Portugal
event: An extensive slave trade begins in modern Cameroon, as the Portuguese sail up the Wuori River.

title: Portugal
event: Fernão do Po claims the central-African islands Bioko and Annobón for Portugal.

title: Shetland
event: February 20 – Orkney and Shetland are returned by Norway to Scotland, due to a defaulted dowry payment.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: Axayacatl, Aztec ruler of Tenochtitlan, invades the territory of the neighboring Aztec city of Tlatelolco. The ruler of Tlatelolco is killed and replaced by a military governor. Tlatelolco loses its independence.

title: Newfoundland (island)
event: Possible discovery of Bacalao (possibly Newfoundland, North America) by Didrik Pining and João Vaz Corte-Real.

title: Celje
event: The city walls and defensive moat are built in Celje, Slovenia.

title: Crown of Castile
event: December 12 – Upon the death of Henry IV of Castile, a civil war ensues between his designated successor Isabella I of Castile and her sister Juana, who is supported by her husband, Alfonso V of Portugal. Isabella wins the civil war after a lengthy struggle when her husband, Ferdinand II of Aragon, the newly crowned king of Aragon, comes to her aid.

title: Battle of Vaslui
event: January 10 – Battle of Vaslui: Stephen III of Moldavia defeats the Ottoman Empire, which was led at that time by Mehmed II, the conqueror of Constantinople.

title: Wallachia
event: November 26 – Vlad III the Impaler manages to become reigning Prince of Wallachia for the third and last time, before later being killed by the Ottoman Turks at the Battle of Bucharest. His head is sent to his old enemy Sultan Mehmed II of the Ottoman Empire.

title: Uppsala University
event: 27 February – The Swedish University of Uppsala is founded.

title: France
event: August 18 – Mary of Burgundy marries Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor in Ghent, bringing her Flemish and Burgundian lands into the Holy Roman Empire and detaching them from France.

title: Albania
event: Fourth Siege of Krujë: The Fourth Siege of Krujë by the Ottoman Empire of Krujë in Albania occurred in 1478 and resulted in the town's capture after the failure of three prior sieges.

title: France
event: Possibly the first reference to cricket, in criquet, as discovered in France by Rowland Bowen in the 20th century.  It has been dismissed by some (most notably John Major) and presaged with Edward II's Creag (1300) by others.

title: Tower of London
event: February 18 – George, Duke of Clarence, convicted of treason against his older brother Edward IV of England, is privately executed in the Tower of London.

title: Switzerland
event: December 28 – Battle of Giornico: Swiss troops defeat the Milanese.

title: Portugal
event: Christopher Columbus, experienced mariner and successful trader in the thriving Genoese ex-pat community in Portugal, '''marries''' Felipa Perestrelo Moniz (Italian on her father's side) and receives no ordinary dowry''':''' her late father's maps and papers, charting the seas and winds around the Madeira Islands and other Portuguese possessions in the Ocean Sea.

title: Kingdom of Hungary
event: October 13 – Battle of Kenyérmező ({{lang-trEkmekotlak}}): The Hungarian army, led by Pál Kinizsi and István Báthori, defeats the Ottoman Turk army in Transylvania, Hungary.

title: Canary Islands
event: March 6 – Treaty of Toledo: Ferdinand and Isabella of Spain recognize the African conquests of Afonso of Africa, and he cedes the Canary Islands to Spain.

title: Rhodes
event: July 28 – Mohamed II fails in his attempt to capture Rhodes from the Knights of Rhodes.

title: Anjou
event: With the death of Duke Charles IV of Anjou, Anjou reverts to the French crown under Louis XI of France.

title: Notre Dame de Paris
event: Fire destroys the roof and the spires of the Cathedral of Notre Dame at Rheims.

title: Portugal
event: The papal bull ''Aeterni regis'' grants all land south of the Canary Islands to Portugal.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: Axayacatl, Aztec ruler of Tenochtitlan, dies and is succeeded by his brother Tízoc.

title: Albania
event: Albania falls to the Ottoman Empire.

title: Utrecht (province)
event: December 26 – Battle of Westbroek: Holland defeats the troops of Utrecht.

title: Portugal
event: The Portuguese erect the Fort of Sao Jorge de Mina (Fort Elmina) near the mouth of the River Benya on the Gold Coast.

title: Portugal
event: Diogo Cão, a Portuguese navigator, becomes the first European to sail up the Congo.

title: Kingdom of England
event: The Kingdom of England captures Berwick from the Kingdom of Scotland, resulting in the only permanent change to the Anglo-Scottish border from the signing of the Treaty of York in 1237 to the present day.

title: Portugal
event: Isaac Abravanel flees Portugal after being implicated in a plot against the king.

title: France
event: April – King Edward V of England and his younger brother Richard, Duke of York reside in the Tower of London. Later this year rumors of their murders start circulating. By December the rumors have reached France. This is the beginning of the mystery concerning the fates of the two Princes in the Tower.

title: Canary Islands
event: April 29 – Gran Canaria, the main of the Canary Islands is conquered by the Kingdom of Castile, very important step in the expansion of Spain.

title: Tower of London
event: June 13 – William Hastings, 1st Baron Hastings, is executed, in the first recorded execution at the Tower of London.

title: Sistine Chapel
event: August 9 – The Sistine Chapel opens.

title: Portugal
event: The King of Portugal appoints a commission of mathematicians to perfect tables to help seamen find their latitude.

title: Namibia
event: July 6 – Portuguese sea captain Diogo Cão finds the mouth of Congo River, Walvis Bay, south of Namibia.

title: Battle of Lochmaben Fair
event: July 22 – Battle of Lochmaben Fair: A 500-man raiding party led by Alexander Stewart, Duke of Albany and James Douglas, 9th Earl of Douglas is defeated by forces loyal to Albany's brother James III of Scotland; Douglas is captured.

title: Mount Tai
event: Spring – Multiple earthquakes near Taishan, China

title: Vienna
event: June 1 – Matthias of Hungary takes Vienna in his conquest of Austria (from Frederick III) and makes the city his capital.

title: Battle of Bosworth Field
event: August 22 – The Battle of Bosworth Field is fought between the armies of King Richard III of England and rival claimant to the throne of England Henry Tudor, Earl of Richmond. Richard dies in battle and Henry Tudor becomes King Henry VII of England.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: Tízoc, Aztec ruler of Tenochtitlan, dies. Some sources suggest that he was poisoned, others that he was the victim of sorcery or illness. He is succeeded by his brother Auitzotl.

title: Valsugana
event: March – Archduke Sigismund of Austria, largely on the poor advice of his counselors, declares war on Venice and seizes silver mines in and around the Valsugana Valley.

title: Cape of Good Hope
event: August – Bartolomeu Dias leaves Lisbon on his voyage to the Cape of Good Hope.

title: Málaga
event: The Spanish take Málaga.

title: Ireland
event: May 24 – Lambert Simnel is crowned King Edward VI of England in Christchurch Cathedral, Dublin, Ireland. He claims to be Edward, Earl of Warwick and challenges Henry VII for the throne of England.

title: Battle of Stoke Field
event: June 16 – Battle of Stoke Field: The rebellion of pretender Lambert Simnel, led by John de la Pole, Earl of Lincoln, and Francis Lovell, 1st Viscount Lovell, is crushed by troops loyal to Henry VII.

title: China
event: September 9 – Hongzhi becomes Emperor of China (Ming dynasty).

title: India
event: The city of Bikaner in western India is founded by Rao Bika.

title: Indian Ocean
event: February 3 – Bartolomeu Dias of Portugal lands in Mossel Bay after rounding the Cape of Good Hope at the tip of Africa, becoming the first known European to travel this far south and entering the Indian Ocean.

title: Beijing
event: February 28 – Ch'oe Pu (1454–1504), the Korean Commissioner of Registers for the island of Cheju, shipwrecks on the southeast coast of China in Taizhou, Zhejiang, during the Ming Dynasty. From then until July 12 he and his crew are hosted by Chinese military courier officers to travel along the Grand Canal of China, all the way to Beijing, and then finally back across the Yalu River into Korea. His written commentary on Chinese customs, foreign and domestic trade, and transport in places such as Hangzhou and Suzhou are valuable records of Ming era culture and commerce.

title: Battle of Saint-Aubin-du-Cormier (1488)
event: July 28 Battle of Saint-Aubin-du-Cormier: Troops loyal to King Charles VIII of France defeat rebel forces led by the Dukes of Orleans and Brittany in the main engagement of the Mad War.

title: Nicosia
event: Nicosia, Cyprus, becomes a possession of Venice.

title: All Saints' Church Wittenberg
event: All Saints' Church, the ''Schlosskirche'' in Wittenberg is begun.

title: Korea
event: The Chinese scholar and printer Hua Sui invents bronze-metal movable type printing in China, although the earlier Wang Zhen had experimented with tin movable type in 1298 and the Koreans had separately innovated bronze movable type{{Citation neededdate=December 2009}}.

title: Yemen
event: Merchants carry coffee from Yemen to Mecca, Arabia (approximate date).

title: Kraków
event: Nicolaus Copernicus enters Kraków University.

title: Komi Republic
event: In the Russian territory of Komi (now the Komi Republic), annexed by Russia in 1478, copper and silver ores are discovered, and the territory gains importance as a mining and metallurgical center.

title: France
event: December 6 – King Charles VIII of France marries Anne of Brittany, forcing her to break her marriage with Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor, thus incorporating Brittany into the kingdom of France.

title: İzmir
event: Sultan Bayezid II of the Ottoman Empire, learning about the expulsion of Jews from Spain, dispatches the Ottoman Navy to bring the Jews safely to Ottoman lands, mainly  to the cities of Thessaloniki (currently in Greece) and İzmir (currently in Turkey).[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/Turkey.html]

title: China
event: In Ming Dynasty China, the commercial transportation of grain to the northern border in exchange for salt certificates is monetarized.

title: North Yorkshire
event: Ermysted's Grammar School, Skipton, North Yorkshire, founded.

title: Emirate of Granada
event: January 2 – Boabdil, the last Moorish King of Granada, surrenders his city to the army of Ferdinand and Isabella after a lengthy siege, ending the 10-year Granada War and the Reconquista which lasted almost 800 years. Christopher Columbus is in Alhambra, and sees the Moorish king come out of the city gates and kiss the hands of the Spanish king, queen and prince.

title: Americas
event: August 3 – Christopher Columbus sails the ocean blue on his first journey across the Atlantic Ocean to Asia, but he ends up in the Americas

title: Caribbean
event: October 12 – Christopher Columbus' expedition makes landfall in the Caribbean and lands on Guanahani, but believes he has reached the East Indies.

title: Alsace
event: November 7 – The Ensisheim meteorite,  a 127-kg meteorite, lands in a wheat field near the village of Ensisheim in Alsace.

title: Hispaniola
event: December 5 – Christopher Columbus becomes the first known European to set foot on the island of Hispaniola.

title: Roussillon
event: January 19 – Treaty of Barcelona: Charles VIII of France returns Cerdagne and Roussillon to Ferdinand of Aragon.

title: Mitla
event: Aztec forces conquer and sack Mitla.

title: Jamaica
event: May 3 – Christopher Columbus first sights Jamaica.

title: Portugal
event: June 7 – Treaty of Tordesillas: Spain and Portugal divide the New World between themselves.

title: Hispaniola
event: June 25 – The first hurricane ever observed by Europeans strikes the Spanish settlement of La Isabela on Hispaniola.

title: Reichskammergericht
event: The Reichskammergericht of the Holy Roman Empire is founded.

title: HMNB Portsmouth
event: Henry VII of England commissions the world's first dry dock at Portsmouth.

title: University of Aberdeen
event: The University of Aberdeen is founded by Bishop William Elphinstone.

title: Battle of Fornovo
event: July 6 – Battle of Fornovo: The French army under King Charles secures its retreat from Italy, by defeating a combined Milanese-Venetian force under Giovanni Francesco Gonzaga, Marquis of Mantua.

title: Karelia
event: November 30 – An explosion at Vyborg Castle deters the Russian forces who have invaded Sweden through Karelia.

title: Canary Islands
event: December 25 – Second Battle of Acentejo: The Spanish crush the native forces of the island of Tenerife, leading to the subjugation of this last bastion of resistance in the Canary Islands.

title: France
event: July – Spanish forces under Gonzalo Hernandez de Cordoba capture Atella after a siege. Among the prisoners is the French viceroy of Naples, the Comte de Montpensier. Ferrante II is restored to the throne of Naples.

title: Jesus College Cambridge
event: Jesus College (University of Cambridge) is founded.

title: Crown of Castile
event: Joanna, second daughter of Ferdinand and Isabella, heiress to Castile, marries the archduke Philip, heir through his mother to the Burgundian Netherlands, and through his father to the Holy Roman Empire.

title: Hispaniola
event: Christopher Columbus forcibly subjugates the island Hispaniola, enslaves the Amerindians and lays the basis for a system of land grants tied to the Amerindians' labor service.

title: Western Hemisphere
event: March 10 – Christopher Columbus leaves Hispaniola for Spain, ending his second visit to the Western Hemisphere.

title: Bristol
event: May 20 – John Cabot sets sail from Bristol on his ship the ''Mathew'', looking for a route to the west (other documents give a May 2 date).

title: North America
event: June 24 – John Cabot lands in North America (near present day Bonavista, Newfoundland).

title: India
event: July 8 – Vasco da Gama's fleet departs from Lisbon, beginning his expedition to India.

title: North Wales
event: Summer – the final Welsh revolt of the medieval era breaks out in Meirionydd, North Wales; Harlech Castle is captured by the rebels before the revolt in suppressed.

title: Kenya
event: The Portuguese sail up to the coasts of modern Tanzania and Kenya.

title: Quelimane
event: January 25 – Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama visits Quelimane and Mozambique in southeastern Africa.

title: India
event: May 20 – Portuguese navigator Vasco da Gama arrives at Calicut (now Kozhikode), India, becoming the first European to get there by sailing around Africa, thus discovering the maritime route to India. He finds a local Arab merchant who is able to interpret for him.

title: Trinidad and Tobago
event: July 31 – On his third voyage to the Western Hemisphere, Christopher Columbus becomes the first European to discover the island of Trinidad.

title: Kingdom of Hungary
event: April 14 – With the Treaty of Krakow, Poland and Hungary recognize the independence of Moldavia.

title: Battle of Dornach
event: July 22 – Battle of Dornach: The Swiss decisively defeat the Imperial army of Emperor Maximilian I.

title: Lake Maracaibo
event: August 24 – Lake Maracaibo is discovered.

title: India
event: September 18 – Vasco da Gama arrives at Lisbon, returning from India, and he is received by King Manuel of Portugal.

title: Seine
event: October 25 – The Pont Notre-Dame in Paris, constructed under Charles VI of France, collapses onto the Seine.

title: Brittany
event: November 5 – The ''Catholicon'' is published in Treguier (Brittany). This Breton-French-Latin dictionary had been written in 1464 by Jehan Lagadeuc. It's the first Breton dictionary, as well as the first French dictionary in world history.

title: Tower of London
event: November 23 – Pretender to the throne Perkin Warbeck is hanged for reportedly attempting to escape from the Tower of London. In 1497 he invaded England, claiming to be the lost son of King Edward IV of England.

title: Tower of London
event: November 28 – Edward, Earl of Warwick is executed for reportedly attempting to escape from the Tower of London. He was the last male member of the House of York.

title: Sudan
event: The Luo, a Nilotic people from modern Sudan, settle the Cwezi states, establishing the state of Bunyoro-Kitara (approximate date).

title: Kerala
event: Duarte Barbosa arrives in India. He works as interpreter and translator in Cochin and Cananor in Kerala.

title: France
event: January 5 – Duke Ludovico Sforza recaptures Milan, but is soon driven out again by the French.

title: Dithmarschen
event: February 17 – Battle of Hemmingstedt: The Danish army fails to conquer the peasants' republic of Dithmarschen.

title: Portugal
event: April 22 – Portuguese navigator Pedro Álvares Cabral officially discovers Brazil and claims the land for Portugal. He has 13 vessels with him.

title: Madagascar
event: August 10 – Diogo Dias discovers an island which he names St Lawrence (after the saint's day on which it was first sighted), later to be known as Madagascar

title: Iran
event: The Safavid kingdom is established in northern Iran.

title: University of Erfurt
event: Martin Luther enters the University of Erfurt.

title: Lisbon
event: April 23 – The Portuguese navigator Pedro Cabral and 6 ships return to Lisbon.

title: Ascension Island
event: May 20 – Joao da Nova Castell discovers Ascension Island.

title: Lisbon
event: July 15 – Explorer Pedro Cabral arrives in Lisbon.

title: Switzerland
event: August 26 – The Canton of Basel is partitioned in twain by the Swiss ''Tagsatzung'', to create the two half-cantons of Basel-City and Basel-Country.

title: Baía de Todos os Santos
event: November 1 – Amerigo Vespucci discovers and names All Saints' Bay.

title: Hispaniola
event: The first African slaves brought to the New World arrive at the island of Hispaniola (present-day Haiti and Dominican Republic).

title: Newfoundland (island)
event: 'Newfoundland' gets its name from a letter.

title: Trujillo Colón
event: Christopher Columbus lands at Trujillo and names the mainland 'Honduras'.

title: Italy
event: In Italy, Asher Lämmlein declares that the Jewish Messiah will arrive in the next 6 months, resulting in the 'year of penance.'

title: Rio de Janeiro
event: January 1 – Portuguese explorers, led by Pedro Álvares Cabral, sail into Guanabara Bay, Brazil, mistaking it for the mouth of a river, which they name Rio de Janeiro.

title: Saint Helena
event: May 21 – Portuguese navigator João da Nova discovers the island of Saint Helena.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: Henry VII’s chapel, the final stage of English gothic art, is begun in Westminster Abbey.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: A perpendicular style chapel is added to Westminster Abbey.

title: Portugal
event: Vasco da Gama establishes India's first Portuguese fortress at Cochin.

title: Bermuda
event: The Bermuda Islands are discovered by Juan de Bermudez.

title: France
event: February 23 – French-Spanish Wars in Italy – Battle of Ruvo: The Spanish defeat the French.

title: France
event: April 21 – Battle of Cerignola: Spanish forces under Gonzalo Fernández de Córdoba defeat the French under the Duc de Nemours, who is killed (considered to be the first battle in history won by gunpowder small arms).

title: Cayman Islands
event: May 10 – Christopher Columbus discovers the Cayman Islands, which he names ''Las Tortugas'' after the numerous sea turtles there.

title: Holyrood Abbey
event: August 8 – King James IV of Scotland marries Margaret Tudor, daughter of King Henry VII of England at Holyrood Abbey, Edinburgh, Scotland.

title: France
event: December 14 – Michel de Nostredame aka Nostradamus is born in France. World famous for his visions, he will write the book ''Les Propheties'', which will first appear in the year 1555.

title: France
event: December 29 – Battle of (the) Garigliano, near Gaeta, Italy: Spanish forces under Gonzalo Fernández de Córdoba defeat a French–Italian mercenary army under Ludovico II, the Marquis of Saluzzo. The French forces withdraw to Gaeta.

title: Belize
event: Christopher Columbus returns to Spain from his fourth voyage, where he and his younger son, Ferdinand, explored the coast of Central America from Belize to Panama.

title: Palazzo Vecchio
event: The Signoria of Florence commissions both Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo to paint the walls of the Grand Council Chamber in the Palazzo Vecchio.

title: Suez Canal
event: Venetian ambassadors suggest to Turkey the construction of a Suez Canal.

title: France
event: January 31 – Treaty of Lyon: France cedes Naples to Ferdinand of Aragon.

title: France
event: March 31 – France and Spain agree to a ceasefire.

title: Colombo
event: Portuguese under Dom Lourenço d'Almeida reach Colombo, Sri Lanka and send envoys to King of Kotte.

title: Portugal
event: Portuguese reach the Comoros.

title: Bermuda
event: Bermuda is discovered by the Portuguese explorer Juan de Bermúdez.

title: Tristan da Cunha
event: The Portuguese mariner Tristão da Cunha sights the islands of Tristan da Cunha, naming the larger one with his own name.

title: China
event: In Ming Dynasty China, the local costs of the courier system are met by a tax in silver assessed by the property of land instead of by corvée labor service.

title: Lisbon
event: Duarte Barbosa returns to Lisbon.

title: Vatican City
event: January 22 – The Swiss Guard arrives at the Vatican, to serve as permanent ceremonial and palace guards under Pope Julius II.

title: St. Peter's Basilica
event: April 18 – Pope Julius II lays the foundation stone of the new (current) St. Peter's Basilica, replacing the Old Saint Peter's Basilica.

title: Battle of Kletsk
event: August 6 – The Grand Duchy of Lithuania defeated the Crimean Khanate in the Battle of Kletsk

title: Crown of Castile
event: Cardinal Cisneros is appointed major inquisitor of Castile.

title: Lamu
event: The Portuguese occupy Mozambique and the islands of Socotra and Lamu.

title: Viana Spain
event: March 12 – At the siege of a castle in Viana, Spain, Cesare Borgia is killed by an unknown soldier by being thrown off the castle wall.

title: Americas
event: April 25 – Martin Waldseemüller publishes his world map, naming the new continent America in honour of Amerigo Vespucci (However, the accuracy of this is still debated).

title: Sistine Chapel
event: December – Michelangelo Buonarroti begins work on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel.

title: Royal Grammar School Guildford
event: Royal Grammar School, Guildford, is founded by Robert Beckingham.

title: Queen Elizabeth's Grammar School Blackburn
event: Queen Elizabeth's Grammar School, Blackburn, is founded as a grammar school for boys.

title: Portugal
event: February 2 – Battle of Diu: The Portuguese defeat a coalition of Indians, Muslims and Italians.

title: Romagna
event: April 27 – Pope Julius II places Venice under interdict and excommunication for refusing to cede part of Romagna to papal control.

title: University of Oxford
event: June 19 – Brasenose College, University of Oxford, is founded by a lawyer, Sir Richard Sutton, of Prestbury, Cheshire, and the Bishop of Lincoln, William Smyth.

title: 1509 Istanbul earthquake
event: September 10 – Istanbul earthquake destroys 109 mosques and kills an estimated 10,000 people.

title: Hampton Court Palace
event: Paolo Cortese publishes ''De Cardinalatu'', a manual for cardinals, including advice on palatial architecture – which inspired Thomas Wolsey in his construction work at Hampton Court Palace.

title: Mary Rose
event: Construction of the ''Mary Rose'' is completed.

title: Portugal
event: February 27 – Afonso de Albuquerque of Portugal conquers Goa.

title: India
event: Duarte Barbosa arrives in India for the second time. He works as clerk in the factory of Cananor and as the liaison with the Indian rajah.

title: Newfoundland (island)
event: Juan de Agramonte, a sailor from Spain, is thought possibly to have travelled to Newfoundland.

title: St John's College Cambridge
event: April 9 – St John's College, Cambridge, England, founded by Lady Margaret Beaufort, receives its charter.

title: Portugal
event: August 24 – Afonso de Albuquerque of Portugal conquers Malacca, the capital of the Sultanate of Malacca. The Sultanate then establishes rule from Johor, starting decades of skirmishes against the Portuguese to regain the fallen city. While taking the city, the Portuguese slaughter a large community of Chinese merchants living there (mentioned by Zhang Xie writing a century later). Malacca is the first city in Southeast Asia to be taken by a Western nation, gaining home rule only in 1957 when it becomes part of Malaysia.

title: Ambon Island
event: António de Abreu discovered Timor island and reached Banda Islands, Ambon Island and Seram. Francisco Serrão reached the Moluccas.

title: Turks and Caicos Islands
event: Juan Ponce de León discovers the Turks and Caicos Islands.

title: Wallachia
event: Moldavia becomes a vassal of the Turkish Empire, on the same conditions as Wallachia: the voivode will be designated by the Turks, but will be of the Orthodox faith. Also, the Turks are not allowed to build mosques, to be buried, to own land or to settle in the country.

title: Wolverhampton Grammar School
event: Wolverhampton Grammar School is founded by Sir Stephen Jenyns.

title: Giggleswick School
event: Giggleswick School is founded by Rev James Carr.

title: Sistine Chapel
event: November 1 – The ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, painted by Michelangelo Buonarroti, is exhibited to the public for the first time.

title: Guam
event: Magellan is the first person recorded to set foot on the Micronesian Islands. He lands on Guam (located in the Mariana Islands) and meets the Chamorros there.

title: Denmark
event: January 20 – Christian II becomes King of Denmark and Norway.

title: Florida
event: March 27 – Juan Ponce de Leon becomes the first European definitely known to sight what is now the territory of the United States (specifically Florida), mistaking it for another island.

title: Guangzhou
event: May – Portuguese explorer Jorge Álvares lands on Lintin Island in the Pearl River estuary. This is followed up by Rafael Perestrello, a cousin of Christopher Columbus, who commands an expedition from Portuguese Malacca in 1516 to land on the shores of mainland southern China, in order to trade with Chinese merchants at Guangzhou.

title: France
event: August 16 – Battle of the Spurs (or Battle of Guinegate):  English troops under Henry VIII defeat a French army under Marshal La Palice.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: September 25 – Vasco Núñez de Balboa, silent upon a peak in Darién, first sees what will become known as the Pacific Ocean.

title: France
event: July – Peace is declared between England and France.

title: Battle of Chaldiran
event: August 23 – Battle of Chaldiran: Selim I crushes the Persian army of Shah Ismail I.

title: Havana
event: Conquistador Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar founds Havana, Cuba.

title: Switzerland
event: September 13 – September 14 – Battle of Marignano: The army of Francis I of France defeats the Swiss, thanks to the timely arrival of a Venetian army.  Francis restores French control of Milan.

title: Río de la Plata
event: Pedro de Solis discovers the Río de la Plata.

title: France
event: Leonardo da Vinci accepts Francis I's invitation to France.

title: Guangzhou
event: The Italian explorer Rafael Perestrello trades with Chinese merchants at Canton during the Ming Dynasty.

title: Guangzhou
