event: Organized western merchants make their first contact with China after Rafael Perestrello was the first to land in southern China in 1513; European merchants venture into port at Guangzhou and trade with Chinese merchants there.

title: Oxford
event: A third outbreak of the sweating sickness in England hits Oxford and Cambridge.

title: Ommen
event: The Dutch city of Ommen is devastated by fire.

title: Cairo
event: February 3 – Cairo is captured by the Ottoman Empire; the Mamluk Sultanate falls.

title: China
event: August 15 – Portuguese merchant Fernao Pires de Andrade meets Ming Dynasty Chinese officials through an interpreter at the Pearl River estuary and lands at what is now in the jurisdiction of Hong Kong. Although the first European trade expeditions to China took place in 1513 and 1516 by Jorge Álvares and Rafael Perestrello, respectively, Andrade's mission is the first official diplomatic mission of a European power to China commissioned by a ruler of Europe—Manuel I of Portugal.

title: Hispaniola
event: A plague of tropical fire ants devastates crops on Hispaniola.

title: Barbados
event: The Spanish find Barbados.

title: Anatolia
event: The first civil revolt in Anatolia takes place, led by Alevi preacher Celâl.

title: Havana
event: Havana moves from the southern to the northern part of Cuba.

title: Estonia
event: The St. Olav Church is completed in Tallinn, Estonia.

title: China
event: According to Wang Yangming (1472–1529), the Ming Dynasty philosopher and governor of Jiangxi, China, he intends to use ''fo–lang–ji'' cannons in suppressing the rebellion of Prince Zhu Chenhao in this year. This is most likely the earliest reference in China to the breech-loading Frankish culverin.

title: Veracruz Veracruz
event: April 21 – Hernán Cortés lands in Veracruz, Veracruz

title: Panama City
event: August 15 – Panama City is founded.

title: Cholula (Mesoamerican site)
event: October 12 – Hernán Cortés and his men, accompanied by 3,000 Tlaxcalans, entered Cholula.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: November 8 – Hernán Cortés enters Tenochtitlan and the court of Aztec ruler Moctezuma.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: June – Moctezuma II, Aztec ruler of Tenochtitlan, is declared deposed due to his captivity by conquistador Hernán Cortés. His brother Cuitláhuac rises to the throne.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: July 1 – La Noche Triste (Night of Sorrow): The forces of Cuitláhuac, Aztec ruler of Tenochtitlan, gain a major victory against the forces of conquistador Hernán Cortés. This results in the death of about 400 conquistadors and some 2,000 of their Native American allies. However, Cortés and the most skilled of his men manage to escape and later regroup.

title: Tenochtitlan
event: October – Cuitláhuac, Aztec ruler of Tenochtitlan, dies from smallpox. He is succeeded by his nephew Cuauhtémoc.

title: Denmark
event: November 8 – Stockholm Bloodbath: A successful invasion of Sweden by Danish forces under the command of Christian II of Denmark results in the execution of around 100 persons (mostly nobility and clergy involved in the previous Swedish war effort).

title: Strait of Magellan
event: November 28 – After navigating through the South American strait, three ships under the command of Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan reach the Pacific Ocean, becoming the first Europeans to sail from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific (the strait was later named the Strait of Magellan).

title: Guam
event: March 6 – Ferdinand Magellan discovers Guam.

title: Philippines
event: March 16 – Ferdinand Magellan reaches the Philippines.

title: Cebu Island
event: April 7 – Ferdinand Magellan arrives at Cebu.

title: Crown of Castile
event: April 24 – Revolt of the Comuneros – Battle of Villalar: Castilian royalists defeat the rebels and execute their three leaders.

title: Philippines
event: April 27 – Magellan is killed in the Philippines.

title: France
event: May – War breaks out between Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor and Francis I, the King of France.

title: France
event: May 20 – Battle of Pampeluna: The French defeat the Spanish.

title: Wallachia
event: June 29 or June 30 – The first document is fully written in Romanian: the letter of Neacşu, a trader from Câmpulung, to Johannes Benkner, the mayor of Braşov, warning that the Ottoman Empire is preparing its troops to cross into Wallachia and Transylvania; the script used is Romanian Cyrillic.

title: France
event: June 30 – Battle of Esquiroz: French forces under Henri d'Albret, exiled King of Navarre, are defeated by the Spanish and forced to abandon their attempt to recover Henri's kingdom.

title: France
event: November 23 – Spanish–German–Papal forces under Prosper Colonna force French Marshal Odet de Lautrec to abandon Milan.

title: Beijing
event: Chinese Ming Dynasty records indicate that the War Ministry official He Ru is the first to acquire the Portuguese breech-loading culverin, while copies of them are made by two Westernized Chinese at Beijing, Yang San (Pedro Yang) and Dai Ming.

title: Australia
event: Some believe that Australia was sighted by a Portuguese expedition led by Cristóvão de Mendonça. They mapped the continent and named it Jave la Grande, meaning The Greater Java.

title: Battle of Bicocca
event: April 27 – Battle of Bicocca: French and Swiss forces under Odet de Lautrec are defeated by the Spanish in their attempt to retake Milan, and are forced to withdraw into Venetian territory.

title: Rhodes
event: July 28 – Ottoman Sultan Suleiman I begins his siege of the Knights of St. John in Rhodes.

title: Rhodes
event: December 18 – The Turks finally break into Rhodes, but the Knights continue fierce resistance in the streets.

title: Malta
event: December 20 – Suleiman the Magnificent accepts the surrender of the surviving Knights, who are allowed to evacuate.  They eventually re-settle on Malta and become known as the Knights of Malta.

title: Portugal
event: The Ming Dynasty Chinese navy captures two Western ships with Portuguese breech–loading culverins aboard, which the Chinese call a fo–lang–ji (Frankish culverin). According to the ''Ming Shi'', these cannons are soon presented to the Jiajing Emperor by Wang Hong, and their design is copied in 1529.

title: Brussels
event: The first Flemish Lutherans are burned in Brussels.

title: Denmark
event: June 6 – Gustav Vasa is elected king of Sweden, finally establishing its full independence from Denmark, marking the end of the Kalmar Union.

title: New York City
event: Giovanni da Verrazzano is the first European to sight the island of Manhattan, the future New York City.

title: K'iche' Kingdom of Q'umarkaj
event: Quiché, the capital of the K'iche' Maya Kingdom, falls to the Spanish Conquistadores.

title: K'iche' Kingdom of Q'umarkaj
event: March – Spanish conquistador Pedro de Alvarado destroys the K'iche' Kingdom of Q'umarkaj

title: Cape Fear (headland)
event: March 1 – Giovanni da Verrazzano lands near Cape Fear (approx. date).

title: Acajutla
event: June 8 – Spanish conquistador Pedro de Alvarado leads the Battle of Acajutla, defeating a battalion of Pipiles, in the neighborhoods of present day Acajutla, El Salvador

title: Granada Nicaragua
event: December 8 – Francisco Hernandez de Cordoba founds the city of Granada, Nicaragua, the oldest Hispanic city in the mainland of the Western Hemisphere.

title: France
event: The Bubonic Plague spreads in southern France.

title: Istanbul
event: The first French ambassador arrives in Istanbul.

title: France
event: February 24 – Battle of Pavia: Spanish forces under Charles de Lannoy and the Marquis of Pescara defeat the French army and capture Francis I of France, after his horse is wounded by Cesare Hercolani.

title: Cape Fear (headland)
event: March 1 (approx. date) – Giovanni da Verrazzano lands near Cape Fear.

title: Battle of Frankenhausen
event: May 15 – German Peasants' War – Battle of Frankenhausen: The rebellious peasants of the Holy Roman Empire are defeated by the Lords, ending the war.

title: Delhi
event: April 21 – First battle of Panipat:  Babur becomes Moghul (or Mughal) emperor , and invades northern India and captures Delhi, beginning the Mughal Empire, which lasts until 1857.

title: Buda
event: August 29 – Battle of Mohács:  The Turkish army of Sultan Suleiman I defeats the Hungarian army of King Louis II, who is killed in the retreat.  Suleiman takes Buda, while Archduke Ferdinand of Austria and John Zapolya, Prince of Transylvania, dispute over the succession.  As a result of the battle, Dubrovnik achieves independence, although it acknowledges Turkish overlordship.

title: Guatemala City
event: The Spanish conquest of Guatemala highlands is completed; the first Guatemala City (Ciudad Vieja) is founded.

title: United Kingdom
event: Bishop Vesey's Grammar School in Sutton Coldfield, West Midlands, UK is founded by Bishop John Vesey.

title: China
event: The Ming Dynasty government of China greatly reduces the quotas for taking grain, severely diminishing the state's capacity to relieve famines through a previously successful granary system.

title: Limmat
event: January 5 – Felix Manz, co-founder of the Swiss Anabaptists, is drowned in the Limmat in Zürich by the Zürich Reformed state church.

title: India
event: March 17 – Battle of Khanwa: This and two other major Moghul victories lead to the domination of northern India.

title: Florida
event: June 17 – The Narváez expedition to conquer Florida set sail from Spain.

title: Newfoundland and Labrador
event: August 3 – The first known letter is sent from North America by John Rut while at St. John's, Newfoundland.

title: Martyrs' Synod
event: August 20 – Sixty Anabaptists meet at the Martyrs' Synod.

title: Denmark
event: August 20 – Diet of Odense (Denmark). King Frederick I declares religious tolerance for Lutherans, permits marriage of priests, forbids seeking papal ''pallium'' (approval) for royal appointments of Church officials..

title: Windsor Castle
event: St George's Chapel in Windsor Castle is completed.

title: France
event: Chateau Fontainebleau in France is begun.

title: China
event: In Henan province of China, during the mid Ming Dynasty, a vast drought deprives the region of harvests for the next two years, killing off half the people in some communities due to starvation and cannibalism, as reported by local gazeteers.

title: Dalarna
event: February – Peasant uprising in Dalarna, Sweden: rebel campaign fails and rebel leader, later known as ''Daljunkern'', flees to Rostock.

title: Italy
event: June 19 – Battle of Landriano: A French army in Italy under Marshal St. Pol is decisively defeated.

title: Texas
event: November 6 – Spanish conquistador Álvar Núñez Cabeza de Vaca and his companions become the first known Europeans to set foot on the shores of what is present-day Texas.

title: Aylesbury
event: Aylesbury is granted the county town of Buckinghamshire in England by King Henry VIII.

title: Portugal
event: April 22 – The Treaty of Saragossa divides the eastern hemisphere between Spain and Portugal, stipulating that the dividing line should lie 297.5 leagues or 17° east of the Moluccas.

title: Constantinople
event: May 10 – The Turkish army under Suleiman I leaves Constantinople to once again invade Hungary.

title: Italy
event: August 5 – Emperor Charles V and Francis I of France sign the Treaty of Cambrai, or the Ladies' Peace. Francis abandons his claims in Italy, but is allowed to retain Burgundy.

title: Buda
event: Buda is recaptured by the invading Turkish forces.

title: Vienna
event: September 23 – Vienna is besieged by the Turkish forces of Suleiman.

title: Malta
event: The Knights of Malta are formed when the Knights Hospitaller are given Malta by Pope Clement VIII.

title: São Vicente São Paulo
event: Martin Afonso de Souza's expedition patrols the Brazilian coast, banishes the French, and creates the first colonial towns: São Vicente and São Paulo.

title: Buda
event: Austrian forces capture Esztergom, Hungary, and raid as far as Buda.

title: Chichen Itza
event: Conquistador Francisco de Montejo claims Chichen Itza as capital of Spanish ruled Yucatán.

title: China
event: An enormous drought in Henan province of China during the Ming Dynasty is coupled with the disaster of a gigantic swarm of locusts in the summer, forcing many in destitute agricultural communities to turn to cannibalism instead of dying off by starvation.

title: Portugal
event: January 26 – Lisbon, Portugal is hit by an earthquake in which thousands die.

title: Puebla Puebla
event: April 16 – The city of Puebla, Mexico is founded.

title: San Juan del Río
event: June 24 – The city of San Juan del Río, Mexico is founded.

title: Our Lady of Guadalupe
event: December 12 – The Virgin Mary, in the guise of Our Lady of Guadalupe, appears to Juan Diego Cuauhtlatoatzin, an Aztec convert to Catholicism.

title: Pechenga Monastery
event: Pechenga Monastery is founded in the Far North of Russia.

title: Cusco
event: November 15 – Francisco Pizarro arrives in Cuzco, Peru.

title: Cambridge University Press
event: Cambridge University Press is given a Royal Charter by Henry VIII and becomes the first of the privileged presses.

title: Northwest Passage
event: May 10 – Jacques Cartier explores Newfoundland while searching for the Northwest Passage.

title: Malmö
event: June 23 – Copenhagen opens its gates to Count Christopher of Oldenburg leading the army of Lübeck (and the Hanseatic League), nominally in the interests of the deposed King Christian II of Denmark. The surrenders of Copenhagen and, a few days later, of Malmö represent the high point of the Count's War for the forces of the League. These victories presumably led the Danish nobility to recognize Christian III as King on July 4.

title: Old Rye
event: July 4 – Christian III is elected King of Denmark and Norway in the town of Rye.

title: New Brunswick
event: July 7 – The first known exchange occurs between Europeans and natives of the Gulf of St. Lawrence, in New Brunswick.

title: France
event: October 18 – Huguenots post placards all over France attacking the Catholic Mass, provoking a violent sectarian reaction.

title: Denmark
event: Combined Swedish and Danish fleets defeat the Hanseatic navy.

title: Lima
event: January 18 – Lima, Peru is founded by Francisco Pizarro.

title: Quebec
event: April{{Factdate=December 2007}} – Jacques Cartier lands near the Iroquois city of Stadacona, Canada (now Quebec) and in May{{Factdate=December 2007}}, the even greater Huron city of Hochelaga.

title: North America
event: May 19 – French explorer Jacques Cartier sets sail for his second voyage to North America with 3 ships, 110 men, and Chief Donnacona's 2 sons  (who Cartier took during his first voyage).

title: Basingwerk Abbey
event: Basingwerk Abbey,

title: Bourne Abbey
event: Bourne Abbey

title: Dore Abbey
event: Dore Abbey

title: Buildwas Abbey
event: The Cistercian Abbey of St Mary and St Chad

title: Haltemprice Priory
event: Haltemprice Priory

title: Tintern Abbey
event: Tintern Abbey

title: Denmark
event: Reformation in Denmark: Protestantism is introduced in Denmark and Norway by King Christian III.

title: Brazil
event: The Portuguese crown divides Brazil into fifteen donatory captaincies.

title: Argentina
event: February 2 – Spaniard Pedro de Mendoza founds Buenos Aires, Argentina.

title: Portugal
event: April 30 – The Inquisition is implemented in Portugal.

title: Machu Picchu
event: May – Manco Inca Yupanqui leads a revolt against the Spanish, and then leads his people to Machu Picchu, deep in the Valcahambra range of the Andes.

title: Paros
event: The island of Paros is conquered by the Ottoman Empire

title: Denmark
event: Christian III forces introduction of Lutheran Protestantism in Denmark and Norway.

title: Bisham Abbey
event: Bisham Priory,

title: Bridlington Priory
event: Bridlington Priory,

title: Valle Crucis Abbey
event: Valle Crucis Abbey.

title: Bisham Abbey
event: Bisham Abbey is founded by Henry VIII in place of Bisham Priory.

title: Bangalore
event: Bangalore is first mentioned.

title: Brazil
event: March 12 – Recife is founded by the Portuguese in Brazil.

title: Asunción
event: August 15 Asunción it`s founded by Juan de Salazar y Espinoza. It's the oldest city in South America

title: Capitoline Hill
event: Michelangelo starts work on the ''Piazza del Campidoglio'' (Capitoline Hill).

title: Bisham Abbey
event: Bisham Abbey is dissolved.

title: China
event: The first in a decade-long series of severe famines and epidemics sweep central and southeastern China during the Ming Dynasty, made worse by a previous decision in 1527 to cut back on the intake of grain quotas for granaries.

title: Zhejiang
event: During the Ming Dynasty of China, a tsunami floods over the seawall in Haiyan County of Zhejiang province, inundating the agricultural crop fields with saltwater and ruining many acres of crops. This drives up the price of foodstuffs and many are forced to live off of tree bark and weeds (as one Wang Wenlu stated in his writing of 1545).

title: Bogotá
event: August 6 – Bogotá, Colombia is founded by Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada.

title: Byland Abbey
event: Byland Abbey is dissolved.

title: Burma
event: January – Battle of Naungyo, Burma

title: St Mary's Abbey York
event: Beaulieu Abbey, Bolton Abbey, Colchester Abbey, St Albans Abbey, the Priory of St Mary, Nottinghamshire, (Newstead Abbey) and St Mary's Abbey, York, fall prey to the Dissolution of the Monasteries.

title: China
event: In Henan province, China, a severe drought with swarms of locusts is made worse by a major epidemic outbreak of the plague.

title: France
event: King Francis I of France issues an ordinance that places the whole of France under the jurisdiction of the royal law courts and makes French the language of those courts.

title: Kingdom of England
event: January 12 – Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor (and Charles I of Spain) and Francis I of France sign the Treaty of Toledo, agreeing to make no further alliances with England. The treaty comes after Henry VIII of England splits with Rome and Pope Paul III.

title: North America
event: May 30 – In Florida, Hernando de Soto lands at Tampa Bay with 600 soldiers with the goal to find gold. He also introduces pigs into North America.

title: Dunstable Priory
event: January – Dunstable Priory falls prey to the Dissolution of the Monasteries.

title: Waltham Abbey (abbey)
event: Waltham Abbey is the final priory to fall prey to Henry VIII's Dissolution of the Monasteries.

title: Society of Jesus
event: September 27 – The Society of Jesus (Jesuits) is approved by Pope Paul III, in his bull ''Regimini militantis Ecclesiae''.

title: Golden Gate (Jerusalem)
event: Ottoman Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent seals off The Golden Gate in Jerusalem.

title: Lordship of Ireland
event: The Parliament of Ireland declares Henry VIII of England King of Ireland, replacing the Lordship of Ireland with the Kingdom of Ireland.

title: Lake Tana
event: The Portuguese defeat the Muslims near Lake Tana.

title: Portugal
event: April 7 – Francis Xavier leaves Lisbon on a mission to the Portuguese East Indies.

title: France
event: May 23 – Jacques Cartier departs from Saint-Malo, France on his third voyage.

title: Massawa
event: July 9 – Estevão da Gama departs Massawa, leaving behind 400 matchlock men and 150 slaves under his brother Christovão da Gama, with orders to assist the Emperor of Ethiopia to defeat Ahmad ibn Ibrihim al-Ghazi, who has invaded his Empire.

title: Buda
event: August 29 – The Janissaries of Suleiman the Magnificent take Buda by ruse, hiding themselves as visitors.

title: China
event: The first contact of Japan with the West occurs when a Portuguese ship, blown off its course to China, lands Fernão Mendes Pinto, Diogo Zeimoto and Cristovão Borralho in Japan

title: Battle of Haddon Rig
event: August 24 – Battle of Haddon Rig: Scotland defeats England.

title: Soßmar
event: August 27 – Advice and citizenry of Hildesheim (Germany) profess themselves to the Lutheran teachings. As a pledge owner, the city Hildesheim provides for the execution of the Reformation in the city and office of Peine. The priests from the localities of Clauen, Hohenhameln, Sossmar, Schmedenstedt, Lengede and Rosenthal {{dn}} resume their offices in the sense of the Reformation.

title: San Diego Bay
event: September 28 – Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo lands in what is now San Diego Bay and named it San Miguel, which will later become San Diego.

title: Battle of Solway Moss
event: November 24 – Battle of Solway Moss: An English army invades Scotland and defeats a Scottish army.

title: Portugal
event: The Japanese receive the first firearms from shipwrecked Portuguese.

title: France
event: August 5 – Turkish and French troops under Hayreddin Barbarossa occupy Nice.

title: France
event: September–October – Landrecies in Picardy is besieged by forces under Emperor Charles V, but withdraw on the approach of the French army.

title: Italy
event: Italian botanist Luca Ghini publishes the first herbarium.

title: University of Königsberg
event: The University of Königsberg is founded.

title: North America
event: Rats make their first appearance in North America.

title: France
event: Gustav I of Sweden signs an alliance with France.

title: Battle of the Shirts
event: Battle of the Shirts: The Frasers and Macdonalds of Clan Ranald fight over a disputed chiefship; reportedly, 5 Frasers and 8 Macdonalds survive.

title: Taiwan
event: Portuguese explorers encounter the island of Taiwan and call it ''Ilha Formosa'' (Beautiful Island).

title: Battle of Ceresole
event: April 11 – Battle of Ceresole: French forces under the Comte d'Enghien defeat Imperial forces under the Marques Del Vasto near Turin.

title: France
event: May – Emperor Charles V again invades eastern France.

title: China
event: During the Ming Dynasty, a large failure of the harvest in Henan province, China occurs due to excessive rainfall, which drives up the price of wheat and forces many to flee their rural counties; those who stay behind are forced to survive by eating leaves, bark, and human flesh.

title: Bolivia
event: Silver is discovered at Potosí, Bolivia.

title: Battle of Ancrum Moor
event: February 27 – Battle of Ancrum Moor: The Scots are victorious over superior English forces.

title: New Guinea
event: June 13 – Spanish explorer Yñigo Ortiz de Retez sets out to navigate the northern coast of New Guinea.

title: Mary Rose
event: July 18 – Battle of the Solent: The fleets of England and France battle to a draw. The ''Mary Rose'' sinks during the naval engagement.

title: Trinity College Cambridge
event: Trinity College, Cambridge and Christ Church, Oxford are founded by Henry VIII of England.

title: St. Peter's Basilica
event: Michelangelo Buonarroti is made chief architect of St. Peter's Basilica.

title: East Anglia
event: Rebellions in East Anglia break out against the Reformation.

title: France
event: June 7 – Treaty of Ardres, also known as the Treaty of Camp, is signed, resulting in peace between England and France.

title: Canterbury
event: Huguenots increasingly immigrate to Kent, especially Canterbury.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: February 20 – Edward VI of England is crowned at Westminster Abbey.

title: Portugal
event: The Ming Dynasty government of China issues a decree banning all foreign trade and closes down all seaports along the coast; these Hai jin laws came during the Wokou wars with Japanese pirates, while the Portuguese began regular trade missions to China in 1449, and the ban on maritime trade was fully lifted in 1567.

title: France
event: July 7 – A marriage treaty is signed between Scotland and France, whereby 5-year-old Mary, Queen of Scots, is betrothed to the future King Francis II of France.

title: East Anglia
event: July – Agricultural workers stage Kett's Rebellion in East Anglia.

title: Macau
event: Although trade existed between the two beforehand, in this year the Portuguese begins to send regular seasonal maritime trade missions to Ming Dynasty China at Sao João Island (also known as Shangchuan Island) near Macau.

title: Brazil
event: March 29 – The city of Salvador da Bahia, Brazil's first capital, is founded.

title: Finland
event: Helsinki, the capital of Finland, is founded by Gustav Vasa.

title: Bolivia
event: The discovery of silver at Zacatecas and Guanajuato in Mexico, and Potosí in Bolivia, stimulates silver rushes (approximate date).

title: Society of Jesus
event: July 21 – The Society of Jesus (Jesuits) is definitely approved by Pope Julius III.

title: Gozo
event: July – Ottomans and Barbary pirates invade the Mediterranean Island of Gozo, enslaving all inhabitants (est. at 5,000 to 6,000), and transporting them to Tarhuna Wa Msalata.

title: Vardzia
event: Persian forces raid and destroy the cave monastery of Vardzia in Georgia (country).

title: Tripoli
event: The Ottomans capture Tripoli.

title: China
event: In Henan province, China, during the Ming Dynasty, a severe frost in the spring destroys the winter wheat crop. Torrential rains in mid summer cause massive flooding of farmland and villages (by some accounts submerged in a meter of water). In the fall a large tornado demolishes houses and flattens much of the buckwheat in the fields. Famine victims either flee, starve, or resort to cannibalism. This follows a series of natural disasters in Henan in the years 1528, 1531, 1539, and 1545.

title: Burma
event: January 11 – Ketumati, Burma is conquered by Bayinnaung.

title: Americas
event: May 12 – The National University of San Marcos is founded in Lima (Peru), being the first officially established university in the Americas.

title: Americas
event: September 21 – The Royal and Pontifical University of Mexico is founded in Mexico City (Mexico), being the second officially established university in the Americas.

title: Drégely Castle
event: July – In Hungary, Drégely Castle is attacked by the Turks.

title: Portugal
event: In the Persian Gulf, the Ottoman Empire Red Sea Fleet attacks the Portuguese stronghold of Hormuz but fails to capture it.

title: Italy
event: In Italy, Bartolomeo Eustachi makes important discoveries on the structure of the ear and heart.

title: Treaty of Chambord
event: January 15 – Henry II of France and Maurice of Saxony sign the Treaty of Chambord.

title: La Imperial Chile
event: April 16 – The city of La Imperial was founded by Pedro de Valdivia.

title: Peace of Passau
event: The Peace of Passau revokes the Augsburg Interim of 1548 and promises religious freedom to the Protestant princes.

title: Tonbridge School
event: Tonbridge School founded by Sir Andrew Judde under the letters patent of Edward VI of England.

title: White Sea
event: Russia: The maritime way of the White Sea is opened by the English explorer Richard Chancellor, beginning the trade with England.

title: Shanghai
event: Shanghai is fortified for the first time.

title: Beijing
event: In the Ming Dynasty of China, the addition of a new section of the Outer City is completed in southern Beijing, bringing the overall size of Beijing to 4 by 4½ miles.

title: Battle of Sievershausen
event: July 9 – Battle of Sievershausen: Prince-elector Maurice of Saxony defeats the Catholic forces of Margrave Albert of Brandenburg-Kulmbach. Maurice is mortally wounded.

title: London
event: August 3 – Queen Mary I of England arrives in London.

title: Eindhoven
event: January 5 – A great fire breaks out in Eindhoven, Netherlands.

title: Brazil
event: January 25 – São Paulo, Brazil is founded.

title: London
event: February – Thomas Wyatt surrenders to government forces in London.

title: Tower of London
event: March 17 – Princess Elizabeth is imprisoned in The Tower.

title: Derby
event: May 21 – A Royal Charter is granted to Derby School at Derby, England.

title: France
event: August 2 – Battle of Marciano: Senese–French forces are defeated by the Florentine–Imperial army.

title: Finland
event: Russia breaks a 60-year-old truce with Sweden by attacking Finland.

title: Gresham's School
event: Gresham's School is founded by Sir John Gresham

title: Panipat
event: Bairam Khan defeats Hindu forces at Panipat.

title: Ireland
event: William Annyas becomes the Mayor of Youghal, Ireland, the first Jew to hold such a position in Ireland or Britain.

title: Ireland
event: Mary I of England establishes the Fort of Maryborough, in what is now Portlaoise, County Laois, Ireland.

title: France
event: The kings of Spain take control of the Flanders region, including what is now the French département of Nord.

title: France
event: The false Martin Guerre appears in the French village of Artigat.

title: Finland
event: King John III of Sweden becomes ruler of Finland as Hertig Johan.

title: China
event: January 23 –  The Shaanxi Earthquake, the deadliest earthquake in history, occurs with its epicenter in Shaanxi province, China:  830,000 people may have been killed.

title: France
event: Truce of Vaucelles: Fighting temporarily ends between France and Spain.

title: Oxford
event: March 21 – In Oxford, Archbishop of Canterbury Thomas Cranmer is burned at the stake  for treason.

title: India
event: November 5 – Second Battle of Panipat: Fifty miles north of Delhi, a Mogul Army defeats Hindu forces of General Hemu, to ensure Akbar the throne of India.

title: Massawa
event: Özdemir Pasha conquers the Red Sea port of Massawa for the Ottoman Empire.

title: Macau
event: With the permission of the Ming Dynasty government of China and the benefit of both Western and Eastern merchants, the Portuguese settle in Macau, which was retroceded in 1999. Direct Sino-Portuguese trade had existed since 1513, but this is the first official legal treaty port on traditional Chinese soil that will be a long term Western settlement.  Soon after, China legalizes foreign trade, and Chinese began to migrate overseas.

title: Kingdom of England
event: January 7 – French troops led by Francis, Duke of Guise take Calais, the last continental possession of the Kingdom of England

title: University of Jena
event: February 2 – The University of Jena is founded in Thuringia, Germany.

title: France
event: July 13 – Battle of Gravelines: In France, Spanish forces led by Count Lamoral of Egmont defeat the French forces of Marshal Paul des Thermes at Gravelines.

title: Estonia
event: July 18 – The city of Tartu, capital of the Bishopric of Dorpat, now in Estonia, surrenders to Russia.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: January 15 – Elizabeth I of England is crowned in Westminster Abbey.

title: Harar
event: March 23 – Emperor Gelawdewos of Ethiopia, defending his lands against the invasion of Nur ibn Mujahid, Sultan of Harar, is killed in battle. His brother Menas succeeds him as king.

title: St. Augustine Florida
event: August 15 – Led by Don Tristán de Luna y Arellano, a Spanish missionary colony of 1,500 men, on 13 ships, arrives from Vera Cruz at Pensacola Bay, founding the oldest European settlement in the mainland U.S. (St. Augustine is founded in 1565.)

title: Pensacola Florida
event: September 19 – Just weeks after arrival at Pensacola, the Spanish missionary colony is decimated by a hurricane that kills hundreds, sinks five ships, with a galleon, and grounds a caravel; the 1,000 survivors divide to relocate/resupply the settlement, but suffer famine & attacks, and abandon the effort in 1561.

title: Kuala Lumpur
event: December – Kuala Lumpur becomes the capital of Malaya.

title: West Midlands (county)
event: Solihull School is founded in Solihull, West Midlands.

title: Italy
event: The oldest surviving violin (dated inside), known as the ''Charles IX'', is made in Cremona, in northern Italy.

title: Caribbean
event: The great age of piracy in the Caribbean starts around this time.

title: Qinghai
event: Mongols invade and occupy Qinghai.

title: Kingdom of England
event: February 27 – The Treaty of Berwick, which expels the French from the Kingdom of Scotland, is signed by the Kingdom of England and the Congregation of Scotland.

title: Djerba
event: March 7 – A Spanish-led expedition, commanded by Juan de la Cerda, 4th Duke of Medinaceli, overruns the Tunisian island of Djerba.

title: Saaremaa
event: April 15 – Denmark buys the Estonian island of Saaremaa from its last prince bishop.

title: Kingston Grammar School
event: Kingston Grammar School is founded.

title: Flanders
event: The first Calvinists settle in England after fleeing Flanders.

title: Madrid
event: Madrid is declared the capital of Spain by Philip II.

title: Estonia
event: Sweden conquers Livonia (modern Estonia).

title: Santa Maria degli Angeli e dei Martiri
event: Michelangelo Buonarroti finishes ''Santa Maria degli Angeli e dei Martiri'' in Rome.

title: Saint Basil's Cathedral
event: Saint Basil's Cathedral in Moscow (started in 1534) is finished.

title: Pensacola Florida
event: Pensacola, the first European settlement in North America, and its support fleet are both destroyed by a hurricane. Two survivors manage to walk the long, arduous journey to Mexico City. The city is not re-settled until 1698.

title: London
event: June 4 – St. Paul's Cathedral in London is badly damaged by fire and the spire is destroyed after being struck by lightning.

title: France
event: August 19 – Mary, Queen of Scots, is denied passage through England after returning from France. She arrives at Leith, Scotland on August 19.

title: Guinea
event: The earliest English slave-trading expedition (under John Hawkins) goes between Guinea and the West Indies. As a result, the Spanish banned English ships from trading at their new world ports.

title: South Carolina
event: French Huguenots establish a colony of Charlesfort on Parris Island, off the coast of South Carolina.

title: Gresham's School
event: Gresham's School is granted a Royal Charter.

title: Malwa
event: Akbar the Great conquers Malwa and defeats Baz Bahadur.

title: France
event: March 1 – Over 1,000 Huguenots are massacred by the ultra-Catholic Francis, Duke of Guise in Wassy-sur-Blaise, marking the start of the First War of Religion in France.  Protestant forces led by Louis I de Bourbon, Prince de Condé and Gaspard de Coligny quickly seize control of Orleans, Rouen, and other cities throughout France.

title: Florida
event: May 1 – Jean Ribault, French navigator, lands in Florida and later establishes a Huguenot colony at Charlesfort.

title: Ireland
event: May 26 – Earl of Tyrone leads a second rebellion in Ireland.

title: Malta
event: The Ottoman Turks invade Malta.

title: Philippines
event: The Spanish found a colony in the Philippines.

title: Manila
event: 1564 – 1571 – Miguel Lopez de Legazpi sails from Mexico and conquers the Philippine Islands, founding Manila.

title: Brazil
event: January 25 – The Portuguese found the city of São Paulo, Brazil.

title: Battle of Angol
event: March 25 – Lorenzo Bernal del Mercado defeated and killed the toqui Illangulién in the Battle of Angol, in Chile.

title: Florida
event: June 22 – French settlers abandon Charlesfort, the first French attempt at colonizing the New World, and establish Fort Caroline in Florida.

title: John Beddoes School
event: John Beddoes School is founded.

title: Vijayanagara Empire
event: January 26 – The Battle of Talikota, a watershed battle fought between the Vijayanagara Empire and the Deccan sultanates. The last Hindu kingdom in South India ended.

title: Philippines
event: February 13 – Spanish Conquistador Miguel López de Legazpi lands with his troops on the shores of Cebu Island in the Philippine archipelago.

title: Brazil
event: March 1 – The city of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, is founded.

title: Cebu City
event: April 27 – Cebu City (originally named San Miguel) is established by López de Legazpi, becoming the first Spanish settlement in the Philippines.

title: Malta
event: May 18 – Ottoman troops land on the island of Malta, beginning  The Great Siege of Malta.

title: St. Augustine Florida
event: August 28 – St. Augustine, Florida (named after St. Augustine), is established. It is the oldest remaining European settlement in the United States.

title: Florida
event: September 4 – The Spanish fleet of Pedro Menéndez de Avilés lands on modern-day Florida to oust the French under Jean Ribault. He later destroys the French colony of Fort Caroline.

title: St. Augustine Florida
event: September 8 – Pedro Menéndez de Avilés settles in St. Augustine, Florida.

title: Stari Most
event: The first bridge crossing the Neretva river at Mostar (in modern-day Bosnia and Herzegovina) is completed by the Ottoman Empire. The white marble bridge is now known as ''Stari Most'' (or Old Bridge).

title: Valletta
event: March 28 – The foundation stone of Valletta (Malta's Capital City) is laid by Grand Master Jean de la Valette.

title: China
event: Although sparse maritime trade existed since its founding, the Ming Dynasty government of China officially revokes the ''hai jin'' maritime trade ban, reinstating foreign trade with all countries except Japan.

title: North Carolina
event: January – A Spanish force under the command of Captain Juan Pardo establishes Fort San Juan in the Native American settlement of Joara.  The fort is the first European settlement in present day North Carolina.

title: India
event: Akbar the Great of the Mughal Empire besieges and captures the massive Chittorgarh Fort in northern India.

title: France
event: March 23 – The Peace of Longjumeau ends the Second War of Religion in France.  Again Catherine de' Medici and Charles IX make substantial concessions to the Huguenots.

title: Battle of Langside
event: May 13 –  Battle of Langside: The forces of Mary, Queen of Scots, are defeated by a confederacy of Scottish Protestants under James Stewart, Earl of Moray, her half-brother.

title: Battle of Heiligerlee
event: May 23 – Battle of Heiligerlee: Troops under Louis of Nassau, brother of William I of Orange, defeat a smaller loyalist force under the Duke of Arenberg in an attempt to invade the Northern Netherlands.  This is effectively the start of the Eighty Years' War.

title: Battle of Jemmingen
event: July 21 – Battle of Jemmingen: The main Spanish army of the Duke of Alva utterly defeats Louis of Nassau's invading army in the Northeastern Netherlands.

title: Battle of Jodoigne
event: October 20 – Battle of Jodoigne.  Spanish forces under the Duke of Alva destroy Orange's rearguard.  Orange abandons his offensive.

title: Great Britain
event: Whitechapel Bell Foundry known to be in existence in London. By the early 21st century it will be the oldest manufacturing company in Great Britain.

title: Concepción Chile
event: February 8 – A magnitude 8.3 earthquake occurs in Concepción, Chile.

title: London
event: Saint Olave's Grammar School is founded in Tooley Street, London.

title: Philippines
event: The Spanish occupy Manila, Philippines. Thus began the great silver flow that linked the New and Old Worlds.

title: Library of Parliament
event: The British House of Commons introduces the pro forma billLibrary of Parliamentdate=2010-01-28}}<.

title: London
event: January 23 – The Royal Exchange opens in London.

title: Vilcabamba Peru
event: Vilcabamba, the last independent remnant of the Inca Empire, is conquered by Spanish.

title: Italy
event: Geronimo Mercuriali from Forlì (Italy) writes the work ''De morbis cutaneis'' (On the diseases of the skin), well known as the first scientific tract about dermatology.

title: Capture of Brielle
event: April 1 – The Sea Beggars, Netherlandish Calvinist rebels, capture the port city of Brielle.  This leads to a wave of uprisings in Holland and Zealand, leaving most of those provinces (with the exception of Amsterdam), under rebel control.

title: Siege of Haarlem
event: December – The Duke of Alva, Spanish commander in the Netherlands, lays siege to Haarlem.

title: Alkmaar
event: August–October – Alva unsuccessfully besieges Alkmaar.

title: Lake Zway
event: Sarsa Dengel, emperor of Ethiopia, defeats the Oromo in a battle near Lake Zway.

title: Bolivia
event: The first Spanish galleon, laden with silver for the porcelain and silk trade with the Ming Dynasty of China, lands at Manila in the Philippines. This occasion marks the beginning of the Spanish silver trade to China that will trump that of the Portuguese, the latter of whom acted as an intermediary between the silver mines of Japan and the luxury items in China to be purchased with that silver. Most of the silver entering China comes from what is now Mexico, Bolivia, and Peru in the New World.

title: China
event: Wanli starts to rule in China.

title: Maldives
event: The Portuguese are expelled from the Maldives.

title: Çorum
event: Turkish New Hammam (Török Fürdö) built in Çorum Province.

title: Córdoba Argentina
event: July 6 – Córdoba, Argentina is founded by Jerónimo Luis de Cabrera.

title: Alkmaar
event: October 8 Spaniards abandon siege on the city of Alkmaar in North Holland

title: France
event: February 23 – The fifth War of Religion against the Huguenots begins in France.

title: France
event: May 30 – On the death of King Charles IX of France, he is succeeded by his brother King Henry of Poland, who becomes King Henry III of France. His mother, Catherine de' Medici, acts as Regent until Henry arrives from Poland.

title: Manila
event: June 10 – Manila gains cityhood.

title: Leiden
event: October 3 – The city of Leiden, besieged by the Spanish, is relieved by a Sea Beggar fleet under Louis Boisot.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: November 22 – The Juan Fernández Islands, in the South Pacific Ocean, are discovered by Spanish sailor Juan Fernández.

title: Paide
event: Russians occupy Pernau in Western Estonia and the fortress of Weissenstein.

title: Luanda
event: Portugal founds the city of Luanda, Angola.

title: China
event: Gaspar da Cruz, a Portuguese Dominican friar, writes about his travels to the Ming Dynasty of China; in this year he writes about the Chinese civil service handbook ''The Bureaucratic System of the Ming Dynasty'', and how the Chinese draw lots to determine which days of the year are most auspicious or most ill-fated to travel upon.

title: Raid of the Redeswire
event: July 7 – Raid of the Redeswire: Sir John Carmichael defeats Sir John Forster. Last Battle between England and Scotland.

title: 1575 Valdivia earthquake
event: December 16 – The 1575 Valdivia earthquake takes place.

title: France
event: The Sixth War of Religion begins in France.

title: Ostroh Academy
event: Konstanty Ostrogski founded Ostroh Academy – first university-like school in Eastern Europe.

title: Frobisher Bay
event: August 11 – English navigator Martin Frobisher, on his search for the Northwest Passage, enters the bay now named after him.

title: Atacama Desert
event: The church in San Pedro de Atacama is built in the Atacama Desert in Chile .

title: Zeeland
event: The Union of Brussels is formed, first without the Protestant counties of Holland and Zeeland (which is accepted by king Philip II of Spain), later with the Protestants, which means open rebellion of the whole of the Netherlands.

title: Strait of Magellan
event: Sir Francis Drake sails through the Strait of Magellan.

title: Newfoundland (island)
event: Martin Frobisher holds the first celebration of Thanksgiving by Europeans in North America at Newfoundland by the Frobisher Expedition.

title: Polotsk
event: Battle of Wenden: The Russians are defeated by the Swedes, who proceed to take Polotsk.

title: London
event: May 31 – Martin Frobisher sails from Harwich, England to Frobisher Bay, Canada, eventually to mine fool's gold, used to pave streets in London.

title: Portugal
event: August 4 – Battle of Al Kasr al Kebir: The Moors defeat the Portuguese. King Sebastian I of Portugal is defeated and killed in North Africa, leaving his elderly uncle, Cardinal Henry, as his heir. This initiates a succession crisis in Portugal.

title: Philippines
event: The municipality of Boac in Marinduque, Philippines is founded.

title: Dutch Republic
event: January 23 –  The Union of Utrecht unites the northern Netherlands in a confederation called the United Provinces. William I of Orange becomes ''Stadtholder'', and the Duc d'Anjou, younger brother of Henry III of France, is invited to become hereditary sovereign.

title: Maastricht
event: March – Maastricht is captured by the Spanish under Parma.

title: Newfoundland (island)
event: June 17 – Sir Francis Drake, during his circumnavigation of the world, lands in what is now California, which he claims for Queen Elizabeth I. With an English claim here and in Newfoundland, it becomes the basis for English colonial charters which will claim all land from the Atlantic to the Pacific, from sea to sea. Drake's claim is called Nova Albion (''New England''), and subsequent maps will show all lands north of New Spain and New Mexico under this name.

title: Karlovac
event: July 13 – Karlovac is founded.

title: Lublin
event: 1580–1764 – The first session of the Jewish ''Vaad'' (Council of Four Lands) is held  in Lublin, Poland; 70 delegates of Jewish local ''qahals'' meet to discuss taxation and other issues important to Jewish communities.

title: Portugal
event: 1580–1640 – Iberian Union – King Philip II of Spain becomes King of Portugal under the name Philip I, following the death without heirs of King Henry of Portugal, in a personal union of the crowns, thus maintaining Portuguese independence (in Europe and throughout the Portuguese Empire). The Portuguese House of Habsburg (also called the Philippine Dynasty) rule lasts until 1640.

title: Siberia
event: Yermak begins the Russian conquest of Siberia with a band of 1,636 men.

title: Buenos Aires
event: June 11 – Juan de Garay founds Buenos Aires.

title: China
event: The Chancellor of Ming Dynasty China, Chief Grand Secretary Zhang Juzheng, imposes the Single Whip Reform, by which taxes are assessed on properties recorded in the land census and paid in silver as the accepted medium of exchange.

title: Dutch Republic
event: Public worship for catholics in the Netherlands is officially forbidden.

title: China
event: In China, Jesuit Matteo Ricci is allowed to enter during the Ming Dynasty.

title: China
event: The earliest date of reference to the publishing of private newspapers in Beijing, during the Ming Dynasty of China.

title: Estonia
event: January 15 – Russia cedes Livonia and Southern-Estonia to Poland.

title: Argentina
event: April 16 – Spanish conquistador Hernando de Lerma founds the settlement of Salta, Argentina.

title: Portugal
event: October 4 of Julian calendar (Thursday) – Italy, Poland, Portugal, and Spain make the next day Friday, October 15 of the Gregorian Calendar, skipping over 10 days. Other countries follow at various later dates.

title: France
event: December 9 of Julian calendar (Sunday) – France makes the next day Monday, December 20 of the Gregorian Calendar.

title: France
event: July – Spanish admiral Santa Cruz defeats the Portuguese, French, and English off Terceira.

title: Osaka Castle
event: Toyotomi Hideyoshi commences construction of Osaka Castle in Japan.

title: University of Edinburgh
event: King James VI of Scotland signs a charter creating Tounis College (now the University of Edinburgh). For some unknown reason, the charter is dated a year earlier{{Citation neededdate=April 2009}}, as 1582.

title: Cuncolim
event: The first documented battle of India's independence against a European colonial ruler is fought by the ''Desai''s of Cuncolim in Goa, against the Portuguese.

title: Dyrehavsbakken
event: The world's oldest, intact, still-surviving amusement park, Dyrehavsbakken, is founded.

title: Newfoundland (island)
event: August 5 – Sir Humphrey Gilbert, in what is now the city of St John's, Newfoundland, claims the island of Newfoundland on behalf of England, marking the beginning of the British Empire.

title: Wallachia
event: August 19 – Petru Cercel enters Bucharest, and becomes Prince of Wallachia.

title: Emmanuel College Cambridge
event: Emmanuel College, Cambridge was founded by Sir Walter Mildmay.

title: North America
event: An expedition led by Phillip Amadas and Arthur Barlowe explores the Outer Banks of what is now North Carolina for a suitable location for England's first North American colony.

title: North Carolina
event: June 4 – Sir Walter Raleigh sends an expedition to Roanoke Island, old Virginia (now North Carolina), with a view to establishing an English colony.

title: Estonia
event: June 11 – Walk (today Valka and Valga towns in Latvia and Estonia respectively) receives city rights from Polish king Stefan Bathory.

title: North Carolina
event: Sir Walter Raleigh sends an expedition to establish a colony on Roanoke Island, off the coast of North Carolina. The settlers face many problems, and soon abandon the colony.

title: Brussels
event: February – The Spanish seize Brussels.

title: Northwest Passage
event: August 8 – John Davis enters Cumberland Sound in his quest for the Northwest Passage.

title: St. Augustine Florida
event: St. Augustine, Florida, and Santo Domingo in the modern day Dominican Republic are plundered and burned by English sea captain Sir Francis Drake.

title: Battle of Zutphen
event: September 22 – Battle of Zutphen: Spanish troops defeat the Dutch rebels and their English allies.

title: London
event: The Rose (theatre) is founded in London by Philip Henslowe.

title: China
event: A severe famine breaks out in China during the Ming Dynasty.

title: Fotheringhay Castle
event: February 8 – Mary, Queen of Scots, is beheaded at Fotheringhay Castle in England, after she is implicated in a plot to murder her cousin, Queen Elizabeth I.

title: North Carolina
event: July 22 – Colony of Roanoke: A group of English settlers arrive on Roanoke Island off of North Carolina to re-establish the deserted colony.

title: Iran
event: October 1 – Shāh ‘Abbās I The Great succeeds as Shahenshah of Iran.Chambers Biographical Dictionaryisbn=0-550-18022-2page=1}}<

title: Leiden University Library
event: October 31 – Leiden University Library opens its doors after its founding in 1575.

title: Sahara
event: Ahmad al-Mansur, sultan of Morocco, demands that the king of Songhay pay a heavy tribute in exchange for Saharan salt, probably as an intentional provocation. When Songhay's answer is defiant, the sultan declares war and marches his army through Sahara to Songhay.

title: Colombo
event: February – The Sinhalese abandon the siege of Colombo, capital of Portuguese Ceylon.

title: English Channel
event: May 28 – The Spanish Armada, with 130 ships and 30,000 men, begins to set sail from Spain heading for the English Channel (it will take until May 30 for all of the ships to leave port).

title: France
event: August 6 – Battle of Gravelines: The Spanish Armada is defeated by an English naval force under command of Lord Charles Howard and Sir Francis Drake off the coast of Gravelines, now in France.

title: San Luigi dei Francesi
event: San Luigi dei Francesi, Rome, is completed by Domenico Fontana.

title: Pechenga Monastery
event: The monks of the Pechenga Monastery, the northernmost in the world, are massacred by the Swedes.

title: Denmark
event: February 26 – Valkendorfs Kollegium is founded in Copenhagen, Denmark.

title: Breda
event: March – Maurice of Nassau, Prince of Orange, takes Breda by concealing 68 of his best men in a peat-boat to get through the impregnable defences.

title: Crown of Castile
event: January 11 – The Cortes of Castile approves a new subsidy, the millones.

title: Caucasus
event: May 21 – Treaty of Ferhat Pasha between Ottoman Turkey and Safavid Persia. Ottomans annex Caucasus.

title: Vienna
event: September 15 – The Neulengbach earthquake causes significant damage and some loss of life in Lower Austria and Vienna; effects felt as far as Bohemia Silesia

title: Zutphen
event: June – Zutphen is captured by the Dutch under Maurice of Nassau.

title: Deventer
event: July – Deventer is captured by the Dutch under Maurice of Nassau.

title: Hyderabad India
event: The city of Hyderabad is founded by Quli Quub Shah.

title: Kent
event: The Durtnell (Dartnell) family of Brasted, Kent, England, begin to work as building contractors. They will still be functioning under the twelfth generation of the family in the 21st century.

title: University of Malta
event: The ''Collegium Melitense'' (now known as the University of Malta) is founded by Bishop Garagallo.

title: Ireland
event: Trinity College, Dublin, Ireland's oldest university, is founded.

title: Korea
event: The Seven-Year War between Korea and Japan starts.

title: Korea
event: April 24 – Battle of Sangju: The Japanese are victorious over the Koreans.

title: Richard Hawkins
event: June – Sir Richard Hawkins arrives in the Bay of San Mateo, where he is attacked and captured by 2 Spanish ships.

title: Macau
event: St. Paul's College, Macao is founded in Macau by Jesuits, being the first western style university in the far east.

title: France
event: February 27 – Henry IV is crowned King of France at Chartres.

title: Dutch Republic
event: July 22 – After a 2-month siege, the city of Groningen submits to Dutch troops, bringing the whole northern Netherlands under the Republic

title: Marquesas Islands
event: Spanish navigator and explorer Álvaro de Mendaña de Neira leads the voyage that discovers (for Europeans) the first known islands of Polynesia, the Marquesas.

title: Leiden University Library
event: May 24 – The ''Nomenclator'' of Leiden University Library appears, the first printed catalog of an institutional library.

title: Ireland
event: June – Sir John Norreys and Sir Geoffrey Fenton travel to Connaught to parley with the local Irish lords.

title: Warsaw
event: King Sigismund III Vasa moves the capital of Poland from Kraków to Warsaw.

title: Sidney Sussex College Cambridge
event: Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge is founded.

title: Java
event: Dutch ships, commanded by Frederick de Houtman, reach Sumatra and Java for the first time.

title: Vlie
event: May 18 – Willem Barents leaves Vlie on his third and final Arctic voyage.

title: Spitsbergen
event: June 17 – Barents discovers Spitsbergen.

title: Colombo
event: July 14 – King Dominicus Corea (Edirille Bandara) is beheaded by the Portuguese in Colombo, Ceylon.

title: Monterrey
event: September 20 – Diego de Montemayor founds the city of Monterrey, Mexico.

title: China
event: 12 million pesos of silver cross the Pacific. Although it is unknown just how much silver flowed from the Spanish base of Manila in the Philippines to the Ming Dynasty of China, it is known that the main port for the Mexican silver trade—Acapulco—shipped out 150,000 to 345,000 kg (4 to 9 million taels) of silver annually from this year to 1602.

title: Portugal
event: A Dutch Expedition commanded by Frederick de Houtman returns to Amsterdam after having successfully reached the Spice Islands. This achievement opens the Spice trade, which had until then been monopolised by the Portuguese, to the Dutch, who in the next years launch several more expeditions to the Indies.

title: Jamaica
event: February 8 – Sir Anthony Shirley, England's best-educated pirate, raids Jamaica.

title: Bantam (city)
event: June 24 – The first Dutch voyage to the East Indies reaches Bantam (on Java).

title: Denmark
event: August 24 – Christian IV of Denmark refuses to let Tycho Brahe return to Denmark.

title: Korea
event: August 28 – Battle of Chilcheollyang: The Japanese fleet defeats the Koreans.  It is the only Japanese naval victory in the Imjin War.

title: Tower of London
event: October – John Gerard, a Jesuit priest, escapes from the Tower of London.

title: China
event: Illustrations of Ottoman Turkish and European riflemen, with detailed illustrations of their firearms, appear in Zhao Shizhen's book ''Shenqipu'' in this year, during the Ming Dynasty of China.

title: Mauritius
event: After being separated from their fleet, 3 Dutch ships discover an island and name it Mauritius, after Maurice of Nassau.

title: France
event: May 2 – The Peace of Vervins ends the war between France and Spain.

title: Battle of the Yellow Ford
event: August – Battle of the Yellow Ford: The Irish rebellion against English rule gains a victory.

title: Capuchin catacombs of Palermo
event: The first Capuchin friar is entombed in the Capuchin catacombs of Palermo.

title: Cahir Castle
event: May 29 – Essex takes Cahir Castle, supposedly the strongest in Ireland, after a short siege.

title: Ireland
event: August 15 – First Battle of Curlew Pass: Irish forces defeat the English.

title: London
event: September 21 – The first performance of Shakespeare's ''Julius Caesar'' at the Globe Theatre in London, is reported by Swiss traveller Thomas Platter the Younger.

title: Ireland
event: Ulster chieftains, with the lead of Hugh O'Neill, 2nd Earl of Tyrone, resist the English reconquest of Ireland.

title: Giordano Bruno
event: February 17 – Giordano Bruno is burned at the stake for heresy in Rome.

title: Huaynaputina
event: February 19 – Huaynaputina volcano undergoes a catastrophic eruption, the worst to be recorded in South America.

title: Wallachia
event: May 6 – Prince Sigismund Báthory of Transylvania loses the city of Suceava to the Voivode Michael the Brave of Wallachia, during the internecine conflict in Hungary and the Danubian Principalities. For the first time, Transylvania, Moldavia, and Wallachia became one country (known today as Romania). However, the union ends one year later when Michael the Brave is killed.

title: Battle of Nieuwpoort
event: July 2 – Battle of Nieuwpoort in the Eighty Years' War (Dutch War of Independence) between the Dutch and the Spanish

title: Ireland
event: 24 December (Julian Calendar) – The Battle of Kinsale ends the siege of Kinsale, Ireland, a siege that started in the autumn of 1601.  According to the Gregorian Calendar used by the Irish and Spanish forces in the battle, its date was 3 January 1602.

title: China
event: The Jesuit Matteo Ricci becomes the first European to enter the Forbidden City in Beijing, China, during the Ming Dynasty.

title: Málaga
event: Dutch troops drive the Portuguese from Málaga.

title: Estonia
event: A famine (-1603) kills about half the Estonian population.

title: Portugal
event: June – James Lancaster's East India Company fleet arrives at Achin (now Aceh), Sumatra to deal with the local ruler. Having defeated Portugal's ally, the ruler is happy to do business, and Lancaster seizes a large Portuguese galleon and loots it.

title: Bahrain
event: Portuguese expelled from Bahrain.

title: Iran
event: Persia and Spain conclude a defensive alliance and declare war on the Ottoman Empire.

title: China
event: The iconoclast and Confucian scholar Li Zhi commits suicide while in a Chinese prison during the late Ming Dynasty; he had taught that women were the intellectual equals of men and should be given equal opportunity in education; he was charged with spreading dangerous ideas.

title: China
event: Matteo Ricci, an Italian Jesuit stationed in Beijing, Ming Dynasty, China, creates a geographical map of East Asia with Chinese-written labeling and map symbols.

title: London
event: Publication of the play ''A Larum for London'' in London.

title: Cape Cod
event: May 15 – Bartolomew Gosnold becomes the first European at Cape Cod.

title: Bodleian Library
event: November 8 – The Bodleian Library at Oxford University is opened to the public.

title: Accademia dei Lincei
event: The Accademia dei Lincei is founded.

title: Singapore
event: February 25 – Portuguese ship Santa Catarina was seized by Dutch East India Company ships off Singapore.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: April 28 – The funeral of Elizabeth I of England is held in Westminster Abbey.

title: France
event: August – Samuel de Champlain returns to France.

title: Winchester Castle
event: November 17 – Sir Walter Raleigh goes on trial for treason in the converted Great Hall of Winchester Castle.

title: North America
event: France begins settling Acadia, first successful French North American colony.

title: French Guiana
event: France begins settling French Guiana.

title: Nottingham
event: Before 1 October, Huntingdon Beaumont completes the Wollaton Wagonway, built to transport coal from the mines at Strelley to Wollaton just west of Nottingham, England. This is currently the world's oldest wagonway with provenance. The exact date is unknown, but a surviving account book for the year ended 30 September 1604 proves it was built within the preceding 12 months.

title: London
event: November 1 – At Whitehall Palace in London, the William Shakespeare tragedy ''Othello'' is presented for the first time.

title: Barbados
event: Crew of the ''Olive'' become the first British visitors to Barbados.

title: Downside Abbey
event: The Priory of St. Gregory's is founded at Douai, Flanders, at this time in the Spanish Netherlands, by its first prior, Saint John Roberts, and other exiles, thus becoming the first English Benedictine house to renew conventual life after the Reformation. More than two centuries later the community will establish Downside Abbey back in England.

title: Battle of Kircholm
event: September 27 – Battle of Kircholm: Swedish armies are defeated by the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.

title: Palace of Westminster
event: November 5 – Gunpowder Plot: A plot by to blow up the English Houses of Parliament is foiled when Sir Thomas Knyvet, a justice of the peace, finds Guy Fawkes in a cellar below the Parliament building and orders a search of the area (records show 36 barrels of gunpowder were found, and Fawkes was arrested for trying to kill King James I of England and the members who were scheduled to sit together in Parliament the next day).

title: Carmarthenshire
event: A storm buries the village of St Ismail near modern-day Kidwelly, Carmarthenshire, Wales.

title: Latvia
event: The Jesuit Joannis Stribingius visits Latvia, and describes Latvian mythology.

title: Australia
event: February 26 – Dutch navigator Willem Janszoon makes the first confirmed sighting of Australia by a European.

title: Gojjam
event: March 10 – Susenyos defeats the combined armies of Yaqob and Abuna Petros II at the Battle of Gol in Gojjam, which makes him Emperor of Ethiopia.

title: Great Britain
event: April 12 – The Union Flag is adopted as the national flag of Great Britain.

title: Portugal
event: August 14 – A Dutch fleet is defeated by a Portuguese fleet in the Battle of Cape Rachado

title: United Kingdom
event: The British national anthem, ''God Save the King'', is first sung.

title: France
event: The rule of Andorra passes jointly to the king of France and the Bishop of Urgell.

title: Philippines
event: January 19 – San Agustin Church in Manila is officially completed; it is currently the oldest church in the Philippines

title: Battle of Gibraltar
event: April 25 – Battle of Gibraltar: A Dutch fleet destroys a Spanish fleet anchored in the Bay of Gibraltar (Battle of Gibraltar).

title: Virginia
event: April 26 – English colonists make landfall at Cape Henry, Virginia, later moving up the James River to found Jamestown, the first permanent English settlement in what is now the United States.

title: North America
event: May 14 – Jamestown, Virginia, is settled as what would become the first permanent English colony in North America.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: May 15 – Jamestown: Christopher Newport, George Percy, Gabriel Archer, and others travel 6 days exploring along the James River up to the falls and Powhatan's village.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: Jamestown: The president directs the fort to be strengthened and armed against the many attacks of the natives:  Hereupon the President was contented the Fort should be pallisadoed, the ordinance mounted, his men armed and exercised, for many were the assaults and Ambuscadoes of the Savages ... [John Smith, Proceedings (Barbour 1964)]

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: May 28 – Jamestown: The Fort is pallisadoed: we laboured, pallozadoing our fort [Gabriel Archer (Arber)].

title: Tresham
event: June 8 – Newton rebellion: The Tresham landowners family kills 40–50 peasants during protests against the enclosure of common land in Newton, Northamptonshire, UK, at the culmination of the Midland Revolt.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: June 10 – Jamestown: John Smith is released from arrest and sworn in as a member of the colony Council.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: June 15: Jamestown: The triangular fort is completed and armed: The fifteenth of June we had built and finished our Fort, which was triangle wise, having three Bulwarkes, at every corner, like a halfe Moone, and foure or five pieces of Artillerie mounted in them. We had made our selves sufficiently strong for these Savages. We had also sowne most of our Corne on two Mountaines. [George Percy (Tyler 1952:19)]

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: June 27: Jamestown: The colony bears extreme toil in strengthening the fort [from John Smith, ''Proceedings'' (Barbour 1964:210)].

title: Popham Colony
event: August 13 – The ship ''Gift of God'' of the Plymouth Company arrives at the mouth of the modern-day Kennebec River in Maine. English colonists establish a ''Fort St. George'', also known as the Popham Colony. The settlement lasts little more than a year, before residents return to England in the first ocean going ship built in the New World, a 30-ton pinnace called ''The Virginia''.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: September 10: Jamestown: President Wingfield is deposed, and then Ratcliffe is elected.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: December – Jamestown: In early December, John Smith is captured by Opechancanough.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: At Jamestown, Virginia, Christopher Newport returns in a ship with the first supply and about 100 new settlers; he finds only 38 survivors.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: July – The English ship ''Mary and Margaret'', captained by Christopher Newport, leaves England bound for Jamestown, Virginia.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: December – Jamestown: Christopher Newport returns to England carrying cargo with tryals of Pitch, Tarre, Glasse, Frankincense, Sope Ashes ...

title: Ireland
event: Old Bushmills Distillery is founded in Bushmills, County Antrim, Ireland.

title: Korea
event: Uniform Land-Tax Law is imposed in Korea.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: January 7 – Fire destroys all the houses in the fort at Jamestown, Virginia; the fort is repaired in March.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: April 10 – Jamestown: Christopher Newport again sails for England.

title: Surat
event: August 24 – The first official English representative to India lands at Surat.

title: University of Oviedo
event: September 21 – The University of Oviedo, Spain is founded.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: October 1 – At Jamestown, a second supply ship, the ''Mary and Margaret'', arrives with Christopher Newport, including 70 settlers, bringing the population back up to 120; the passengers include 8 glassmen.

title: France
event: Samuel de Champlain claims the Lake Champlain area of Vermont for France.

title: Ryukyu Islands
event: The Japanese Shimazu clan Invades the Ryukyu Islands, making the Ryukyu Kingdom a vassal of Japan.

title: Warsaw
event: Warsaw becomes the capital of Poland.

title: Philippines
event: The municipality of Buenavista in Marinduque, Philippines was founded.

title: Virginia
event: May 23 – The Second Charter of Virginia is officially ratified, which is intended to replace the council with a Governor who has absolute control in the colony.

title: Bermuda
event: July 23 – Jamestown: A hurricane at sea separates the 9 ships (600 more settlers) en route, one ship sinks, and the ship ''Sea Venture'' wrecks at Bermuda.

title: Virginia
event: July 28 – Bermuda is first settled by survivors of the English ''Sea Venture'', en route to Virginia.

title: France
event: July 30 – At what is now Crown Point, New York, Samuel de Champlain participates in a battle between the Huron and Iroquois, shooting and killing two Iroquois chiefs; this helps set the tone for French–Iroquois relations for the next 100 years.

title: Bermuda
event: August – Jamestown: Seven ships arrive at the colony, with 200–300 men, women, and children, reporting that the ''Sea Venture'' wrecked near Bermuda.

title: Delaware Bay
event: August 28 – Henry Hudson is the first European to see Delaware Bay.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: September 10 – Jamestown: Capt. George Percy replaces Captain John Smith as president of the Council, and Smith returns to England.

title: London
event: October 12 –  Three Blind Mice is published by London teenage songwriter Thomas Ravenscroft.

title: Virginia
event: In Jamestown, Virginia, only 60 out of 500 settlers survive over winter.

title: Brazil
event: By this year, the Portuguese colony of Brazil has either 400 mills producing 57,000 tons of sugar a year, or only 230 mills producing 14,000 tons of sugar a year; accepting either figure depends on which expert you believe is more accurate, according to Alfred W. Crosby Jr. on page 69 of his book The ''Columbian Exchange: Biological and Cultural Consequences of 1492''. In any case, the incredible wealth the Portuguese acquire from selling sugar in Europe prompts the English and French to follow suit in this century.

title: China
event: The Manchu tribal leader Nurhaci breaks his relations with the Ming Dynasty of China, then under the aloof and growingly negligent Wanli Emperor; Nurhaci's line later becomes the emperors of the Qing Dynasty that overthrow the short-lived Shun Dynasty in 1644 and the remnants of the Ming throne in 1662.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: May 23 – Jamestown, Virginia: Acting as temporary Governor, Thomas Gates, along with John Rolfe, Ralph Hamor, Sir George Somers, and other survivors from the ''Sea Venture'' (wrecked at Bermuda) arrive at Jamestown; they find that 60 have survived the starving time (during winter), the fort palizadoes and gates have been torn down, and empty houses have been used for firewood, in fear of attacks by natives outside the fort area.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: May 24 – Jamestown, Virginia: The temporary Governor, Thomas Gates, issues The Divine, Moral, and Martial Laws.

title: Battle of Klushino
event: June 4 – A Polish-Lithuanian army defeats a much larger Russian army at the Battle of Klushino.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: June 7 – Jamestown: Temporary Governor Gates decides to abandon Jamestown.

title: Mulberry Island
event: June 8 – Jamestown: Temporary Governor Gates' convoy meets the ships of Governor Thomas West, 3rd Baron De La Warr (Delaware) at Mulberry Island.

title: Newfoundland (island)
event: July 5 – John Guy sets sail from Bristol with 39 other colonists for Newfoundland.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: August 2 – Henry Hudson sails into what it is now known as Hudson Bay, thinking he has made it through the Northwest Passage and reached the Pacific Ocean.

title: Trinidad
event: Jamestown: John Rolfe imports tobacco seeds from the island of Trinidad (''Nicotiana tabacum''); the native tobacco is ''Nicotiana rustica''.

title: Denmark
event: Denmark attacks Sweden.

title: Begemder
event: March 9 – Yemana Kristos, brother of Emperor Susenyos, ends the rebellion of Melka Sedeq in the Battle of Segaba in Begemder.

title: University of Santo Tomas
event: April 28 – The Colegio de Nuestra Señora del Santísimo Rosario is established in Manila, the Philippines (later renamed Colegio de Santo Tomas, now known as the University of Santo Tomas).

title: London
event: November 1 – At Whitehall Palace in London, William Shakespeare's romantic comedy ''The Tempest'' is performed for the first time.

title: Trinidad
event: Jamestown: John Rolfe exports first crop of improved tobacco (seeds from Trinidad).

title: Lancashire
event: The Pendle witch trials are held in Pendle, Lancashire.

title: Nagoya Castle
event: Nagoya Castle is completed.

title: Northampton
event: July 22 – Northamptonshire Witch Trials: Four women and one man hanged at Abingdon Gallows, Northampton, England.

title: India
event: November 30 – Battle of Swally: Forces of the British East India Company and Portugal engage off the coast of India, resulting in a British victory.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: June – At Jamestown, John Rolfe makes the first shipment of West Indian tobacco grown in Virginia to England.

title: Hertfordshire
event: The New River is opened, to supply London with drinking water from Hertfordshire.

title: France
event: A locust swarm destroys La Camarque, France.

title: Hopewell Virginia
event: Near Jamestown, Virginia, Sir Thomas Dale starts a settlement called Bermuda City which later becomes part of Hopewell, Virginia.

title: Denmark
event: January 20 – King James I of England successfully mediates the Treaty of Knäred  between Denmark and Sweden.

title: Newfoundland (island)
event: March 27 – The first English child is born in Canada at Cuper's Cove, Newfoundland to Nicholas Guy.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: April – Near Jamestown, Virginia, Samuel Argall captures Chief Powhatan’s daughter, Pocahontas, and she is brought to Jamestown.

title: London
event: June 29 – Fire destroys London's famed Globe Theatre.

title: France
event: The French Estates-General meets for the last time before the era of the French Revolution. In between, France will be governed as an absolute monarchy.

title: Osaka Castle
event: Toyotomi Hideyori attempts to restore Osaka Castle. Tokugawa Ieyasu, father of the Shogun, is outraged at this act, and takes the castle by storm.

title: University of Groningen
event: August 23 – The University of Groningen is established in the Netherlands.

title: 45th parallel north
event: 1 January – The New Netherland Company is granted a 3-year monopoly in North American trade between the 40th and 45th parallels.

title: Groenlo
event: The Grolsch Brewery is founded in Groenlo, Netherlands.

title: Tower of London
event: Mary Talbot, Countess of Shrewsbury, is released from the Tower of London in recognition of her role in helping to discover the murder of Sir Thomas Overbury.

title: Bermuda
event: The Somers Isles Company is founded to administer Bermuda.

title: Great Britain
event: King James I of Great Britain sends Sir Thomas Roe as his ambassador to the Mughal court of Jahangir.

title: The Perse School
event: The Perse School in Cambridge, England, is founded by Dr Stephen Perse.

title: China
event: Manuel Dias (Yang MaNuo), a Portuguese jesuit missionary introduces for the first time in China the telescope in his book ''Tian Wen Lüe'' (''Explicatio Sphaerae Coelestis'').

title: France
event: June 2 – The first Récollet missionaries arrive at Quebec City, from Rouen, France.

title: Osaka Castle
event: June 4 – Forces under the shogun Tokugawa Ieyasu take Osaka Castle in Japan, beginning a period of peace which lasts nearly 250 years. Bands of Christian samurai support Ieyasu's enemies at the Battle of Osaka.

title: Ahom kingdom
event: November –  The Mughals under Abu Bakr launch the first offensive against Kajali, a border post of the Ahom kingdom.

title: Brazil
event: Physician Aleixo de Abreu is granted a pension of 16,000 reis for services to the crown in Angola and Brazil by Philip III of Spain, who also appoints him physician of his chamber.

title: Bhutan
event: Ngawang Namgyal arrives in Bhutan, having escaped Tibet.

title: Italy
event: Week-long festivities in honor of the Prince of Urbano, of the Barbarini family, occur in Florence, Italy.

title: Sultan Ahmed Mosque
event: Constantinople's Sultan Ahmed Mosque (also known as the ''Blue Mosque'') is completed during the rule of Ahmed I.

title: China
event: Nurhaci declares himself khan (emperor) of China and founds the Later Jin Dynasty.

title: India
event: Richard Steel and John Crowther journey from Ajmeer in Mogul India, to Ispahan, Persia, in 1615 and 1616.

title: Maine
event: Captain John Smith (1580–1631) publishes his book ''A description of New England'' in London. Smith relates one voyage to the coast of Massachusetts and Maine, in 1614, and an attempted voyage the following year (1615) when he was captured by French pirates and detained for several months escaping.

title: New England
event: The New England Indian smallpox epidemic of 1616–1619 begins to depopulate the region, killing an estimated 90% of the coastal native peoples.

title: London
event: In London and neighboring towns, an epidemic of louse-borne typhus ravages the poor, crowded English. Lack of bathing encourages body lice that, when scratched, defecate on the skin, where a minor cut or sore can serve as an entry portal for the typhus-infected feces to enter the bloodstream, leading to high fever, delirium, and gangrenous sores.

title: Saco River
event: At the behest of Sir Ferdinando Gorges, Dr. Richard Vines, a physician, passes the winter of 1616—17 at Biddeford, Maine, at the mouth of the Saco River, that he calls Winter Harbor. This is the site of the earliest permanent settlement in Maine of which we have a conclusive record. Maine will become an important refuge for religious dissenters persecuted by the Puritans.

title: Suwannee River
event: In Spanish Florida, the Cofa Mission at the mouth of the Suwannee River disappears.

title: Bermuda
event: The first African slaves are brought to Bermuda, an English colony, by Captain George Bargrave to dive for pearls, because of their reputed skill in pearl-diving. Harvesting pearls off the coast proves unsuccessful, and the slaves are put to work planting and harvesting the initial large crops of tobacco and sugar cane. (At the same time, the freedom-loving English refused to purchase Brazilian sugar because it was produced by slave labor.)

title: China
event: William Baffin is held at bay from finding the Northwest Passage to China.

title: King's Bench Prison
event: English dramatist Thomas Dekker is imprisoned in the King's Bench Prison (1612–1619) because of a debt of 40 ₤ to the father of John Webster. In prison he continues to write.

title: France
event: Saint Ambrose Edward Barlow, recently graduated from the College of Saint Gregory, Douai, France, and the Royal College of Saint Alban in Valladolid, Spain, enters the Benedictine Order. In 1641 he is hanged, drawn and quartered in Lancaster, England, for preaching.

title: France
event: Italian natural philosopher Giulio Cesare Vanini publishes a radically heterodox book in France after his English interlude ''De admirandis naturae reginae deaeque mortalium arcanis,'' for which he is condemned and forced to flee Paris. For his opinion that the world is eternal and governed by immanent laws, as expressed in this book, he is executed in 1619.

title: Italy
event: Francesco Albani paints the ceiling frescoes of ''Apollo and the Seasons'' at the Palazzo Verospi in Via del Corso for Cardinal Fabrizio Verospi. Italy still houses most of the Renaissance artwork of Europe.

title: France
event: Witch-hunting: Elizabeth Rutter is hanged as a witch in Middlesex, England. Orkney witch Elspeth Reoch is tried, and Agnes Berrye is hanged as a witch in Enfield, England. In France Leger (first name unknown) is condemned for witchcraft on May 6, and Sylvanie de la Plaine is burned at Pays de Labourde as a witch. In Orleans, France, 18 witches are killed.

title: Leicester
event: The Leicester witch trial, in which nine women were hanged on the testimony of a raving 13-year old boy named John Smith, is held under the 1604 Witchcraft Statute of King James I.
