This bill was supported by some of the most able and learned men in England, including the Earl of Northumberland, the Bishop of Lincoln, the Chief Justice of the Court of Common Pleas, the Attorney General for England and Wales, the Lord Chief Baron of the Exchequer, and the Chief Justice of the King's Bench.

title: Blackfriars Theatre
event: Ben Jonson's witty and satirical play ''The Devil Is an Ass'', a comedy in five acts, is produced at Blackfriars Theatre by the King's Men, in October or November. The play pokes fun at credence in witchcraft and Middlesex juries. It is published in 1631.

title: Italy
event: Human deformities are seen as producing monsters. Italian Fortunio Liceti publishes his book ''De monstrorum natura caussis et differentiis'' (''On the nature, causes and differences of monsters'').

title: Java
event: Dutch traders smuggle the coffee plant out of Mocha, a port in Yemen on the Red Sea, and cultivate it at the Amsterdam Botanical Gardens. Dutch later introduce Mocha coffee to Java.

title: China
event: Anti-Christian persecutions break out in Nanking, China, and Nagasaki, Japan. The Jesuit-lead Christian community in Japan at this time was over 3000,000 strong.

title: France
event: Master seafarer Henry Mainwaring (1587–1653), Oxford graduate and lawyer turned successful Newfoundland pirate, returns to England, is pardoned after rescuing a Newfoundland trading fleet near Gibraltar, and writes a revealing treatise on piracy. He is knighted and later becomes Vice-Admiral and Chancellor of Ireland under Kings James I and Charles I, before being exiled to France for being on the losing side of the English Civil War. In his book, he advises the King against granting pardons to pirates.

title: North America
event: The Dutch establish their colony of Essequibo in the region of the Essequibo River in northern South America (present-day Guyana) for sugar and tobacco production. The colony is protected by the Kyk-Over-Al fort, now in ruins. The Dutch also map the Delaware River in North America.

title: Lisbon
event: The Ottoman Empire attempts landings at the shoreline between Cadiz and Lisbon.

title: Franche-Comté
event: Pierre Vernier is employed, with his father, in making fine-scale maps of France (Franche-Comté area).

title: University of Copenhagen
event: Danish natural philosopher Ole Worm collects materials that will later be incorporated into his museum in Copenhagen. His museum is the nucleus of the University of Copenhagen's Zoological Museum.

title: Italy
event: Italian artist Guido Reni executes his famous ''Pietà'', on commission from the Senate of Bologna and placed on the greater altar of the church of Santa Maria della Pietà on November 13.

title: Italy
event: A fatal disease of cattle, probably rinderpest, spreads through the Italian provinces of Padua, Udine, Treviso, and Vicenza, introduced most likely from Dalmatia or Hungary. Great numbers of cattle die in Italy, as they had in previous years (1559, 1562, 1566, 1590, 1598) in other European regions when harvest failure also drives people to the brink of starvation (for example, 1595–1597 in Germany). The consumption of beef and veal is prohibited, and Pope Paul V issues an edict prohibiting the slaughter of draught oxen that were suitable for plowing. Calves are also not slaughtered for a some time afterwards, so that Italy's cattle herds can be replenished.

title: University of Sassari
event: In Sardinia, the Faculty of Medicine and Surgery of the University of Sassari is founded.

title: New York
event: Gian Lorenzo Bernini (1598–1680) sculpts ''Bacchanal: A Faun Teased by Children'', at the age of 18 years. This work is now in New York, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Brazil
event: A slave ship carries smallpox from the Kongo to Salvador, Brazil.

title: Vienna
event: Jesuit astronomer Christoph Scheiner becomes the advisor to Archduke Maximilian, brother of Holy Roman Emperor Rudolph II in Vienna. In a series of published letters in 1612 and 1613, Scheiner had sparred with Galileo over the nature of sunspots and been roundly trounced since Galileo's careful observations indicated that sunspots could not be satellites around the Sun because they often disappear on the disk. In fact, Scheiner sought to remove these smudges to the celestial body's immaculate reputation. A life-long enemy of Galileo, Scheiner is credited with reopening the 1616 accusations against Galileo in 1633.

title: France
event: European imperialism and expansion, whether for colonial, military, religious, or commercial reasons, is aimed at the New World, Asia, Africa, Australia, and Oceania. The main European players in this game are Spain, England, Netherlands, Portugal, France, Venice, and Genoa.

title: Maluku Islands
event: January – The Dutch try to gain control of all the nutmeg-producing spice islands with the retreat of the English from Ai to Pula Run Island. Nutmeg at this time is more valuable than gold, and the English, led by Nathaniel Courthope, hold on to Run.

title: Brazil
event: January – António Vieira arrives, with his parents, in Bahia (present-day Salvador) in colonial Brazil, an unpromising beginning for his great career as a diplomat, noted author, leading figure of the Church, and protector of Brazilian Indians in an age of intolerance.

title: Württemberg
event: January – Officials in Württemberg charge astronomer Johannes Kepler with practicing forbidden arts (witchcraft). His mother had also been so charged and spent 14 months in prison.

title: France
event: January 12 – The city of Belém, Brazil is founded on the Amazon River delta by the Portuguese captain Francisco Caldeira Castelo Branco, who had previously taken the city of São Luís in Maranhão from the French.

title: France
event: January 15 – After overwintering with the Huron Indians, Samuel de Champlain and Recollect Father Joseph Le Caron visit the Petun and Ottawa Indians of the Great Lakes. This is Champlain's last trip in North America before returning to France. Having secured Canada, he helps create French America, New France, or L'Acadie.

title: Cape Horn
event: January 24 – Dutch captain Willem Schouten rounds the southern tip of South America and names it ''Kaap Hoorn'', after his birthplace in the Netherlands.

title: London
event: February – English merchants of the East India Company complain that the great troubles and wars in Japan since their arrival have put them to much pains and charges. Two great cities, Osaka and Sakaii, have been burned to the ground, each one almost as big as London, and not one house left standing, and it is reported above 300,000 men have lost their lives, “yet the old Emperor Ogusho Same hath prevailed and Fidaia Same either slain or fled secretly away, that no news is to be heard of him.” Jesuits, priests, and friars are banished by the emperor and their churches and monasteries pulled down; they put the fault on the arrival of the English; it is said if Fidaia Same had prevailed against the emperor, he promised them entrance again, when without doubt all the English would have been driven out of Japan.

title: Philippines
event: February 19 – First recorded eruption of Mayon Volcano, the Philippines' most active volcano.

title: Tower of London
event: March 19 – Sir Walter Raleigh, English explorer of the New World, is released from prison in the Tower of London in order to conduct a second, ill-fated expedition in search of El Dorado in South America.

title: Denmark
event: May – The Thomas Overbury Murder Scandal (1615–1616) ends with the conviction of Earl and Countess of Somerset, who were, however, not hanged but imprisoned until 1622 in the Tower of London. Although King James I of England has ordered the investigation of the poet's murder and allowed his former court favorite to be arrested and tried, his court, now under the influence of the Earl of Buckingham (George Villiers) gains the reputation of being corrupt and vile. The royal visit of James's brother-in-law Christian IV, king of Denmark, a notorious soak, adds further scandal.

title: Bismarck Sea
event: July 6 – First recorded eruption of Manam Volcano (erupting frequently since then), forming a 10-km-wide island in the Bismarck Sea, 13 km off coast of Papua New Guinea, in the southwestern part of the Pacific Ring of Fire.

title: Ireland
event: July 20 – Hugh O'Neill, 2nd Earl of Tyrone, dies in Rome, thus concluding the Flight of the Earls from Ireland.

title: China
event: August 8 – The Tokugawa shogunate (Bakufu) in Japan forbids foreigners other than Chinese from traveling freely or trading outside of the ports of Nagasaki and Hirado.

title: Italy
event: September 15 – The first non-aristocratic, free public school in Europe is opened in Frascati, Italy.

title: Lincoln's Inn
event: October- John Donne is appointed as Reader in Divinity at his old inn of court, Lincoln's Inn.

title: Eendracht
event: October 25 – Dirk Hartog makes the second recorded landfall by a European on Australian soil, at Dirk Hartog Island off the Western Australian coast. The pewter Hartog Plate, left to mark the landfall of the Dutch ship Eendracht, is now in the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam.

title: Virginia
event: November – With small profits to show, the Virginia Company decides to distribute land in Virginia to stockholders according to the number of shares owned. Each stockholder can set up a particular plantation and pay associated expenses, receiving {{Convert100acrekm2}} of land for each share and {{Convert50acrem2}} for each person transported (the headrights system).

title: London
event: November – Author Richard Burton is made vicar of St. Thomas in the west suburbs of London.

title: London
event: November 4 – Charles I (15 year-old second son of James I of England and Anne of Denmark) is invested as Prince of Wales at Whitehall in London, the last such investiture until 1911.

title: Whitehall
event: November 5 – Bishop Lancelot Andrewes preaches the annual Gunpowder Treason sermon before King James I of England at Whitehall (both were intended victims).

title: France
event: November 30 – Cardinal Richelieu, Armand-Jean du Plessis, is named French Secretary of State by young king Louis XIII. Richelieu will change France into a unified centralised state, able to resist both England and the Habsburg Empire.

title: Baghdad
event: December – In the Middle East, traveller Pietro Della Valle marries Jowaya, daughter of a Nestorian Catholic father and an Armenian mother, in Baghdad. The couple then sets off (1617) to find the Shah in Isfahan.

title: India
event: December 22 – An Indian youth (called one of the first fruits of India) is baptized with the name Peter in London at the St. Dionis Backchurch, in a ceremony attended by the Lord Mayor, the Privy Council, city aldermen, and officials of the Honourable East India Company. Peter thus becomes the first convert to the Anglican Church in India. He returns to India as a missionary, schooled in English and Latin.

title: Karelia
event: February 27 – The Treaty of Stolbovo ends the Ingrian War between Sweden and Russia. Sweden gains Ingermanland and Karelia.

title: Philippines
event: April 14 – Second Battle of Playa Honda: The Spanish navy defeats a Dutch fleet at the Philippines.

title: Brandenburg-Prussia
event: The markgraves of Brandenburg are granted Polish approval to inherit the Duchy of Prussia, creating the state of Brandenburg-Prussia.

title: Italy
event: The 3,000 seat Teatro Farnese, the first permanent proscenium theatre, is built into the Great Hall of the Palazzo della Pilotta in Parma, Italy.

title: India
event: Jahangir grants a British mission important commercial concessions at Surat on the west coast of India.

title: India
event: England establishes its first outpost in India.

title: Muchalls Castle
event: The Muchalls Castle reconstruction is completed.

title: Banqueting House Whitehall
event: The Banqueting House of James I of England is destroyed by fire.

title: Svalbard
event: The Danish–Dutch whaling settlement of Smeerenburg is founded in Svalbard.

title: Tierra del Fuego
event: A Spanish expedition sails around Tierra del Fuego, mapping the coast and discovering the Diego Ramirez Islands.

title: Americas
event: July 30 – In Jamestown, Virginia, the first representative assembly in the Americas, the House of Burgesses, convenes for the first time.

title: Americas
event: August – Captain Jope's ship brings the first Africans to what will later be called America. Jope trades these Africans for food and supplies. This trade of Africans is as temporary indentured servants in the same way that English whites are owned as laborers in the New World. Because the Spanish had Christianized these Africans, this labor arrangement is for a specified time and then they are free to live their lives, just as the English laborers are. These Africans had been stolen from the cargo of a Spanish vessel on the high seas. The enslavement of Africans in America is progressively and intentionally implemented later, beginning with the sentencing of John Punch in 1640.

title: France
event: August 10 – The Treaty of Angoulême ends the civil war in France.

title: Hastings
event: November 16 – William Parker School, Hastings is founded by the will of Rev. William Parker.

title: Vienna
event: November 23 – Thirty Years' War – Battle of Humenné: Polish troops assist the Holy Roman Emperor by defeating a Transylvanian force, forcing Gabor Bethlen to raise his siege of Vienna.

title: Americas
event: December 4 – Thirty-eight colonists from Berkeley Parish in England disembark in Virginia and give thanks to God (considered by some to be the first Thanksgiving in the Americas).

title: Eskdale Dumfries and Galloway
event: A severe frost in England, with the Thames frozen. 13 continuous days of snow in Scotland. On Eskdale Moor only 35 of a flock of 20,000 sheep survive.

title: South Africa
event: Two officers of the British East India Company attempt to claim the Table Mountain region (in present-day South Africa) for England, but fail.

title: Osaka Castle
event: Shogun Tokugawa Hidetada restores Osaka Castle. Its current appearance dates from this remodeling.

title: Quebec
event: June 3 – The oldest stone church in French North America, Notre-Dame-des-Anges, is begun at Quebec City, Quebec Canada.

title: Leiden
event: July 15 – The ship ''Speedwell'' departs Delfshaven with the Leiden colonists and Pilgrims.

title: Cape Cod
event: September 6 (O.S.) – The ''Mayflower'' departs from Plymouth, England, on its 3rd attempt without the ''Speedwell'', arriving on November 11 (Old Style date) at Cape Cod (named from ''Concord'' voyage of 1602).

title: Gojjam
event: October 6 – The Roman Catholic Ras Sela Kristos, half-brother of the Emperor Susenyos crushes a group of rebels in at Mount Amedamit in Gojjam, who were opposed to Susenyos' pro-Catholic beliefs.

title: Battle of White Mountain
event: November 8 – Thirty Years' War – Battle of White Mountain: Catholic forces are victorious in only two hours near Prague.

title: Petare
event: The Venezuelan city of Petare is founded by Spanish conquistadors as San Jose de Guanarito.

title: Tornio
event: The Swedish king Gustav II Adolf grants city rights to Luleå, Piteå and Torneå (Tornio).

title: Banda Islands
event: The Dutch East India Company sends 2000 soldiers under the command of Jan Pieterszoon Coen to the Banda Islands in order to force the local inhabitants to accept the Dutch trade monopoly on the lucrative nutmeg, which was grown almost exlcusively on the Banda islands. The soldiers proceed to massacre most of the 15.000 indigenous inhabitants.

title: Dutch Republic
event: April – The Twelve Years' Truce between the Dutch Republic and the Spanish Empire expires, and both sides prepare to resume the Eighty Years' War.

title: Massachusetts
event: April 1 – The Plymouth, Massachusetts colonists create the first treaty with native Americans.

title: Battle of White Mountain
event: June 21 – Thirty Years' War: Twenty-seven Czech lords are executed on the Old Town Square in Prague as a consequence of the Battle of White Mountain.

title: Gibraltar
event: Dutch ships under Joachim Swartenhondt, while escorting a convoy, repel a Spanish squadron near Gibraltar.

title: Lake Superior
event: Étienne Brûlé is the first European to see Lake Superior.

title: Ormus
event: Portugal loses control of the island of Ormus, after 107 years.

title: Florida Keys
event: Spanish galleon ''Nuestra Señora de Atocha'' sinks off the Florida Keys, while carrying copper, 35 tons of silver, 161 pieces of gold, tobacco, and indigo (wreck discovered 1985).

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: March 22 – Jamestown massacre: Algonquian natives kill 347 English settlers outside Jamestown, Virginia (1/3 of the colony's population) and burn the Henricus settlement.

title: Portugal
event: April 22 – Hormuz is captured from the Portuguese by an Anglo-Persian force.

title: Battle of Mingolsheim
event: April 27 – Thirty Years' War: A Skirmish at Mingolsheim is fought between Protestant forces under Mansfeld and Georg Friedrich of Baden-Durlach, against Imperial forces under Tilly. The Protestants win, but afterwards Tilly links up with a Spanish Army under Gonzalo de Córdoba, greatly increasing his strength.

title: Dutch East Indies
event: May 13 – The ''Eendracht'', a VOC ship and the second recorded European ship to make landfall on Australian soil, is wrecked off the western coast of Ambon Island, Dutch East Indies.

title: Tryall
event: May 25 – The English ship ''Tryall'', which left Plymouth, England for Batavia (now Jakarta), wrecks on the Tryal Rocks, 9 months later (wreck discovered in 1969).

title: Battle of Höchst
event: June 20 – Thirty Years' War: Imperial forces under Tilly attempt to prevent Christian of Brunswick from moving his army across the Main river to link up with Mansfeld. At the Battle of Höchst, Tilly manages to inflict considerable casualties on the Protestant forces, as well as seizing Brunswick's baggage train. Nonetheless, the bulk of Brunswick's forces manage to unite with Mansfeld.

title: Macau
event: June 24 – Dutch-Portuguese War: The outnumbered Portuguese forces successfully defend Macau from the Dutch fleet in the Battle of Macau, keeping a Portuguese foothold in the Far East.

title: Dutch Republic
event: July 13 – Thirty Years' War: After Mansfeld fails to relieve the siege of Heidelberg, Frederick V, Elector Palatine, cancels Mansfeld's contract and disbands his army. The unemployed army of Mansfeld and Christian of Brunswick is subsequently hired by the Dutch.

title: Portugal
event: July 13/14 – English and Dutch ships defeat the Portuguese near Mozambique.

title: Siege of Bergen-op-Zoom (1622)
event: July 18 – Eighty Years' War: Bergen-op-Zoom is besieged by a Spanish army under the command of Ambrogio Spinola.

title: Dutch Republic
event: August 29 – Thirty Years' War: While on their way to relieve the Siege of Bergen-op-Zoom in the Netherlands, the army of Mansfeld and Christian of Brunswick is blocked by a Spanish army led by Gonzalo de Córdoba. In the Battle of Fleurus, Cordoba manages to fight off the Protestant assault. The next day, Cordoba surprises the retreating Protestant army with his cavalry, resulting in the destruction of most of the Protestant army.

title: Electoral Palatinate
event: September 19 – Thirty Year's War: Heidelberg, the capital of the Electoral Palatinate, is taken by the Imperial army of Tilly after a three-month siege.

title: Siege of Bergen-op-Zoom (1622)
event: October 2 – Eighty Years' War: After a siege of 86 days, Bergen-op-Zoom is relieved by a Dutch army led by Maurice of Nassau and Ernst von Mansfeld.

title: Baghdad
event: The Safavids recapture Baghdad.

title: Saint Kitts and Nevis
event: England first colonizes Saint Kitts and Nevis.

title: Vatican Library
event: Procopius' long-lost ''Secret History'' is rediscovered in the Vatican Library.

title: Gloucester Massachusetts
event: On the coast of Massachusetts Bay, the settlement that will become the City of Gloucester, Massachusetts is first inhabited by Englishmen from Dorchester, England.

title: New Hampshire
event: The first European settlement in New Hampshire is founded.

title: France
event: February – France, Savoy, and Venice sign the Treaty of Paris, agreeing to cooperate in removing Spanish forces from the strategic Alpine pass of Valtelline.

title: Electoral Palatinate
event: February 25 – Thirty Years' War: Duke Maximilian I of Bavaria becomes Elector of the Palatinate.

title: Virginia
event: March 5 – The first American temperance law is enacted, in Virginia.

title: Jamestown Settlement
event: March 20 – Richard Frethorne begins writing a letter to his parents from the Jamestown Settlement.

title: Virginia
event: June 14 – The first breach-of-promise lawsuit: Rev. Gerville Pooley, in Virginia, files against Cicely Jordan, but he loses.

title: Dutch Republic
event: August 6 – Thirty Years' War: Chased by Tilly's army, Christian of Brunswick's army attempts to flee to the Dutch Republic. Tilly's army catches Brunswick 5 miles from the border. In the resulting Battle of Stadtlohn, Christian's army is destroyed.

title: Taiwan
event: The Netherlands establishes a trading colony at Tainan on Taiwan.

title: Palace of Versailles
event: The Palace of Versailles is first built by Louis XIII, as a hunting lodge.

title: Philippines
event: The Japanese Shogun expels the Spanish from the land and severs trade with the Philippines.

title: Denmark
event: Mail service begins in Denmark.

title: Bolivia
event: The University of Saint Francis Xavier is founded in Bolivia.

title: Latymer Upper School
event: The Latymer School and Latymer Upper School in London are founded by the bequest of Edward Latymer.

title: Dunfermline Abbey
event: The city of Dunfermline is destroyed by fire, but The Abbey, The Palace, the The Abbot House and many other buildings survive.

title: Baghdad
event: January 14 – After 90 years of Ottoman occupation, the Safavid empire recaptures Baghdad.

title: Massawa
event: January 24 – Alfonso Mendez, appointed by Pope Gregory XV as Prelate of Ethiopia, arrives at Massawa from Goa.

title: Dutch Republic
event: May 8 – A Dutch fleet captures Bahia, Brazil from the Spanish.

title: France
event: June 10 – Treaty of Compiègne, signed between France and the Netherlands

title: France
event: August 12 – Cardinal Richelieu is appointed by Louis XIII of France to be his first minister.

title: New York City
event: The Dutch settle Manhattan, founding the town of New Amsterdam. The town would transform into a piece of what is now New York City.

title: Ireland
event: March 27 – Charles Stuart (Charles I of England, Scotland and Ireland) succeeds James I of England.

title: Frederick Henry Prince of Orange
event: April 4 – Frederick Henry of Nassau marries Amalia, Countess von Solms-Braunfels.

title: Frederick Henry Prince of Orange
event: April 23 – Stadtholder Maurice of Nassau of the Dutch Republic dies and is succeeded by his younger brother, Frederick Henry.

title: Recapture of Bahia
event: May 1  – A Portuguese-Spanish expedition recaptures Salvador, Bahia (Bahia) from the Dutch.

title: Holland
event: June 2 – Prince Frederick Henry is sworn in as the stadtholder of Holland and Zealand.

title: Breda
event: June 5 – Eighty Years' War: Spanish troops under Spinola conquer Breda after a year long siege.

title: France
event: June 13 – King Charles I of England marries Henrietta Maria, Princess of France and Navarre.

title: Groningen (province)
event: August 6 – Ernest Casimir of Nassau-Dietz is appointed as stadtholder of Groningen.

title: Recapture of Bahia
event: October 25 – A Dutch fleet attacks the Portuguese garrison at Elmina castle at present-day Elmina, Ghana, but is defeated with heavy casualties. This defeat, along with the defeats at Bahia and Puerto Rico caused a 5 year long lull in Dutch attacks on Spanish and Portuguese colonies.

title: China
event: The Battle of Ningyuan in Xingcheng, Liaoning, China: With a much smaller force, the Ming Dynasty commander Yuan Chonghuan defeats the Manchu tribal leader Nurhaci, who dies soon after and is succeeded by Huang Taiji.

title: Quebec
event: When Quebec was first established its settlers depended  on supplies sent from France. However, Champlain  wanted the settlement at Quebec to be able to survive on its own. In 1626, Champlain decided to build  a farm to raise livestock, or animals to provide food for the people living in the habitation. Champlain described  the construction of Cap tourmente (Kap toor-mont) farm in one of his journals.

title: Latvia
event: January 7 – Polish-Swedish War: Gustavus II Adolphus defeats a Polish army in the Battle of Wallhof, Latvia.

title: Texel
event: January 9 – Peter Minuit sails from Texel Island for America's New Netherland colony, with 2 ships of Dutch emigrants.

title: Manhattan
event: May 24 – Peter Minuit buys Manhattan from a Native American tribe (Lenape or Shinnecock or Canarsie) for trade goods, valued at 60 guilders ($24).

title: Oldenzaal
event: August 1 – Eighty Years' War: Ernst Casimir of Nassau-Dietz retakes Oldenzaal, forcing Spain to withdraw from Overijssel.

title: Battle of Lutter
event: August 27 – Thirty Years' War: Tilly defeats king Christian IV of Denmark's army in the Battle of Lutter.

title: Manhattan
event: November 6 – (O.S.) The ship ''Arms of Amsterdam'' arrives in Europe from New Netherland (left September 23) with the news: They have purchased the Island Manhattes [''Manhattan''] from the Indians for the value of 60 guilders. (from P. Schagen letter dated November 7).

title: Vatican City
event: November 18 – The new St Peter's Basilica in the Vatican is consecrated, the anniversary of that of the previous church in 326.

title: South Australia
event: A Dutch ship makes the first recorded sighting of the coast of South Australia.

title: Barbados
event: England places the first European settlers on Barbados.

title: China
event: After the First Manchu invasion of Korea, the Joseon Dynasty of Korea becomes a tributary state of the Manchus, but still pays respects to the Ming Dynasty of China. After rejecting a Manchu alteration to the original diplomatic terms in 1636, the Manchus invade again in 1637.

title: Kingdom of Hungary
event: Archduke Ferdinand III of Austria, heir apparent of the Habsburg Monarchy and a future Holy Roman Emperor, already King of Hungary ascends to be king of the religiously troubled Bohemia where his (still living) father's repression of Protestantism had triggered the ongoing Thirty Years' War in 1618.

title: Siege of Groenlo (1627)
event: July 20 to August 19 – Eighty Years' War: Frederick Henry, Prince of Orange, lays siege to Grol, the last Spanish stronghold in the eastern Netherlands, and captures it after a 1-month siege.

title: Italy
event: July 27 – An earthquake destroys the cities of San Severo and Torremaggiore in southern Italy.

title: Pomerania
event: November 20 – Thirty Years' War: Bogislaw XIV, Duke of Pomerania, signs the Capitulation of Franzburg, in which Pomerania is forced to pay for the Imperial army that Wallenstein sent to occupy it. Nonetheless, despite the treaty, Pomerania is devastated by the Imperial troops.

title: France
event: The War of the Mantuan Succession breaks out over Mantua and Montferrat. The war is fought between the Duke of Savoy, who is supported by Spain, and the Duke of Nevers, who is supported by France.

title: Vasa (ship)
event: August 10 – The Swedish 64 gun sailing ship ''Vasa'' sinks on her maiden voyage in the Stockholm harbor.

title: Battle of Wolgast
event: September 2 – Thirty Years' War: Wallenstein defeats Christian IV of Denmark's army in the Battle of Wolgast.

title: Salem Massachusetts
event: September 6 – Puritans settle Salem, which will later become part of Massachusetts Bay Colony.

title: Battle in the Bay of Matanzas
event: September 7-8 – Eighty Years' War: Dutch admiral Piet Hein captures 16 ships of the Spanish treasure fleet in the Battle in the Bay of Matanzas. The immense booty taken brings in over 11 million guilders, part of which is used to fund the entire army of the Dutch republic for 8 months long.

title: Taiwan
event: Fort Santo Domingo is built in Formosa by the Spanish settlers.

title: China
event: Chongzhen, the Chinese emperor of the Ming Dynasty, reiterates the state prohibition against female infanticide, while the empire and the Chinese economy begins to crumble. In the same year, a third of the courier stations are closed down due to lack of government funds to sustain them.

title: Port Royal Nova Scotia
event: William Alexander, 1st Earl of Stirling briefly establishes a Scottish colony at Port Royal, Nova Scotia.

title: 's-Hertogenbosch
event: April 30 – Eighty Years' War: Frederick Henry of Orange lays siege to 's-Hertogenbosch, one of Spain's most important fortresses along the Spanish-Dutch border.

title: Denmark
event: May 22 – Thirty Years' War: Christian IV of Denmark and Wallenstein sign the Treaty of Lübeck, ending Denmark's involvement in the Thirty Years' War.

title: Australia
event: June 4 – Dutch East India Company ship ''Batavia'' is wrecked on a reef near Beacon Island off Western Australia on her maiden voyage to the Indies. Following mutiny among the survivors, two exiled murderers become the first Europeans to settle in Australia. Their subsequent fate is unknown.

title: North America
event: June 7 – The Dutch States-General ratifies the Dutch West India Company's Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions, making it more attractive to invest in the colony of New Netherland in North America.

title: Nevis
event: June 17 – Anglo-Spanish War (1625): A Spanish expedition led by Fadrique de Toledo wipes out the English colony on Nevis.

title: Dutch Republic
event: August 19 – Eighty Years' War: The Spanish garrison of Wesel is surprised by a small Dutch army, and the city is taken by the Dutch Republic. As Wesel functioned as principal supply base of Hendrik van den Bergh's army, the loss of supply forces him to retreat to the Spanish Netherlands, leaving him unable to intervene in the ongoing siege of 's-Hertogenbosch.

title: 's-Hertogenbosch
event: September 14 – Eighty Years' War: After a 5 month long siege, 's-Hertogenbosch surrenders to Frederick Henry. As a result of the capture of this key fortress, Spain's situation along the Spanish-Dutch border worsens greatly.

title: Great Britain
event: Paramaribo, Suriname is first settled by the British.

title: London
event: Puritan pamphleteer Dr. Alexander Leighton publishes ''Zion's Plea Against Prelacy: An Appeal to Parliament'', an attack on Anglican bishops, in London. He is sentenced by Archbishop William Laud's High Commission Court to public whipping, branding, and having his ears cut off.

title: Salem Massachusetts
event: July 6 – The ''Success'', last ship of the Winthrop Fleet, lands safely at Salem harbor, Massachusetts Bay Colony.

title: Pomerania
event: July 6 – Thirty Years' War: Leading an army of 13.000, king Gustav Adolf of Sweden enter the Thirty Years' War on protestant side by making landfall at Peenemünde, Pomerania.

title: Massachusetts
event: September 17 – The city of Boston, Massachusetts is founded.

title: Virginia
event: September 24 – The first ship of de Sauce's emigrants arrive at Southampton Hundred on the James River in Virginia.

title: Notre Dame de Paris
event: The bell Emmanuel in Notre Dame de Paris is recast.

title: Taj Mahal
event: The Taj Mahal's construction is started (it is finished in 1653).

title: France
event: January 23 – Thirty Years' War: Sweden and France sign the Treaty of Bärwalde, a military alliance in which France provides funds for the Swedish army invading northern Germany.

title: Estonia
event: February 16 – Gustav Adolf Secondary School is founded in Tallinn, Estonia by Swedish king Gustav II Adolf.

title: France
event: May 30 – Thirty Years' War: Bavaria and France sign the Treaty of Fontainebleau, forming a secret alliance. The secret alliance does not last long, however.

title: Ireland
event: June 20 – Algerian pirates sack Baltimore, County Cork in Ireland.

title: Brazil
event: September 12 – Eighty Years' War: A Spanish fleet under the command of admiral Antonio de Oquendo defeats a Dutch fleet off the coast of Brazil in the Battle of Albrolhos.

title: Battle of Breitenfeld (1631)
event: September 17 – Thirty Years' War: In the Battle of Breitenfeld, Tilly's imperial army is decisively defeated by Gustav II Adolf of Sweden, shattering the imperial army of the Holy Roman Empire and marking the first significant victory for the Protestants in the war.

title: Antigua and Barbuda
event: Antigua and Barbuda is first colonized by England.

title: Bengal
event: The Portuguese driven out of Bengal.

title: Maryland
event: Charles I of England issues a charter for the colony of Maryland (named in honor of Henrietta Maria), under the control of Lord Baltimore.

title: Estonia
event: The University of Tartu is founded in Estonia.

title: Quebec
event: March 29 – The Treaty of Saint-Germain is signed, returning Quebec to French control after the English had seized it in 1629.

title: Sittard
event: June – Eighty Years' War – Leading a Dutch army, Frederick Henry, Prince of Orange captures in short succession the cities of Venlo, Roermond and Sittard, before besieging the city of Maastricht.

title: Maastricht
event: August 22 – Eighty Years' War – A Dutch army led by Frederick Henry, Prince of Orange, captures the city of Maastricht after a two-month siege.

title: France
event: September 1 – A rebellion against french king Louis XIII is crushed at the Battle of Castelnaudary. The leader of the rebellion, Gaston, Duke of Orleans, the brother of Louis XIII, surrenders.

title: Battle of the Alte Veste
event: September 9 – Thirty Years' War – Besieged by Wallenstein at Nuremberg, Swedish king Gustav Adolph attempts to break the siege, but is defeated in the Battle of the Alte Veste.

title: Battle of Lützen (1632)
event: November 16 – Thirty Years' War – Battle of Lützen – Swedish king Gustav II Adolf leads an assault on Wallenstein's army, but is killed early in the battle. Despite the king's death, the Swedish commanders manage to rally the army and eventually defeat Wallenstein's army. As a result, Wallenstein withdraws from Saxony.

title: Poznań
event: The Jews of Poznań are granted the privilege of forbidding Christians to enter into their city quarter.

title: Kinmen
event: October 22 – Ming dynasty fight with Dutch East India Company sea battle of gulf Kinmen, Zheng Zhilong won great victory.

title: Curaçao
event: Curaçao is captured by the Dutch.

title: Green Bay (Lake Michigan)
event: Jean Nicolet becomes the first European to set foot in Wisconsin. He is in search of a water-route to the Pacific when he lands at Green Bay, most likely in August of 1634.

title: Oberammergau Passion Play
event: The first decennial performance of the Oberammergau Passion Plays is held.

title: North America
event: In Maryland, the Jesuits Andrew White, John Altham Gravenor, and Thomas Gervase arrived with Lord Leonard Calvert on March 25, 1634, and in that year established an institution of higher learning at St. Mary's which later became known as Georgetown University, North America's oldest university.

title: Portugal
event: Suspecting that Patriarch Afonso Mendes played a part in the Portuguese assault on Mombasa, Emperor Fasilides expels him and several Jesuit missionaries from Ethiopia.

title: St. Mary's City Maryland
event: March 25 – The first settlers arrive in St. Mary's City, Maryland (led by Lord Baltimore), the fourth permanent settlement in British North America.

title: Quebec
event: July 4 – The city of Trois-Rivières is founded in New France (later the Canadian province of Quebec).

title: France
event: Guadeloupe and Martinique are colonized by France.

title: Dominica
event: Dominica is claimed by France.

title: Yemen
event: The Ottomans are expelled from Yemen.

title: Massachusetts
event: Boston Latin School, the oldest school in the United States of America, is founded in Boston, Massachusetts.

title: Constantinople
event: April 13 – Maronite warlord Fah-al-Din II is executed in Constantinople.

title: Narragansett Bay
event: August 25 – The Great Colonial Hurricane of 1635 strikes Narragansett Bay as a possible Category 3 hurricane, killing over 46 people.

title: Rhode Island
event: October 9 – Rhode Island founder Roger Williams is banished from Massachusetts Bay Colony as a religious dissident, after speaking out against punishments for religious offenses and giving away Native American land.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: November 15 – Thomas Parr, dead at the alleged age of 152, is buried in Westminster Abbey.

title: Gondar
event: Emperor Fasilides of Ethiopia founds the city of Gondar, which becomes the capital of Ethiopia for the next two centuries.

title: Harvard University
event: Harvard University is established by the colonial Massachusetts legislature.

title: Massachusetts
event: The first American ancestor of John Adams, Henry Adams, emigrates to Massachusetts.

title: Shenyang
event: Manchus occupy the Liaoning region in north China, select Shenyang (Mukden) as their capital, and proclaim the new Qing Dynasty (pure).

title: Rhode Island
event: In the American colonies, Roger Williams (theologian) founds Rhode Island.

title: Kahal Zur Israel Synagogue
event: The first synagogue of the New World, Kahal Zur Israel Synagogue, is founded in Recife by the Dutch.

title: France
event: August 15 – The Spanish besiege Corbie, France.

title: Dedham Massachusetts
event: August 15 – The covenant of the Town of Dedham, Massachusetts is first signed.

title: North America
event: September 8 –  A vote of the Great and General Court of the Massachusetts Bay Colony establishes Harvard College as the first college founded in North America.

title: France
event: France places a few missionaries in the Côte d'Ivoire, a country it will rule more than 200 years later.

title: Kingdom of England
event: The Kingdom of England wages war against the Mashantucket Pequots.

title: Taunton Massachusetts
event: Elizabeth Poole becomes the first woman to have founded a town (Taunton, Massachusetts) in the Americas.

title: Joseon Dynasty
event: Second Manchu invasion of Korea: The Joseon court reluctantly submits to the Manchu's demands of vassalhood while continuing to pledge loyalty to the Chinese Ming Dynasty.

title: Dutch Republic
event: February 3 – Tulip mania collapses in the United Provinces (now the Netherlands).

title: Guangzhou
event: June 27 – The first English venture to China is undertaken by Admiral Weddell, who sails into port in Macau and Canton during the late Ming Dynasty. The voyages are for trade, which is dominated there by the Portuguese (then combined with the power of Spain).

title: Muchalls Castle
event: Covenanters meet at Muchalls Castle to compose responses to the Bishops of Aberdeen.

title: Mauritius
event: The Netherlands colonizes Mauritius.

title: Belize
event: Shipwrecked sailors from England found the first known European settlement in Belize.

title: Finland
event: The Finnish postal service, ''Suomen Posti'', is founded.

title: China
event: The Beijing Gazette makes an official switch in its production process of newspapers, from woodblock printing to movable type printing; private newspapers in Ming Dynasty China were first mentioned in 1582.

title: Baghdad
event: Sultan Murad IV captures Baghdad.

title: Delhi
event: Shah Jahan transfers the capital of the Moghul Empire from Agra to Delhi.

title: Belize River
event: Buccaneer Peter Wallace called Ballis by the Spanish, settles near and perhaps gives his name to the Belize River.

title: Essex County Massachusetts
event: John Spofford originator and forefather of the decedents of Spofford family arrives in and is one of the first people to establish Rowely, Essex County, Massachusetts.

title: Rhode Island
event: March – Anne Hutchinson is banished from the Massachusetts Bay Colony for heresy and goes to Rhode Island.

title: France
event: March 3 –  a mercenary army under Bernard de Saxe-Weimar fighting for France defeats imperial forces at the Battle of Rheinfelden.

title: France
event: March 5 – Thirty Years' War – The Treaty of Hamburg is signed by France and Sweden.

title: Delaware
event: March 29 – The Swedish arrive on the ships ''Kalmare Nyckel'' and ''Fågel Grip'' to America, to establish the first settlement in Delaware, called New Sweden.

title: New Hampshire
event: April 3 – John Wheelwright is banished from Boston and founds Exeter New Hampshire.

title: Portugal
event: May 23 – signing of the Kandyan Treaty between the Singhala King Rajasimha II and the Dutch to rid Ceylon of the Portuguese.

title: Battle of Kallo
event: June 20 –  Spanish troops under Ferdinand of Austria defeat a much larger Dutch force near Antwerp at the Battle of Kallo during the Eighty Years War.

title: Widecombe-in-the-Moor
event: October 21 – The Great Thunderstorm breaks out in Widecombe-in-the-Moor, England.

title: Church of Scotland
event: November – The General Assembly of the Church of Scotland is summoned to Glasgow by King Charles I of England.

title: France
event: December 18 – Mazarin becomes first adviser to French potentate Richelieu on the death of Leclerc du Tremblay.

title: Causey Mounth
event: June – The first battle of the Bishops' Wars is fought by Earl Marischal and the Marquess of Montrose, when they lead a Covenanter army of 9,000 men past Muchalls Castle over the Causey Mounth to fight at the Bridge of Dee.

title: Casiquiare canal
event: The Casiquiare canal, a river forming a natural canal between the Amazon River and Orinoco River basins, is first encountered by Europeans.

title: Cambridge Massachusetts
event: The first printing press in North America is started in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

title: Okhotsk
event: Russian Cossacks advance over the Urals to the Pacific, to Okhotsk.

title: Montreal
event: Montreal is first settled.

title: Iraq
event: Treaty of Zuhab between Ottoman (Turkish) Empire and Safavid Persia. Modern Turkey-Iran and Iraq-Iran border lines.

title: Connecticut
event: January 14 – Connecticut's first constitution, the ''Fundamental Orders,'' is adopted.

title: Taunton Massachusetts
event: March 3 – The early settlement of Taunton, Massachusetts is incorporated as a town.

title: Harvard University
event: March 13 – Harvard University is named for clergyman John Harvard.

title: Battle of the Downs
event: October 31 – Naval Battle of the Downs: A Republic of the United Provinces fleet decisively defeats a Spanish fleet in English waters.

title: Finland
event: The first university in Finland, the Academy of Åbo, is founded in Turku.

title: North America
event: The first book (the ''Bay Psalm Book'') is printed in North America.

title: Nagasaki
event: August 9 – Forty-one Spanish delegates to Japan at Nagasaki are beheaded.

title: House of Commons of England
event: The English House of Commons pass the Triennial Act, which compels the king to summon Parliament every three years in England.

title: Dejima
event: The Dutch found a trading colony on Dejima, near Nagasaki, Japan.

title: Portugal
event: Portugal is ousted from Malacca by the Dutch.

title: Beijing
event: A massive epidemic breaks out in northern and central China, just 3 years before the fall of the Ming Dynasty. It races south down along the Grand Canal of China and the densely populated settlements there, from the northern terminus at Beijing, to the fertile Jiangnan region. In some local areas and towns it wipes out 90% of the local populace.

title: Brazil
event: July 12 – Portugal and the Dutch Republic sign a Treaty of Offensive and Defensive Alliance. The treaty is not respected by both parties and as a consequence it has no effect in the Portuguese colonies (Brazil and Angola) that are under Dutch rule.

title: Siege of Hull (1642)
event: July – First English Civil War: Charles I besieges Hull in an attempt to gain control of its arsenal.

title: Taiwan
event: The Dutch drive Spain from Taiwan.

title: Beijing
event: The Manchu under their leader Huang Taiji raid the Ming Chinese province of Shandong from their base in Manchuria. Two years later Beijing falls to rebels, the Chongzhen Emperor commits suicide, and the Shunzhi Emperor becomes the first Qing Emperor to rule over China proper.

title: Yellow River
event: Kaifeng flood of 1642: Some 300,000 people die when the Ming Dynasty army in China intentionally breaks the dams and dykes of the Yellow River to break the siege by the large rebel force of Li Zicheng.

title: Brazil
event: Isaac Aboab da Fonseca is appointed rabbi in Pernambuco, Brazil, thus becoming the first rabbi of the Americas.

title: Montreal
event: May 17 – Sieur de Maisonneuve founds the Ville Marie de Montreal.

title: Battle of Lostwithiel
event: August 21 – First Battle of Lostwithiel.

title: Battle of Edgehill
event: October 23 – First English Civil War – Battle of Edgehill: Royalists and Parliamentarians battle to a draw.

title: London
event: November 13 – First English Civil War – Battle of Turnham Green: The Royalist forces withdraw in face of the Parliamentarian army and fail to take London.

title: Tasmania
event: November 24 – Abel Tasman becomes the first European to discover the island Van Diemen's Land (later renamed Tasmania).

title: New Zealand
event: December 13 – Abel Tasman is the first recorded European to sight New Zealand.

title: France
event: Baden-Baden is pillaged by the French.

title: Mount Royal
event: Paul Chomedey de Maisonneuve places the first cross atop Mount Royal.

title: China
event: Hong Taiji, Emperor of the Qing Dynasty of the Manchu dies and is succeeded by his 5-year-old son, the later Shunzhi Emperor of China.

title: Rhode Island
event: Roger Williams, a co-founder of Rhode Island, publishes ''A Key into the Language of America''.

title: Fiji
event: February 6 – Abel Tasman discovers the Fiji islands.

title: Cheshire
event: March 13 – First English Civil War – First Battle of Middlewich: The Roundheads rout the Cavaliers at Middlewich in Cheshire, England.

title: France
event: May 19 –  Battle of Rocroi: The French defeat the Spanish at Rocroi, France.

title: Yorkshire
event: June 30 – First English Civil War – Battle of Adwalton Moor: Cavaliers (supporters of Charles I) gain control of Yorkshire.

title: Battle of Lansdowne
event: July 5 – First English Civil War – Battle of Lansdowne: Royalists and Parliamentarians battle to a draw.

title: Battle of Roundway Down
event: July 13 – First English Civil War – Battle of Roundway Down: In England, Lord Henry Wilmot, Earl of Rochester, commanding the Royalist forces, wins a crushing victory over the Parliamentarian Sir William Waller.

title: France
event: November 24 – Battle of Tuttlingen: France is defeated by forces of the Holy Roman Empire.

title: Warsaw
event: Kolumna Zygmunta (Sigismund's Column) is erected in Warsaw to commemorate King Sigismund III Vasa, who moved the capital of Poland from Kraków to Warsaw in 1596.

title: Jamestown Settlement
event: Opechancanough leads the Powhatan Indians in an unsuccessful uprising against the English at Jamestown. This is the last such Indian rebellion of the region.

title: Cheshire
event: January 26 – First English Civil War – Battle of Nantwich: The Parliamentarians defeat the Royalists, allowing them to end the 6-week Siege of Nantwich in Cheshire, England.

title: Australia
event: February–August – Explorer Abel Tasman's second expedition for the Dutch East India Company maps the north coast of Australia.

title: Beijing
event: April 25 – A popular Chinese rebellion led by Li Zicheng sacks Beijing, prompting Chongzhen, the last emperor of the Ming Dynasty, to commit suicide.

title: Beijing
event: June 6 – The invading Manchu army, with the help of Ming general Wu Sangui, captures Beijing, China. This marks the beginning of the Qing Dynasty (also known as the Manchu Dynasty), the last imperial dynasty of China.

title: Battle of Marston Moor
event: July 2 – English Civil War – Battle of Marston Moor: The Parliamentarians crush the Royalists, ending Charles I's hold on the north of England.

title: Battle of Tippermuir
event: September 1 – English Civil War – Battle of Tippermuir: Montrose defeats Elcho's Covenanters, reviving the Royalist cause in Scotland.

title: Battle of Lostwithiel
event: September 2 – English Civil War – Second Battle of Lostwithiel: Charles I and the Royalists gain their last major victory.

title: Raglan Castle
event: The Siege of Raglan Castle occurs during the English Civil War.

title: Lahore Fort
event: In the Mughal Empire, Shah Jahan builds the Pearl Mosque at Lahore Fort.

title: Bristol
event: March 4 – English Civil War: Prince Rupert leaves Oxford for Bristol.

title: House of Lords
event: April 3 – The House of Lords passes the Self-Denying Ordinance.

title: Battle of Auldearn
event: May 9 – Battle of Auldearn: The Covenanters are defeated by Montrose.

title: Kingdom of England
event: June 14 – English Civil War – Battle of Naseby: 12,000 Royalist forces are beaten by 15,000 Parliamentarian soldiers.

title: Battle of Langport
event: July 10 – English Civil War – Battle of Langport: Cromwell wins at Somerset.

title: Halland
event: August 13 – The Treaty of Brömsebro is signed between Sweden and Denmark-Norway, ceding Jemtland, Herjedalen, Gotland and Ösel (Saaremaa) to Sweden, and holding the province of Halland for a period of 30 years as a guarantee.

title: Battle of Philiphaugh
event: September 13 – Battle of Philiphaugh: Covenanters defeat Montrose at Selkirk.

title: Battle of Rowton Heath
event: September 24 – English Civil War – Battle of Rowton Heath: Parliamentarians defeat the Royalist cavalry.

title: Hôtel-Dieu de Montréal
event: October 8: Jeanne Mance founds the Hôtel-Dieu de Montréal, the first hospital in North America.

title: Bourne Lincolnshire
event: October 11 – English Civil War:  The re-fortification of Bourne, Lincolnshire Castle begins against a threatened Royalist attack.

title: Battle of Torrington
event: February 16 – First English Civil War – The Battle of Great Torrington, Devon, the last major battle of the conflict, is fought.

title: Massachusetts
event: February 28 – Roger Scott is tried in Massachusetts for sleeping in church.

title: Massachusetts
event: March 6 – Joseph Jenkes, in Massachusetts, receives the first colonial machine patent.

title: Oxford
event: April 27 – King Charles I flees from Oxford.

title: Bredevoort
event: July 12 – Lightning strikes the gunpowder tower of the castle of Bredevoort, causing an explosion that destroys parts of the castle and the town, killing Lord Haersolte of Bredevoort and his family, as well as others. Only one son, Anthonie, who is not home that day, survives.

title: Raglan Castle
event: August 19 – English Civil War – Raglan Castle surrenders to General Fairfax in after a 3 month siege.  The castle is later destroyed.

title: Massachusetts
event: November 4 – Massachusetts enacts the death penalty for having a rebellious child.

title: Aberystwyth
event: Aberystwyth Castle is razed to the ground by Parliamentarian troops.

title: France
event: March 14 – Thirty Years' War: Bavaria, Cologne, France and Sweden sign the Truce of Ulm.

title: 1647 Santiago earthquake
event: May 13 – 1647 Santiago earthquake rattles Chile.

title: London
event: August – The New Model Army marches to London.

title: Ireland
event: August 8 – Battle of Dungan's Hill: Irish forces are defeated by English Parliamentary forces.

title: Battle of Stirling (1648)
event: Battle of Stirling (1648) took place.

title: Agra Fort
event: In India, building of the Red Fort is completed.

title: North America
event: Semyon Dezhnev discovers the Bering Strait between Asia and North America.

title: Prague Castle
event: The west bank of Prague (including the Prague Castle) is occupied and looted by Swedish armies.

title: Dutch Republic
event: January 30 – The Dutch and the Spanish sign the Treaty of Munster, ending the Eighty Years' War. The Spanish Empire recognizes the Dutch Republic of United Netherlands as a sovereign state, (governed by the House of Orange-Nassau and the Estates General) which was before a province of the Spanish Empire.

title: Brazil
event: April 19 – The Portuguese army defeats the Dutch army in the north of Brazil.

title: Muscat Oman
event: August – The Arabs besieged Muscat, Oman

title: Saint Martin
event: November 11 – France and the Netherlands agree that Mto divide the island of Sint Maarten/Saint Martin.

title: London
event: December 11 – Pride's Purge occurs in England, with elements of the New Model Army, under the leadership of Oliver Cromwell invading London and expelling a majority of the Long Parliament, resulting in the creation of the Rump Parliament.

title: Ulan Bator
event: Urga is founded (now Mongolia's capital).

title: France
event: King Charles I of England, Scotland and Ireland is beheaded. His widow Henrietta Maria returns to her native France.

title: Ireland
event: The Commonwealth of England, a republican form of government, replaces the monarchy as the form of government of England and later of Scotland and Ireland. Members of the Long Parliament serve as government.

title: Ireland
event: Prince Charles Stuart declares himself King Charles II of England, Scotland and Ireland. At the time, none of the three kingdoms recognize him as ruler.

title: France
event: March 11 – The Frondeurs (rebels) and the French government sign the Peace of Rueil.

title: House of Lords
event: March 19 – The House of Commons passes an act abolishing the House of Lords, declaring that it is ''useless and dangerous to the people of England''.

title: Italy
event: September 2 – The Italian city of Castro is completely destroyed by the forces of Pope Innocent X, ending the Wars of Castro.

title: Palio di Siena
event: The first modern Palio horserace is held in Siena.

title: France
event: Jews are allowed to return to France and England.

title: Portugal
event: Abyssinia deports Portuguese diplomats and missionaries.

title: Sharon Massachusetts
event: The town of Sharon, Massachusetts is founded.

title: Beijing
event: Estimation: Istanbul becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Beijing.[http://geography.about.com/library/weekly/aa011201a.htm]

title: Battle of Carbisdale
event: April 27 – Battle of Carbisdale: A Royalist army invades mainland Scotland from the Orkney Islands but is defeated by a Covenanter army.

title: Ireland
event: June 23 – Claimant King Charles II of England, Scotland and Ireland arrives in Scotland, the only of the three Kingdoms that has accepted him as ruler.

title: Battle of Dunbar (1650)
event: September 3 – Third English Civil War: Battle of Dunbar (1650).

title: London
event: September 29 – Henry Robinson opens his ''Office of Addresses and Encounters'' (the first historically documented dating service) in Threadneedle Street, London.

title: Dutch Republic
event: November 4 – William III of Orange becomes Prince of the House of Orange the moment of his birth, succeeding his father who had died a few days earlier. He doesn't become stadtholder, so the United Provinces become a true republic.

title: Gresham's School
event: December 25 – Thomas Cooper, former Usher of Gresham's School, England, is hanged as a Royalist rebel.

title: Buise
event: Possible year of the disappearance of the island Buise in St. Peter's Flood.

title: France
event: Fronde civil war in France (1648–1653)

title: Battle of Worcester
event: September 3 –  English Civil War – Battle of Worcester: Charles II of England is defeated in the last major battle of the war.

title: Massachusetts
event: October 14 – Laws are passed in Massachusetts forbidding poor people from adopting excessive styles of dress.

title: France
event: Fronde civil war in France (1648–1653)

title: Cape of Good Hope
event: April 6 – Dutch sailor Jan van Riebeeck establishes a resupply camp for the Dutch East India Company at the Cape of Good Hope, and founds Cape Town.

title: North America
event: May 18 – Rhode Island passes the first law in North America making slavery illegal.

title: Dutch Republic
event: August 26 – First Anglo-Dutch War – Battle of Plymouth: A fleet from the Commonwealth of England attacks an outward-bound convoy of the United Provinces, escorted by 23 men-of-war and 6 fire ships commanded by Vice-Commodore Michiel de Ruyter.

title: North Sea
event: October 8 – First Anglo-Dutch War – Battle of the Kentish Knock: The battle is fought near the shoal called the Kentish Knock in the North Sea, about 30 km from the mouth of the River Thames.

title: Taj Mahal
event: The Taj Mahal mausoleum is completed.

title: New York City
event: February 2 – New Amsterdam (later renamed New York City) is incorporated.

title: Battle of the Gabbard
event: June 12–June 13 – First Anglo-Dutch War – Battle of the Gabbard: The English navy defeats the Dutch fleet, which loses 17 ships.

title: Texel
event: August 8–August 10 – Battle of Scheveningen: The final naval battle of the First Anglo-Dutch War is fought, between the fleets of the Commonwealth of England and the United Provinces; The English navy defeats the Dutch fleet off the Texel.

title: Ireland
event: December 16 – Oliver Cromwell becomes Lord Protector of England, Scotland and Ireland.

title: New York City
event: August 22 – Twenty-three Jewish refugees from Brazil settle in New Amsterdam, forming the nucleus of what would be the largest urban Jewish community in history, the Jewish community of New York City.

title: Delft
event: October 12 – Carel Fabritius, the most promising student of Rembrandt, dies aged 32 in an explosion at the arsenal at Delft. The Delft Explosion devastates the city in the Netherlands, killing more than 100.

title: Delaware
event: August – The governor of New Netherland, Peter Stuyvesant, attacks the New Sweden (Delaware) colony.

title: Leiden University Library
event: The ''Bibliotheca Thysiana'' is erected, the only surviving 17th century example in the Netherlands of a building designed as a library.

title: Manhattan
event: April 26 – The Dutch West India Company denies Peter Stuyvesant's request to exclude Jews from New Amsterdam (Manhattan).

title: Jamaica
event: May 10 – English troops land on Jamaica.

title: Vilnius
event: July 31 – Russo-Polish War (1654–1667): The Russian army enters the capital of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, Vilnius, which it holds for 6 years.

title: Warsaw
event: September 8 – Swedish King Karl X Gustav occupies Warsaw (Poland).

title: Delaware
event: September 26 – Peter Stuyvesant recaptures Dutch Ft. Casimir and defeats the New Sweden (Delaware) colony.

title: Lublin
event: October 15 – The Jews of Lublin are massacred.

title: France
event: November 3 – England and France sign military and economic treaties.

title: Vergulde Draeck
event: July – In an attempt to rescue survivors of the ''Vergulde Draeck'', a search party is sent ashore, in ''Goede Hoop'''s boat, which smashes against rocks and sinks: 8 sailors drown; 3 more disappear ashore.

title: Shropshire
event: Adams' Grammar School in Shropshire, England is founded by William Adams.

title: Colombo
event: The Dutch capture the city of Colombo in Sri Lanka.

title: Cape of Good Hope
event: April 28 – The ship ''Vergulde Draeck'' is wrecked off Ledge Point, Western Australia after it departs the Cape of Good Hope; rescue missions fail to find survivors.

title: Italy
event: The Accademia del Cimento is founded in Florence, Italy (the first equivalent to a scientific research center).

title: France
event: Coffee is introduced to France.

title: London
event: January 8 – Miles Sindercombe, would-be-assassin of Oliver Cromwell, and his group are captured in London.

title: Jamaica
event: February – Admiral Robert Blake defeats the Spanish West Indian Fleet in a battle over the seizure of Jamaica.

title: France
event: March 23 – France and England form an alliance against Spain; England receives Dunkirk.

title: New York City
event: April 20 – The Jews of New Amsterdam (later New York City) are granted freedom of religion as full citizens.{{Citation neededdate=September 2009}}

title: New York
event: December 27 –  The Flushing Remonstrance is signed in New Amsterdam at the site of the future Flushing Town Hall (built 1862) in New York.

title: France
event: France joins England in the war against Spain, which began in 1654.

title: Portugal
event: Portuguese traders are expelled from Ceylon by Dutch invaders.

title: Taj Mahal
event: After his father Shah Jahan completes the Taj Mahal, his son Aurangzeb deposes him as ruler of the Mughal Empire.

title: Madagascar
event: The Dutch in the Cape Colony start to import slaves from India and South-East Asia (later from Madagascar).

title: Tower of London
event: January 13 – Edward Sexby, who had plotted against Oliver Cromwell, dies in the Tower of London.

title: Denmark
event: February 6 – Swedish troops of Charles X Gustav of Sweden cross The Great Belt (Storebælt) in Denmark over frozen sea.

title: Denmark
event: February 26 – The peace between Sweden and Denmark is concluded in Roskilde by the Treaty of Roskilde, under which Denmark is forced to cede significant territory.

title: Jepara
event: March 22 – The ship ''Waeckende Boey'' is wrecked on the coast of Java; the 4 survivors walk overland to Jepara.

title: Ireland
event: September 3 – Oliver Cromwell dies and his son Richard assumes his father's former position as Lord Protector of England, Scotland and Ireland.

title: India
event: Drought occurs in India.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: February 16 – The first known cheque (400 pounds) is written (on display at Westminster Abbey).

title: Artois
event: November 7 – Treaty of Pyrenees: French King Louis XIV and King Philip IV of Spain agree to French acquisition of Roussillon and most of Artois, and formally end their 24-year war.

title: Denmark
event: November 25 – Dutch forces under Michiel de Ruyter free the Danish city of Nyborg from Swedish conquest (earlier in the year).

title: Denmark
event: Sweden recovers its southern provinces from Denmark.

title: France
event: The expulsion of the Carib indigenous people from Martinique is carried out by French occupying forces.

title: Hopkins School
event: Hopkins School is founded.

title: Denmark
event: Absolutism is established in Denmark.

title: London
event: January – Colonel George Monck with his regiment crosses from Scotland to England at the village of Coldstream and begins his advance towards London in support of the English Restoration.

title: London
event: February 2 – George Monck and his regiment arrive in London.

title: London
event: May 29 – King Charles II of England arrives in London and assumes the throne, marking the beginning of the English Restoration.

title: Winchester Cathedral
event: August 19  –  Dr Edward Stanley preached the sermon in the nave of Winchester Cathedral to commemorate the return of the Chapter following the English Restoration.

title: Gresham College
event: November 28 – At Gresham College, 12 men, including Christopher Wren, Robert Boyle, John Wilkins, and Sir Robert Moray meet after a lecture by Wren and decide to found a College for the Promoting of Physico-Mathematicall Experimentall Learning (later known as the Royal Society).

title: China
event: February 5 – The Shunzhi Emperor of the Qing Dynasty of China dies and is succeeded by his son the Kangxi Emperor.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: April 23 – King Charles II of England, Scotland, Ireland is crowned in Westminster Abbey, for the second time.

title: Dutch Republic
event: August 6 – Portugal and the Dutch Republic sign the Treaty of The Hague, whereby New Holland is formally ceded to Portugal by the Dutch Republic.

title: London
event: John Graunt, in one of the earliest uses of statistics, publishes statistical information about births and deaths in London.

title: Vynohradiv
event: January 23 – Battle of Nagyszőllős: János Kemény of Transylvania is killed.

title: Kingdom of Tungning
event: February 1 – The Chinese general Koxinga seizes the Dutch Fort Zealandia on the island of Taiwan after a 9-month siege, then establishes the Kingdom of Tungning. In response, the Kangxi Emperor of the mainland Qing Dynasty migrates all residents along the southern coast by 50 miles.

title: London
event: May 9 – Samuel Pepys witnesses a Punch and Judy show in London (the first on record).

title: Tangier
event: May 30 – Catherine of Braganza marries Charles II of England; as part of the dowry, Portugal cedes Bombay and Tangier to England.

title: France
event: October 27 – Charles II of England sells Dunkirk to France for £40,000 (or 2.5 million livres).

title: London
event: The Theatre Royal, Drury Lane opens in London.

title: Surat
event: The Marathas sack Surat.

title: Surat
event: January 5 – Battle of Surat: The Maratha Chhatrapati Shivaji is defeated by the Inayat Khan of Mughal.

title: Kingdom of England
event: March 12 – New Jersey becomes a colony of England.

title: Battle of Saint Gotthard (1664)
event: August 1 – Battle of Saint Gotthard: The Ottoman Empire is defeated by an Austrian army led by Raimondo Montecuccoli, resulting in the Peace of Vasvár.

title: Virginia
event: ''Ye Bare & Ye Cubbe'', the first play in English in the American colonies, is performed in Pungoteague, Virginia.

title: Derby plague of 1665
event: The Derby plague of 1665 leaves its mark.

title: Réunion
event: Colonisation of Réunion begins with the French East India Company sending 20 settlers.

title: France
event: January 5 – The ''Journal des sçavans'' begins publication in France.

title: Bucharest
event: March 16 – Bucharest allows Jews to settle in the city in exchange for an annual tax of 16 guilders.

title: New York City
event: June 12 – England installs a municipal government in New York City (the former Dutch settlement of New Amsterdam).

title: London
event: July 7 – King Charles II of England leaves London with his entourage, fleeing the Great Plague. He moves his court to Salisbury, then Exeter.

title: University of Kiel
event: October 5 – The University of Kiel is founded.

title: Portugal
event: October 29 – Battle of Mbwila: Portuguese forces defeat and kill King António I of Kongo.

title: Chittagong
event: Expulsion of the Portuguese from the Bengal port city of Chittagong by Mughal forces of Emperor Aurangzeb under General Bujurg Umed Khan and renaming the city as Islamabad.

title: Lund University
event: Lund University is founded in Lund, Sweden.

title: North America
event: Jean Talon completes a census of New France, the first census in North America.

title: St. James's Day Battle
event: July 25 (julian calendar)/August 4 (gregorian calendar) – Second Anglo-Dutch War: English fleet defeats the Dutch under Michiel de Ruyter at St. James's Day Battle.

title: Holmes's Bonfire
event: August 9 – Rear Admiral Robert Holmes leads a raid on the Dutch island of Terschelling, destroying 150 merchant ships in the Vlie estuary, and pillaging the town of West-Terschelling, an act later referred to as ''Holmes's Bonfire''.

title: London Bridge
event: September 2 – Great Fire of London: A large fire breaks out in London in the house of Charles II's baker on Pudding Lane near London Bridge.  The fire burns for 3 days, destroying 10,000 buildings including St. Paul's Cathedral, but only 6 people are known to have died.

title: Great Fire of London
event: September 5 – The Great Fire of London ends.

title: Republic of Ragusa
event: April 6 – 1667 Dubrovnik earthquake:  Earthquake in Republic of Ragusa which kills one fifth of the population.

title: Franche-Comté
event: May 24 – The War of Devolution begins; France invades Flanders and Franche-Comté.

title: Sheerness
event: June 12–June 17 – Raid on the Medway: A Dutch fleet under Admiral Michiel de Ruyter burns Sheerness, sails up the River Medway, raids Chatham dockyards and tows away the royal flagship ''The Royal Charles''.

title: France
event: July 31 – Second Anglo-Dutch War – The Treaty of Breda ends the war, and recognizes Acadia as a French possession.

title: Caucasus
event: November 25 – A devastating earthquake rocks Caucasia, killing 80,000 people.

title: Dutch Republic
event: January – The Triple Alliance of 1668 is formed between England, Sweden and the United Provinces.

title: Panama City
event: Mid-July – Henry Morgan sacks Portobello and Panama City; the lack of booty from the latter attack leads to the city being burned.

title: King William's College
event: Bishop Isaac Barrow founds the Bishop Barrow Trust to establish a university on the Isle of Man (King William's College).

title: Gondar
event: Emperor Yohannes I of Ethiopia convenes a church council in Gondar, which decides to expel all Roman Catholics in Ethiopia.

title: Lisbon
event: February 13 – In Lisbon, a peace treaty is established between Afonso VI of Portugal and Carlos II of Spain, by mediation of Charles II of England, where the legitimacy of the Portuguese monarch is recognized. Portugal yields Ceuta to Spain.

title: Bengal
event: Famine in Bengal kills 3 million people.

title: Mount Etna
event: March 11 – Mount Etna erupts, destroying the town of Nicolosi and killing 20,000 people.

title: Crete
event: June 25 – Francis of Vendome, Duke of Beaufort, disappears during a battle in the Siege of Candia in Crete.

title: University of Zagreb
event: September 23 – Leopold I Habsburg grants the status and privileges of a university to the Jesuit Academy in Zagreb, the precursor to the modern University of Zagreb.

title: Jamaica
event: England gains formal possession of Jamaica.

title: Middlesex
event: January 21 – Highwayman Claude Duval is executed in Tyburn, Middlesex.

title: Les Invalides
event: November 24 – Louis XIV of France authorises work to commence on the construction of ''Les Invalides''.

title: Newport Rhode Island
event: December – The first Seventh Day Baptist church in America is founded at Newport, Rhode Island.

title: Tower of London
event: May 9 – Thomas Blood, disguised as a clergyman, attempts to steal the Crown Jewels from the Tower of London. He is immediately caught because he is too drunk to run with the loot. He is later condemned to death and then mysteriously pardoned and exiled by King Charles II.

title: Dutch Republic
event: March 12 – The Kingdom of England declares war on the Dutch Republic.

title: Münster (region)
event: June 1 – Münster and Cologne begin their invasion of the Dutch Republic. 1672 becomes known as ''het rampjaar'' (the disaster year) in the Netherlands.

title: Battle of Solebay
event: June 7 – Battle of Solebay, a sea battle between the Dutch Republic and the joined forces of England and France.

title: Rhine
event: June 12 – French forces under king Louis XIV cross the Rhine into the Netherlands. Utrecht (city) is occupied by the French Army.

title: Zeeland
event: July 4 – William III of Orange is appointed Stadtholder of Holland, and in Zeeland on the 16th.

title: Holland
event: August 20 – Johan de Witt, Grand Pensionary of Holland, is slaughtered by a mob in The Hague.

title: St. Augustine Florida
event: October – Spain begins construction on the masonry fort that will become Castillo de San Marcos, to protect St. Augustine, Florida.

title: France
event: France begins its expedition against Ceylon.

title: Chelsea Physic Garden
event: Chelsea Physic Garden, the second oldest botanic garden in England, is founded by the Society of Apothecaries for the study of medicinal and other plants.

title: Aegean Sea
event: The Stalactic grotto of Antiparos (Aegean Sea) is discovered.

title: Newgate
event: January 22 – Impostor Mary Carleton is hanged in Newgate prison in England for multiple thefts and returning from penal transportation.

title: Society of Jesus
event: May 17 – In America, trader Louis Joliet and Jesuit missionary-explorer Jacques Marquette begin exploring the Mississippi River and the Great Lakes.

title: Dutch Republic
event: June 7 – First Battle of Schooneveld: In a sea battle of the Third Anglo-Dutch War, fought off the Netherlands coast, the Dutch win with the fleet of the United Provinces (commanded by Michiel de Ruyter) against the allied Anglo-French fleet commanded by Prince Rupert of the Rhine.

title: Arkansas
event: June 17 – French explorers Father Jacques Marquette and Louis Joliet reach the headwaters of the Mississippi River and descend to Arkansas.

title: Maastricht
event: July 6 – French troops conquer Maastricht.

title: Denmark
event: July 11 – The Netherlands and Denmark sign a defense treaty.

title: Oxford
event: July 24 – Edmund Halley enters Queen's College at Oxford, as an undergraduate.

title: New York City
event: August 8 – In the American colonies, a Dutch battle fleet of 23 ships demands the surrender of New York City.

title: New York
event: August 9 – Dutch forces under Admiral Cornelis Evertsen de Jonge recapture New York from English (regained by English in following year, 1674).

title: India
event: The East India Company arranges a trading treaty with the Maratha Empire that has recently been founded by Shivaji Bhonsle in central India.

title: New York
event: February 19 – England and the Netherlands sign the Treaty of Westminster. A provision of the agreement transfers the Dutch colony of New Amsterdam to England, which renames it New York.

title: India
event: June 6 – Shivaji is crowned as Chatrapati Shivaji at Raigad Fort in India.

title: Lake Michigan
event: December 4 – Father Jacques Marquette founds a mission on the shores of Lake Michigan to minister to the Illinois people (the mission would later grow into the city of Chicago).

title: France
event: January 5 – Franco-Dutch War – Battle of Turckheim: In Turckheim, Alsace, France, the French defeat Austria and Brandenburg.

title: New England
event: January 29 – John Sassamon, an English-educated Native American Christian, dies at Assawampsett Pond, an event which will trigger a year-long war between English American colonists of New England and Algonquin Native American tribes.

title: Massachusetts
event: June 14–June 25 – Colonial authorities of Rhode Island, Plymouth, and Massachusetts attempt a negotiation with Metacomet (King Philip), leader of the Wampanoags, and seek guarantees of fidelity from the Nipmuck and Narragansett tribes.

title: Pocasset Massachusetts
event: June 26 – June 29 – Wampanoags assault Rehoboth and Taunton; the natives elude colonial troops and leave Mount Hope for Pocasset, Massachusetts. The Mohegan tribe travels to Boston in order to side with the English colonists against the Wampanoags.

title: Connecticut
event: July 15 – The Narragansett tribe signs a peace treaty with Connecticut.

title: Massachusetts
event: July 16 – July 24 – An envoy from Massachusetts attempts to negotiate with the Nipmuck tribe.

title: London
event: August 10 – King Charles II of England places the foundation stone of the Royal Greenwich Observatory in London; construction begins.

title: Northampton Massachusetts
event: September 18 – The Narragansetts sign a treaty with the English in Boston; meanwhile, Massachusetts troops are ambushed near Northampton, Massachusetts.

title: Springfield Massachusetts
event: October 5 – The Pocomtuc tribe attacks and destroys Springfield, Massachusetts.

title: Deer Island (Massachusetts)
event: October 13 – The Massachusetts Council convenes and agrees that all Christian Indians should be ordered to move to Deer Island.

title: New England
event: 12 August – King Philip (Metacomet), the chief of the Wampanoags that had waged war throughout southern New England in a war that bore his name, is killed by an Indian named Alderman, a soldier led by Captain Benjamin Church.

title: New England
event: King Philip's War continues, between the settlers in New England and the indigenous tribes led by Metacomet.

title: India
event: The French East India Company founds its principal Indian base at Pondicherry, on the Coromandel Coast.

title: New England
event: January – Six months into King Philip's War, Metacomet (King Philip), leader of the Algonquin tribe known as the Wampanoag, travels westward to the Mohawk nation, seeking an alliance with the Mohawks against the English colonists of New England; his efforts in creating such an alliance are a failure.

title: Northampton Massachusetts
event: February 14 – Metacomet and his Wampanoags attack Northampton, Massachusetts; meanwhile, the Massachusetts Council debates whether a wall should be erected around Boston.

title: Deer Island (Massachusetts)
event: February 23 – While the Massachusetts Council debates how to handle the Christian Indians they had exiled to Deer Island on October 13, 1675, a coalition of Indians led by Metacomet attacks colonial settlements just 16 km (10 miles) outside of Boston.

title: Cambridge Massachusetts
event: May 31 – The Massachusetts Council finally decides to move the Christian Indians from Deer Island to Cambridge, Massachusetts (approximate date).

title: Connecticut
event: June 12 – The Indian coalition attacks Hadley, Massachusetts, but are repelled by Connecticut troops.

title: Rhode Island
event: July 2 – Major John Talcott and his troops begin sweeping Connecticut and Rhode Island, capturing large numbers of Native Americans from Algonquin tribes and exporting them out of the Thirteen Colonies as slaves.

title: Taunton Massachusetts
event: July 11 – The Wampanoags attack Taunton, Massachusetts, but are repelled by colonists.

title: France
event: July 17 – In France, Marie-Madeleine-Marguerite d'Aubray, Marquise de Brinvilliers is executed for poisoning her father and brothers. The case also scares the king Louis XIV into starting a series of investigations about possible poisonings and witchcraft, later called the Poison affair.

title: Jamestown Virginia
event: September 19 – Jamestown is burned to the ground by the forces of Nathaniel Bacon during Bacon's Rebellion.

title: Massachusetts
event: November 16 – A prison is founded on Nantucket Island in the English colony of Massachusetts.

title: Virginia
event: May 29 – The Treaty of Middle Plantation establishes peace between the Virginia colonists and the local Indians.

title: Denmark
event: May 31 – Danish ships clash with Swedish ships under Niels Juel between Fehmarn and Warnemünde; the Danish defeat the Swedish and capture a number of ships.

title: Denmark
event: July 14 – Battle of Landskrona: Sweden defeats the Danes.

title: France
event: November 16 – French troops occupy Freiburg.

title: Virginia
event: About 1,200 Irish families sail from Barbados to Virginia and the Carolinas.

title: Ireland
event: In Ireland, the Diocese of Kildare is united with Leighlin to form the Diocese of Kildare and Leighlin.

title: Curaçao
event: May 11 – French admiral d'Estrees runs his whole fleet aground in Curaçao.

title: London
event: October 17 – British magistrate Sir Edmund Berry Godfrey is found murdered in Primrose Hill, London. Titus Oates claims it as a proof of his allegations.

title: Niagara Falls
event: European explorers discover Niagara Falls.

title: Duluth Minnesota
event: The city of Duluth, Minnesota is founded.

title: Battle of Drumclog
