event: June 1 – Battle of Drumclog: Scottish Covenanters defeat a small government force.

title: Battle of Bothwell Bridge
event: June 22 – Battle of Bothwell Bridge: The Duke of Monmouth subdues the Covenanters.

title: Niagara River
event: August 7 – The brigantine ''Le Griffon'', commissioned by René Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle, is towed to the southern end of the Niagara River, to become the first ship to sail the upper Great Lakes.

title: Massachusetts
event: November 27 – A fire in Boston, Massachusetts, burns all of the warehouses, 80 houses, and all of the ships in the dockyards.

title: Alsace
event: Chambers of Reunion (French courts under Louis XIV) decide on complete annexation of Alsace.

title: Macau
event: The first Portuguese governor is appointed to Macau.

title: Krakatoa
event: May – The volcano Krakatoa erupts, probably on a relatively small scale.

title: Cambridge Massachusetts
event: July 8 – The first documented tornado in America kills a servant at Cambridge, Massachusetts.

title: London
event: November 17 – Whigs organize pope-burning processions in London.

title: Kandy
event: August – Robert Knox escapes prison in Ceylon, and details his adventures across Kandy and life in the kingdoms of the Tamil country Vanni in his book ''An Historical Relation of the Island Ceylon''.

title: China
event: December – Wu Shifan, grandson of Chinese general Wu Sangui, commits suicide in Yunnan province, ending the 8-year conflict of the Revolt of the Three Feudatories against Qing Dynasty authority in China, then led by the Kangxi Emperor.

title: France
event: France annexes the city of Strasbourg.

title: Port of Honfleur
event: The Port of Honfleur in France is re-modelled by Abraham Duquesne.

title: Pennsylvania
event: March 14 – Charles II of England grants a land charter to William Penn for the area that will later become Pennsylvania.

title: London
event: October 28 –  A London woman is publicly flogged for the crime of involving herself in politics.

title: Royal Hospital Chelsea
event: December 22 – King Charles II of England signs a warrant for the building of the Royal Hospital Chelsea.

title: Pennsylvania
event: The Richard Wall House is built in Pennsylvania.

title: France
event: April 9 – At the mouth of the Mississippi River, near modern Venice, Louisiana, Robert de La Salle buries an engraved plate and a cross, claiming the territory as ''La Louisiane'' for France.

title: Swansea
event: September 14 – Bishop Gore School in Swansea, Wales is founded.

title: Istanbul
event: October 12 – Sultan Mehmed IV departs Istanbul for Adrianople.

title: Pennsylvania
event: October 27 – The city of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania is founded by William Penn.

title: Penghu
event: July 8 – The Qing Dynasty Chinese admiral Shi Lang leads 300 ships with 20,000 troops out of Tongshan, Fujian and sails towards the Kingdom of Tungning, in modern-day Taiwan and Penghu, in order to quell the kingdom in the name of Qing.

title: Vienna
event: July 14 – A 140,000-man Ottoman force arrives at Vienna and starts to besiege the city.

title: Guangzhou
event: The British East India Company receives Chinese permission to build a trading station at Canton. Tea sells in Europe for less than a shilling a pound, but the import duty of 5 shillings makes it too expensive for most English people to afford.

title: Gulf of Mexico
event: July 24 – René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle sails from France, again, with a large expedition designed to establish a French colony on the Gulf of Mexico, at the mouth of the Mississippi River.

title: London
event: September – The first organised street lighting was introduced in London with oil lamps to be lit outside every tenth house on moonless winter nights.

title: China
event: The Chinese army of the Qing Dynasty attacks a Russian post at Albazin, during the reigns of the Kangxi Emperor and the dual Russian rulers Ivan V of Russia and Peter I of Russia. The events lead to the Treaty of Nerchinsk.

title: Madagascar
event: Adam Baldridge finds a pirate base at Île Sainte-Marie in Madagascar.

title: Ireland
event: February 6 – James Stuart, Duke of York becomes James II of England and Ireland and King James VII of Scotland in succession to his brother Charles II (1630–1685), King of Great Britain since 1660.  James II and VII reigns to 1688.

title: Texas
event: February 18 – Fort St. Louis is established by a Frenchman at Matagorda Bay, thus forming the basis for France's claim to Texas.

title: Ireland
event: June 20 – Monmouth Rebellion: James Scott, 1st Duke of Monmouth, illegitimate son of King Charles II of England, Scotland and Ireland declares himself King and heir to his father's Kingdoms as James II of England and Ireland and James VII of Scotland, after already forming his own army and campaigning against his uncle.

title: Battle of Sedgemoor
event: July 6 – Monmouth Rebellion – Battle of Sedgemoor: the armies of King James II of England defeat rebel forces under Monmouth and capture the Duke himself, shortly after the battle.

title: Charborough House
event: A group of conspirators meet at Charborough House in Dorset to plan the overthrow of King James and replace him with the Protestant Dutch Stadtholder, William III of Orange-Nassau.

title: Electoral Palatinate
event: The League of Augsburg is founded in response to claims made by Louis XIV of France on the Palatinate in western Germany.  It comprises the Holy Roman Empire, the Netherlands, Sweden, Spain and the electors of Bavaria, Saxony and the Palatinate.

title: Peloponnese
event: In Greece, Ottoman-occupied Morea (i.e., the Peloponnese) falls to the Venetians.

title: Philippines
event: May 4 – The Municipality of Ilagan is founded in the Philippines.

title: Albany New York
event: July 22 – New York City and Albany, New York are granted city charters by the colonial governor.

title: Buda
event: September 2 – The forces of the Holy League of 1684 liberate Buda from Ottoman Turkish rule (leading to the end of Turkish rule in Hungary during the subsequent years).

title: Parthenon
event: September – The Venetian navy raids the Dalmatian coast and attacks Turkish strongholds in Greece. On 28 September, the Parthenon in Athens is badly damaged when Venetian mortar fire explodes a Turkish powder magazine housed in the building.

title: Cape of Good Hope
event: 31 December – In response to the revocation of the Edict of Nantes in 1685, a group of Huguenots set sail from France and settle in the recently established Dutch colony at the Cape of Good Hope where, using their native skills, they establish the first South African vineyards.

title: Germantown Philadelphia Pennsylvania
event: 18 April (Julian calendar) – The Germantown Quaker Protest Against Slavery is drafted by 4 Germantown Quakers.

title: Brandenburg-Prussia
event: 29 April – Death of Friedrich Wilhelm, the Great Elector of Brandenburg-Prussia.  Friedrich III becomes Elector of Brandenburg-Prussia until 1701, when he becomes the first King of Prussia as Friedrich I.

title: London
event: 5 November – The Glorious Revolution begins: William of Orange lands at Torbay with a multinational force of 15,000 mercenaries.  He makes no claim to the English Crown, saying only that he has come to save Protestantism, and begins a march on London.

title: Lake Onega
event: 23 November – A group of 1,500 Old Believers immolate themselves to avoid capture when troops of the tsar lay siege to their monastery on Lake Onega.

title: Lloyd's of London
event: Edward Lloyd opens the London coffee house that soon becomes a popular meeting place for shipowners, merchants, insurance brokers and underwriters.  In time the business association they form will outgrow the coffee house premises and become Lloyd's of London.

title: Vienna
event: The Ottoman Turks besiege Vienna.

title: Burghley House
event: Antonio Verrio begins work on the Heaven Room at Burghley House.

title: Christmas Island
event: March – William Dampier makes the first recorded visit to Christmas Island.

title: Perthshire
event: 27 July – Battle of Killiecrankie, near Pitlochry in Perthshire, is won by the Highland supporters of King James but their leader Viscount Dundee is killed and the Scottish rebellion fades away.

title: Lachine Quebec
event: 5 August – A force of 1,500 Iroquois attacks the village of Lachine, in New France.

title: Battle of Dunkeld
event: 21 August – Battle of Dunkeld: English Orange Royalists defeat the Jacobite Royalists in Scotland.

title: China
event: 27 August – China and Russia sign the Treaty of Nerchinsk.

title: China
event: 22 November – The Tsar decrees the construction of the Great Siberian Road to China.

title: Nova Scotia
event: Beginning of King William's War (1689–1697) which is the first of four North American Wars until 1763 between English and French colonists, both sides allied to Native American tribes. The nature of the fighting is a series of raids on each other's settlements across the Canadian and New England borders. The English capture Port Royal in Nova Scotia but otherwise there are no real territorial gains: each side would attack, destroy and withdraw.

title: India
event: The British East India Company expands its influence with the establishment of administrative districts called presidencies in the Indian provinces of Bengal, Madras and Bombay, the effective beginning of the company's long rule in India.

title: Kingdom of England
event: February 13 – William III and Mary II are proclaimed co-rulers of England, Scotland and Ireland.

title: Kingdom of England
event: April 11 – William III and Mary II are crowned as King and Queen of England, Scotland and Ireland. Ireland does not recognise them yet, while the Estates of Scotland declare King James VII of Scotland deposed.

title: St Sepulchre-without-Newgate
event: 7 January – The first recorded full peal is rung, at St Sepulchre-without-Newgate in the City of London, marking a new era in change ringing.

title: North America
event: 3 February – The colony of Massachusetts issues the first paper money in America.

title: Ireland
event: June – William III lands in Ireland to confront James VII & II.

title: Battle of Beachy Head (1690)
event: 10 July – Anglo-Dutch navy defeated by the French in the Battle of Beachy Head (also known as the Battle of Bévéziers), giving rise to fears of a Jacobite invasion of England.

title: Battle of the Boyne
event: 12 July – Battle of the Boyne, north of Dublin. James VII & II is defeated and sails back to France. The rebellion in Ireland continues for a further year until the Orange army gains control.

title: Devon
event: 26 July – French landing party raids and burns Teignmouth in Devon. However, with the loss of James VII & II's position in Ireland, any plans for a real invasion are soon shelved and Teignmouth is the last-ever French attack on England.

title: Massachusetts
event: 25 September – The only issue of ''Publick Occurrences'' is published in Boston, Massachusetts, before being suppressed by the colonial authorities.

title: Quebec
event: 6 October–12 October – Massachusetts Puritans led by Sir William Phips besiege the city of Quebec. The siege ends in failure.

title: Italy
event: 29 December – An earthquake hits Anconer in the Papal States, Italy.

title: Hooghly River
event: An Anglo-Moghul treaty allows the British East India Company to establish a fort and trading settlement on the Hooghly River, which becomes Calcutta.

title: Buise
event: Possible year of the disappearance of the island Buise in St. Peter's Flood.

title: Ireland
event: Battle of Aughrim: Williamite troops defeat the Jacobites in Ireland.

title: New England
event: In New England the two separate colonies of Massachusetts Bay Colony and Plymouth Colony are united into a single entity by an act of the King and Queen of England.

title: New York
event: March 20 – Leisler's Rebellion:  A new governor arrives in New York – Jacob Leisler surrenders after a standoff of several hours.

title: London
event: April 9 – A fire at the Palace of Whitehall in London destroys its Stone Gallery.

title: Massacre of Glencoe
event: February 13 – Massacre of Glencoe: The forces of Robert Campbell slaughter 38 members of the Clan MacDonald of Glencoe for allegedly refusing to sign an oath of allegiance to King William III of England.

title: Jamaica
event: June 7 – An earthquake and related tsunami destroy Port Royal, capital of Jamaica and submerges a major part of it – an estimated 2,000 are immediately killed, 2,300 injured, and a probable additional 2,000 die from the diseases which ravage the island in the following months.

title: London
event: September 8 Earthquake in London.

title: Guangzhou
event: China concentrates all its foreign trade on Canton; European ships are forbidden to land anywhere else.

title: Italy
event: The Knights of the Apocalypse are formed in Italy.

title: London
event: Financier Richard Hoare founds Hoare's Bank in London.

title: London
event: The Royal Hospital School is founded in Greenwich, London.

title: Malta
event: January 11 – Mount Etna erupts, causing a devastating earthquake that affects parts of Sicily and Malta.

title: Electoral Palatinate
event: May 18 – Forces of Louis XIV of France attack Heidelberg (now Germany), the Palatine capital.

title: Bank of England
event: 27 July – The Bank of England is founded through Royal Charter by the Whig-dominated Parliament to raise capital by offering safe and steady returns of interest guaranteed by future taxes. A total of £1.2 million is raised for the war effort against Louis XIV by the end of the year to establish the first-ever National Debt.

title: Great Fire of Warwick
event: 5 September – The Great Fire of Warwick.

title: Cape of Good Hope
event: February 5 – The ship ''Ridderschap van Holland'' is lost at sea after it departs the Cape of Good Hope, but does not arrive at Batavia.

title: Brazil
event: February 6 – The colony Quilombo dos Palmares, Brazil is destroyed.

title: St. Augustine Florida
event: After 23 years of construction, Spain completes Castillo de San Marcos to protect St. Augustine, Florida from foreign threats.

title: House of Commons of England
event: English manufacturers call for an embargo on Indian cloth and silk weavers picket the House of Commons.

title: Potala Palace
event: After many years of construction, the Potala Palace is completed.

title: Brazil
event: Gold is discovered in Brazil

title: Gondar
event: April – Fire destroys the Gra Bet (or Left Quarter) of Gondar, the capital of Ethiopia.

title: Estonia
event: A famine wipes out almost a third of the population of Finland and a fifth of the population of Estonia.

title: Don River (Russia)
event: July 18 – The fleet of Tsar Peter I of Russia occupies Azov at the mouth of the Don River.

title: London
event: November 21 – John Vanbrugh's ''Relapse or Virtue in Danger'' premieres in London.

title: Portugal
event: December 24 – The Inquisition burns a number of Marrano Jews in Evora, Portugal.

title: Petén Basin
event: Tayasal, capital of the Itza Maya in the Petén Basin, the last independent Maya polity, is conquered by Spain.

title: Battle of Zenta
event: September 11 – Battle of Zenta – Prince Eugene of Savoy crushes the Ottoman army of Mustafa II and effectively ends Turkish hopes of recovering lost ground in Hungary.

title: Nova Scotia
event: September 20 – The Treaty of Ryswick signed by France and the Grand Alliance to end both the Nine Years' War and King William's War.  The conflict having been inconclusive, the treaty is proposed because the combatants have exhausted their national treasuries.  Louis XIV recognises William III as King of England & Scotland and both sides return territories they have taken in battle.  In North America, the treaty returns Port Royal (Nova Scotia) to France.  In practice, the treaty is little more than a truce; it does not resolve any of the fundamental colonial problems and the peace lasts only five years.

title: London
event: December 2 – St Paul's Cathedral is opened in London.

title: New York
event: The Whigs sponsor Captain Kidd of New York as a privateer against French shipping.

title: Eddystone Rocks
event: The first lighthouse to be built on Eddystone Rocks, near Plymouth, is completed.

title: University of Oxford
event: Humphrey Hody is appointed regius professor of Greek at Oxford.

title: Wallachia
event: Bucharest becomes the capital of Wallachia (now part of Romania).

title: Zanzibar
event: In Africa, Mombasa and Zanzibar are captured by Oman.

title: New England
event: January 1 – The Abenaki tribe and the Massachusetts colonists sign a treaty ending the conflict in New England.

title: London
event: January 4 – The Palace of Whitehall in London is destroyed by fire.

title: Darien scheme
event: July 14 – Darien scheme: The first Scottish settlers leave for an ill-fated colony in Panama.

title: New Orleans
event: October 24 – Iberville and Bienville sail from Brest to the Gulf of Mexico to defend the southern borders of New France; they will eventually found 3 capitals of Louisiana (New France), as the future American cities: Mobile, Biloxi & New Orleans.

title: Rotterdam
event: 22 September – Citizens of Rotterdam strike over the high price of butter.

title: Constantinople
event: January 26 – Treaty of Karlowitz is concluded.  The Republic of Venice, Poland and Austria sign a peace treaty with the Ottoman Empire.  The Ottoman Turks cede to Austria all their former territories in Transylvania, Slavonia, Croatia and the whole of Hungary except for the Banat of Temesvar.  The Peloponnese and Dalmatia are ceded to Venice.  Large parts of the Ukraine are ceded to Poland.  The treaty marks a significant stage in the decline of the Ottoman Empire that has dominated eastern Europe since the fall of Constantinople in 1453.

title: Ocean Springs Mississippi
event: May 1 – Pierre Le Moyne d'Iberville founds the first European settlement in the Mississippi River Valley, at Fort Maurepas (Ocean Springs, Mississippi).

title: Gondar
event: April – Fire destroys many buildings in Gondar, the capital of Ethiopia, including 2 in the palace complex.

title: Rhode Island
event: May – In Rhode Island (American colony), Walter Clarke, former governor 1679–1686, becomes governor again for 14 more years.

title: Mission San Xavier del Bac
event: Mission San Xavier del Bac is founded in New Spain near Tucson, as a Spanish Roman Catholic mission.

title: Libya
event: Lions became extinct in Libya around this date.

title: Vancouver Island
event: January 26 – The Cascadia Earthquake, one of the largest earthquakes on record, ruptures the Cascadia subduction zone offshore from Vancouver Island to northern California, creating a tsunami recorded in written records in Japan and in oral traditions of indigenous peoples in North America. Houses in First Nations communities on Vancouver Island collapsed from the shaking and an entire village on the island's west coast was destroyed, with no survivorsCTV.caaccessdate=2010-02-28date=2010-02-28}}<.

title: Estonia
event: February 12 – The Great Northern War begins with a joint invasion of Swedish territory in Germany and Latvia by Denmark and Poland/Saxony.  Sweden has control of the Baltic Sea and holds territory that includes Finland, Estonia, Latvia and parts of northern Germany.  To challenge Sweden's power, an alliance is formed between Tsar Peter I of Russia, King Frederick IV of Denmark and Augustus II the Strong, King of Poland and Elector of Saxony.  Sweden's ruler is the militaristic Karl XII, known as the Swedish Meteor.

title: New Britain
event: February 27 – The island of New Britain is discovered.

title: Denmark
event: March 1 (Gregorian) – Protestant Germany and Denmark–Norway adopt the Gregorian calendar.

title: East Prussia
event: 18 January – The electorate of Brandenburg-Prussia becomes the Kingdom of Prussia as Elector Frederick III is proclaimed King Frederick I.  Prussia remains part of the Holy Roman Empire.  It consists of Brandenburg, Pomerania and East Prussia.  Berlin is the capital.

title: London
event: 23 May – After being convicted of murdering William Moore and for piracy,  Captain William Kidd is hanged in London.

title: Yale University
event: 9 October – The Collegiate School of Connecticut (later renamed Yale University) is chartered in Old Saybrook, Connecticut.

title: Daugava River
event: Following his victories over Denmark and Russia in 1700, Karl XII of Sweden escalates the conflict in the Great Northern War by an invasion of Poland.  The Swedes defeat the army of Saxony (then a Polish territory) at the River Dvina.

title: France
event: March – The War of the Spanish Succession begins.  It is an international retaliation to Louis XIV’s acceptance in 1700 of the Spanish crown on behalf of his grandson Philip of Anjou, who became Philip V, first Bourbon king of Spain.  Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor forms the Grand Alliance with Great Britain, the Netherlands, Denmark, Portugal, Savoy and Prussia.  Louis XIV allies France with Spain and Bavaria.

title: Fort Maurepas
event: 12 January – In America, ships from Fort Maurepas arrive at Twenty-Seven Mile Bluff to build ''Fort Louis de la Mobile'' (future Mobile, Alabama) to become the capital of French Louisiana.

title: Dutch Republic
event: 8 March (O.S.) – William III dies; Princess Anne Stuart becomes Queen Anne of England, Scotland and Ireland. Anne is the mother of 17 children by her husband Prince George of Denmark but none of them will survive childhood and she will die without heir to enable the Hanoverian Succession.  In the Netherlands, the Staten Generaal do not appoint a new stadtholder and so the United Provinces become a true republic again.

title: France
event: 4 May–14 May – The War of the Spanish Succession widens, as war is declared on France by the Grand Alliance.

title: Rhine
event: June – Queen Anne's Captain-General John Churchill forces the surrender of Kaiserswerth on the Rhine.

title: Florida
event: 27 October – English troops plunder St. Augustine in Florida.

title: Delaware
event: Delaware designated a separate colony.

title: France
event: Queen Anne's War (1702–1713).  The second of the North American Wars fought from 1689 to 1763, it is concurrent with the War of the Spanish Succession in Europe but is entirely due to the unresolved commercial and colonial rivalry between Great Britain and France.

title: Warsaw
event: May – Warsaw is conquered by Charles XII of Sweden, who later the same year defeats Poland again at the Battle of Kliszow.

title: London
event: George Psalmanazar arrives in London.

title: Italy
event: January 14 – An earthquake hits Norcia, Italy.

title: Italy
event: February 2 – An earthquake hits the town of L'Aquila, Italy.

title: Portugal
event: May 26 – Portugal joins the Grand Alliance.

title: Gondar
event: October – A whirlwind blows down the tower of the Gan Takal in Gondar, capital of Ethiopia, killing 30.

title: Bastille
event: November 19 – The Man in the Iron Mask dies in the Bastille.

title: English Channel
event: November 24 to December 2 – The Great Storm of 1703, an Atlantic hurricane, ravages southern England and the English Channel, killing nearly 8,000, mostly at sea.

title: Portugal
event: December 27 – Portugal and England sign the Methuen Treaty, which gives preference to Portuguese wines imported into England.

title: Sultanate of Sulu
event: The Sultanate of Brunei cedes its north-east territories to the Sultanate of Sulu.

title: Delaware
event: The lower 3 counties of the Province of Pennsylvania become the colony of Delaware.

title: Gondar
event: An earthquake strikes Gondar, Ethiopia.

title: Aleppo
event: Thomas Darley purchases the bay Arabian horse Darley Arabian in Aleppo, Syria, and ships him to stud in England where he becomes the most important foundation sire of all modern thoroughbred racing bloodstock.

title: Louisiana
event: February – In America, Mardi Gras is celebrated with the ''Masque de la Mobile'' in the capital of French Louisianne, Mobile (Alabama).

title: Gibraltar
event: August 4 – English and Dutch forces under Sir George Rooke capture Gibraltar from Spain.

title: France
event: August 13 – War of the Spanish Succession – Battle of Blenheim: Allied troops under John Churchill, the Earl of Marlborough and Prince Eugene of Savoy defeat the Franco-Bavarian army.

title: Málaga
event: August 24 – French and English fleets clash off Málaga, causing heavy casualties in both sides but without sinking any ships.

title: Edenton North Carolina
event: 8 March – The Province of Carolina incorporates the town of Bath, making it the first incorporated town in present day North Carolina.  The town becomes the political center and de facto capital of the northern portion of the Province of Carolina until Edenton is incorporated in 1722.

title: Oxfordshire
event: Construction begins on Blenheim Palace, in Oxfordshire, England. It is completed in 1724.

title: Taiwan
event: Taichung City, Taiwan is founded as the village of Dadun.

title: Virginia
event: November – In Williamsburg, capital of the Virginia colony in America, construction of the Capitol building is completed.

title: Battle of Ramillies
event: May 23 – Battle of Ramillies: English, Dutch, and German troops defeat the French.

title: Portugal
event: 1 January – John V is crowned King of Portugal.

title: India
event: 3 March – Death of Aurangzeb precipitates disintegration of Mughal Empire in India.

title: Kingdom of England
event: 1 May – The Acts of Union become law, uniting the Parliaments of the Kingdom of England and Kingdom of Scotland to form the Parliament of the Kingdom of Great Britain.

title: Almanza
event: 25 April – The Allied army is defeated by the Bourbon army at Almanza, Spain in the War of the Spanish Succession.

title: Luang Prabang
event: The Lao empire of Lan Xang officially ends and splits into the kingdoms of Vientiane, Luang Prabang, and Champasak.

title: France
event: July 29–August 21 – War of the Spanish Succession: Battle of Toulon – Allies are obliged to withdraw, but the French fleet is effectively put out of action.

title: Isles of Scilly
event: October 22 – Scilly naval disaster: four Royal Navy ships run aground in the Isles of Scilly because of faulty navigation. Admiral Sir Cloudesley Shovell and at least 1450 sailors drown.

title: London
event: October 23 – The Parliament of the Kingdom of Great Britain first sits in London.

title: Mount Fuji
event: December 16 – The last recorded eruption of Mount Fuji begins in Japan.

title: Gibraltar
event: December 24 – The first British Governor of Gibraltar, directly appointed by Queen Anne, Roger Elliott, takes up residence in the Convent of the Franciscan Friars.

title: Masuria
event: One third of the population of Masuria dies of the plague.

title: Estonia
event: Fearful of a Swedish attack, the Russians blow up the city of Tartu in Estonia.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 11 – Queen Anne withholds Royal Assent from the Scottish Militia Bill, the last time a British monarch vetoes legislation.

title: Firth of Forth
event: March 23 – James Francis Edward Stuart unsuccessfully tries to land at the Firth of Forth.

title: Massachusetts
event: August 29 – A native American attack in Haverhill, Massachusetts kills 16 settlers.

title: New York City
event: Trinity School is founded as the Charity School of Trinity Church in New York City.

title: Mobile Bay
event: February – In America, Mardi Gras is celebrated one more time with ''Masque de la Mobile'' in the capital of French Louisianne, Mobile (Alabama), before Mobile is moved 27 miles (43 km) down the Mobile River to Mobile Bay in 1711.

title: Battle of Poltava
event: June 27 (Old Style) – Battle of Poltava: Peter the Great defeats Charles XII of Sweden, thus effectively ending Sweden's role as a major power in Europe (see below).

title: Battle of Poltava
event: July 8 (New Style) – Battle of Poltava: In the Ukraine, Peter I of Russia defeats Charles XII of Sweden at Poltava (see above).

title: France
event: September 11 – Battle of Malplaquet: Great Britain, the Netherlands and Austria defeat France.

title: New York
event: December 25 – In London, 10 ships leave for the New York colony, carrying over 4,000 people.

title: Bern
event: June – Swiss and Palatine German Protestants under the leadership of Christoph von Graffenried travel to Bath County in the Province of Carolina.  The settlers displace the native town of Chattoka and found New Bern, named for von Graffenried's hometown of Bern, Switzerland.

title: Istanbul
event: Estimation: Beijing becomes the largest city of the world, taking the lead from Istanbul.

title: Ireland
event: St. Francis Abbey Brewery, Kilkenny, Ireland is founded by John Smithwick, the home of Smithwick's Ale.

title: Pamlico River
event: July – Cary's Rebellion: Lieutenant Governor Alexander Spottswood of Virginia dispatches a company of Royal marines to assist Governor Hyde.  After hearing of this, Cary's troops abandon all of their fortifications along the Pamlico River.  Cary and many of his supporters are soon caught and sent to England as prisoners, ending Cary's Rebellion.

title: North Carolina
event: January – Cary's Rebellion: The Lords Proprietors appoint Edward Hyde to replace Thomas Cary as the governor of the North Carolina portion of the Province of Carolina.  Hyde's policies are deemed hostile to Quaker interests, leading former governor Cary and his Quaker allies to take up arms against the province.

title: Alabama
event: February – French settlers at ''Fort Louis de la Mobile'' celebrate Mardi Gras in Mobile (Alabama) by parading a large papier-mache ox head on a cart (the first Mardi Gras parade in America).

title: London
event: February 24 – ''Rinaldo'' by George Frideric Handel, the first Italian opera written for the London stage, premieres in that city.

title: Albemarle Sound
event: May 27 – Cary's Rebellion: Edward Hyde, Governor of the North Carolina portion of the Province of Carolina, leads a force across the Albemarle Sound to gather additional troops in order to capture former governor Thomas Cary.

title: Chowan River
event: June 30 – Cary's Rebellion: Former governor Thomas Cary, after declaring himself Governor of North Carolina, sails an armed brigantine up the Chowan River to attack Governor Hyde's forces fortified at Colonel Thomas Pollock's plantation.  The attack fails and Cary's forces retreat.

title: Neuse River
event: September 10 – John Lawson, Christoph von Graffenried, 2 African American slaves and 2 Native Americans leave on an exploration expedition from New Bern, and travel north by canoe up the Neuse River (this event has also been dated September 12, 1711).

title: South Carolina
event: June – Tuscarora War: An agent from the North Carolina portion of the Province of Carolina asks the provincial government in Charles Town, South Carolina for 1,000 troops under the command of a commander other than Colonel John Barnwell to fight the Tuscarora and their allies.  The request is granted.

title: Switzerland
event: The Treaty of Aargau is signed by Catholics and Protestants, introducing the Protestant faith into Switzerland.

title: Staffordshire
event: Thomas Newcomen builds the first piston-operated steam engine at Tipton, Staffordshire, England.

title: Edenton North Carolina
event: After many years of settlement, the Town on Queen Anne's Creek is established as a courthouse for Chowan County, North Carolina.  The town is renamed Edenton in 1720 and incorporated in 1722.

title: Western Australia
event: The VOC ''Zuytdorp'' is wrecked off the coast of Western Australia.

title: Cape Fear River
event: January 26 – Tuscarora War: More than half of the Native Americans in Colonel John Barnwell's Carolina militia desert during the crossing of the Cape Fear River.

title: Bath North Carolina
event: February 5 – Tuscarora War: Due to severe desertion by Native American troops, Colonel John Barnwell's militia changes course and heads towards Bath.

title: South Carolina
event: February 11 – Tuscarora War: The Carolina militia of Native Americans and settlers from the South Carolina portion of the Province of Carolina arrive at Bath.

title: North Carolina
event: March 1 – Tuscarora War: The Carolina militia, strengthened by settlers and Native Americans from the North Carolina portion of the Province of Carolina, arrive at the Tuscaroran stronghold of Catechna to find it deserted.

title: New Bern North Carolina
event: March 6 – Tuscarora War: Colonel John Barnwell's militia leaves Catechna for New Bern, the North Carolina portion of the Province of Carolina, after agreeing to meet with the Chief Hancock of the Tuscarora on March 19 for peace negotiations.

title: Neuse River
event: March 19 – Tuscarora War: Scheduled peace negotiations between the Tuscarora and the Province of Carolina fail when the Tuscarora fail to send a representative to the meeting.  Colonel John Barnwell's forces begin building Fort Barnwell on the Neuse River near Contentea Creek.

title: New York City
event: April – A black insurrection takes place in New York City; 21 blacks are executed after the militia suppresses the rebellion.

title: Battle of Gadebusch
event: December 9 – Battle of Gadebusch: Sweden defeats Denmark and Saxony.

title: North Carolina
event: January 17 – Tuscarora War: Colonel James Moore leads the Carolina militia out of Albermarle County, North Carolina in a second offensive against the Tuscarora.  Heavy snows force the troops to take refuge in Fort Reading on the Pamlico River.

title: Fort Neoheroka
event: March 1 – Tuscarora War: Colonel James Moore's Carolina militia lays siege to the Tuscaroran stronghold of Fort Neoheroka, located a few miles up Contentnea Creek from Fort Hancock.

title: North Carolina
event: March 23 – Tuscarora War: Fort Neoheroka falls to the Carolina militia, effectively ending the Tuscarora nation's military strength.  Two Tuscaroran allies, the Machapunga and Coree tribes, continue offensive actions against North Carolina.

title: Nova Scotia
event: June 23 – French residents of Acadia given one year to declare allegiance to Britain or leave Nova Scotia Canada.

title: Natchitoches Louisiana
event: Louis Juchereau de St. Denis establishes Fort St. Jean Baptiste at the site of present day Natchitoches, Louisiana (the first permanent European settlement in the Louisiana Territory, after Biloxi (1699) and Mobile, Alabama (1702) were separated).

title: University of Oxford
event: Worcester College, University of Oxford is founded (formerly Gloucester College, closed during the Dissolution of the Monasteries).

title: Stockholm County
event: Stockholm County founded

title: Lake Thun
event: Redirection of the river Kander (Switzerland) into the Lake Thun

title: Battle of Gangut
event: July 27 – Battle of Gangut: The Russian Navy gains its first important victory.

title: Karlsruhe
event: Karlsruhe Palace is built, resulting in the town of Karlsruhe growing up around it.

title: Lake Mattamuskeet
event: February 11 – Tuscarora War: The Tuscarora and their allies sign a peace treaty with the Province of Carolina and agree to move to a reservation near Lake Mattamuskeet, effectively ending the Tuscarora War.  Large numbers of Tuscarora subsequently move to New York.

title: London
event: May 3 – A total solar eclipse is seen across southern England, Sweden and Finland (the last total eclipse visible in London, UK for almost 900 years).

title: Florida
event: July 24 – A Spanish treasure fleet of 10 ships under General Don Juan Ubilla leaves Havana, Cuba for Spain. Seven days later, nine of them sink in a storm off the coast of Florida (some centuries later, treasure salvage is found from these wrecks).

title: Liverpool
event: August 31 – Opening of Old Dock, Liverpool, England, the world's first enclosed commercial wet dock (Thomas Steers, engineer).

title: France
event: September – The first of the major Jacobite Rebellions in Scotland against the rule of King George I breaks out. The Earl of Mar raises the standard of James Edward Stuart and marches on Edinburgh. James, the son of the deposed King James VII, arrives from France.

title: Battle of Sheriffmuir
event: November 13 – The indecisive Battle of Sheriffmuir during the Jacobite rising in Scotland.

title: Battle of Preston (1715)
event: November 14 – Battle of Preston: Government forces defeat the Jacobite incursion at the conclusion of a five-day siege and action, the last battle fought on English soil.

title: Caribbean
event: Pirate Blackbeard (Edward Teach) raids shipping in the Caribbean.

title: Battle of Sheriffmuir
event: The town of Crieff, Scotland, is burned to the ground by Jacobites returning from the Battle of Sheriffmuir.

title: France
event: February 10 – James Edward Stuart flees from Scotland to France with a handful of supporters following failure of the Jacobite Rebellion.

title: Banque de France
event: May – John Law founds the Banque de France.

title: Bastille
event: Voltaire is sentenced to the Bastille for a year because of his satirical writings.

title: Portugal
event: Montevideo, Uruguay, is founded by the Portuguese.

title: Istanbul
event: Lady Mary Wortley Montagu, wife of the British ambassador to Istanbul, has her son inoculated.

title: France
event: January 4 – The Netherlands, Britain & France sign  the Triple Alliance.

title: Drury Lane
event: March 2 – Dancer John Weaver performs in the first ballet in Britain shown in Drury Lane,  ''The Loves of Mars and Venus''.

title: Massachusetts
event: April 26 – The ''Whydah Gally'', flagship of Black Sam Bellamy, is wrecked in a storm off Wellfleet, Massachusetts. The ''Whydah'' sinks with a reputed four and a half tons of treasure on board, and all but 2 of her crew are lost, including Bellamy.

title: London
event: June 24 – The Premier Grand Lodge of England, the 'Modern' and first Free-Masonic Grand Lodge (which later merges with the Ancient Grand Lodge of England in 1813 to form the United Grand Lodge of England), is founded in London, England.

title: London
event: September – The first known Druid revival ceremony is held by John Toland at Primrose Hill, in London, at the Autumnal Equinox, to found the Mother Grove, what is later to become the Ancient Order of Druids (AOD).

title: Antigua Guatemala
event: September 29 – A 7.4 magnitude earthquake strikes Antigua Guatemala, destroying much of the city and making authorities consider moving the capital of Guatemala to a different city.

title: Caribbean
event: November – Crews on two ships commanded by Benjamin Hornigold and Edward Teach attack and capture the British-built French guineyman Concorde in the eastern Caribbean.  Hornigold soon accepts a British amnesty for all pirates, but Teach rejects it and subsequently becomes known as Blackbeard.

title: Denmark
event: December 24/25 – A disastrous flood hits the North Sea coast between the Netherlands and Denmark; thousands die or lose their houses.

title: Bath North Carolina
event: June – Blackbeard and Bonnet take refuge in Bath, North Carolina, where Governor Charles Eden pardons them and their crew.

title: New England
event: The white potato reaches New England from England.

title: France
event: January – France declares war on Spain, leading to the 2-year War of the Quadruple Alliance.

title: North Carolina
event: May – Blackbeard leads 400 sailors in 4 ships to blockade the port of Charleston, South Carolina.  The ''Queen Anne's Revenge'' and ''Adventure'' are both lost at Beaufort Inlet, North Carolina, 1 week later.  Blackbeard allows Stede Bonnet to once again command the ''Revenge'', which is renamed the ''Royal James''.  Bonnet rescues 25 sailors abandoned by Blackbeard on a sandbar and continues his life of piracy.

title: Cape Fear River
event: October – Stede Bonnet and his crew are captured near the mouth of the Cape Fear River and taken to Charleston, South Carolina, where they are tried for piracy.  All but four of Bonnet's crew are found guilty and sentenced to death.

title: Ocracoke Inlet
event: November 22 – Citing violations of the amnesty agreement with Blackbeard, Virginia Governor Alexander Spottswood sends a Royal Navy contingent to North Carolina, where they battle Blackbeard and his crew in Ocracoke Inlet.  Blackbeard is killed in action after receiving 5 musketball wounds and 20 sword lacerations.

title: France
event: December 17 – Austria, Great Britain, and France declare war on Spain, launching the War of the Quadruple Alliance.

title: Great Britain
event: June 10 – Battle of Glen Shiel: British forces defeat the Jacobites and their Spanish allies.

title: Edenton North Carolina
event: The Town on Queen Anne's Creek, North Carolina is renamed Edenton in honor of North Carolina Governor Charles Eden.  It is later incorporated in 1722.

title: North Carolina
event: The Tuscarora flee North Carolina as a result of European colonization.

title: Lisbon
event: The ''Academia Real da Historia'' is founded in Lisbon, Portugal.

title: Guangzhou
event: Emperor Kangxi announces that all western businessmen can only trade in Guangzhou.

title: Jamaica
event: November 16 – Pirate Jack Rackham is brought to trial at St. Jago de la Vega in Jamaica.

title: New Bern North Carolina
event: Edenton is incorporated as the county seat of Chowan County, North Carolina.  The governor and assembly of North Carolina move to Edenton, making it the de facto capital of North Carolina until 1746, when the government is moved to New Bern.

title: Iran
event: March 8 – Persia's Safavid dynasty falls during a bloody revolt of the Afghani people, in The Battle of Gulnabad.

title: Easter Island
event: April 5 – Easter Sunday: Dutch admiral Jakob Roggeveen lands on what is now Easter Island.

title: Pennsylvania
event: May 5 – Pennsylvania colony enacts a statute requiring all persons importing any person previously convicted of sodomy to pay £5 for each such incoming person.

title: Virginia
event: June 2 – Wapping, a male Negro slave owned by a Mr. Heale, is hanged for murder in the colony of Virginia.

title: Massachusetts
event: July 25 – The Three Years War begins along the Maine and Massachusetts border.

title: Pennsylvania
event: August 15 – William Battin, 17, is hanged for arson and murder in the colony of Pennsylvania.

title: North Carolina
event: The Province of Carolina monica incorporates Beaufort, North Carolina as the Port of Beaufort, making it the third incorporated town in the province.

title: North Carolina
event: November 23 – The Province of Carolina incorporates New Bern as Newbern (the town later becomes the capital of North Carolina).

title: China
event: China expels foreign missionaries.

title: Battle of Blenheim
event: Blenheim Palace construction is completed. It is presented as a gift to the Duke of Marlborough for his involvement in the Battle of Blenheim in 1704.

title: London
event: February 20 – The premiere of ''Giulio Cesare'', an Italian  opera by George Frideric Handel, takes place in London.

title: Iran
event: June 23 – Treaty of Constantinople is signed, partitioning Persia between the Ottoman Empire and Russia.

title: China
event: In Qing Dynasty China 66 copies of a 5,020 volume long encyclopedia, the ''Gujin Tushu Jicheng'' (''Complete Collection of Illustrations and Writings from the Earliest to Current Times'') are printed, necessitating the crafting of 250,000 movable type characters cast in bronze.

title: New Hampshire
event: February 20 – The first reported case of white men scalping Native Americans takes place in New Hampshire colony.

title: London
event: March 2 – In London, a night watchman finds a severed head by the Thames; it is later recognized to be that of the husband of Catherine Hayes. She and one accomplice are later executed.

title: France
event: September 3 – The Treaty of Hanover is signed between Great Britain, France and Prussia.

title: Jamaica
event: August 7 – Pirate Nicholas Brown captured near Xtabi, Jamaica

title: Brazil
event: 1727–1800 – Lt. Col. Francisco de Mello Palheta smuggles coffee seeds to Brazil in a bouquet, starting a coffee empire.

title: North America
event: The first Amish move to America.

title: France
event: Catholic Charities is founded in New Orleans, by the French Ursuline Sisters.

title: Ursuline Academy (New Orleans Louisiana)
event: Ursuline Academy is founded by the Sisters of the Order of Saint Ursula in New Orleans. Ursuline Academy enjoys the distinction of being both the oldest, continuously operating school for girls and the oldest Catholic school in the United States.

title: Iran
event: November 18 – An earthquake in Tazriz, Persia kills 77,000.

title: University of Havana
event: The University of Havana ([http://www.uh.cu/ Universidad de la Habana]), Cuba's most well-established university, is founded.

title: Battle of Palkhed
event: February 28 – At the Battle of Palkhed, Maratha Peshwa Baji Rao I defeats the Mughal Governor of Deccan, Nizam-ul-Mulk.

title: Copenhagen Fire of 1728
event: October 20–October 23 – The Copenhagen Fire of 1728 (the largest in the city's history) burns.

title: Port Gibson Mississippi
event: The third oldest settlement in Mississippi, Port Gibson, is founded.

title: Istanbul
event: A fire in Istanbul destroys 12,000 houses and kills 7,000 inhabitants.

title: Putney Bridge
event: Putney Bridge was built.

title: South Carolina
event: July 25 – Seven of the original eight Lords Proprietors sell their tracts within the Province of Carolina back to the crown.  The Province is permanently divided and reorganized into the Royal Colonies of North Carolina and South Carolina.

title: Dutch Republic
event: November 9 – The Treaty of Seville is signed between Great Britain, France, Spain and the Dutch Republic.

title: Fort Rosalie
event: November 28 – The worst Indian massacre to take place on Mississippi soil occurs when Natchez Indians kill 138 Frenchmen, 35 French women, and 56 children at Fort Rosalie (near modern-day Natchez, Mississippi).

title: York County Pennsylvania
event: Establishment of Wright's Ferry under the authority of the Province of Pennsylvania triggers Cresap's War – a ''nine year long conflict'' also known as the '''Maryland-Pennsylvania boundary dispute''' – the conflict mainly centered in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania and York County, Pennsylvania on either banks of the Susquehanna River.

title: 1730 Valparaiso earthquake
event: July 8 – 1730 Valparaiso earthquake in Chile.

title: Wilmington North Carolina
event: Royal Colony of North Carolina Governor George Burrington asks the North Carolina General Assembly to pass an act establishing a town on the Cape Fear River, in what is seen as a political move to shift the power away from the powerful Cape Fear plantation class.  The town is laid out in 1733 and later incorporated as Wilmington in 1740.

title: Italy
event: The Royal Theatre of Mantua (Italy) is built by Ferdinando Galli Bibiena.

title: York County Pennsylvania
event: Cresap's War – in its 2nd year – Maryland-Pennsylvania boundary dispute, conflict mainly centered in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania and York County, Pennsylvania on either banks of the Susquehanna River.

title: Dutch Republic
event: March 16 – The Treaty of Vienna is signed between the Holy Roman Empire, Great Britain, the Dutch Republic and Spain.

title: Corsica
event: Genoa regains Corsica.

title: York County Pennsylvania
event: Cresap's War – in its 3rd year – Maryland-Pennsylvania boundary dispute, conflict mainly centered in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania and York County, Pennsylvania on either banks of the Susquehanna River.

title: London
event: February 23 –  Handel's ''Orlando'' is first performed in London.

title: Quebec
event: September 16 – The magnitude 5.8 Montreal earthquake occurs in Montreal, Quebec, Canada.

title: Royal Opera House
event: December 7 – The original Covent Garden Theatre Royal (now the Royal Opera House) is opened.

title: York County Pennsylvania
event: Cresap's War – in its 4th year – Maryland-Pennsylvania boundary dispute, conflict mainly centered in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania and York County, Pennsylvania on either banks of the Susquehanna River.

title: Cape Fear River
event: April – Royal Colony of North Carolina Commissioners John Watson, Joshua Grainger, Michael Higgins and James Wimble plan the town of New Carthage (which would eventually become Wilmington, North Carolina on the east side of the Cape Fear River).

title: Quebec
event: May 29 – The right of Canadians to keep Indian slaves is upheld at Quebec.

title: York County Pennsylvania
event: Cresap's War – in its 5th year – Maryland-Pennsylvania boundary dispute, conflict mainly centered in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania and York County, Pennsylvania on either banks of the Susquehanna River.

title: North America
event: January 8 – Salzburgers, Lutherans who were expelled by the Roman Catholic Bishop of Salzburg, Austria, in October 1731, set sail for the British Colony of Georgia, in America.

title: France
event: June 21 – In Montreal, New France, a black slave known by the French name of Marie-Joseph Angélique is tortured then hanged by the French authorities for allegedly setting a fire that destroyed part of the city.

title: France
event: June 30 – War of the Polish Succession: Russian troops take Gdańsk (German: Danzig), which had been besieged since February 1734. Gdańsk is captured after the failure of a French expedition to relieve the city.

title: Augusta Georgia
event: Augusta, Georgia, is founded.

title: York County Pennsylvania
event: Cresap's War – in its 6th year – Maryland-Pennsylvania boundary dispute, conflict mainly centered in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania and York County, Pennsylvania on either banks of the Susquehanna River.

title: Royal Opera House
event: January 8 – George Frideric Handel's opera ''Ariodante'' premieres at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden.

title: London
event: April 16 – ''Alcina'', George Frideric Handel's finest Italian opera, premieres at the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden, London.

title: New York
event: August 4 – Freedom of the press: New York Weekly Journal writer John Peter Zenger is acquitted of seditious libel against the royal governor of New York, on the basis that what he published was true.

title: Arizona
event: ''Real Arissona'', namesake of the U.S. state Arizona, is founded in what is now that state.

title: Great Britain
event: George Hamilton, 1st Earl of Orkney becomes the first Field Marshal of Great Britain.

title: Bushehr
event: Bushehr is founded in Persia.

title: York County Pennsylvania
event: Cresap's War – in its 7th year – Maryland-Pennsylvania boundary dispute, conflict mainly centered in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania and York County, Pennsylvania on either banks of the Susquehanna River.

title: France
event: May 26 – Battle of Ackia: British and Chickasaw Native Americans defeat French troops.

title: Philadelphia
event: Benjamin Franklin creates the Philadelphia Police Force – the first city-paid force.

title: Richmond Virginia
event: Richmond, Virginia is founded.

title: Our Lady of Guadalupe
event: Our Lady of Guadalupe is designated the patron saint of Mexico City.

title: Ireland
event: The oldest existing English language newspaper in the world, ''The (Belfast) News Letter'', is founded in Ireland.

title: Lancaster County Prison
event: Lancaster County Prison, Lancaster, Pennsylvania is first constructed in response to the seven violent years preceding of the ongoing Cresap's War in the Maryland-Pennsylvania boundary dispute and war.

title: York County Pennsylvania
event: Cresap's War – in its 8th year – Maryland-Pennsylvania boundary dispute, conflict mainly centered in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania and York County, Pennsylvania on either banks of the Susquehanna River.

title: Great Britain
event: June 21 – In Britain the Theatrical Licensing Act requires plays to be submitted to the Lord Chamberlain for censorship.

title: Bengal
event: October 7 – A tropical cyclone strikes Bengal, India killing approximately 300,000.

title: Kamchatka Peninsula
event: October 16 – An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 9.3 occurs off the shore of Russia's Kamchatka Peninsula. Tsunamis up to 60m (200 ft) high followed in the Pacific ocean.

title: Teatro di San Carlo
event: November 4 – The Teatro di San Carlo, the oldest working opera house in Europe, is inaugurated in Naples, Italy.

title: Dniester
event: Russo–Turkish War (1735–1739): The Russian army fails to cross the Dniester.  They are decimated by plague.

title: Guangzhou
event: China's Qing government announces that all western businessmen have to use the Cohong in Guangzhou to trade.

title: Herculaneum
event: The excavation of Herculaneum, a Roman city buried by Vesuvius in AD 79, begins.

title: Mason–Dixon Line
event: Cresap's War – brought to an end in May by George II in its 9th year – Maryland-Pennsylvania boundary dispute, where the conflict mainly centered in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania and York County, Pennsylvania on either banks of the Susquehanna River. The dispute would simmer until establishment of the Mason–Dixon Line settled the borders in 1767.

title: Württemberg
event: February 4 – Court Jew Joseph Suss Oppenheimer is executed in Württemberg.

title: London
event: April 15 – ''Serse'', an Italian opera by George Frideric Handel, premieres in London.

title: Viceroyalty of New Granada
event: Ecuador becomes a part of New Granada.

title: France
event: January 1 – Bouvet Island is discovered by French explorer Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier.

title: India
event: March 20 – Nader Shah occupies Delhi in India and sacks the city, stealing the jewels of the Peacock Throne, including the Koh-i-Noor.

title: London
event: October 17 – The Foundling Hospital is created in London by royal charter.

title: Great Britain
event: October 23 – War of Jenkins' Ear: Great Britain declares war on Spain.

title: Portobelo Colón
event: November 21 – The British capture the South American silver exporting town of Portobelo from the Spanish.

title: Enfield North Carolina
event: Enfield, North Carolina is founded.

title: Cliveden
event: The song ''Rule Britannia'' is first performed at Cliveden.

title: University of Pennsylvania
event: University of Pennsylvania is founded.

title: St. Augustine Florida
event: Spain begins construction on Fort Matanzas in the Matanzas Inlet, approximately {{convert15mikm}} south of St. Augustine, Florida.

title: Wilmington North Carolina
event: February 20 – The North Carolina General Assembly incorporates the town of Newton as Wilmington, North Carolina, named for Spencer Compton, 1st Earl of Wilmington, and patron of Royal Governor Gabriel Johnston.

title: Vienna
event: ''Stemmatographia'' by Hristofor Zhefarovich, regarded as the first Serbian and Bulgarian secular printed book, is printed in Vienna.

title: China
event: The population of China reaches c. 143 million.

title: New York City
event: April – The New York Slave Insurrection of 1741, a plot to torch New York City, is discovered.

title: Kingdom of Hungary
event: June 25 – Maria Theresa of Austria is crowned Queen Regnant of Hungary in Bratislava.

title: Alaska
event: July 15 – Alexei Chirikov sights land in Southeast Alaska. He sends some men aboard in a longboat, making them the first Europeans to visit Alaska.

title: Siberia
event: December 19 – Vitus Bering dies in his expedition east of Siberia.

title: Sark
event: Daniel le Pelley succeeds Nicolas le Pelley as Seigneur of Sark.

title: House of Lords
event: Robert Walpole is elevated to the peerage and thus moves from the British House of Commons to the House of Lords, effectively ending his reign as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom (see February 16, above).

title: London
event: Construction starts on the Foundling Hospital in London.

title: St. Augustine Florida
event: Spain completes the construction of Fort Matanzas in the Matanzas Inlet, approximately {{convert15mikm}} south of St. Augustine, Florida.

title: La Guaira
event: February 18 – The British attack La Guaira.

title: London
event: February 21 – George Frideric Handel's oratorio, ''Samson'' premieres in London .

title: Battle of La Guaira
event: March 2 – Battle of La Guaira

title: Twelve Collegia
event: September 11 – Natalia Lopukhina is flogged in front of the Twelve Collegia building in Saint Petersburg.

title: Great Britain
event: September 13 – The Treaty of Worms is signed between Great Britain, Austria, and Sardinia.

title: Nova Scotia
event: The third French and Indian War, known as King George's War, breaks out at Port Royal, Nova Scotia.

title: France
event: February 22–February 23 – Battle of Toulon: The British fleet is defeated by a Franco-Spanish fleet.

title: Derby
event: 4 December – The Jacobite Army reaches Derby; two days later it begins retreat.

title: Clifton Moor Skirmish
event: 19 December The Jacobite army led by Bonnie Prince Charlie; on retreat from Derby, was defeated by the Duke of Cumberland at the Battle of Clifton Moor near Penrith, Cumberland. This was the last land battle ever to take place on English soil.

title: France
event: May 11 – War of Austrian Succession: Battle of Fontenoy – French forces defeat an Anglo-Dutch-Hanoverian army including the Black Watch.

title: United Kingdom
event: September 21 – Battle of Prestonpans: British Government forces are defeated.

title: Istanbul
event: December 28 – For 5 days, fire destroys buildings in Istanbul.

title: Edenton North Carolina
event: Royal Colony of North Carolina Governor Gabriel Johnston moves to the province's largest and most prosperous city of New Bern.  As a result, New Bern replaces Edenton as the capital of North Carolina (a title it holds until Raleigh is established in 1792).

title: United Kingdom
event: January 17 – Battle of Falkirk: British Government forces are defeated by Jacobite forces.

title: Battle of Culloden
event: April 16 – The Battle of Culloden, the final pitched battle fought on British soil, brings an end to the Jacobite Rising.

title: Tower of London
event: August 18 – Two of the four rebellious Scottish lords, Earl of Kilmarnock and Lord Balmeniro, are beheaded in the Tower (Lord Lovat was executed in 1747).

title: Princeton University
event: October 22 – The College of New Jersey is founded (it becomes Princeton University in 1896).

title: Brunswick North Carolina
event: War of the Austrian Succession: Spanish troops invade and occupy the coastal towns of Beaufort and Brunswick in the Royal Colony of North Carolina during what becomes known as the Spanish Alarm. They are later driven out by the local militia.

title: London Lock Hospital
event: January 31 –  The first venereal diseases clinic opens at London Lock Hospital.

title: Nova Scotia
event: February 11 – A combined French and Indian force, commanded by Captain Nicholas Antoine Coulon de Villiers, attacks British troops at Grand Pré, Nova Scotia.

title: Great Britain
event: April 9 – The Scottish Jacobite Lord Lovat is beheaded by axe on Tower Hill, London, for high treason (the last man to be executed in this way in Britain).

title: Northwest Passage
event: June 24–October 14 – The English ships ''Dobbs'' galley and ''California'', under Captains William Moore and Francis Smith, explore Hudson Bay, discovering there is no Northwest Passage by this route.

title: Great Britain
event: July 2 – War of the Austrian Succession – Battle of Lauffeld: France defeats the combined armies of Hanover, Great Britain and the Netherlands.

title: Dutch Republic
event: November 22 – Prince William IV of Orange becomes stadtholder of all the provinces of the United Provinces.

title: France
event: Great Britain obtains Madras, in India, from France, in exchange of the fortress of Louisbourg in Canada.

title: Lahore
event: Ahmad Shah Bahadur captures Lahore.

title: Pompeii
event: The ruins of Pompeii are discovered.

title: Vermont
event: January 3 – Benning Wentworth issues the first of the New Hampshire Grants, leading to the establishment of Vermont.

title: Great Britain
event: July 9 – The naval settlement of Halifax, Nova Scotia is founded as the British answer to Louisbourg.

title: Istanbul
event: January – A fire in Istanbul destroys 10,000 homes.

title: Portugal
event: July – José I takes over the throne of Portugal from his deceased father, João V. King José Manuel appoints the Marquis of Pombal as his Chief Minister, who then strips the Inquisition of its power.

title: Oceania
event: Oceania: 2,000,000

title: Great Britain
event: April 4 – A small earthquake hits Warrington, England, Great Britain

title: Northampton
event: September 30 – A small earthquake hits Northampton, England.

title: Westminster Bridge
event: November 16 – Westminster Bridge is officially opened.

title: University of Glasgow
event: Adam Smith is appointed professor of logic at the University of Glasgow.

title: Philadelphia
event: May 11 – The Pennsylvania legislature grants a charter to Benjamin Franklin and Dr. Thomas Bond for the establishment in Philadelphia of the first hospital in the Colonies.

title: University of Pennsylvania
event: August 13 – The Academy and College of Philadelphia, predecessor to the private University of Pennsylvania, opens its doors, with Benjamin Franklin as president.

title: University of Glasgow
event: Adam Smith transfers to professor of moral philosophy at the University of Glasgow.

title: Great Britain
event: September 2 – Great Britain and the British Empire adopts the Gregorian calendar, making the Julian date of September 2 be followed by the Gregorian date of September 14.

title: Palmyra
event: Robert Wood publishes ''The ruins of Palmyra; otherwise Tedmor in the desart'' in English and French, making the ancient Syrian city of Palmyra known to the West.

title: France
event: October 31 – Virginia Lieut. Gov. Robert Dinwiddie commissions 21-year-old militia Maj. George Washington to dissuade the French from occupying the Ohio Country.

title: Columbia University
event: July – Columbia University is founded as King's College by royal charter of King George II of England.  The college is originally located in Lower Manhattan.  Instruction is suspended in 1776 and the school reopens in 1784 as Columbia College.  With the college's growth in the 19th Century, it is renamed Columbia University in 1896.

title: Hillsborough North Carolina
event: Surveyor William Churton lays out what will become the county seat of Orange County, North Carolina.  The town is named Corbin Town for Francis Corbin, a member of the North Carolina governor's council.  Corbin Town is renamed Childsburgh in 1759 and finally Hillsborough in 1766.

title: Battle of Jumonville Glen
event: May 28 – The Battle of Jumonville Glen begins the French and Indian War in North America.

title: New England
event: June 19 – The Albany Congress of New England Colonies proposes an American Union.

title: Fort Necessity National Battlefield
event: July 3 – French and Indian War: George Washington surrenders Fort Necessity to French Capt. Louis Coulon de Villiers.

title: Leicester
event: Wolsey, the clothes manufacturer, is established in Leicester; the business celebrates its 250th anniversary in 2005.

title: China
event: Construction of the Puning Temple complex in Chengde, China is complete, during the reign of the Qianlong Emperor.

title: Moscow State University
event: January 25 – Moscow University is established on Tatiana Day.

title: North America
event: February 20 – General Braddock lands in Virginia to take command of the British forces against the French in North America.

title: France
event: July 9 – French and Indian War – Braddock Expedition: British troops and colonial militiamen are ambushed and suffer a devastating defeat inflicted by French and Indian forces. During the battle, British General Edward Braddock is mortally wounded. Colonel George Washington survives.

title: South Africa
event: July 17 – In a convoy of ships from Great Britain, returning to India for the East India Company, the lead ship ''Dodington'' wrecks at Port Elizabeth, losing a chest of gold coins from Robert Clive, worth £33,000.  In 1998, 1,400 coins are offered for sale, and in 2002 a portion is given to the South African government.

title: Lisbon
event: November 1 – 1755 Lisbon earthquake: In Portugal, Lisbon is destroyed by a massive earthquake and tsunami, killing 60,000–90,000 people.

title: Massachusetts
event: November 18 – An earthquake occurs in the vicinity of Cape Ann, Massachusetts, causing extensive damage.

title: Eddystone Lighthouse
event: December 2 – The second Eddystone Lighthouse is destroyed by fire.

title: New York City
event: March 17 – St. Patrick's Day is celebrated in New York City for the first time (at the Crown and Thistle Tavern).

title: Minorca
event: April 12 – Seven Years' War: The French invade Minorca, then under British control.

title: France
event: May 15 – Seven Years' War: The Seven Years' War formally begins when Great Britain declares war on France.

title: Catherine Palace
event: July 30 – Bartolomeo Rastrelli presents the newly built Catherine Palace to Empress Elizabeth and her courtiers.

title: Fort Oswego
event: August 14 – Seven Years' War-  French and Indian War: Fort Oswego falls to the French.

title: Battle of Lobositz
event: October 1 – Seven Years' War – Battle of Lobositz: Frederick defeats an Austrian army under Marshal Maximilian Ulysses Count Browne.

title: Kolkata
event: January 2 – Britain captures Calcutta (part of the fighting in the Seven Years' War).

title: India
event: June 23 – Battle of Plassey: 3,000 British troops under Robert Clive defeat  a 50,000 strong Indian army under Siraj ud-Daulah at Plassey.

title: Fort William Henry
event: August 3 – August 9 – French and Indian War: A French army under Louis-Joseph de Montcalm forces the English to surrender Fort William Henry. The French army's Indian allies slaughter the survivors for unclear reasons.

title: France
event: First European settlement in what is now Erie County by the French at the mouth of Buffalo Creek.

title: Melenci
event: The first Isakov family member (Trifun Isakov) is mentioned in ''Melenci''.

title: France
event: April 29 – Battle of Cuddalore: A British fleet under Sir George Pocock engages the French fleet of Anne Antoine d'Aché indecisively near Madras.

title: Pennsylvania
event: May 21 – Seven Years' War – French and Indian War: Mary Campbell is abducted from her home in Pennsylvania by Lenape.

title: Louisbourg Nova Scotia
event: June 12 – Seven Years' War – French and Indian War: Siege of Louisbourg: James Wolfe's attack at Louisbourg, Nova Scotia commences.

title: France
event: June 23 – Seven Years' War – Battle of Krefeld: Anglo-Hanoverian forces under Ferdinand of Brunswick defeat the French.

title: Pittsburgh
event: September 14 – Seven Years' War – French and Indian War: Battle of Fort Duquesne: A British attack on Fort Duquesne (present day Pittsburgh) is defeated.

title: Great Britain
event: October 16 – Seven Years' War – Battle of Clostercamp: The French defeat the combined forces of Great Britain, Prussia, Hanover, Brunswick, and Hesse-Kassel.

title: Pittsburgh
event: November 25 – Seven Years' War: French and Indian War: French forces abandon Fort Duquesne to the British, who then name the area Pittsburgh.

title: Ireland
event: The Famous Guinness Brewery is founded in St. James's Gate, Dublin Ireland.

title: Hillsborough North Carolina
event: Churton Town, the Orange County, North Carolina county seat laid out in 1754, is renamed Childsburgh in honor of North Carolina attorney general Thomas Child.  It is later renamed Hillsborough in 1766.

title: France
event: April 14 – Seven Years War – Battle of Bergen: A French army defeats Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick.

title: Fort Rouillé
event: July 25 – Seven Years' War (French and Indian War): In Canada, British forces capture Fort Niagara from French, who subsequently abandon Fort Rouillé.

title: Battle of Minden
event: August 1 – Battle of Minden: Anglo–Hanoverian forces under Ferdinand of Brunswick defeat the French army of the Duc de Broglie, but due to the disobedience of the English cavalry commander Lord George Sackville, the French are able to withdraw unmolested.

title: Battle of Kunersdorf
event: August 12 – Battle of Kunersdorf: Frederick the Great is rebuffed in bloody assaults on the combined Austro–Russian army of Pyotr Saltykov and Ernst von Laudon.  This is one of Frederick's greatest defeats.

title: Great Britain
event: September 10 – Battle of Pondicherry: An inconclusive naval battle is fought off the coast of India between the French Admiral d'Aché and the British under George Pocock. The French forces are badly damaged and returned home, never to return.

title: Battle of the Plains of Abraham
event: September 13 – Seven Years' War (French and Indian War): Quebec falls to British forces following General Wolfe's victory in the Battle of the Plains of Abraham just outside the city. Both the French Commander (the Marquis de Montcalm) and the British General James Wolfe are fatally wounded.

title: Brittany
event: November 20 – Battle of Quiberon Bay: The British fleet of Sir Edward Hawke defeats a French fleet under Marshal de Conflans near the coast of Brittany.  This is the decisive naval engagement of the Seven Years' War – after this, the French are no longer able to field a significant fleet.

title: Germantown Academy
event: December 6 – The Germantown Union School (now called Germantown Academy), America's oldest nonsectarian day school, is founded.

title: Jamaica
event: Tacky's rebellion occurs in Jamaica.

title: Portsmouth
event: The dockyards of Portsmouth catch fire.

title: France
event: February 27 – Seven Years' War – French and Indian War: Cherokee natives allied with French forces attack a North Carolina militia stationed at Fort Dobbs in the western part of the province. The attack is repelled by the militia.

title: Nova Scotia
event: June 4 – Great Upheaval: New England planters arrive to claim land in Nova Scotia Canada taken from the Acadians.

title: Battle of Restigouche
event: July 8 – Seven Years' War – French and Indian War: Battle of Restigouche: British defeat French forces in last naval battle in New France.

title: Battle of Warburg
event: July 31 – Seven Years' War – Battle of Warburg: The Anglo-Hanoverian army of Ferdinand of Brunswick storms Warburg, with a heroic role being played by the English commander Lord Granby.

title: Soho Manufactory
event: Matthew Boulton's ''Soho Manufactory'' opens.

title: France
event: The tune to ''Twinkle Twinkle Little Star'' is published in France.

title: France
event: January 16 – The British capture Pondicherry, India from the French.

title: London
event: February 8 – An earthquake in London breaks chimneys in Limehouse and Poplar.

title: Portugal
event: September 19 – The slave trade to and within Portugal is forbidden.

title: Kołobrzeg
event: December 16 – Seven Years' War: After four months of siege, the Russians under Pyotr Rumyantsev take the Prussian fortress of Kolberg.

title: Palace of Versailles
event: Louis XV orders the construction of the Petit Trianon, in the park of the Palace of Versailles, for his mistress Madame de Pompadour.

title: Virginia
event: The town of Charlottesville, Virginia is founded.

title: Hummelstown Pennsylvania
event: The town of Hummelstown, Pennsylvania was founded.

title: Philippines
event: August 10 – The British East India Company seizes the port city of Manila, Philippines from the Spaniards.

title: Battle of Signal Hill
event: September 15 – Battle of Signal Hill: British troops defeat the French

title: Manila
event: October 5 – The British take Manila and make it an Open Port.

title: Istanbul
event: Little Hagia Sophia in Istanbul, Turkey, damaged in an earthquake.

title: Rio de Janeiro
event: The seat of colonial administration in the Viceroyalty of Brazil is moved from Salvador to Rio de Janeiro.

title: Anson County North Carolina
event: February 1 – The Royal Colony of North Carolina officially creates Mecklenburg County from the western portion of Anson County.  The county is named for Queen Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz, who married King George III in 1761.

title: Great Britain
event: February 10 – French and Indian War/Seven Years' War: The 1763 Treaty of Paris ends the war and France cedes Canada to Great Britain.

title: Zsámbék
event: June 28 – A massive earthquake occurs on the same day in Komárom in Hungary, in Komárno in Slovakia and in Zsámbék in Hungary.

title: Pennsylvania
event: August 5 – Pontiac's War – Battle of Bushy Run: British forces led by Henry Bouquet defeat Chief Pontiac's Indians at Bushy Run in the Pennsylvania backcountry.

title: Franklin County North Carolina
event: The Royal Colony of North Carolina establishes a new county from the eastern portion of Granville County and names it Bute County for John Stuart, 3rd Earl of Bute, who had recently resigned his post as Prime Minister of Great Britain.  In 1779 the State of North Carolina abolishes the county when it forms Warren County from the northern portion and Franklin County from the southern portion.

title: Kingdom of Hungary
event: January 7 – Siculicidium: Hundreds of innocent Székely people are murdered by the Austrians in a massacre at Madéfalva (Transylvania, Kingdom of Hungary).

title: House of Commons of Great Britain
event: January 19 – John Wilkes is expelled from the House of Commons of Great Britain for seditious libel.

title: St. Louis Missouri
event: February 15 – The American city of St Louis is established.

title: North America
event: June 21 – The English-language ''Quebec Gazette'' is established in Quebec City, Quebec, Canada. As of 2008, it is the oldest surviving newspaper in North America.

title: Capitoline Hill
event: October 15 – English scholar Edward Gibbon conceives the idea of writing ''The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire'' as I sat musing amid the ruins of the Capitol.

title: Lisbon
event: In Lisbon, the ''auto de fé'' parade (often an excuse for violence against Jews or Christian 'heretics') is abolished.

title: Navsari
event: Desai Atash Behram was established in Navsari, India.

title: Great Britain
event: March 22 – The British Parliament passes the Stamp Act, which is the first direct tax levied from Great Britain on the American colonies.

title: Great Britain
event: March 24 – Great Britain passes the Quartering Act, requiring the 13 American colonies to house British troops.

title: Quebec
event: May 18 – Fire destroys one quarter of the town of Montreal, Quebec.

title: Isle of Man
event: June 21 – The Isle of Man is brought under British control.

title: North America
event: November 1 – The Stamp Act goes into effect in the 13 colonies, in order to help pay for British military operations in North America.

title: London
event: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart returns to Salzburg after touring Paris and London with his father.

title: Burma
event: The Burmese begin to invade the Thai kingdom of Ayutthaya.

title: Hillsborough North Carolina
event: Childsburgh, the Orange County, North Carolina county seat laid out as Corbin Town in 1754 and renamed in 1759, is renamed Hillsborough in honor of Wills Hill, Earl of Hillsborough.

title: Great Britain
event: January 1 – Bonnie Prince Charlie becomes the new Stuart claimant to the throne of Great Britain as King Charles III and figurehead for Jacobitism.

title: Denmark
event: January 14 – Christian VII becomes King of Denmark.

title: Wilmington North Carolina
event: February 5 – An observer in Wilmington, North Carolina reports to the Edinburgh newspaper ''Caledonian Mercury'' that 3 ships were seized by British men-of-war on the charge of carrying official documents without stamps.  The strict enforcement causes 7 other ships to leave Wilmington for other ports.

title: Saint Kitts
event: February 20 – The ''Pennsylvania Gazette'' reports that a British sloop outside of Wilmington, North Carolina seized 1 sloop sailing from Philadelphia and 1 sloop sailing from Saint Christopher on the charge of carrying official documents without stamps.  In response, local residents threaten to burn a Royal Man-of-War attempting to deliver stamps to Wilmington, forcing the ship to return to the mouth of the Cape Fear River.

title: New Orleans
event: March 5 – Antonio de Ulloa, the first Spanish governor of Louisiana, arrives in New Orleans.

title: Rutgers University
event: November 10 – The last Colonial governor of New Jersey, William Franklin, signs the charter of Queen's College (later renamed Rutgers University).

title: New York City
event: November 27 – An observer in New York City, New York reports to the ''Pennsylvania Gazette'' that a British Sloop of War is searching all vessels passing near Cape Lookout, North Carolina and that some vessels have been seized.

title: Kentucky
event: Autumn - North Carolina woodsman Daniel Boone goes through the Cumberland Gap and reaches Kentucky, in defiance of the Royal Proclamation of 1763 issued by King George III. He discovers a rich hunting ground, contested by several Native American tribes.

title: Tryon Palace
event: January 9 – William Tryon, governor of the Royal Colony of North Carolina, signs a contract with architect John Hawks to build Tryon Palace, a lavish Georgian style governor's mansion on the New Bern waterfront.

title: New Bern North Carolina
event: August 26 – Construction begins on Tryon Palace in New Bern, North Carolina.  The construction proves more expensive than initially expected, leading the government to increase local taxes.  This stirs resentment among some North Carolinians and helps prolong the War of the Regulation.

title: Palace of Versailles
event: The Petit Trianon, originally built for Madame de Pompadour, is achieved in the park of the Palace of Versailles and inaugurated by Louis XV.

title: United Kingdom
event: Boston citizens refuse to quarter British troops.

title: Nepal
event: King Prithvi Narayan Shah unified several small kingdoms to establish the modern-day Nepal.

title: Bering Island
event: The Steller's sea cow, discovered on Bering Island in 1741, is driven to extinction.

title: Bougainville Strait
event: Bougainville Strait was discovered.

title: London
event: January 9 – Philip Astley stages the first modern circus, with acrobats on galloping horses (London).

title: London
event: May 10 – John Wilkes is imprisoned for writing an article for the ''North Briton'' severely criticizing King George III. This action provokes rioting in London.

title: France
event: May 15 – After the Treaty of Versailles, the island of Corsica is ceded by Genoa to France.

title: Nepal
event: December 21 – Nepal is united.

title: Great Britain
event: James Watt demonstrates the first practical steam engine, an invention which inaugurates the Industrial Revolution in Great Britain.

title: France
event: Nicolas-Joseph Cugnot demonstrates a steam-powered artillery tractor (''see drawing'') in France.

title: Bengal
event: Famine in Bengal kills 10 million people, a third of the population, in the worst natural disaster in human history (in terms of lives lost).

title: Italy
event: The city of Brescia, Italy is devastated when the Church of San Nazaro, near Venice, is struck by lightning.
