The resulting fire ignites 200,000 lb (90,000 kg) of gunpowder being stored there, causing a massive explosion which destroys 1/6 of the city and kills 3,000 people.  The disaster prompts the Roman Catholic Church to abandon their religious objection to using lightning rods to protect their property.

title: Hindustan
event: Famine in Hindustan (1769-1770): three million die.

title: Tahiti
event: April 13 – James Cook arrives in Tahiti on the ship HM Bark ''Endeavour'', preparing to observe the solar eclipse of the planet Venus, which takes place on June 3. After the voyage, the data is found to be inaccurate in determining the distance between the Sun and Earth.

title: California
event: May 14 – Charles III of Spain sends Spanish missionaries, who found California missions in San Diego, Santa Barbara, San Francisco and Monterey and begin the settlement of California.

title: Royal Botanic Gardens Kew
event: June 3 – (O.S.) A transit of Venus is followed 5 hours later by a total solar eclipse, the shortest such interval in the historical past.  The predicted transit is viewed by King George III of Great Britain at the Kew Observatory.

title: Kentucky
event: June 7 – Frontiersman Daniel Boone first begins to explore the present-day Bluegrass State, Kentucky.

title: Mission San Diego de Alcalá
event: July 16: Father Junípero Serra founds Mission San Diego de Alcalá, the first of the 21 California missions.

title: Santa Monica California
event: August 3: The party of Gaspar de Portolà becomes the first white group to set foot in the area now known as Santa Monica, California.

title: Bengal
event: September – Massive droughts in Bengal, which eventually lead to the Bengal famine of 1770.

title: Poverty Bay
event: October 7– James Cook lands in New Zealand at Poverty Bay.

title: New Hampshire
event: December 13 – Dartmouth College in Hanover, New Hampshire is established as John Wentworth, the Royal Governor, conveys a charter from King George III of England.

title: Botany Bay
event: April – James Cook drops anchor in a wide bay about 16 kilometres (10 mi) south of the present city of Sydney, Australia. Because the young botanist on board the ship, Joseph Banks discovers 30,000 specimens of plant life in the bay, 1,600 of them unknown to European science, James Cook calls the place Botany Bay.

title: Hindustan
event: Famine in Hindustan (1769-1770): three million die.

title: Boston Massacre
event: March 5 – Boston Massacre: Five Americans are shot by British troops in an event that helps start the American Revolutionary War 5 years later.

title: Aspindza
event: April 20 – Georgian king Erekle II defeats Persians in battle of Aspindza, though Russian General Totleben betrays him.

title: France
event: May 7 – Fourteen-year-old  Marie Antoinette arrives at the French court.

title: France
event: May 16 – Fireworks lit by Eric Engelbrecht, at the wedding of the crown prince of France in Paris, cause a fire, killing 132 people.

title: California Republic
event: June 3 – Gasper de Portola and Father Junipero Serra establish Monterey, the ''presidio''  of Alta California territory for Spain from 1777–1822, United Mexican States 1824–1846, until the California Republic.

title: Great Britain
event: August 22 – James Cook claims the eastern coast of New Holland (Australia) for Great Britain.

title: Denmark
event: The trade monopoly with Iceland is transferred to the Danish crown.

title: Pitt County North Carolina
event: The North Carolina General Assembly passes an act establishing the town of Martinsborough, named for Royal Governor Josiah Martin, on the land of Richard Evans, which will serve as the county seat of Pitt County.

title: China
event: Construction of the Putuo Zongcheng Temple complex in Chengde, China is completed during the reign of the Qianlong Emperor.

title: Orange County North Carolina
event: March 12 – The North Carolina General Assembly establishes Wake County (named for Margaret Wake, the wife of North Carolina Royal Governor William Tryon) from portions of Cumberland, Johnston and Orange counties.  Bloomsbury (later known as Wake Courthouse) is made the informal county seat.

title: Hillsborough North Carolina
event: May 11 – War of the Regulation: North Carolina Governor William Tryon marches his militia out of Hillsborough to come to the aid of General Hugh Waddell's beleaguered forces.  Tryon's army stops at Alamance Creek, {{convert5mikm}} away from the Regulator army.

title: Bloody Falls Massacre
event: July 17 – Bloody Falls Massacre: Chipewyan chief Matonabbee, traveling as the guide to Samuel Hearne on his Arctic overland journey, massacres a group of unsuspecting Inuit.

title: San Gabriel California
event: September 8 – In California, Fathers Pedro Cambon and Angel Somera found Mission San Gabriel Arcangel in what is now San Gabriel, California.

title: Finland
event: October 9 – The Dutch merchant ship ''Vrouw Maria'' sinks near the coast of Finland; Captain Raymund Lourens and his crew escape unharmed.

title: Newcastle upon Tyne
event: November 16 – During the night the Tyne floods, destroying many bridges and killing several people; the main bridge at Newcastle upon Tyne is not completed until 1781.

title: Denmark
event: January 17 – Johann Friedrich Struensee and Queen Caroline Matilda are arrested, leading to his execution and her banishment from Denmark.

title: Tennessee
event: May – The Watauga Association is formed in East Tennessee.

title: Rhode Island
event: June 9 – The British vessel ''Gaspee'' is burned off of Rhode Island.

title: Smithsonian Institution
event: August 12 – The volcano Mount Papandayan in West Java erupts and partially collapses, the debris avalanche killing several thousands.Smithsonian Institutionaccessdate=2010-09-09url=http://www.volcano.si.edu/world/volcano.cfm?vnum=0603-10=}}<

title: Mission San Luis Obispo de Tolosa
event: September 1 – Mission San Luis Obispo de Tolosa is founded in San Luis Obispo, California.

title: Guatemala City
event: Antigua, Guatemala is destroyed by an earthquake, and the capital of Guatemala is moved to Guatemala City.

title: Istanbul Technical University
event: Istanbul Technical University is established (under the original name of Royal School of Naval Engineering) as the world's first comprehensive institution of higher learning dedicated to engineering education.

title: China
event: In China, written work begins on the ''Siku Quanshu'', the largest literary compilation of books in China's history (surpassing the Yongle Encyclopedia of the 15th Century). Upon completion in 1782, the books are bound in 36,381 volumes (册) with more than 79,000 chapters (卷), comprising about 2.3 million pages, and approximately 800 million Chinese characters.

title: Antarctic Circle
event: January 17 – Captain James Cook becomes the first European explorer to cross the Antarctic Circle.

title: North America
event: April 27 or May 10 – The British Parliament passes the Tea Act, designed to save the British East India Company by granting it a monopoly on the North American tea trade.

title: Society of Jesus
event: July 21 – Under the pressure of the Bourbon courts, Pope Clement XIV suppresses the Society of Jesus (brief ''Dominus ac Redemptor'').

title: Kentucky
event: Daniel Boone leads the first attempt by British colonists to establish a settlement in Kentucky, but is turned back in an attack by American Indians in which his son is killed.

title: France
event: October 13 – French astronomer Charles Messier discovers the ''Whirlpool Galaxy'', an interacting, grand-design spiral galaxy located at a distance of approximately 23 million light-years in the constellation Canes Venatici.

title: Boston Tea Party
event: December 16 – Boston Tea Party: A group of Americans, dressed as Mohawk Indians, steal aboard ships of the British East India Company and dump their cargo of tea into Boston Harbor.

title: North America
event: The British pass the Quebec Act, setting out rules of governance for the colony of Quebec in British North America.

title: Pitt County North Carolina
event: To avoid severe flooding, Martinsborough, North Carolina is moved to higher ground {{convert3mikm}} west. The North Carolina General Assembly incorporates Martinsborough as the new county seat of Pitt County, 3 years after its founding.

title: Boston Tea Party
event: March 31 – Intolerable Acts: The British Parliament passes the Boston Port Act, closing the port of Boston, Massachusetts as punishment for the Boston Tea Party.

title: France
event: May 10 – Louis XVI becomes King of France following the death of his grandfather, Louis XV.

title: Pennsylvania
event: September 5 – The First Continental Congress assembles in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

title: Fairfax County Virginia
event: September 21 – George Mason and George Washington found the Fairfax County Militia Association, a military unit independent of British control.

title: Virginia
event: October 10 – Dunmore's War – Battle of Point Pleasant: Cornstalk is forced to make peace with Dunmore at the Treaty of Camp Charlotte, ceding Shawnee land claims south of the Ohio (modern Kentucky) to Virginia.

title: Taunton Massachusetts
event: October 21 – The word justice is first displayed on a flag raised by colonists in Taunton, Massachusetts, in defiance of British rule in Colonial America.

title: South Carolina
event: November – American Revolution: Colonel Richard Richardson's South Carolina revolutionaries march through Ninety Six District in what becomes known as the ''Snow Campaign'', effectively ending all major support for the Loyalist cause in the backcountry of South Carolina.

title: New England
event: A smallpox epidemic begins in New England.

title: Tseax Cone
event: Tseax Cone in northwestern British Columbia erupts.

title: South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands
event: January 17 – James Cook takes possession of South Georgia for Britain.

title: Richmond Virginia
event: March 23 – American Revolution: Patrick Henry, a delegate to the Second Virginia Convention after the Virginia House of Burgesses was disbanded by the Royal Governor, delivers his Give me Liberty, or give me Death! speech at St. John's Church in Richmond, Virginia.

title: Battles of Lexington and Concord
event: April 19 – American Revolution: Hostility between Britain and its American colonies explodes into bloodshed at the Battles of Lexington and Concord on the 19th,April 19, 1775, with the Battles of Lexington and Concord.< which ignites the American Revolution.

title: Capture of Fort Ticonderoga
event: American Revolution: Ethan Allen and Benedict Arnold, leading the Green Mountain Boys of Vermont, capture Fort Ticonderoga.

title: Battle of Bunker Hill
event: June 17 – American Revolution: Two months into the colonial siege of Boston, British open fire on Breed's Hill on Charles Town Peninsula. After 3 charges, the British take the hill in the misnamed Battle of Bunker Hill.

title: Nova Scotia
event: August 29 – September 12 – The ''Independence Hurricane'' from South Carolina to Nova Scotia kills 4,170, mostly fishermen and sailors.

title: Quebec
event: November 13 – American Revolution – Battle of Montreal: American forces under Brigadier General Richard Montgomery capture Montreal. British General Guy Carleton escapes to Quebec.

title: Cambridge Massachusetts
event: December 5 – American Revolution: Henry Knox begins his journey to  Cambridge, Massachusetts with the artillery that has been captured from Fort Ticonderoga.

title: Quebec
event: December 31 – American Revolution: British forces repulse an attack by Continental Army generals Richard Montgomery and Benedict Arnold at Quebec.

title: South Carolina
event: January 20 – American Revolution: South Carolina Loyalists led by Robert Cunningham sign a petition from prison agreeing to all demands for peace by the formed state government of South Carolina.

title: Cambridge Massachusetts
event: January 24 – American Revolution: Henry Knox arrives at Cambridge, Massachusetts with the artillery that he has transported from Fort Ticonderoga

title: Wilmington North Carolina
event: February 27 – American Revolution: Battle of Moore's Creek Bridge: North Carolina Loyalists charge across Moore's Creek bridge near Wilmington to attack what they mistakenly believe to be a small force of rebels. Several loyalist leaders are killed in the ensuing battle. The patriot victory virtually ends all British authority in the town.

title: Massachusetts
event: March 4 – The American Revolution: The Americans capture Dorchester Heights dominating the port of Boston, Massachusetts.

title: Rhode Island
event: May 4 – Rhode Island becomes the first American colony to renounce allegiance to King George III of Great Britain.

title: Virginia
event: June 7 – American Revolution: Richard Henry Lee of Virginia proposes to the Continental Congress that these united colonies are, and of right ought to be, free and independent states.

title: Battle of Trois-Rivières
event: June 8 – American Revolution: Battle of Trois-Rivières: American invaders are driven back at Trois-Rivières, Quebec.

title: New York City
event: July 9 – American Revolution: An angry mob in New York City topples the equestrian statue of George III in Bowling Green.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: July 12 – Captain James Cook sets off from Plymouth England on his third, and fatal, expedition to the Pacific Ocean.

title: Brooklyn
event: August 27 – American Revolution: Battle of Long Island: Washington's troops routed in Brooklyn by British under William Howe.

title: Guadeloupe
event: September 6 – Hurricane hits Guadeloupe, killing more than 6000.

title: New York Harbor
event: September 7 – American Revolution: World's first submarine attack. American submersible craft ''Turtle'' attempts to attach a time bomb to the hull of British Admiral Richard Howe's flagship ''HMS Eagle'' in New York Harbor.

title: Landing at Kip's Bay
event: September 15 – American Revolution: British land on Manhattan at Kip's Bay.

title: New York City
event: September 22 – American Revolution: Nathan Hale executed in New York City for espionage.

title: New York City
event: October 11 – American Revolution: Battle of Valcour Island: On Lake Champlain near Valcour Island, a British fleet led by Sir Guy Carleton defeats 15 American gunboats commanded by Brigadier General Benedict Arnold. Although nearly all of Arnold's ships are destroyed, the two day-long battle will give Patriot forces enough time to prepare defenses of New York City.

title: Battle of White Plains
event: October 28 – American Revolution: Battle of White Plains: British forces arrive at White Plains, attack and capture Chatterton Hill from the Americans.

title: Battle of Fort Washington
event: November 16 – American Revolution: Hessian mercenaries under Lieutenant General Wilhelm von Knyphausen capture Fort Washington from the American Continentals.

title: North Carolina
event: December 21 – American Revolution: The Royal Colony of North Carolina reorganizes into the State of North Carolina after adopting its own constitution. Richard Caswell becomes the first governor of the newly formed state.

title: Battle of Trenton
event: December 26 – American Revolution: Battle of Trenton: Washington's troops surprise the 1500 Hessian troops under the command of Col. Johann Rall at 8 a.m. outside Trenton and score a victory, taking 948 prisoners while suffering only 5 wounded.

title: Ireland
event: The code duello is adopted at the Clonmell Summer Assizes as the form for pistol duels in Ireland. It is quickly denounced but nevertheless widely adopted throughout the English-speaking world.

title: Kunsthochschule Kassel
event: Kunsthochschule Kassel is founded

title: United Kingdom
event: January 3 – American Revolution – Battle of Princeton: American general George Washington defeats British general Charles Cornwallis.

title: Mission Santa Clara de Asís
event: January 12 – Mission Santa Clara de Asís is founded in what is now Santa Clara, California.

title: New York
event: January 15 – Vermont declares its independence from New York, becoming the Vermont Republic, an independent country, a status it retains until it joins the United States as the 14th state in 1791.

title: United Kingdom
event: August 16 – American Revolution – Battle of Bennington: British forces are defeated by American troops.

title: Delaware
event: September 3 – American Revolution – Cooch's Bridge: In a minor skirmish in New Castle County, Delaware, the Flag of the United States was flown in battle for the first time.

title: Pennsylvania
event: September 11 – American Revolution – Battle of Brandywine: The British gain a major victory in Chester County, Pennsylvania.

title: Philadelphia
event: September 26 – American Revolution – British troops occupy Philadelphia during the Revolutionary War.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 4 – American Revolution – Battle of Germantown: Troops under George Washington are repelled by British troops under Sir William Howe.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 17 – American Revolution – Battle of Saratoga: British General John Burgoyne surrenders to the American troops.

title: York Pennsylvania
event: November 15 – American Revolution: After 16 months of debate, the Continental Congress approves the Articles of Confederation in the temporary American capital at York, Pennsylvania.

title: Alta California
event: November 29 – San Jose, California is founded.  It is the first ''pueblo'' in Spanish Alta California.

title: Louisville Kentucky
event: The first settlement is made in the area of what is now Louisville, Kentucky by 13 families under Colonel George Rogers Clark.

title: Phillips Academy
event: Phillips Academy, the most prestigious secondary boarding school in the United States, is founded by Samuel Phillips Jr.

title: New Jersey
event: The term thoroughbred is first used in the United States in an advertisement in a Kentucky gazette to describe a New Jersey stallion called Pilgarlick.

title: Kauai
event: January 18 – The third Pacific expedition of Capt. James Cook, with ships HMS ''Resolution'' and HMS ''Discovery'', first view O'ahu then Kaua'i in the Hawaiian Islands, which he names the ''Sandwich Islands''.

title: South Carolina
event: February 5 – South Carolina becomes the first state to ratify the Articles of Confederation.

title: France
event: February 6 – American Revolutionary War: In Paris the Treaty of Alliance and the Treaty of Amity and Commerce are signed by the United States and France, signaling official recognition of the new republic.

title: Pennsylvania
event: February 23 – American Revolutionary War: Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben arrives at Valley Forge, Pennsylvania and begins to train the American troops.

title: Valley Forge
event: May 30 – Benedict Arnold signs US oath of allegiance at Valley Forge

title: Virginia
event: June 24 – A total solar eclipse takes place across parts of USA from Texas to Virginia.

title: New Jersey
event: June 28 – American Revolutionary War – Battle of Monmouth: George Washington's Continental Army battles the British general Sir Henry Clinton's army to a draw near Monmouth, New Jersey.

title: Wilkes-Barre Pennsylvania
event: July 3 – American Revolutionary War: the Wyoming Massacre takes place near Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, ending in a terrible defeat of the local colonists.

title: France
event: July 27 – American Revolution – First Battle of Ushant: British and French fleets fight to a standoff.

title: Triglav
event: August 26 – Triglav, at 2,864 meters above sea level the highest peak of Slovenia, is ascended for the first time by four brave{{Citation neededdate=May 2010}} men: Luka Korošec, Matevž Kos, Štefan Rožič, and Lovrenc Willomitzer on Sigmund Zois' initiative.

title: Aquidneck Island
event: August 29 – American Revolutionary War: The Battle of Rhode Island takes place when the Continental Army attempts to retake Aquidneck Island from the British.

title: Maui
event: November 26 – In the Hawaiian Islands, Capt. James Cook becomes the first European to land on Maui.

title: Gibraltar
event: July – The Great Siege of Gibraltar (fourteenth and last military siege) starts. This is an action by French and Spanish forces to wrest control of Gibraltar from the established British garrison. The garrison, led by George Augustus Eliott, later 1st Baron Heathfield of Gibraltar, survives all attacks and a blockade of supplies.

title: Shropshire
event: The Iron Bridge is completed across the River Severn in Shropshire (the first all cast-iron bridge ever constructed).

title: Boulton and Watt
event: Boulton and Watt's  ''Smethwick Engine'', now the oldest working engine in the world, is brought into service.

title: Finland
event: The city of Tampere, Finland is founded.

title: Orange County New York
event: January 22 – American Revolutionary War: Claudius Smith is hanged at Goshen, Orange County, New York for supposed acts of terrorism upon the people of the surrounding communities.

title: Louisburg North Carolina
event: January 29 – After a second petition for partition from its residents, the North Carolina General Assembly abolishes Bute County, North Carolina (established 1764) by dividing it and naming the northern portion Warren County (for Revolutionary War hero Joseph Warren) and the southern portion Franklin County (for Benjamin Franklin).  The General Assembly also establishes Warrenton (also named for Joseph Warren) to be the county seat of Warren County and Louisburg (named for Louis XVI of France) to be the county seat of Franklin County.

title: Innviertel
event: May 13 –  War of Bavarian Succession: Russian and French mediators at the Congress of Teschen negotiate an end to the war. In the agreement Austria receives a part of the Bavarian territory (the Innviertel) and relinquishes the rest.

title: Penobscot Expedition
event: July 24 – American Revolutionary War: American forces led by Commodore Dudley Saltonstall launch the Penobscot Expedition in what is now Castine, Maine, resulting in the worst naval defeat in U.S. history until Pearl Harbor.

title: Battle of Flamborough Head
event: September 23 – American Revolution – Battle of Flamborough Head: The American ship ''Bonhomme Richard'', commanded by John Paul Jones, engages the British ship ''Serapis''.  The ''Bonhomme Richard'' sinks, but the Americans board the ''Serapis'' and other vessels, and are victorious.

title: Wayne County North Carolina
event: November 2 – The North Carolina General Assembly carves a new county from Dobbs County, North Carolina and names it Wayne County in honor of United States General Anthony Wayne.

title: Nashville Tennessee
event: December 25 – Fort Nashborough, later to become Nashville, Tennessee, is founded by James Robertson.

title: Cape St. Vincent
event: 9 August – American Revolutionary War: Spanish admiral Luis de Córdova y Córdova captures a British convoy totalling 55 vessels amongst Indiamen, frigates and other cargo ships off Cape St. Vincent.

title: Craven Cottage
event: The original Craven Cottage is built by William Craven, 6th Baron Craven (located on the centre circle of the pitch).

title: Battle of Cape St. Vincent (1780)
event: January 16 – American Revolutionary War – Battle of Cape St. Vincent:  British Admiral Sir George Rodney defeats a Spanish fleet.

title: Denmark
event: February – The League of Armed Neutrality is formed between Denmark, Sweden, and Russia.

title: University of Münster
event: April 16 – The University of Münster in Münster, North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany is founded.

title: New England
event: May 19 – New England's Dark Day: An unaccountable darkness spreads over New England, regarded by some observers as a fulfillment of Bible prophecy.

title: House of Lords
event: June 2 – Gordon Riots in London, Great Britain: The Duke of Richmond calls, in the House of Lords, for manhood suffrage and annual parliaments.

title: Camden South Carolina
event: August 16 – American Revolutionary War – Battle of Camden: British troops inflict heavy losses on a Patriot army at Camden, South Carolina.

title: West Point New York
event: September 21 – Benedict Arnold gives detailed plans of West Point to Major John André. Three days later, André is captured with papers revealing that Arnold was planning to surrender West Point to the British.

title: New York
event: September 25 – Benedict Arnold flees to British-held New York.

title: Battle of Kings Mountain
event: October 7 – American Revolutionary War – Battle of Kings Mountain: Patriot militia forces annihilate a Loyalists under British Major Patrick Ferguson at Kings Mountain in South Carolina.

title: Martinique
event: October 10–October 16 – The Great Hurricane flattens the islands of Barbados, Martinique and St. Eustatius: 22,000 dead.

title: Socorro Santander
event: March – Riots break out in Socorro and spread to other towns.

title: Washington & Jefferson College
event: December – A school is founded in Washington County, Pennsylvania that would later be known as Washington & Jefferson College.

title: Phillips Exeter Academy
event: Founding of Phillips Exeter Academy

title: Maryland
event: January 2 – Virginia passes a law ceding its western land claims, paving the way for Maryland to ratify the Articles of Confederation.

title: Richmond Virginia
event: January 5 – American Revolution: Richmond, Virginia is burned by British naval forces led by Benedict Arnold.

title: Battle of Jersey
event: January 6 – Battle of Jersey: The British beat the French in what is technically the last battle fought in the British Islands (coming after the Battle of Culloden in 1745). It is the last attempt by France to invade Jersey militarily.

title: Battle of Cowpens
event: January 17 – American Revolution – Battle of Cowpens: Americans under Daniel Morgan defeat British forces.

title: Maryland
event: February 2 – The Articles of Confederation are ratified by Maryland, the 13th and final state to do so.

title: Lima
event: May 18 – An army sent from Lima put down the rebellions and captures and savagely execute Túpac Amaru II.

title: Moore County North Carolina
event: July 29 – American Revolution – Skirmish at the House in the Horseshoe: A Tory force under David Fanning attacks Phillip Alston's smaller force of Whigs at Alston's home in Cumberland County, North Carolina (in present day Moore County, North Carolina).  Alston's troops surrender after Fanning's men attempt to ram the house with a cart of burning straw.

title: Battle of Groton Heights
event: September 6 – American Revolution – Battle of Groton Heights: The British army attacks a fort in Groton, Connecticut.

title: New York City
event: September 10 – American Revolution: Graves gives up trying to break through the now-reinforced French fleet and returns to New York, leaving Cornwallis to his fate.

title: Siege of Yorktown
event: October 19 – American Revolution: Following the Siege of Yorktown, General Charles Cornwallis surrenders to General George Washington at Yorktown, Virginia, ending the armed struggle of the American Revolution.

title: London
event: Henry Hurle officially founds the Ancient Order of Druids(AOD) in London, England.

title: London
event: London creates the Foot Patrol for public security.

title: Parliament of the United Kingdom
event: The British parliament extends James Watt's patent for the steam engine to the year 1800.

title: China
event: In China, the Siku Quanshu is completed, the largest literary compilation in China's history (surpassing the Yongle Encyclopedia of the 15th century). The books are bound in 36,381 volumes (册) with more than 79,000 chapters (卷), comprising about 2.3 million pages, and approximately 800 million Chinese characters.

title: Minorca
event: The Spanish defeat British forces and capture Minorca.

title: Ohio
event: In Ohio, the Gnadenhutten massacre of Native Americans takes place in which 29 men, 27 women, and 34 children are killed by white militiamen in retaliation for raids carried out by another Native American group.

title: Mission San Buenaventura
event: March 31 – Mission San Buenaventura was founded on Easter Sunday in Las Californias, part of the Spanish Viceroyalty of New Spain.

title: Bangkok
event: April 6 – Rama I succeeds King Taksin of Siam, who was overthrown in an coup d'etat; moves capital to Bangkok.

title: France
event: April 12 – Battle of the Saintes: A British fleet under Admiral Sir George Rodney defeats a French fleet under the Comte de Grasse in the West Indies.

title: Switzerland
event: June 18 – In Switzerland, Anna Göldi is sentenced to death for witchcraft (the last legal witchcraft sentence).

title: Nova Scotia
event: July 1 – American privateers attack Lunenburg, Nova Scotia.

title: New York
event: Loyalists from New York settle Great Abaco in the Bahamas.

title: Ireland
event: Ireland's last grey wolf is killed.

title: Great Britain
event: February 3 – American Revolutionary War: Britain acknowledges the United States independence.

title: Great Britain
event: American Revolutionary War: Great Britain formally declares that it will cease hostilities with the United States of America.

title: Italy
event: A sequence of earthquakes begins in Calabria, Italy, leaves 50,000 dead.

title: Saint John New Brunswick
event: May 18 – Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada – The first United Empire Loyalists reach Parrtown.

title: France
event: June 4 or June 5 – The Montgolfier brothers publicly demonstrate their ''montgolfière'' (hot air balloon) in Annonay, France.

title: Laki
event: June 8 – The volcano Laki, in Iceland, begins an 8-month eruption which kills tens of thousands throughout Europe, including 1/5 of Iceland's population, and causes widespread famine. It has been described as one of the greatest environmental catastrophes in European History.

title: Mount Asama
event: August 5 – Mount Asama erupts, causing turmoil in Edo period Japan.

title: France
event: August 18 – A large fireball passes on a thousand-mile track across the North Sea, the United Kingdom and France, prompting scientific discussion.

title: Jacques Charles
event: August 27 – ''Le Globe'' - Jacques Charles and Les Frères Robert launched the world's first hydrogen-filled balloon in Paris.

title: Dickinson College
event: September 9 – Dickinson College was chartered in Carlisle, Pennsylvania.

title: Rocky Hill New Jersey
event: November 2 – In Rocky Hill, New Jersey, US General George Washington gives his ''Farewell Address to the Army''.

title: Trinidad and Tobago
event: November 24 – In Spain, the ''Cedula of Population'' is signed, stating that anyone who will swear fealty to Spain and is of the Roman Catholic faith is welcome to populate Trinidad and Tobago.

title: New York City
event: November 25 – American Revolutionary War: The last British troops leave New York City 3 months after the signing of the Treaty of Paris.

title: New Jersey
event: November 30 – A 5.3 magnitude earthquake struck New Jersey.

title: Jacques Charles
event: December 1 – ''La Charlière'' - Jacques Charles and Nicolas-Louis Robert made the first manned flight in a hydrogen-filled balloon in Paris.

title: New York City
event: December 4 – At Fraunces Tavern in New York City, U.S. General George Washington formally bids his officers farewell.

title: Alta California
event: King Carlos III of the Spanish Empire authorizes land grants in Alta California.

title: Morganton North Carolina
event: The North Carolina General Assembly incorporates the town of Morgansborough, named for Daniel Morgan.  The town is designated as the county seat for Burke County, North Carolina and is subsequently renamed Morgantown and later shortened to become Morganton.

title: South Africa
event: A huge locust swarm hits South Africa.

title: France
event: Benjamin Franklin tries in vain to persuade the French to alter their clocks in winter to take advantage of the daylight.

title: India
event: The India Act requires that the governor general be chosen from outside the British East India Company and it makes company directors subject to parliamentary supervision.

title: London
event: January 15 – Henry Cavendish's paper to the Royal Society of London, ''Experiments on Air'', reveals the composition of water.Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of Londonvolume=75pages=372-384}}<

title: France
event: June 4 – Elisabeth Thible is the first woman to ride in a balloon, at Lyon, France.

title: New Brunswick
event: August 16 – Britain creates the colony of New Brunswick.

title: Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Baltimore
event: November 26 – The Roman Catholic Apostolic Prefecture of the United States is established.

title: University of New Brunswick
event: The University of New Brunswick is founded in Fredericton, New Brunswick, Canada.

title: Barbados
event: The British government establishes a permanent land force in the Eastern Caribbean, based in Barbados.

title: Lincoln County North Carolina
event: The North Carolina General Assembly incorporates Lincolnton, North Carolina (named for American General Benjamin Lincoln) as the new county seat for Lincoln County.

title: Belfast
event: Belfast Academy (later Belfast Royal Academy) is founded by Rev. Dr James Crombie in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

title: London
event: January 1 – The first issue of the ''Daily Universal Register'', later known as ''The Times'', is published in London.

title: English Channel
event: January 7 – Frenchman Jean-Pierre Blanchard and American John Jeffries travel from Dover, England to Calais, France in a hydrogen gas balloon, becoming the first to cross the English Channel by air.

title: University of Georgia
event: January 27 – The University of Georgia is founded.

title: Cherokee Nation
event: November 28 – The Treaty of Hopewell is signed between the United States of America and the Cherokee Nation.

title: Belize
event: An Anglo-Spanish treaty gives Belize to Britain.

title: Australia
event: The first ship leaves Britain for Botany Bay, Australia: 820 out of 1,138 aboard are convicts.

title: Denmark
event: The trade with Iceland is opened to all Danish and Norwegian traders.

title: Reykjavík
event: Reykjavík, the capital of Iceland, is founded.

title: Greenville North Carolina
event: The town of Martinsborough, North Carolina, itself named for Royal Governor Josiah Martin in 1771, is renamed Greenesville in honor of United States General Nathanael Greene by the North Carolina General Assembly; the name Greenesville is later shortened to become Greenville.

title: Kolkata
event: February 2 – In a speech before The Asiatic Society in Calcutta, Sir William Jones notes the formal resemblances between Latin, Greek, and Sanskrit, laying the foundation for comparative linguistics and Indo-European studies.

title: Vienna
event: May 1 – Mozart's opera ''The Marriage of Figaro'' premieres in Vienna.

title: China
event: June 10 – An earthquake-caused landslide dam on the Dadu River gives way, killing 100,000 in the Sichuan province of China.

title: Bering Sea
event: June 25 – Gavriil Pribylov discovers St. George Island of the Pribilof Islands in the Bering Sea.

title: West Virginia
event: August – James Rumsey tests his first steam boat in the Potomac river at Shepherdstown Virginia (now West Virginia).

title: Mont Blanc
event: August 8 –  Mont Blanc is climbed for the first time by Dr. Michael-Gabriel Paccard and Jacques Balmat.

title: Massachusetts
event: August 29 – Shays' Rebellion begins in Massachusetts.

title: Barbados
event: September 2 – A hurricane strikes Barbados.

title: Mission Santa Barbara
event: December 4 – Mission Santa Barbara is founded by Father Fermín Francisco de Lasuén, becoming the 10th mission in the California mission chain.

title: Wayne County North Carolina
event: The North Carolina General Assembly incorporates Waynesborough and designates it the county seat for Wayne County, North Carolina.

title: Pittsboro North Carolina
event: January 6 – The North Carolina General Assembly authorizes nine commissioners to purchase {{Convert100acrekm2}} of land for the county seat of Chatham County.  The town is named Pittsborough (later shortened to Pittsboro) for William Pitt the Younger.

title: University of Pittsburgh
event: February 28 – A charter is granted establishing the institution known today as the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Vreeswijk
event: May – Orangist troops attack Vreeswijk, Harmelen and Maarssen; civil war starts in the Netherlands.

title: Australia
event: May 13 – Captain Arthur Phillip leaves Portsmouth, England with 11 ships packed with 1,000 convicts and their jailers to establish a penal colony in Australia.

title: Pennsylvania
event: May 14 – In Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, delegates begin arriving to write a new Constitution for the United States.

title: Pennsylvania
event: May 25 – In Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, delegates begin to convene a Constitutional Convention intended to amend the Articles of Confederation. However, a new Constitution for the United States is eventually produced. George Washington presides over the Convention.

title: Goejanverwellesluis
event: June 28 – Princess Wilhelmina of Orange, sister of Frederick, the king of Prussia, is captured by patriots and taken to Goejanverwellesluis, and not allowed to travel to the Hague.

title: New York
event: October 27 – The first of the ''Federalist Papers'', a series of essays calling for ratification of the U.S. Constitution, is published in a New York paper.

title: Estates Theatre
event: October 29 – Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's opera ''Don Giovanni'' (libretto by Lorenzo da Ponte) premieres in the Estates Theatre in Prague.

title: Delaware
event: December 7 – Delaware ratifies the Constitution and becomes the first U.S. state.

title: Pennsylvania
event: December 12 – Pennsylvania becomes the second U.S. state.

title: New Jersey
event: December 18 – New Jersey becomes the third U.S. state.

title: Georgia (U.S. state)
event: January 2 – Georgia ratifies the United States Constitution and becomes the 4th U.S. state under the new government.

title: Connecticut
event: January 9 – Connecticut ratifies the United States Constitution and becomes the 5th U.S. state.

title: Botany Bay
event: January 18 – Captain Arthur Phillip's ship arrives at Botany Bay.

title: Sydney Cove
event: January 26 – Captain Arthur Phillip decides to make the permanent settlement at Sydney Cove.

title: New South Wales
event: January 26 – Australia Day: Eleven ships of the First Fleet from Botany Bay, led by Arthur Phillip, land in what will become Sydney, Australia. Great Britain establishes the prison colony of New South Wales, the first permanent European settlement on the continent.

title: Great Britain
event: January 31 – Henry Benedict Stuart becomes the new Stuart claimant to the throne of Great Britain as King Henry IX and the figurehead of Jacobitism.

title: Massachusetts
event: February 6 – Massachusetts ratifies the United States Constitution and becomes the 6th U.S. state.

title: Norfolk Island
event: February 17 – The uninhabited Lord Howe Island is discovered by the brig HMS ''Supply'', commanded by Lieutenant Ball, who is on his way from Botany Bay to Norfolk Island with convicts to start a penal settlement there.

title: St. Louis Cathedral New Orleans
event: March 21 – Great New Orleans Fire (1788) kills 25% of the population and destroys 856 buildings, including St. Louis Cathedral and the Cabildo, leaving most of the town in ruins.

title: Maryland
event: April 28 – Maryland ratifies the United States Constitution and becomes the 7th U.S. state.

title: Royal Dramatic Theatre
event: May 10 – The ''Royal Dramatic Theatre'', Sweden's national stage, is founded.

title: South Carolina
event: May 23 – South Carolina ratifies the United States Constitution and becomes the 8th U.S. state.

title: France
event: June 7 – France: Day of the Tiles, which some consider the beginning of the French Revolution.

title: Niger River
event: June 9 – England: The African Association, an exploration group dedicated to plotting the Niger River and finding Timbuktu, is founded.

title: New Hampshire
event: June 21 – New Hampshire ratifies the United States Constitution and becomes the 9th U.S. state, enabling the Constitution to go into effect. (The latter happened on March 4, 1789, when the first Congress elected under the new Constitution assembled.)

title: Vienna
event: June 26 – Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, in Vienna, completes his antepenultimate symphony, now called the Symphony No. 39 (Mozart) in E-flat. He completes the 40th and 41st in July and August.

title: New York
event: July 26 – New York ratifies the United States Constitution and becomes the 11th U.S. state.

title: Vienna
event: July 28- Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, in Vienna, completes his penultimate symphony, now called the Symphony No. 40 (Mozart) in G Minor.

title: Vienna
event: August 10 – Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, in Vienna, completes his final symphony, now called the Symphony No. 41 (Mozart) in C Major, and nicknamed (after Mozart's death) ''The Jupiter.''

title: Fort Washington Cincinnati Ohio
event: Fort Washington is built in Cincinnati, Ohio, to protect early U.S. settlements in the Northwest Territory.

title: Massachusetts
event: January 21 – The first American novel, ''The Power of Sympathy or the Triumph of Nature Founded in Truth'', is printed in Boston, Massachusetts.

title: Georgetown University
event: January 23 – Georgetown University is founded in Washington, D.C., becoming the first Catholic college in the United States.

title: New York City
event: March 4 – At Federal Hall in New York City, the 1st United States Congress meets and declares the new United States Constitution to be in effect.

title: Pennsylvania
event: April 1 – At Federal Hall, the United States House of Representatives attains its first quorum and elects Frederick Muhlenberg of Pennsylvania as its first Speaker of the House.

title: HMS Bounty
event: April 28 – Mutiny on the ''Bounty'': Fletcher Christian leads the mutiny on HMS ''Bounty'' against Captain William Bligh.

title: France
event: May 5 – In France, the Estates-General convenes for the first time in 175 years.

title: Timor
event: June 14 – ''Bounty'' mutiny survivors, including Captain William Bligh and 18 others, reach Timor after a nearly {{convert4000mikmadj=on}} journey in an open boat.

title: France
event: June 17 – In France, representatives of the Third Estate at the Estates-General declare themselves the National Assembly.

title: Tennis Court Oath
event: June 20 – Tennis Court Oath is made in Versailles.

title: Grand Théâtre de Bordeaux
event: July 1 – The comic ballet ''La fille mal gardée'' choreographed by Jean Dauberval is first presented under the title ''Le ballet de la paille'' at the Grand Théâtre de Bordeaux, in Bordeaux, France.

title: Mackenzie River
event: July 10 – Alexander Mackenzie reaches Mackenzie River Delta.

title: France
event: July 11 – Louis XVI of France fires popular Chief Minister Necker.

title: France
event: August 4 – In France, members of the Constituent Assembly take an oath to end feudalism and abandon their privileges.

title: France
event: August 26 – The Declaration of the Rights of Man is proclaimed in France.

title: New Jersey
event: November 20 – New Jersey ratifies the United States Bill of Rights, the first state to do so.

title: North Carolina
event: November 21 – North Carolina ratifies the United States Constitution and becomes the 12th U.S. state.

title: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
event: December 11 – The University of North Carolina, the  oldest public university in the United States, is founded.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: February 1 – In New York City the Supreme Court of the United States convenes for the first time.

title: France
event: March 4 – France is divided into 83 départements, which cut across the former provinces, in an attempt to dislodge regional loyalties based on noble ownership of land.

title: New York
event: March 21 – Thomas Jefferson reports to President George Washington in New York as the new United States Secretary of State.

title: Estonia
event: May 13 – Battle of Reval: Gustav III of Sweden sends the battlefleet to eliminate the Russian squadron wintering at Reval (Estonia), but is defeated: 8 Russians, 51 Swedes are killed, 250 captured, and 2 ships are sunk.

title: Rhode Island
event: May 29 – Rhode Island ratifies the United States Constitution and becomes the last of the 13 original states to do so.

title: London
event: June 23 – The alleged ''London Monster'' is arrested in London: he later receives 40 years for 10 assaults.

title: Baltic Sea
event: July 9 – Russo-Swedish War – Second Battle of Svensksund: In a massive Baltic Sea battle of 300 ships, the Swedish navy captures one third of the Russian fleet: 304 Swedes are killed, 3,500 Russians killed and 6,000 captured, 51 Russian ships are sunk and 22 are taken.

title: Izmail
event: December 11 – Russo-Turkish War, 1787-1792: 26,000 Turkish soldiers lose their lives during Suvorov's storm of Izmail.

title: Pittsfield Massachusetts
event: An ordinance is written barring the game of baseball within 80 yards of the Meeting House in Pittsfield, Massachusetts (first known reference to the game of baseball in North America).

title: Parliament of the United Kingdom
event: January 25 – The British Parliament passes the Constitutional Act of 1791, splitting the old province of Quebec into Upper and Lower Canada.

title: Vermont
event: March 4 – Vermont is admitted as the 14th U.S. state.

title: Jones Point Light
event: April 21 – The first of forty boundary stones delineating the borders of the new District of Columbia is laid at Jones Point Light, in Alexandria, Virginia.

title: Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth
event: May 3 – The Sejm  of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth proclaims the Constitution of May 3, 1791, the first modern codified constitution in Europe.

title: Birmingham
event: July 14 – The Priestley Riots break out in Birmingham, England.

title: Champ de Mars
event: July 17 – The Champ de Mars Massacre occurs during the French Revolution.

title: Brandenburg Gate
event: August 6 – The Brandenburg Gate in Berlin is finished.

title: Mission Santa Cruz
event: September 25 – Mission Santa Cruz is founded by Father Fermín Francisco de Lasuén, becoming the 12th mission in the California mission chain.

title: Vienna
event: September 30 – Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's singspiel ''Die Zauberflöte'' ''(Magic Flute)'' premieres in the Freihaustheater in Vienna.

title: Mission Nuestra Señora de la Soledad
event: October 9 – Mission Nuestra Señora de la Soledad is founded by Father Fermín Francisco de Lasuén, becoming the 13th mission in the California mission chain.

title: India
event: Tipu Sultan invades Kerala in India, but is repulsed.

title: London
event: Thomas Holcroft produces the play ''Road to Ruin'' in London.

title: Vienna
event: Johann Georg Albrechtberger becomes Kapellmeister in Vienna.

title: Wake County North Carolina
event: March 20 – A new capital of North Carolina and county seat of the newly formed Wake County is established after North Carolina State Senator and surveyor William Christmas submits his design for the city.  A few months later the capital is officially named Raleigh in honor of Sir Walter Raleigh.

title: France
event: April 20 – France declares war against Austria.

title: Brazil
event: April 21 – Tiradentes, prime figure in the Inconfidência Mineira plot, is executed in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

title: France
event: April 24 – The guillotine is first used experimentally in France.

title: France
event: ''La Marseillaise'', the French national anthem, is composed by Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle.

title: Mount Unzen
event: May 21 – An old lava dome collapses in Kyūshū, Japan when Mount Unzen volcano erupts; the resulting avalanche and tsunami kills about 14,300 people.

title: Kentucky
event: June 1 – Kentucky becomes the 15th state of The United States of America.

title: Puget Sound
event: June 4 – Captain George Vancouver claims Puget Sound for Great Britain.

title: Burrard Inlet
event: June 13 – Vancouver becomes the first European to enter Burrard Inlet.

title: France
event: June 13 – Prussia declares war against France.

title: Tuileries Palace
event: August 10 – French Revolution: The Tuileries Palace is stormed, and Louis XVI of France is arrested and taken into custody.

title: China
event: September – George Macartney, 1st Earl Macartney sails from Portsmouth to China.

title: Battle of Valmy
event: September 20 – Battle of Valmy: The French revolutionary army defeats Prussians under the Duke of Brunswick, after a 7-hour artillery duel.

title: French First Republic
event: September 21 – The French Convention abolishes the monarchy and establishes the First Republic.

title: New York
event: October 12 – The first Columbus Day celebration in the USA is held in New York, 300 years after his arrival in the New World.

title: White House
event: October 13 – Foundation of Washington, DC: The cornerstone of the United States Executive Mansion, known as the White House after 1818, is laid.

title: Oregon
event: October 29 – Mount Hood (Oregon) is named after the British naval officer Samuel Hood by Lt. William E. Broughton, who spots the mountain near the mouth of the Willamette River.

title: Guangzhou
event: June – George Macartney, 1st Earl Macartney reaches Canton.

title: France
event: The Holy Roman Empire declares war on France.

title: France
event: The metric system is adopted in France.

title: Great Britain
event: February 1 – France declares war on Great Britain and the Netherlands (see French Revolutionary Wars).

title: Philadelphia
event: March 4 – George Washington is sworn in as President of the United States in Philadelphia, for his second term.

title: France
event: March 5 – French troops are defeated by Austrian forces and Liège is recaptured.

title: France
event: April 6 – The Committee of Public Safety is established in France with Georges Danton as its head.

title: Jardin des Plantes
event: June 10 – The Jardin des Plantes and the Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle are created by the National Convention. The museum opens in Paris the following year and also becomes the first public zoo.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: July 22 – Alexander Mackenzie reaches the Pacific Ocean.

title: France
event: September 5 – In France, the French National Convention votes to implement terror measures to repress 'counter-revolutionary' activities. The ensuing ''Reign of Terror'' lasts until the spring of 1794 and causes the deaths of 35,000–40,000 people.

title: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
event: October 12 – The cornerstone of Old East, the oldest state university building in the United States, is laid in Chapel Hill, North Carolina, on the campus of the University of North Carolina (the 12th of October is now celebrated at the University as University Day).

title: New York City
event: December 9 – New York City's first daily newspaper, the ''American Minerva'', is established by Noah Webster.

title: Siege of Toulon
event: December 18 – French forces under Dugommier capture Toulon from royalists and British forces under Vice Admiral Lord Hood. The British fire the dockyards and take 16 ships, one of which is ''HMS Lutine'', a famous treasure ship.

title: France
event: France occupies Aachen.

title: Ayrshire
event: The Ayrshire (Earl of Carrick's Own) Yeomanry, a British Yeomanry Cavalry Regiment, is formed by the Earl of Cassillis at Culzean Castle, Ayrshire.

title: Mississippi
event: Britain agrees to evacuate border forts in the Northwest Territory (roughly the area north of the Ohio River and east of the Mississippi) and thereby end British support for the Indians.

title: USS Constitution
event: March 27 – The United States Government authorizes the building of the first 6 United States Navy vessels (in 1797 the first 3 frigates, USS ''United States'', USS ''Constellation'' and USS ''Constitution'' go into service), not to be confused with October 13, 1775 which is observed as the [http://www.history.navy.mil/birthday.htm Navy's Birthday].

title: Dutch Republic
event: June 26 – Battle of Fleurus: French forces defeat the Austrians and their allies, leading to permanent loss of the Austrian Netherlands and destruction of the Dutch Republic. French use of an observation balloon marks the first participation of an aircraft in battle.

title: Corsica
event: July 12 – Horatio Nelson loses the sight in his right eye at Calvi in Corsica.

title: University of Tennessee
event: September 10 – The University of Tennessee is established at Knoxville.

title: Fort Edmonton
event: The Hudson's Bay Company trading post Fort Edmonton is constructed; the city of Edmonton, Alberta eventually grows from it.

title: Curaçao
event: A large slave rebellion occurs in Curaçao.

title: France
event: Spain cedes its half of Hispaniola to France.

title: France
event: Sans-culottes revolt in France.

title: Nova Scotia
event: Daniel McGinnis discovers the famed money pit on Oak Island, Nova Scotia.

title: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
event: January 14 – The University of North Carolina (renamed The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1963) opens to students, becoming the first state university in the United States.

title: France
event: January 16 – The French occupy Utrecht, Netherlands.

title: Batavian Republic
event: January 19 – The Batavian Republic is proclaimed.

title: IJsselmeer
event: January 21 – The Dutch fleet, frozen in IJsselmeer, is captured by the French 8th Hussards.

title: France
event: April 5 – Peace of Basel signed between France and Prussia.

title: France
event: April 7 – France adopts the metre as the unit of length.

title: New South Wales
event: May and June – The ''Battle of Richmond Hill'' is fought in the colony of New South Wales, between the Darug people and British colonial forces.

title: Oahu
event: May 1 – Battle of Nu'uanu: Kamehameha I of the Island of Hawaii defeats the Oahuans, solidifying his control of the major islands of the archipelago and officially founding the Kingdom of Hawaii.

title: Brittany
event: British forces land off Quiberon to aid the revolt in Brittany.

title: France
event: June 28 – The French government announces that the heir to the French throne has died of illness (many doubt the statement).

title: Pontcysyllte Aqueduct
event: July 25 – Construction of the Pontcysyllte Aqueduct in Wales begins.

title: Treaty of Greenville
event: August 3 – The signature of the Treaty of Greenville puts an end to the Northwest Indian War.

title: Tbilisi
event: September 11 – 3 500 Georgians were likely to win over 35 000 Persians in battle of Krtsanisi, but two Armenians, Araratiants and Bebutov betrayed Georgian king and the Persian army of Agha Mohammad Khan Qajar destroys the Georgian capital Tbilisi.

title: Ireland
event: September 21 – Battle of the Diamond: Protestant forces defeat Catholic troops in Loughgall, Ireland, leading to the foundation of the Orange Order.

title: Yorkshire
event: December 13 – A meteorite falls at Wold Newton, a hamlet in Yorkshire in England. This meteorite fall is subsequently used as a literary premise by the science fiction writer Philip José Farmer as the basis for the Wold Newton family stories (see Wold Newton meteorite).

title: Norman Cross
event: The British government purchases a 40-acre (162,000 m²) site at Norman Cross (the first purposely built prisoner of war camp in Britain at that time).

title: Italy
event: April 27 – Case of the Lyons Mail: During the night of April 27, 5 highwaymen attack the mail between Paris and Lyon, kill the postmen, and steal the funds sent to the armies in Italy.

title: Derbent
event: Persian Expedition of 1796: Russian troops storm Derbent.

title: Italy
event: War of the First Coalition – Battle of Lodi: General Napoleon Bonaparte defeats Austrian rearguard in forcing a crossing of the bridge over the River Adda in Italy. The Austrians lose some 2,000 men, 14 guns, and 30 ammunition wagons.

title: Surrey
event: May 20 – The last mock Garrat Elections are held in Surrey, England.

title: Tennessee
event: June 1 – Tennessee is admitted as the 16th U.S. state.

title: Ségou
event: July 21 – Mungo Park reaches Ségou, the capital of the Bamana Empire.

title: Ohio
event: July 22 – Surveyors of the Connecticut Land Company name an area in Ohio Cleveland after Gen. Moses Cleaveland, the superintendent of the surveying party.

title: France
event: September 8 – French Revolutionary Wars – Battle of Bassano: French forces defeat Austrian troops.

title: Tripoli
event: November 4 – The Treaty of Tripoli (between the United States and Tripoli) is signed at Tripoli (see also 1797).

title: Italy
event: November 17 – French Revolutionary Wars – Battle of Arcole: French forces defeat the Austrians in Italy.

title: Tripoli
event: January 3 – The Treaty of Tripoli (a peace treaty between the United States and Tripoli) is signed at Algiers (see also 1796).

title: Cisalpine Republic
event: January 7 – The parliament of the Cisalpine Republic adopts the Italian green-white-red tricolour as the official flag (this is considered the birth of the flag of Italy).

title: Trinidad and Tobago
event: February 18 – Spanish Governor José Maria Chacón peacefully surrenders the colony of Trinidad to a British naval force commanded by Sir Ralph Abercromby.

title: Bank of England
event: February 26 – The Bank of England (national bank of Britain) issues the first one-pound and two-pound notes (discontinued March 11, 1988).

title: Battle of Santa Cruz de Tenerife (1797)
event: July 24 – Horatio Nelson is wounded at the Battle of Santa Cruz, losing an arm.

title: Tripoli
event: October 21 – In Boston Harbor, the 44-gun United States Navy frigate ''USS Constitution'' is launched to fight Barbary pirates off the coast of Tripoli.

title: Brazil
event: The first census in Brazil counts 2 million blacks in a total population of 3.25 million.

title: Ayrshire
event: The Ayrshire (Earl of Carrick's Own) Yeomanry, a British Yeomanry Cavalry Regiment, formed by The Earl of Cassillis at Culzean Castle, Ayrshire in 1794, is adopted onto the British Army list.

title: Batavian Republic
event: January 22 – A coup d'état is staged in the Netherlands (Batavian Republic). Unitarian Democrat Pieter Vreede makes an end to the power of the parliament (with a conservative-moderate majority).

title: Papal States
event: March 7 – French forces invade the Papal States and establish the Roman Republic.

title: South Carolina
event: April 7 – The Mississippi Territory is organized from territory ceded by Georgia and South Carolina and is later twice expanded to include disputed territory claimed by both the U.S. and Spain.

title: France
event: April 26 – France annexes Geneva.

title: Great Britain
event: May 23 – Irish republicans and nationalists known as the Society of United Irishmen launch a rebellion against British rule in expectation of support from France. The United Irishmen are unique amongst Irish nationalist movements in that they manage to unify Catholics and Protestants around republican ideals. The rebellion rages sporadically but is swiftly ended by October.

title: Malta
event: The French take Malta.

title: Batavian Republic
event: Another moderate coup d'état in the Netherlands (Batavian Republic) deposes Pieter Vreede.

title: Mission San Luis Rey de Francia
event: June 13 – Mission San Luis Rey de Francia is founded.

title: France
event: July 7 – Quasi-War: The United States Congress rescinds treaties with France, sparking the war.

title: Cairo
event: July 24 – Napoleon occupies Cairo.

title: Batavian Republic
event: July 31 – A second round of elections are held in the Netherlands (Batavian Republic); no general elections this time.

title: Abu Qir
event: August 1 – Battle of the Nile (near Abu Qir): Lord Nelson defeats the French navy under Admiral Brueys; Nelson himself is wounded in the head.

title: County Mayo
event: August 22 – French troops land at Kilcummin in County Mayo to assist the Irish rebellion.

title: Belize
event: September 10 – Battle of St. George's Caye: Off the coast of British Honduras (now Belize), a group of British nationals and African slaves defeat a force sent from Mexico to drive them out.

title: Place des Vosges
event: The Place Royale in Paris is renamed ''Place des Vosges'' when the Department of Vosges becomes the first to pay new Revolutionary taxes.

title: Prince Edward Island
event: The small town of Tignish, PE, Canada is founded.

title: North Carolina
event: 12-year-old Conrad John Reed finds what he describes as a heavy yellow rock along Little Meadow Creek in Cabarrus County, North Carolina and makes it a doorstop in his home. Conrad's father John Reed learns that the rock is actually gold in 1802, initiating the first gold rush in the United States.

title: India
event: The Nawab (provincial governor) of Oudh in northern India sends to George III of England the Padshah Nama, an official history of the reign of Shah Jahan.

title: Albania
event: March 7 – Napoleon captures Jaffa in Palestine and his troops proceed to kill more than 2,000 Albanian captives.

title: New York
event: March 29 – New York passes a law aimed at gradually abolishing slavery in the state.

title: Battle of Seringapatam
event: May 4 – Battle of Seringapatam: Tippu Sultan is defeated and killed by the British.

title: France
event: July 15 – In the Egyptian port city of Rosetta, French Captain Pierre Bouchard finds the Rosetta Stone.

title: Batavian Republic
event: August 27 – The British and Russians send an expedition to the Batavian Republic (now the Netherlands).

title: France
event: December – A new constitution is approved in a plebiscite in France.

title: Mount Vernon Virginia
event: December 14 – George Washington, the first President of the United States, dies in Mount Vernon, Virginia.

title: Oceania
event: Oceania: 2,000,000

title: Banque de France
event: February 13 – The Bank of France is founded

title: Library of Congress
event: April 24 – The U.S. Library of Congress is founded.

title: United Kingdom
event: May 5 – Great Britain passes the Act of Union to join Great Britain and Ireland into the United Kingdom (to take effect on 1 January 1801). The act is signed by King George III in August.

title: Italy
event: May 15 – Napoleon Bonaparte crosses the Alps and invades Italy.

title: Trinity Bight Newfoundland and Labrador
event: June 2 – First smallpox vaccination is made in North America, at Trinity, Newfoundland.

title: Gozo
event: September 5 – At the invitation of the Maltese, British troops liberate the Islands of Malta and Gozo from the French.

title: Great Britain
event: September 30 – The Convention of 1800, or Treaty of Mortefontaine, is signed between France, Britain, and the United States of America, ending the Quasi-War.

title: White House
event: U.S. President John Adams becomes the first President of the United States to live in the Executive Mansion (later renamed the White House).

title: Middlebury College
event: Middlebury College is granted its charter by the Vermont General Assembly.

title: France
event: Aachen is officially annexed by France.

title: London
event: The first census is held in Great Britain. London is revealed to have 860,035 residents. 1.5 million people live in cities of 20,000 or more in England and Wales, these accounting for 17% of the total English population.

title: France
event: The first census is held in France.

title: Hispaniola
event: Toussaint Louverture conquers Santo Domingo, declares himself emperor of the entire island of Hispaniola, abolishes slavery and institutes reforms.

title: Ireland
event: The legislative union of Great Britain and Ireland is completed under the Act of Union 1800, bringing about the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.

title: France
event: February 16 – The Treaty of Lunéville ends the war (Second Coalition) between France and Austria.

title: France
event: March 21 – Second Battle of Abukir: a British army under Ralph Abercromby defeats the French troops.

title: United Kingdom
event: April 2 – First Battle of Copenhagen: The British fleet under Admiral Sir Hyde Parker, along with Admiral Horatio Nelson, attack Copenhagen; the Armed Neutrality of the North is dissolved.

title: Tripoli
event: May 10 – The pascha of Tripoli declares war on the United States by having the flagpole on the consulate chopped down.

title: Portugal
event: June 7 – Portugal and Spain sign the Treaty of Badajoz; Portugal loses the city of Olivenza.

title: United Kingdom
event: June 27 – Cairo falls to British troops.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 6 – Battle of Algeciras: The French fleet defeats the British fleet.

title: Batavian Republic
event: October 17 – A coup d'état is staged in the Netherlands (Batavian Republic).

title: United Kingdom
event: 5 July to 28 August – A general election in the United Kingdom brings victory for the Tories, led by Henry Addington.

title: United States Military Academy
event: March 16 – United States Military Academy of West Point is established.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 25–March 27 – Napoleonic Wars: The Treaty of Amiens between France and the United Kingdom ends the War of the Second Coalition.

title: France
event: April 26 – A general amnesty signed by Napoleon Bonaparte allows all but about 1,000 of the most notorious émigrés of the French Revolution to return to France, as part of a reconciliary gesture to make peace with the various factions of the ''Ancien Regime'' that ultimately consolidates his own rule.

title: France
event: May 19 – Napoleon Bonaparte establishes the French ''légion d'honneur'' (Legion of Honour).

title: Australia
event: June 2 – Indigenous Australian Pemulwuy, a leader of the resistance to European settlement of Australia, is shot dead by Henry Hacking.

title: Fort de Joux
event: June 8 – Haitian revolutionary Toussaint L'Ouverture is seized by French troops and sent to Fort de Joux for prison.

title: United States Military Academy
event: July 4 – At West Point, New York the United States Military Academy opens.

title: Westminster Bridge
event: September 3 – William Wordsworth publishes the poem ''Westminster Bridge''.

title: French First Republic
event: September 11 – The Italian region of Piedmont becomes a part of the French First Republic.

title: Switzerland
event: October – The French army enters Switzerland.

title: Tripoli
event: October 2 – War ends between Sweden and Tripoli. The United States also negotiates peace, but war continues over the size of compensation.

title: France
event: France: the Livre Tournois (Tours Pound) is replaced by the Franc.

title: Greece
event: Thomas Bruce, 7th Earl of Elgin begins removal of the Elgin Marbles from the Parthenon in Athens where they are at risk of destruction during the Ottoman occupation of Greece.

title: India
event: Orissa, India is occupied by the British under the British East India Company after the Second Anglo-Maratha War.

title: New Orleans
event: January 30 – Monroe and Livingston sail for Paris to discuss, and possibly buy, New Orleans; they end up completing the Louisiana Purchase.

title: Bank of England
event: February 21 – Edward Despard and 6 others are hanged and beheaded for plotting to assassinate King George III and to destroy the Bank of England.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: February 24 – ''Marbury v. Madison'': The Supreme Court of the United States establishes the principle of judicial review.

title: Ohio
event: March 1 – Ohio is admitted as the 17th U.S. state, retroactive from August 7, 1953.

title: France
event: April 30 – Louisiana Purchase is made by the United States from France.

title: France
event: May 18 – The United Kingdom resumes war on France after France refuses to withdraw from Dutch territory.

title: Cairo
event: May 19 – Master Malati, a Coptic Christian leader, is beheaded by a Muslim mob in Cairo, Egypt.

title: France
event: July 5 – The convention of Artlenburg leads to the French occupation of Hanover (which had been ruled by the British king).

title: Ireland
event: July 23 – Robert Emmet's uprising in Ireland begins.

title: Gwalior
event: August 3 – The British begin the Second Anglo-Maratha War against Sindhia of Gwalior.

title: India
event: September 23 – Battle of Assaye (India): British-led troops defeat Maratha forces.

title: France
event: November 30 – At the Cabildo building in New Orleans, Spanish representatives Governor Manuel de Salcedo and the Marqués de Casa Calvo, officially transfer the Louisiana Territory to French representative Prefect Pierre Clément de Laussat (just 20 days later, France transfers the same land to the United States as the Louisiana Purchase).

title: Australia
event: Matthew Flinders recommends that New Holland be renamed ''Australia'' (from the Latin australis meaning of the south).

title: France
event: January 1 – Haiti gains independence from France and becomes the first black republic, having the only successful slave revolt ever.

title: New Jersey
event: February 15 – New Jersey becomes the last northern state to abolish slavery.

title: Ohio University
event: February 18 – Ohio University is chartered by the Ohio General Assembly.

title: South Wales
event: February 21 – The Cornishman Richard Trevithick's newly-built Penydarren steam locomotive operates on the Merthyr Tramroad between Penydarren in Merthyr Tydfil and Abercynon in South Wales, following several trials since February 13, the world's first locomotive to work on rails.Railway and Canal Historical Societylocation=Oxfordisbn=0-901461-52-0}}<

title: France
event: March 10 – Louisiana Purchase: In St. Louis, a formal ceremony is conducted to transfer ownership of Louisiana Territory from France to the United States.

title: France
event: March 21 – The ''Code Napoleon'' is adopted as French civil law.

title: Portugal
event: April 2 – Forty merchantmen are wrecked when a convoy led by the HMS ''Apollo'' runs aground off Portugal.

title: New Hampshire
event: June 15 – The Twelfth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is ratified by New Hampshire, and arguably becomes effective (subsequently vetoed by the Governor of New Hampshire).

title: Tennessee
event: July 27 – The Twelfth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution ratified by Tennessee, removing doubt surrounding adoption.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: November 30 – The Democratic-Republican-controlled United States Senate begin an impeachment trial against Federalist-partisan Supreme Court of the United States Justice Samuel Chase (he was charged with political bias but was acquitted by the United States Senate of all charges on March 1, 1805).

title: Notre Dame de Paris
event: December 2 – At Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself as the first Emperor of the French in a thousand years (the Napoleonic Code is adopted).

title: United Kingdom
event: December 12 – Spain declares war on Britain.

title: Australia
event: James Squire becomes the first person in  Australia to cultivate Hops.

title: London
event: The Horse Patrol, a mounted law enforcement force, is founded in London, England.

title: France
event: Sweden declares war on France.

title: Michigan Territory
event: January 11 – Michigan Territory is created.

title: Tripoli
event: April 27 – United States Marines and Berbers attack the Tripolitan city of Derna (The Shores of Tripoli).

title: Batavian Republic
event: April 29 – Rutger Jan Schimmelpenninck is appointed as Grand Pensionary of the Batavian Republic by Napoleon.

title: Italy
event: June 1 – Luigi Boccherini is buried in Italy after being found dead on May 28.

title: Horse Guards Parade
event: June 4 – The first Trooping the Colour ceremony is held at the Horse Guards Parade in London.

title: Battle of Ulm
event: October 17 – Napoleonic Wars – Battle of Ulm: Austrian General Mack von Leiberich is forced to surrender his entire army to Napoleon after being surrounded.

title: France
event: October 21 – Napoleonic Wars – Battle of Trafalgar: British naval  fleet led by Admiral Horatio Nelson defeats a combined French and Spanish fleet off the coast of Spain; however, Admiral Nelson is fatally shot.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: November 7 – The Lewis and Clark Expedition arrives at the Pacific Ocean.

title: France
event: November 11 – Napoleonic Wars – Battle of Dürenstein: 8,000 French troops attempt to slow the retreat of a vastly superior Russian and Austrian force.

title: Battle of Schöngrabern
event: November 16 – Napoleonic Wars – Battle of Schöngrabern: – Russian forces under Pyotr Bagration delay the pursuit by French troops under Murat.

title: Pontcysyllte Aqueduct
event: November 26 – The Pontcysyllte Aqueduct is opened.

title: France
event: December 2 – Napoleonic Wars – Battle of Austerlitz: French troops  under Napoleon decisively defeat a joint Russo-Austrian force.

title: Parthenon
event: Thomas Bruce, 7th Earl of Elgin, removes the Elgin Marbles from the Parthenon in Athens.

title: Cape of Good Hope
event: January 19 – The British occupy the Cape of Good Hope.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: March 23 – After traveling through the Louisiana Purchase and reaching the Pacific Ocean, explorers Lewis and Clark and their ''Corps of Discovery'' begin their journey home.

title: National Road
event: March 29 – Construction is authorized of the ''National Road'' (the first United States federal highway).

title: France
event: July 4 – Battle of Maida: Britain defeats France in Calabria.

title: St. Louis Missouri
event: July 15 – Pike expedition: Near St. Louis, Missouri, United States Army Lieutenant Zebulon Pike leads an expedition from Fort Belle Fountaine to explore the west.

title: France
event: September – Prussia declares war on France, and is joined by Saxony and other minor German states.

title: St. Louis Missouri
event: September 23 – The Lewis and Clark Expedition reaches St. Louis, Missouri, ending a successful exploration of the Louisiana Territory and the Pacific Northwest.

title: France
event: October 24 – French forces enter Berlin.

title: Pikes Peak
event: November 15 – Pike expedition: During his second exploratory expedition, Lieutenant Zebulon Pike sees a distant mountain peak while near the Colorado foothills of the Rocky Mountains (later named Pikes Peak in his honor).

title: France
event: November 24 – The last major Prussian field force, under Gebhard Leberecht von Blücher, surrenders to the French near Lübeck. Frederick William III has by this time fled to Russia.

title: Warsaw
event: November 28 – French troops enter Warsaw.

title: Battle of Golymin
event: December 26 – 1806 Battles of Pultusk and Golymin. Battle of Pultusk: Russian forces under General Bennigsen narrowly escape from a direct confrontation with Napoleon, who goes into winter quarters. Battle of Golymin: Russian forces under General Golitsyn fight a successful rearguard action against French forces under Marshall Murat.

title: France
event: Battle of Abrantês: The French under Jean-Andoche Junot take the town.

title: Philippines
event: The municipality of Mogpog in Marinduque, Philippines is founded.

title: Alabama
event: February 19 – In Alabama, Former Vice President of the United States Aaron Burr is tried for conspiracy and acquitted.

title: France
event: April 27 – French forces capture Danzig after a 6-week siege.

title: Portugal
event: June 6 – An earthquake strikes Lisbon, Portugal.

title: Battle of Friedland
event: June 14 – Battle of Friedland: Napoleon decisively defeats Bennigsen's Russian army.

title: Río de la Plata
event: July 5 – A disastrous British attack is mounted against Buenos Aires during the second failed invasion of the Río de la Plata.

title: Kingdom of Westphalia
event: July 7–July 9 – The Peace of Tilsit is signed between France, Prussia and Russia. Napoleon and Russian Emperor Alexander I ally together against the British. The Prussians are forced to cede more than half their territory, which is formed into the Duchy of Warsaw in their former Polish lands and the Kingdom of Westphalia in western Germany.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 13 – With the death of Henry Benedict Stuart, the last Stuart claimant to the throne of the United Kingdom, the movement of Jacobitism comes to an effective end.

title: Albany New York
event: August 17 – The ''Clermont'', Robert Fulton's first American steamboat, leaves New York City for Albany, New York on the Hudson River, inaugurating the first commercial steamboat service in the world.

title: Louisiana
event: September 1 – Former U.S. Vice President Aaron Burr is acquitted of treason. He had been accused of plotting to annex parts of Louisiana and Mexico to become part of an independent republic.

title: Denmark
event: September 2 – September 7 – Battle of Copenhagen: The Royal Navy bombards Copenhagen with fire bombs and phosphorus rockets to prevent Denmark from surrendering its fleet to Napoleon; 30% of the city is destroyed and 2,000 citizens are killed.

title: Guangzhou
event: September 4 – Robert Morrison, the first Protestant missionary to China, arrives in Guangzhou.

title: Portugal
event: November 29 – The Portuguese Queen Maria I and the Court embark at Lisbon bound for Brazil. Rio de Janeiro becomes the Portuguese capital.

title: New South Wales
event: 26 January – Rum Rebellion: On the 20th anniversary of the foundation of the colony of New South Wales, disgruntled military officers of the New South Wales Corps (the ''Rum Corps'') overthrow and imprison Governor William Bligh and seize control of the colony.

title: Mauritius
event: The British siege of Mauritius begins.

title: Academy of Fine Arts Munich
event: The Academy of Fine Arts, Munich is founded.

title: Brazil
event: January 22 – The Bragança Portuguese Royal Family arrives in Brazil, running away from the French army.

title: Finland
event: February – Russia issues an ultimatum to Sweden, to join France, Denmark and Russia and attack Finland.

title: Papal States
event: February 2 – French troops occupy the Papal States (Vatican).

title: HMS Bounty
event: February 6 – The ship ''Topaz'' (from Boston April 5, 1807 hunting seals) rediscovers the Pitcairn Islands; only one HMS ''Bounty'' mutineer is still alive, Alexander Smith (John Adams).

title: Pennsylvania
event: February 11 – Anthracite coal is first burned as fuel by Jesse Fell in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania; the discovery leads to the use of coal as the key fuel source of America's industrial revolution.

title: Finland
event: February 21 – Finnish War: Russian troops cross the border into Finland without a declaration of war.

title: Brazil
event: March 8 – Brazil: With the arrival of the Portuguese royal family in Brazil (1808), the colony became the seat of Portuguese Empire.

title: Finland
event: April 16 – Troops under colonel Carl von Döbeln clash with Russian troops in Pyhäjoki, Finland.

title: Madrid
event: May 2 – Peninsular War: The people of Madrid rise up against the French troops.

title: Lapua
event: July 14 – Troops under Colonel Adlercreutz force the Russians to withdraw in Lapua.

title: Battle of Bailén
event: July 22 – French General Dupont surrenders to Spanish irregular forces following the Battle of Bailén.

title: Finland
