event: July 24 – Reconstruction: Tennessee becomes the first U.S. state to be readmitted to the Union following the American Civil War.

title: Austro-Prussian War
event: August 23 – The Treaty of Prague ends the Austro-Prussian War.

title: Italy
event: October 12 – The Treaty of Vienna ends the war between Austria and Italy; it formalizes the annexation of Venetia by Italy.

title: Varna
event: November 7 – The Ruse-Varna railway line (the first railway in Bulgaria) officially opens.

title: College of Wooster
event: December 18 – The College of Wooster was founded.

title: New Orleans
event: Yellow fever kills 3,093 in New Orleans.

title: South Africa
event: South African diamond fields are discovered.

title: Ireland
event: The Fenian rising occurs in Ireland.

title: Fiji
event: The Reverend Thomas Baker, a Wesleyan Methodist missionary (born in Playden, East Sussex, England) is cooked and eaten by Navatusila tribespeople at Nabutautau on Fiji, together with eight of his local followers, the last missionary in that country to suffer cannibalism.

title: London Wasps
event: The Wasps R.F.C. is formed in Middlesex, England (''see'' London Wasps ''and'' Wasps FC).

title: Michigan
event: At historic Fountain Point, Michigan, an artesian water spring gushes continuously till the present day.

title: Covington Kentucky
event: January 1 – The John A. Roebling Suspension Bridge opens between Cincinnati, Ohio and Covington, Kentucky, becoming the longest suspension bridge in the world.

title: Morgantown West Virginia
event: February 7 – West Virginia University is established in Morgantown, West Virginia.

title: Suez Canal
event: February 17 – The first ship passes through the Suez Canal.

title: Hubei
event: February 19 – Battle of inlon river in Hubei China

title: Nebraska
event: March 1 – Nebraska is admitted as the 37th U.S. state.

title: Ottawa
event: March 29 –  The British North America Act receives royal assent, forming the Dominion of Canada in an event known as the Confederation. This unites the Province of Canada (Quebec and Ontario), New Brunswick, and Nova Scotia as of July 1. Ottawa becomes the capital, and John A. Macdonald becomes the Dominion's first prime minister.

title: Alaska
event: March 30 – Alaska is purchased for $7.2 million from Alexander II of Russia, about 2 cent/acre ($4.19/km²), by United States Secretary of State William H. Seward. The news media call this Seward's Folly.

title: London
event: April 1 – The Strait Settlement of Singapore, formerly ruled from Calcutta, becomes a Crown Colony under the jurisdiction of the Colonial Office in London.

title: London
event: May 11 – First public performance of Cox and Box by Francis Burnand and Arthur Sullivan at the Adelphi Theatre, London

title: Montana
event: June 15 – The Atlantic Cable Quartz Lode mine is named in Montana.

title: Massachusetts
event: July 17 – In Boston, Massachusetts, the Harvard School of Dental Medicine is established as the first dental school in the United States.

title: Sheffield
event: September 4 – The Sheffield Wednesday F.C. is founded at the Adelphi Hotel in Sheffield.

title: Midway Atoll
event: September 30 – The United States takes control of Midway Island.

title: Oklahoma
event: October 21 – ''Manifest Destiny'' – Medicine Lodge Treaty: Near Medicine Lodge Creek, Kansas, a landmark treaty is signed by southern Great Plains Indian leaders. The treaty requires Native American Plains tribes to relocate to a reservation in western Oklahoma.

title: Minnesota
event: November 15 – Former Minnesota farmer Oliver Hudson Kelley founds the Order of the Patrons of Husbandry (better known today as The Grange).

title: Manchester
event: November 23 – The so-called Manchester Martyrs are hanged in Manchester, England for the murder of a policeman whilst attempting to rescue two Irish men from jail.

title: New York City
event: December 2 – In a New York City theater, British author Charles Dickens gives his first public reading in the United States.

title: North Island
event: June – Titokowaru's War breaks out in the South Taranaki District of New Zealand's North Island between the Ngāti Ruanui Māori tribe and the New Zealand Government.

title: Australia
event: Brisbane Grammar School is founded, providing the opportunity for secondary education for the first time in the colony of Brisbane in Australia.

title: Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Santa Fe
event: The Roman Catholic See of Tucson is established as the Apostolic Vicariate of Arizona in 1868, taking its territory from the former Diocese of Santa Fe. The Diocese of Tucson is canonically erected on May 8, 1897.

title: Asunción
event: January 5 – War of the Triple Alliance: Brazilian Army commander Luís Alves de Lima e Silva enters Asunción, Paraguay's capital. Some days later he declares the war is over. Nevertheless, Francisco Solano López, Paraguay's president, prepares guerrillas to fight in the countryside.

title: War Office
event: February 13 – The British War Office sanctions the formation of what becomes the Army Post Office Corps.

title: New York City
event: February 16 – In New York City the Jolly Corks organization is renamed the ''Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks'' (BPOE).

title: France
event: March – French geologist Louis Lartet discovers the first identified skeletons of Cro-Magnon, the first early modern humans (early ''Homo sapiens sapiens''), at Abri de Crô-Magnon, a rock shelter at Les Eyzies, Dordogne, France.

title: University of Virginia
event: March 1 – The Pi Kappa Alpha Fraternity is founded at the University of Virginia.

title: California
event: March 23 – The University of California is founded in Oakland, California when the Organic Act is signed into California law.

title: Hampton Virginia
event: April 1 – The Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute is established in Hampton, Virginia.

title: Amba Mariam
event: April 9 – Emperor Tewodros II of Ethiopia massacres at least 197, perhaps more, of his own people at Magdala. These were prisoners who had been, for the most part, incarcerated for very trivial offenses, and were killed for asking for bread and water.

title: United Kingdom
event: May 26 – Fenian bomber Michael Barrett becomes the last person publicly hanged in Britain.

title: Parc de Saint-Cloud
event: May 31 – The first popular bicycle race is held at Parc de Saint-Cloud, Paris.

title: Manchester
event: June 2 – The first Trades Union Congress is held in Manchester, England.

title: London
event: July 5 – Preacher William Booth establishes the Christian Mission, predecessor of the Salvation Army, in the East End of London.

title: Wyoming
event: July 25 – Wyoming becomes a United States territory.

title: United Kingdom
event: August 20 – Abergele Train Disaster in  Wales: An ''Irish Mail'' passenger train collides with 4 cargo trucks loaded with paraffin: 33 are killed (the first major train disaster in Britain).

title: United Kingdom
event: August 22 – The Yangzhou riot in China targets a station of the China Inland Mission, and nearly leads to war between Britain and China.

title: Sewanee Tennessee
event: September 18 – The University of the South holds its first convocation in Sewanee, Tennessee.

title: 66th Street (Manhattan)
event: October 6 – The City of New York grants Mount Sinai Hospital a 99-year lease for a property on Lexington Avenue and 66th Street, for the sum of $1.00.

title: New Zealand
event: November 2 – New Zealand officially adopts nationally observed standard time, and is perhaps the first country to do so.

title: Battle of Washita River
event: November 27 – Indian Wars – Battle of Washita River: In the early morning, United States Army Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer leads an attack on a band of Cheyenne living on reservation land with Chief Black Kettle, killing 103 Cheyenne.

title: Australia
event: The British Parliament ends transportation to Australia as punishment for criminals.

title: David Livingstone
event: James Gordon Bennett, Jr. of the New York Herald asks Henry Morton Stanley to find Dr. Livingstone.

title: Manchester
event: The co-operative Central Board (later Co-operatives UK) is founded in Manchester.

title: France
event: The opposition, consisting of republicans, monarchists and liberals, polls almost 45% of the vote in France.

title: Philadelphia
event: Marcus Jastrow arrives in the United States to become rabbi of Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia.

title: Farmington Senior High School (Minnesota)
event: Farmington Senior High School (Minnesota) is built

title: Madagascar
event: February 20 – Ranavalona II, the Merina Queen of Madagascar, is baptized.

title: North German Confederation
event: March 1 – North German Confederation issues 10gr and 30gr value stamps, printed on goldbeater's skin.

title: North Island
event: March 24 – Titokowaru's War ends with surrender of last Māori troops at large in the South Taranaki District of New Zealand's North Island .

title: West Lafayette Indiana
event: May 6 – Purdue University is founded in West Lafayette, Indiana.

title: New York
event: May 15 – Woman's suffrage: In New York, Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton form the National Woman's Suffrage Association.

title: London
event: may 22 – Sainsbury's first store in Drury Lane, London, opened.

title: Massachusetts
event: May 26 – Boston University is chartered by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

title: India
event: June 2 – Sherwood College is founded in Nainital, India.

title: University of Bucharest
event: July 4 – The University of Bucharest is founded.

title: Wallace Monument
event: September 11 – Work on the Wallace Monument is completed in Stirling, Scotland.

title: Princeton University
event: November 6 – The first game of American Football between two American colleges is played.  Rutgers University defeats Princeton University 6–4 in a forerunner to American football and College football.

title: Red Sea
event: November 17 – In Egypt, the Suez Canal, linking the Mediterranean Sea with the Red Sea, is inaugurated in an elaborate ceremony.

title: Cutty Sark
event: November 23 – In Dumbarton, Scotland, the last surviving clipper ship, ''Cutty Sark'', is launched.

title: Gallatin Missouri
event: December 7 – American outlaw Jesse James commits his first confirmed bank robbery in Gallatin, Missouri.

title: University of Virginia
event: December 10 – The first American chapter of Kappa Sigma is founded at the University of Virginia.

title: Wyoming
event: December 10 – The Wyoming territorial legislature gives women the right to vote, the first such law in the world.

title: Asunción
event: December 31 – Triple Alliance forces take Asunción.

title: India
event: Infanticide is banned in India.

title: India
event: Just one of the 916 members of the Indian Civil Service is Indian.

title: Brooklyn Bridge
event: Plans for the Brooklyn Bridge are completed.

title: Brooklyn Bridge
event: January 3 – Construction of the Brooklyn Bridge begins.

title: John D. Rockefeller
event: January 10 – John D. Rockefeller incorporates Standard Oil.

title: Virginia
event: January 26 – Reconstruction: Virginia rejoins the Union.

title: DePauw University
event: January 27 – The first college sorority, Kappa Alpha Theta, is established at DePauw University.

title: Australia
event: February 1 – Goodna State School in Goodna, Queensland, Australia is founded.

title: Anaheim California
event: Anaheim, California is incorporated.

title: Utah
event: February 12 – Women gain the right to vote in Utah Territory.

title: Mississippi
event: February 23 – Military control of Mississippi ends and it is readmitted to the Union.

title: Mississippi
event: February 25 – Hiram Rhodes Revels, a Republican from Mississippi, is sworn into the United States Senate, becoming the first African American ever to sit in the U.S. Congress.

title: Manitoba
event: March 4 – Thomas Scott is executed by Louis Riel's provisional government during the Red River Rebellion in modern day Manitoba Canada.

title: Syracuse University
event: March 24 – Syracuse University is established and officially opens.

title: Texas
event: Texas is readmitted to the Union following Reconstruction.

title: Manitoba
event: May 12 – The Canadian province of Manitoba is created in response to Louis Riel's Red River Rebellion.

title: Nelson College
event: May 14 – The first rugby match is played in New Zealand, between the Nelson Football Club and Nelson College.

title: South Australia
event: May 24 – The Port Adelaide Football Club plays their first match of Australian rules football at Buck's Flat, Glanville, South Australia.

title: France
event: July 13 – The ''Ems Dispatch'' serves as a reason for a war between Prussia and France.

title: Georgia (U.S. state)
event: July 15 – Reconstruction: Georgia becomes the last former Confederate state to be readmitted to the Union, and the C.S.A. is dissolved.

title: France
event: July 19 – Franco-Prussian War: France declares war on Prussia.

title: France
event: September 2 – Franco-Prussian War – Battle of Sedan: Prussian forces defeat the French armies and take emperor Napoleon III and 100,000 of his soldiers prisoner at Sedan.

title: Papal States
event: September 20 – With ''Bersaglieri'' soldiers entering Rome at Porta Pia, the unification of Italy is completed, ending the last remnant of the Papal States.

title: Italy
event: October 2 – A plebiscite held in Rome supports, by 133,681 votes to 1,507, the annexation of the city by Italy.

title: Italy
event: October 6 – Rome becomes the capital of unified Italy.

title: Alsace
event: The provinces of Alsace and Lorraine are transferred from France to Germany.

title: Troy
event: Heinrich Schliemann begins the excavation of Troy.

title: New York
event: William M. Tweed serves his last year as the Boss of the Tammany Hall political machine in New York.

title: John D. Rockefeller
event: The South Improvement Company is formed by John D. Rockefeller and a group of major railroad interests in an early effort to organize and control the petroleum industry in the U.S.A.

title: Korea
event: The Ameican minister to China takes five warships to attempt to open up Korea, but his forces leave after exchanges of fire result in 250 Koreans dying and the Korean government still unwilling to make any concessions.

title: Maine
event: Virginia adopts a new Constitution, taking into account of, among other things, all of the counties that had left Virginia in 1863 to form the new non-slave state of West Virginia and became a new state of the United States, with all of the rights and privileges thereof. This exiting of one state to form a new one has never been done otherwise without the permission / consent of the Legislature of the one involved, as was done in the cases of Vermont, Kentucky, and Maine.

title: Dijon
event: January 21 – Giuseppe Garibaldi's group of French and Italian volunteer troops in support of the French Third Republic win a battle against the Prussians in Dijon.

title: North Carolina
event: March 22 – In North Carolina, William Holden becomes the first governor of a U.S. state to be removed from office by impeachment.

title: Nebraska
event: March 22 – The U.S. Army issued an order for the abandonment of Fort Kearny, Nebraska.

title: Royal Albert Hall
event: March 29 – The Royal Albert Hall is opened by Queen Victoria.

title: France
event: May 10 –  France surrenders, ending the Franco-Prussian War.

title: London
event: May 11 – The first trial of the case of Tichborne Claimant begins in the London Court of Common Pleas.

title: Rigi-Bahnen
event: May 21 – Opening of the first rack railway in Europe, the Rigi-Bahnen on Mount Rigi.

title: Korea
event: June 10 – Captain McLane Tilton leads 109 U.S. Marines in a naval attack on the Han River forts in Korea - the United States expedition to Korea

title: Durham University
event: June 18 – The University Tests Act removes religious tests at Oxford, Cambridge and Durham universities.

title: British Columbia
event: British Columbia joins the confederation of Canada.

title: Hayden Geological Survey of 1871
event: July 21 – August 26 – First ever photographs of Yellowstone National Park region taken by the photographer William Henry Jackson during Hayden Geological Survey of 1871

title: Yellowstone Lake
event: July 28 – The ''Annie'', the first boat ever launched on Yellowstone Lake in Yellowstone National Park region.

title: Alaska
event: September – Whaling Disaster of 1871: 1,219 people abandon 33 whaling ships caught in the ice pack off the northern coast of Alaska.

title: Great Chicago Fire
event: October 8 – Four major fires break out on the shores of Lake Michigan in Chicago, Illinois, Peshtigo, Wisconsin, Holland, Michigan, and Manistee, Michigan. The Great Chicago Fire is the most famous of these, leaving nearly 100,000 people homeless, although the Peshtigo Fire kills as many as 2,500 people, making it the deadliest fire in United States history.

title: Wickenburg massacre
event: November 5 – Wickenburg massacre: six men travelling by stagecoach are reportedly murdered by the Yavapai Indians.

title: Lake Tanganyika
event: November 10 – Henry Morton Stanley locates the missing explorer and missionary Dr. David Livingstone in Ujiji, near Lake Tanganyika, and greets him by saying Dr. Livingstone, I presume?

title: New York
event: November 17 – The National Rifle Association is granted a charter by the state of New York.

title: Birmingham Alabama
event: December 19 – The city of Birmingham, Alabama, is incorporated with the merger of three pre-existing towns.

title: Glasgow Green
event: May – Rangers F.C. play their first ever game on the public pitches of Glasgow Green.

title: Brazil
event: In the aftermath of the War of the Triple Alliance, the new government of Paraguay makes peace with Brazil, grants reparations and territorial concessions.

title: Wyoming
event: U.S. government geologist Clarence King reveals the diamond hoax in Wyoming.

title: New Orleans
event: February 13 – Rex, the most famous parade on Mardi Gras, parades for the first time in New Orleans for Grand Duke Alexei Mikhailovich of Russia.

title: Philippines
event: February 17 – Execution of the Filipino priests: Jose Burgos, Mariano Gomez, and Jacinto Zamora in Bagumbayan Fields, Manila, Philippines.

title: New York City
event: February 20 – In New York City, the Metropolitan Museum of Art closes for urban renovation.

title: Great Britain
event: March 11 – Work begins erecting the Seven Sisters Colliery, South Wales, located on one of the richest coal sources in Britain.

title: Lone Pine California
event: March 26 – An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 7.2 strikes Lone Pine, California.

title: France
event: Georges Bizet's comic opera Djamileh premieres at the Opera-Comique in Paris, France.

title: Society of Jesus
event: July 4 – The Society of Jesus is pronounced illegal in the German Empire.

title: British Honduras
event: September 1 – A group of Icaiche Maya under Marcos Canul attack Orange Walk Town in British Honduras; the British send troops against them.

title: New York City
event: September 26 – The first Shriners Temple (called Mecca) is established in New York City.

title: Mary Celeste
event: November 7 – The ''Mary Celeste'' sets sail from New York; bound for Genoa, Italy.

title: Massachusetts
event: November 9 – Great Boston Fire of 1872: In Boston, Massachusetts, a large fire begins to burn on Lincoln Street (the 2-day event destroys about 65 acres (0.3 km²) of the city, 776 buildings, much of the financial district and causes US$60 million in damage).

title: Hamilton Crescent
event: November 30 – First international football match to be recognised (retrospectively) by FIFA as official takes place at Hamilton Crescent, Scotland; the result is Scotland 0, England 0. Earlier international soccer matches had already taken place in 1870, in 1871 and again in 1872 at the Oval, London.

title: United Kingdom
event: December 4 – The now-crewless American ship ''Mary Celeste'' is found (still seaworthy) by the British brig ''Dei Gratia''.

title: Springwell Pit Disaster
event: December 6 – The Springwell Pit Disaster (a coal-mining incident) in Dawley, UK claims eight lives.

title: Portsmouth
event: December 21 – ''HMS Challenger'' sails from Portsmouth on the 4-year scientific expedition that lays the foundation for the science of oceanography.

title: Llanelidan
event: December –  Major Walter Clopton Wingfield designed and patented a similar game — which he called sphairistike (Greek: σφάίρίστική, from ancient Greek meaning skill at playing at ball), and was soon known simply as sticky — for the amusement of his guests at a garden party on his estate of Nantclwyd, in Llanelidan, Wales.

title: North America
event: Royal Montreal Club in Montreal, Quebec, the first permanent golf club in North America

title: St Mary's School (Calne)
event: St Mary's School, Calne

title: Clydebank High School
event: Clydebank High School, Clydebank, Scotland

title: United Kingdom
event: The United Kingdom declares war against Ghana's King Kofi KariKari, who is involved in the trading of slaves. The war ends by July and the British establish the Gold Coast Colony.

title: Fray Bentos
event: Liebig's Extract of Meat Company begin producing tinned corned beef, sold under the label Fray Bentos from the town in Uruguay where it is processed.

title: Veracruz Veracruz
event: In Mexico, the Veracruz to Mexico City railroad is completed.

title: Zanzibar
event: Britain puts pressure on Sultan Barghash Sayyid, who closes slave markets in Zanzibar.

title: New York
event: Centennial Park is officially completed in New York City, New York.

title: Long Island
event: Nine Pekin ducks are imported to Long Island (the first in the United States).

title: Nova Scotia
event: April 1 – The British steamer RMS ''Atlantic'' sinks off Nova Scotia, killing 547.

title: Illinois
event: May – Henry Rose exhibits barbed wire at an Illinois county fair, which is taken up by Joseph Glidden and Jacob Haish, who invent a machine to mass-produce it.

title: Manchester New Hampshire
event: Levi Strauss and Jacob Davis received United States patent#139121 for using copper rivets to strengthen the pockets of denim work pants. Levi Strauss & Co. began manufacturing the famous Levi's brand of jeans, using fabric from the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company in Manchester, New Hampshire.

title: Royal Canadian Mounted Police
event: The Canadian Parliament establishes the North-West Mounted Police (which is renamed the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in 1920).

title: Tripoli Lebanon
event: C. Laan brings order to the chaos created by the dockworker riots of Tripoli, Lebanon.

title: Khiva
event: The city of Khiva falls to Imperial Russian forces, under the command of General Konstantin Petrovich Von Kaufman.

title: London
event: June 9 – Alexandra Palace in London is destroyed by fire only a fortnight after its opening.

title: Prince Edward Island
event: July 1 – Prince Edward Island joins the Canadian Confederation.

title: Adair Iowa
event: July 21 – At Adair, Iowa, Jesse James and the James-Younger Gang pull off the first successful train robbery in the American Old West (US$3,000 from the Rock Island Express).

title: Montana
event: August 4 – Indian Wars: While protecting a railroad survey party in Montana, the Seventh Cavalry, under Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer, clashes for the first time with the Sioux, near the Tongue River (only 1 man on each side is killed).

title: France
event: September 16 – German troops leave France upon completion of payment of indemnity for the Franco-Prussian War.

title: Drury University
event: September 25 – Classes begin at Drury University.

title: Óbuda
event: November 17 – From Pest, Buda and Óbuda, Budapest, Hungary's capital, is formed.

title: New York
event: December 15 – Women of Fredonia, New York march against the retail liquor dealers in town to inaugurate the Woman's Crusade of 1873–74. This leads to the creation of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union.

title: San Diego Natural History Museum
event: The San Diego Natural History Museum is founded.

title: Ireland
event: The Home Rule Movement is created to protest British Government control over Ireland (see History of Ireland).

title: India
event: The Agra canal opens in India.

title: Charles Taze Russell
event: Charles Russell and the Bible Student movement claim this year to mark the invisible return of Jesus Christ to earth.

title: Black Hills
event: Gold is discovered in the Black Hills.

title: Mycenae
event: Heinrich Schliemann begins excavation at Mycenae.

title: United Kingdom
event: January – The Pangkor Treaty (also known as the Pangkor Engagement), by which the British extended their control over, first the Sultanate of Perak and later the other independent Malay States, is signed.

title: The Bronx
event: January 1 – New York City annexes The Bronx.

title: 92nd Street Y
event: March – The Young Men's Hebrew Association in Manhattan (which still operates today  as the 92nd Street Y) is founded.

title: Hawaii
event: March 18 – Hawaii signs a treaty with the United States granting exclusive trading rights.

title: Otepää
event: June 4 – The flag of Estonia is consecrated as the flag of the Estonian Students Society in Otepää.

title: Estella-Lizarra
event: June 25–June 27 – Third Carlist War of Spain: Battle of Monte Muro: Carlist forces entrenched around Abárzuza, on the approach to Estella in Navarre, repel an attack by Isabelino/Liberal(supporters of Queen Isabella II) troops led by General Manuel Gutiérrez de la Concha, Marqués del Duero, who is killed on the third day of fighting.

title: Philadelphia Zoo
event: July 1 – Philadelphia Zoo opens, the first public zoo in the U.S.

title: University of Zagreb
event: October 19 – The modern University of Zagreb is founded in Zagreb.

title: Syracuse University
event: November 11 – The Gamma Phi Beta sorority is founded at Syracuse University. This is the first women's Greek letter organization to be called a sorority.

title: Bombay Stock Exchange
event: Asia's first stock exchange was established. The Native Share & Stock Brokers Association now called as the Bombay Stock Exchange.

title: Cowgate
event: The Hibernian F.C. is founded in the Cowgate area of Edinburgh, Scotland.

title: Birmingham
event: The Birmingham City F.C. is founded, as Small Heath Alliance, in Small Heath, Birmingham, England.

title: China
event: January 12 – Kwang-su becomes emperor of China.

title: SS Gothenburg
event: February 24 – The ''SS Gothenburg'' sinks off the Australian east coast with the loss of approximately 102 lives, including a number of high profile civil servants and dignitaries.

title: San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation
event: February 25 – The majority of the Yavapai (Wipukyipai) and Tonto Apache (Dil Zhéé) tribes are forced by the U.S. Cavalry under command of Brigadier General George Crook to walk at gunpoint from the Arizona's Verde Valley, to the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation, 180 miles to the southeast. The two tribes are not allowed to return to the Verde Valley until 1900.

title: Romualdo Pacheco
event: February 27 – Newton Booth, 11th Governor of California, resigns, having been elected Senator. Lieutenant Governor of California Romualdo Pacheco becomes acting Governor. He is later replaced by elected governor William Irwin.

title: Montreal
event: March 3 – The first organized indoor game of ice hockey is played between two teams at the Victoria Skating Rink in Montreal, Canada.

title: Princeton University
event: April 25 – Ten sophomores from Rutgers College (now Rutgers University) steal a one-ton cannon from the campus of the College of New Jersey (now Princeton University) and start the Rutgers-Princeton Cannon War.

title: Isles of Scilly
event: May 7 – The S.S. ''Schiller'' wrecks on the rocks off the Isles of Scilly.

title: Harvard University
event: June 4 – Two American colleges play each other in arguably the first game of College Football : Tufts University and Harvard University at Jarvis Field in Cambridge, Mass..

title: English Channel
event: August 25 – Captain Matthew Webb becomes the first person to swim the English Channel.

title: Ireland
event: September 1 – A murder conviction effectively forces the violent Irish anti-owner coal miners, the Molly Maguires, to disband.

title: Cheyenne River
event: October 15 – Chief Lone Horn of the Minneconjou dies at the Cheyenne River, leaving his son Big Foot as the new chief.

title: Provo Utah
event: October 16 – Brigham Young University is founded in Provo, Utah.

title: Massachusetts
event: October 25 – The first performance of the Piano Concerto No. 1 by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky is given in Boston, Massachusetts with Hans von Bülow as soloist.

title: Montana
event: November 9 – Indian Wars: In Washington, D.C., Indian Inspector E.C. Watkins issues a report stating that hundreds of Sioux and Cheyenne associated with Sitting Bull and Crazy Horse are hostile to the United States (the Battle of the Little Bighorn is fought in Montana the next year).

title: New York City
event: December 4 – Notorious New York City politician Boss Tweed escapes from prison and flees to Cuba, then to Spain.

title: International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement
event: December 20 – ICRM renamed International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC).

title: Little Bighorn River
event: Spring – Vast numbers of Indians move north to an encampment of the Sioux chief Sitting Bull in the region of the Little Bighorn River, creating the last great gathering of native peoples on the Great Plains.

title: India
event: 1876–1878 – Famine and cholera in India: six million die.

title: Missouri
event: Adolphus Busch's brewery, Anheuser-Busch in St. Louis, Missouri, first markets Budweiser, a pale lager, as a nationally sold beer.

title: Bedford
event: Charles Wells opens his brewery based in Bedford, England.

title: Tiburon California
event: Lyford House, by Richardson Bay, Tiburon, California is constructed.

title: Spandau Prison
event: Construction of Spandau Prison is completed.

title: Korea
event: Japan brings a fleet to Incheon, the port of Seoul. The Japanese force the Korean government to sign an unequal treaty, open 3 ports to Japanese trade and cease considering itself a tributary of China. On China's urging Korea also signs treaties with the European powers in effort to counterbalance Japan.

title: Illinois
event: February 2 – The National League of Professional Base Ball Clubs is formed at a meeting in Chicago, Illinois; it replaced the National Association of Professional Base Ball Players. Morgan Bulkeley of the Hartford Dark Blues is selected as the league's first President.

title: Batak massacre
event: May – Batak massacre refers to the massacre of Bulgarians in Batak by Ottoman troops in 1876 at the beginning of the April Uprising. The number of victims ranges from 3,000 to 5,000, depending on the source.

title: Pennsylvania
event: May 10 – The Centennial Exposition begins in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

title: British Library
event: May 17 – Nikolaus Otto files his patent for the four-stroke cycle internal combustion engine.British Libraryyear=2001isbn=0-7123-0881-4pages=104–5}}<

title: Dodge City Kansas
event: May 18 – Wyatt Earp starts work in Dodge City, Kansas, serving under Marshal Larry Deger.

title: New York City
event: June 4 – The Transcontinental Express arrives in San Francisco, California via the First Transcontinental Railroad, 83 hours and 39 minutes after having left New York City.

title: Battle of the Little Bighorn
event: June 25 – Indian Wars – Battle of the Little Bighorn: 300 men of the U.S. 7th Cavalry Regiment under Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer are wiped out by 5,000 Lakota, Cheyenne and Arapaho led by Sitting Bull and Crazy Horse.

title: Colorado
event: August 1 – Colorado is admitted as the 38th U.S. state.

title: Bayreuth Festival
event: August 13 – Richard Wagner inaugurates Bayreuth Festival

title: Texas A&M University
event: October 4 – Texas A&M University opens for classes.

title: India
event: October 31 – A catastrophic cyclone strikes the east coast of India, killing 200,000.

title: Newfoundland and Labrador
event: November 2 – A giant squid, 6.1 meters long, washes ashore at Thimble Tickle Bay in Newfoundland.

title: Karlsruhe
event: November 4 – The long-awaited First Symphony of Johannes Brahms is premiered at Karlsruhe under the baton of Otto Dessoff.

title: Lincoln Tomb
event: November 7 – U.S. presidential election, 1876: After long and heated disputes, Rutherford Birchard Hayes is eventually declared the winner over Samuel Jones Tilden. A failed grave robbery of the Lincoln Tomb took place on the same night.

title: Pennsylvania
event: November 10 – The Centennial Exposition ends in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

title: New York City
event: November 23 – Corrupt Tammany Hall leader William Marcy Tweed (better known as Boss Tweed) is delivered to authorities in New York City after being captured in Spain.

title: Powder River (Montana)
event: November 25 – Indian Wars: In retaliation for the dramatic American defeat at the Battle of the Little Bighorn, United States Army troops under General Ranald S. Mackenzie sack Chief Dull Knife's sleeping Cheyenne village at the headwaters of the Powder River (the soldiers destroy all of the villagers' winter food and clothing, and then slash their ponies' throats).

title: Brooklyn Theater Fire
event: December 5 – The Brooklyn Theater Fire kills at least 278, possibly more than 300.

title: Ashtabula River Railroad Disaster
event: December 29 – The Ashtabula River Railroad bridge disaster occurs, leaving 92 dead.

title: Tian Shan
event: Winter 1877–1878 – After the defeat of the Dungan revolt in China, several thousand refugees cross the Tian Shan to settle in the Russian Empire, thus starting the future Soviet Dungan ethnic group.

title: India
event: Famine and cholera in India: six million die (1876–1878).

title: Montana
event: January 8 – Indian Wars – Battle of Wolf Mountain: Crazy Horse and his warriors fight their last battle with the United States Cavalry in Montana.

title: University of Oxford
event: March 24 – For the only time in history, the Boat Race between the Universities of Cambridge and Oxford is declared a dead heat (i.e. a draw).

title: New York City
event: May 8 – At Gilmore's Gardens in New York City, the first Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show opens and had a massive impact on the Civil rights movement. (ends May 11).

title: United States Military Academy
event: June 15 – Henry Ossian Flipper becomes the first African American cadet to graduate from the United States Military Academy.

title: Nez Perce
event: June 17 – Indian Wars – Battle of White Bird Canyon: The Nez Perce defeat the U.S. Cavalry at White Bird Canyon in the Idaho Territory.

title: Jim Thorpe Pennsylvania
event: June 21 – The Molly Maguires are hanged at Carbon County Prison in Jim Thorpe, Pennsylvania.

title: The Championships Wimbledon
event: July 9 – The All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club begins its first lawn tennis tournament at Wimbledon.

title: Siege of Plevna
event: July 19 – Russo-Turkish War, 1877–1878: The first battle in the Siege of Plevna is fought.

title: Siege of Plevna
event: July 30 – The second battle in the Siege of Plevna is fought.

title: Montana
event: August 9 – Indian Wars – Battle of Big Hole: Near Big Hole River in Montana, a small band of Nez Percé Indians who refused government orders to move to a reservation, clash with the United States Army. The army loses 29 soldiers and Indians lose 89 warriors in a U.S. Army victory.

title: Phobos (moon)
event: August 18 – Asaph Hall discovers Phobos, the inner moon of Mars.

title: Siege of Plevna
event: September 1 – The Battle of Lovcha, third battle in the Siege of Plevna, is fought.

title: Nebraska
event: September 5 – Indian Wars: Oglala Sioux chief Crazy Horse is bayoneted by a United States soldier, after resisting confinement in a guardhouse at Fort Robinson in Nebraska.

title: Blantyre mining disaster
event: October 22 – The Blantyre mining disaster in Scotland kills 207 miners.

title: Manhattan College
event: November 22 – The first college lacrosse game is played between New York University and Manhattan College.

title: Siege of Plevna
event: December 9 – The fourth battle of the Russo-Turkish War, 1877–1878 is fought, concluding the Siege of Plevna.

title: China
event: 1876–1879 – Great North China Famine: ten million die.

title: India
event: 1876–1878 – Famine and cholera in India: six million die.

title: Gran Chaco
event: U.S. arbitration rejects Argentine claims to Paraguay's part of the Chaco region.

title: Isle of Man
event: The Buchan School, Isle of Man

title: Nainital Cantonment
event: Nainital Cantonment

title: Cleopatra's Needle
event: January – ''Cleopatra's Needle'' arrives in London.

title: Dardanelles
event: January 23 – Benjamin Disraeli orders the British fleet to the Dardanelles.

title: Istanbul
event: February 8 – The British fleet enters Turkish waters and anchors off Istanbul; Russia threatens to occupy Istanbul but does not carry out the threat.

title: Lincoln County New Mexico
event: February 18 – The Lincoln County War begins in Lincoln County, New Mexico.

title: Hyde Park London
event: February 24 – Anti-Russian demonstrations occur in Hyde Park, London.

title: Mississippi State University
event: February 28 – Mississippi State University is created by the Mississippi Legislature (under the name The Agricultural and Mechanical College of the State of Mississippi).

title: Malta
event: March 27 – In anticipation of war with Russia, Disraeli mobilizes the reserves and calls up Indian troops to Malta.

title: Tokyo Stock Exchange
event: May 15 – The Tokyo Stock Exchange is established

title: Universal Postal Union
event: June 1 – Universal Postal Union (UPU)

title: California
event: July 26 – In California, the poet and American West outlaw calling himself Black Bart makes his last clean getaway when he steals a safe box from a Wells Fargo stagecoach. The empty box is found later with a taunting poem inside.

title: Connecticut
event: August 9 – The Wallingford Tornado of 1878, the deadliest tornado in Connecticut history, destroys the town of Wallingford, killing 34 people and injuring 70 or more.

title: Madeira
event: September 30 – The ship ''Priscilla'' arrives in Hawaii from Funchal, Madeira, marking the beginning of the Portuguese immigration to the Hawaiian Islands (1878–1913).

title: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
event: October 1 – Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (Virginia Tech) opens as Virginia Agricultural and Mechanical College.

title: Sheffield
event: October 14 – The world's first recorded floodlit football fixture is played at Bramall Lane in Sheffield.

title: Khyber Pass
event: November 21 – The Second Afghan War commences when the British attack Ali Masjid in the Khyber Pass.

title: California
event: January – The current constitution of The State of California, USA is ratified.

title: China
event: 1876–1879 – Great North China Famine: ten million die.

title: France
event: Ferdinand Cheval begins to build his ''Palais Idéal'' in France.

title: Equatorial Guinea
event: Tetteh Quarshie first brings cocoa to Ghana from Equatorial Guinea.

title: United Kingdom
event: January 22 – Anglo-Zulu War – Battle of Isandlwana: Zulu troops massacre British troops.  At Rorke's Drift, outnumbered British soldiers drive the attackers away after hours of fighting.

title: North America
event: February 12 – At New York City's Madison Square Garden, the first artificial ice rink in North America opens.

title: Bolivia
event: February 14 – At Antofagasta, Chile, Chilean troops disembark in this port, then Bolivian. This is the beginning of the War of the Pacific between Chile and the joint forces of Peru and Bolivia.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: February 15 – Women's rights: American President Rutherford B. Hayes signs a bill allowing female attorneys to argue cases before the Supreme Court of the United States.

title: Utica New York
event: February 22 – In Utica, New York, Frank Woolworth opens the first of many of 5 and 10-cent Woolworth stores.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 12 – Anglo-Zulu War – Battle of Intombe: A British force over one-hundred strong is ambushed and destroyed by Zulu forces.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 28 – Anglo-Zulu War – Battle of Hlobane: British forces suffer a defeat.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 29 – Anglo-Zulu War – Battle of Kambula: British forces defeat 20,000 Zulus.

title: Fiji
event: May 14 – The first group of 463 Indian indentured labourers arrive in Fiji abroad the ''Leonidas''.

title: United Kingdom
event: May 26 –  Russia and the United Kingdom sign the Treaty of Gandamak, establishing an Afghan state.

title: Madison Square Garden (1879)
event: May 30 –  New York City's Gilmore's Garden is renamed Madison Square Garden by William Henry Vanderbilt, and is opened to the public at 26th Street and Madison Avenue.

title: Battle of Ulundi
event: July 4 – Anglo-Zulu War: The Anglo-Zulu War effectively ends at the Battle of Ulundi.

title: New Mexico
event: July 19 – Doc Holliday kills for the first time after a man shoots up Holliday's New Mexico saloon.

title: The Octagon Dunedin
event: September 8 – The Octagon fire claims 12 victims in Dunedin, New Zealand.

title: South Dakota
event: September 25 – Deadwood, South Dakota  fire: Two-thousand people left homeless. Three hundred buildings destroyed. Total loss of property is estimated at $3 million.

title: Colorado
event: September 29 – Meeker Massacre: Nathan Meeker and others are killed in an uprising at the White River Ute Indian Reservation in Colorado.

title: Tay Rail Bridge
event: December 28 – The Tay Bridge disaster – the central part of the Tay Rail Bridge in Dundee, Scotland collapses as a train passes over it, killing 75.

title: Devon
event: December 30 – ''The Pirates of Penzance'' is first performed in Paignton, Devon, England.

title: Cologne Cathedral
event: Cologne Cathedral is completed, after construction began in 1248, 632 years earlier.

title: Capuchin catacombs of Palermo
event: The Capuchin catacombs of Palermo are officially closed (there will be some burials afterwards).

title: Congo River
event: Pierre Savorgnan de Brazza signs a treaty of protection with the chief on the large Teke tribe and begins to establish a French protectorate on the north bank of the Congo River.

title: Wabash Indiana
event: February 2 – The first electric streetlight is installed in Wabash, Indiana.

title: Wabash Indiana
event: March 31 – Wabash, Indiana becomes the first electrically lit city in the world.

title: Tahiti
event: June 29 – France annexes Tahiti.

title: North America
event: October – The Blizzard of 1880 begins in North America.

title: University of Southern California
event: October 6 – The University of Southern California opens its doors to 53 students and 10 faculty.

title: Victorio
event: October 15 – Mexican soldiers kill Victorio, one of the greatest Apache military strategists.

title: Clarkson Memorial
event: October 28 – The first stone is laid for the Clarkson Memorial in Wisbech.

title: Melbourne
event: November 11 – Australian bushranger and bank robber Ned Kelly is hung in Melbourne.

title: New York City
event: November 22 – Vaudeville actress Lillian Russell makes her debut at Tony Pastor's Theatre in New York City.

title: South African Republic
event: December 30 – The Transvaal becomes a republic and Paul Kruger becomes its first president.

title: Kinshasa
event: Kinshasa is founded by Henry Morton Stanley as a trading outpost called Léopoldville.

title: Convent of the Sacred Heart (New York)
event: New York City's oldest independent school for girls, the Convent of the Sacred Heart New York (91st Street), is founded.

title: Ireland
event: University College Dublin is established in Ireland.

title: Vatican City
event: Some Vatican archives are opened to scholars for the first time.

title: Abilene Texas
event: Abilene, Texas is founded.

title: Minto North Dakota
event: Minto, North Dakota is founded.

title: Argentina
event: Rafaela, Argentina is formed.

title: United Kingdom
event: Culford School, a public school in Suffolk, United Kingdom, is founded.

title: Geok Tepe
event: January 16–January 24 – Siege of Geok Tepe: Russian troops under General Mikhail Skobelev defeat the Turkomans.

title: Ireland
event: January 24 – William Edward Forster, the chief secretary for Ireland, introduces his Coercion Bill, which temporarily suspended habeas corpus so that those people suspected of committing an offence could be detained without trial; it goes through a long debate before it is accepted February 2.

title: Phoenix Arizona
event: February 5 – Phoenix, Arizona is incorporated.

title: Kansas
event: February 19 – Kansas becomes the first U.S. state to prohibit all alcoholic beverages.

title: El Paso Texas
event: April 14 – The Four Dead in Five Seconds Gunfight erupts in El Paso, Texas.

title: Temuco
event: April 15 – Temuco, Chile is founded.

title: University of Connecticut
event: April 21 – The University of Connecticut is founded as the Storrs Agricultural School.

title: Australia
event: April 25 – Caulfield Grammar School is founded in Melbourne, Australia.

title: New Mexico
event: April 28 – Billy the Kid escapes from his 2 jailers at the Lincoln County Jail in Mesilla, New Mexico, killing James Bell and Robert Ollinger before stealing a horse and riding out of town.

title: France
event: May 12 – In North Africa, Tunisia becomes a French protectorate.

title: Great Britain
event: May 13 – The Pacific island of Rotuma cedes to Great Britain, becoming a dependency of the Colony of Fiji.

title: Arctic Ocean
event: June 12 – The USS ''Jeannette'' is crushed in an Arctic Ocean ice pack.

title: Alabama
event: July 4 – In Alabama, the Tuskegee Institute opens.

title: Fort Sumner
event: July 14 – Billy the Kid is shot and killed by Pat Garrett outside Fort Sumner.

title: Montana
event: July 20 – Indian Wars: Sioux chief Sitting Bull leads the last of his fugitive people in surrender to United States troops at Fort Buford in Montana.

title: Buenos Aires
event: July 23 – The Boundary treaty of 1881 between Chile and Argentina is signed in Buenos Aires.

title: United Kingdom
event: August 3 – The Pretoria Convention peace treaty is signed, officially ending the war between the Boers and Britain.

title: Michigan
event: September 5 – The Thumb Fire in the U.S. state of Michigan destroys over a million acres (4,000 km²) and kills 282 people.

title: Austin High School (Austin Texas)
event: September 12 – Francis Howell High School (Howell Institute) in St. Charles, Missouri, and Stephen F. Austin High School in Austin, Texas open on the same day, putting them in a tie for the title of the oldest public high school west of the Mississippi River.

title: Cochise County Arizona
event: October 26 – The Gunfight at the O.K. Corral occurs in Tombstone, Cochise County, Arizona, USA.

title: Clarkson Memorial
event: November 11 – The Clarkson Memorial in Wisbech is completed and unveiled to the public.

title: Odessa
event: November 19 – A meteorite strikes earth near the village of Großliebenthal, a few kilometers southwest of Odessa, Ukraine.

title: Vienna
event: December 8 – At least 620 die in a fire at the Ring Theatre, Vienna.

title: United Kingdom
event: The Married Women's Property Act 1882 in Britain enables women to buy, own and sell property and to keep their own earnings.

title: South Africa
event: Zulu king Cetshwayo returns to South Africa.

title: United Kingdom
event: The British Chartered Institute of Patent Agents is founded (now called Chartered Institute of Patent Attorneys).

title: Cornwall
event: Redruth Mining School opens in Cornwall.

title: Waterloo R.F.C.
event: Waterloo Rugby Club

title: Coatbridge
event: Albion Rovers F.C. (though the amalgamation of two Coatbridge clubs, Albion and Rovers)

title: Thames Ditton Lawn Tennis Club
event: Thames Ditton Lawn Tennis Club

title: Sierra Leone
event: March 20 – British gunboats enter Monrovia, with Arthur Havelock demanding that Liberia cede disputed territory to the British colony of Sierra Leone.

title: France
event: March 28 – Republican Jules Ferry makes primary education in France free, non-clerical (laique) and obligatory.

title: Phoenix Park
event: May 6 – The Invincibles (militant Irish republicans) kill Lord Frederick Cavendish, chief secretary for Ireland and permanent undersecretary T.H. Burke in Phoenix Park, Dublin;

title: Italy
event: May 20 – The Triple Alliance is formed between Germany, Austria-Hungary and Italy.

title: Arabian Sea
event: A cyclone in the Arabian Sea causes flooding in Bombay harbor, leaving about 100,000 dead.

title: Gojjam
event: Battle of Embabo: The Shewan forces of Menelik defeat the Gojjame army.

title: Sierra Leone
event: June 28 – Anglo-French Convention of 1882 signed marking territorial boundaries between Guinea and Sierra Leone.

title: Suez Canal
event: July 11 – British troops occupy Alexandria and the Suez Canal.

title: New York City
event: September 5 – The first United States Labor Day parade is held in New York City.

title: Cairo
event: September 13 – 1882 Anglo-Egyptian War: British troops occupy Cairo, and Egypt becomes a British protectorate.

title: Tombstone Arizona
event: November 14 – Franklin Leslie shoots Billy Claiborne dead in the streets of Tombstone, Arizona.

title: Yale University
event: The Wolf's Head Society (known as ''The Third Society'' until 1888) is founded at Yale University.

title: Sagrada Família
event: Antoni Gaudí begins to build the Sagrada Família Cathedral.

title: Duncan Arizona
event: Duncan, Arizona is founded.

title: Australia
event: The suburb of Ingleburn, in Sydney, Australia is established.

title: Ontario
event: During construction of the Canadian Pacific Railway in 1883, blasting and excavation reveal high concentrations of nickel–copper ore at Murray Mine on the edge of the Sudbury Basin located near Sudbury, Ontario, Canada.

title: Houghton College
event: Houghton College

title: Milwaukee
event: January 10 – A fire at the Newhall Hotel in Milwaukee kills 73 people.

title: Roselle New Jersey
event: January 19 –  The first electric lighting system employing overhead wires begins service in Roselle, New Jersey (it was built by Thomas Edison).

title: Italy
event: February 13 – The German composer Richard Wagner dies of a heart attack in Venice, Italy.

title: Alabama
event: February 23 – Alabama becomes the first U.S. state to enact an antitrust law.

title: Massachusetts
event: February 28 – The first vaudeville theater is opened, in Boston, Massachusetts.

title: Hong Kong Observatory
event: March 2 – The Hong Kong Observatory is formed.

title: Gloucester City A.F.C.
event: March 5 – The Gloucester City A.F.C. is formed.

title: Brooklyn Bridge
event: May 24 – Brooklyn Bridge is opened to traffic after 13 years of construction.

title: Brooklyn Bridge
event: May 30 – In New York City, a rumor that the Brooklyn Bridge is going to collapse causes a stampede which crushes 12 people.

title: Italy
event: June 28 – In Milan in Italy inaugurated the first central European electricity power station.

title: Pecos Texas
event: July 4 – The world's first rodeo is held in Pecos, Texas.

title: Isle of Man
event: August – King William's College is opened on the Isle of Man.

title: 1883 eruption of Krakatoa
event: August 26–28 – Krakatoa or Krakatau volcano erupts at 10:02 AM (local time); 163 villages are destroyed, 36,380 killed.

title: University of Texas at Austin
event: The University of Texas at Austin opens to students.

title: Great Lakes
event: September 29 – A consortium of flour mill operators in Minneapolis, Minnesota forms the Minneapolis, Sault Ste. Marie and Atlantic Railway as a means to get their product to the Great Lakes ports but avoid the high tariffs of Chicago.

title: Australia
event: October 1 – Sydney Boys High School (the first boys' public school) is founded in Sydney, Australia.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: October 15 – The Supreme Court of the United States declares part of the Civil Rights Act of 1875 to be unconstitutional, since the Court allows private individuals and corporations to discriminate based on race.

title: Tarapacá Region
event: October 20 – Peru and Chile sign the Treaty of Ancón, by which the Tarapacá province is ceded to the latter, bringing an end to Peru's involvement in the War of the Pacific.

title: Cardiff University
event: October 24 – Cardiff University, Wales, opens (under the name of University College of South Wales and Monmouthshire).

title: Walla Walla Washington
event: November 28 – Whitman College is chartered as a 4-year college in Walla Walla, Washington.

title: Castle Mountain
event: The first ascent is made of Castle Mountain by geologist Arthur Philemon Coleman.

title: Wuhan
event: The Yellow Crane Tower last burns in Wuhan.

title: France
event: 1884–1885 – France conquers Vietnam.

title: China
event: Reformers in Korea who admire the Meiji Restoration in Japan stage a coup with Japan's help. China intervens to rescue the king and help suppress the rebels. Afterward both China and Japan agree to withdraw their troops and military advisers.

title: London
event: January 4 – The Fabian Society is founded in London.

title: Sudan
event: March 13 – The siege of Khartoum, Sudan begins (ends on January 26, 1885).

title: United Kingdom
event: April 22 – The Colchester earthquake, England, the UK's most destructive, occurs.

title: Cameroon
event: July 5 – Germany takes possession of Cameroon.

title: New York Harbor
event: August 5 – The cornerstone for the Statue of Liberty is laid on Bedloe's Island in New York Harbor.

title: Maine
event: August 10 – A severe earthquake, magnitude 5.5, (intensity VII) occurs off the northeast Atlantic coast. The area affected extends from central Virginia to southern Maine, and west as far as Cleveland.

title: Staten Island Academy
event: September 5 – Staten Island Academy is founded.

title: Newport Rhode Island
event: October 6 – The United States Naval War College is established in Newport, Rhode Island.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 18 – The University of Wales, Bangor (UK) is founded.

title: Ireland
event: November 1 – The Irish Gaelic Athletic Association is founded in Thurles, Ireland.

title: Puget Sound
event: The Committee of Fifteen tries to expel all remaining Chinese from the Puget Sound area.

title: Illinois
event: The first skyscraper (the Home Insurance Building) is built in Chicago, Illinois, USA (10 floors).

title: Camp Dudley YMCA
event: Camp Dudley, the oldest continually running boys' camp in America, is founded.

title: Michigan Technological University
event: Michigan Technological University (originally Michigan Mining School) opens its doors for the first time in what is now the Houghton County Fire Hall.

title: Liverpool
event: January 24 – Edge Hill College opens in Liverpool

title: Khartoum
event: January 26 – Troops loyal to the Mahdi Muhammad Ahmad conquer Khartoum.

title: Congo Free State
event: February 5 – King Léopold II of Belgium establishes the Congo Free State as a personal possession.

title: Hawaii
event: February 9 – The first Japanese arrive in Hawaii.

title: New York
event: March 3 – A subsidiary of the American Bell Telephone Company, American Telephone and Telegraph (AT&T), is incorporated in New York.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 26 – ''The Times'' reports that A lady well-known in literary and scientific circles has been cremated by the Cremation Society in Woking, Surrey. Jeannette C. Pickersgill is the first person to be officially cremated in the United Kingdom.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 31 – The United Kingdom establishes a protectorate over Bechuanaland.{{Citation neededdate=April 2009}}

title: Frog Lake Alberta
event: April 2 – The battle of Frog Lake, Alberta between the Cree and mounties.

title: Niagara Falls
event: April 30 – A bill is signed in the New York State legislature forming the Niagara Falls State Park.

title: Congo Free State
event: The Congo Free State is established by King Léopold II of Belgium.

title: New York City
event: June 17 – The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York Harbor.

title: Niagara Falls
event: July 15 – The Reservation at Niagara Falls opens, enabling access to all for free. Thomas V. Welch is the first Superintendent of the Park.

title: Regina Saskatchewan
event: July 28 – Louis Riel's trial for treason begins in Regina.

title: China
event: September 2 – The Rock Springs Massacre occurs in Rock Springs, Wyoming; 150 white miners attack their Chinese coworkers, killing 28, wounding 15, and forcing several hundred more out of town.

title: Minnesota
event: September 8 – Saint Thomas Academy is founded in Minnesota.

title: Plovdiv
event: September 18 – The union of Eastern Rumelia with Bulgaria is proclaimed at Plovdiv.

title: Georgia (U.S. state)
event: October 13 – The Georgia Institute of Technology is established in Atlanta, Georgia as the Georgia School of Technology.

title: Craigellachie British Columbia
event: November 7 – Canadian Pacific Railway: In Craigellachie, British Columbia, construction ends on a railway extending across Canada. Prime Minister Sir John A. Macdonald considers the project to be vital to Canada due to the exponentially greater potential for military mobility.

title: India
event: December 28 – 72 Indian lawyers, academics and journalists gather in Bombay to form the Congress Party.

title: United Kingdom
event: Heinz Baked Beans are first launched at the Fortnum & Mason department store in London, United Kingdom, although they are manufactured in Canada.

title: Great Britain
event: Horse-drawn streetcars of Austria-Hungary, France, Germany and Great Britain are carrying c. 900 million riders per year.

title: Burma
event: January 1 – Burma is presented to Queen Victoria as a birthday gift, after the country is annexed into British India in November 1885.

title: Los Angeles
event: February 14 – The first train load of oranges leaves Los Angeles via the transcontinental railroad.

title: Kiel Canal
event: March 16 – A law establishing the Kiel Canal is adopted.

title: Mississippi
event: March 17 – Carrollton Massacre: 20 African Americans are killed in Mississippi.

title: Parliament of the United Kingdom
event: April 4 – William Ewart Gladstone introduces the First Irish Home Rule Bill in the British Parliament; it is defeated on June 8.

title: France
event: May 15 – Portugal and France agree to regulate the borders of their colonies in Guinea.

title: White House
event: June 2 – U.S. President Grover Cleveland marries Frances Folsom in the White House, becoming the only president to wed in the executive mansion. She is 27 years his junior.

title: Pink and White Terraces
event: June 10 – The Mount Tarawera volcano erupts in New Zealand, resulting in the deaths of over 150 people and the destruction of the famous Pink and White Terraces.

title: British Columbia
event: June 13 – A fire devastates much of Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: United Kingdom
event: June 30 – The Royal Holloway, University of London is opened by Queen Victoria in Surrey, United Kingdom.

title: Brooklyn Bridge
event: July 23 – Steve Brodie fakes a jump from the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Indianola Texas
event: August 20 – A massive hurricane demolishes the town of Indianola, Texas.

title: South Carolina
event: August 31 – An earthquake of between 7.3 and 7.6 on the Richter Scale hits Charlestown, South Carolina, leaving 40,000 homeless.

title: Arizona
event: September 4 – Indian Wars: After almost 30 years of fighting, Apache leader Geronimo surrenders with his last band of warriors to General Nelson Miles at Skeleton Canyon in Arizona.

title: New York Harbor
event: October 28 – In New York Harbor, U.S. President Grover Cleveland dedicates the Statue of Liberty.

title: Columbia University
event: Teachers College, later part of Columbia University, is founded.

title: Iwo Jima
event: Japan annexes Iwo Jima.

title: Zulu Kingdom
event: Zululand becomes a British colony.

title: Spandau Prison
event: Construction of Spandau Prison in Berlin is completed.

title: Australia
event: Brisbane receives a daily rainfall of 465 millimetres – a record for any Australian capital city.

title: Italy
event: January 24 – Battle of Dogali: Abyssinian troops defeat the Italians.

title: Montana
event: January 28 – In a snowstorm at Fort Keogh, Montana, USA, the largest snowflakes on record are reported. They are 15 inches (38 cm) wide and 8 inches (20 cm) thick.

title: France
event: January 28 – Construction of the foundations of the Eiffel Tower starts in Paris, France.

title: Punxsutawney Pennsylvania
event: February 2 – In Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania, the first Groundhog Day is observed.

title: La Scala
event: February 5 – The Giuseppe Verdi opera ''Otello'' premieres at La Scala.

title: Mediterranean Sea
event: February 23 – The French Riviera is hit by a large earthquake, killing around 2,000 along the coast of the Mediterranean Sea.

title: Sydney Cricket Ground
event: February 26 – At the Sydney Cricket Ground, George Lohmann becomes the first bowler to take eight wickets in a Test innings.

title: North Carolina State University
event: March 7 – North Carolina State University is established as North Carolina College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts.

title: Argonia Kansas
event: April 4 – Argonia, Kansas elects Susanna M. Salter as the first female mayor in the United States.

title: The Catholic University of America
event: April 10 – The Catholic University of America is founded on Easter Sunday.

title: 1887 Sonora earthquake
event: May 3 – An earthquake hits Sonora, Mexico.

title: London
event: May 9 –  ''Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show'' opens in London.

title: California
event: May 14 – The cornerstone of the new Stanford University, in northern California, is laid (the college opens in 1891).

title: Brisbane
event: June 29 – The United Retail Federation is established in Brisbane.

title: France
event: July 1 – Construction of the metal structure of the Eiffel Tower starts in Paris, France

title: National Institutes of Health
event: August – The U.S. National Institutes of Health is founded at the Marine Hospital, Staten Island, NY, as the Laboratory of Hygiene.

title: Theatre Royal Exeter
event: September 5 – The Theatre Royal, Exeter, England burns down, killing 186 people.

title: Florida A&M University
event: October 3 – Florida A&M University opens its doors in Tallahassee, Florida.

title: Portugal
event: November 3 – The Associação Académica de Coimbra, the students' union of the University of Coimbra in Portugal, is founded.

title: Glenfiddich
event: December 25 – ''Glenfiddich'' single malt Scotch whisky is first produced.

title: Borneo
event: Sarawak and Borneo become British protectorates.

title: Greece
event: A national library in Athens, Greece is established.

title: China
event: The first railway in China goes into operation.

title: New Zealand
event: The dolphin Pelorus Jack is first sighted in Cook Strait, New Zealand.

title: United Kingdom
event: The Camborne School of Mines is founded in Cornwall, United Kingdom.

title: India
event: Rudyard Kipling's short story collection ''Plain Tales from the Hills'' is published in Calcutta, India.

title: Pennsylvania
event: The Baldwin School is founded in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania.

title: Texas
event: Texas finishes its 3 million dollar state capital building in Austin.

title: Manhattan
event: Katz's Delicatessen is founded in the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: Lick Observatory
event: January 3 – The 91-centimeter telescope is first used at Lick Observatory.

title: Texas
event: January 12 – Blizzards (see: ''Schoolhouse Blizzard'') hit Dakota Territory, the states of Montana, Minnesota, Nebraska, Kansas, and Texas, leaving 235 dead, many of whom are children on their way home from school.

title: National Geographic Society
event: January 13 – In Washington, DC, the National Geographic Society is founded.

title: West Orange New Jersey
event: February 27 – In West Orange, New Jersey, Thomas Edison meets with Eadweard Muybridge, who proposes a scheme for sound film.

title: Logan Utah
event: March 8 – The Agriculture College of Utah, (later Utah State University) is founded in Logan, Utah.

title: Coney Island
event: April 3 – The  Brighton Beach Hotel in Coney Island is moved 520 feet using six steam locomotives by Civil Engineer B.C. Miller to save it from ocean storms.

title: Bangkok
event: April 6 – first New Year's Day of the solar calendar adopted by Siamese King Chulalongkorn with the 106th anniversary of Bangkok's founding in 1782 as its epoch (reference date).

title: Concertgebouw
event: April 11 – The Concertgebouw in Amsterdam is inaugurated.

title: Fort Belknap Indian Reservation
event: May 1 – The United States Congress establishes the Fort Belknap Indian Reservation.

title: Brazil
event: May 13 – Brazil abolishes the last remnants of slavery.

title: The Crystal Palace
event: June 29 – Handel's ''Israel in Egypt'' is recorded onto wax cylinder at The Crystal Palace, it being the earliest known recording of classical music.

title: London
event: In London, the dead body of Annie Chapman is found. She is considered to be the second victim of Jack the Ripper.

title: London
event: September 30 – In London, the bodies of Elizabeth Stride and Catherine Eddowes are found. They are generally considered Jack the Ripper's third and fourth victims, respectively.

title: Sofia University
event: October 1 – Sofia University officially opens, becoming the first university in liberated Bulgaria.

title: Leeds Bridge
event: Louis Le Prince films the first motion picture: ''Roundhay Garden Scene'' in Roundhay, Leeds, West Yorkshire, UK (followed by his movie ''Leeds Bridge'').

title: Shewa
event: Seeking to extend to extend Mahdist control over what is now southwestern Ethiopia, governor Khalil al-Khuzani is routed at the Battle of Guté Dili by an alliance of Shewan forces under ''Ras'' Gobana Dacche and Moroda Bekere, ruler of Leqa Naqamte. Only a handful, including Khalil, barely manage to flee the battle field.

title: London
event: November 9 – In London, England, the dead body of Mary Jane Kelly is found. She is considered to be the fifth, and last, of Jack the Ripper's victims. A number of similar murders in England follow, but the police attribute them to copy-cat killers.

title: Colorado
event: December 18 – Richard Wetherill and his brother-in-law discover the Indian ruins of Mesa Verde in southwestern Colorado.

title: Italy
event: An early method of high-voltage direct current (HVDC) transmission as developed by the Swiss engineer Rene Thury  is implemented commercially in Italy by the ''Acquedotto de Ferrari-Galliera'' company. This system transmitsd 630 kW at 14 kV DC over a distance of 120 km.]<

title: West Virginia
event: The first West Virginia tornado is recorded.

title: Diet of Japan
event: The Diet of Japan is founded.

title: Panama Canal
event: Yellow fever interrupts the building of the Panama Canal.

title: Nile
event: A huge locust swarm crosses the Red Sea and destroys crops in the Nile Valley.

title: Capilano Suspension Bridge
event: The Capilano Suspension Bridge (the longest suspension foot-bridge in the world) is opened.  Capilano Bridge.

title: Wichita Kansas
event: Riverside Elementary School (Wichita, Kansas)

title: Nevada
event: January 1 – A total eclipse of the sun is seen over parts of California and Nevada.

title: Georgia (U.S. state)
event: January 15 – The ''Coca-Cola Company'', then known as the Pemberton Medicine Company, is originally incorporated in Atlanta, Georgia.

title: Mayerling
event: January 30 – Crown Prince Rudolf of Austria and his mistress Baroness Mary Vetsera commit a double suicide (or a murder suicide) in the Mayerling hunting lodge.

title: Washington (U.S. state)
event: February 22 – President Grover Cleveland signs a bill admitting North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana and Washington as U.S. states.

title: Sudan
event: March 9 – Yohannes IV is killed in the Battle of Metemma; Sudanese forces, who had been almost defeated, rally and destroy the Ethiopian army.

title: North Carolina
event: March 11 – The North Carolina Legislature issues a charter for the creation of Elon College.

title: Sheffield
event: March 22 – Sheffield United formed on 22 March 1889 at the Adelphi Hotel, Sheffield

title: Eiffel Tower
event: March 31 – The Eiffel Tower is inaugurated (opens May 6). Contemporary critics regard it as aesthetically displeasing.

title: Guthrie Oklahoma
event: April 22 – At high noon in Oklahoma Territory, thousands rush to claim land in the Land Run of 1889. Within hours the cities of Oklahoma City and Guthrie are formed, with populations of at least 10,000.

title: Italy
event: May 2 – Menelik II, Emperor of Ethiopia, signs a treaty of amity with Italy, giving Italy control over what will become Eritrea.

title: Eiffel Tower
event: May 6 – The Eiffel Tower opens in Paris.

title: Johnstown Pennsylvania
event: May 31 – Johnstown Flood: The South Fork Dam collapses in western Pennsylvania, killing more than 2,200 people in and around Johnstown, Pennsylvania.

title: Ireland
event: June 12 – The Armagh rail disaster near Armagh in Ireland kills 78.

title: Argentina
event: August – The Jewish Settlement of Moisés Ville is founded in Argentina.

title: Royal Mail Mount Pleasant Sorting Office
event: August 30 – Official opening of Royal Mail Mount Pleasant Sorting Office in London.

title: New York Military Academy
event: September 17 – Civil War veteran Charles Charles Jefferson Wright founds New York Military Academy with 75 students on {{convert30acrem2}} of land in Cornwall, NY.

title: Nintendo
event: September 23 – The ''Nintendo'' Koppai (Later ''Nintendo'' Company, Limited) is founded by Fusajiro Yamauchi to produce and market Hanafuda playing cards.

title: Moulin Rouge
event: October 6 – The ''Moulin Rouge'' cabaret opens in Paris.

title: New South Wales
event: October 24 – Sir Henry Parkes, Premier of New South Wales, delivers the Tenterfield Oration calling for the Federation of Australia.

title: South Dakota
event: November 2 – North Dakota and South Dakota are admitted as the 39th and 40th U.S. states.

title: Montana
event: November 8 – Montana is admitted as the 41st U.S. state.

title: Washington (U.S. state)
event: November 11 – Washington is admitted as the 42nd U.S. state.

title: Brazil
event: November 20 – Argentina is the first country to recognize the abolition of the monarchy in Brazil.

title: Clemson South Carolina
event: November 27 – Clemson University is founded in Clemson, South Carolina.

title: Diet of Japan
event: July – Politics of Japan: In the first general election for the House of Representatives of Japan, c. 5% of the adult male population elect a lower house of the Diet of Japan.

title: Brooklyn
event: The corrugated cardboard box is invented by Robert Gair, a Brooklyn printer who developed production of paper-board boxes in 1879.

title: Boise Idaho
event: The United States city of Boise, Idaho drills the first geothermal well.

title: East End of London
event: Blackwall Buildings, Whitechapel, noted philanthropic housing, is built in the East End of London.

title: Tell el-Hesi
event: W.M.F. Petrie excavated the site of Tell el-Hesi in Palestine, during which excavation he discovered how tells were formed.

title: Michigan State University
event: In Michigan, the wooden steamer ''Mackinaw'' burns in a fire on the Black River.Michigan State Universityyear=2000url=http://web1.msue.msu.edu/iosco/tbfulllist.htm MSUE-TB-wrecks}}<

title: Corsica
event: The steamship ''Persia'' is wrecked off Corsica; 130 lives are lost.{{Citation neededdate=October 2009}}

title: White House
event: Alice Sanger becomes the first female staffer in the White House.

title: Mariinsky Theatre
event: January 15 – The Sleeping Beauty (ballet) with music by Tchaikovsky is premiered at the Imperial Mariinsky Theatre in St Petersburg, Russia.

title: World's Columbian Exposition
event: February 24 – Chicago is selected to host the Columbian Exposition

title: United Kingdom
event: The British steamship ''Quetia'' founders in the Lorres Straits: 124 lives are lost.{{Citation neededdate=October 2009}}

title: Fargo North Dakota
event: March 8 – North Dakota State University is founded in Fargo, North Dakota.

title: Louisville Kentucky
event: March 27 – A tornado strikes Louisville, Kentucky, killing 76 people and injuring 200.

title: Pullman Washington
event: March 28 – Washington State University is founded in Pullman, Washington.

title: Americas
event: April 14 – Commercial Bureau of the American Republics

title: Gloucestershire
event: May 12 – The first ever ''official'' County Championship cricket match begins in Bristol; Yorkshire beats Gloucestershire by 8 wickets.

title: Michigan
event: June 12 – In Michigan, the wooden steamer ''Ryan'' is lost near Thunder Bay Island.

title: Idaho
event: July 3 – Idaho is admitted as the 43rd U.S. state.

title: Wyoming
event: July 10 – Wyoming is admitted as the 44th U.S. state.

title: Lake Pepin
event: July 13 – In Minnesota, storms result in the Sea Wing disaster on Lake Pepin killing 98.

title: Buenos Aires
event: July 26 – In Buenos Aires, the ''Revolución del Parque'' takes place, forcing President Juárez Celman's resignation.

title: New York
event: August 6 – At Auburn Prison in New York, William Kemmler becomes the first person to be executed in the electric chair.

title: United States Department of Agriculture
event: October 1 – Weather Bureau (within Department of Agriculture).

title: France
event: October 8 –  The first brief, partially controlled flight of Clément Ader's airplane Eole takes place in Satory, France.

title: Michigan
event: In Michigan, the schooner ''J.F. Warner'' is lost at Thunder Bay.

title: Cornell University
event: The Delta Chi Fraternity is founded by 11 law students at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York.

title: Scotland Yard
event: November – Scotland Yard, headquarters of the Metropolitan Police Service, moves to a building on London's Victoria Embankment, as the New Scotland Yard.

title: Diet of Japan
event: The Meiji Constitution goes into effect in Japan and the first Diet convenes.

title: West Point New York
event: In West Point, New York, the United States Navy defeats the United States Army 24–0 in the first Army–Navy Game.

title: Shanghai
event: December 27 – The British steamship ''Shanghai'' burns in the China Seas; 101 lives are lost.{{Citation neededdate=October 2009}}

title: Wounded Knee South Dakota
event: December 29 – Wounded Knee Massacre: At Wounded Knee, South Dakota, a Native American camp, the U.S. 7th Cavalry Regiment tries to disperse the non-violent Ghost-Dance which was promised to usher in a new era of power and freedom to Native Americans but was feared as a potential rallying tool for violent rebellion by some in the U.S. government.  Shooting begins, and 153 Lakota Sioux and 25 troops are killed; about 150 flee the scene.

title: New Scotland Yard
event: New Scotland Yard becomes the HQ of the London Metropolitan Police.

title: Iran
event: The Tobacco Protest occurs in Iran.

title: Seattle University
event: Seattle University is established.

title: Drexel University
event: Drexel University is founded as the ''Drexel Institute of Art, Science and Industry''.

title: Djurgården
event: Skansen is established as the world's first open air museum by Artur Hazelius on the island of Djurgården in Stockholm, Sweden.

title: Texas
event: January 20 – Jim Hogg becomes the first native Texan to be governor of that state.

title: Hawaii
event: January 29 – Liliuokalani is proclaimed Queen of Hawaii.

title: Portugal
event: January 31 – The Portuguese republican revolution breaks out in the northern city of Porto.

title: New Orleans
event: March 14 – In New Orleans, a lynch mob storms the Old Parish Prison and lynches 11 Italians arrested but found innocent of the murder of Police Chief David Hennessy.

title: Gibraltar
event: March 17 – The British steamship SS ''Utopia'' sinks in the inner harbor of Gibraltar, killing 564.HMS ''Immortalité'' - ''[http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F10D10F7345F10738DDDA90A94DB405B8185F0D3 The Dead of the Utopia]''. The New York Times, March 20, 1891.<

title: France
event: May 1 – Troops fire on a workers' May Day demonstration in support of the 8-hour workday in Fourmies, France, killing 9 and wounding 30.

title: New York City
event: May 5 – The Music Hall in New York (now known as Carnegie Hall) has its grand opening and first public performance, with maestro Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky as the guest conductor.

title: Telluride Colorado
event: June 21 – First long-distance transmission of alternating current by the Ames power plant near Telluride, Colorado by Lucien and Paul Nunn.

title: France
event: August 27 – France and Russia conclude a defensive alliance.

title: Stanford University
event: October 1 – In California, Stanford University opens its doors.

title: Gifu Prefecture
event: October 27 – An 8.0 earthquake strikes the village of Utsuzumi in rural Gifu, Japan, killing over 7,000 across the region and creating a 3-meter-tall surface fault that is still visible.

title: Oil City Pennsylvania
event: An oil fire in Oil City, Pennsylvania kills 130.

title: Powderham Castle
event: A tortoise called ''Timothy'' is brought to the estate of Powderham Castle in England, where she lives until her death in 2004.

title: United Kingdom
event: Abu Dhabi becomes a British protectorate.

title: Springfield Massachusetts
event: January 20 – At the YMCA in Springfield, Massachusetts, the first official basketball game is played.

title: Abraham Lincoln
event: February 12 – Former President Abraham Lincoln's birthday is declared a national holiday in the United States.

title: Pennsauken Township New Jersey
event: February 18 – Pennsauken Township, New Jersey is incorporated.

title: Anfield
event: March 15 – The Liverpool Football Club is founded by John Houlding, the owner of Anfield. Houlding decides to form his own team after Everton leaves Anfield in an argument over rent.

title: Buenos Aires
event: March 31 – The world's first fingerprinting bureau is formally opened by the Buenos Aires Chief of Police; it had been operating unofficially since the previous year.

title: Wyoming
event: April – The Johnson County War breaks out between small farmers and large ranchers in Wyoming.

title: Redondo Beach California
event: April 29 – Redondo Beach, California, USA is founded.

title: Nigeria
event: May 19 – Battle of Yemoja River: British troops defeat Ijebu infantry in modern-day Nigeria, using a maxim gun.

title: Nigeria
event: May 22 – The British conquest of Ijebu-Ode marks a major extension of colonial power into the Nigerian interior.

title: Australia
event: June 11 – The Limelight Department, later one of the world's first film studios, is officially established in Melbourne, Australia.

title: Homestead Pennsylvania
