event: January 28 – Conflict between Japan and China in the Battle of Shanghai.

title: Republic of China
event: The League of Nations again recommends negotiations between the Republic of China and Japan.

title: China
event: Japan occupies Harbin, China.

title: Vatican City
event: February 11 – Pope Pius XI meets Benito Mussolini in Vatican City.

title: Finland
event: February 27 – The Mäntsälä Rebellion occurs in Finland.

title: Hopewell New Jersey
event: Charles Lindbergh, Jr., the infant son of Anne Morrow Lindbergh and Charles Lindbergh, is kidnapped from the family home near Hopewell, New Jersey.

title: Dearborn Michigan
event: March 7 – Four people are killed when police fire upon 3,000 unemployed autoworkers marching outside the Ford River Rouge Plant in Dearborn, Michigan.

title: Irish Free State
event: March 9 – Eamon de Valera is elected President of the Executive Council.  It is the first change of government in the Irish Free State in 10 years.

title: Sydney Harbour Bridge
event: March 19 – The Sydney Harbour Bridge opens.

title: LZ 127 Graf Zeppelin
event: March 20 – The ''Graf Zeppelin'' begins a regular route to South America.

title: Finland
event: April 5 – Prohibition is lifted in Finland at 10 in the morning (local time), resulting in a new mnemonic 543210.

title: Iraq
event: April 25 – Two of the companions of Islam's Last Prophet Muhammad are moved from their graves upon informing of water in the graves in the dream of King Faisal of Iraq in Salmaan Paak, Iraq. Their names are Hazrat Hudhayfah ibn al-Yaman and Hazrat Jabir ibn Abd-Allah.

title: Amelia Earhart
event: May 20–May 21 – Amelia Earhart flies from the USA to Derry, Northern Ireland in 14 hours 54 minutes.

title: Argentina
event: May 20 – ''Federación Obrera de la Industria de la Carne'' initiates a major strike in the Argentinian meat-packing industry.

title: House of Lords
event: May 26 – judgement in Donoghue v Stevenson handed down in the House of Lords, creating the neighbour principle in English law.

title: Portugal
event: July 5 – Antonio de Oliveira Salazar becomes the fascist prime minister of Portugal (for the next 36 years).

title: Brazil
event: July 9 – The Constitutionalist Revolution starts in Brazil, with the uprising of the state of São Paulo.

title: Venice Film Festival
event: August 6 – The first Venice Film Festival is held.

title: Cass County Missouri
event: August 10 – A 5.1 kg chondrite-type meteorite breaks into at least 7 fragments and strikes earth near the town of Archie in Cass County, Missouri.

title: Iraq
event: October 3 – Iraq becomes an independent kingdom under Faisal.

title: Switzerland
event: Riots between conservative and socialist supporters in Switzerland leave 13 dead, 60 injured.

title: New York City
event: November 16 – New York City's Palace Theatre fully converts to a cinema, which is considered the final death knell of vaudeville as a popular entertainment in the United States.

title: China
event: December 25 – An earthquake in the Kansu Province in China kills 70,000.

title: Radio City Music Hall
event: December 27 – ''Radio City Music Hall'' opens in New York City.

title: Nazi Germany
event: Nazi Germany forms the ''Expert Committee on Questions of Population and Racial Policy'' under Reich Interior Minister Wilhelm Frick.

title: Nashville Tennessee
event: The first doughnut store under the Krispy Kreme name opens in Nashville, Tennessee.The Tennessean}}<

title: Angel Falls
event: Jimmie Angel becomes the first foreigner to see the Angel Falls (they are named after him).

title: Great Britain
event: The Children and Young Persons Act is passed in Great Britain.

title: France
event: Five coalition cabinets form and fall in France.

title: North Sydney Boys High School
event: The first dated ISCF group was started in Australia at North Sydney Boys High School, with the group still running today.

title: San Francisco Bay
event: January 5 – Construction of the Golden Gate Bridge begins in San Francisco Bay.

title: New Zealand
event: January 11 – Sir Charles Kingsford Smith makes the first commercial flight between Australia and New Zealand.

title: Philippines
event: January 17 – The U.S. Congress votes favorably for Philippines independence, against the view of President Herbert Hoover.

title: France
event: Edouard Daladier forms a government in France.

title: Oxford Union
event: February 9 – The Oxford Union approves a resolution stating, That this House will in no circumstances fight for its King and country.

title: New York City
event: February 10 – The New York City-based Postal Telegraph Company introduces the first singing telegram.

title: Reichstag (building)
event: February 27 – Germany's parliament building in Berlin, the Reichstag, is set on fire (see Reichstag fire).

title: New York City
event: March 2 – The original film version of ''King Kong'', starring Fay Wray, premieres at Radio City Music Hall and the RKO Roxy Theatre in New York City.

title: Ching Yun University
event: Ching Yun University is established.

title: 1933 Sanriku earthquake
event: A powerful earthquake and tsunami hit Honshū, Japan, killing some 3,000.

title: Parliament of Austria
event: The Parliament of Austria is suspended because of a quibble over procedure; Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss initiates authoritarian rule by decree (see Austrofascism).

title: Dachau concentration camp
event: March 20 – Dachau, the first Nazi concentration camp, is completed (it opens March 22).

title: New Jersey
event: April 4 – The American airship ''Akron'' crashes off the coast of New Jersey, leaving 73 dead.

title: Denmark
event: The International Court in the Hague decides that Greenland belongs to Denmark and condemns Norwegian landings on eastern Greenland. Norway submits to the decision.

title: Cape of Good Hope
event: April 11 – Aviator Bill Lancaster takes off in England, in an attempt to make a speed record to the Cape of Good Hope, but vanishes (his body was not found until 1962, in the Sahara Desert).

title: Nazi Germany
event: April 21 – Nazi Germany outlaws the kosher ritual shechita.

title: London
event: The Jessop & Son department store in Nottingham, England is acquired by John Lewis Partnership (its first store outside of London).

title: Bolivia
event: Paraguay declares war on Bolivia.

title: Century of Progress
event: The ''Century of Progress'' World's Fair opens in Chicago.

title: Camden New Jersey
event: June 6 – The first drive-in theater opens in Camden, New Jersey.

title: Federal Bureau of Investigation
event: June 17 – Union Station massacre: In Kansas City, Missouri, Pretty Boy Floyd kills 4 unarmed FBI agents and captured fugitive Frank Nash in a failed attempt to free him.

title: India
event: July 4 – Gandhi is sentenced to prison in India.

title: Comiskey Park
event: July 6 – The first Major League Baseball All-Star Game is played at Comiskey Park in Chicago.

title: Dexter Iowa
event: July 24 – Several members of the Barrow Gang are injured or captured during a running battle with local police near Dexter, Iowa.

title: Baltic Sea
event: August 2 – Opening of the Stalin White Sea – Baltic Sea Canal, a 227 km navigable waterway constructed using forced labour in the Soviet Union connecting the White Sea with Lake Onega and the Baltic.

title: Oregon
event: August 14 – Loggers cause a forest fire in the Coast Range of Oregon, later known as the first forest fire of the Tillamook Burn. It is extinguished on September 5, after destroying 240,000 acres (971 km²).

title: Sichuan
event: August 25 – The Diexi earthquake shakes Mao County, Sichuan, China and kills 9,000 people.

title: Chesterton Indiana
event: October 10 – A United Airlines Boeing 247 is destroyed near Chesterton, Indiana, by a bomb. This is the first proven case of air sabotage in commercial airline history.

title: Nazi Germany
event: October 17 – Albert Einstein arrives in the United States as a refugee from Nazi Germany.

title: South Dakota
event: November 11 – Dust Bowl: In South Dakota, a very strong dust storm strips topsoil from desiccated farmlands (one of a series of disastrous dust storms that year).

title: Brazil
event: President of Brazil Getulio Vargas names himself dictator.

title: France
event: December 24 – A train crash in Lagny, France kills over 200.

title: Tokyo
event: The Nissan Motor Company is organized in Tokyo, Japan.

title: France
event: Abidjan becomes the capital of the French colony of Côte d'Ivoire.

title: Philippines
event: US Congress makes the Philippines a self-governing commonwealth and schedules independence for 1944. Sugar imports are reduced and immigration is limited to 50 Filipino people per year.

title: Pennsylvania
event: The house Fallingwater in southwestern Pennsylvania is designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: Nazi Germany
event: Nazi Germany passes the Law for the Prevention of Hereditarily Diseased Offspring.

title: Estonia
event: The new Constitution of Estonia enters into force.

title: White House
event: Einstein visits the White House.

title: Harlem
event: The ''Apollo Theater'' opens in Harlem, New York City.

title: Second Polish Republic
event: The 10 year German-Polish Non-Aggression Pact is signed by Germany and the Second Polish Republic.

title: Palais Bourbon
event: February 6 – French political crisis: The French far right leagues rally in front of the Palais Bourbon, in an attempted coup against the Third Republic.

title: Crown Point Indiana
event: John Dillinger escapes from jail in Crown Point, Indiana, using a wooden pistol.

title: Estonia
event: March 12 – Konstantin Päts and general Johan Laidoner stage a coup in Estonia, and ban all political parties.

title: Mason City Iowa
event: March 13 – John Dillinger, Baby Face Nelson and their gang rob the First National Bank in Mason City, Iowa.

title: Hokkaido
event: The Great Hakodate fire kills at least 2,166 people in southern Hokkaido, Japan.

title: Grapevine Texas
event: April 1 – Clyde Barrow and Bonnie Parker kill 2 young highway patrolmen near Grapevine, Texas.

title: Mount Washington (New Hampshire)
event: April 12 – The worlds largest ever recorded surface wind speed of 231 miles per hour was recorded on the summit of Mt. Washington NH.

title: Wisconsin
event: April 22 – John Dillinger and two others shoot their way out of an FBI ambush in northern Wisconsin.

title: Portsmouth
event: April 28 – FA Cup: Manchester City beat Portsmouth 2 – 1 at Wembley Stadium

title: Philippines
event: May 7 – The Pearl of Lao Tzu, 24 x 14 cm, is found in a giant clam off Palawan, Philippines.

title: Latvia
event: Kārlis Ulmanis establishes an authoritarian government in Latvia.

title: Gibsland Louisiana
event: May 23 – A team of police officers, led by former Texas Ranger Frank Hamer, ambush bank robbers Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow near Gibsland, Louisiana, killing them both.

title: Toledo Ohio
event: The 5-day Battle of Toledo occurs during the Auto-Lite strike in Toledo, Ohio.

title: Callander Ontario
event: May 28 – Near Callander, Ontario, the Dionne quintuplets are born to Oliva and Elzire Dionne, becoming the first quintuplets to survive infancy.

title: Barmen
event: May 29 – May 31 – The Confessional Synod of the German Evangelical Church meets in Barmen, Germany to write the Barmen Declaration.

title: Yemen
event: June 27 – The Emir of Yemen and ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia conclude a peace treaty.

title: Illinois
event: The world famous Brookfield Zoo opens in Brookfield, Illinois.

title: North Dakota
event: July 17 – The North Dakota Supreme Court declares Lieutenant Governor Ole H. Olson the legitimate governor and tells William Langer to resign. Langer proceeds to declare North Dakota independent. He revokes the declaration after the Supreme Court justices meet him.

title: McGuffey Ohio
event: August 25 – Anti-union vigilantes seize the town of McGuffey, Ohio, during the Hardin County onion pickers strike.

title: New Jersey
event: September 8 – Off the New Jersey coast, a fire aboard the passenger liner ''Morro Castle'' kills 134 people.

title: Lindbergh kidnapping
event: Bruno Richard Hauptmann is arrested in connection with the Lindbergh kidnapping case.

title: New York City
event: Cole Porter's musical ''Anything Goes'', starring Ethel Merman, premieres in New York City.

title: Ogaden
event: November 23 – An Anglo-Ethiopian boundary commission in the Ogaden discovers an Italian garrison at Walwal, which lays well within Ethiopian territory. This encounter leads to the Abyssinia Crisis.

title: Hollywood
event: November 26 – Universal Pictures releases the first film version of Fannie Hurst's novel, ''''Imitation of Life'''', starring Claudette Colbert and Louise Beavers. It gives Beavers, usually featured in small roles as a maid, her best screen role, and features the largest supporting role played by a black person in a Hollywood film up till then. Its storyline is extremely daring for a 1934 film – part of it revolves around a young mulatto girl rejecting her mother and trying to pass for white. It is the first Hollywood film to seriously deal with this subject. The 1936 film version of ''Show Boat'', also from Universal, will deal with a similar storyline.

title: Iran
event: December 27 – Persia becomes Iran.

title: Library of Congress
event: January – Haile Selassie I of Ethiopia creates a military school at Holeta.Library of Congress<

title: Libya
event: January 1 – The Italian colonies of Tripoli and Cyrenaica are joined together as Libya.

title: Flemington New Jersey
event: January 3 – The trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, accused of the kidnapping and murder of Charles Lindbergh, Jr., begins in Flemington, New Jersey.

title: France
event: January 7 – Italian premier Benito Mussolini and French Foreign Minister Pierre Laval conclude an agreement in which each power agrees not to oppose the other's colonial claims.

title: California
event: January 11 – Amelia Earhart becomes the first person to fly solo from Hawaii to California.

title: Richmond Virginia
event: January 24 – The first canned beer is sold in Richmond, Virginia, United States, by Gottfried Krueger Brewing Company.

title: White House
event: February 22 – Airplanes are banned from flying over the White House.

title: Hachikō
event: March 8 – Hachikō, the loyal dog who was remembered for his loyalty to his owner, even many years after his owners death, passes away on the very same spot he had waited for over nine years.

title: Harlem
event: March 19 – A riot breaks out in Harlem, NYC, after a rumor that police killed a shoplifter in the S. H. Kress & Co. department store circulates.

title: Iran
event: March 21 – Persia is renamed Iran.

title: Crosley Field
event: May 24 – The first nighttime Major League Baseball game is played between the Cincinnati Reds and Philadelphia Phillies at Crosley Field in Cincinnati, Ohio.

title: Philadelphia
event: May 30 – Eventual Baseball Hall of Famer Babe Ruth appears in his last career game, playing for the Boston Braves in Philadelphia against the Phillies.

title: China
event: June 9 – He-Umezu Agreement: China's Kuomintang government concedes Japanese military control of north-eastern China.

title: Louisiana
event: June 12 – Senator Huey Long of Louisiana makes the longest speech on Senate record, taking 15½ hours and containing 150,000 words.

title: Madison Square Garden Bowl
event: June 13 – James J. Braddock defeats Max Baer at Madison Square Garden Bowl to win the heavyweight boxing championship of the world.

title: United Kingdom
event: June 18 – Anglo-German Naval Agreement: Britain agrees to a German navy equal to 35% of her own naval tonnage.

title: Eastbourne Bandstand
event: August 5 – Eastbourne Bandstand officially opened in Eastbourne, United Kingdom.

title: Barrow Alaska
event: August 15 – Humorist Will Rogers and aviator Wiley Post are killed when Post's plane crashes shortly after takeoff near Barrow, Alaska.

title: Florida Keys
event: September 2 – Labor Day Hurricane of 1935: The strongest hurricane ever to strike the United States landfalls in the Upper Florida Keys as a Category 5 storm with 185 mph winds, killing 423.

title: Louisiana
event: September 8 – Carl Weiss kills Huey Long, U.S. Senator from Louisiana, in the Louisiana Capitol Building in Baton Rouge.

title: Columbia Mississippi
event: September 24 – Earl Bascom and his brother Weldon Bascom produce the first night rodeo held outdoors under electric lights at Columbia, Mississippi.

title: Italy
event: October 2–October 3 – The Second Italo-Abyssinian War begins as General Emilio de Bono of Italy invades Ethiopia.

title: United Kingdom
event: November 14 – In the General Election in Britain, Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin returns to office at the head of a National Government led by the Conservative Party with a large but reduced majority.

title: Manila
event: November 22 – The ''China Clipper'' takes off from Alameda, California in an attempt to deliver the first airmail cargo across the Pacific Ocean (the aircraft later reaches its destination, Manila, and delivers over 110,000 pieces of mail).

title: United Kingdom
event: November 30 – The 1935 British-made film ''Scrooge'', the first all-talking film version of Charles Dickens classic, opens in the U.S. after its British release. Seymour Hicks plays Scrooge, a role he has played onstage hundreds of times. The film is criticized by some for not showing all of the ghosts physically, and quickly fades into obscurity. Widespread interest in it does not surface until the film is shown on television in the 1980s, in very shabby-looking prints. It is eventually restored on DVD, but the criticisms of it remain.

title: United Kingdom
event: Samuel Hoare resigns as British foreign secretary and is replaced by Anthony Eden.

title: North America
event: A major heat wave strikes North America; high temperature records are set and thousands die.

title: China
event: West China Famine: five million die.

title: Albany New York
event: The YMCA Youth and Government program is founded in Albany, New York.

title: Tasmania
event: Death of probably the last thylacine (Tasmanian wolf).

title: Toledo Ohio
event: January 15 – The first building to be completely covered in glass is completed in Toledo, Ohio, for the Owens-Illinois Glass Company.

title: Sing Sing
event: January 16 – Serial killer Albert Fish is executed in Sing Sing Prison.

title: Nazi Germany
event: March 7 – In violation of the Treaty of Versailles,  Nazi Germany reoccupies the Rhineland.

title: Pennsylvania
event: March 17–March 18 – St. Patrick's Day Flood: Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, suffers the worst flooding in its history.

title: New Jersey
event: April 3 – Bruno Richard Hauptmann, convicted of kidnapping and killing Charles Lindbergh III, is executed in New Jersey.

title: Gainesville Georgia
event: April 6 – Two tornadoes strike Gainesville, Georgia. The smaller tornado hits north Gainsville, the stronger tornado the west side of town. 203 die and 1,600 are injured in the 5th deadliest tornado in U.S. history.

title: Addis Ababa
event: May 5 – Italian forces occupy Addis Ababa.

title: Italy
event: May 7 – Italy annexes Ethiopia.

title: Southampton
event: British luxury liner {{RMSQueen Mary}} leaves Southampton on her maiden voyage across the Atlantic

title: Estonia
event: June 15 – An army laboratory explodes in Estonia, killing 60.

title: New York City
event: June 19 – Max Schmeling knocks out Joe Louis in the 12th round of their heavyweight boxing match at Yankee Stadium in New York City.

title: Robert F. Kennedy Bridge
event: July 11 – Triborough Bridge in New York City is opened to traffic.

title: Indiana
event: July 13 – 14 – Peak of July 1936 heat wave: The U.S. states of Wisconsin, Michigan, and Indiana all set new state records for high temperature. At Mio in northern Michigan, it soars to 113°F (45°C).

title: Owensboro Kentucky
event: Rainey Bethea was hanged in Owensboro, Kentucky, in the last public execution in the United States

title: Hobart Zoo
event: September 7 – The last known Tasmanian Tiger named Benjamin dies in Hobart Zoo in Tasmania.

title: Columbia Mississippi
event: October 11 – Earl Bascom, rodeo cowboy and artist, designs and builds Mississippi's first permanent rodeo arena at Columbia, Mississippi.

title: Uptown Theater (Washington D.C.)
event: October 29 – The historic Uptown Theater opens in Washington D.C.

title: California
event: November 12 – In California, the San Francisco–Oakland Bay Bridge opens to traffic.

title: Akita Prefecture
event: November 20 – A levee failure and continued massive rain at the Mitsubishi Osarizawa mine, Kazuno, northeastern Akita, Japan, results in at least 375 deaths.

title: New York City
event: November 25 – The Abraham Lincoln Brigade sails from New York City on its way to the Spanish Civil War.

title: London
event: November 30 – In London, the Crystal Palace is destroyed in a fire (it had been built for the 1851 Great Exhibition).

title: New York City
event: December 3 – Radio station WQXR is officially founded in New York City.

title: Irish Free State
event: December 12 – The Irish Free State passes the External Relations Act to legislate for Edward VIII's abdication in that realm.

title: Pablo Picasso
event: June – Picasso completes his painting ''Guernica''.

title: United Kingdom
event: The National House Builders Registration Council (now the NHBC) is formed in the United Kingdom.

title: Hawaii
event: The Vibora Luviminda trades union's sugar plantation strike on Maui island, Hawaii.

title: Leeds
event: January 3 – The first science fiction convention is held in Leeds, England.

title: New York City
event: January 19 – Howard Hughes sets a new record by flying from Los Angeles to New York City in 7 hours, 28 minutes and 25 seconds.

title: Michigan
event: January 26 – The U.S. state of Michigan celebrates its Centennial Anniversary of statehood.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: February 5 – U.S President Franklin D. Roosevelt proposes a plan to enlarge the Supreme Court of the United States.

title: Málaga
event: February 8 – Spanish Civil War: Falangist troops take Málaga.

title: Sydney
event: Airliner VH-UHH (''Stinson'') goes down over Lamington National Park, bound for Sydney, killing five people.

title: Addis Ababa
event: During a public ceremony at the Viceregal Palace (the former Imperial residence) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, two Eritrean nationalists attempt to kill viceroy Rodolfo Graziani with a number of grenades. The Italian security guard fire into the crowd of Ethiopian onlookers, and over the passing weeks indiscriminately slaughter native Ethiopians in reprisal.

title: Argentina
event: February 20 – Roberto Ortiz is elected president of Argentina.

title: New London Texas
event: March 18 – In the worst school disaster in American history in terms of lives lost, the New London School in New London, Texas suffers a catastrophic natural gas explosion, killing in excess of 295 students and teachers.

title: New London School explosion
event: March 19 – Mother Frances Hospital opens in Tyler, Texas in response to the New London School explosion.

title: Crystal City Texas
event: In Crystal City, Texas, spinach growers erect a statue of the cartoon character Popeye.

title: London
event: April 9 – The ''Kamikaze'' arrives at Croydon Airport in London; it is the first Japanese-built aircraft to fly to Europe.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: April 12 – ''NLRB v. Jones & Laughlin Steel'': The Supreme Court of the United States rules that the National Labor Relations Act is constitutional.

title: Estonia
event: April 20 – A cine film fire in an elementary school in Kilingi-Nõmme, Estonia, kills seventeen students and injures fifty.

title: Bombing of Guernica
event: April 26 – Spanish Civil War: Guernica, Spain is bombed. In his report of the Falangist attack on Guernica, British journalist George Steer reports finding German bomb casings, connecting Luftwaffe planes with the attack.

title: France
event: May 1 – A general strike occurs in Paris, France.

title: Lakehurst New Jersey
event: May 6 – ''Hindenburg'' disaster: In the United States, the German airship ''Hindenburg'' bursts into flame when mooring to a mast in Lakehurst, New Jersey. Of the 36 passengers and 61 crew on board, 13 passengers and 22 crew die, as well as one member of the ground crew

title: Francisco Franco
event: May 7 – Spanish Civil War: The German Condor Legion Fighter Group, equipped with Heinkel He 51 biplanes, arrives in Spain to assist Francisco Franco's forces.

title: London
event: May 12 – The coronation of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth takes place at Westminster Abbey, London.

title: Arctic Ocean
event: A Soviet station becomes the first scientific research settlement to operate on the drift ice of the Arctic Ocean.

title: Italy
event: As one of the reprisals for the attempted assassination of Italian viceroy Rodolfo Graziani, a detachment of Italian troops massacres the entire community of Debre Libanos, killing 297 monks and 23 laymen.

title: Marin County California
event: May 27 – In California, the Golden Gate Bridge opens to pedestrian traffic, creating a vital link between San Francisco and Marin County. The next day, President Franklin D. Roosevelt pushes a button in Washington, D.C., signaling the start of vehicle traffic over the Golden Gate Bridge.

title: Pennsylvania
event: June 14 – Pennsylvania becomes the first (and only) of the United States to celebrate Flag Day officially as a state holiday.

title: France
event: June 21 – The coalition government of Léon Blum resigns in France.

title: Irish Free State
event: In a referendum the people of the Irish Free State accept the new Constitution by 685,105 votes to 527,945.

title: New Guinea
event: Amelia Earhart and navigator Fred Noonan disappear after taking off from New Guinea during Earhart's attempt to become the first woman to fly around the world.

title: Tomb of the Unknowns
event: A guard takes his place at the Tomb of the Unknowns in Washington, DC; continuous guard has been maintained there ever since.

title: Yellow Grass Saskatchewan
event: July 5 – The highest recorded temperature in Canada, at Yellow Grass, Saskatchewan, is 45°C.

title: China
event: July 7 – Sino-Japanese War: Battle of Lugou Bridge (aka Marco Polo Bridge Incident): Japanese forces invade China (often seen as the beginning of World War II in Asia).

title: Beijing
event: July 8 – Japan occupies Beijing.

title: Geibeltbad Pirna
event: July 20 – The Geibeltbad Pirna is opened in Dresden, Germany.

title: Irish Free State
event: July 21 – Eamon de Valera is elected president of the Irish Free State.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: July 22 – New Deal: The United States Senate votes down President Franklin D. Roosevelt's proposal to add more justices to the Supreme Court of the United States.

title: Alabama
event: July 24 – Alabama drops rape charges against the so-called ''Scottsboro Boys''.

title: Tianjin
event: July 25–July 31 – Sino-Japanese War: Battle of Beiping-Tianjin, a series of actions fought arouond Beiping and Tianjin, resulting in Japanese victory.

title: Belfast
event: July 28 – The IRA attempts the assassination by bomb of King George VI in Belfast.

title: Madrid
event: August 6 – Spanish Civil War: Falangist artillery bombards Madrid.

title: Shanghai
event: August 26 – Sino-Japanese War: Japanese aircraft attack the car carrying the ambassador of Great Britain during a raid on Shanghai.

title: Llanes
event: September 5 – Spanish Civil War: The city of Llanes falls to the Falangists.

title: Hollywood Bowl
event: September 7 – CBS broadcasts a two-and-a-half hour memorial concert nationwide on radio in memory of George Gershwin, live from the Hollywood Bowl.  Many celebrities appear, including Oscar Levant, Fred Astaire, Otto Klemperer, Lily Pons, and members of the original cast of ''Porgy and Bess''. The concert is recorded and released complete years later in what is excellent sound for its time, on CD. The Los Angeles Philharmonic is the featured orchestra.

title: Abraham Lincoln
event: September 17 – Abraham Lincoln's head is dedicated at Mount Rushmore.

title: Switzerland
event: September 19 – Swiss professional ice hockey club HC Ambrì-Piotta founded.

title: Brussels
event: October 13 – Germany, in a note to Brussels, guarantees the inviolability and integrity of Belgium so long as the latter abstains from military action against Germany.

title: Reich Chancellery
event: World War II: In the Reich Chancellery, Adolf Hitler holds a secret meeting and states his plans for acquiring living space for the German people (recorded in the Hossbach Memorandum).

title: Italy
event: November 6 – Italy joins the Anti-Comintern Pact.

title: Shanghai
event: November 9 – Sino-Japanese War: Japanese troops take Shanghai.

title: Brazil
event: November 10 – Brazilian president Getúlio Vargas announces the Estado Novo (New State), thence becoming dictator of Brazil until 1945.

title: Italy
event: December 11 – Italy withdraws from the League of Nations.

title: USS Panay (PR-5)
event: Panay incident: Japanese bombers sink the American gunboat USS Panay (PR-5)

title: West End theatre
event: December 16 – The original production of the musical ''Me and My Girl'' opens at the West End Victoria Palace Theatre in London. A later revival of this musical would win an award.

title: Los Angeles
event: December 21 – Walt Disney's ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs'', the first feature-length animated cartoon with sound, opens in Los Angeles. By the end of its original run, it will earn over $8 million in international box office receipts.

title: Irish Free State
event: December 29 – The new Irish constitution, Bunreacht na hÉireann, comes into force. The Irish Free State becomes Éire and Eamon de Valera becomes the first Taoiseach (prime minister) of the new state. A Presidential Commission (made up the Irish Chief Justice, the Speaker of Dáil Éireann and the President of the High Court) assumes the powers of the new presidency of Ireland pending the election of the first president in June 1938. The new constitution prohibits divorce.

title: Guangzhou
event: October – The Japanese Imperial Army largely overruns Canton.

title: Interpol
event: Under regime of Nazi Germany, many countries cease participation in the ICPC organization (1938–1945).

title: Estonia
event: The new Constitution of Estonia enters into force.

title: Cairo
event: January 20 – King Farouk of Egypt marries Queen Farida Zulficar in Cairo.

title: Princeton New Jersey
event: January 22 – Thornton Wilder's play ''Our Town'' is performed for the first time anywhere in Princeton, New Jersey.  It premieres in New York City on February 4.

title: Gibraltar
event: January 25 – A brilliant aurora borealis described variously as a curtain of fire and a huge blood-red beam of light startles people across Europe and is visible as far south as Gibraltar.

title: Niagara Falls New York
event: The Niagara Bridge at Niagara Falls, New York collapses due to an ice jam.

title: Vermont
event: January 28 – The first ski tow in America begins operation in Vermont.

title: Sydney
event: February 6 – Black Sunday at Bondi Beach, Sydney, Australia: 300 swimmers are dragged out to sea in 3 freak waves; 80 lifesavers save all but 5.

title: Singapore
event: February 14 – The British naval base at Singapore begins operations.

title: Quabbin Reservoir
event: April 28 – The towns of Dana, Enfield, Greenwich, and Prescott in Massachusetts are disincorporated to make way for the Quabbin Reservoir.

title: Francisco Franco
event: The Vatican recognizes Franco's government in Spain.

title: Estonia
event: May 9 – Kaarel Eenpalu becomes prime minister of Estonia.

title: Latvia
event: June 11 – Fire destroys 212 buildings in Ludes, Latvia.

title: Yankee Stadium (1923)
event: June 22 – Heavyweight boxing champion Joe Louis knocks out Max Schmeling in the first round of their rematch at Yankee Stadium in New York City.

title: St. Augustine Florida
event: Marineland opens near St. Augustine, Florida.

title: Chicora Pennsylvania
event: June 24 – A {{convert450MTST0lk=onadj=on}} meteorite explodes about {{convert12mikm0}} above the earth near Chicora, Pennsylvania.

title: Battle of Gettysburg
event: The last reunion of the Blue and Gray commemorates the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania.

title: Eiger
event: July 24 – First ascent of the Eiger north face.

title: Chania
event: July 28 – A revolt against the Ioannis Metaxas dictatorship is put down in Chania, Greece.

title: Thousand Islands Bridge
event: The Thousand Islands Bridge, connecting the United States with Canada, is dedicated by U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: Carpathian Ruthenia
event: August 23 – Hitler, hosting a dinner on board the ocean liner ''Patria'' in Kiel Bay, tells the Regent of Hungary, Admiral Horthy, that action against Czechoslovakia is imminent and that he who wants to sit at the table must at least help in the kitchen, a reference to Horthy's designs on Carpathian Ruthenia.

title: Long Island
event: The New England Hurricane of 1938 strikes Long Island and southern New England, killing over 300 along the Rhode Island shoreline and 600 altogether.

title: Zaolzie
event: October 1 – German troops march into the Sudetenland. The Polish government gives the Czech government an ultimatum stating that Zaolzie region must be handed over within twenty-four hours. The Czechs have little choice but to comply. Polish forces occupy Zaolzie.

title: 1938 Tiberias massacre
event: Tiberias massacre: Arabs murder 20 Jews.

title: Sarnia Ontario
event: October 10 – The Blue Water Bridge opens, connecting Port Huron, Michigan and Sarnia, Ontario.

title: Free City of Danzig
event: At a friendly luncheon in Berchtesgaden, German foreign minister Joachim von Ribbentrop tells Józef Lipski, the Polish ambassador to Germany, that the Free City of Danzig must return to Germany, that the Germans must be given extraterritorial rights in the Polish Corridor, and that Poland must sign the Anti-Comintern Pact.

title: Pimlico Race Course
event: November 1 – Horse Racing: Seabiscuit defeats War Admiral by four lengths in their famous match race at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore, Maryland.

title: Neuengamme concentration camp
event: December 13 – The Neuengamme concentration camp opens near Hamburg.

title: Chalumna River
event: December 23 – A coelacanth, a fish thought to have been extinct, is caught off the coast of South Africa near Chalumna River.

title: Mahen Theatre
event: December 30 – The ballet ''Romeo and Juliet'' with music by Prokofiev receives its first full performance at the Mahen Theatre in Brno, Czechoslovakia.

title: Corrales New Mexico
event: Sandia View Academy, a private Adventist school, is founded in Corrales, New Mexico,

title: Texas A&M University
event: Texas A&M University wins its only football national championship.

title: Amelia Earhart
event: January 5 – Amelia Earhart is officially declared dead after her disappearance.

title: Victoria (Australia)
event: January 13 – Black Friday: 71 people die across Victoria in one of Australia's worst ever bushfires.

title: 1939 Chillán earthquake
event: January 24 – An earthquake kills 30,000 in Chile, and razes about {{convert50000sqmikm2abbr=on}}.

title: Italy
event: Spanish Civil War: Spanish Nationalist troops, aided by Italy, take Barcelona.

title: France
event: In a response to Georges Bonnet's speech of January 26, German Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop, referring to Bonnet's alleged statement of December 6, 1938 accepting Eastern Europe as being in Germany's exclusive sphere of influence, protests that all French security commitments in that region are now off limits.

title: Francisco Franco
event: The United Kingdom and France recognize Franco's government.

title: Borley Rectory
event: Borley Rectory in England is destroyed by fire.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: Sit-down strikes are outlawed by the Supreme Court of the United States.

title: India
event: In Bombay, Mohandas Gandhi begins a fast protesting against British rule in India.

title: Harvard University
event: Students at Harvard University demonstrate the new tradition of swallowing goldfish to reporters.

title: South Africa
event: In Durban, South Africa the Timeless Test begins between England and South Africa, the longest game of cricket ever played. It is abandoned twelve days later when the English team has to catch the last ferry home.

title: London
event: Irish writer Flann O'Brien's comic metafiction ''At Swim-Two-Birds'' is published in London but attracts little attention at this time.

title: Birmingham
event: March 17 – British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain gives a speech in Birmingham, stating that Britain will oppose any effort at world domination on the part of Germany.

title: Nazi Germany
event: March 22 – After an ultimatum of March 20, Nazi Germany takes Memelland from Lithuania.

title: Madrid
event: March 28 – Dictator Francisco Franco assumes power in Madrid.

title: Iraq
event: Faisal II becomes King of Iraq.

title: Albania
event: April 7 – Italy invades Albania; King Zog flees.

title: 1939 New York World's Fair
event: April 30 – The 1939 New York World's Fair opens.

title: All India Forward Bloc
event: The All India Forward Bloc is formed by Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose.

title: Finland
event: Sweden, Norway, and Finland refuse Germany's offer of non-aggression pacts.

title: Italy
event: May 22 – Germany and Italy sign the Pact of Steel.

title: Albania
event: Albanian fascist leader Tefik Mborja is appointed as member of the Italian Chamber of Fasces and Corporations.

title: Florida
event: June 4 – The ''St. Louis'', a ship carrying a cargo of 907 Jewish refugees, is denied permission to land in Florida after already having been turned away from Cuba. Forced to return to Europe, many of its passengers later die in Nazi death camps during the Holocaust.

title: Cooperstown New York
event: June 12 – The National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum is officially dedicated in Cooperstown, New York.

title: China
event: June 14 – Tientsin Incident: The Japanese blockade the British concession in Tianjin, China, beginning a crisis which almost causes an Anglo-Japanese war in the summer of 1939.

title: Hatay State
event: June 23 – Talks are completed in Ankara between French Ambassador René Massigli and Turkish Foreign Minister Şükrü Saracoğlu, resolving the Hatay dispute in Turkey's favor. Turkey annexes Hatay.

title: Neuengamme concentration camp
event: The Neuengamme concentration camp becomes autonomous.

title: New Zealand
event: July 27 – The only recorded snowfall in Auckland, New Zealand since records began in 1853.

title: Hollywood
event: August 15 – MGM's classic musical film ''The Wizard of Oz'', based on L. Frank Baum's famous novel, and starring Judy Garland as Dorothy, premieres at Grauman's Chinese Theatre in Hollywood.

title: Inner Mongolia
event: August 20 – Armored forces under the command of Soviet General Georgi Zhukov deliver a decisive defeat to Japanese Imperial Army forces in the Japanese-Soviet border war in Inner Mongolia.

title: Latvia
event: August 23 – Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact: Adolf Hitler and Joseph Stalin agree to divide Europe between Germany and the Soviet Union (Finland, Estonia, Latvia, eastern Poland and Bessarabia (today Moldova), north-east province of Romania to the Soviet Union; Lithuania and western Poland to Germany).

title: Coventry
event: An Irish Republican Army bomb explodes in the centre of Coventry, England, killing 5 people.

title: Nazi Germany
event: August 30 – Poland begins a mobilization against Nazi Germany.

title: Westerplatte
event: At 04.45 Central European Time, the German battleship ''Schleswig-Holstein'' opens bombardment on the Westerplatte, a Polish military base outside Danzig, firing what are, according to many sources, the first shots of the war. At the same time, regular Wehrmacht troops begin crossing the border into Poland.

title: Switzerland
event: Norway, Finland, Sweden, and Switzerland declare their neutrality.

title: Nazi Germany
event: Following the invasion of Poland, Danzig (now Gdańsk, Poland) is annexed to Nazi Germany.

title: Ireland
event: Spain and Ireland declare their neutrality.

title: Nazi Germany
event: The United Kingdom, France, New Zealand and Australia declare war on Germany.

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: British liner SS ''Athenia'' becomes the first civilian casualty of the war when she is torpedoed and sunk by German submarine ''U-30'' in the eastern Atlantic. Of the 1,418 aboard, 98 passengers and 19 crew are killed.

title: Nazi Germany
event: September 4 – World War II: Nepal declares war on Germany.

title: Nazi Germany
event: September 6 – World War II: South Africa declares war on Germany.

title: Warsaw
event: World War II: Forward elements of General Hoeppner's XVI Panzerkorps take up positions outside Warsaw. The world is stunned by the rapidity of the German advance and the Polish High Command is effectively isolated, but lack of infantry support and effective civilian resistance cause Hoeppner to halt outside the city itself.

title: Westerplatte
event: World War II: Polish troops on the Westerplatte are forced, due to lack of food and ammunition, to surrender. The garrison of about two hundred had held out against thousands of German forces (many of them Naval officer cadets from the ''Schleswig-Holstein,'') for seven days.

title: Nazi Germany
event: September 10 – World War II: Canada declares war on Germany.

title: Warsaw
event: September 15 – World War II: Diverse elements of the German Wehrmacht surround Warsaw and demand its surrender. The Poles refuse and the siege begins in earnest.

title: WJSV
event: September 21 – Radio station WJSV in Washington, D.C. records an entire broadcast day for preservation in the National Archives.

title: Nazi Germany
event: Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union agree on a division of Poland after their invasion.

title: Kock
event: Warsaw surrenders to Germany; Modlin surrenders a day later; the last Polish large operational unit surrenders near Kock 8 days later.

title: Nazi Germany
event: October 8 – World War II: Germany annexes Western Poland.

title: Estonia
event: October 12 – Jüri Uluots becomes prime minister of Estonia.

title: New York City
event: October 25 – ''The Time of Your Life'', a drama by William Saroyan, debuts in New York City.

title: Hollywood
event: ''Hedda Hopper's Hollywood'' debuts on radio with Hollywood gossip columnist Hedda Hopper as host (the show runs until 1951, making Hopper a powerful figure in the Hollywood elite).

title: Kraków
event: World War II – Sonderaktion Krakau: Germans take action against scientists from the University of Kraków and other Kraków universities at the beginning of World War II.

title: Beer Hall Putsch
event: November 8 – In Munich, an attempt to kill Adolf Hitler is made by Georg Elser while Hitler is celebrating the 16th anniversary of the Beer Hall Putsch.

title: Secret Intelligence Service
event: November 9 – Venlo Incident: Two British agents of SIS are captured by the Germans.

title: Finland
event: Winter War: Soviet forces attack Finland and reach the Mannerheim Line, starting the war.

title: New York City
event: December 2 – La Guardia Airport opens for business in New York City.

title: HMS Barham (04)
event: December 12 – World War II: ''HMS Duchess'' sinks after a collision with ''HMS Barham'' off the coast of Scotland with the loss of 124 men.

title: Battle of the River Plate
event: December 13 – World War II – Battle of the River Plate:  The German pocket battleship, ''Admiral Graf Spee'' is trapped by cruisers HMS ''Ajax'', HMNZS ''Achilles'', and HMS ''Exeter'' after a running battle off the coast of Uruguay. ''Admiral Graf Spee'' is scuttled by its crew off Montevideo harbor on December 17.

title: Finland
event: December 14 – The League of Nations expels the USSR for attacking Finland.

title: Borinage
event: December 26 – Miners strike in Borinage, Belgium.

title: Anatolia
event: December 27 – The 1939 Erzincan earthquake in Eastern Anatolia, Turkey, kills 30,000.

title: Louisiana
event: September – The U.S. Army 45th Infantry Division (previously a National Guard Division in Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Oklahoma), is activated and ordered into federal service for 1 year, to engage in a training program in Ft. Sill and Louisiana, prior to serving in World War II.

title: Korea
event: In Korea, ''The Hunmin Jeong-eum Haerye'' (1446) is discovered, explaining the basis of Hangul.

title: Finland
event: Olympic Games, assigned to Tokyo, Japan, and later to Helsinki, Finland, are suspended due to World War II.

title: Nazi Germany
event: January 4 – WWII: (Axis powers): Luftwaffe General Hermann Göring assumes control of most war industries in Germany.

title: Battle of Suomussalmi
event: January 8 – WWII: Winter War – Battle of Suomussalmi: The Russian 44th Assault Division is destroyed by Finnish forces.

title: United Kingdom
event: January 8 – WWII: Food rationing begins in Great Britain.

title: Australia
event: January 26 – Brisbane, Australia swelters through its hottest day ever, 43.2 degrees Celsius (109.76 Fahrenheit).

title: Parliament of South Africa
event: January 27 – WWII:  A peace resolution introduced in the Parliament of South Africa is defeated 81–59.

title: Karelian Isthmus
event: February 1 – WWII: Winter War – Russian forces launch a major assault on Finnish troops occupying the Karelian Isthmus.

title: Jøssingfjord
event: February 16 – WWII: Altmark Incident: The British destroyer ''Cossack'' pursues the German tanker ''Altmark'' into Jøssingfjord in southwestern Norway.

title: Katyn massacre
event: March 5 – Katyn massacre: Members of the Soviet Politburo (Joseph Stalin, Vyacheslav Molotov, Lazar Kaganovich, Mikhail Kalinin, Kliment Voroshilov and Lavrenty Beria) sign an order, prepared by Beria, for the execution of 25,700 Polish intelligentsia, including 14,700 Polish POWs.

title: California
event: March 11 – Ed Ricketts, John Steinbeck and six others leave Monterey, California for The Sea of Cortez on a collecting expedition.

title: Finland
event: March 12 – The Soviet Union and Finland sign a peace treaty in Moscow ending the Winter War; Finns, along with the world at large, are shocked by the harsh terms.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 18 – WWII: Axis powers: Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini meet at Brenner Pass in the Alps and agree to form an alliance against France and the United Kingdom.

title: Lahore
event: March 23 – The ''Pakistan Resolution'' is rallied around by the All-India Muslim League; Muslims from every corner of India meet up around Iqbal Park, Lahore (now in modern-day Pakistan).

title: Wadden Sea
event: March 31 – WWII: Commerce raiding ''hilfskreuzer Atlantis'', leaves the Wadden Sea for what will become the longest warship cruise of the war. (622 days without in-port replenishment or repair)

title: Denmark
event: April 9 – WWII: Germany invades Denmark and Norway in Operation ''Weserübung.'' The British campaign in Norway is simultaneously commenced.

title: Nazi Germany
event: April 12 – The Faroe Islands are occupied by British troops, following the taking over of Denmark by Nazi Germany. This action is taken to avert a possible German occupation of the islands, which would have had very grave consequences for the course of the Battle of the Atlantic

title: Rhythm Club fire
event: April 23 – A fire at the Rhythm Night Club in Natchez, Mississippi kills 198.

title: United Kingdom
event: Iceland is invaded by the United Kingdom.

title: Rotterdam
event: May 14 – Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands and her government flee to London; Rotterdam is subjected to savage terror bombing by the Luftwaffe; 980 are killed, and 20,000 buildings destroyed.

title: United Kingdom
event: May 14 – Recruitment begins in Britain for a home defence force: the Local Defence Volunteers, later known as the Home Guard.

title: San Bernardino California
event: May 15 – The very first McDonald's restaurant opens in San Bernardino, California.

title: Brussels
event: May 17 – Brussels falls to German forces; the Belgian government flees to Ostend.

title: France
event: May 18 – Marshal Philippe Pétain is named vice-premier of France.

title: France
event: May 19 – General Maxime Weygand replaces Maurice Gamelin as commander-in-chief of all French forces.

title: English Channel
event: May 20 – WWII: German forces (2nd Panzer division), under General Rudolf Veiel, reach Noyelles on the English Channel.

title: Parliament of the United Kingdom
event: May 22 – WWII: The British Parliament passes the Emergency Powers Act, giving the government full control over all persons and property.

title: Dunkirk evacuation
event: May 26 – WWII: The Dunkirk evacuation of the British Expeditionary Force starts

title: The Holocaust
event: June 3 – The Holocaust: Franz Rademacher proposes the Madagascar Plan.

title: France
event: June 4 – WWII: The Dunkirk evacuation ends – British forces complete evacuating 300,000 troops from Dunkirk in France.

title: United Kingdom
event: June 10 – WWII: Italy declares war on France and the United Kingdom.

title: University of Virginia
event: June 10 – WWII: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt denounces Italy's actions with his [ftp://webstorage2.mcpa.virginia.edu/library/nara/fdr/audiovisual/speeches/fdr_1940_0610.mp3 Stab in the Back] speech during the graduation ceremonies of the University of Virginia.

title: Italy
event: June 10 – WWII: Canada declares war on Italy.

title: France
event: June 12 – WWII: 13,000 British and French troops surrender to Field Marshal Erwin Rommel at St. Valery-en-Caux.

title: Tarnów
event: June 14 – WWII: A group of 728 Polish political prisoners from Tarnów become the first residents of the Auschwitz concentration camp.

title: Sturgis South Dakota
event: June 16 – The Sturgis Motorcycle Rally is held for the first time in Sturgis, South Dakota.

title: Latvia
event: June 17 – The Soviet Army enters the Baltic states of Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia.

title: France
event: June 17 – WWII: Operation Ariel begins: Allied troops start to evacuate France, following Germany's takeover of Paris and most of the nation.

title: France
event: June 17 – A Luftwaffe Junkers 88 bomber sinks the British ship ''RMS Lancastria'', which was evacuating troops from near Saint-Nazaire, France, killing some 5,800 men. (Wartime censorship prevents the story from becoming public.)

title: Nazi Germany
event: June 18 – WWII: General Charles de Gaulle broadcasts from London, calling on all French people to continue the fight against Nazi Germany:  France has lost a battle. But France has not lost the war.

title: France
event: June 23 – WWII: German leader Adolf Hitler surveys newly defeated Paris in now occupied France.[http://history1900s.about.com/library/holocaust/blhitler38.htm]

title: Philadelphia
event: June 24 – U.S. politics: The Republican Party begins its national convention in Philadelphia and nominates Wendell Willkie as its candidate for president.

title: Italy
event: June 24 – WWII: Vichy France signs armistice terms with Italy.

title: United Kingdom
event: June 28 – General Charles de Gaulle is officially recognized by Britain as the Leader of all Free Frenchmen, wherever they may be.

title: Guernsey
event: June 30 – WWII: German forces land in Guernsey, marking the start of the 5-year Occupation of the Channel Islands.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 3 – WWII:  British naval units sink or seize ships of the French fleet anchored in the Algerian ports of Oran and Mers-el-Kebir.  The following day, Vichy France breaks off diplomatic relations with Britain.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 19 – WWII: Adolf Hitler makes a peace appeal to Britain in an address to the Reichstag.  Lord Halifax, British foreign minister, flatly rejects peace terms in a broadcast reply on July 22.

title: Soldier Field
event: August 4 – Gen. John J. Pershing, in a nationwide radio broadcast, urges all-out aid to Britain in order to defend the Americas, while Charles Lindbergh speaks to an isolationist rally at Soldier Field in Chicago.

title: University of Oxford
event: August 24 – Howard Florey and a team including Ernst Chain and Norman Heatley at the Sir William Dunn School of Pathology, University of Oxford, publish their laboratory results showing the ''in vivo'' bactericidal action of penicillin. They have also purified the drug.Sciencevolume=287issue=5460pages=1960–4doi=10.1126/science.287.5460.1960pmid=10720314}}<

title: Bermuda
event: September 2 – WWII: An agreement between America and Great Britain is announced to the effect that 50 U.S. destroyers needed for escort work will be transferred to Great Britain. In return, America gains 99-year leases on British bases in the North Atlantic, West Indies and Bermuda.

title: North Sea
event: September 5 – WWII: Commerce raiding ''hilfskreuzer Komet'' enters the Pacific Ocean via the Bering Strait after crossing the Arctic Ocean from the North Sea with the help of Soviet icebreakers ''Lenin'', ''Stalin'', and ''Kaganovich''.

title: London
event: September 7 – WWII: The Blitz – Nazi Germany begins to rain bombs on London (the first of 57 consecutive nights of strategic bombing).

title: France
event: September 12 – In Lascaux, France, 17,000-year-old cave paintings are discovered by a group of young Frenchmen hiking through Southern France.  The paintings depict animals and date to the Stone Age.

title: Succasunna-Kenvil New Jersey
event: September 12 – The Hercules Munitions Plant in Succasunna-Kenvil, New Jersey explodes, killing 55 people.

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: September 17–18 – WWII: SS ''City of Benares'' is torpedoed by U-48 in the Atlantic with the loss of 248 of the 406 on board, including child evacuees bound for Canada. This results in cancellation of the British Children's Overseas Reception Board's plan to relocate children overseas.

title: Italy
event: September 27 – WWII: Germany, Italy and Japan sign the Tripartite Pact.

title: Joachim Schepke
event: October 18–October 19 – WWII: Thirty-two ships are sunk from Convoy SC 7 and Convoy HX 79 by the most effective Wolf pack of the war including U-boat aces Kretschmer, Prien and Schepke

title: Tacoma Narrows Bridge (1940)
event: November 7 – In Tacoma, Washington, the {{convert600ftmsing=on}}-long center span of the Tacoma Narrows Bridge (known as Galloping Gertie) collapses.

title: Bucharest
event: November 10 – An earthquake in Bucharest, Romania kills 1,000.

title: Battle of Taranto
event: November 11 – WWII: The Royal Navy launches the first aircraft carrier strike in history, on the Italian battleship fleet anchored at Taranto naval base.

title: United Kingdom
event: November 11 – WWII: The German ''Hilfskreuzer'' (commerce raider) ''Atlantis'' captures top secret British mail, and sends it to Japan.

title: Coventry
event: November 14 – WWII: The city of Coventry, England is destroyed by 500 German Luftwaffe bombers (150,000 fire bombs, 503 tons of high explosives, and 130 parachute mines level 60,000 of the city's 75,000 buildings; 568 people are killed).

title: Coventry
event: November 16 – WWII: In response to Germany levelling Coventry 2 days before, the Royal Air Force begins to bomb Hamburg (by war's end, 50,000 Hamburg residents will have died from Allied attacks).

title: Greece
event: November 18 – WWII: German leader Adolf Hitler and Italian Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano meet to discuss Benito Mussolini's disastrous invasion of Greece.

title: Battle of Cape Spartivento
event: November 27 – WWII: The Royal Navy and Regia Marina fight the Battle of Cape Spartivento.

title: Sheffield
event: December 12 & December 15 – WWII: Sheffield Blitz – The City of Sheffield is badly damaged by German air-raids.

title: Italy
event: December 23 – WWII: Winston Churchill, in a broadcast address to the people of Italy, blames Benito Mussolini for leading his nation to war against the British, contrary to Italy's historic friendship with them: One man has arrayed the trustees and inheritors of ancient Rome upon the side of the ferocious pagan barbarians.

title: Second Great Fire of London
event: December 29 – WWII: Second Great Fire of London – Luftwaffe carries out a massive incendiary bombing raid, starting 1,500 fires. Many famous buildings, including the Guildhall and Trinity House, are either damaged or destroyed.

title: Pasadena California
event: December 30 – California's first modern freeway, the future State Route 110, opens to traffic in Pasadena, California, as the Arroyo Seco Parkway (now the Pasadena Freeway).

title: Special Air Service
event: July – The British Army's Special Air Service is formed.

title: Valley of Geysers
event: The Valley of Geysers is discovered in Russia.

title: Brooklyn
event: January 6 – The keel of  the {{USSMissouriBB-636}} is laid at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn.

title: Southern Ocean
event: January 14 – WWII: Commerce raiding ''hilfskreuzer Pinguin'' captures the Norwegian whaling fleet near Bouvet Island, effectively ending Southern Ocean whaling for the duration of the war.

title: Libya
event: January 21 – WWII – Battle of Tobruk: Australian and British forces  attack Tobruk, Libya.

title: Darnah Libya
event: January 30 – WWII – Australians capture Darnah, Libya from the Italians.

title: Benghazi
event: February 6 – WWII – Fall of Benghazi to the Western Desert Force. Lieutenant-General Erwin Rommel is appointed commander of Afrika Korps.

title: Tripoli
event: WWII: Erwin Rommel arrives in Tripoli.

title: Oxford
event: Reserve Constable Albert Alexander, a patient at the Radcliffe Infirmary in Oxford, becomes the first person treated with penicillin intravenously, by Howard Florey’s team. He reacts positively but there is insufficient supply of the drug to reverse his terminal infection. A successful treatment is achieved during May.

title: Swansea
event: February 19–February 22 – WWII: Three Nights' Blitz over Swansea, South Wales: Over these 3 nights of intensive bombing, which last a total of 13 hours and 48 minutes, Swansea's town centre is almost completely obliterated by the 896 high explosive bombs employed by the Luftwaffe. A total of 397 casualties and 230 deaths are reported.

title: Nashville Tennessee
event: W47NV begins operations in Nashville, Tennessee, becoming the first FM radio station.

title: National Gallery of Art
event: In Washington, D.C., the National Gallery of Art is officially opened by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: Washington (U.S. state)
event: March 22 – Washington's Grand Coulee Dam begins to generate electricity.

title: Vienna
event: March 25 – WWII: The Kingdom of Yugoslavia joins the Axis powers in Vienna.

title: Empire of Japan
event: WWII – Attack on Pearl Harbor: Empire of Japanese spy Takeo Yoshikawa arrives in Honolulu, Hawaii and begins to study the Pacific Fleet at Pearl Harbor.

title: Battle of Cape Matapan
event: WWII – Battle of Cape Matapan: Off the Peloponnesus coast in the Mediterranean, British naval forces defeat those of Italy, sinking 5 warships. Battle ends on March 29.

title: Benghazi
event: April 4 – WWII: Axis forces capture Benghazi.

title: Schauspielhaus Zürich
event: April 19 – Bertolt Brecht's anti-war play ''Mother Courage and Her Children'' ({{lang-deMutter Courage und ihre Kinder}}) receives its first theatrical production at the Schauspielhaus Zürich.

title: Crete
event: April 21 – WWII: Greece capitulates. Commonwealth troops and some elements of the Greek Army withdraw to Crete.

title: Addis Ababa
event: May 5 – WWII: Emperor Haile Selassie enters Addis Ababa, which had been liberated from Italian forces; this date has been since commemorated as Liberation Day in Ethiopia.

title: California
event: May 6 – At California's March Field, entertainer Bob Hope performs his first USO Show.

title: German submarine U-110 (1940)
event: May 9 – WWII: The German submarine ''U-110'' is captured by the British Royal Navy. On board is the latest Enigma cryptography machine, which Allied cryptographers later use to break coded German messages.

title: Crete
event: May 20 – WWII: The Battle of Crete begins as Germany launches an airborne invasion of Crete.

title: HMS Hood (51)
event: May 24 – WWII: In the North Atlantic, the German battleship ''Bismarck'' sinks battlecruiser HMS ''Hood'', killing all but 3 crewmen aboard the pride of the Royal Navy.

title: German battleship Bismarck
event: May 26 – WWII: In the North Atlantic, Fairey Swordfish aircraft from the carrier HMS ''Ark Royal'' cripple the steering of ''Bismarck'' in an aerial torpedo attack.

title: German battleship Bismarck
event: WWII:''Bismarck'' is sunk in the North Atlantic, killing 2,300.

title: Latvia
event: Mass deportations by Soviet Union authorities take place in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.

title: Sisak
event: WWII: The First Sisak Partisan Brigade, the first anti-fascist armed unit in occupied Europe, is founded by partisans near Sisak, Croatia.

title: Albania
event: June 28 – WWII: Albania declares war on the Soviet Union.

title: Empire of Japan
event: July 2 – WWII:  Empire of Japan calls up 1 million men for military service.

title: Nazi Germany
event: July 4 – The Mass murder of Polish scientists and writers is committed by German troops in the captured Polish city of Lwów.

title: Estonia
event: WWII: German troops take over Estonia from the Soviets.

title: Philippines
event: WWII: General Douglas MacArthur is named commander of all U.S. forces in the Philippines; the Philippines Army is ordered nationalized by President Roosevelt.

title: Florida
event: August 6 – Six-year-old Elaine Esposito goes to an appendix operation in Florida and lapses into a coma. She dies in 1978, still in a coma.

title: Argentia Newfoundland and Labrador
event: August 9 – Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill meet at Argentia, Newfoundland and Labrador. The Atlantic Charter is created as a result.

title: HMS Mercury (shore establishment)
event: August 16 – The HMS ''Mercury'', Royal Navy Signals School and Combined Signals School open at Leydene, near Petersfield, Hampshire, England.

title: Nazi Germany
event: August 18 – Adolf Hitler orders a temporary halt to Nazi Germany's systematic euthanasia of the mentally ill and handicapped due to protests. However, graduates of the T-4 Euthanasia Program are then transferred to concentration camps, where they continue in their trade.

title: Estonia
event: August 24 – WWII: A Luftwaffe bomb hits an Estonian steamer with 3,500 Soviet-mobilized Estonian men on board, killing 598 of them.

title: Iran
event: August 25 – WWII: Operation Countenance begins with United Kingdom and Soviet forces invading Iran.

title: Star of David
event: September 6 – Holocaust: The requirement to wear the Star of David with the word Jew inscribed, is extended to all Jews over the age of 6 in German-occupied areas.

title: Des Moines Iowa
event: September 11 – WWII: Charles Lindbergh, at an America First Committee rally in Des Moines, Iowa, accuses the British, the Jewish, and the Roosevelt administration of leading the United States toward war. Widespread condemnation of Lindbergh follows.

title: Sea of Azov
event: October 8 – WWII: In their invasion of the Soviet Union, Germany reaches the Sea of Azov with the capture of Mariupol.

title: Fall River Massachusetts
event: October 11–October 12 – Fire destroys a Firestone Tire & Rubber Co. plant in Fall River, Massachusetts, consuming 15,850 tons of rubber and causing a setback to the United States war effort.

title: Yugoslavia
event: October 21 – WWII: The Germans rampage in Yugoslavia, killing thousands of civilians.

title: USS Reuben James (DD-245)
event: WWII: The destroyer USS ''Reuben James'' is torpedoed by a German U-boat near Iceland, killing more than 100 United States Navy sailors.

title: Mansion House London
event: November 10 – In a speech at the Mansion House in London, Winston Churchill promises, should the United States become involved in war with Japan, the British declaration will follow within the hour.

title: Battle of Moscow
event: November 12 – WWII: As Battle of Moscow begins, temperatures around Moscow drop to -12 °C, and the Soviet Union launches ski troops for the first time against the freezing German forces near the city.

title: German submarine U-81 (1941)
event: November 13 – WWII: The aircraft carrier HMS ''Ark Royal'' is hit by German U-boat ''U-81''.

title: German submarine U-81 (1941)
event: November 14 – WWII: The {{HMSArk Royal916}} capsizes and sinks, having been torpedoed by ''U-81''.

title: German auxiliary cruiser Kormoran
event: November 19 – WWII: Both commerce raiding ''hilfskreuzer Kormoran'' and Australian cruiser HMAS ''Sydney'' sink following a battle off the coast of Western Australia.  There are no survivors from the 645 Australian sailors aboard ''Sydney''.

title: German auxiliary cruiser Atlantis
event: November 22 – WWII: HMS ''Devonshire'' sinks commerce raiding ''hilfskreuzer Atlantis'', ending the longest warship cruise of the war. (622 days without in-port replenishment or repair)

title: Yreka California
event: A group of young men stop traffic on U.S. Highway 99 south of Yreka, California, handing out fliers proclaiming the establishment of the State of Jefferson.

title: Straits Settlements
event: WWII: A state of emergency is declared in Malaya and the Straits Settlements.

title: Attack on Pearl Harbor
event: December 2 – WWII – Attack on Pearl Harbor: The code message Climb Mount Niitaka is transmitted to the Japanese task force, indicating that negotiations have broken down and that the attack is to be carried out according to plan.

title: Yreka California
event: December 4 – The State of Jefferson is declared in Yreka, California, with judge John Childs as a governor.

title: Attack on Pearl Harbor
event: (December 8, Japan standard time) – The Japanese Navy launches a surprise attack on the United States fleet at Pearl Harbor, thus drawing the United States into WWII. The attack is announced on radio stations in the US at about 2:26 p.m. EST (19.26 GMT).

title: Empire of Japan
event: WWII: The United States, United Kingdom, China and The Netherlands officially declare war on the Empire of Japan.

title: Philippines
event: WWII: Empire of Japan launches invasions in Hong Kong, Malaya, Manila, Singapore and the Philippines.

title: Singapore
event: December 10 – WWII: The British battleships HMS ''Prince of Wales'' and HMS ''Repulse'' are sunk by Japanese aircraft in the South China Sea north of Singapore.

title: Empire of Japan
event: WWII: British India declares war on Empire of Japan.

title: Philippines
event: WWII: The Kimura Detachment of the Japanese Imperial forces is occupied in Legaspi, Albay in Eastern Philippines.

title: Vilhelmina Municipality
event: December 13 – Sweden's low temperature record of -53°C is set in a village within the Vilhelmina Municipality.

title: Wake Island
event: December 23 – WWII: A second Japanese landing attempt on Wake Island is successful, and the American garrison surrenders after a full night and morning of fighting.

title: Benghazi
event: December 24 – WWII: British forces capture Benghazi.

title: Iran
event: Lions become extinct in Iran.

title: Philippines
event: January 1 – WWII: The United States and Philippines troops fight the Battle of Bataan.

title: Manila
event: January 2 – WWII: Manila is captured by Japanese forces.

title: Bataan Peninsula
event: January 7 – WWII: The siege of the Bataan Peninsula begins.

title: Las Vegas Nevada
event: January 16 – Actress Carole Lombard and her mother are among those killed in a plane crash near Las Vegas, Nevada, while returning from a tour to promote the sale of war bonds.

title: United Kingdom
event: January 25 – WWII: Thailand declares war on the United States and United Kingdom.

title: Portugal
event: António Óscar Carmona is elected president of Portugal.

title: New York City
event: February 10 – In the early hours of the morning the SS Normandie capsizes at pier 88 in New York City.

title: English Channel
event: February 11 – Operation Cerberus A flotilla of Kriegsmarine ships dash from Brest through the English Channel to northern ports; the British fail to sink any one of them.

title: Battle of Singapore
event: February 15 – WWII: Singapore surrenders to Japanese forces.

title: Australia
event: Japanese warplanes attack Darwin, Australia.

title: Italy
event: President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs executive order 9066 allowing the United States military to define areas as exclusionary zones. These zones affect the Japanese on the West Coast, and Germans and Italians primarily on the East Coast.

title: Edward O'Hare
event: February 20 – Lieutenant Edward O'Hare becomes America's first U.S. Navy World War II flying ace.

title: Philippines
event: February 22 – WWII: President Franklin Delano Roosevelt orders General Douglas MacArthur out of the Philippines as American defense of the nation collapses.

title: Japanese submarine I-17
event: February 23 – The Japanese submarine ''I-17'' fires 17 high-explosive shells toward an oil refinery near Santa Barbara, California, causing little damage.

title: SS Struma
event: February 24 – the SS Struma, which carried Jewish refugees from Axis-allied Romania to British-controlled Palestine, was torpedoed and sunk by the Soviet submarine ''Shch 213'', killing 768 men, women and children, with only one survivor, a 19 year old man, making it the largest exclusively civilian naval disaster of the war.

title: California
event: February 25 – Battle of Los Angeles: Over 1,400 AA shells are fired at an unidentified, slow-moving object in the skies over Los Angeles. The appearance of the object triggers an immediate wartime blackout over most of Southern California, with thousands of air raid wardens being deployed throughout the city. In total there are 6 deaths. Despite the several hour barrage no planes are downed.

title: China
event: The worst coal dust explosion to date, in Honkeiko, China, claims 1,549 lives.

title: Los Angeles
event: The 14th Academy Awards ceremony is held in Los Angeles; How Green Was My Valley wins Best Picture.

title: Java Sea
event: February 27 – WWII – Battle of the Java Sea: An allied (ABDA) task force under Dutch command, trying to stem a Japanese invasion of the Dutch East Indies, is defeated by a Japanese task force in the Java Sea.

title: Badger Army Ammunition Plant
event: March – Construction begins on the Badger Army Ammunition Plant (the largest in the United States during WWII).

title: France
event: March 28 – WWII: Operation Chariot - British Commandos raid St. Nazaire on the coast of Western France.

title: Bataan Peninsula
event: April 3 – WWII: Japanese forces begin an all-out assault on the United States and Filipino troops on the Bataan Peninsula.

title: HMS Dorsetshire (40)
event: April 5 – WWII: the Japanese Navy attacks Colombo in Ceylon (Sri Lanka). Royal Navy Cruisers HMS Cornwall and HMS Dorsetshire are sunk southwest of the island.

title: HMAS Vampire (D68)
event: WWII: The Japanese Navy launches an air raid on Trincomalee in Ceylon (Sri Lanka); the Royal Navy aircraft carrier ''HMS Hermes'' and Royal Australian Navy destroyer ''HMAS Vampire'' are sunk off the country's East Coast.

title: Malta
event: April 15 – WWII: King George VI awards the George Cross to Malta, saying, To honour her brave people I award the George Cross to the Island Fortress of Malta, to bear witness to a heroism and a devotion that will long be famous in history (from January 1 to July 24, there is only one 24-hour period during which no bombs fall on this tiny island).

title: Madagascar
event: May 5 – WWII – Operation Ironclad: United Kingdom forces invade the French colony of Madagascar.

title: Philippines
event: May 6 – WWII: On Corregidor, the last American and Filipino forces in the Philippines surrender to the Japanese.

title: Battle of the Coral Sea
event: May 8 – WWII: The Battle of the Coral Sea (first battle in naval history where 2 enemy fleets fight without seeing each other's fleets) ends in an Allied victory.

title: Key West
event: May 21 – WWII: Mexico declares war against Nazi Germany after the sinking of the Mexican tanker ''Faja de Oro'' by the German U-boat, U-160, off Key West.

title: Battle of Bir Hakeim
event: May 26 – WWII – Battle of Bir Hakeim: The Free French and British troops slow the German advance in North Africa.

title: Operation Anthropoid
event: May 27 – WWII – Operation Anthropoid: Czech paratroopers attempt to assassinate Reinhard Heydrich in Prague.

title: Operation Anthropoid
event: June 4 – WWII: Reinhard Heydrich succumbs to wounds sustained on May 27 from Czechoslovakian paratroopers acting in Operation Anthropoid.

title: Battle of Midway
event: June 4–June 7 – WWII – The Battle of Midway: The Japanese naval advance in the Pacific is halted.

title: Aleutian Islands
event: June 7 – WWII: Japanese forces invade the Aleutian Islands (the first invasion of American soil in 128 years).

title: Newcastle New South Wales
event: June 8 – WWII: Attack on Sydney Harbour: The Australian cities of Sydney and Newcastle are shelled by Japanese submarines. The eastern suburbs of both cities are damaged and the east coast is blacked out.

title: First Battle of El Alamein
event: July 1 – July 27 – WWII: the First Battle of El Alamein.

title: Guadalcanal
event: July 3 – Guadalcanal, occupied only by aborigines falls to the Japanese Naval construction force deployed to construct an air field on the island.

title: German battleship Tirpitz
event: Twenty-four ships are sunk by German bombers and submarines after Convoy PQ 17 to the Soviet Union is scattered in the Arctic Ocean to evade the German battleship Tirpitz.

title: New Guinea
event: July 21 – The Japanese establish a beachhead on the north coast of New Guinea in the Buna-Gona area; a small Australian force begins a rearguard action on the Kokoda Track Campaign.

title: Warsaw Ghetto
event: July 22 – Holocaust: The systematic deportation of Jews from the Warsaw Ghetto begins.

title: Presidium of the Supreme Soviet
event: July 29 – The Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR institutes the Order of Suvorov, the Order of Kutuzov, and reinstates the Order of Alexander Nevsky.

title: India
event: Quit India resolution is passed by the Bombay session of the All India Congress Committee (AICC), which led to the start of a historical civil disobedience movement across India.

title: United Kingdom
event: Indian leader, Mohandas Gandhi is arrested in Bombay by British forces.

title: Italy
event: August 22 – WWII: Brazil declares war on Germany and Italy.

title: Milne Bay
event: August 25 – WWII: Japanese marines land at Milne Bay.

title: Brookings Oregon
event: September 9 – WWII – A Japanese floatplane drops incendiary devices at Mount Emily, near Brookings, Oregon, in the first of two Lookout Air Raids, the first bombing of the continental United States.

title: France
event: September 24 – Andrée Borrel and Lise de Baissac became the first female SOE agents to be parachuted into occupied France.

title: Liberty ship
event: September 27 – WWII – Both commerce raiding ''hilfskreuzer Stier'' and Liberty ship ''Stephen Hopkins'' sink following a gun battle in the South Atlantic. ''Stier'' is the only commerce raider to be sunk by Defensively Equipped Merchant Ships.

title: RMS Queen Mary
event: October 2 – The British cruiser ''Curaçao'' collides with the liner ''Queen Mary'' off the coast of Donegal and sinks; 338 drown.

title: Test Stand VII
event: October 3 – The first A-4 rocket is successfully launched from Test Stand VII at Peenemünde, Germany. The rocket flies 147 kilometres wide and reaches a height of 84.5 kilometres, becoming the first man-made object to reach space.

title: Australia
event: October 9 – The Statute of Westminster Adoption Act formalizes Australian autonomy.

title: Battle of Cape Esperance
event: October 11 – WWII – Battle of Cape Esperance: On the northwest coast of Guadalcanal, United States Navy ships intercept and defeat a Japanese fleet on their way to reinforce troops on the island.

title: SS Caribou
event: October 14 – A German U-boat sinks the ferry ''SS Caribou'', killing 137.

title: Palm Springs California
event: October 23 – Award-winning composer and Hollywood songwriter Ralph Rainger (''Thanks for the Memory'') is among 12 people killed in the mid-air collision between an American Airlines DC-3 airliner and a U.S. Army bomber near Palm Springs, California.

title: Second Battle of El Alamein
event: October 23 – November 4 – WWII – Second Battle of El Alamein: British troops go on the offensive against the Axis forces.

title: Battle of the Santa Cruz Islands
event: October 26 – WWII – Battle of the Santa Cruz Islands: two Japanese aircraft carriers are heavily damaged and one U.S.N. carrier is sunk.

title: Nazi Germany
event: October 29 – Holocaust: In the United Kingdom, leading clergymen and political figures hold a public meeting to register outrage over Nazi Germany's persecution of Jews.

title: Second Battle of El Alamein
event: November 3 – WWII – Second Battle of El Alamein: German forces under Erwin Rommel are forced to retreat during the night.

title: United Kingdom
event: Operation Torch – United States and United Kingdom forces land in French North Africa.

title: Japanese battleship Hiei
event: Battle of Guadalcanal: Aviators from the USS ''Enterprise'' sink the Japanese battleship Hiei.

title: Naval Battle of Guadalcanal
event: The Naval Battle of Guadalcanal ends: Although the United States Navy suffers heavy losses, it retains control of Guadalcanal.

title: Bay of Biscay
event: A BOAC scheduled passenger flight, a DC-3 with registration G-AGBB, (formerly KLM PH-ALI, Ibis), enroute between Lisbon and Bristol, is attacked over the Bay of Biscay by German fighters. Although damaged, it escapes and lands in England. Other attacks follow on the same aircraft and scheduled route: April 19 and June 1, 1943 (fatal).

title: Darnah Libya
event: British forces capture Derna.

title: Operation Uranus
event: November 19 – WWII – Battle of Stalingrad: Soviet Union forces under General Georgy Zhukov launch the Operation Uranus counter-attacks at Stalingrad, turning the tide of the battle in the USSR's favor.

title: Benghazi
event: November 20 – WWII –British forces capture Benghazi.

title: Operation Uranus
event: November 22 – WWII – Battle of Stalingrad: The situation for the German attackers of Stalingrad seems desperate during the Soviet counter-attack Operation Uranus, and General Friedrich Paulus sends Adolf Hitler a telegram saying that the German Sixth Army is surrounded.

title: Poon Lim
event: November 23 – A German U-boat sinks the ''S.S. Ben Lomond'' off the coast of Brazil. One crewman, Chinese second steward Poon Lim, is separated from the others and spends 130 days adrift until he is rescued on April 3, 1943.

title: New York City
event: November 26 – The movie ''Casablanca'' premières at the Hollywood Theater in New York City.

title: Cocoanut Grove fire
event: In Boston, Massachusetts, a fire in the Cocoanut Grove night club kills 491 people.

title: University of Chicago
