event: December 2 – Manhattan Project: Below the bleachers of Stagg Field at the University of Chicago, a team led by Enrico Fermi initiates the first self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction (a coded message, The Italian navigator has landed in the new world is then sent to U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt).

title: Warsaw
event: Holocaust: In Warsaw, 2 women, Zofia Kossak and Wanda Filipowicz, risk their lives by setting up the Council for the Assistance of the Jews.

title: New Zealand
event: Arana Hall, Otago is founded in New Zealand.

title: China
event: The United States and United Kingdom give up territorial rights in China.

title: Argentina
event: Roberto María Ortiz dies in Argentina; Ramón Castillo succeeds him.

title: The Pentagon
event: The world's largest office building, The Pentagon, is dedicated in Arlington, Virginia.

title: Tripoli
event: WWII: British forces capture Tripoli from the Italians.

title: New York City
event: Duke Ellington plays at New York City's Carnegie Hall for the first time.

title: Battle of Stalingrad
event: February 2 – WWII: In Russia, the Battle of Stalingrad comes to an end with the surrender of the German 6th Army.

title: USAT Dorchester
event: February 3 – WWII: The Four Chaplains of the U.S. Army are drowned, when their ship (USAT Dorchester) is struck by a German torpedo.

title: Battle of the Kasserine Pass
event: Battle of the Kasserine Pass: German General Erwin Rommel and his Afrika Korps launch an offensive against Allied defenses in Tunisia; it is the United States' first major battle defeat of the war.

title: Third Battle of Kharkov
event: February 16 – WWII: The Soviet Union reconquers Kharkov, but is later driven out in the Third Battle of Kharkov

title: Parícutin
event: The Mexican volcano Parícutin is born in a farmer's cornfield.

title: Ireland
event: February 23 – A fire at St. Joseph's Orphanage, County Cavan, Ireland, kills 36 people (35 of whom are children).

title: Bearcreek Montana
event: February 27 – The Smith Mine #3 in Bearcreek, Montana, United States explodes, killing 74 men.

title: Vemork
event: February 28 – Operation Gunnerside: 6 Norwegians led by Joachim Ronneberg successfully attack the heavy water plant Vemork.

title: Australia
event: March 2 – WWII: Battle of the Bismarck Sea – United States and Australian forces sink Japanese convoy ships.

title: London
event: March 3 – 173 people are killed in a crush while trying to enter an air-raid shelter at Bethnal Green tube station in London.

title: Los Angeles
event: March 4 – The 15th Academy Awards ceremony is held in Los Angeles.

title: Bougainville Island
event: March 8 – WWII: American forces are attacked by Japanese troops on Hill 700 in Bougainville, in a battle that will last 5 days.

title: Brazil
event: March 10 – Banco Bradesco was founded by Amador Aguiar in Marília, São Paulo, Brazil.

title: Bougainville Island
event: WWII: On Bougainville, Japanese troops end their assault on American forces at Hill 700.

title: Kraków
event: Holocaust: German forces liquidate the Jewish ghetto in Kraków.

title: HMS Thetis (N25)
event: March 14 –  WWII: British submarine HMS ''Thunderbolt'' sunk off Sicily by an Italian corvette, the second time this vessel has been lost with all hands.

title: Kiska
event: March 26 – WWII – Battle of the Komandorski Islands: In the Aleutian Islands, the battle begins when United States Navy forces intercept Japanese troops attempting to reinforce a garrison at Kiska.

title: Firth of Clyde
event: March 27 – WWII – Escort carrier ''Dasher'' was destroyed by an accidental explosion in the Firth of Clyde, killing 379 of the crew of 528.

title: Italy
event: March 28 – In Italy a ship full of weapons and ammunition explodes in the port of Naples, killing 600.

title: Broadway theatre
event: March 31 – Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''Oklahoma!'' opens on Broadway, heralds a new era in integrated stage musicals, becomes an instantaneous stage classic, and goes on to be Broadway's longest-running musical up to that time (1948).

title: Brazil
event: April 3 – Shipwrecked steward Poon Lim is rescued by Brazilian fishermen after being adrift for 130 days.

title: Katyn massacre
event: April 13 – WWII: Radio Berlin announces the discovery by Wehrmacht of mass graves of Poles killed by Soviets in the Katyn massacre.

title: China
event: May 9–May 12 – Japanese troops carry out the Changjiao massacre in Changjiao, Hunan, China.

title: Aleutian Islands
event: May 11 – WWII: American troops invade Attu in the Aleutian Islands, in an attempt to expel occupying Japanese forces.

title: Italy
event: May 13 – WWII: German Afrika Korps and Italian troops in North Africa surrender to Allied forces.

title: Queensland
event: May 14 – The ''Australian Hospital Ship Centaur'' is sunk off the coast of Queensland, by a Japanese submarine.

title: ENIAC
event: The United States Army contracts with the University of Pennsylvania's Moore School to develop the computer ENIAC.

title: United Kingdom
event: June 1 – British Overseas Airways Corporation Flight 777, a DC-3 with registration G-AGBB, (formerly KLM PH-ALI, Ibis), on a scheduled passenger flight, is shot down over the Bay of Biscay by German Junkers Ju 88s, all 17 persons aboard perish, including the actor Leslie Howard. There is speculation that the downing was an attempt to kill British Prime Minister Winston Churchill as the Germans may have had wrong information he was aboard.

title: Argentina
event: June 4 – A military coup d'état in Argentina ousts Ramón Castillo.

title: Hashirajima
event: June 8 – WWII: Japanese battleship Mutsu was destroyed by an accidental magazine explosion in Hashirajima anchorage, killing 1,121.

title: Kolombangara
event: July 6 – WWII: Americans and Japanese fight the Battle of Kula Gulf off Kolombangara.

title: Italy
event: July 10 – WWII – Allied invasion of Sicily: The allied invasion of Axis-controlled Europe begins with landings on the island of Sicily off mainland Italy, by the Seventh United States Army and the British Eighth Army including the 1st Canadian Infantry Division.

title: Battle of Prokhorovka
event: July 12 – WWII – Battle of Prokhorovka: The Wehrmacht and the Red Army fight to a draw.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 24 – WWII: Operation Gomorrah begins: British and Canadian aeroplanes bomb Hamburg by night, those of the Americans by day. By the end of the operation in November, 9,000 tons of explosives will have killed more than 30,000 people and destroyed 280,000 buildings.

title: Italy
event: July 25 – In Italy the Gran Consiglio del Fascismo withdraws its support of Mussolini; Mussolini is arrested and the power is given to Maresciallo d'Italia Gen. Pietro Badoglio.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 28 – WWII: Operation Gomorrah – The British bomb Hamburg, causing a firestorm that kills 42,000 German civilians.

title: Motor Torpedo Boat PT-109
event: August 2 – WWII: John F. Kennedy's PT-109 is rammed by a destroyer.

title: USS Intrepid (CV-11)
event: August 4 – WWII: The ''USS Intrepid (CV-11)'' is launched.

title: Kolombangara
event: August 6 – WWII – Battle of Vella Gulf: Americans defeat a Japanese convoy off Kolombangara, as the U.S. Army drives the Japanese out of Munda airfield on New Georgia.

title: Denmark
event: August 29 – WWII: Germany dissolves the Danish government after it refuses to deal with a wave of strikes and disturbances to the satisfaction of the German authorities (see Occupation of Denmark).

title: Italy
event: September 3 – WWII: Mainland Italy is invaded by Allied forces under Bernard L. Montgomery, for the first time in the war.

title: Italy
event: United States General Dwight D. Eisenhower publicly announces the surrender of Italy to the Allies.

title: Grace University
event: September 8 – The first classes commence at Grace University.

title: Schauspielhaus Zürich
event: September 9 – Bertolt Brecht's play ''Life of Galileo'' ({{Lang-deLeben des Galilei}}) receives its first theatrical production at the Zurich Schauspielhaus.

title: Italy
event: October 13 – WWII: The new government of Italy sides with the Allies and declares war on Germany.

title: USS Tarpon (SS-175)
event: October 17 – WWII: The last commerce raider ''hilfskreuzer Michel'', was sunk off Japan by United States submarine ''Tarpon''.

title: China
event: October 18 – Chiang Kai-shek takes the oath of office as president of China.

title: Bougainville Island
event: November 1 – WWII – Operation Goodtime: United States Marines land on Bougainville in the Solomon Islands.

title: Bougainville Island
event: November 2 – WWII: In the early morning hours, American and Japanese ships fight the inconclusive Battle of Empress Augusta Bay off Bougainville.

title: Vemork
event: November 16 – WWII: After flying from Britain, 160 American bombers strike a hydro-electric power facility and heavy water factory in German-controlled Vemork, Norway.

title: USS Corvina (SS-226)
event: November 16 – WWII: A Japanese submarine sinks the surfaced U.S. submarine ''USS Corvina'' near Truk.

title: Battle of Berlin (air)
event: November 18 – WWII: The Royal Air Force opens its bombing campaign against Berlin, with 440 planes causing only light damage and killing 131. The RAF loses 9 aircraft and 53 aviators.

title: Gilbert Islands
event: November 20 – WWII: Battle of Tarawa: United States Marines land on Tarawa and Makin atolls in the Gilbert Islands and take heavy fire from Japanese shore guns.

title: France
event: Lebanon gains independence from France.

title: Deutsche Oper Berlin
event: November 23 – The Deutsche Opernhaus on Bismarckstraße in the Berlin neighborhood of Charlottenburg is destroyed. It is rebuilt in 1961 and called the Deutsche Oper Berlin.

title: New Ireland (island)
event: November 25 – WWII: Americans and Japanese fight the naval Battle of Cape St. George between Buka and New Ireland.

title: Tehran
event: November 28 – WWII – Tehran Conference: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Soviet leader Joseph Stalin meet in Tehran to discuss war strategy (on November 30 they establish an agreement concerning a planned June 1944 invasion of Europe codenamed Operation Overlord).

title: Jajce
event: November 29 – The second session of AVNOJ, the Anti-Fascist Council of National Liberation of Yugoslavia, is held in Jajce, Bosnia and Herzegovina, to determine the post-war ordering of the country.

title: Italy
event: December 2 – A Luftwaffe bombing raid on the harbour of Bari, Italy, sinks an American ship with a mustard gas stockpile, causing numerous fatalities (though the exact death toll is unresolved, as the bombing raid itself causes hundreds of deaths too).

title: Yugoslavia
event: WWII: In Yugoslavia, resistance leader Marshal Tito proclaims a provisional democratic Yugoslav government in-exile.

title: Bolivia
event: December 20 – A military coup is staged in Bolivia.

title: India
event: December 30 – Subhash Chandra Bose sets up a pro-Japanese Indian government at Port Blair, India.

title: China
event: WWII: The Japanese launch an offensive in central and south China.

title: London
event: Austrian-born economist Friedrich Hayek publishes his book ''The Road to Serfdom'' (in London).

title: Northwest Passage
event: Canadian Arctic explorer Henry Larsen becomes the first person to successfully navigate the Northwest Passage in both directions in a schooner. He chronicles the event in his autobiography, ''The Big Ship''. ({{ASINB000ETAS4K}}).

title: Battle of Monte Cassino
event: January 4 – WWII: The Battle of Monte Cassino begins.

title: Luzon
event: January 8 – WWII: Philippine Commonwealth troops enter the province of Ilocos Sur in Northern Luzon and attack Japanese forces.

title: San Juan Argentina
event: An earthquake hits San Juan, Argentina, killing an estimated 10,000 people in the worst natural disaster in Argentina's history.

title: Italy
event: British forces in Italy cross the Garigliano River.

title: Australia
event: Meat rationing ends in Australia.

title: Italy
event: January 22 – WWII – Operation Shingle: The Allies begin the assault on Anzio, Italy. The U.S. Army 45th Infantry Division stands their ground at Anzio against violent assaults for 4 months.

title: Marshall Islands
event: January 31 – WWII: American forces land on Kwajalein Atoll and other islands in the Japanese-held Marshall Islands.

title: Marshall Islands
event: February 1 – WWII: United States troops land in the Marshall Islands.

title: Marshall Islands
event: February 3 – WWII: United States troops capture the Marshall Islands.

title: Italy
event: February 7 – WWII: In Anzio, Italian forces launch a counteroffensive.

title: Monte Cassino
event: February 15 – WWII – Battle of Monte Cassino: The monastery atop Monte Cassino is destroyed by Allied bombing.

title: Italy
event: An anti-fascist strike begins in northern Italy.

title: Italy
event: March 2 – WWII: A train stalls inside a railway tunnel outside Salerno, Italy; 521 choke to death.

title: Estonia
event: March 6 – WWII: Soviet Army planes attack Narva, Estonia, destroying almost the entire old town.

title: Estonia
event: March 9 – WWII: Soviet Army planes attack Tallinn, Estonia.

title: Greece
event: March 12 – WWII: The Political Committee of National Liberation is created in Greece.

title: Battle of Monte Cassino
event: WWII: Battle of Monte Cassino: Allied aircraft bomb German-held monastery and stage an assault.

title: Rîbniţa
event: March 17 – WWII: The Nazis execute almost 400 prisoners, Soviet citizens and anti-fascist Romanians at Rîbniţa.

title: Italy
event: March 18 – The eruption of Mount Vesuvius in Italy kills 26 and causes thousands to flee their homes.

title: Markowa
event: In the Polish village of Markowa, German police kill Józef and Wiktoria Ulm, their 6 children and 8 Jews they were hiding.

title: Devon
event: April 28 – WWII: 749 American troops are killed in Exercise Tiger at Start Bay, Devon, England.

title: India
event: May 5 – WWII: Mohandas Gandhi is released in India.

title: Monte Cassino
event: Battle of Monte Cassino: The Germans evacuate Monte Cassino and Allied forces take the stronghold after a struggle that claimed 20,000 lives.

title: West Loch Disaster
event: May 24 – WWII: Six LSTs are accidentally destroyed and 163 men killed in Pearl Harbor's West Loch Disaster.

title: Monaco
event: May 30 – Princess Charlotte Louise Juliette Louvet Grimaldi of Monaco, heir to the throne, resigns from her rights in favor of her son Prince Rainier Louis Henri Maxence Bertrand Grimaldi, later reigning Prince Rainier III of Monaco.

title: France
event: June 1 – WWII: The BBC transmits a coded message (the first line of the poem Chanson d'automne by Paul Verlaine) to underground resistance fighters in France, warning that the invasion of Europe is imminent.

title: France
event: June 2 – WWII: The provisional French government is established.

title: United Kingdom
event: More than 1,000 British bombers drop 5,000 tons of bombs on German gun batteries on the Normandy coast in preparation for D-Day.

title: France
event: June 6 – WWII – Battle of Normandy: ''Operation Overlord'', commonly known as D-Day, commences with the landing of 155,000 Allied troops on the beaches of Normandy in France. The Allied soldiers quickly break through the Atlantic Wall and push inland, in the largest amphibious military operation in history. This operation helps liberate France from Germany, and also weakens the Nazi hold on Europe.

title: Santorini
event: The steamer ''Danae'' ({{lang-elΔανάη}}) carrying 350 Cretan Jews and 250 Cretans on the first leg of their way to Auschwitz was sunk without survivors off the shore of Santorini.

title: Finland
event: June 9 – WWII: Soviet leader Joseph Stalin launches the Vyborg–Petrozavodsk Offensive against Finland, with the intent of defeating Finland before pushing for Berlin.

title: France
event: June 10 – WWII: 642 men, women and children are killed in the Oradour-sur-Glane Massacre in France.

title: Saipan
event: Battle of Saipan: The United States invades Saipan.

title: Denmark
event: June 17 – Iceland declares full independence from Denmark.

title: Nordic countries
event: June 25 – WWII: The Battle of Tali-Ihantala (the largest battle ever in the Nordic countries) begins between Finnish and Soviet troops.

title: The Holocaust
event: June 29 – The Holocaust – The deportation of Hungarian Jews to Auschwitz and other Nazi concentration camps begins.

title: Bretton Woods New Hampshire
event: July 1 – The United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference begins at Bretton Woods, New Hampshire.

title: Minsk
event: Soviet troops liberate Minsk.

title: United Kingdom
event: Battle of Imphal: Japanese forces call off their advance, ending the battle in a British victory.

title: Hartford circus fire
event: Hartford circus fire: More than 100 children die in one of the worst fire disasters in the history of the United States.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 9 – WWII: British and Canadian forces capture Caen.

title: Vilnius
event: July 13 – WWII: Vilnius is liberated.

title: Halifax Harbour
event: The largest convoy of the war embarks from Halifax, Nova Scotia under Royal Canadian Navy protection.

title: Guam
event: Battle of Guam: American troops land on Guam (the battle ends August 10).

title: The Holocaust
event: August 4 – The Holocaust: A tip from a Dutch informer leads the Gestapo to a sealed-off area in an Amsterdam warehouse, where they find Jewish diarist Anne Frank and her family.

title: Warsaw
event: The Holocaust: Polish insurgents liberate a German labor camp in Warsaw, freeing 348 Jewish prisoners.

title: Italy
event: The Allies capture Florence, Italy.

title: France
event: Operation Pluto: The world's first undersea oil pipeline is laid between England and France.

title: Belfort Gap
event: August 15 – WWII: Operation Dragoon lands Allies in southern France. The U.S. Army 45th Infantry Division participates in its fourth assault landing at St. Maxime, spearheading the drive for the Belfort Gap.

title: Liberation of Paris
event: August 19 – WWII: An insurrection starts in Paris.

title: Buchenwald concentration camp
event: 168 captured allied airmen, including Phil Lamason, accused of being terror fliers by the Gestapo, arrive at Buchenwald concentration camp.

title: Tsushima Maru
event: August 22 – WWII: Tsushima Maru, a Japanese unmarked passenger/cargo ship, is sunk by torpedoes launched by the submarine USS Bowfin off Akuseki-jima, killing 1,484 civilians including 767 schoolchildren.

title: Liberation of Paris
event: Liberation of Paris: The Allies enter Paris, successfully completing Operation Overlord.

title: The Holocaust
event: The Holocaust: Diarist Anne Frank and her family are placed on the last transport train from Westerbork to Auschwitz, arriving 3 days later.

title: Brussels
event: September 3 – WWII: The Allies liberate Brussels.

title: United Kingdom
event: The British 11th Armored Division liberates the city of Antwerp in Belgium.

title: London
event: September 7 – WWII: The Belgian government in exile returns to Brussels from London.

title: London
event: London is hit by a V2 rocket for the first time.

title: Dijon
event: September 11 – WWII: Northern and Southern France invasion forces link up near Dijon.

title: Estonia
event: September 20 – WWII: Jüri Uluots, prime minister in capacity of president of Estonia, escapes to Sweden; 2 days later, Tallinn is taken by the Red Army.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 9 – WWII: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Soviet Union Premier Joseph Stalin begin a 9-day conference in Moscow to discuss the future of Europe.

title: The Holocaust
event: October 10 – The Holocaust/Porajmos: 800 Gypsy children are systematically murdered at the Auschwitz death camp.

title: Latvia
event: October 13 – WWII: Riga, the capital of Latvia, is taken by the Red Army.

title: Philippines
event: American forces land in Red Beach in Palo, Leyte as General Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines with Philippine Commonwealth president Sergio Osmeña, and  Armed Forces of the Philippines Generals Basilio J. Valdes and Carlos P. Romulo.

title: Battle of Leyte
event: United States and Filipino troops with Filipino guerillas begin the Battle of Leyte.

title: Philippines
event: American forces land on the beaches in Dulag, Leyte, the Philippines, accompanied by Filipino troops entering the town, and fiercely opposed by the Japanese occupation forces.

title: Philippines
event: October 23 – WWII: The Naval Battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philippines begins (lasts until October 26).

title: USS Tang (SS-306)
event: October 25 – WWII: Medal of Honor winning submarine ace Richard O'Kane becomes a prisoner of war when ''Tang'' is sunk in the Formosa Strait.

title: Kirkenes
event: October 25 – WWII: The Red Army liberates Kirkenes, the first town in Norway to be liberated.

title: Bergen-Belsen concentration camp
event: October 30 – The Holocaust – Anne Frank and sister Margot Frank are deported from Auschwitz to the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp.

title: Library of Congress
event: October 30 – ''Appalachian Spring'', a ballet by Martha Graham with music by Aaron Copland, debuts at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C., with Graham in the lead role.

title: Manus Island
event: November 10 – WWII: Ammunition ship ''Mount Hood'' disintegrated from accidental detonation of 3800 tons of cargo in the Seeadler Harbor fleet anchorage at Manus Island.  Twenty-two small boats were destroyed, 36 nearby ships damaged, 432 men killed and 371 more injured.United States Naval Institute month=February  year=1963}}<

title: Church of the Eremitani
event: November 11 – WWII  An Allied bombing destroys the  frescoes by Andrea Mantegna and other Italian masters in the Renaissance Ovetari Chapel, Church of the Eremitani, Padua, northern Italy

title: United Kingdom
event: November 27 – RAF Fauld explosion: Between 3,450 and 3,930 tons (3,500 and 4,000 tonnes) of ordnance explodes at an underground storage depot in Staffordshire, England, leaving about 75 dead and a crater 120 metres (400 ft) deep and 1,200 metres (0.75 miles) across, one of the largest non-nuclear explosions in history and the largest on UK soil.After The Battlevolume=18pages=35-40issn=0306-154X}}<

title: USS Archer-Fish (SS-311)
event: November 29 – WWII: Submarine ''Archer-Fish'' sinks aircraft carrier {{ShipJapanese aircraft carrierShinano2}}.  ''Shinano'' was the largest aircraft carrier built to that date, and remained through the twentieth century the largest ship ever sunk by a submarine.

title: Greece
event: December 3 – WWII: Fighting breaks out between Communists and royalists in newly liberated Greece, eventually leading to a full-scale Greek Civil War.

title: Philippines
event: December 13 – Battle of Mindoro: United States, Australian and Philippine Commonwealth troops land in Mindoro Island, the Philippines.

title: English Channel
event: December 15 – A private airplane carrying bandleader Glenn Miller disappears in heavy fog over the English Channel while flying to Paris.

title: Malmedy massacre
event: December 17 – WWII: German troops carry out the Malmedy massacre.

title: Estonia
event: December 19 – The entire territory of Estonia is taken by the Red Army.

title: English Channel
event: December 24 – WWII: Troopship ''Leopoldville'' is sunk in the English Channel by German submarine U-486.  The ship was carrying reinforcements to the battle of the bulge and 763 soldiers of the 66th Infantry Division (United States) drown.

title: Battle of Leyte
event: December 31 – WWII: Battle of Leyte: Thousands of Japanese Imperial forces are killed in action, in a significant Filipino and Allied military victory.

title: Bergen-Belsen concentration camp
event: March – Anne Frank, dies in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp, Lower Saxony, Germany of typhus.

title: Interpol
event: May – For all practical purposes the ICPC ceases to exist (recreated on June 3, 1946).

title: North America
event: Saskatchewan Government Insurance, the first state-owned automobile insurance company in North America, is created.

title: Denmark
event: Denmark recognizes independent Iceland.

title: Berklee College of Music
event: The Berklee College of Music is founded in Boston.

title: Canadian Memorial Chiropractic College
event: The Canadian Memorial Chiropractic College, the first chiropractic college in Canada, initiates its four year doctoral program.

title: Mayo Clinic
event: At the Mayo Clinic, streptomycin is first used to treat tuberculosis.

title: Chalk River Ontario
event: The first nuclear reactor outside of the U.S. is completed in Chalk River, Ontario.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: High-altitude, west-to-east winds across the Pacific Ocean (discovered by the Japanese in 1942 and by U.S. Army Air Forces in 1944) are dubbed the ''jet stream''.

title: Klamath Falls Oregon
event: The first geothermal milk pasteurization is done in Klamath Falls, Oregon.

title: Australia
event: January 5 – Australia recognizes the new pro-Soviet government of Poland.

title: United Kingdom
event: January 7 – British General Bernard Montgomery holds a press conference at Zonhoven describing his supporting role at the Battle of the Bulge.

title: Warsaw
event: WWII: The Soviet Union occupies Warsaw.

title: The Holocaust
event: The Holocaust: The evacuation of Auschwitz concentration camp begins.

title: The Holocaust
event: January 27 – The Holocaust: The Red Army liberates the Auschwitz and Birkenau death camps.

title: China
event: January 28 – WWII: Supplies begin to reach China over the newly reopened Burma Road.

title: Baltic Sea
event: January 30 – The ''Wilhelm Gustloff'', with over 10,000 mainly civilian Germans from Gotenhafen (Gdynia) in the Gdansk Bay, is sunk by three torpedoes from the ''Soviet submarine S-13'' in the Baltic Sea; 7,700 die.

title: Philippines
event: January 30 – Raid at Cabanatuan: 121 American soldiers and 800 Filipino guerrillas free 813 American POWs from the Japanese-held camp at Cabanatuan City, Philippines.

title: Yalta Conference
event: February 2 – WWII: President Franklin D. Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill leave to meet with Soviet leader Joseph Stalin at the Yalta Conference.

title: Manila
event: Battle of Manila: United States forces capture Manila from the Japanese Imperial Army.

title: Yalta Conference
event: February 4–February 11 – WWII: President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom Winston Churchill and Soviet leader Joseph Stalin hold the Yalta Conference.

title: Manila
event: February 7 – WWII: General Douglas MacArthur returns to Manila.

title: SS General von Steuben
event: February 10 – WWII: The ''SS General von Steuben'' is sunk by the Soviet submarine S-13.

title: Philippines
event: American and Filipino ground forces land on Corregidor Island in the Philippines.

title: Iwo Jima
event: February 19 – WWII – Battle of Iwo Jima: About 30,000 United States Marines land on Iwo Jima.

title: Battle of Iwo Jima
event: Battle of Iwo Jima: A group of United States Marines reach the top of Mount Suribachi on the island and are photographed raising the American flag. The photo, ''Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima'' (taken by Joe Rosenthal), later wins a Pulitzer Prize.

title: Philippines
event: The capital of the Philippines, Manila, is liberated by combined American and Filipino ground troops.

title: Intramuros
event: American and Filipino troops enter Intramuros, Manila.

title: Poznań
event: The German garrison in Poznań capitulates to Red Army and Polish troops.

title: Bucharest
event: February 28 – In Bucharest, had place a violent demonstration, during it the bolsevic group opened fire straight to the army and the protestatars. This eveniment permitted that A.I.Vâșinski, The adjunct minister of URSS and president of Allied Control Commission for Romania, place the Groza government in the lead of Romania.

title: Yalta Conference
event: March 1 – Franklin D. Roosevelt gives what will be his last address to a joint session of Congress, reporting on the Yalta Conference.

title: Bachem Ba 349
event: March 2 – The Bachem Ba 349 Natter is launched from Stetten am kalten Markt. The Natter is the first manned rocket, developed as anti-aircraft weapon. The launch fails and the pilot dies.History International

title: Finland
event: Previously neutral Finland declares war on the Axis powers.

title: Philippines
event: United States and Filipino troops take Manila, Philippines.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 4 – In the United Kingdom, Princess Elizabeth, later to become Queen Elizabeth II, joins the British Army as a driver.

title: Rhine
event: March 7 – WWII: American troops seize the bridge over the Rhine River at Remagen, Germany and begin to cross.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: March 8 – Josip Broz Tito forms a government in Yugoslavia.

title: Bombing of Tokyo
event: March 9–March 10 – WWII: American B-29 bombers attack Japan with incendiary bombs; Tokyo is fire-bombed, killing 100,000 citizens.

title: Battle of Iwo Jima
event: March 16 – WWII: The Battle of Iwo Jima unofficially ends, with small pockets of guerrilla resistance persisting past the official conclusion of the battle.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 21 – WWII: British troops liberate Mandalay, Burma.

title: Cairo
event: March 22 – The Arab League is formed with the adoption of a charter in Cairo, Egypt.

title: Rhine
event: WWII – Operation Varsity: Two airborne divisions capture bridges across the Rhine River to aid the Allied advance.

title: Battle of Iwo Jima
event: March 26 – WWII: The Battle of Iwo Jima officially ends, with the mopping up of the remaining areas of Japansese resistance.

title: DePaul University
event: March 29 – The Clash of Titans: George Mikan and Bob Kurland duel at Madison Square Garden. OSU defeats DePaul 52–44.

title: Vienna
event: Soviet Union forces invade Austria and take Vienna.

title: Yalta Conference
event: Alger Hiss congratulated in Moscow for his part in bringing positions of Western powers and the USSR closer to each other at the Yalta Conference.

title: Okinawa Prefecture
event: April 1 – WWII – Battle of Okinawa: United States troops land on Okinawa.

title: Ohrdruf concentration camp
event: April 4 – WWII: American troops liberate their first Nazi concentration camp, Ohrdruf death camp in Germany.

title: Nazi Germany
event: April 6 – WWII: Sarajevo is liberated from the Nazi Germany and Nazi Croatia (German puppet state) by the Yugoslav Partisans.

title: Operation Ten-Go
event: The Japanese battleship ''Yamato'' is sunk {{convert200mikm}} north of Okinawa while enroute on a suicide mission.

title: East Prussia
event: WWII: The Battle of Königsberg, in East Prussia, ends.

title: Buchenwald concentration camp
event: The Allied Forces liberate the Nazi concentration camp, Buchenwald.

title: Visoko Bosnia and Herzegovina
event: Visoko is liberated by the 7th, 9th and 17th Krajina Brigades from the Tenth Division of Yugoslav Partisan forces.

title: Warm Springs Georgia
event: April 12 – United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt (1933–1945) dies suddenly at Warm Springs, Georgia; Vice President Harry S. Truman becomes the 33rd President, serving until 1953.

title: Bergen-Belsen concentration camp
event: April 15 – The Bergen-Belsen concentration camp is liberated.

title: Italy
event: April 17 – Brazilian forces liberate the town of Montese, Italy, from German forces.

title: Okinawa Prefecture
event: April 18 – American war correspondent Ernie Pyle is killed by Japanese machine gun fire on the island of Ie Shima off Okinawa.

title: Broadway theatre
event: April 19 – Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''Carousel'', a musical play based on Ferenc Molnár's ''Liliom'', opens on Broadway and becomes their second long-running stage classic.

title: Ponte Pietra (Verona)
event: April 24 – Retreating German troops destroy all the bridges over the Adige in Verona, including the historical Ponte di Castelvecchio and Ponte Pietra.

title: Italy
event: Brazilian forces liberate the commune of Fornovo di Taro, Italy, from German forces.

title: Führerbunker
event: Adolf Hitler marries his long-time mistress Eva Braun in a closed civil ceremony in the Berlin Führerbunker.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: Troops of the Yugoslav 4th Army, together with the Slovene 9th Corpus NOV, enter Trieste.

title: Neuengamme concentration camp
event: The concentration camp ''Neuengamme'' near Hamburg is liberated by the British Army.

title: Italy
event: Ezra Pound, the poet and author, is arrested by American soldiers in Italy for treason.

title: Mauthausen-Gusen concentration camp
event: The US 11th Armored Division liberates the prisoners of Mauthausen concentration camp, including Simon Wiesenthal.

title: France
event: May 7 – WWII: General Alfred Jodl signs unconditional surrender terms at Reims, France, ending Germany's participation in the war. The document takes effect the next day.

title: Nazi Germany
event: V-E Day (Victory in Europe, as Nazi Germany surrenders) commemorates the end of WWII in Europe, with the final surrender being to the Soviets in Berlin, attended by representatives of the Western Powers.

title: Carinthia (state)
event: The British 8th Army, together with Slovene partisan troops and a motorized detachment of the Yugoslav 4th Army, arrives in Carinthia and Klagenfurt.

title: Neuengamme concentration camp
event: Alderney, an annex of the concentration camp ''Neuengamme'', is liberated.

title: United Kingdom
event: May 23 – President of Germany Karl Dönitz and Chancellor of Germany Count Lutz Graf Schwerin von Krosigk are arrested by British forces at Flensburg. They are respectively the last German Head of state and Head of government until 1949.

title: London
event: May 28 – William Joyce (Lord Haw-Haw) is captured. He is later charged with high treason in London for his English-language wartime broadcasts on German radio, convicted, and then hanged in January 1946.

title: Iran
event: May 30 – The Iranian government demands that all Soviet and British troops leave the country.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: June 12 – The Yugoslav Army leaves Trieste, leaving the New Zealand Army in control.

title: Red Square
event: June 24 – WWII: A victory parade is held in Red Square in Moscow.

title: Carpathian Ruthenia
event: June 29 – Czechoslovakia cedes Carpathian Ruthenia to the Soviet Union.

title: Philippines
event: July 5 – WWII: The Philippines are declared liberated.

title: Trinity (nuclear test)
event: July 16 – The Trinity Test, the first of an atomic bomb, using about six kilograms of plutonium, succeeds in unleashing an explosion equivalent to that of 19 kilotons of TNT.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 26 – Winston Churchill resigns as the United Kingdom's Prime Minister after his Conservative Party is soundly defeated by the Labour Party in the 1945 general election. Clement Attlee becomes the new Prime Minister.

title: Philippine Sea
event: July 30 – WWII: The heavy cruiser USS ''Indianapolis'' is hit and sunk by torpedoes from the ''Japanese submarine I-58'' in the Philippine Sea. Some 900 survivors jump into the sea and are adrift for up to four days. Nearly 600 die before help arrives. Captain Charles B. McVay III of the cruiser is later court-martialed and convicted.

title: Little Boy
event: August 6 – WWII: Atomic bombing of Hiroshima: A United States B-29 Superfortress, the Enola Gay, drops an atomic bomb, codenamed Little Boy, on Hiroshima, Japan, at 8:15 a.m. (local time).

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: August 7 – President Harry Truman announces the successful bombing of Hiroshima with the atomic bomb, while returning from the Potsdam Conference aboard the U.S. Navy heavy cruiser {{USSAugustaCA-31}} in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Nagasaki
event: A United States B-29 Bomber, the Bockscar, drops an atomic bomb, codenamed Fat Man, on  Nagasaki, Japan, at 11:02 a.m. (local time).

title: Israel
event: August 13 – The Zionist World Congress approaches the British government to discuss the founding of the country of Israel.

title: International Civil Aviation Organization
event: August 15 – Provisional International Civil Aviation Organization founded as a specialized agency of the United Nations.

title: Korea
event: Korea gains independence following Japan's surrender.

title: George Orwell
event: The novel ''Animal Farm'' by George Orwell is first published by Fredric Warburg in London.

title: USS Missouri (BB-63)
event: WWII ends: The final official surrender of Japan is accepted by the Supreme Allied Commander, General Douglas MacArthur, and Fleet Admiral Chester Nimitz for the United States, and delegates from Australia, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, The Netherlands, China, and others from a Japanese delegation led by Mamoru Shigemitsu, on board the American battleship USS ''Missouri'' in Tokyo Bay (but in Japan August 14 is recognized as the day the Pacific War ended).

title: Wake Island
event: September 4 – WWII: Japanese forces surrender on Wake Island after hearing word of their country's surrender.

title: Yokohama
event: Iva Toguri D'Aquino, a Japanese-American suspected of being wartime radio propagandist Tokyo Rose, is arrested in Yokohama.

title: North America
event: The Russian code clerk Igor Gouzenko comes forward with numerous documents implicating the Soviet Union in numerous spy rings in North America: both in the United States and in Canada.

title: Korea
event: American troops occupy southern Korea, while the Soviet Union occupies the north, with the dividing line being the 38th parallel of latitude. This arrangement proves to be the indirect beginning of a divided Korea.

title: Borneo
event: The Batu Lintang camp in Sarawak, Borneo is liberated by Australian forces.

title: Singapore
event: September 12 – The Japanese Army formally surrenders to the British in Singapore.

title: India
event: September 20 – Mohandas Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru demand that all British troops depart India.

title: Operation Backfire (WWII)
event: October 1–October 15 – Operation Backfire: Three A4 rockets are launched near Cuxhaven in order to show Allied forces the rocket with liquid fuel.

title: Argentina
event: October 17 – A massive number of people, headed for CGT, gather in the Plaza de Mayo in Argentina to demand Juan Perón's release. This is known to the Peronists as the ''Día de la lealtad'' (Loyalty Day). It is considered the founding day of Peronism.

title: France
event: October 21 – Women's suffrage: Women are allowed to vote in France for the first time.

title: Brazil
event: Getúlio Vargas resigns as the president of Brazil.

title: New York City
event: At Gimbels Department Store in New York City, the first ballpoint pens go on sale at $12.50 each.

title: Palace of Justice (Nuremberg)
event: November 20 – The Nuremberg Trials begin: Trials against 24 Nazi war criminals of WWII start at the Nuremberg Palace of Justice.

title: 1945 Balochistan earthquake
event: November 28 – An earthquake in Balochistan (Pakistan) causes a tsunami and kills 4,000.

title: Josip Broz Tito
event: The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is declared (this day is celebrated as Republic Day until the 1990s). Marshal Tito is named president.

title: ENIAC
event: Assembly of the world's first general purpose electronic computer, the Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer (ENIAC), is completed. It covers {{convert1800sqftm2}} of floor space. The first set of calculations is run on the computer.

title: Brazil
event: General Eurico Gaspar Dutra is elected president of Brazil.

title: Banque de France
event: French banks (Banque de France, BNCI, CNEP, Crédit Lyonnais, and Société Générale) nationalized.

title: Flight 19
event: December 5 – A flight of USAF Avenger torpedo bombers known as Flight 19 disappears on a training exercise.

title: Quebec
event: Female suffrage is enacted in Belgium, Romania, Yugoslavia, Argentina and the Canadian province of Quebec.

title: Argentina
event: Eva Perón tours Spain, Italy and France on behalf of Argentina, a circuit called the Rainbow Tour.

title: Binghamton University
event: Binghamton University is founded.

title: Ziegfeld Theatre
event: January 6 – A revised and streamlined revival of Kern and Hammerstein's  ''Show Boat'' opens on Broadway at the Ziegfeld Theatre.

title: London
event: The first meeting of the United Nations is held in London.

title: Mahabad
event: January 22 – Iran: Qazi Muhammad declares the independent people's Republic of Mahabad at the Chuwarchira Square in the Kurdish city of Mahabad. He is the new president, Hadschi Baba Scheich is the prime minister.

title: Central Intelligence Agency
event: January 29 – The Central Intelligence Group is established (the CIA in 1947).

title: Republic of Macedonia
event: January 31 – Yugoslavia's new constitution, modeling the Soviet Union, establishes 6 constituent republics (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia and Slovenia).

title: Bank of England
event: The Bank of England is nationalized.

title: University of Pennsylvania
event: ENIAC (for Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer), an early general-purpose electronic computer, is unveiled at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Philadelphia
event: February 28 – In Philadelphia, General Electric strikers and police clash.

title: Iran
event: British troops withdraw from Iran according to treaty; the Soviets do not.

title: North Vietnam
event: Ho Chi Minh is elected President of North Vietnam.

title: Iron Curtain
event: March 5 – In his speech at Westminster College, in Fulton, Missouri, Winston Churchill talks about the ''Iron Curtain''.

title: France
event: March 6 – Vietnam War: Ho Chi Minh signs an agreement with France which recognizes Vietnam as an autonomous state in the Indochinese Federation and the French Union.

title: Burnden Park
event: Bolton Wanderers stadium disaster at Burnden Park, Bolton, England, 33 killed and hundreds amongst the injured

title: India
event: March 15 – Clement Attlee promises independence to India as soon as they can agree on a constitution.

title: Switzerland
event: The Soviet Union and Switzerland resume diplomatic relations.

title: France
event: French Guiana, Guadeloupe, Martinique and Réunion become overseas départements of France.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 22 – The United Kingdom grants Transjordan, as it is then known, its independence; 3 years later the country changes its name to Jordan.History Channel International<

title: Hawaii
event: A 14-meter high tsunami strikes Hilo and Laupāhoehoe on the Big Island of Hawaii; 173 are killed, thousands injured.

title: Malayan Union
event: The Malayan Union is formed.

title: Singapore
event: Singapore becomes a Crown colony.

title: Philippines
event: April 3 – Japanese Lt. General Masaharu Homma is executed outside Manila, the Philippines for leading the Bataan Death March.

title: France
event: April 17 – Syria's independence from France is officially recognized.

title: International Court of Justice
event: The inaugural session of the International Court of Justice (ICJ) occurs.

title: Yugoslavia
event: The United States recognizes Josip Broz Tito's government in Yugoslavia.

title: UNESCO
event: April 28 – Pestalozzi Children’s Village (''Kinderdorf Pestalozzi'') established at Trogen in Switzerland to accommodate and educate orphans of World War II according to Pestalozzian principles.UNESCOdate=1948-10-01accessdate=2010-11-23}}<

title: Tokyo
event: April 29 – Trial against war criminals begin in Tokyo; the accused include Hideki Tojo, Shigenori Togo and Hiroshi Oshima.

title: Western Australia
event: May 1 – At least 800 Indigenous Australian pastoral workers walk off the job in Northwest Western Australia, starting one of the longest industrial strikes in Australia.

title: India
event: Nehru is elected leader of the Congress Party in India.

title: White Sands Missile Range
event: The first V-2 rocket is successfully launched at the White Sands Missile Range.

title: Los Alamos New Mexico
event: May 21 – At the Los Alamos Laboratory, Dr. Louis Slotin saves his coworkers but receives a fatal dose of ionizing radiation (the incident is initially classified).

title: Greece
event: May 31 – A Greek referendum supports the return of the monarchy.

title: Italy
event: June 2 – In a referendum, Italians decide to turn Italy from a monarchy into a republic. Women vote for the first time.

title: Interpol
event: June 3 – The Interpol organization re-founded, telegraphic address “Interpol” adopted.

title: New York City
event: June 6 – The Basketball Association of America is formed in New York City.

title: Italy
event: June 10 – Italy is declared a republic.

title: Portugal
event: June 13 – Humbert II of Italy leaves the country and goes into exile in Portugal; Alcide de Gasperi becomes head of state.

title: Detroit River
event: A tornado on the Detroit River kills 17.

title: Bikini Atoll
event: July 1 – Nuclear testing: Operation Crossroads, a series of nuclear weapon tests conducted by the United States at Bikini Atoll in Micronesia, is initiated by detonation of ''Able'' at an altitude of 520 feet (158 m).

title: Ankara University
event: Ankara University is founded in Turkey.

title: Philippines
event: After over 381 years of Western dominance, the Philippines attains full independence.

title: King David Hotel
event: July 22 – King David Hotel bombing: The Irgun bombs the King David Hotel (headquarters of the British civil and military administration) in Jerusalem, killing 90.

title: Operation Crossroads
event: Nuclear testing: In the first underwater test of the atomic bomb, the surplus USS ''Saratoga'' is sunk near Bikini Atoll in the Pacific Ocean, when the United States detonates the ''Baker'' device during Operation Crossroads.

title: New Jersey
event: At Club 500 in Atlantic City, New Jersey, Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis stage their first show as a comedy team.

title: Georgia (U.S. state)
event: In the last mass lynching in the United States, a mob of white men shoot and kill two African-American couples near Moore's Ford Bridge in Georgia.

title: Disneyland
event: August 3 – Holiday World, originally called ''Santa Claus Land'', opens to the public. It became the 1st themed park preceding Disneyland by 9 years.

title: 1946 Dominican Republic earthquake
event: August 4 – The 1946 Dominican Republic earthquake (magnitude 8.0) hits the northern Dominican Republic, killing 100, and leaving 20,000 homeless.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 1 – Mensa International is founded in the United Kingdom.

title: France
event: October 13 – France adopts the constitution of the Fourth Republic.

title: Nuremberg Trials
event: October 15 – Nuremberg Trials: Hermann Göring, founder of the Gestapo and recently convicted Nazi war criminal, poisons himself hours before his scheduled execution.

title: Nuremberg Trials
event: Nazi War criminals convicted in the Nuremberg Trials are executed by hanging in a gymnasium in the Nuremberg Palace of Justice premises.

title: Long Island
event: The United Nations' first meeting in Long Island is held.

title: UNESCO
event: November 4 – UNESCO established as a specialized agency of the United Nations.

title: WWT Slimbridge
event: The Slimbridge Wetland Reserve opens in England.

title: United Kingdom
event: November 17 – Eight British servicemen are killed in Jerusalem by Jewish nationalists.

title: Oxford Union
event: November 22 – Tony Benn is elected as Treasurer of the Oxford Union.

title: India
event: November 27 – Cold War: Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru appeals to the United States and the Soviet Union to end nuclear testing and to start nuclear disarmament, stating that such an action would save humanity from the ultimate disaster.

title: Winecoff Hotel
event: December 7 – A fire at the Winecoff Hotel in Atlanta, United States kills 119.

title: Francisco Franco
event: The United Nations severs relations with Franco's Spain and recommends that member countries sever diplomatic relations.

title: Iran
event: A communist government takes power in Tabriz, Iranian Azerbaijan Province.

title: 1946 Nankaidō earthquake
event: At least 1,362 people are killed in an earthquake and associated tsunami in Japan.

title: Havana
event: December 22 – The Havana Conference begins between U.S. organized crime bosses in Havana, Cuba.

title: France
event: December 24 – France's Fourth Republic is founded.

title: Las Vegas Strip
event: The Flamingo Hotel opens on the Las Vegas Strip.

title: Hollywood
event: The House Un-American Activities Committee begins its investigations into communism in Hollywood.

title: Argentina
event: Women's suffrage is granted in Argentina.

title: Dead Sea
event: In a cave in and around the Wadi Qumran (near the ruins of the ancient settlement of Khirbet Qumran, on the northwest shore of the Dead Sea), several tall pottery jars containing leather scrolls are discovered, which later become known as the '''Dead Sea scrolls'''.History Channel International<

title: Nigeria
event: Nigeria gains limited autonomy.

title: Los Angeles
event: January 15 – Elizabeth Short, an aspiring actress nicknamed the Black Dahlia, is found brutally murdered in a vacant lot in Los Angeles.  The case remains unsolved to this day.

title: France
event: January 16 – Vincent Auriol is inaugurated as president of France.

title: Greece
event: January 19 – A shipwreck near Athens, Greece kills 392.

title: Hong Kong
event: January 25 – A Philippine plane crashes in Hong Kong, with $5 million worth of gold and money.

title: Snag Yukon
event: The lowest air temperature in North America (-63 degrees Celsius) is recorded in Snag, Yukon Territory.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: February 10 – In Paris, France, peace treaties are signed between the World War II Allies and Italy, Hungary, Romania, Bulgaria, and Finland. Italy cedes most of Istria to the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.

title: Sikhote-Alin
event: A meteor creates an impact crater in Sikhote-Alin, in the Soviet Union.

title: New York City
event: February 21 – In New York City, Edwin Land demonstrates the first instant camera, his Polaroid Land Camera, to a meeting of the Optical Society of America.

title: Casablanca
event: The United States grants France a military base in Casablanca.

title: 228 Incident
event: In Taiwan, civil disorder is put down with large loss of civilian lives.

title: France
event: March 4 – Treaty of Dunkirk (coming into effect 8 September) signed between the United Kingdom and France providing for mutual assistance in the event of attack.

title: Newport News Virginia
event: March 6 – The ''USS Newport News'', the first completely air-conditioned warship, is launched in Newport News, Virginia.

title: Centralia Illinois
event: March 25 – A coal mine explosion in Centralia, Illinois, kills 111 miners.

title: Madagascar
event: March 29 – A rebellion against French rule erupts in Madagascar.

title: Mahabad
event: March 31 – The leaders of the Kurdish People's Republic of Mahabad, the second Kurdish state in the history of Iran, are hanged at the Chuwarchira Square in Mahabad after that country had been overrun by the Iranian army.

title: International Civil Aviation Organization
event: April 4 – International Civil Aviation Organization

title: Texas City Texas
event: April 16 – Texas City Disaster: An Ammonium nitrate cargo of the ''SS Grandcamp'' explodes in Texas City, Texas, killing 552, injuring 3,000, causing 200 lost, and destroying 20 city blocks.

title: Greece
event: May 22 – Cold War: In an effort to fight the spread of Communism, President Harry S. Truman signs an Act of Congress that implements the Truman Doctrine. This Act grants $400 million in military and economic aid to Turkey and Greece.

title: Portugal
event: June 15 – The Portuguese government orders 11 military officers and 19 university professors who were accused of revolutionary activity to resign.

title: Puget Sound
event: Seaman Harold Dahl claims to have seen six UFOs near Maury Island in Puget Sound, Washington. On the next morning, Dahl reports the first modern so-called Men in Black encounter.

title: Washington (U.S. state)
event: June 24 – Kenneth Arnold makes the first widely-reported UFO sighting near Mount Rainier, Washington.

title: India
event: July 17 – The Indian passenger ship ''Ramdas'' is capsized by a cyclone at Mumbai, India, with 625 people killed.

title: Central Intelligence Agency
event: July 26 – Cold War: U.S. President Harry S. Truman signs the National Security Act of 1947 into law, creating the Central Intelligence Agency, the Department of Defense, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the National Security Council.

title: ENIAC
event: July 29 – After being shut down on November 9, 1946, for a refurbishment, the ENIAC computer, the world's first electronic digital computer, is turned back on again. It then remains in continuous operation until October 2, 1955.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: Thor Heyerdahl's balsa wood raft, the ''Kon-Tiki'', smashes into the reef at Raroia in the Tuamotu Islands after a 101 day, 4,300 mile, voyage across the Eastern Pacific Ocean, proving that pre-historic peoples could hypothetically have traveled to the Central Pacific islands from South America.

title: India
event: The Muslim majority region formed by the Partition of India gain independence from the British Empire and adopts the name '''Pakistan'''. While the transition is officially at midnight on this day, Pakistan celebrates its independence on August 14, compared with India on the 15th, because the Pakistan Standard Time is 30 minutes behind the standard time of India.

title: India
event: The greater Indian subcontinent with a mixed population of Hindus,Muslims,Sikhs,Buddhists,Jains,etc formed by the Partition of India gain independence from the British Empire and retains the name '''India'''.

title: Greece
event: August 16 – In Greece, General Markos Vafiadis takes over the government.

title: India
event: September 13 – Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru suggests the exchange of four million Hindus and Muslims between India and Pakistan.

title: Florida
event: September 17–September 21 – The 1947 Fort Lauderdale Hurricane in southeastern Florida, and also in Alabama, Mississippi, and Louisiana, causes widespread damage and kills 51 people.

title: North Yemen
event: September 30 – Pakistan and Yemen join the United Nations.

title: Kashmir
event: October 20 – A war begins in Kashmir, along the border between India and Pakistan, leading to the Indo-Pakistani War of 1947 in the following year. Also, Pakistan established diplomatic relations with the United States of America.

title: California
event: In California, the designer and airplane pilot Howard Hughes performs the maiden flight of the ''Spruce Goose'', the largest fixed-wing aircraft ever built. (The flight lasts only eight minutes, and the Spruce Goose is never flown again.)

title: Junagadh
event: November 9 – Junagadh is invaded by the Indian army.

title: Universal Postal Union
event: November 15 – Universal Postal Union (UPU) becomes a specialized agency of the United Nations (effective 1 July 1948).

title: Brussels
event: In Brussels, 15,000 people demonstrate against the relatively short sentences of Belgian Nazi criminals.

title: New Zealand
event: November 18 – The Ballantyne's Department Store fire in Christchurch, New Zealand, kills 41 people.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: Princess Elizabeth, the daughter of King George VI, marries the Duke of Edinburgh at Westminster Abbey in London, England.

title: Havana
event: November 21 – The United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment begins in Havana, Cuba. This conference ends in 1948, when its members finish the Havana Charter.

title: United Kingdom
event: November 25 – New Zealand ratifies the Statute of Westminster, and that country thus becomes independent of legislative control by the Parliament of the United Kingdom.

title: Israel
event: November 29 – The United Nations General Assembly votes to partition Palestine between Arab and Jewish regions, which results in the creation of the State of Israel.

title: National Assembly of France
event: December 4 – The French Interior Minister, Jules S. Moch, takes emergency measures against his country's rioters after six days of violent arguments in the National Assembly.

title: Iran
event: December 12 – The Iranian Royal Army takes back power in the Azerbaijan province.

title: Brandeis University
event: Brandeis University is founded.

title: Fresh Kills Landfill
event: The Fresh Kills Landfill, the world's largest, opens on Staten Island, New York.

title: Pyrenees
event: The Tunnel of Vielha is opened in the Aran Valley, Spanish Pyrenees.

title: Kazakhstan
event: Last recorded sighting of the Caspian Tiger in Kazakhstan.

title: United Kingdom
event: UK railways are nationalized to form British Railways.

title: United Kingdom
event: January 4 – Burma gains its independence from the United Kingdom.

title: Delhi
event: January 12 – Mahatma Gandhi begins his fast-unto-death in Delhi, to stop the communal violence during the Partition of India.

title: Java
event: January 17 – A truce is declared between nationalist Indonesian and Dutch troops in Java.

title: NATO
event: January 22 – British foreign secretary Bevin proposes the formation of a Western Union between Britain, France and the Benelux countries to stand up against the Soviet Union. The Treaty of Brussels is signed March 17 as a consequence, a predecessor to NATO.

title: California
event: January 29 – Plane crash at Los Gatos Creek, California kills 4 US citizens and 28 deportees, commemorated in a song by Woody Guthrie.

title: India
event: Indian pacifist and leader Mahatma Gandhi is assassinated by Nathuram Godse.

title: Switzerland
event: 1948 Winter Olympics open in St. Moritz, Switzerland.

title: Irish Free State
event: February 18 – Eamon de Valera, Irish head of government since 1932, loses power to an opposition coalition. John A. Costello is appointed Taoiseach of Éire (formerly called the Irish Free State) by President O'Kelly.

title: United Kingdom
event: Treaty of Brussels signed by Belgium, France, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom, providing for economic, social and cultural collaboration and collective self-defence.

title: California
event: The Hells Angels motorcycle gang is founded in California.

title: Singapore
event: Singapore holds its first elections.

title: Shanghai
event: A fire in a Buddhist monastery Shanghai kills 20 monks.

title: Bogotá
event: Jorge Eliécer Gaitán's assassination provokes a violent riot in Bogotá (the ''Bogotazo''), and a further 10 years of violence in all of Colombia (''La Violencia'').

title: Deir Yassin massacre
event: The Deir Yassin massacre takes place in British Mandate of Palestine.

title: Italy
event: April 18 – The first democratic general election with universal suffrage is held in Italy.

title: Burma
event: April 19 – Burma joins the United Nations.

title: Organization of American States
event: April 30 – Organization of American States (OAS) founded.

title: London
event: May 4 – Laurence Olivier's film version of ''Hamlet'' makes its world premiere in London.

title: Blackburn
event: The murder of a 3-year-old girl in Blackburn, England leads to the fingerprinting of more than 40,000 men in the city in an attempt to find the murderer.

title: Israel
event: May 15 – 1948 Arab-Israeli War: The British Mandate of Palestine is officially terminated; expeditionary forces from Egypt, Transjordan, Syria and Iraq attack Israel and clash with Israeli forces.

title: Republic of China
event: May 18 – The first Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China officially convenes in Nanking.

title: California
event: June 3 – The Palomar Observatory telescope is finished in California.

title: Mount Carmel Pennsylvania
event: June 17 – A Douglas DC-6 carrying United Air Lines Flight 624 crashes near Mount Carmel, Pennsylvania, killing all 43 people on board.

title: London
event: June 22 – The ship ''Empire Windrush'' brings a large group of Afro-Caribbean immigrants to Tilbury near London, the start of a large wave of immigration to Britain.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: The Cominform Resolution marks the beginning of the Informbiro period in Yugoslavia and the Soviet/Yugoslav split.

title: 1948 Fukui earthquake
event: 1948 Fukui earthquake strikes Fukui, Japan. 3,769 dead, 22,203 injured.

title: London
event: The first London chapter of Alcoholics Anonymous is founded.

title: Finland
event: July 24 – A great oil fire breaks out in the harbor of Naantali, Finland.

title: London
event: July 29 – The 1948 Summer Olympics begin in London, the first since the 1936

title: New York
event: July 31 – At Idlewild Field in New York, New York International Airport (later renamed John F. Kennedy International Airport) is dedicated.

title: The Oval
event: August 14 – 1948 Ashes series: The Australian batsman Don Bradman, playing his last Test cricket match, against England at The Oval, is bowled by Eric Hollies for a duck; however, The Invincibles win the match by an innings and 149 runs, and The Ashes 4-0.

title: North Korea
event: September 9 – The Democratic People's Republic of Korea is formally declared, with Kim Il-sung as prime minister.

title: 1948 Ashgabat earthquake
event: October 5 – The 1948 Ashgabat earthquake kills 110,000.

title: Donora Pennsylvania
event: October 26 – Killer smog settles into Donora, Pennsylvania.

title: Tokyo
event: November 12 – In Tokyo, an international war crimes tribunal sentences 7 Japanese military and government officials to death, including General Hideki Tojo, for their roles in World War II.

title: Israel
event: November 16 – ''Operation Magic Carpet'' to transport Jews from Yemen to Israel begins.

title: New Zealand
event: November 20 – Geoffrey B. Orbell rediscovers the Takahē, last seen 50 years previously, near Lake Te Anau, New Zealand.

title: Varsity Stadium
event: November 27 – The Calgary Stampeders defeat the Ottawa Rough Riders 12–7 before 20,013 fans at Toronto's Varsity Stadium to capture their first Grey Cup and complete the only perfect season to date in Canadian Football.

title: North Korea
event: December 26 – The last Soviet troops withdraw from North Korea

title: Negev
event: December 31 – 1948 Arab-Israeli War: Israeli troops drive the Egyptians from Negev

title: Vatican City
event: The Vatican announces that bones uncovered in its subterranean catacombs could be the apostle Peter; 19 years later, Pope Paul VI announces confirmation that the bones belong to this first saint.History Channel International.<

title: Kashmir
event: January 1 – UN sponsored ceasefire brings an end to the Indo-Pakistan War of 1947. The war results in a stalemate and the division of Kashmir, which still continues to this day.

title: New York
event: January 4 – ''RMS Caronia'' of the Cunard Line departs Southampton for New York on her maiden voyage.

title: Nevada
event: January 4–February 22 – Series of winter storms in Nebraska, Wyoming, South Dakota, Utah, Colorado and Nevada – winds of up to 72 mph – tens of thousands of cattle and sheep perish.

title: KDKA-TV
event: KDKA-TV becomes the first local, on-air television station in the US.

title: New York
event: January 17 – The first Volkswagen Beetle to arrive in the United States, a 1948 model, is brought to New York by Dutch businessman Ben Pon.  Unable to interest dealers or importers in the Volkswagen, Pon sells the sample car to pay his travel expenses.  Only two 1949 models will be sold in America that year, convincing Volkswagen chairman Heinrich Nordhoff that the car has no future in the U.S. (The VW Beetle goes on to become the greatest automobile phenomenon in American history.)

title: Israel
event: In the first Israeli election, David Ben-Gurion becomes Prime Minister.

title: Australia
event: January 26 – Australian citizenship comes into being.

title: Beijing
event: January 31 – Forces from the Communist Party of China enter Beijing.

title: Yale University
event: February 19 – Ezra Pound is awarded the first Bollingen Prize in poetry by the Bollingen Foundation and Yale University.

title: Yukon Oklahoma
event: February 22 – Grady the Cow, a 1,200-pound cow, gets stuck inside a silo on a farm in Yukon, Oklahoma and garners national media attention.

title: Shamrock Hotel
event: March 17 – The Shamrock Hotel in Houston, Texas, owned by oil tycoon Glenn McCarthy, has its grand opening.

title: Oakland California
event: March 20 – The Chicago, Burlington & Quincy, Denver & Rio Grande Western and Western Pacific railroads inaugurate the ''California Zephyr'' passenger train between Chicago and Oakland, California, as the first long distance train to feature Vista Dome cars as regular equipment.

title: Latvia
event: March 25 – An extensive deportation campaign is conducted in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. The Soviet authorities deport more than 92,000 people from the Baltics to remote areas of the Soviet Union.

title: Rockefeller Center
event: March 26 – The first half of Giuseppe Verdi's opera ''Aida'', conducted by legendary conductor Arturo Toscanini, and performed in concert (i.e. no scenery or costumes), is telecast by NBC, live from Studio 8H at Rockefeller Center. The second half is telecast a week later. This is the only complete opera that Toscanini ever conducts on television.

title: James Forrestal
event: United States Secretary of Defense James Forrestal resigns suddenly.

title: Newfoundland and Labrador
event: March 31 – The former British colony of Newfoundland and Labrador joins Canada as its 10th province.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: Éire leaves the British Commonwealth and becomes the Republic of Ireland.

title: Tokyo Stock Exchange
event: The Tokyo Stock Exchange is founded.

title: NATO
event: April 4 – The North Atlantic Treaty is signed in Washington, D.C., creating the NATO defense alliance.

title: Broadway theatre
event: April 7 – Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''South Pacific'', starring Mary Martin and Ezio Pinza, opens on Broadway and goes on to become R&H's second longest-running musical. It becomes an instant classic of the musical theatre. The score's biggest hit is the song ''Some Enchanted Evening''.

title: San Marino California
event: April 8 – Kathy Fiscus, 3 and 1/2 years old, dies from falling down an abandoned well in San Marino, California.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: April 18 – Éire formally becomes the Republic of Ireland.

title: Yangtze River
event: April 20 – The Royal Navy frigate ''HMS Amethyst (U16)'' goes up the Yangtze River to evacuate British Commonwealth refugees escaping the advance of Mao's communist forces. Under heavy fire it runs aground off Rose Island. After an aborted rescue attempt on April 26 it anchors 10 miles upstream. Negotiations with the communist forces to let the ship leave drag on for weeks.

title: Nanjing
event: April 23 – Chinese communist troops take Nanjing.

title: India
event: India issues the London Declaration, enabling it (and, thereafter, any other nation) to remain in the British Commonwealth despite becoming a republic, creating the position of 'Head of the Commonwealth', and renaming the organisation as the 'Commonwealth of Nations'.

title: Aurora Quezon
event: Former Philippine First Lady Aurora Quezon, 61, is assassinated while en route to dedicate a hospital in memory of her late husband; her daughter and 10 others are also killed.

title: Monaco
event: May 9 – Rainier III of Monaco becomes Prince of Monaco, upon the death of his maternal grandfather Louis II.

title: Israel
event: Israel is admitted to the United Nations as its 59th member.

title: National Security Agency
event: The AFSA (predecessor of the NSA) is established.

title: Taiwan
event: The Kuomintang regime declares Taiwan under martial law.

title: James Forrestal
event: May 22 – After two months in Bethesda Naval Hospital, James Forrestal commits suicide, under circumstances that seem suspicious to many.

title: Mahabodhi Temple
event: June 6 – With the passage of the Bodh Gaya Temple Act by the Indian government, Mahabodhi Temple is restored to partial Buddhist control.

title: Federal Bureau of Investigation
event: Red Scare: Celebrities including Helen Keller, Dorothy Parker, Danny Kaye, Fredric March, John Garfield, Paul Muni and Edward G. Robinson are named in an FBI report as Communist Party members.

title: George Orwell
event: George Orwell's book ''Nineteen Eighty-Four'' is published.

title: North Carolina
event: June 19 – Glenn Dunnaway wins the inaugural NASCAR race at Charlotte Speedway, a 3/4 mile oval in Charlotte, North Carolina, but is disqualified due to illegal springs. Jim Roper is declared the official winner.

title: United Kingdom
event: Dock workers strike in the UK.

title: South Africa
event: Apartheid: The ''South African Citizenship Act'' suspends the granting of citizenship to British Commonwealth immigrants after 5 years and imposes a ban on mixed marriages.

title: Cape Horn
event: July 11 – ''Pamir'' is the last ''commercial'' sailing ship to round Cape Horn under sail alone.

title: Israel
event: July 20 – Israel and Syria sign a truce to end their 19-month war.

title: Wusong
event: July 31 – Captain Kerans of the ''HMS Amethyst'' decides to make a break after nightfall, under heavy fire from the Chinese People's Liberation Army on both sides of the Yangtze River, and successfully rejoins the fleet at Woosung the next day.

title: Bhutan
event: August 8 – Bhutan becomes independent

title: Indianapolis
event: August 28 – The last 6 surviving veterans of the American Civil War meet in Indianapolis.

title: Nazi Germany
event: September 6 – Allied military authorities relinquish control of former Nazi Germany assets back to Germany.

title: Quebec
event: Albert Guay affair: A dynamite bomb destroys Canadian Pacific Airlines Douglas DC-3 in Quebec.

title: Portugal
event: September 13 – The Soviet Union vetoes United Nations membership for Ceylon, Finland, Iceland, Italy, Jordan and Portugal.

title: United Kingdom
event: September 19 – The United Kingdom government devalues the pound sterling from $4.03 to $2.80, leading to many other currencies being devalued.

title: National People's Congress
event: The First Plenary Session of the National People's Congress approves a design for the Flag of the People's Republic of China.

title: People's Republic of China
event: October 1 – The People's Republic of China is officially proclaimed.

title: Greece
event: October 16 – Civil war ends in Greece with a communist surrender.

title: Guangzhou
event: October 17 – Chinese communist troops take Guangzhou

title: Taiwan
event: Chinese communist troops fail to take Kinmen in the Battle of Kuningtou; their advance towards Taiwan is halted.

title: New York
event: An airliner flying from Paris to New York crashes in the Azores island of São Miguel. Among the victims are violinist Ginette Neveu and French boxer Marcel Cerdan.

title: Squaw Valley Placer County California
event: November 24 – The ski resort in Squaw Valley, California officially opens.

title: India
event: November 26 – The Indian Constituent Assembly adopts India's constitution [http://lawmin.nic.in/coi.htm].

title: Kingsway Hall
event: November 28 – Winston Churchill makes a landmark speech in support of the idea of a European Union at Kingsway Hall, London.

title: Taiwan
event: December 7 – The government of the Republic of China finishes its evacuation to Taiwan, and declares Taipei its temporary capital city.

title: Korea
event: December 15 – A typhoon strikes a fishing fleet off Korea, killing several thousand.

title: People's Republic of China
event: December 17 – Burma recognizes the People's Republic of China.

title: People's Republic of China
event: December 30 – India recognizes the People's Republic of China.

title: Tel Aviv
event: IBM Israel begins operating in Tel Aviv.

title: France
event: President Harry Truman sends United States military advisers to Vietnam to aid French forces.

title: Republic of China
event: January 6 – The United Kingdom recognizes the People's Republic of China; the Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Britain in response.

title: Israel
event: January 9 – The Israeli government recognizes the People's Republic of China.

title: Philippines
event: January 11 – Huk guerrillas manhandle the town of Hermosa, Bataan in the Philippines.

title: Thames Estuary
event: The British submarine ''Truculent'' collides with a Swedish oil tanker in the Thames Estuary and sinks; 64 die.

title: Finland
event: January 13 – Finland forms diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China.

title: Israel
event: January 23 – The Knesset passes a resolution that states Jerusalem is the capital of Israel.

title: War Office
event: January 24 – Cold War: Klaus Fuchs, German émigré and physicist, walks into London's War Office and confesses to being a Soviet spy: for 7 years, he passed top secret data on U.S. and British nuclear weapons research to the Soviet Union;History Channel International< formally charged February 2.

title: India
event: January 26 – India promulgates its constitution, forming a republic, and Rajendra Prasad is sworn in as its first president.

title: Italy
event: January 28 – Somaliland is put under Italian mandate.

title: China
event: The last Kuomintang troops surrender in mainland China.

title: New York City
event: February 8 – Payment first made by Diners Club card, in New York, first use of a charge card.

title: Wheeling West Virginia
event: February 9 – Second Red Scare: In his speech to the Republican Women's Club at the McClure Hote in Wheeling, West Virginia, Senator Joseph McCarthy accuses the United States Department of State of being filled with 205 Communists.

title: France
event: Two Viet Minh battalions attack a French base in French Indochina.

title: Finland
event: Finland recognizes Indonesia.

title: Finland
event: Juho Kusti Paasikivi is re-elected president of Finland.

title: Taiwan
event: Chiang Kai-shek resumes his duties as Chinese president after moving his government to Taipei, Taiwan.

title: Llandow air disaster
event: March 12 – A plane carrying returning rugby fans from Ireland to Wales crashes near Llandow, with the loss of 80 lives.

title: University of California Berkeley
event: March 17 – University of California, Berkeley researchers announce the creation of element 98, which they have named californium.

title: Suez Canal
event: March 22 – Egypt demands that Britain remove all its troops in the Suez Canal.

title: West Bank
event: April 24 – Jordan formally annexes the West Bank.

title: South Africa
event: Apartheid: In South Africa, the Group Areas Act is passed, formally segregating the races.

title: Denmark
event: Tollund Man is unearthed in Denmark.

title: Finland
event: May 27 – The Linnanmäki amusement park opens in Finland.

title: Nova Scotia
event: May 29 – ''St. Roch'', the first ship to circumnavigate North America, arrives in Halifax, Nova Scotia.

title: Hawaii
event: June 1–June 23 – Mauna Loa in Hawaii starts erupting.

title: Annapurna
event: June 3 – Annapurna I, 10th highest mountain in the world, is first ascended.

title: Australia
event: June 8 – Sir Thomas Blamey becomes the only Field Marshal in Australian history.

title: Parliament of South Africa
event: June 26 – The South African Parliament passes the Suppression of Communism Act, No. 44 of 1950.

title: North Korea
event: June 28 – Korean War: North Korean forces capture Seoul.

title: 1950 FIFA World Cup
event: June 29 – United States defeats England 1–0 in the 1950 FIFA World Cup.

title: 1950 FIFA World Cup
event: July 16 – Uruguay beat Brazil 2–1 to win the 1950 World Cup.

title: English Channel
event: Florence Chadwick swims across the English Channel in 13 hours, 22 minutes.

title: Brussels
event: August 6 – Monarchist demonstrations lead to a riot in Brussels.

title: Immaculate Heart of Mary Seminary
event: August 22 – The Immaculate Heart of Mary Seminary is founded in Tagbilaran City, Philippines.

title: Darlington Raceway
event: Darlington Raceway is the site of the inaugural Southern 500, the first 500-mile NASCAR race.

title: California
event: September 9 – The U.S. state of California celebrates its centennial anniversary.

title: Incheon
event: September 15 – Korean War – Battle of Inchon: Allied troops commanded by Douglas MacArthur land in Inchon, occupied by North Korea, to begin a U.N. counteroffensive.

title: People's Republic of China
event: The 1950-1951 invasion of Tibet by People's Republic of China begins.

title: Agate Pass Bridge
event: The Agate Pass Bridge opens for traffic in Washington State.

title: Tacoma Narrows Bridge
event: The second Tacoma Narrows Bridge opens.

title: People's Republic of China
event: October 19 – Korean War: The People's Republic of China enters the conflict by sending thousands of soldiers across the Yalu River

title: Australia
event: October 20 – Australia passes the Communist Party Dissolution Act, which is later struck down by the High Court.

title: Vatican City
event: Pope Pius XII witnesses The Miracle of the Sun at the Vatican and defines a new dogma of Roman Catholicism, the Munificentissimus Deus, which says that God took Mary's body into Heaven after her death (the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary).

title: Libya
event: November 18 – The United Nations accepts the formation of the Libyan National Council.

title: Battle of Chosin Reservoir
event: November 26 – Korean War: Troops from the People's Republic of China and launched a massive counterattack against South Korean and United Nations forces at the Ch'ongch'on River and the Chosin Reservoir, dashing any hopes for a quick end to the conflict.

title: Yugoslavia
event: November 28 – Greece and Yugoslavia reform diplomatic relations.

title: Singapore
event: December 11–December 13 – The Maria Hertogh riots occur in Singapore, leaving 18 dead and 173 injured.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: December 24–December 25 – Scottish nationalists take the Stone of Scone from Westminster Abbey.

title: Peak District
event: December 28 – The Peak District becomes Britain's first National Park.

title: Buchenwald concentration camp
event: January 15 – Ilse Koch, The Witch of Buchenwald, wife of the commandant of the Buchenwald concentration camp, is sentenced to life imprisonment in a court in West Germany.

title: Third Battle of Seoul
event: January 18 – Korean War: Chinese and North Korean forces captured Seoul for the second time.

title: Italy
event: January 20 – Avalanches in the Alps kill 240 and bury 45,000 for a time in Switzerland, Austria and Italy.

title: Las Vegas Nevada
event: January 27 – Nuclear testing at the Nevada Test Site begins with a 1-kiloton bomb dropped on Frenchman Flat, northwest of Las Vegas, Nevada.

title: China
event: February 1 – The United Nations General Assembly declares that China is an aggressor in the Korean War in United Nations General Assembly Resolution 498.

title: Woodbridge Township New Jersey
