event: February 6 – A Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train derails near Woodbridge Township, New Jersey, killing 85 people and injuring over 500, in one of the worst rail disasters in American history.

title: Australia
event: February 19 – Jean Lee becomes the last woman hanged in Australia, when Lee and her 2 pimps are hanged for the murder and torture of a 73-year-old bookmaker.

title: UNESCO
event: West Germany joins UNESCO.

title: Broadway theatre
event: Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''The King and I'' opens on Broadway and runs for 3 years. It's the first Rodgers & Hammerstein musical specifically written for an actress (Gertrude Lawrence). Lawrence is stricken with cancer during the run of the show and dies halfway through its run a year later. The show makes a star of Yul Brynner.

title: Greece
event: April 1 – Female suffrage begins in Greece.

title: Arbroath Abbey
event: After its removal from Westminster Abbey on Christmas Day, 1950, the Stone of Scone resurfaces on the altar of Arbroath Abbey.

title: Yokohama
event: April 24 – In Yokohama, Japan a fire on a train kills more than 100.

title: Australia
event: April 28 – Robert Menzies' Liberal Party government in Australia is re-elected for a second term.

title: Royal Festival Hall
event: King George VI opens London's Royal Festival Hall as a patron.

title: Marshall Islands
event: May 9 – Operation Greenhouse: The first  thermonuclear weapon is tested on Enewetok Atoll in the Marshall Islands, by the United States.

title: Bolivia
event: May 15 – A military coup occurs in Bolivia.

title: New York
event: May 21 – The Ninth Street Show, otherwise known as the 9th Street Art Exhibition, a gathering of a number of notable artists, marks the stepping-out of the post war New York avant-garde, collectively known as the New York School.

title: People's Republic of China
event: May 23 – The Tibetan government signs the Seventeen Point Agreement for the Peaceful Liberation of Tibet with the People's Republic of China.

title: British Columbia
event: June 15 – July 1- In New Mexico, Arizona, California, Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia, thousands of hectares of forests are destroyed in fires.

title: Battle Ground Washington
event: June 18 – Battle Ground, Washington is incorporated.

title: Ireland
event: July 1 – Judy Garland opens the first of 14 concerts in Dublin, Ireland at the Theatre Royal.

title: Kaesong
event: July 10 – Korean War: Armistice negotiations begin at Kaesong.

title: Kansas
event: The Great Flood of 1951 reaches its highest point in Northeast Kansas, culminating in the greatest flood damage to date in the Midwestern United States.

title: New York City
event: MGM's Technicolor film version of ''Show Boat'', starring Kathryn Grayson, Ava Gardner, and Howard Keel, premieres at Radio City Music Hall in New York City. The musical brings overnight fame to bass-baritone William Warfield (who sings ''Ol' Man River'' in the film).

title: Joplin Missouri
event: July 14 – In Joplin, Missouri, the George Washington Carver National Monument becomes the first United States National Monument to honor an African American.

title: Springfield Massachusetts
event: Western New England College in Springfield, Massachusetts is chartered.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 26 – Walt Disney's 13th animated film, ''Alice in Wonderland'', premieres in London, United Kingdom.

title: France
event: August 11 – René Pleven becomes Prime Minister of France.

title: New Zealand
event: September 1 – The United States, Australia and New Zealand all sign a mutual defense pact, called the ANZUS Treaty.

title: Iran
event: September 10 – The United Kingdom begins an economic boycott of Iran.

title: Greece
event: September 20 – NATO accepts Greece and Turkey as members.

title: New York
event: MGM's Technicolor musical film, ''An American in Paris'', starring Gene Kelly and Leslie Caron, premieres in New York. It was directed by Vincente Minnelli. It would go on to win 6 Academy Awards, including Best Picture.

title: Framingham Massachusetts
event: Shoppers World (one the first shopping malls in the U.S.) opens in Framingham, Massachusetts.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 6 – Malayan Emergency: Communist insurgents kill British commander Sir Henry Gurney.

title: Oklahoma
event: October 20 – The ''Johnny Bright Incident'' occurs in Stillwater, Oklahoma.

title: Italy
event: October 21 – A Storm in southern Italy kills over 100.

title: Sudan
event: October 27 – Farouk of Egypt declares himself king of Sudan, with no support.

title: Nevada
event: November 1 – The first military exercises for nuclear war, with infantry troops included, are held in the Nevada desert.

title: Argentina
event: November 11 – Juan Peron is re-elected president of Argentina.

title: The Carlu
event: November 12 – The National Ballet of Canada performs for the first time in Eaton Auditorium.

title: Italy
event: November 20 – The Po River floods in northern Italy.

title: Broadway theatre
event: November 24 – The Broadway play ''Gigi'' opens, starring little known actress Audrey Hepburn as the lead character.

title: Lebanese University
event: December 3 – The Lebanese University is founded in Lebanon.

title: Tucumcari New Mexico
event: December 13 – A water storage tank collapses in Tucumcari, New Mexico, resulting in 4 deaths, and 200 buildings destroyed.

title: India
event: December 16 – Salar Jung Museum is opened to the public by Prime Minister of India Jawaharlal Nehru.

title: Ontario
event: December 20 – A chartered C46 Curtis Commando crash lands in Cobourg, Ontario Canada; all on board survived.

title: Italy
event: Libya becomes independent from Italy.

title: Nordic countries
event: The Nordic Council agrees to the unrestricted transport of people, goods and services throughout the Nordic Countries.

title: Indiana
event: The National Prohibition Foundation is incorporated in Indiana.

title: Finland
event: Saynatsalo Town Hall in Finland, designed by Alvar Aalto, is completed.

title: France
event: The influential multistorey residential building, Unité d'Habitation in Marseille, France, designed by Le Corbusier, is completed.

title: American Embassy School
event: The American Embassy School of New Delhi is founded.

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: February 2 – A tropical storm forms just north of Cuba moving northeast. The storm makes landfall in southern Florida the next day. It is the earliest reported landfall from a tropical storm, and the earliest formation of a tropical storm on record in the Atlantic basin.

title: Ontario
event: King George VI of the United Kingdom dies aged 56 after a long illness. He is succeeded by his daughter Princess Elizabeth, who is on a visit to Kenya. She is simultaneously proclaimed Queen of Canada at Rideau Hall, Ottawa, Ontario.

title: London
event: February 7 – Elizabeth II is proclaimed Queen of the United Kingdom at St. James's Palace, London, England.

title: St. George's Chapel Windsor Castle
event: February 15 – The funeral of King George VI takes place at St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle.

title: NATO
event: February 18 – Turkey joins the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: United Kingdom
event: Winston Churchill scraps UK compulsory national Identity Cards.

title: UNESCO
event: February 21 – In Dhaka, East Pakistan (present-day Bangladesh) police open fire on a procession of students, killing 4 people and starting a country-wide protest which leads to the recognition of Bengali as one of the national languages of Pakistan. The day is later declared International Mother Language Day by UNESCO.

title: United Kingdom
event: February 26 – United Kingdom Prime Minister Winston Churchill announces that the United Kingdom has an atomic bomb.

title: Réunion
event: March 15 – March 16 – 73 inches (1,870 mm) of rain falls in Cilaos, Réunion, the most rainfall ever in one day.

title: Israel
event: In the Hague Tribunal, Israel demands reparations worth $3 billion from Germany.

title: West Ice
event: West Ice accidents: During a severe storm in the West Ice, east of Greenland, 78 seal hunters on 5 Norwegian seal hunting vessels perish without a trace.

title: Battle of Nanri Island
event: April 11 – Battle of Nanri Island: The Republic of China seizes the island from the Peoples' Republic of China.

title: Bolivia
event: Bolivia National Revolution: A universal vote enables indigenous peoples  and women to vote, nationalizes mines and enacts agrarian reform.

title: Nevada
event: April 23 – A nuclear test is held in the Nevada desert.

title: New York City
event: April 29 – Lever House officially opens at 390 Park Avenue in New York City, heralding a new age of commercial architecture in the United States. Designed by Gordon Bunshaft of Skidmore, Owings and Merrill, it is the first International Style skyscraper.

title: London
event: May 2 – The first passenger jet flight route between London and Johannesburg.

title: North Pole
event: May 3 – U.S. lieutenant colonels Joseph O. Fletcher and William P. Benedict land a plane at the geographic North Pole.

title: India
event: May 13 – Pandit Nehru forms his first government in India.

title: Israel
event: May 15 – Diplomatic relations are established between the governments of Israel and Japan at the level of legations.

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: May 18 – Ann Davison becomes the first woman to single-handedly sail the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Black Sea
event: Navigation opens on the Volga-Don Canal, connecting the Caspian Sea basin with that of the Black Sea.

title: USS Nautilus (SSN-571)
event: The keel is laid for the U.S. nuclear submarine USS ''Nautilus''.

title: France
event: Myxomatosis introduced to Europe on the French estate of Dr. Paul Armand Delille.

title: Malayan Union
event: June 26 – The Pan-Malayan Labour Party is founded in Malaya, as a union of statewise labour parties.

title: Finland
event: June 29 – Finnish contestant Armi Kuusela wins the title of Miss Universe.

title: Finland
event: July 19 – August 3 – The 1952 Summer Olympics are held in Helsinki, Finland.

title: Argentina
event: July 26 – In Argentina, Maria Eva Duarte de Perón, known as Evita,  dies of cancer at the age of 33. She was Perón's wife and a recognized union and social activist, promulgating the female vote in 1951.

title: Republic of China
event: August 5 – The Treaty of Taipei between Japan and the Republic of China goes into effect, to officially end the Second Sino-Japanese War.

title: Devon
event: August 16 – Lynmouth, North Devon, England is devastated by floods; 34 die.

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: August 26 – A British passenger jet makes a return crossing of the Atlantic Ocean in the same day.

title: Israel
event: August 27 – Reparation negotiations between West Germany and Israel end in Luxembourg: Germany will pay 3 billion Deutsche Marks.

title: Finland
event: August 30 – The last Finnish war reparations are sent to the Soviet Union.

title: Grenzlandring
event: August 31 – The Grenzlandring racetrack closes in Wegberg, Germany.

title: University of Minnesota
event: September 2 – Dr. C. Walton Lillehei and Dr. F. John Lewis perform the first open-heart surgery at the University of Minnesota.

title: Quebec
event: September 6 – Television debuts in Canada as the CBC in Montreal, Quebec airs.

title: European Parliament
event: September 10 – European Parliamentary Assembly (from Mar 1962, European Parliament) opens.

title: Korea
event: Negotiations for a ceasefire in Korea are postponed.

title: Beekman (Panhellenic) Tower
event: October 12 – The Gamma Sigma Sigma National Service Sorority is founded in New York City at Panhellenic Tower.

title: New York City
event: October 14 – The United Nations begins work in the new United Nations building in New York City, designed by Le Corbusier and Oscar Niemeyer.

title: London
event: October 16 – ''Limelight'' opens in London; writer/actor/director/producer Charlie Chaplin arrives by ocean liner; in transit his re-entry permit to the USA is revoked by J. Edgar Hoover.

title: Barbados
event: Alain Bombard begins to sail from the Canary Islands to Barbados in 65 days; he reaches them December 23.

title: Kenya
event: October 20 – Martial law is declared in Kenya due to the Mau Mau uprising.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: November 1 – Nuclear testing: Operation Ivy: The United States successfully detonates the first hydrogen bomb, codenamed Mike, at Eniwetok Atoll in the Marshall Islands in the central Pacific Ocean, with a yield of 10.4 megatons.

title: Kamchatka Peninsula
event: An 8.25 Richter scale earthquake hits the Kamchatka Peninsula.

title: National Security Agency
event: The U.S. National Security Agency is founded.

title: Kenya
event: November 18 – Jomo Kenyatta is arrested in Kenya for an alleged connection to the Mau Mau uprising.

title: New Zealand
event: A fireball crashes in a backyard in Havelock North, New Zealand.{{Citation neededdate=February 2007}}

title: Los Angeles
event: The first official passenger flight over the North Pole is made from Los Angeles to Copenhagen.

title: London
event: November 25 – Agatha Christie's murder-mystery play ''The Mousetrap'' opens at the Ambassadors Theatre in London; as of 2007, it continues next door at the St. Martin's Theatre, and remains the longest continuously running production of a play in history.

title: Korea
event: November 29 – Korean War: U.S. President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower fulfills a political campaign promise, by traveling to Korea to find out what can be done to end the conflict.

title: Denmark
event: The ''New York Daily News'' carries a front page story announcing that Christine Jorgensen, a transsexual woman in Denmark, has become the recipient of the first successful sexual reassignment operation.

title: London
event: December 4 – Great Smog of 1952: A killer fog descends on London (in the process coining the word Smog, for smoke and fog).

title: Ohio
event: December 14 – The first successful surgical separation of Siamese twins is conducted in Mount Sinai Hospital, Cleveland, Ohio.

title: Israel
event: December 26 – Joseph Ivor Linton, the first Israeli Minister Plenipotentiary in Japan, presents his credentials to the Japanese Emperor.

title: Burma
event: January 6 – The first Asian Socialist Conference opens in Rangoon, Burma.

title: Estonia
event: January 12 – Estonian émigrés found a government in exile in Oslo.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: Marshal Josip Broz Tito is chosen President of Yugoslavia.

title: Central Intelligence Agency
event: The CIA-sponsored Robertson Panel first meets to discuss the UFO phenomenon.

title: Broadway theatre
event: January 22 – ''The Crucible'', a drama by Arthur Miller, opens on Broadway.

title: Kenya
event: January 24 – Mau Mau Uprising: Rebels in Kenya kill the Ruck family (father, mother and six-year-old son).

title: Wandsworth (HM Prison)
event: January 28 – Derek Bentley is executed for murder in HM Prison Wandsworth.

title: Irish Sea
event: January 31–February 1 – The North Sea flood of 1953 kills 1,835 people in the southwestern Netherlands (especially Zeeland), 307 in the United Kingdom and several hundred at sea, including 133 on the ferry ''Princess Victoria'' in the Irish Sea.

title: Israel
event: The Soviet Union breaks diplomatic relations with Israel.

title: Denmark
event: February 13 – Transsexual Christine Jorgenson returns to New York after successful sexual reassignment surgery in Denmark.

title: Georgia (U.S. state)
event: February 19 – Georgia approves the first literature censorship board in the United States.

title: Yugoslavia
event: Greece, Turkey, and Yugoslavia sign the Balkan Pact.

title: Library of Congress
event: Joseph Stalin suffers a stroke after an all-night dinner with Soviet Union interior minister Lavrenty Beria and future premiers Georgi Malenkov, Nikolai Bulganin and Nikita Khrushchev. The stroke paralyzes the right side of his body and renders him unconscious until his death on March 5.Library of Congress accessdate=9 August 2010}}<

title: Windsor Castle
event: Bernard Freyberg, 1st Baron Freyberg is made deputy constable and lieutenant governor of Windsor Castle.

title: Nevada
event: March 17 – The first nuclear test of Operation Upshot-Knothole is conducted in Nevada, with 1,620 spectators at 3.4 km (2.1 miles).

title: Kenya
event: March 25 – 26 – ''Lari Massacre'' in Kenya: Mau Mau rebels kill up to 150 Kikuyu natives.

title: United Kingdom
event: Ian Fleming publishes his first James Bond novel, ''Casino Royale'' in the United Kingdom.

title: Rogers Dry Lake
event: May 18 – At Rogers Dry Lake, Californian Jackie Cochran becomes the first woman to break the sound barrier (in a F-86 Sabrejet at an average speed of 652.337 miles-per-hour).

title: Westminster Abbey
event: June 2 – Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II at Westminster Abbey.

title: Technical Services Staff
event: CIA Technical Services Staff head Sidney Gottlieb approves of the use of LSD in a MKULTRA subproject.

title: Worcester Massachusetts
event: Flint-Worcester Tornadoes: A tornado spawned from the same storm system as the Flint tornado hits in Worcester, Massachusetts, killing 94.

title: Yugoslavia
event: June 16 – The Soviet Union and Yugoslavia form diplomatic relations.

title: East Berlin
event: June 17 – Workers Uprising: In East Germany, the Soviet Union orders a division of troops into East Berlin to quell a rebellion.

title: France
event: July 5 – The European Economic Community holds its first assembly in Strasbourg, France.

title: Moncada Barracks
event: July 26 – Fidel Castro and his brother lead a disastrous assault on the Moncada Barracks, preliminary to the Cuban Revolution.

title: Arizona
event: July 26 – The Short Creek Raid is carried out on a polygynous Mormon sect in Arizona.

title: North Korea
event: July 27 – The Korean War ends: United Nations Command (Korea) (United States), People's Republic of China, North Korea sign an armistice agreement.

title: Greece
event: August 12 – A magnitude 7.2 earthquake totally devastates most of the Ionian Sea islands, in Greece's worst natural disaster in centuries.

title: France
event: August 13 – 4 million workers go on strike in France to protest austerity measures.

title: California
event: August 17 – The first planning session of Narcotics Anonymous is held in Southern California (see October 5).

title: 1953 Iranian coup d'état
event: August 19 – Cold War: The CIA helps to overthrow the government of Mohammed Mossadegh in Iran, and retain Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi on the throne (see Operation Ajax).

title: Corsica
event: The French government ousts King Mohammed V of Morocco and exiles him to Corsica.

title: France
event: August 25 – The general strike ends in France.

title: China
event: September 5 – The United Nations rejects the Soviet Union's suggestion to accept China as a member.

title: United Kingdom
event: September 26 – Rationing of cane sugar ends in the UK.

title: British Guiana
event: The Guyanese constitution is suspended.

title: New York
event: October 12 – The play ''The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial'' opens at Plymouth Theatre, New York.

title: DWWX-TV
event: October 23 – The Philippines' DZAQ-TV3 (now ABS-CBN) makes its initial telecast, becoming Asia's first commercial television broadcaster.

title: Israel
event: November 5 – David Ben-Gurion resigns as prime minister of Israel.

title: France
event: November 9 – Cambodia becomes independent from France.

title: Dien Bien Phu
event: November 29 – French paratroopers take Dien Bien Phu.

title: Uganda
event: November 30 – Edward Mutesa II, the ''kabaka'' (king) of Buganda, is deposed and exiled to London by Sir Andrew Benjamin Cohen, Governor of Uganda.

title: Iran
event: December 2 – The United Kingdom and Iran reform diplomatic relations.

title: New York City
event: December 8 – U.S. president Dwight D. Eisenhower delivers his Atoms for Peace address to the UN General Assembly in New York City.

title: New Zealand
event: December 24 – Tangiwai disaster: A railway bridge collapses at Tangiwai, New Zealand, sending a fully loaded passenger train into the Whangaehu River; 151 are killed.

title: Amami Islands
event: December 25 – Amami Islands are returned to Japan after 8 years of United States Military occupation.

title: New Zealand
event: New Zealand inventor Sir William Hamilton invents the world's first water pump-jet engine, later named the Hamilton Jet.

title: New York City
event: New York City Ballet founding balletmaster George Balanchine's production of ''The Nutcracker'' is staged for the first time in New York City, and it became a  tradition there, still being performed annually as of 2010.

title: Kenya
event: January 15 – Mau Mau leader Waruhiu Itote is captured in Kenya.

title: Yugoslavia
event: January 17 – In Yugoslavia, Milovan Djilas, one of the leading members of the League of Communists of Yugoslavia, is relieved of his duties.

title: France
event: January 25 – The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union meet at the Berlin Conference.

title: Australia
event: February 3 – Queen Elizabeth II becomes the first reigning monarch to visit Australia.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: U.S. officials announce that a hydrogen bomb test has been conducted on Bikini Atoll in the Pacific Ocean.

title: Finland
event: March 12 – Finland and Germany officially end their state of war.

title: Dien Bien Phu
event: March 13 – French troops begin the battle against the Viet Minh in Dien Bien Phu.

title: Madison Square Garden (1925)
event: March 19 – Joey Giardello knocks out Willie Tory at Madison Square Garden, in the first televised boxing prize fight to be shown in color.

title: Battle of Dien Bien Phu
event: March 23 – In Vietnam, the Viet Minh capture the main airstrip of Dien Bien Phu. The remaining French Army units there are partially isolated.

title: WKAQ-TV
event: March 28 – Puerto Rico's first television station, ''WKAQ-TV'', commences broadcasting.

title: Battle of Dien Bien Phu
event: March 29 – A C-47 transport with the French nurse Genevieve de Galard on board is wrecked on the runway at Dien Bien Phu.

title: Ontario
event: March 30 – The first operational subway line in Canada opens in Toronto, Ontario.

title: Colorado
event: April 1 – The U.S. Congress and President Dwight D. Eisenhower authorize the founding of the United States Air Force Academy in Colorado

title: Australia
event: April 3 – Vladimir Petrov defects from the Soviet Union and asks for political asylum in Australia.

title: France
event: May 7 – Vietnam War: The Battle of Dien Bien Phu ends in a French defeat (the battle began on March 13).

title: Philippines
event: May 8 – Asian Football Confederation (AFC) was formed in Manila, Philippines.

title: Madrid
event: May 15 – Latin Union (Unión Latina) created by Convention of Madrid, member countries belong to the five Romance languages: Italian, French, Spanish, Portuguese and Romanian.

title: Australia
event: The Petrov Royal Commission in Australia begins its inquiry.

title: Australia
event: May 29 – Robert Menzies's government is re-elected for a 4th term in Australia.

title: Switzerland
event: June 15 – The UEFA (Union of European Football Associations) is formed in Basel, Switzerland.

title: France
event: June 18 – Pierre Mendès-France becomes prime minister of France.

title: Obninsk
event: The world's first atomic power station opens at Obninsk, near Moscow.

title: Australia
event: July 10 – Peter Thomson becomes the first Australian to win the British Open Golf Championship.

title: Silverstone Circuit
event: Juan Fangio, the Argentine driver for German Grand Prix team Mercedes-Benz, makes a new fastest lap of the Silverstone Circuit with an average speed of 100.35 mph, the previous record being 100.16 mph.

title: North Vietnam
event: July 21 – First Indochina War: The Geneva Conference sends French forces to the south, and Vietnamese forces to the north, of a ceasefire line, and calls for elections to decide the government for all of Vietnam by July 1956. Failure to abide by the terms of the agreement leads to the establishment de facto of regimes of North Vietnam and South Vietnam, and the Vietnam War.

title: K2
event: July 31 – Italian mountaineers Lino Lacedelli and Achille Compagnoni become the first successfully to reach the summit of the Himalayan peak K2.

title: Quebec
event: August 6 – Emilie Dionne, one of the Dionne Quintuplets, dies of asphyxiation following an epileptic seizure at Sainte Agathe, Quebec. She was the first of the five to perish, and three of them lived into the 21st Century.

title: Brazil
event: August 24 – The Brazilian president, Getulio Vargas, commits suicide after being accused of involvement in a  conspiracy to murder a Brazilian Air Force officer.

title: Philippines
event: September 6 – The SEATO treaty is signed in Manila, Philippines.

title: Bangkok
event: September 8 – The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) is established in Bangkok, Thailand.

title: Chlef
event: September 9 – An earthquake centered on the city of Orleansville, Algeria kills 1,500 and leaves thousands homeless.

title: AFL Grand Final
event: September 25 – The Footscray Football Club wins their first Australian Football League Grand Final.

title: Tsugaru Strait
event: September 26 – The Japanese ferry ''Toya Maru'' sinks during a typhoon in the Tsugaru Strait. More than 1,100 people are killed.

title: North Vietnam
event: Vietnam War: The Viet Minh takes control of North Vietnam.

title: North Carolina
event: October 15 – Hurricane Hazel makes U.S. landfall; it is the only recorded Category 4 hurricane to strike as far north as North Carolina.

title: Texas Instruments
event: October 18 – Texas Instruments announces the development of the first transistor radio.

title: NATO
event: West Germany joins NATO.

title: United Kingdom
event: Paris Agreement sets up the Western European Union to implement the Treaty of Brussels (1948) providing for mutual self-defence and other collaboration between Belgium, France, West Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom.

title: Italy
event: October 25 – Landslides caused by heavy rains hit Salerno, Italy, killing about 300.

title: France
event: October 31 – Algerian War of Independence: The Algerian National Liberation Front begins a revolt against French rule.

title: Tokyo
event: November 3 – The first ''Godzilla'' movie premieres in Tokyo, Japan.

title: Burma
event: November 5 – Japan and Burma sign a separate peace treaty in Rangoon, to end their formal state of war.

title: Arlington National Cemetery
event: November 10 – U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower dedicates the USMC War Memorial (Iwo Jima memorial) in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: New York Harbor
event: November 12 – The main immigration port-of-entry in New York Harbor at Ellis Island closes.

title: Sylacauga Alabama
event: November 30 – In Sylacauga, Alabama, a four kilogram piece of the Hodges Meteorite crashes through the roof of a house and badly bruises a napping woman, in the first documented case of an object from outer space hitting a person.

title: France
event: December 24 – Laos gains full independence from France.

title: Strömsund Bridge
event: Strömsund Bridge in Sweden completed, the first significant cable-stayed bridge of the modern era.

title: North America
event: North America: 186,884,000

title: Panama City
event: January 2 – José Antonio Remón Cantera, president of Panama, is assassinated at a race track in Panama City.

title: New York City
event: January 7 – Marian Anderson is the first African American singer to perform at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City.

title: Republic of China
event: January 18–January 20 – Battle of Yijiangshan Islands: The Chinese Communist People's Liberation Army seizes the islands from the Republic of China (Taiwan).

title: The Pentagon
event: January 22 – The Pentagon announces a plan to develop ICBMs (intercontinental ballistic missiles) armed with nuclear weapons.

title: Sutton Coldfield rail crash
event: January 23 – Sutton Coldfield rail crash kills 17 near Birmingham, England.

title: Presidium of the Supreme Soviet
event: January 25 – Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union announces the end of the war between the USSR and Germany, which began during World War II in 1941.

title: People's Republic of China
event: January 28 – United States Congress authorizes President Dwight D. Eisenhower to use force to protect Formosa from the People's Republic of China.

title: Taiwan
event: February 10 – Seventh Fleet of the United States Navy helps the Republic of China evacuate Chinese Nationalist army and residents from the Tachen Islands to Taiwan.

title: Yokohama
event: February 16 – Nearly 100 die in a fire at a home for the elderly in Yokohama, Japan.

title: Montgomery Alabama
event: March 2 – Claudette Colvin (a fifteen year old African American girl) refuses to give up her seat on a bus in Montgomery, Alabama, to a white woman after the driver demands it. She is carried off the bus backwards whilst being kicked and handcuffed and harassed on the way to the police station.

title: Jackson Tennessee
event: March 5 – WBBJ-TV signs on the air in the Jackson, Tennessee, with WDXI as its initial call-letters, to expanded American commercial television in mostly-rural areas.

title: Montreal
event: March 17 – The Richard Riot occurs in Montreal.

title: KXTV
event: March 19 – KXTV of Stockton, California, signs on the air in the United States, being the 100th commercial television station in this country.

title: Taiwan
event: April 11 – The Taiwanese Kuomintang sabotage the ship ''Kashmir Princess'', killing 16 but failing to assassinate the People's Republic of China leader, Zhou Enlai.

title: Inland Sea
event: May 11 – Japanese National Railways' ferry ''Shiun Maru'' sinks after collision with sister ship ''Uko Maru'' in thick fog off Takamatsu, Shikoku, in the Seto Inland Sea of Japan; 166 passengers (many children) and two crew are killed. This event is influential in plans to construct the Akashi-Kaikyō Bridge (built 1986-98).

title: 1955 Le Mans disaster
event: June 11 – Le Mans disaster: eighty-three people are killed and at least 100 are injured after two race cars collide in the 1955 24 Hours of Le Mans.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 13 – Ruth Ellis (born 1926) is hanged for murder in London, becoming the last woman ever to be executed in the United Kingdom.

title: Anaheim California
event: July 17 – The largest Live Television Broadcast at the time showed the preview of Disneyland Theme Park in Anaheim, California.

title: Anaheim California
event: The Disneyland Theme Park opens to the public in Anaheim, California.

title: Arco Idaho
event: The first nuclear-generated electrical power is sold commercially, partially powering the town of Arco, Idaho.

title: Lockheed Constellation
event: July 27 – El Al Flight 402 from Vienna, Austria to Tel Aviv-Yafo via Istanbul is shot down over Bulgaria. All 58 passengers and crewmen aboard the Lockheed Constellation airplane are killed.

title: Spring City Tennessee
event: August 22 – Eleven schoolchildren are killed when their school bus is hit by a freight train in Spring City, Tennessee.

title: Istanbul
event: September 6 – Istanbul Pogrom: Istanbul's Greek minority is the target of a government-sponsored pogrom.

title: United Kingdom
event: September 22 – Independent Commercial Television (ITV) begins broadcasting in the United Kingdom.

title: James Dean
event: September 23 – Alec Guinness meets the actor James Dean. Guinness supposedly has a premonition of Dean's death.

title: Cholame California
event: September 30 – Actor James Dean is killed when his automobile collides with another car at a highway junction near Cholame, California. Dean is just 24 years old.

title: United Kingdom
event: Cardiff is announced as the capital city of the principality of Wales, within the United Kingdom.

title: Longmont Colorado
event: November 1 – A time bomb explodes in the cargo hold of United Airlines Flight 629, a Douglas DC-6B airliner flying above Longmont, Colorado, killing all 39 passengers and 5 crew members on board.

title: Rimutaka Tunnel
event: November 3 – The five-and-one-half-mile long Rimutaka Railroad tunnel opens in New Zealand.

title: Montgomery Alabama
event: The Montgomery Improvement Association is formed in Montgomery, Alabama, by Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and other Black ministers to coordinate a Black people's boycott of all city buses.

title: New York
event: The Tappan Zee Bridge in New York opens to traffic.

title: Portugal
event: Albania, Austria, Bulgaria, Cambodia, Finland, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Jordan, Laos, Libya, Nepal, Portugal, Romania, Spain, and Sri Lanka join the United Nations simultaneously, after several years of morotorium on admitting new members that began during the Korean War.

title: London
event: August – The exhibition ''This Is Tomorrow'' opens at Whitechapel Art Gallery in London.

title: Sudan
event: January 1 – The Anglo-Egyptian Condominium ends in Sudan.

title: Porkkala
event: January 25–January 26 – Finnish troops reoccupy Porkkala after Soviet troops vacate its military base. Civilians can return February 4.

title: Italy
event: January 26 – The 1956 Winter Olympic Games open in Cortina d'Ampezzo, Italy.

title: International Civil Aviation Organization
event: March 1 – The International Air Transport Association finalizes a draft of the Radiotelephony spelling alphabet for the International Civil Aviation Organization.

title: France
event: March 2 – Morocco declares its independence from France.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: 96 U.S. Congressmen sign the Southern Manifesto, a protest against the 1954 Supreme Court ruling (''Brown v. Board of Education'') desegregating public education.

title: New York City
event: March 15 – The Broadway musical ''My Fair Lady'' opens in New York City.

title: Rotterdam
event: March 19 – At age 48, Dutch boxer Bep van Klaveren contests his last match in Rotterdam.

title: France
event: March 20 – Tunisia gains independence from France.

title: Chew Valley Lake
event: April 17 – Queen Elizabeth II inaugurates Chew Valley Lake.

title: Corfu (city)
event: April 18 – Maria Desylla-Kapodistria is elected mayor of Corfu and becomes the first female mayor in Greece.

title: Portsmouth
event: British diver Lionel Crabb dives into Portsmouth harbor to investigate a visiting Soviet cruiser and vanishes.

title: Grace Kelly
event: Actress Grace Kelly marries Rainier III, Prince of Monaco.

title: Israel
event: Austria and Israel form diplomatic relations. {{noMention}}

title: Lhotse
event: May 18 – Lhotse (main), the fourth highest mountain, is first ascended.

title: Switzerland
event: May 24 – The first Eurovision Song Contest is broadcast from Lugano, Switzerland. The winning song is ''Refrain'' by Lys Assia (music by Géo Voumard, text by Émile Gardaz).

title: India
event: May 25 – India announces the institution of diplomatic relations with Spain (still under Franco's rule)

title: Singapore
event: June 6 – In Singapore, chief minister David Marshall resigns after the breakdown of talks about internal self government in London.

title: Eindhoven
event: June 15 – Eindhoven University of Technology is founded in Eindhoven, The Netherlands.

title: House of Commons of the United Kingdom
event: MP Sydney Silverman's bill for the abolition of the death penalty in the UK passes the British House of Commons.

title: Poznań 1956 protests
event: Labour riots in Poznań, Poland, are crushed with heavy loss of life. Soviet troops fire at a crowd that protests high prices,  killing 53.

title: Arizona
event: June 30 – A TWA Lockheed Constellation and United Airlines Douglas DC-7 collide in mid-air over the Grand Canyon in Arizona, killing all 128 people aboard both aircraft in the deadliest civil aviation disaster to date; the accident leads to sweeping changes in the regulation of cross-country flight and air traffic control over the United States.

title: House of Lords
event: July 10 – The British House of Lords defeats the abolition of the death penalty.

title: New York City
event: July 24 – At New York City's Copacabana Club, Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis perform their last comedy show together (their act started on July 25, 1946).

title: SS Andrea Doria
event: July 25 – 72 kilometers (45 miles) south of Nantucket Island, the Italian ocean liner SS ''Andrea Doria'' sinks after colliding with the Swedish ship SS ''Stockholm'' in heavy fog, killing 51.

title: Suez Canal
event: July 26 – Egyptian leader Gamal Abdel Nasser nationalizes the Suez Canal sparking international condemnation.

title: Old Trafford Cricket Ground
event: July 31 – Cricket: Jim Laker sets an extraordinary record at Old Trafford in the fourth Test between England and Australia, taking 19 wickets in a first class match (the previous best was 17).

title: Marcinelle
event: August 8 – 262 miners die in a fire in a coal mine in Marcinelle, Belgium.

title: UNESCO
event: Finland joins UNESCO.

title: Lockheed Constellation
event: The Lockheed L-1649A Starliner makes its first flight.

title: India
event: October 14 – Dr. B. R. Ambedkar, Indian Untouchable leader, converts to Buddhism along with 385,000 followers (see Neo-Buddhism).

title: Granma (yacht)
event: Fidel Castro and Che Guevara depart from Tuxpan, Veracruz, Mexico, enroute to Santiago de Cuba aboard the yacht ''Granma'' with 82 men.

title: Suez Canal
event: Suez Crisis: Israel invades the Sinai Peninsula and push Egyptian forces back toward the Suez Canal.

title: Tangier
event: Tangier Protocol: The international city Tangier is reintegrated into Morocco.

title: Suez Canal
event: October 31 – Suez Crisis: The United Kingdom and France begin bombing Egypt to force the reopening of the Suez Canal.

title: Kerala
event: November 1 – The States Reorganisation Act of India reforms the boundaries and names of Indian states. Two new states Kerala and Karnataka were formed.

title: Israel
event: November 7 – Suez Crisis: The United Nations General Assembly adopts a resolution calling for the United Kingdom, France, and Israel to withdraw their troops from Arab lands immediately.

title: Ankara
event: November 15 – Middle East Technical University is founded in Ankara, Turkey.

title: Josip Broz Tito
event: November 20 – In Yugoslavia, former prime minister Milovan Djilas is arrested after he criticizes Josip Broz Tito.

title: Australia
event: November 22 – The 1956 Summer Olympics begin in Melbourne, Australia.

title: France
event: November 28 – Roger Vadim's drama film ''And God Created Woman'' released in France (as ''Et Dieu… créa la femme'') propels Brigitte Bardot into the public spotlight as a sex kitten.

title: Granma (yacht)
event: Fidel Castro and his followers land in Cuba in the boat ''Granma''.

title: Brooklyn
event: A pipe bomb planted by George Metesky explodes at the Paramount Theater in Brooklyn, injuring 6 people.

title: Great Britain
event: December 19 – John Bodkin Adams is arrested for the murder of 2 patients in Eastbourne, Great Britain.

title: Suez Canal
event: December 23 – British and French troops leave the Suez Canal region.

title: United Kingdom
event: The Consumers' Association is founded in the United Kingdom.

title: Gordium
event: The so-called 'mound of Midas', the Great Tumulus near Gordium, is excavated.

title: Brazil
event: The Africanized bee is accidentally released in Brazil.

title: China
event: The Asian Flu pandemic begins in China.

title: Liverpool
event: January 16 – The Cavern Club opens in Liverpool.

title: Sinai Peninsula
event: Israel withdraws from the Sinai Peninsula (captured from Egypt on October 29, 1956).

title: New York City
event: The New York City Mad Bomber, George P. Metesky, is arrested in Waterbury, Connecticut and is charged with planting more than 30 bombs.

title: Brazil
event: January 26 – The Ibirapuera Planetarium (the first in the Southern Hemisphere) is inaugurated in the city of São Paulo, Brazil.

title: Los Angeles
event: January 31 – Three students on a junior high school playground in Pacoima, California are among the 8 persons killed following a mid-air collision between a Douglas DC-7 airliner and a Northrop F-89 Scorpion fighter jet, in the skies above the San Fernando Valley section of Los Angeles, US.

title: Guddu Barrage
event: February 2 – President Iskander Mirza of Pakistan lays the foundation-stone of the Guddu Barrage across the river Indus near Sukkur.

title: France
event: France prohibits U.N. involvement in Algeria.

title: United Kingdom
event: The Toddlers' Truce, a controversial television closedown between 6.00 p.m. and 7.00 p.m., is abolished in the United Kingdom.

title: Warrenton Missouri
event: February 17 – A fire at a home for the elderly in Warrenton, Missouri kills 72 people.

title: Kenya
event: Kenyan rebel leader Dedan Kimathi is executed by the British colonial government.

title: New Zealand
event: The last person to be executed in New Zealand, Walter James Bolton, is hanged at Mount Eden Prison for poisoning his wife.

title: Burma
event: U Nu becomes Prime Minister of Burma.

title: Eurovision Song Contest 1957
event: March 3 – ''Net als toen'' by Corry Brokken (music by Guus Jansen, text by Willy van Hemert) wins the Eurovision Song Contest 1957 for the Netherlands.

title: Ghana
event: United Kingdom colonies Gold Coast and British Togoland become the independent nation of Ghana.

title: Suez Canal
event: March 8 – Egypt re-opens the Suez Canal.

title: Oregon
event: March 10 – Floodgates of The Dalles Dam are closed, inundating Celilo Falls and ancient Indian fisheries along the Columbia River in Oregon, US.

title: Federal Bureau of Investigation
event: March 13 – The United States Federal Bureau of Investigation arrests Jimmy Hoffa and charges him with bribery.

title: 1957 Cebu Douglas C-47 crash
event: March 17 – Philippine President Ramon Magsaysay and 24 others are killed in a plane crash.

title: Kerala
event: April 5 – The Communist Party of India wins the elections in Kerala, making E. M. S. Namboodiripad its first chief minister.

title: Suez Canal
event: April 9 – Egypt reopens the Suez Canal to all shipping.

title: Singapore
event: The United Kingdom announces that Singapore will gain self-rule on January 1, 1958.

title: Old Bailey
event: April 17 – Suspected serial killer John Bodkin Adams is found not guilty of murder at the Old Bailey.

title: Manhattan
event: May 2 – Vincent Gigante fails to assassinate mafioso Frank Costello in Manhattan.

title: California
event: May 3 – Brooklyn Dodgers owner Walter O'Malley agrees to move the team from Brooklyn, New York, to Los Angeles, California.

title: United Kingdom
event: Operation Grapple: At Malden Island in the Pacific, Britain tests its first hydrogen bomb, which fails to detonate properly.

title: Taiwan
event: May 24 – Anti-American riots erupt in Taipei, Taiwan.

title: Oklahoma
event: June 15 – Oklahoma celebrates its semi-centennial statehood. A brand new 1957 Plymouth Belvedere is buried in a time capsule (to be opened 50 years later on June 15, 2007).

title: Cameron Louisiana
event: June 27 – Hurricane Audrey demolishes Cameron, Louisiana, US, killing 400 people.

title: Aga Khan III
event: July 11 – His Highness Prince Karim Aga Khan becomes the 49th Imam of the Shia Ismaili Muslims at age 20. His grandfather Sir Sultan Mohammed Shah Aga Khan III appoints Prince Karim in his will.

title: New York
event: July 16 – United States Marine Major John Glenn flies an F8U supersonic jet from California to New York in 3 hours, 23 minutes and 8 seconds, setting a new transcontinental speed record.

title: International Atomic Energy Agency
event: July 29 – The International Atomic Energy Agency is established.

title: German Grand Prix
event: August 4 – Juan Manuel Fangio, driving for Maserati, wins the Formula One German Grand Prix, clinching (with 4 wins that season) his record 5th world drivers championship, including his 4th consecutive championship (also a record); these 2 records endure for nearly half a century.

title: WPVI-TV
event: August 5 – ''American Bandstand'', a local dance show produced by WFIL-TV in Philadelphia, joins the ABC Television Network.

title: United Kingdom
event: August 31 – The Federation of Malaya gains independence from the United Kingdom. Tuanku Abdul Rahman ibni Almarhum Tuanku Muhammad, Yang di-Pertuan Besar of Negeri Sembilan becomes the first Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaya.

title: Jamaica
event: September 1 – 175 die in Jamaica's worst railway disaster.

title: United Kingdom
event: September 3 – The Wolfenden Report on homosexuality is published in the United Kingdom.

title: Arkansas
event: American Civil Rights Movement – Little Rock Crisis: Governor Orville Faubus of Arkansas calls out the US National Guard, to prevent African-American students from enrolling in Central High School in Little Rock.

title: Massachusetts
event: September 9 – Catholic Memorial High School opens its doors for the first time in Boston, Massachusetts.

title: Pamir (ship)
event: The sailing ship ''Pamir'' sinks off the Azores in a hurricane.

title: Arkansas
event: September 24 – U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower sends federal troops to Arkansas to provide safe passage into Central High School for the Little Rock Nine.

title: Kyshtym disaster
event: September 29 – Kyshtym disaster occurs at a nuclear fuel reprocessing plant in Russia.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
event: October 2 – David Lean's film ''The Bridge on the River Kwai'' opens in the UK.

title: Dover Delaware
event: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower apologizes to the finance minister of Ghana, Komla Agbeli Gbdemah, after he is refused service in a Dover, Delaware restaurant.

title: Windscale fire
event: A fire at the Windscale power station in the UK releases radioactive material into the surrounding environment, including Iodine-131.

title: Cheshire
event: The Jodrell Bank Radio telescope opens in Cheshire, UK.

title: Cambridge Massachusetts
event: The orbit of the last stage of the R-7 Semyorka rocket (carrying Sputnik I) is first successfully calculated on an IBM 704 computer by teams at The M.I.T. Computation Center and Operation Moonwatch, Cambridge, Massachusetts.

title: New York City
event: October 25 – Mafia boss Albert Anastasia is assassinated in a barber shop, at the Park Sheraton Hotel in New York City, US.

title: Michigan
event: November 1 – The Mackinac Bridge, the world's longest suspension bridge between anchorages at the time, opens in the US to connect Michigan's two peninsulas.

title: Italy
event: Flooding in the Po River valley of Italy leads to flooding also in Venice.

title: Apalachin New York
event: November 14 – Apalachin Meeting: American Mafia leaders meet in Apalachin, New York at the house of Joseph Barbara; the meeting is broken up by a curious patrolman.

title: Isle of Wight
event: A plane crash in the Isle of Wight leaves 43 dead.

title: Yugoslavia
event: Yugoslavia announces the end of an economic boycott of Franco's Spain (although it does not reinstitute diplomatic relations).

title: Plainfield Wisconsin
event: Serial killer Edward Gein murders his last victim, Bernice Worden of Plainfield, Wisconsin, US.

title: United Kingdom
event: December 4 – The Lewisham train disaster in the UK leaves 92 dead.

title: Nobel Peace Prize
event: December 10 – Canadian diplomat Lester B. Pearson receives the Nobel Peace Prize for his peackeeping efforts in the United Nations.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
event: December 18 – ''The Bridge on the River Kwai'' is released in the U.S. It goes on to win the Academy Award for Best Picture. Additional Oscars go to Alec Guinness (Best Actor) and David Lean (Best Director), among others. This is Lean's first Oscar for directing.

title: Broadway theatre
event: December 19 – Meredith Willson's classic musical ''The Music Man'', starring Robert Preston, debuts on Broadway.

title: Amirkabir University of Technology
event: The Amirkabir University of Technology is founded.

title: Illinois
event: Illinois observes the centennial of the Lincoln-Douglas Debates.

title: Great Britain
event: USA, USSR and Great Britain agree to stop testing atomic bombs for 3 years.

title: Maxton North Carolina
event: January 18 – Armed Lumbee Indians confront a handful of Klansmen in Maxton, North Carolina.

title: United Arab Republic
event: February 1 – Egypt and Syria unite to form the United Arab Republic.

title: United Arab Republic
event: Gamel Abdel Nasser is nominated as the first president of the United Arab Republic.

title: Yugoslavia
event: February 6 – Seven Manchester United footballers are among the 21 people killed in the Munich air disaster in West Germany on the return flight from a European Cup game in Yugoslavia. 23 people survive, but four of them, including manager Matt Busby and players Johnny Berry and Duncan Edwards, are in a serious condition.

title: People's Republic of China
event: Marshal Chen Yi succeeds Zhou Enlai as Chinese Minister of Foreign affairs.

title: Iraq
event: February 14 – The Hashemite Kingdoms of Iraq and Jordan unite in the Arab Federation of Iraq and Jordan with Iraqi King Faisal II as head of state.

title: Cape Canaveral
event: February 20 – A test rocket explodes at Cape Canaveral.

title: Argentina
event: Arturo Frondizi is elected president of Argentina.

title: Sierra Maestra
event: February 24 – In Cuba, Fidel Castro's ''Radio Rebelde'' begins broadcasting from Sierra Maestra.

title: İzmit
event: March 1 – The Turkish passenger ship ''Uskudar'' capsizes and sinks at Izmit Bay, Kocaeli, Turkey; at least 300 die.

title: USS Wisconsin (BB-64)
event: March 8 – The USS ''Wisconsin'' is decommissioned, leaving the United States Navy without an active battleship for the first time since 1896 (it is recommissioned October 22, 1988).

title: South Carolina
event: March 11 – A U.S. B-47 bomber accidentally drops an atom bomb on Mars Bluff, South Carolina. Its conventional explosives destroy a house and injure several people, but no nuclear fission occurs.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
event: The 30th Academy Awards ceremony took place; The Bridge on the River Kwai wins 7 Academy Awards, including Academy Award for Best Picture.

title: Havana
event: April 3 – Castro's revolutionary army begins its attacks on Havana.

title: Berkshire
event: April 4 – April 7 – In the first protest march for the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament from Hyde Park, London to Aldermaston, Berkshire, demonstrators demand the banning of nuclear weapons.

title: California
event: April 15 – The San Francisco Giants beat the Los Angeles Dodgers 8–0 at San Francisco's Seals Stadium, in the first Major League Baseball regular season game ever played in California.

title: Brussels
event: April 17 – King Baudouin of Belgium officially opens the World Fair in Brussels, also known as Expo '58.

title: North American Aerospace Defense Command
event: May 12 – A formal North American Aerospace Defense Command agreement is signed between the United States and Canada.

title: Bristol
event: May 21 – United Kingdom Postmaster General Ernest Marples announces that from December, Subscriber Trunk Dialling will be introduced in the Bristol area. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/21/newsid_2510000/2510289.stm]

title: Arlington National Cemetery
event: May 30 – The bodies of unidentified soldiers killed in action during World War II and the Korean War are buried at the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: France
event: Charles de Gaulle is brought out of retirement to lead France by decree for 6 months.

title: California
event: June 2 – In San Simeon, California, [http://www.hearstcastle.com Hearst Castle] opens to the public for guided tours.

title: Argentina
event: June 27 – The Peronist Party becomes legal again in Argentina.

title: Alaska
event: President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs the Alaska Statehood Act into United States law.

title: Alaska
event: July 9 – A 7.5 Richter scale earthquake in Lituya Bay, Alaska, causes a landslide that produces a huge 520-meter high wave

title: Iraq
event: July 14 – Iraqi Revolution: The Iraqi monarchy is overthrown by Arab nationalists, King Faisal II is murdered and Abdul Karim Qassim assumes power.

title: Beirut
event: July 15 – In Lebanon, 5,000 United States Marines land in the capital Beirut in order to protect the pro-Western government there.

title: NASA
event: July 29 – The U.S. Congress formally creates the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA).

title: North Pole
event: August 3 – The nuclear powered submarine ''USS Nautilus (SSN-571)'' becomes the first vessel to cross the North Pole under water.

title: London
event: August 30 – September 1 – Riots between blacks and whites occur in Notting Hill, London.

title: Artek (camp)
event: September 6 – Paul Robeson performs in concert at the Soviet Young Pioneer camp Artek.

title: French Fifth Republic
event: September 28 – In France, a majority of 79% says yes to the constitution of the Fifth Republic.

title: NASA
event: NASA starts operations and replaces the NACA.

title: France
event: October 2 – Guinea declares itself independent from France.

title: NASA
event: October 11 – Pioneer 1, the second and most successful of the 3 project Able space probes, becomes the first spacecraft launched by the newly formed NASA.

title: Blue Peter
event: October 16 – UK TV series Blue Peter started.

title: UNESCO
event: November 3 – The new UNESCO building is inaugurated in Paris.

title: Rio de Janeiro
event: November 10 – The Bossa nova is born in Rio de Janeiro, with Joao Gilberto's  recording of Chega de Saudade.

title: Republic of the Congo
event: November 28 – Chad, the Republic of the Congo, and Gabon become autonomous republics within the French Community.

title: France
event: November 30 – Gaullists win parliamentary elections in France.

title: Bristol
event: Subscriber trunk dialling (STD) is inaugurated in the UK by the Queen, when she dials a call from Bristol to Edinburgh and speaks to the Lord Provost. [http://www.bt.com/archives/history/19461959.htm#1958]

title: M55 motorway
event: The Preston bypass, the United Kingdom's first motorway, opens to traffic for the first time. This stretch is now part of the M6 and M55 motorways.

title: France
event: December 21 – General Charles de Gaulle is elected president of France with 78.5% of the votes.

title: Dartmoor
event: The first Ten Tors event is held in Dartmoor.

title: United Kingdom
event: Import tariffs are lifted in the United Kingdom.

title: Belgian Congo
event: The first known human with HIV dies in the Congo. {{DOI10.1038/35400}} PMID 9468138

title: Havana
event: Cuba: Fulgencio Batista flees Havana when the forces of Fidel Castro advance.

title: Havana
event: Castro's troops approach Havana.

title: Baikonur Cosmodrome
event: Soviet Union successfully launches Luna 1 spacecraft from Baikonur Cosmodrome.

title: Maldives
event: The island of Addu in the Maldives declares independence.

title: Alaska
event: Alaska is admitted as the 49th U.S. state.

title: Havana
event: In Cuba, rebel troops led by Che Guevara and Camilo Cienfuegos enter the city of Havana.

title: Kinshasa
event: In Léopoldville, 42 people are killed during food fights between the police and participants of a meeting of the Abako Party.

title: French Fifth Republic
event: January 8 – Charles De Gaulle is inaugurated as the first president of the French Fifth Republic.

title: Caves of Nerja
event: Caves of Nerja are discovered in Spain.

title: Port Griffith Pennsylvania
event: January 22 – Knox Mine Disaster: Water breaches the River Slope Mine near Pittston City, Pennsylvania in Port Griffith; 12 miners are killed.

title: The Day the Music Died
event: February 3 – A chartered plane transporting musicians Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens, Roger Peterson and The Big Bopper goes down in foggy conditions near Clear Lake, Iowa, killing all 4 occupants on board, including pilot Roger Peterson. The tragedy is later termed The Day the Music Died, popularized in Don McLean's 1972 song American Pie.

title: Florida
event: February 6 – At Cape Canaveral, Florida, the first successful test firing of a Titan intercontinental ballistic missile is accomplished.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: February 9 – Yugoslavia and Spain set trade relations (not diplomatic ones)

title: Newfoundland and Labrador
event: A blizzard causes a massive power outage in Newfoundland.

title: Nepal
event: Women in Nepal vote for the first time.

title: United Kingdom
event: February 19 – The United Kingdom decides to grant Cyprus its independence.

title: CBS 30th Street Studio
event: March 2 – Recording sessions for the album Kind of Blue by Miles Davis took place at Columbia's 30th Street Studio in New York City.

title: Lhasa
event: March 10 – A Tibetan uprising against 10 years of Chinese rule erupts in Lhasa.

title: Eurovision Song Contest 1959
event: ''Een beetje'' by Teddy Scholten (music by Dick Schallies, text by Willy van Hemert) wins the Eurovision Song Contest 1959 for the Netherlands.

title: New York
event: ''A Raisin in the Sun'' by Lorraine Hansberry opens on Broadway in New York.

title: India
event: March 17 – Tenzin Gyatso, the 14th Dalai Lama, starts to flee Tibet and travels to India.

title: Hawaii
event: March 18 – American President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs a bill allowing for Hawaiian statehood.

title: Addu Atoll
event: March 19 – Two other islands join Addu in the United Suvadive Republic (abolished September 1963), in the Maldives Islands.

title: Tampa Florida
event: March 31 – Busch Gardens in Tampa, Florida is dedicated and opens its gates.

title: Inter-American Development Bank
event: April 8 – The Inter-American Development Bank (IADB) is established.

title: NASA
event: April 9 – NASA announces its selection of 7 military pilots to become the first U.S. astronauts (see Mercury Seven).

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: April 25 – The  St. Lawrence Seaway linking the North American Great Lakes and the Atlantic Ocean officially opens to shipping.

title: National People's Congress
event: April 27 – National People's Congress elects Liu Shaoqi as Chairman of the People's Republic of China, as a successor of Mao Zedong.

title: Guinea
event: May 18 – The National Liberation Committee of Côte d'Ivoire is launched in Conakry, Guinea.

title: Singapore
event: June 3 – Singapore becomes a self-governing crown colony of Britain with Lee Kuan Yew as Prime Minister.

title: Singapore
event: June 5 – A new government of the State of Singapore is sworn in by Sir William Goode. Two former ministers are re-elected to the Legislative Assembly.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: Sean Lemass becomes the third Taoiseach of Ireland.

title: Ireland
event: ''Darby O'Gill and the Little People'', a film based on H.T. Kavanagh's short stories, is released in the U.S. by Walt Disney, after world premiering in Ireland.

title: Alaska
event: July 4 – With the admission of Alaska as the 49th U.S. state earlier in the year, the 49-star flag of the United States debuts in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

title: Tanzania
event: July 17 – The first skull of Australopithecus is discovered by Louis Leakey and his wife Mary Leakey in the Olduvai Gorge of Tanzania.

title: Louis Blériot
event: July 25 – The SR-N1 hovercraft crosses the English Channel from Calais to Dover in just over 2 hours, on the 50th anniversary of Louis Bleriot's first crossing by heavier-than-air craft.

title: Florida
event: August 7 – Explorer program: The United States launches Explorer 6 from the Atlantic Missile Range in Cape Canaveral, Florida.

title: Taiwan
event: August 8 – A flood in Taiwan kills 2,000.

title: 1959 Yellowstone earthquake
event: August 17 – The Hebgen Lake Earthquake in southwest Montana kills 28.

title: Hawaii
event: August 21 – Hawaii is admitted as the 50th U.S. state.

title: Bass Strait
event: September 23 – The ''M/S Princess of Tasmania'' (Australia's first passenger RO/RO diesel ferry) makes its maiden voyage across the Bass Strait.

title: Beijing
event: September 30 – Soviet Union leader Nikita Khrushchev meets Mao Zedong in Beijing.

title: New York City
event: October 21 – In New York City, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum (designed by Frank Lloyd Wright) opens to the public.

title: Belgian Congo
event: October 31 – Riots break out in the Belgian Congo.

title: Rwanda
event: November 1 – In Rwanda, Hutu politician Dominique Mbonyumutwa is beaten up by Tutsi forces, leading to a period of violence known as the wind of destruction.

title: Leeds
event: November 2 – The first section of the M1 motorway in England opens between Hertfordshire, just north of London, and the border of Northamptonshire and Warwickshire. The motorway is set to be expanded over the next few years to provide an unbroken motorway link with London and Leeds. A full motorway network across Britain is also set to be developed over the coming decade and into the 1970s.

title: Holcomb Kansas
event: November 15 – The Clutter family of Holcomb, Kansas is brutally murdered, inspiring Truman Capote's ''In Cold Blood''.

title: Antarctica
event: December 1 – Cold War – Antarctic Treaty: 12 countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, sign a landmark treaty, which sets aside Antarctica as a scientific preserve and bans military activity on that continent (the first arms control agreement established during the Cold War).

title: France
event: December 2 – Malpasset Dam in southern France collapses and water flows over the town of Frejus, killing 412.

title: Kenya
event: January – The state of emergency is lifted in Kenya, officially ending the Mau Mau Uprising.

title: Madagascar
event: December – African and Malagasy Organisation for Economic Cooperation (OAMCE) (Organisation Africain et Malagache de Coopération Économique).

title: Argentina
event: The US census lists all people from Latin America as white, including blacks from the Dominican Republic, European whites from Argentina and Mexicans who resemble Native Americans.

title: Argentina
event: Beginning in 1959, Argentina suffers economic recession.

title: France
event: January 1 – Cameroon gains its independence from French-administered U.N. trusteeship.

title: Australia
event: January 14 – The Reserve Bank and Commonwealth Bank are created in Australia.

title: South Africa
event: January 21 – A mine collapses at Coalbrook, South Africa, killing 500 miners.

title: France
event: In France, President Charles de Gaulle fires Jacques Massu, the commander-in-chief of the French troops in Algeria.

title: Mariana Trench
event: Jacques Piccard and Don Walsh descend into the Mariana Trench in the ''bathyscaphe Trieste'', reaching the depth of 10,916 meters and become the first human beings (and so far the only) to reach the lowest spot on Earth.

title: North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University
event: February 1 – In Greensboro, North Carolina, four black students from North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University begin a sit-in at a segregated Woolworth's lunch counter. Although they are refused service, they are allowed to stay at the counter. The event triggers many similar nonviolent protests throughout the Southern United States, and six months later the original four protesters are served lunch at the same counter.

title: Ghana
event: February 3 – Prime Minister of the United Kingdom Harold Macmillan makes the Wind of Change speech to the South African Parliament in Cape Town (although he had first made the speech, to little publicity, in Accra, Gold Coast – now Ghana – on January 10).

title: Switzerland
event: February 5 – The first CERN particle accelerator becomes operational in Geneva, Switzerland.

title: Hollywood Walk of Fame
event: Joanne Woodward receives the first star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in Southern California.

title: Belgian Congo
event: February 10 – A conference about the  proposed independence of the Belgian Congo begins in Brussels, Belgium.

title: Massachusetts
event: The N class blimp ZPG-3W of the U.S. Navy is destroyed during a storm over Massachusetts.

title: People's Republic of China
event: Twelve Indian soldiers die in clashes with Red Chinese troops along their small common border.

title: France
event: February 13 – France tests its first atomic bomb - in the Sahara Desert of Algeria.

title: Placer County California
event: February 18 – The 1960 Winter Olympic Games begin at the Squaw Valley Ski Resort, in Placer County, California.

title: 1960 Agadir earthquake
event: February 29 – The 1960 Agadir earthquake completely destroys the town of  Agadir, Morocco.

title: Switzerland
event: The Canton of Geneva in Switzerland gives women the right to vote.

title: South Africa
event: March 21 – The Sharpeville massacre in South Africa results in more than 69 dead, 300 injured.

title: France
event: March 29 – ''Tom Pillibi'' by Jacqueline Boyer (music by André Popp, text by Pierre Cour) wins the Eurovision Song Contest 1960 for France.

title: South Africa
event: April 16 – The gunman David Pratt shoots South African Prime Minister Henrik Verwoerd in Johannesburg, wounding him seriously.

title: Memphis Tennessee
event: April 17 – Russwood Park, a baseball stadium in Memphis, Tennessee, burns to the ground from a fire shortly after a Chicago White Sox versus Cleveland Indians Major League Baseball game.

title: Rio de Janeiro
event: April 21 – In Brazil, the country's capital (Federal District) is relocated from the city of Rio de Janeiro to the new city, Brasília, in the highlands. The actual city of Rio de Janeiro becomes the State of Guanabara.

title: France
event: April 27 – Togo gains independence from France, with the French-administered United Nations Trust Territory being terminated.

title: Central Intelligence Agency
event: Several Soviet surface-to-air missiles shoot down an American Lockheed U-2 spy plane. Its pilot, Francis Gary Powers, of the Central Intelligence Agency is captured.

title: New York City
event: May 3 – The Fantasticks, the world's longest-running musical, opens at New York City's Sullivan Street Playhouse where it would play for 42 years.

title: Nazi Germany
event: May 4 – West German refugee minister Theodor Oberländer is fired because of his past with Nazi Germany.

title: USS Triton (SSRN-586)
event: May 10 – The nuclear submarine USS ''Triton'', under the command of Captain Edward L. Beach, Jr., completes the first underwater circumnavigation of the Earth.

title: Israel
event: May 11 – In Buenos Aires, four Mossad agents abduct the fugitive Nazi criminal against humanity, Adolf Eichmann, in order that he could be taken to Israel and put on trial. Eichmann was later convicted and executed.

title: Dhaulagiri
event: May 13 – A joint Swiss & Austrian expedition makes the first ascent of the Asian mountain, Dhaulagiri, the world's 7th highest mountain.

title: Kenya
event: May 14 – The Kenyan African National Congress Party is founded in Kenya, when 3 political parties join forces.

title: Diet of Japan
event: May 20 – In Japan, police carry away socialist members of the Diet of Japan. The Diet next approves a mutual security treaty with the United States.

title: Taitao Peninsula
event: May 22 – The Great Chilean Earthquake: Chile's subduction fault ruptures from Talcahuano to Taitao Peninsula, causing a tsunami and one of the greatest earthquakes on record. Because of its power, the seismographs in the city of Valdivia are overloaded and malfunction through the entire earthquake.

title: New Zealand
event: June 1 – New Zealand's first television station begins broadcasting in the city of Auckland.

title: California
event: June 7 – U.S. Senator John F. Kennedy wins the California Democratic primary.

title: China
event: June 9 – Typhoon Mary kills 1,600 people in the Fukien province of China.

title: Philippines
event: June 19 – The Associated Broadcasting Company (Now TV5) is founded in the Philippines.

title: France
event: June 20 – The short-lived Mali Federation, consisting of the Sudanese Republic (now the Republic of Mali) and Senegal, gains independence from France.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: June 24 – Joseph Kasavubu is elected as the first President of the independent Congo.

title: United Kingdom
event: British Somaliland gains independence from the United Kingdom. Five days later it unites with Somalia (the former Italian Somaliland) to create the modern Somali Republic - a country that was destined to break apart into indefinite anarchy later on.

title: France
event: The Malagasy Republic, now Madagascar, becomes independent from France

title: Belgian Congo
event: The Belgian Congo gains independence from Belgium as the Republic of the Congo (Léopoldville); civil war follows.

title: Italy
event: Public demonstrations by democratic and left forces, against Italian government support of the post-fascist Italian Social Movement, are heavily suppressed by police.

title: Ghana
event: Ghana becomes a republic and Kwame Nkrumah becomes its first President.

title: Barents Sea
event: Cold War: A Soviet Air Force MiG-15 fighter plane flying north of Murmansk, Russia, over the Barents Sea shoots down a six-man RB-47 Stratojet reconnaissance plane of the U.S. Air Force. Four of the U.S. Air Force officers are killed, and the two survivors are held prisoner in the U.S.S.R.

title: Italy
event: Italian Somaliland gains its independence from Italy, 5 days after British Somaliland, with which it unites to form the Somali Republic.

title: Philadelphia
event: July 4 – Following the admission of the State of Hawaii as the 50th State in August 1959, the new 50-star Flag of the United States is first officially flown over Philadelphia, Pa.

title: Los Angeles
event: July 13 – The U.S. Senator John F. Kennedy is nominated for President of the United States at the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles.

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: July 21 – Francis Chichester, English navigator and yachtsman, arrives at New York City aboard his yacht, ''Gypsy Moth II'', crossing the Atlantic Ocean solo in a new record of just forty days.

title: Greensboro North Carolina
event: July 25 – The Woolworth Company's lunch counter in Greensboro, North Carolina, the location of a sit-in that had sparked demonstrations by Negroes across the Southern United States, serves a meal to its first black customer.

title: France
event: August 1 – Dahomey, now known as Benin, becomes independent from France.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: In the Republic of the Congo (Léopoldville), now the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Albert Kalonji declares the independence of the Autonomous State of South Kasai.

title: Mali Federation
event: August 20 – Senegal breaks away from the Mali Federation, declaring its independence.

title: North Pole
event: The nuclear submarine USS ''Seadragon'' (SSN-584) surfaces at the North Pole, the first submarine ever to do so, and her crew plays softball there.

title: New England
event: August 29 – Hurricane Donna kills 50 in the State of Florida and in New England.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: The Congolese president, Joseph Kasavubu, fires Patrice Lumumba's entire government, and also places Lumumba under house arrest.

title: NASA
event: September 8 – In Huntsville, Alabama, President Dwight D. Eisenhower formally dedicates the Marshall Space Flight Center (wnich had been activated by NASA on July 1).

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: Colonel Joseph Mobutu takes power in Republic of the Congo via a military coup.

title: Iraq
event: The countries of Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, and Venezuela form OPEC.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 1 – Nigeria becomes independent from United Kingdom, and Nnamdi Azikiwe becomes its first native-born Governor General.

title: South Africa
event: October 5 – White South Africans vote to make this country a republic.

title: Nigeria
event: October 7 – Nigeria becomes the 99th member of the United Nations.

title: Baikonur Cosmodrome
event: A large booster rocket explodes on the launch pad at the Baikonur Cosmodrome, killing at least 90 people of the Soviet space program.

title: Robert F. Kennedy
event: October 26 – Robert F. Kennedy telephones Coretta Scott King, the wife of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and he also secures King's release from jail regarding a traffic violation in Atlanta, State of Georgia.

title: Louisville Kentucky
event: October 29 – In Louisville, Kentucky, Cassius Clay (later Muhammad Ali) wins his first professional boxing match.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 30 – Dr. Michael Woodruff carries out the first successful kidney transplant in the United Kingdom, in Edinburgh, Scotland, at the Edinburgh Royal Infirmary.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: Belgium threatens to leave the United Nations over criticism of its policy concerning the Republic of the Congo.

title: Florida
event: November 15 – A Polaris missile is test-launched from Cape Canaveral, Florida

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: November 22 – The United Nations supports the government of Joseph Kasavubu and Joseph Mobutu in the Republic of the Congo.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: Patrice Lumumba, the deposed premier of the Republic of the Congo, is arrested by the troops of Colonel Joseph Mobutu.

title: Vatican City
event: The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, talks with Pope John XXIII for about one hour in Vatican City. This is the first time that any chief of the Anglican Church had ever visited the Pope.

title: Florida
event: President Dwight D. Eisenhower authorizes the use of $1.0 million for the relief and resettlement of Cuban refugees, who had been arriving in Florida at the rate of about 1,000 per week.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: December 7 – The United Nations Security Council is called into session by the Soviet Union in order to consider Soviet demands for the Security Council to seek the immediate release of the former Congolese Premier Patrice Lumumba.

title: Coronation Street
event: The first episode of the classic British TV series ''Coronation Street'' is telecast. It had ben planned to be a 13-part drama, but it became such a success among TV watchers that it is still shown five times per week as of {{CURRENTYEAR}}.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: December 12 – The Supreme Court of the United States upholds a lower Federal Court ruling that the State of Louisiana's laws on racial segregation laws are unconstitutional, and overturns them.

title: Brazil
event: While Emperor Haile Selassie I of Ethiopia visits Brazil, his Imperial Bodyguard leads a military coup against his rule, proclaiming that the emperor's son, Crown Prince Asfa Wossen, is the new emperor.

title: Nicaragua
event: The countries of El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua announce the formation of the Central American Common Market.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: Antoine Gizenga proclaims in Stanleyville, Republic of the Congo, that he has taken over as the premier.

title: NATO
event: Secretary of State Christian Herter announces that the United States will commit five nuclear submarines and 80 Polaris missiles to the defense of the NATO countries by the end of 1963.

title: New York City
event: 1960 New York air disaster: a United Airlines DC-8 collides in mid-air with a TWA Lockheed Constellation over Staten Island in New York City. All 128 passengers and crewmembers on the two airliners are killed, and also six people on the ground are killed.

title: Brazil
event: December 17 – Troops loyal to Emperor Haile Selassie I in Ethiopia overcome the illegal coup that began on December 13, returning the reins to the Emperor upon his return from a trip to Brazil. The Emperor absolves his own son of any guilt.

title: USS Constellation (CV-64)
event: December 19 – Fire sweeps through the USS ''Constellation'', to become the U.S. Navy's largest aircraft carrier, while she is under construction at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. 50 workers are killed and 150 are injured.

title: Reggane
event: December 27 – France sets off its third A-bomb test at its nuclear weapons testing range aroung Reggane, Algeria.

title: United Kingdom
event: December 31 – The farthing, used since the 13th century, ceases to be legal tender in the United Kingdom.

title: Guadalupe Island
event: March–April – Drilling for Project Mohole is undertaken off the coast of Guadalupe Island, Mexico.

title: SL-1
event: At the National Reactor Testing Station near Idaho Falls, Idaho, atomic reactor SL-1 explodes, killing 3 military technicians.

title: Guinea
event: January 7 – Following a 4-day conference in Casablanca, 5 African chiefs of state announce plans for a NATO-type African organization to ensure common defense. The Charter of Casablanca involves the Casablanca Group: Morocco, the United Arab Republic, Ghana, Guinea, and Mali.

title: France
event: January 8 – In France, a referendum supports Charles de Gaulle's policies on independence for Algeria.

title: London
event: January 9 – British authorities announce that they have discovered a large Soviet spy ring in London.

title: Goldsboro North Carolina
event: January 24 – B-52 Stratofortress, with two nuclear bombs, crashes near Goldsboro, North Carolina.

title: Barents Sea
event: In Washington, DC John F. Kennedy delivers the first live presidential news conference. In it, he announces that the Soviet Union has freed the 2 surviving crewmen of a USAF RB-47 reconnaissance plane shot down by Soviet flyers over the Barents Sea July 1, 1960 (see RB-47H shot down).

title: China
event: February 3 – China buys grain from Canada for $60 million.

title: Berkeley California
event: February 14 – Discovery of the chemical elements: Element 103, Lawrencium, is first synthesized in Berkeley, California.

title: Brussels
event: A Sabena Boeing 707 crashes near Brussels, Belgium, killing 73, including the entire United States figure skating team and several coaches.

title: Australia
event: February 25 – The last public trams in Sydney, Australia, cease operation, bringing to an end the Southern Hemisphere's largest tramway network.

title: Holy Loch
event: The first U.S. Polaris submarines arrive at Holy Loch.

title: United Kingdom
event: Black and white £5 notes cease to be legal tender in the UK.

title: Portugal
event: United States delegate to the UNSC Adlai Stevenson votes against Portuguese policies in Africa.

title: South Africa
event: South Africa withdraws from the Commonwealth of Nations.

title: Portugal
event: The Union of Peoples of Angola, led by Holden Roberto, attacks strategic locations in the north of Angola. These events result in the beginning of the colonial war with Portugal.

title: New York
event: March 30 – The Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs is signed at New York.

title: MV Dara
event: April 8 – The British passenger ship ''Dara'' blows up and sinks off Dubai. 238 passengers and crew are killed.

title: Yuri Gagarin
event: Vostok 1'': Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin becomes the first human in space.

title: Portugal
