event: June 4 – Stockport Air Disaster: British Midland flight G-ALHG crashes in Hopes Carr, Stockport, killing 72 passengers and crew.

title: Golan Heights
event: Six-Day War: Israel occupies the West Bank, Gaza Strip, Sinai peninsula and Golan Heights after defeating its Arab neighbours.

title: USS Liberty incident
event: June 8 – Six-Day War – USS Liberty incident: Israeli fighter jets and Israeli warships fire at the USS ''Liberty'' off Gaza, killing 34 and wounding 171.

title: Israel
event: Israel and Syria agree to a United Nations-mediated cease-fire.

title: Israel
event: The Soviet Union severs diplomatic relations with Israel.

title: Denmark
event: Margrethe, heir apparent to the throne of Denmark, marries French count Henri de Laborde de Monpezat.

title: Tampa Florida
event: June 11 – A race riot occurs in Tampa, Florida after the shooting death of Martin Chambers by police while allegedly robbing a camera store.  The unrest lasts several days.

title: People's Republic of China
event: The People's Republic of China tests its first hydrogen bomb.[http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/world/china/nuke.htm]

title: New York City
event: June 14–June 15 – Glenn Gould records Prokofiev's Seventh Piano Sonata, Op. 83, in New York City (his only recording of a Prokofiev composition).

title: Monterey Pop Festival
event: June 16 – The Monterey Pop Festival begins and is held for 3 days.

title: People's Republic of China
event: June 17 – The People's Republic of China announces a successful hydrogen bomb test.

title: Glassboro New Jersey
event: June 23 – Cold War: U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson meets with Soviet Premier Alexei Kosygin in Glassboro, New Jersey, for the 3-day Glassboro Summit Conference. Johnson travels to Los Angeles for a dinner at the Century Plaza Hotel where earlier in the day thousands of war protesters clashed with L.A. police.  [http://www.lbjlib.utexas.edu/johnson/archives.hom/diary/1967/670623.asp]

title: Israel
event: June 28 – Israel declares the annexation of East Jerusalem.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: June 30 – Moise Tshombe, former President of Katanga and former prime minister of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, is kidnapped to Algeria.

title: The Championships Wimbledon
event: The first UK colour television broadcasts begin on BBC2. The first one is from the tennis championship at Wimbledon. A full colour service begins on BBC2 on December 2.

title: American Samoa
event: American Samoa's first constitution becomes effective.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: July 3 – A military rebellion led by Belgian mercenary Jean Schramme begins in Katanga, Democratic Republic of the Congo.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: July 5 – Troops of Belgian mercenary commander Jean Schramme revolt against Mobutu Sese Seko, and try to take control of Stanleyville, Congo.

title: Biafra
event: Biafran War: Nigerian forces invade Biafra, following the latter's secession May 30.

title: Jay Florida
event: July 16 – A prison riot in Jay, Florida leaves 37 dead.

title: Australia
event: July 18 – The United Kingdom announces the closing of its military bases in Malaysia and Singapore. Australia and the U.S. disapprove.

title: Montreal
event: July 24 – During an official state visit to Canada, French President Charles de Gaulle declares to a crowd of over 100,000 in Montreal: ''Vive le Québec libre!'' (Long live free Quebec!). The statement, interpreted as support for Quebec independence, delights many Quebecers but angers the Canadian government and many English Canadians.

title: Gulf of Tonkin
event: An explosion and fire aboard the U.S. Navy aircraft carrier ''USS Forrestal'' in the Gulf of Tonkin leaves 134 dead.

title: Israel
event: Israel annexes East Jerusalem.

title: Trabzon
event: August 2 – The Turkish football club Trabzonspor is established in Trabzon.

title: United Kingdom
event: August 5 – Pink Floyd releases their debut album ''The Piper at the Gates of Dawn'' in the United Kingdom.

title: North Vietnam
event: Vietnam War: The People's Republic of China agrees to give North Vietnam an undisclosed amount of aid in the form of a grant.

title: Israel
event: A general strike in the old quarter of Jerusalem protests Israel's unification of the city.

title: Bangkok
event: August 8 – The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is founded in Bangkok, Thailand.

title: Bukavu
event: August 10 – Belgian mercenary Jean Schramme's troops take the Congolese border town of Bukavu.

title: Montana
event: August 13 – Night of the Grizzlies sparks national concern over bear drama, from PBS in Montana's Glacier National Park.

title: United Kingdom
event: August 15  – The United Kingdom Marine Broadcasting Offences Act declares participation in offshore pirate radio illegal. Radio Caroline defies the Act and continues broadcasting.

title: India
event: August 18 – The State of Tamil Nadu, India is established.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: A truce is declared in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

title: People's Republic of China
event: The People's Republic of China announces that it has shot down United States planes violating its airspace.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: August 30 – Thurgood Marshall is confirmed as the first African American Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

title: Principality of Sealand
event: September 2 – Paddy Roy Bates occupies Roughs Tower and establishes the Principality of Sealand.

title: North Vietnam
event: September 4 – Vietnam War – Operation Swift: The United States Marines launch a search and destroy mission in Quang Nam and Quang Tin Provinces. The ensuing 4-day battle in Que Son Valley kills 114 Americans and 376 North Vietnamese.

title: California
event: September 9 – Fashion Island, one of California's first outdoor shopping malls, opens in Newport Beach.

title: Gibraltar
event: September 10 – In Gibraltar, only 44 out of 12,182 voters support union with Spain.

title: Southampton
event: September 27 – The {{RMSQueen Mary}} arrives in Southampton, at the end of her last transatlantic voyage.

title: Brunei
event: October 4 – Omar Ali Saifuddin III of Brunei abdicates in favour of his son, His Majesty Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah.

title: Bolivia
event: October 8 – Guerrilla leader Che Guevara and his men are captured in Bolivia.

title: North Vietnam
event: October 12 – Vietnam War: U.S. Secretary of State Dean Rusk states during a news conference that proposals by the U.S. Congress for peace initiatives are futile, because of North Vietnam's opposition.

title: The Pentagon
event: Tens of thousands of Vietnam War protesters march in Washington, D.C.. Allen Ginsberg symbolically chants to 'levitate' The Pentagon.

title: Suez Canal
event: An Egyptian surface-to-surface missile sinks the Israeli destroyer ''Eilat'', killing 47 Israeli sailors. Israel retaliates by shelling Egyptian refineries along the Suez Canal.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 25 – An abortion bill passes in the British Parliament.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: Mobutu's troops launch an offensive against mercenaries in Bukavu, Congo.

title: Quebec
event: The Montreal, Quebec Expo 67 closes, having received over 50 million attendees.

title: Hong Kong
event: October 30 – Hong Kong 1967 riots: British troops and Chinese demonstrators clash on the border of China and Hong Kong.

title: Battle of Dak To
event: November 3 – Vietnam War – Battle of Dak To: Around Dak To (located about 280 miles north of Saigon near the Cambodian border), heavy casualties are suffered on both sides (the Americans narrowly win the battle on November 22).

title: Rwanda
event: November 4–November 5 – Mercenaries of Jean Schramme and Jerry Puren withdraw from Bukavu, over the Shangugu Bridge, to Rwanda.

title: NASA
event: November 9 – Apollo program: NASA launches a Saturn V rocket carrying the unmanned ''Apollo 4'' test spacecraft from Cape Kennedy.

title: Phnom Penh
event: November 11 – Vietnam War: In a propaganda ceremony in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, 3 United States prisoners of war are released by the Viet Cong and turned over to New Left antiwar activist Tom Hayden.

title: Congress of Colombia
event: November 14 – The Congress of Colombia in commemoration of the 150-year anniversary  of the death of Policarpa Salavarrieta, declares this day as the Day of the Colombian Woman.

title: Bolivia
event: French author Régis Debray is sentenced to 30 years imprisonment in Bolivia.

title: United Kingdom
event: November 18 – The UK pound is devalued from 1 GBP = 2.80 USD to 1 GBP = 2.40 USD.

title: Israel
event: November 22 – UN Security Council Resolution 242 is adopted by the UN Security Council, establishing a set of principles aimed at guiding negotiations for an Arab–Israeli peace settlement.

title: Portugal
event: November 26 – Major floods hit Lisbon, Portugal, killing 462.

title: Penny Lane
event: November 27 – The Beatles release ''Magical Mystery Tour'' in the US as a full album. The songs added to the original six songs on the double EP include ''All You Need Is Love'', ''Penny Lane'', ''Strawberry Fields Forever'', ''Baby, You're a Rich Man'' and ''Hello, Goodbye''. Release as a double EP will not take place in the UK until December.

title: North Vietnam
event: November 29 – Vietnam War: U.S. Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara announces his resignation to become president of the World Bank. This action is due to U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson's outright rejection of McNamara's early November recommendations to freeze troop levels, stop bombing North Vietnam and hand over ground fighting to South Vietnam.

title: United Kingdom
event: The People's Republic of South Yemen becomes independent of the United Kingdom.

title: RMS Queen Mary
event: December 1 – The RMS ''Queen Mary'' is retired. Her place is taken by the RMS ''Queen Elizabeth 2''.

title: Groote Schuur Hospital
event: December 3 – Christiaan Barnard carries out the world's first heart transplant at Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town.

title: Antarctica
event: At 6:50 PM, a volcano erupts on Deception Island in Antarctica.

title: New York City
event: December 5 – In New York City, Benjamin Spock and Allen Ginsberg are arrested for protesting against the Vietnam War.

title: France
event: December 11 – Supersonic airliner Concorde is unveiled in Toulouse, France.

title: Mothman
event: December 15 – The Silver Bridge over the Ohio River in Point Pleasant, West Virginia, collapses, killing 46 dead. It has been linked to the so-called ''Mothman'' mystery.

title: Melbourne
event: December 17 – Harold Holt, Australian prime minister, disappears when swimming at a beach 60 km from Melbourne.

title: Las Vegas Strip
event: Motorcycle daredevil Evel Knievel attempted to jump 141 feet over the Caesars Palace Fountains on the Las Vegas Strip.  Knievel crashed on landing and the accident was caught on film.

title: Tasmania
event: Tasmania abolishes capital punishment.

title: Cañada College
event: Cañada College opens in Redwood City, California.

title: North Vietnam
event: Lyndon B. Johnson calls for negotiations with North Vietnam.

title: United Kingdom
event: January 8 – British Prime Minister Harold Wilson endorses the 'I'm Backing Britain' campaign for working an additional half hour each day without pay.

title: White House
event: January 19 – At a White House conference on crime, singer and actress Eartha Kitt denounces the Vietnam War to Lady Bird Johnson while attending a ladies' lunch.

title: Battle of Khe Sanh
event: Vietnam War – Battle of Khe Sanh: One of the most publicized and controversial battles of the war begins, ending on April 8.

title: 1968 Thule Air Base B-52 crash
event: A U.S. B-52 Stratofortress crashes in Greenland, discharging 4 nuclear bombs.

title: USS Pueblo (AGER-2)
event: January 23 – North Korea seizes the ''USS Pueblo'', claiming the ship violated its territorial waters while spying.

title: Israel
event: January 25 – The Israeli submarine ''INS Dakar'' sinks in the Mediterranean Sea, killing 69.

title: Australia
event: Nauru president Hammer DeRoburt declares independence from Australia.

title: France
event: February 6–February 18 – The 1968 Winter Olympics are held in Grenoble, France.

title: Orangeburg South Carolina
event: February 8 – American civil rights movement: A civil rights protest staged at a white-only bowling alley in Orangeburg, South Carolina is broken up by highway patrolmen; 3 college students are killed.

title: Israel
event: February 11 – Border clashes take place between Israel and Jordan.

title: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
event: February 13 – Civil rights disturbances occur at the University of Wisconsin–Madison and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

title: Harlem
event: February 27 – Ex-Teenagers singer Frankie Lymon is found dead from a heroin overdose in Harlem.

title: Mauritius
event: Mauritius achieves independence from British rule.

title: Utah
event: March 14 – Nerve gas leaks from the U.S. Army Dugway Proving Ground near Skull Valley, Utah.

title: Robert F. Kennedy
event: U.S. Senator Robert F. Kennedy enters the race for the Democratic Party presidential nomination.

title: Grosvenor Square
event: March 17 – A demonstration in London's Grosvenor Square against U.S. involvement in the Vietnam War leads to violence; 91 people are injured, 200 demonstrators arrested.

title: Howard University
event: March 19–March 23 – Afrocentrism, Black power, Vietnam War: Students at Howard University in Washington, D.C., signal a new era of militant student activism on college campuses in the U.S. Students stage rallies, protests and a 5-day sit-in, laying siege to the administration building, shutting down the university in protest over its ROTC program and the Vietnam War, and demanding a more Afrocentric curriculum.

title: Howard University
event: March 21 – Vietnam War:  In ongoing campus unrest, Howard University students protesting the Vietnam War, the ROTC program on campus and the draft, confront Gen. Lewis Hershey, then head of the U.S. Selective Service System, and as he attempts to deliver an address, shout him down with cries of America is the Black man's battleground!

title: London
event: March 24 – Aer Lingus Flight 712 crashed en route from Cork to London near Tuskar Rock, Wexford, killing 61 passengers and crew.

title: New York City
event: March 26 – Joan Baez marries activist David Harris in New York.

title: Brazil
event: March 28 – Brazilian high school student Edson Luís de Lima Souto is shot by the police in a protest for cheaper meals at a restaurant for low-income students. The aftermath of his death was one of the first major events against the military dictatorship.

title: Memphis Tennessee
event: Martin Luther King, Jr. is shot dead at the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, Tennessee.   Riots erupt in major American cities, lasting for several days afterwards.

title: Apollo 6
event: Apollo Program: Apollo-Saturn mission 502 (''Apollo 6'') is launched, as the second and last unmanned test-flight of the Saturn V launch vehicle.

title: Royal Albert Hall
event: ''La, la, la'' by Massiel (music and lyrics by Manuel de la Calva and Ramón Arcusa) wins the Eurovision Song Contest 1968 for Spain, at the Royal Albert Hall in London.

title: Richmond Indiana
event: A double explosion in downtown Richmond, Indiana kills 41 and injures 150.

title: Hockenheimring
event: April 7 – Racing driver Jim Clark is killed in a Formula 2 race at Hockenheim.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: President Mobutu releases captured mercenaries in the Congo.

title: New York City
event: April 23–April 30 – Vietnam War: Student protesters at Columbia University in New York City take over administration buildings and shut down the university (see main article Columbia University protests of 1968).

title: Broadway theatre
event: April 29 – The musical ''Hair'' officially opens on Broadway.

title: France
event: May – ''May of '68'' is a symbol of the political movement of that generation. Agitations and strikes in Paris lead many youth to believe that a revolution is starting. Student and worker strikes, sometimes referred to as the French May, nearly bring down the French government.

title: Jonesboro Arkansas
event: May 15 – An outbreak of severe thunderstorms produces tornadoes causing massive damage and heavy casualties in Charles City, Iowa, Oelwein, Iowa, and Jonesboro, Arkansas.

title: Maryland
event: May 17 – The Catonsville Nine enter the Selective Service offices in Catonsville, Maryland, take dozens of selective service draft records, and burn them with napalm as a protest against the Vietnam War.

title: Italy
event: A general election is held in Italy.

title: Ambassador Hotel (Los Angeles)
event: June 5 – U.S. presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy is shot at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles, California by Sirhan Sirhan. Kennedy dies from his injuries the next day.

title: Parliament Buildings (Northern Ireland)
event: June 20 – Austin Currie, Member of Parliament (MP) at Stormont in Northern Ireland, along with others, squats a house in Caledon to protest discrimination in housing allocations.

title: Buenos Aires
event: June 23 – A football stampede in Buenos Aires leaves 74 dead and 150 injured.

title: Italy
event: June 24 – Giorgio Rosa declares the independence of his Republic of Rose Island, an artificial island off Rimini, Italy. Italian troops demolish it not long after.

title: Bonin Islands
event: June 26 – Bonin Islands are returned to Japan after 23 years of occupation by the United States Navy.

title: Phoenix Program
event: The Central Intelligence Agency's Phoenix Program is officially established.

title: Portsmouth
event: July 4 – Yachtsman Alec Rose, 59, receives a hero's welcome as he sails into Portsmouth, England after his 354-day round-the-world trip.

title: Iraq
event: July 17 – Saddam Hussein becomes Vice Chairman of the Revolutionary Council in Iraq after a coup d'état.

title: Arenal Volcano
event: July 29 – Arenal Volcano erupts in Costa Rica for the first time in centuries.

title: London
event: July 30 – Thames Television starts transmission in London.

title: Miami Beach Florida
event: August 5–August 8 – The Republican National Convention in Miami Beach, Florida nominates Richard Nixon for U.S. President and Spiro Agnew for Vice President.

title: Liverpool
event: August 11 – The last steam passenger train service runs in Britain. A selection of British Railways steam locomotives make the 120-mile journey from Liverpool to Carlisle and return to Liverpool, before having their fires dropped for the last time (a working known as the Fifteen Guinea Special).

title: Hida River
event: August 18 – Two charter buses push into the Hida River on National Highway Route 41 in Japan, in an accident caused by heavy rain; 104 are killed.

title: Illinois
event: August 22–August 30 – Police clash with anti-war protesters in Chicago, Illinois, outside the 1968 Democratic National Convention, which nominates Hubert Humphrey for U.S. President, and Edmund Muskie for Vice President.

title: France
event: August 24 – France explodes its first hydrogen bomb.

title: Atlantic City New Jersey
event: 150 women (members of New York Radical Women) arrive in Atlantic City, New Jersey to protest against the Miss America Pageant, as exploitative of women. Led by activist and author Robin Morgan, it is one of the first large demonstrations of Second Wave Feminism as Women's Liberation begins to gather much media attention.

title: Sud Aviation Caravelle
event: September 11 – French General René Cogny and 94 others die in an Air France Caravelle jetliner crash near Nice in the Mediterranean.

title: Albania
event: Albania officially retreats from the Warsaw Pact upon the Soviet Union-led Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia, having already ceased to participate actively in Pact activity since 1962.

title: United Kingdom
event: Agreement for merger between the General Electric Company and English Electric, the largest industrial merger in the UK up to this date.

title: South Africa
event: September 17 – The D'Oliveira Affair: The Marylebone Cricket Club tour of South Africa is cancelled when the South Africans refuse to accept the presence of Basil D'Oliveira, a Cape Coloured, in the side.

title: Portugal
event: September 27 – Marcelo Caetano becomes prime minister of Portugal.

title: Greece
event: September 29 – A referendum in Greece gives more power to the military junta.

title: Apollo 7
event: Apollo program: NASA launches ''Apollo 7'', the first manned Apollo mission (Wally Schirra, Donn Eisele, Walter Cunningham).   Mission goals include the first live television broadcast from orbit and testing the lunar module docking maneuver.

title: Equatorial Guinea
event: October 12 – Equatorial Guinea receives its independence from Spain.

title: Skorpios
event: October 20 – Former U.S. First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy marries Greek shipping tycoon Aristotle Onassis on the Greek island of Skorpios.

title: North Vietnam
event: October 31 – Vietnam War: Citing progress in the Paris peace talks, U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson announces to the nation that he has ordered a complete cessation of all air, naval, and artillery bombardment of North Vietnam effective November 1.

title: Maldives
event: A second republic is declared in the Maldives.

title: Yale University
event: November 14 – Yale University announces it is going to admit women.

title: Havana
event: November 24 – 4 men hijack Pan Am Flight 281 from JFK International Airport, New York to Havana, Cuba.

title: Tokyo
event: December 10 – Japan's biggest heist, the still-unsolved 300 million yen robbery, occurs in Tokyo.

title: Broadway theatre
event: December 11 – The film ''Oliver!'', based on the hit London and Broadway musical, opens in the U.S. after being released first in England. It goes on to win the Academy Award for Best Picture. The Rolling Stones Rock and Roll Circus is also filmed on this date, but not released until 1996.

title: Brazil
event: December 13 – Brazilian president Artur da Costa e Silva decrees the AI-5 (or the Fifth Institutional Act), which lasts until 1978 and marks the beginning of the hard times of Brazilian military dictatorship.

title: California
event: December 20 – The Zodiac Killer is believed to have shot Betty Lou Jensen and David Faraday on Lake Herman Road, Benicia, San Francisco Bay, California.

title: China
event: Mao Zedong advocates that educated youth in urban China be re-educated in the country. It marks the start of the Up to the mountains and down to the villages movement.

title: Apollo 8
event: December 24 – Apollo Program: U.S. spacecraft ''Apollo 8'' enters orbit around the Moon. Astronauts Frank Borman, Jim Lovell and William A. Anders become the first humans to see the far side of the Moon and planet Earth as a whole. The crew also reads from Genesis.

title: People's Park
event: A grassroots movement of Berkeley community members seizes an empty lot owned by the University of California to begin the formation of People's Park.

title: Mauritius
event: Common African, Malagasy and Mauritian Organization (OCAMM) (Organisation Commune Africaine Malgache et Mauricienne).

title: Israel
event: War of Attrition, between Egypt and Israel

title: Belfast
event: People's Democracy begins a march from Belfast to Derry, Northern Ireland in support of civil rights.

title: Rose Bowl Game
event: Ohio State defeats USC in the Rose Bowl to win the national title for the 1968 season.

title: Bogside
event: Members of the Royal Ulster Constabulary (RUC) damage property and assault occupants in the Bogside in Derry.  In response, residents erect barricades and establish Free Derry.

title: Hawaii
event: January 14 – An explosion aboard the USS ''Enterprise'' near Hawaii kills 27 and injures 314.

title: Madrid
event: Martial law is declared in Madrid, the University is closed and over 300 students are arrested.

title: Israel
event: Fourteen men, nine of them Jews, are executed in Baghdad for spying for Israel.

title: Wisconsin
event: A blow-out on Union Oil's Platform spills 80,000 to 100,000 barrels of crude oil into a channel and onto the beaches of Santa Barbara County in Southern California inspiring Wisconsin Senator Gaylord Nelson to organize the first Earth Day in 1970

title: Soyuz 5
event: The Soviet Union launches ''Soyuz 5'', which will dock with Soyuz 4 for a transfer of crew.

title: Wenceslas Square
event: Student Jan Palach sets himself on fire in Prague's Wenceslas Square to protest the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia; 3 days later he dies.

title: Cairo
event: February 4 – In Cairo, Yasser Arafat is elected Palestine Liberation Organization leader at the Palestinian National Congress.

title: 1969 Santa Barbara oil spill
event: February 5 – A huge oil spill off the coast of Santa Barbara, California closes the city's harbor.

title: Moccasin Tuolumne County California
event: February 7 – The original Hetch Hetchy Moccasin Powerhouse is removed from service.

title: France
event: In Toulouse, France the first Concorde test flight is conducted.

title: Ussuri River
event: Soviet and Chinese forces clash at a border outpost on the Ussuri River.

title: Robert F. Kennedy
event: In a Los Angeles, California court, Sirhan Sirhan admits that he killed presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy.

title: Apollo 9
event: Apollo program: NASA launches ''Apollo 9'' (James McDivitt, David Scott, Rusty Schweickart) to test the lunar module.

title: Memphis Tennessee
event: In Memphis, Tennessee, James Earl Ray pleads guilty to assassinating Martin Luther King Jr. (he later retracts his guilty plea).

title: Apollo 9
event: March 13 – Apollo program: ''Apollo 9'' returns safely to Earth after testing the Lunar Module.

title: Israel
event: Golda Meir becomes the first female prime minister of Israel.

title: Anguilla
event: British paratroopers and Marines land on the island of Anguilla.

title: Walter Reed Army Medical Center
event: March 28 – Former United States General and President Dwight D. Eisenhower dies after a long illness in the Walter Reed Army Medical Center, Washington, D.C..

title: France
event: March 29 – The Eurovision Song Contest 1969 is held in Madrid, and results in four co-winners, with 18 votes each, from Spain, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and France.

title: Harvard University
event: The Harvard University Administration Building is seized by close to 300 students, mostly members of the Students for a Democratic Society. Before the takeover ends, 45 will be injured and 184 arrested.

title: Queensland
event: April 13 – Queensland: The Brisbane Tramways end service after 84 years of operation.

title: Sea of Japan
event: April 15 – The EC-121 shootdown incident: North Korea shoots down the aircraft over the Sea of Japan, killing all 31 on board.

title: Portugal
event: April 24 – Recently formed British Leyland launches their first new model, the Austin Maxi in Portugal .

title: France
event: April 28 – Charles de Gaulle steps down as president of France after suffering defeat in a referendum the day before.

title: Zap North Dakota
event: Zip to Zap, a harbinger of the Woodstock Concert, ends with the dispersal and eviction of youth and young adults at Zap, North Dakota by the National Guard.

title: Kuala Lumpur
event: May 13 – May 13 Incident: Race riots occur in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

title: North America
event: May 15 – An American teenager known as 'Robert R.' dies in St. Louis, Missouri, of a baffling medical condition. In 1984 it will be identified as the first confirmed case of HIV/AIDS in North America.

title: Apollo 10
event: May 18 – Apollo program: ''Apollo 10'' (Tom Stafford, Gene Cernan, John Young) is launched, on the full dress-rehearsal for the Moon landing.

title: California
event: May 20 – United States National Guard helicopters spray skin-stinging powder on anti-war protesters in California.

title: Apollo 10
event: May 22 – Apollo program: ''Apollo 10'''s lunar module flies to within 15,400 m of the Moon's surface.

title: Apollo 10
event: Apollo program: ''Apollo 10'' returns to Earth, after a successful 8-day test of all the components needed for the upcoming first manned Moon landing.

title: Córdoba Argentina
event: ''Cordobazo'': A general strike and civil unrest break out in Córdoba, Argentina.

title: Curaçao
event: May 30 – Riots in Curaçao mark the start of an Afro-Caribbean civil rights movement on the island.

title: National Arts Centre
event: June 2 – In Ottawa, Canada, the National Arts Centre opens its doors to the public for the first time.

title: South China Sea
event: Melbourne-Evans collision: The Australian aircraft carrier ''Melbourne'' collides with the U.S. destroyer ''Frank E. Evans'' in the South China Sea; 74 U.S. sailors are killed.

title: Hyde Park London
event: June 7 – The rock supergroup Blind Faith play its debut gig in front of 100000 people in London's Hyde Park.

title: Midway Atoll
event: June 8 –  U.S. President Richard Nixon and South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu meet at Midway Island.   Nixon announces that 25,000 U.S. troops will be withdrawn by September.

title: Cuyahoga River
event: The Cuyahoga River fire helps spur an avalanche of water pollution control activities resulting in the Clean Water Act, Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement and the creation of the federal Environmental Protection Agency

title: United Kingdom
event: June 24 – The United Kingdom and Rhodesia sever diplomatic ties.

title: New York City
event: June 28 – The Stonewall riots in New York City mark the start of the modern gay rights movement in the U.S.

title: Kenya
event: July 5 – Tom Mboya, Kenyan Minister of Development, is assassinated.

title: Organization of American States
event: Football War: After Honduras loses a soccer game against El Salvador, rioting breaks out in Honduras against Salvadoran migrant workers. Of the 300,000 Salvadoran workers in Honduras, tens of thousands are expelled, prompting a brief Salvadoran invasion of Honduras. The OAS works out a cease-fire on July 18, which takes effect on July 20.

title: Merauke
event: Act of Free Choice commenced in Merauke, West Irian.

title: Apollo 11
event: July 16 – Apollo program: ''Apollo 11'' (Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin, Michael Collins) lifts off toward the first landing on the Moon.

title: Massachusetts
event: July 18 – Chappaquiddick incident – Edward M. Kennedy drives off a bridge on his way home from a party on Chappaquiddick Island, Massachusetts. Mary Jo Kopechne, a former campaign aide to his brother, dies in the early morning hours of July 19 in the submerged car.

title: Apollo 11
event: The ''Apollo 11'' astronauts return from the first successful Moon landing, and are placed in biological isolation for several days, on the chance they may have brought back lunar germs. The airless lunar environment is later determined to preclude microscopic life.

title: United Kingdom
event: The Soviet Union returns Gerald Brooke to the  United Kingdom in exchange for spies Peter and Helen Kroger (Morris and Lona Cohen).

title: France
event: August 4 – Vietnam War: At the apartment of French intermediary Jean Sainteny in Paris, U.S. representative Henry Kissinger and North Vietnamese representative Xuan Thuy begin secret peace negotiations. They eventually fail since both sides cannot agree to any terms.

title: Battle of the Bogside
event: August 12 – Violence erupts after the Apprentice Boys of Derry march in Derry, Northern Ireland, resulting in a 3-day communal riot known as the Battle of the Bogside.

title: People's Republic of China
event: August 13 – Serious border clashes occur between the Soviet Union and the People's Republic of China.

title: United Kingdom
event: August 14 – British troops are deployed in Northern Ireland following the 3-day Battle of the Bogside.

title: New York
event: August 15–August 18 – The Woodstock Festival is held in upstate New York, featuring some of the top rock musicians of the era.

title: Mississippi
event: August 17 – Category 5 Hurricane Camille, the most powerful tropical cyclonic system at landfall in history, hits the Mississippi coast, killing 248 people and causing US$1.5 billion in damage (1969 dollars).

title: Australia
event: August 21 – Australian Denis Michael Rohan sets the Al-Aqsa Mosque on fire.

title: Libya
event: September 1 – A coup in Libya ousts King Idris, and brings Colonel Muammar al-Gaddafi to power.

title: My Lai Massacre
event: September 5 – My Lai Massacre: Lieutenant William Calley is charged with 6 counts of premeditated murder, for the deaths of 109 Vietnamese civilians in My Lai.

title: Indiana
event: September 9 – Allegheny Airlines Flight 853 DC-9 collides in flight with a Piper PA-28, and crashes near Fairland, Indiana USA.

title: Rabat
event: September 22–September 25 – An Islamic conference in Rabat, Morocco, following the al-Aqsa Mosque fire (August 21), condemns the Israeli claim of ownership of Jerusalem.

title: Illinois
event: September 24 – The ''Chicago Eight'' trial begins in Chicago, Illinois.

title: Alaska
event: October 2 – A 1.2 megaton thermonuclear device is tested at Amchitka Island, Alaska. This test is code-named Project Milrow, the 11th test of the Operation Mandrel 1969–1970 underground nuclear test series. This test is known as a calibration shot to test if the island is fit for larger underground nuclear detonations.

title: University of Wyoming
event: Fourteen black athletes are kicked off the University of Wyoming football team for wearing black armbands into their coach's office.

title: Wal-Mart
event: October 31 – Wal-Mart incorporates as Wal-Mart Stores, Inc.

title: My Lai Massacre
event: November 12 – Vietnam War – My Lai Massacre: Independent investigative journalist Seymour Hersh breaks the My Lai story.

title: Apollo 12
event: November 14 – Apollo program: NASA launches ''Apollo 12'' (Pete Conrad, Richard Gordon, Alan Bean), the second manned mission to the Moon.

title: Barents Sea
event: Cold War: The Soviet submarine K-19 collides with the American submarine USS ''Gato'' in the Barents Sea.

title: United Kingdom
event: Regular colour television broadcasts begin on BBC1 and ITV in UK.

title: Apollo 12
event: Apollo program: ''Apollo 12'' astronauts Charles Conrad and Alan Bean land at Oceanus Procellarum (Ocean of Storms), becoming the third and fourth humans to walk on the Moon.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: The United States Senate votes down the Supreme Court nomination of Clement Haynsworth, the first such rejection since 1930.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: November 24 – Apollo program: The ''Apollo 12'' spacecraft splashes down safely in the Pacific Ocean, ending the second manned mission to the Moon.

title: New York City
event: December 2 – The Boeing 747 jumbo jet makes its debut. It carries 191 people, most of them reporters and photographers, from Seattle, Washington, to New York City.

title: Altamont Free Concert
event: December 6 – The Altamont Free Concert is held at the Altamont Speedway in northern California. Hosted by the Rolling Stones, it is an attempt at a Woodstock West and is best known for the uproar of violence that occurred. It is viewed by many as the end of the sixties.

title: Piazza Fontana bombing
event: December 12 – The Piazza Fontana bombing in Italy (Strage di Piazza Fontana) takes place. A U.S. Navy officer and C.I.A. agent called David Carrett is later investigated for possible involvement.

title: Harlem
event: December 28 – The Young Lords took over the First Spanish Methodist Church in East Harlem.

title: Ireland
event: The first Regional Technical Colleges open in Ireland.

title: People's Republic of China
event: An earthquake (Richter Scale 7.7 magnitude) at Yunnan, China kills at least 15,621.

title: Biafra
event: January 12 – Biafra capitulates, ending the Nigerian civil war.

title: Biafra
event: January 15 – After a 32-month fight for independence from Nigeria, Biafran forces under Philip Effiong formally surrender to General Yakubu Gowon.

title: Thames Barrier
event: January 20 – The Greater London Council announces its plans for the Thames Barrier at Woolwich to prevent flooding (the barrier opens in 1981).

title: Argentina
event: February 1 – A train collision near Buenos Aires, Argentina kills 236.

title: France
event: February 10 – An avalanche at Val d'Isère, France kills 39 tourists.

title: Australia
event: February 19 – Poseidon bubble: shares in Australian nickel mining company Poseidon NL, which stood at $0.80 in September 1969, peak at around $280 before the speculative bubble bursts.

title: Istanbul
event: February 21 – Construction begins on the Boğaziçi Bridge crossing the Bosphorus in Istanbul.

title: Guyana
event: February 22 – Guyana becomes a Republic within the Commonwealth of Nations.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 1 – Rhodesia severs its last tie with the United Kingdom, declaring itself a racially segregated republic.

title: Nova Scotia
event: A Solar Eclipse passes along the Atlantic coast region. Totality was visible across southern Mexico and across the southeast coast of the United States, Nantucket, and Nova Scotia.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 12 – Teenagers in the United Kingdom vote for the first time, in a by-election in Bridgwater.

title: Expo '70
event: March 15 – The Expo '70 World's Fair opens in Suita, Osaka, Japan.

title: California
event: United States Postal Service workers in New York City go on strike; the strike spreads to the state of California and the cities of Akron, Ohio, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Chicago, Boston, and Denver, Colorado; 210,000 out of 750,000 U.S. postal employees walk out. President Nixon assigns military units to New York City post offices. The strike lasts 2 weeks.

title: Ireland
event: All Kinds of Everything, sung by Dana (music and text by Derry Lindsay and Jackie Smith), wins the Eurovision Song Contest 1970 for Ireland.

title: NASA
event: NASA's ''Explorer 1'', the first American satellite and Explorer program spacecraft, reenters Earth's atmosphere after 12 years in orbit.

title: Tokyo
event: Japan Airlines Flight 351, carrying 131 passengers and 7 crew from Tokyo to Fukuoka, is hijacked by Japanese Red Army members. All passengers are eventually freed.

title: Apollo 13
event: Apollo program: ''Apollo 13'' (Jim Lovell, Fred Haise, Jack Swigert) is launched toward the Moon.

title: Apollo 13
event: April 13 – An oxygen tank in the Apollo 13 spacecraft explodes, forcing the crew to abort the mission and return in 4 days.

title: Splashdown (spacecraft landing)
event: April 17 – Apollo program: ''Apollo 13'' splashes down safely in the Pacific.

title: Australia
event: April 21 – The Hutt River Province Principality secedes from Australia.

title: Ohio
event: May 4 – Kent State shootings: Four students at Kent State University in Ohio are killed and 9 wounded by Ohio State National Guardsmen, at a protest against the incursion into Cambodia.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: Arms Crisis in the Republic of Ireland: Charles Haughey and Neil Blaney are dismissed as members of the Irish Government, for accusations of their involvement in a plot to import arms for use by the Provisional IRA in Northern Ireland.

title: New York City Hall
event: Hard Hat riot: Unionized construction workers attack about 1,000 students and others protesting the Kent State shootings near the intersection of Wall Street and Broad Street and at New York City Hall.

title: Oxford North Carolina
event: Henry Marrow is murdered in a violent hate crime in Oxford, North Carolina.

title: Topeka Kansas
event: Lubbock Tornado: An ''F5'' tornado hits downtown Lubbock, Texas, the first to hit a downtown district of a major city since Topeka, Kansas in 1966; 28 are killed.

title: Jackson State University
event: In the second day of violent demonstrations at Jackson State University in Jackson, Mississippi, state law enforcement officers fire into the demonstrators, killing 2 and injuring 12.

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: May 17 – Thor Heyerdahl sets sail from Morocco on the papyrus boat ''Ra II'', to sail the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Menai Strait
event: May 23 – A fire occurs in the Britannia Bridge over the Menai Strait in north Wales, contributing to its partial destruction and amounting to approximately £1,000,000 worth of fire damage.

title: Kola Superdeep Borehole
event: May 24 – The scientific drilling of the Kola Superdeep Borehole begins in the USSR.

title: Tupolev Tu-144
event: May 26 – The Soviet Tupolev Tu-144 becomes the first commercial transport to exceed Mach 2.

title: Yungay Peru
event: The 1970 Ancash earthquake causes a landslide that buries the town of Yungay, Peru; more than 47,000 people are killed.

title: Soyuz 9
event: June 1 – ''Soyuz 9'', a two man spacecraft, is launched in the Soviet Union.

title: North Sea
event: June 2 – Norway announces that it has rich oil deposits off its North Sea coast.

title: United Kingdom
event: June 4 – Tonga gains independence from the United Kingdom.

title: New York
event: June 7 – The Who become the first act to perform rock music (their rock opera, Tommy) at the Metropolitan Opera House, New York.

title: Argentina
event: June 8 – A coup in Argentina brings a new junta of service chiefs; on June 18, Roberto M. Levingston becomes President.

title: Nizwa
event: June 12 – N.D.F.L.O.A.G. guerrillas attack military garrisons at Izki and Nizwa in Oman.

title: University of Northern Colorado
event: Colorado State College changes its name to University of Northern Colorado.

title: Ontario
event: July 6 – Air Canada Flight 621 catches fire after landing at Toronto International Airport, Toronto, Ontario; all 109 passengers and crew are killed.

title: Pyrenees
event: July 11 – The first tunnel under the Pyrenees links the towns of Aragnouet (France) and Bielsa (Spain).

title: Barbados
event: July 12 – Thor Heyerdahl's papyrus boat ''Ra II'' arrives in Barbados.

title: Pittsburgh
event: July 16 – Three Rivers Stadium in Pittsburgh opens.

title: Gulf Stream
event: August 17 – August 18 – The U.S. sinks 418 containers of nerve gas into the Gulf Stream near the Bahamas.

title: New York City
event: August 26 – The Women's Strike for Equality takes place down Fifth Avenue in New York City.

title: Amman
event: Fighting breaks out between Arab guerillas and government forces in Amman, Jordan.

title: Guinea
event: Guinea recognizes East Germany.

title: Phoenix Arizona
event: Elvis Presley begins his first concert tour since 1958 in Phoenix, Arizona at the Veterans Memorial Coliseum.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: September 27 – Richard Nixon begins a tour of Europe, visiting Italy, Yugoslavia, Spain, the United Kingdom and Ireland.

title: Utah State University
event: October 2 – The Wichita State University football team's Gold plane crashes in Colorado, killing most of the players. They were on their way (along with administrators and fans) to a game with Utah State University.

title: Bolivia
event: In Bolivia, Army Commander General Rogelio Miranda and a group of officers rebel and demand the resignation of President Alfredo Ovando Candía, who fires him.

title: Los Angeles
event: In Los Angeles, Rock and blues singer Janis Joplin dies in her hotel room, from an overdose of heroin.

title: Quebec
event: The Front de libération du Québec (FLQ) kidnaps James Cross in Montreal and demands release of all its imprisoned members. The next day the Canadian government announces it will not meet the demand, beginning Quebec's October Crisis.

title: Khmer Republic
event: October 9 – The Khmer Republic is proclaimed in Cambodia.

title: Fiji
event: Fiji becomes independent.

title: Quebec
event: October Crisis: In Montreal, Quebec, a national crisis hits Canada when Quebec Minister of Labour Pierre Laporte becomes the second statesman kidnapped by members of the FLQ terrorist group.

title: People's Republic of China
event: Canada and the People's Republic of China establish diplomatic relations.

title: Melbourne
event: A section of the new West Gate Bridge in Melbourne collapses into the river below, killing 35 construction workers.

title: Istanbul
event: A cholera epidemic breaks out in Istanbul.

title: South Carolina
event: October 25 – The wreck of the Confederate submarine ''Hunley'' is found off Charleston, South Carolina, by pioneer underwater archaeologist, Dr. E. Lee Spence, then just 22 years old. ''Hunley'' was the first submarine in history to sink a ship in warfare.

title: France
event: November 1 – Club Cinq-Sept fire in Saint-Laurent-du-Pont, France, kills 146.

title: Sudan
event: November 8 – Egypt, Libya and Sudan announce their intentions to form a federation.

title: Massachusetts
event: Vietnam War: The Supreme Court of the United States votes 6–3 not to hear a case by the state of Massachusetts, about the constitutionality of a state law granting Massachusetts residents the right to refuse military service in an undeclared war.

title: Bangladesh
event: 1970 Bhola cyclone: A 120-mph (193 km/h) tropical cyclone hits the densely populated Ganges Delta region of East Pakistan (now Bangladesh), killing an estimated 500,000 people (considered the 20th century's worst cyclone disaster).

title: Marshall University
event: Southern Airlines Flight 932 crashes in Wayne County, West Virginia; all 75 on board, including 37 players and 5 coaches from the Marshall University football team, are killed.

title: Lunokhod 1
event: Luna program: The Soviet Union lands ''Lunokhod 1'' on Mare Imbrium (Sea of Rains) on the Moon. This is the first roving remote-controlled robot to land on another world, and is released by the orbiting Luna 17 spacecraft.

title: North Vietnam
event: U.S. President Richard Nixon asks the U.S. Congress for US$155 million in supplemental aid for the Cambodian government (US$85 million is for military assistance to prevent the overthrow of the government of Premier Lon Nol by the Khmer Rouge and North Vietnam).

title: Operation Ivory Coast
event: Vietnam War – Operation Ivory Coast: A joint Air Force and Army team raids the Son Tay prison camp in an attempt to free American POWs thought to be held there (no Americans are killed, but the prisoners have already moved to another camp; all U.S. POWs are moved to a handful of central prison complexes as a result of this raid).

title: Conakry
event: November 22 – Guinean president Sekou Toure accuses Portugal of an attack when hundreds of mercenaries land near the capital Conakry.

title: Tokyo
event: November 25 – In Tokyo, author and Tatenokai militia leader Yukio Mishima and his followers take over the headquarters of the Japan Self-Defense Forces. When Mishima's speech fails to sway public opinion towards his right-wing political beliefs, he commits seppuku.

title: Manila
event: November 27 – Bolivian artist Benjamin Mendoza tries to assassinate Pope Paul VI during his visit in Manila.

title: People's Republic of China
event: Ethiopia recognizes the People's Republic of China.

title: San Sebastián
event: The Basque ETA kidnaps West German Eugen Beihl in San Sebastián.

title: United Kingdom
event: December 3 – October Crisis: In Montreal, Quebec, kidnapped British Trade Commissioner James Cross is released by the Front de libération du Québec terrorist group after being held hostage for 60 days. Police negotiate his release and in return the Government of Canada grants 5 terrorists from the FLQ's Chenier Cell their request for safe passage to Cuba.

title: Rio de Janeiro
event: Giovanni Enrico Bucher, the Swiss ambassador to Brazil, is kidnapped in Rio de Janeiro; kidnappers demand the release of 70 political prisoners.

title: South Africa
event: The U.N. General Assembly supports the isolation of South Africa for its apartheid policies.

title: Warsaw Ghetto
event: During his visit to the Polish capital, German Chancellor Willy Brandt goes down on his knees in front of a monument to the victims of the Warsaw Ghetto.

title: Libya
event: The Libyan Revolutionary Council declares that it will nationalize all foreign banks in the country.

title: Bolivia
event: The Bolivian government releases Régis Debray.

title: World Trade Center
event: The North Tower of the World Trade Center is topped out at 1,368 feet (417 m), making it the tallest building in the world.

title: India
event: December 27 – India's president declares new elections.

title: Francisco Franco
event: Francisco Franco commutes the death sentences of the Burgos Trial defendants to 30 years in prison.

title: Massachusetts
event: June – Massachusetts passes its Chapter 766 laws enacting Special Education.

title: Camden New Jersey
event: August – Camden, New Jersey erupts in race riots following the beating death of a Puerto Rican motorist by city police. Looting and arson occurred. This was a turning point in Camden's decline to one of the poorest and highest-crime municipalities in the United States. Camden was, however, the site of a 1949 shooting rampage by Howard Unruh, considered by some to be the first mass murderer in the United States. The riots resulted in the demise of Camden's Sears and A&P branches. Also in 1971, Philadelphia International Records was established, with Camden native Leon Huff as co-founder.

title: Mahé Seychelles
event: Seychelles International Airport in Victoria, Seychelles (Mahe) is completed.

title: Ibrox disaster
event: Ibrox disaster: A stairway crush at the Rangers vs. Celtic football match in Glasgow, Scotland kills 66.

title: United Kingdom
event: January 3 – BBC Open University begins in the United Kingdom.

title: Brazil
event: January 14 – Seventy Brazilian political prisoners are released in Santiago, Chile. Giovanni Enrico Bucher is released January 16.

title: Florida
event: January 17 – Super Bowl V: The Baltimore Colts defeat the Dallas Cowboys 16–13 at the Orange Bowl in Miami, Florida.

title: Persian Gulf
event: January 19 – Representatives of 23 western oil companies begin negotiations with OPEC in Tehran to stabilize oil prices. February 14 they sign a treaty with 6 Persian Gulf countries.

title: Guinea
event: January 24 – The Guinean government sentences to death 92 Guineans who helped Portuguese troops in the failed landing attempts in November 1970; 72 are sentenced to hard labor for life; 58 of the sentenced are hanged the next day.

title: Uganda
event: In Uganda, Idi Amin deposes Milton Obote in a coup, and becomes president.

title: Los Angeles
event: In Los Angeles, Charles Manson and three female Family members are found guilty of the 1969 Tate-LaBianca murders.

title: India
event: Himachal Pradesh becomes the 18th Indian state.

title: Apollo 14
event: January 31 – Apollo program: ''Apollo 14'' (carrying astronauts Alan Shepard, Stuart Roosa, and Edgar Mitchell) lifts off on the third successful lunar landing mission.

title: Apollo 14
event: February 5 – ''Apollo 14'' lands on the Moon.

title: Italy
event: An earthquake in the city of Tuscania, Italy kills 31.

title: Switzerland
event: Switzerland gives women voting rights in state elections, but not in all canton-specific ones.

title: California
event: The Sylmar earthquake (6.4 on the Richter Scale) hits the San Fernando Valley area of California.

title: Apollo 14
event: Apollo program: ''Apollo 14'' returns to Earth after the third manned Moon landing.

title: Amman
event: February 11–February 12 – Palestinian and Jordanian fighters clash in Amman.

title: Kingdom of Laos
event: February 13 – Vietnam War: Backed by American air and artillery support, South Vietnamese troops invade Laos.

title: Brussels
event: Protesting Belgian farmers bring 3 live cows to crash the EEC meeting in Brussels.

title: Italy
event: February 16 – In Italy, a local parliament elects the city of Catanzaro as the capital of Calabria; residents of Reggio di Calabria riot for 5 days because of the decision.

title: Mississippi
event: Fifty tornadoes rage in Mississippi, killing 74 people.

title: Vienna
event: February 21 – The Convention on Psychotropic Substances is signed at Vienna.

title: United States Capitol
event: A bomb explodes in the men's room at the United States Capitol.  Weather Underground Organization claims responsibility.

title: Montreal
event: March 4 – The southern part of Quebec, and especially Montreal, receive 42 cm of snow in what becomes known as the Century's Snowstorm (''la tempête du siècle'').

title: Switzerland
event: March 6 – A fire in a mental hospital at Burghölzli, Switzerland, kills 28 people.

title: Dhaka
event: Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, political leader of then East Pakistan (present day - Bangladesh), delivers his famous speech in the Racecourse Field in Dhaka, calling on the masses to be prepared to fight for national independence.

title: Madison Square Garden
event: March 8 – Boxer Joe Frazier defeats Muhammad Ali at Madison Square Garden.

title: Fillmore East
event: March 12–March 13 – The Allman Brothers Band plays their legendary concert at the Fillmore East.

title: Lake Yanahuani
event: March 18 – A landslide at Chungar, Peru crashes into Lake Yanahuani, killing 200.

title: Argentina
event: March 23 – General Alejandro Lanusse of Argentina takes power in a military coup.

title: Chittagong
event: East Pakistan (now Bangladesh) independence is declared by local Awami League leader Hannan Sarker on behalf of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, from Kalurghat Radio Station in Chittagong.

title: Chittagong
event: March 27 – East Pakistan (now Bangladesh) independence is repeatedly declared by Army Major (later President of Bangladesh) Ziaur Rahman on behalf of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman from Kalurghat Radio Station, Chittagong.

title: United Kingdom
event: April 1 – The United Kingdom lifts all restrictions on gold ownership.

title: Monaco
event: April 3 – ''Un banc, un arbre, une rue'' by Séverine (music by Jean-Pierre Bourtayre, text by Yves Dessca) wins the Eurovision Song Contest 1971 for Monaco.

title: Mount Etna
event: Mount Etna erupts in Sicily.

title: Greece
event: April 7 – Greece releases 261 political prisoners, 50 of whom are sent into internal exile.

title: Amman
event: April 12 – Palestinians retreat from Amman to the north of Jordan.

title: Bangladesh
event: The People's Republic of Bangladesh forms, under Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, at Mujibnagor.

title: Libya
event: Libya, Syria and Egypt sign an agreement to form a confederation.

title: India
event: The government of Bangladesh flees to India.

title: Sierra Leone
event: Sierra Leone becomes a republic.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: ''Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education'': The Supreme Court of the United States rules unanimously that busing of students may be ordered to achieve racial desegregation.

title: Sierra Leone
event: Siaka Stevens is elected the first president of Sierra Leone.

title: Ryukyu Islands
event: A tsunami 85 m high rises over the Ryukyu Islands in Japan. It throws a 750-ton block of coral 2.5 km inland.

title: Ankara
event: April 26 – The government of Turkey declares a state of siege in 11 provinces, Ankara included, due to violent demonstrations.

title: Italy
event: April 28 – The first number of ''Il Manifesto'' is issued in Italy.

title: Bolivia
event: April 29 – Bolivia nationalizes the American-owned Matilde zinc mine.

title: Switzerland
event: May 5 – The US dollar floods the European currency markets and threatens especially the Deutsche Mark; the central banks of Austria, Belgium, Netherlands and Switzerland stop the currency trading.

title: Burdur
event: May 12 – An earthquake in Turkey destroys most of the city of Burdur.

title: Istanbul
event: May 15 – Efraim Elrom, Israeli ambassador to Turkey, is kidnapped; he is found killed in Istanbul May 25.

title: United Kingdom
event: May 23 – An air crash at Rijeka Airport, Yugoslavia kills 78 people, mostly British tourists.

title: People's Republic of China
event: Austria and the People's Republic of China establish diplomatic relations.

title: Vienna
event: Six armed passengers hijack a Romanian passenger plane and force it to fly to Vienna.

title: UNESCO
event: May 28 – Portugal resigns from UNESCO.

title: Bangladesh
event: May 31 – The birth of Bangladesh is declared by the government in exile, in territory formerly part of Pakistan.

title: Soyuz 11
event: Soyuz program: ''Soyuz 11'' (Vladislav Volkov, Georgi Dobrovolski, Viktor Patsayev) is launched.

title: Duarte California
event: A midair collision between Hughes Airwest Flight 706 Douglas DC-9 jetliner and a U.S. Marine Corps McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom jet fighter near Duarte, California, claims 50 lives.

title: People's Republic of China
event: The U.S. ends its trade embargo of China.

title: Parliament of Australia
event: June 11 – Neville Bonner becomes the first Indigenous Australian to sit in the Australian Parliament.

title: North Sea
event: June 14 – Norway begins oil production in the North Sea.

title: San Antonio
event: June 18 – Southwest Airlines, a low cost carrier, begins its first flights between Dallas, Houston, And San Antonio.

title: Madagascar
event: June 25 – Madagascar accuses the U.S. of being connected to the plot to oust the current government; the U.S. recalls its ambassador.

title: Fillmore East
event: June 27 – Concert promoter Bill Graham closes the legendary Fillmore East, which first opened on 2nd Avenue (between 5th and 6th Streets) in New York City on March 8, 1968.

title: Soyuz 11
event: After a successful mission aboard ''Salyut 1'', the world's first manned space station, the crew of the ''Soyuz 11'' spacecraft are killed when their air supply leaks out through a faulty valve.

title: France
event: July 3 – Jim Morrison, leader of The Doors is found dead in his bathtub in Paris, France.

title: Malawi
event: July 6 – Hastings Banda is proclaimed President for Life of Malawi.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 9 – The United Kingdom increases its troops in Northern Ireland to 11,000.

title: Yugoslavia
event: The Yugoslavian government begins allowing foreign companies to take their profits from the country.

title: Tiger Stadium (Detroit)
event: Paced by a prodigious home run by Reggie Jackson which hits a transformer on the roof of Tiger Stadium, the American League defeats the National League 6-4 in the Major League Baseball All-Star Game in Detroit.

title: Libya
event: July 14 – Libya severs its diplomatic ties with Morocco.

title: Francisco Franco
event: July 16 – Spanish dictator and head of state Francisco Franco makes Prince Juan Carlos his successor.

title: Italy
event: July 17 – Italy and Austria sign a treaty that ends the schism about Alto Adige/Südtirol.

title: Persian Gulf
event: July 18 – The Trucial States are formed in the Persian Gulf.

title: World Trade Center
event: July 19 – The South Tower of the World Trade Center is topped out at 1,362 feet, making it the second tallest building in the world.

title: Sudan
event: July 19–July 23 – Major Hashem al-Atta ousts Jaafar Muhammad al-Nimeiri in a military coup in Sudan.   Fighting continues until on July 22, when pro-Nimeiri troops win. Al-Atta and 3 officers are executed.

title: Apollo 15
event: July 26 – ''Apollo 15'' (carrying astronauts David Scott, Alfred Worden, and James Irwin) is launched.

title: Sudan
event: July 28 – Abdel Khaliq Mahjub, Sudanese communist leader, is hanged.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 29 – The United Kingdom opts out of the Space Race, with the cancellation of its Black Arrow launch vehicle.

title: Apollo 15
event: July 31 – ''Apollo 15'' astronauts David Scott and James Irwin become the first to ride in a lunar rover, a day after landing on the Moon.

title: New York City
event: August 1 – In New York City, 40,000 attend the Concert for Bangladesh.

title: Apollo 15
event: August 7 – ''Apollo 15'' returns to Earth.

title: India
event: India signs a 20-year treaty of friendship and cooperation with the Soviet Union.

title: Maze (HM Prison)
event: Internment in Northern Ireland: British security forces arrest hundreds of nationalists and detain them without trial in Long Kesh prison; 20 people die in the riots that follow.

title: New Orleans
event: August 11 – Construction begins on the Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: Three thousand people from Belfast and Derry flee to the Republic of Ireland because of the violence.{{Citation neededdate=March 2010}}

title: Ireland
event: British troops are stationed on the Ireland border to stop arms smuggling.

title: Bahrain
event: Bahrain declares independence as the State of Bahrain (Kingdom of Bahrain as of February 2002).

title: Bretton Woods system
event: President Richard Nixon announces that the United States will no longer convert dollars to gold at a fixed value, effectively ending the Bretton Woods system. He also imposes a 90-day freeze on wages, prices and rents.

title: New Zealand
event: Vietnam War: Australia and New Zealand decide to withdraw their troops from Vietnam.

title: Bolivia
event: August 19–August 22 – A right-wing coup ignites a rebellion in Bolivia. Miners and students join troops to support president Juan Jose Torres, but eventually Hugo Banzer takes over.

title: San Clemente California
event: The USS Manatee (AO-58) spills 1,000 gallons of fuel oil on President Nixon's Western White House beach in San Clemente, California.

title: Philippines
event: A bomb made of two hand grenades by communist rebels explodes in the Liberal Party campaign party in Plaza Miranda in Quiapo, Manila the Philippines, injuring several anti-Marcos political candidates.

title: Uganda
event: Border clashes occur between Tanzania and Uganda.

title: Bengal
event: Bangladesh and eastern Bengal are flooded; thousands flee the area.

title: Greece
event: August 26 – A civilian government takes power in Greece.

title: Alberta
event: August 30 – The Progressive Conservatives under Peter Lougheed defeat the Social Credit government under Harry E. Strom in a general election, ending 36 years of uninterrupted power for Social Credit in Alberta.

title: United Kingdom
event: Qatar gains independence from the United Kingdom. Unlike most nearby emirates, Qatar declines to become part of either the United Arab Emirates or Saudi Arabia.

title: NATO
event: Manlio Brosio resigns as NATO Secretary General.

title: Juneau Alaska
event: September 4 – A Boeing 727 (Alaska Airlines Flight 1866) crashes into the side of a mountain near Juneau, Alaska, killing all 111 people on board.

title: John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts
event: September 8 – In Washington, DC, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is inaugurated, with the opening feature being the premiere of Leonard Bernstein's ''Mass''.

title: Attica (town) New York
event: September 9 – September 13 – Attica Prison riots: – A revolt breaks out at the maximum-security prison in Attica, New York. In the end, state police and the United States National Guard storm the facility; 42 are killed, 10 of them hostages.

title: India
event: September 29 – A cyclone in the Bay of Bengal, in Orissa State in India, kills 10,000.

title: Orlando Florida
event: October 1 – Walt Disney World opens in Orlando, Florida

title: Iran
event: October 15 – The 2,500 Year Celebration of Iran begins, celebrating the birth of Persia.

title: New York City
event: October 18 – In New York City, the Knapp Commission begins public hearings on police corruption.

title: Republic of China
event: October 25 – The United Nations General Assembly admits the People's Republic of China and expels the Republic of China (or Taiwan).

title: Zaire
event: October 27 – The Democratic Republic of the Congo is renamed Zaire.

title: United Kingdom
event: The United Kingdom becomes the 6th nation to launch a satellite into orbit, the Prospero X-3, using a Black Arrow carrier rocket.

title: Cairo
event: The Egyptian Opera House (Khedivial Opera House) burns down in Cairo.

title: London
event: October 31 – A bomb explodes at the top of the Post Office Tower in London.

title: Alaska
event: November 6 – Operation Grommet: The U.S. tests a thermonuclear warhead at Amchitka Island in Alaska, code-named Project Cannikin.   At around 5 megatons, it is the largest ever U.S. underground detonation.

title: Phnom Penh
event: November 10 – In Cambodia, Khmer Rouge forces attack Phnom Penh and its airport, killing 44, wounding at least 30 and damaging 9 airplanes.

title: Brazil
event: November 20 – A bridge still in construction, called Elevado Engenheiro Freyssinet, falls over the Paulo de Frontin Avenue, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; 48 people are killed and several injured. Reconstructed, the bridge is currently a part of the Linha Vermelha elevate.

title: Republic of China
event: November 23 – The People's Republic of China takes the Republic of China's seat on the United Nations Security Council (see China and the United Nations).

title: D. B. Cooper
event: During a severe thunderstorm over Washington, a man calling himself D. B. Cooper parachutes from the Northwest Orient Airlines plane he hijacked, with US$200,000 in ransom money, and is never seen again (as of March 2008, this case remains the only unsolved skyjacking in history).

title: Greece
event: A Brussels court sentences pretender Alexis Brimeyer to 18 months in jail for falsely using a noble title; Brimeyer has already fled to Greece.

title: Phnom Penh
event: December 1 – Cambodian Civil War: Khmer Rouge rebels intensify assaults on Cambodian government positions, forcing their retreat from Kompong Thmar and nearby Ba Ray, 10 kilometers northeast of Phnom Penh.

title: Persian Gulf
event: December 2 – Six Persian Gulf sheikdoms found the United Arab Emirates.

title: India
event: December 3–December 4 – The Indian navy destroyer ''INS Rajput'' sinks Pakistani submarine PNS ''Ghazi'' (former USS ''Diablo'').

title: Belfast
event: The McGurk's Bar bombing in Belfast kills 15.

title: Malta
event: December 29 – The United Kingdom gives up its military bases in Malta.

title: Iraq
event: June – Iraq nationalizes the Iraq Petroleum Company.

title: North Vietnam
event: July – U.S. actress Jane Fonda tours North Vietnam, during which she is photographed sitting on a North Vietnamese anti-aircraft gun.

title: Honolulu
event: At a scientific meeting in Honolulu, Herbert Boyer and Stanley N. Cohen conceive the concept of recombinant DNA. They publish their results in November 1973 in PNAS. Separately in 1972, Paul Berg also recombines DNA in a test tube. Recombinant DNA technology has dramatically changed the field of biological sciences, especially biotechnology, and opened the door to genetically modified organisms.

title: UNESCO
event: The ''International Year of the Book''  is designated by UNESCO.

title: Yugoslavia
event: The last major epidemic of smallpox in Europe breaks out in Yugoslavia.

title: Special Air Service
event: The United Kingdom begin to train Special Air Service for anti-terrorist duties.

title: Amstel
event: The tea house Mellow Yellow opens on the Amstel River in Amsterdam, pioneering the legal sale of cannabis in the Netherlands.

title: Dartmouth College
event: The first women are admitted to Dartmouth College.

title: Ciudad Perdida
event: Colombian looters find Ciudad Perdida but keep it a secret until the government reveals it in 1975.

title: Yellow River
event: The Yellow River dries up for the first time in known history.

title: United Kingdom
event: The Second Cod War breaks out between the United Kingdom and Iceland.

title: University of East Anglia
event: The Climatic Research Unit is founded by climatologist Hubert Lamb at the University of East Anglia.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia bans the cultural organization Matica hrvatska, founded in 1842.

title: New York City
event: Pierre Hotel Robbery: Six men rob the safety deposit boxes of The Pierre Hotel in New York City of at least $4 million.

title: London
event: Rose Heilbron becomes the first woman judge at the Old Bailey in London.

title: Hong Kong
event: January 9 – The RMS ''Queen Elizabeth'' is destroyed by fire in Hong Kong harbor.

title: Bangladesh
event: January 10 – Father of The Nation Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman returns Bangladesh from Pakistan

title: Ghana
event: January 13 – Prime Minister of Ghana Kofi Abrefa Busia is overthrown in a military coup.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: January 19 – The Libertarian enclave Minerva on a platform in the South Pacific, sponsored by the Phoenix Foundation, declares independence. Soon neighboring Tonga annexes the area and dismantles the platform.

title: Guam
event: January 24 – Japanese soldier Shoichi Yokoi is discovered in Guam; he had spent 28 years in the jungle.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: Yugoslavian air stewardess Vesna Vulović is the only survivor when her plane crashes in Czechoslovakia.   She survives after falling 10,160 meters in the tail section of the aircraft.

title: Canberra
event: The Aboriginal Tent Embassy is set up on the lawn of Parliament House in Canberra.

title: Bloody Sunday (1972)
event: Bloody Sunday: The British Army kills 14 unarmed nationalist civil rights marchers in Derry, Northern Ireland.

title: Nepal
event: January 31 – King Birendra succeeds his father as King of Nepal.

title: Ireland
event: Anti-British riots take place throughout Ireland. The British Embassy in Dublin is burned to the ground, as are several British-owned businesses.

title: Basketball Hall of Fame
event: Bob Douglas becomes the first African American elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: Mount Asama
event: February 19 – Asama-Sansō incident: Five United Red Army members break into a lodge below Mount Asama, taking the wife of the lodge keeper hostage.

title: People's Republic of China
event: February 21–February 28 – U.S. President Richard M. Nixon makes an unprecedented 8-day visit to the People's Republic of China and meets with Mao Zedong.

title: Aden
event: A Lufthansa plane is hijacked and taken to Aden. Passengers are released after a ransom of 16 million German marks is agreed.

title: Caruthers California
event: February 23 – Angela Davis is released from jail.   A Caruthers, California farmer, Rodger McAfee, helps her make bail.

title: West Virginia
event: A coal sludge spill kills 125 people in Buffalo Creek, West Virginia.

title: Ubon Ratchathani Province
event: The Thai province Yasothon is created after being split off from the Ubon Ratchathani Province.

title: Georgia (U.S. state)
event: March 3 – Sculpted figures of Jefferson Davis, Robert E. Lee, and Stonewall Jackson are completed at Stone Mountain, Georgia.

title: Libya
event: Libya and the Soviet Union sign a cooperation treaty.

title: People's Republic of China
event: The United Kingdom and the People's Republic of China elevate diplomatic exchanges to the ambassadorial level after 22 years.

title: New York
event: Clifford Irving admits to a New York court that he had fabricated Howard Hughes' autobiography.

title: Pruitt–Igoe
event: March 16 – The first building of the Pruitt–Igoe housing development is destroyed.

title: Bangladesh
event: March 19 – India and Bangladesh sign a friendship treaty.

title: United Kingdom
event: The British government announces the prorogation of the Parliament of Northern Ireland and the introduction of 'Direct Rule' of Northern Ireland, after the Unionist government refuses to cede security powers.

title: Mount Fuji
event: An avalanche on Mount Fuji kills 19 climbers.

title: Bradford
event: The last trolleybus system in the United Kingdom closes in Bradford, West Riding of Yorkshire after over 60 years of operation.

title: North Vietnam
event: March 30 – Vietnam War: The Easter Offensive begins after North Vietnamese forces cross into the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) of South Vietnam.

title: Iran
event: A 7.0 Richter scale earthquake kills 5,000 people in the Iranian province of Fars.

title: Dorothy Chandler Pavilion
event: The 44th Annual Academy Awards are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles.

title: Taiwan
event: April 13 – The Universal Postal Union decides to recognize the People's Republic of China as the only legitimate Chinese representative, effectively expelling the Republic of China administering Taiwan.

title: Apollo 16
event: ''Apollo 16'' (John Young, Ken Mattingly, Charlie Duke) is launched.   During the mission, the astronauts achieve a lunar rover speed record of 18 km/h.

title: North Vietnam
event: Vietnam War – Nguyen Hue Offensive: Prompted by the North Vietnamese offensive, the United States resumes bombing of Hanoi and Haiphong.

title: Idaho
event: May 2 – Fire in a silver mine in Idaho kills 91.

title: Italy
event: May 7 – General elections are held in Italy.

title: Laurel Maryland
event: Governor George C. Wallace of Alabama is shot by Arthur Herman Bremer at a Laurel, Maryland political rally.

title: Special Air Service
event: May 18 – Four troopers of both SAS and SBS are parachuted onto the ''RMS Queen Elizabeth 2'', {{convert1000mikm}} off Britain in the Atlantic, after a bomb threat and ransom demand, which turns out to be bogus.

title: Pietà (Michelangelo)
event: May 21 – In Rome, Laszlo Toth attacks Michelangelo's Pietà statue with a sledgehammer, shouting that he is Jesus Christ.

title: NASA
event: Wernher von Braun retires from NASA, frustrated by the agency's unwillingness to pursue a manned trans-orbital space program.

title: Australia
event: Willandra National Park is established in Australia.

title: United Kingdom
event: The Angry Brigade goes on trial in the United Kingdom.

title: Israel
event: May 30 – Three Japanese Red Army members kill 24 and injure 100 in Lod Airport, Israel.

title: South Dakota
event: June 9 – The Black Hills flood kills 238 in South Dakota.

title: Colorado
event: June 15–June 18 – The first U.S. Libertarian Party National Convention is held in Denver, Colorado.

title: France
event: June 16 – 108 die as two passenger trains hit the debris of a collapsed railway tunnel near Soissons, France.

title: White House
event: Watergate scandal: Five White House operatives are arrested for burglarizing the offices of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Federal Bureau of Investigation
event: June 23 – Watergate Scandal: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon and White House chief of staff H. R. Haldeman are taped talking about using the C.I.A. to obstruct the F.B.I.'s investigation into the Watergate break-ins.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: June 29 – ''Furman v. Georgia'': The Supreme Court of the United States rules that the death penalty is unconstitutional.

title: Oceania
event: The Canadian ketch ''Vega'', flying the Greenpeace III banner, collides with the French naval minesweeper ''La Paimpolaise'' while in international waters, to protest French nuclear weapon tests in the South Pacific.

title: India
event: July 2 – Following Pakistan's surrender to India in the Indo-Pakistani War of 1971, both nations sign the historic Simla Agreement, agreeing to settle their disputes bilaterally.

title: Colorado
event: July 4 – The first Rainbow Gathering is held in Colorado.

title: Pruitt–Igoe
event: July 15 – The Pruitt–Igoe housing development is demolished in Saint Louis, Missouri.

title: Belfast
event: Bloody Friday: 22 bombs planted by the Provisional IRA explode in Belfast, Northern Ireland; nine people are killed and 130 seriously injured.

title: Milwaukee
event: Comedian George Carlin is arrested by Milwaukee police for public obscenity, for reciting his Seven Words You Can Never Say On Television at Summerfest.

title: Belfast
event: Operation Motorman, 4:00 <small>AM</small>: British Army begins to regain control of the no-go areas established by Irish republican paramilitaries in Belfast, Derry (Free Derry) and Newry.

title: Claudy
event: Claudy bombing (“Bloody Monday”), 10:00 <small>AM</small>: Three car bombs in Claudy, County Londonderry, kill nine. It becomes public knowledge only in 2010 that that a local Catholic priest was an IRA officer believed to be involved in the bombings but his rôle was covered up by the authorities.

title: Uganda
event: Dictator Idi Amin declares that Uganda will expel 50,000 Asians with British passports to Britain within 3 months.

title: Rabat
event: August 16 – As part of a coup attempt, members of the Royal Moroccan Air Force fire upon, but fail to bring down, Hassan II of Morocco's plane while he is traveling back to Rabat.

title: Florida
event: August 21 – The Republican National Convention in Miami Beach, Florida renominates U.S. President Richard Nixon and Vice President Spiro Agnew for a second term.

title: Reykjavík
event: September 1 – Bobby Fischer defeats Boris Spassky in a chess match at Reykjavík, Iceland, becoming the first American chess champion (see Match of the Century).

title: Israel
event: September 5–September 6 – Munich Massacre: Eleven Israeli athletes at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich are murdered after 8 members of the Arab terrorist group Black September invade the Olympic Village; 5 guerillas and 1 policeman are also killed in a failed hostage rescue.

title: Tanzania
event: September 17 – Uganda announces that there are Tanzanian troops in its territory.

title: Brazil
event: September 18 – São Paulo Metro is inaugurated in Brazil.

title: London
event: September 19 – A parcel bomb sent to the Israeli Embassy in London kills 1 diplomat.

title: Philippines
event: September 23 – Philippine president Ferdinand Marcos issues Proclamation No. 1081 placing the entire country under martial law.

title: Sacramento Executive Airport
event: September 24 – An F-86 fighter aircraft leaving an air show at Sacramento Executive Airport fails to become airborne and crashes into a Farrell's Ice Cream Parlor, killing 12 children and 11 adults.

title: Beijing
event: September 27 – The Joint Communique of the Government of Japan and the Government of the People's Republic of China is signed in Beijing.

title: Republic of China
event: September 29 – Sino-Japanese relations: Japan normalizes diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China after breaking official ties with the Republic of China (Taiwan).

title: Faroe Islands
event: October 2 – Denmark joins the European Community; the Faroe Islands stay out.

title: USS Kitty Hawk (CV-63)
event: October 12 – En route to the Gulf of Tonkin, a racial riot involving more than 200 sailors breaks out aboard the United States Navy aircraft carrier USS ''Kitty Hawk''; nearly 50 sailors are injured.

title: Uruguayan Air Force Flight 571
event: October 13 – Uruguayan Air Force Flight 571: A Fairchild FH-227D passenger aircraft transporting a rugby union team crashes at about 14,000' in the Andes mountain range, near the Argentina/Chile border. Sixteen of the survivors are found alive December 20 but they have had to resort to cannibalism to survive.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: October 17 – Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom visits Yugoslavia.

title: Federal Bureau of Investigation
event: The first female FBI agents are hired.

title: Israel
