title: South Africa
event: June 10 – Apartheid: The African National Congress in South Africa publishes a statement by their imprisoned leader Nelson Mandela.

title: Lake Forest Illinois
event: June 10 – A Unabomber bomb injures United Airlines president Percy Wood in Lake Forest, Illinois.

title: Aerolinee Itavia Flight 870
event: June 26 – Aerolinee Itavia Flight 870 crashes into the sea near Palermo after an explosion occurs in the air; 81 people die. A bomb or a missile is suspected to be the cause of the accident but no culprits are ever found.

title: Lublin
event: July 8 – A wave of strikes begins in Lublin, Poland

title: Brazil
event: July 9 – Pope John Paul II visits Brazil; 7 people are crushed to death in a crowd meeting him.

title: Eau Claire Wisconsin
event: July 15 – A severe and destructive thunderstorm strikes 4 counties in western Wisconsin, including the city of Eau Claire. It causes over $250m in damage, and 1 person is killed.

title: California
event: July 16 – Former California Governor and actor Ronald Reagan is nominated for U.S. President, at the Republican National Convention in Detroit, Michigan. Influenced by the Religious Right, the convention also drops its long standing support for the Equal Rights Amendment, dismaying moderate Republicans.

title: Cairo
event: July 27 – Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, deposed shah of Iran, dies in Cairo.

title: Knesset
event: Israel's Knesset passes the Jerusalem Law.

title: Italy
event: August 2 – A terrorist bombing at the railway station in Bologna, Italy kills 85 people and wounds more than 200.

title: Gdańsk Shipyard
event: August 7–August 31 – Lech Wałęsa leads the first of many strikes at the  Gdańsk Shipyard.

title: New York City
event: August 14 – U.S. President Jimmy Carter defeats Senator Edward Kennedy to win renomination, at the 1980 Democratic National Convention in New York City.

title: Australia
event: August 17 – In Australia, baby Azaria Chamberlain disappears from a campsite at Ayers Rock (Uluru), reportedly taken by a dingo.

title: Riyadh
event: August 19 – In one of aviation's worst disasters, 301 persons are killed when Saudia Flight 163 catches fire in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

title: Gdańsk Shipyard
event: August 31 – Victory of the strike in Gdańsk Shipyard, Poland. Gdańsk Agreement is signed, opening a way to start the first in the communist block free organization not controlled by regime Solidarność i.e. Solidarity.

title: Switzerland
event: September 5 – The St. Gotthard Tunnel opens in Switzerland as the world's longest highway tunnel at 10.14 miles (16.32 km), stretching from Goschenen to Airolo.

title: Gdańsk
event: After weeks of strikes at the Lenin Shipyard in Gdańsk, Poland, the nationwide independent trade union Solidarity is established.

title: Asunción
event: Former Nicaraguan President Anastasio Somoza Debayle is killed in Asunción, Paraguay.

title: Iran
event: The command council of Iraq orders its army to deliver its fatal blow on Iranian military targets, initiating the Iran–Iraq War.

title: Estonia
event: Youth riots in the capital of the Soviet Republic of Estonia are quickly forced down.

title: Chlef
event: El Asnam, Algeria is destroyed by an earthquake, which claims more than 2,600 lives. After the quake, El Asnam is rebuilt and changes its name to the city of Chlef.

title: United Kingdom
event: James Callaghan announces his resignation as Leader of the British Labour Party.

title: Australia
event: October 18 – The Fraser Government is re-elected for a third consecutive term in Australia with a reduced majority.

title: Maze (HM Prison)
event: October 27 – Six Provisional Irish Republican Army prisoners in Maze prison refuse food and demand status as political prisoners; the hunger strike lasts until December.

title: International Court of Justice
event: October 30 – El Salvador and Honduras sign a peace treaty to put the border dispute fought over in 1969's Football War before the International Court of Justice.

title: Iran
event: Reza Pahlavi, eldest son of the shah of Iran, proclaims himself the rightful successor to the Peacock Throne.

title: California
event: November 4 – United States presidential election, 1980: Republican challenger and former Governor Ronald Reagan of California defeats incumbent Democratic President Jimmy Carter, exactly 1 year after the beginning of the Iran hostage crisis.

title: NASA
event: November 10 – November 12 – Voyager program: The NASA space probe ''Voyager I'' makes its closest approach to Saturn, when it flies within 77,000 miles of the planet's cloud-tops and sends the first high resolution images of the world back to scientists on Earth.

title: Lake Peigneur
event: A Texaco oil rig breaks through to a mine under Lake Peigneur.

title: Las Vegas Strip
event: A fire at the MGM Grand Hotel and Casino on the Las Vegas Strip kills 85 people.

title: Italy
event: November 23 – Italy Earthquake of 1980: a magnitude 7 earthquake in southern Italy kills approximately 4,800 people and leaves 300,000 homeless.

title: New York City
event: December 8 – John Lennon, an English musician and peace activist, is murdered  in New York City.

title: Borneo
event: January – The subterranean Sarawak chamber is discovered in Borneo.

title: Australia
event: Public funding of election campaigns is introduced in New South Wales, Australia.

title: Beijing
event: The State Council of the People's Republic of China lists the 4 cities (Beijing, Hangzhou, Suzhou and Guilin) as those where the protection of historical and cultural heritage, as well as natural scenery, should be treated as a priority project.

title: India
event: Information Technology Training Institution NIIT in India is established.

title: Greece
event: Greece enters the ''European Community'', which later becomes the European Union.

title: Palau
event: Palau becomes a self-governing territory.

title: Peter Sutcliffe
event: January 4 – Sheffield police arrest Peter Sutcliffe, a 34-year-old lorry driver, on suspicion of being the Yorkshire Ripper who has killed 13 women and attacked 7 others over the last 6 years.

title: Brazil
event: January 6 – The Brazilian double decker boat ''Novo Amapo'' capsizes in the Amazon River, Belem de Cajari, Macapa, Brazil; 230 are killed.

title: Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front
event: January 10 – Salvadoran Civil War: The FMLN launches its first major offensive, gaining control of most of Morazán and Chalatenango departments.

title: Philippines
event: January 17 – Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos lifts martial law.

title: Iran
event: January 19 – United States and Iranian officials sign an agreement to release 52 American hostages after 14 months of captivity.

title: Iran
event: January 20 – Ronald Reagan succeeds Jimmy Carter, as the 40th President of the United States. Minutes later, Iran releases the 52 Americans held for 444 days, ending the Iran hostage crisis.

title: London
event: January 22 – Fowzi Nejad, sole survivor of the terrorists from the Iranian Embassy siege in London, pleads guilty to manslaughter of 2 hostages and gets jailed for life.

title: China
event: January 23 – An earthquake of 6.8 magnitude in Sichuan, China kills 150.

title: People's Republic of China
event: Chiang Ching ('Madame Mao') is sentenced to death in the People's Republic of China.

title: Louisiana
event: Super Bowl XV: The Oakland Raiders defeat the Philadelphia Eagles 27–10 at the Louisiana Superdome in New Orleans, Louisiana.

title: Java Sea
event: January 27 – The Indonesian passenger ship ''Tamponas 2'' catches fire and capsizes in the Java Sea, killing 580.

title: Las Vegas Hilton
event: February 10 – A fire at the Las Vegas Hilton hotel-casino kills 8 and injures 198.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: Stardust fire: A fire at the Stardust nightclub in Artane, Dublin, Ireland in the early hours kills 48 and injures 214.

title: Australia
event: Australia withdraws recognition of the Pol Pot regime in Cambodia.

title: Congress of Deputies (Spain)
event: February 23 – Antonio Tejero, with members of the Guardia Civil, enters the Spanish Congress of Deputies and stops the session where Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo is about to be named president of the government. The coup d'état fails thanks to King Juan Carlos.

title: Kiato
event: February 24 – A powerful, magnitude 6.7 earthquake hits Athens, killing 16 people, injuring thousands and destroying several buildings, mostly in Corinth and the nearby towns of Loutraki, Kiato and Xylokastro.

title: Maze (HM Prison)
event: March 1 – Bobby Sands, a Provisional Irish Republican Army member, begins a hunger strike for political status in Long Kesh prison (he dies May 5, the first of 10 men).

title: United Kingdom
event: March 10 – Sir Geoffrey Howe announces the British budget, which raises taxes in the middle of a recession.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 26 – The British Social Democratic Party is launched at the Connaught Rooms in London.

title: Reagan assassination attempt
event: March 30 – U.S. President Ronald Reagan is shot in the chest outside a Washington, D.C.  hotel by John Hinckley, Jr. Two police officers and Press Secretary James Brady are also wounded.

title: Los Angeles
event: March 31 – The 53rd Academy Awards, hosted by Johnny Carson, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles. Robert Redford's directorial debut in ''Ordinary People'' wins Best Picture and Best Director.

title: United Kingdom
event: April 2 – Tony Benn announces that he will challenge Denis Healey for the Deputy Leadership of the British Labour Party.

title: Pawtucket Rhode Island
event: A Minor League Baseball game between the Rochester Red Wings and the Pawtucket Red Sox at McCoy Stadium in Pawtucket, Rhode Island, becomes the longest professional baseball game in history: 8 hours and 25 minutes/33 innings (the 33rd inning is not played until June 23).

title: House of Commons of the United Kingdom
event: May 5 – Bobby Sands, Provisional Irish Republican Army volunteer and elected member of the House of Commons of the United Kingdom, dies aged 27 while on hunger strike in HM Prison Maze.

title: France
event: In the second round of the presidential elections in France, François Mitterrand beats Valéry Giscard d'Estaing.

title: Vatican City
event: May 13 – Pope John Paul II is shot and nearly killed by Mehmet Ali Ağca, a Turkish gunman, as he enters St. Peter's Square in Vatican City to address a general audience.

title: France
event: May 21 – In France, Socialist François Mitterrand becomes President.

title: Peter Sutcliffe
event: May 22 – Peter Sutcliffe is found guilty of being the Yorkshire Ripper. He is sentenced to life imprisonment on 13 counts of murder and 7 of attempted murder.

title: Bahrain
event: May 25 – In Riyadh, the Gulf Cooperation Council is created between Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.

title: Chittagong
event: May 30 – Bangladesh President Ziaur Rahman is assassinated in Chittagong.

title: California
event: June 5 – The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report that 5 homosexual men in Los Angeles, California have a rare form of pneumonia seen only in patients with weakened immune systems (the first recognized cases of AIDS).

title: India
event: June 6 – Bihar train disaster: Seven coaches of an overcrowded passenger train fall off the tracks into the River Kosi in Bihar, India; about 800 die.

title: Iraq
event: June 7 – The Israeli Air Force destroys Iraq's Osirak nuclear reactor.

title: London
event: June 13 – At the Trooping the Colour ceremony in London, Marcus Sarjeant fires 6 blank shots at Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom.

title: Philippines
event: June 26 – Couples For Christ, a Christian charismatic organization, is established in the Philippines.

title: Leeds
event: July 3 – The Toxteth riots in Liverpool, UK start after a mob saves a youth from being arrested.   Shortly afterward, the Chapeltown riots in Leeds start after increased racial tension.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: July 7 – President Ronald Reagan nominates the first woman, Sandra Day O'Connor, to the Supreme Court of the United States.

title: California
event: July 8 – California Governor Jerry Brown, faced with a Mediterranean fruit fly infestation, chooses to delay the aerial spraying of malathion, in favor of continuing ground-based eradication efforts.

title: Maze (HM Prison)
event: July 8 – Irish Republican Joe McDonnell dies at the Long Kesh Internment Camp after a 61-day hunger strike.

title: Kansas City Missouri
event: Hyatt Regency walkway collapse: Two skywalks filled with people at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Kansas City, Missouri collapse into a crowded atrium lobby, killing 114.

title: Beirut
event: Israeli aircraft bomb Beirut, destroying multi-story apartment blocks containing the offices of PLO associated groups, killing approximately 300 civilians and resulting in worldwide condemnation and a U.S. embargo on the export of aircraft to Israel.

title: Bolivia
event: In Bolivia, General Luis Gracia Meza leads a bloody coup d'état against the elected government of Lidia Gayler.

title: New Zealand
event: July 19 – The 1981 Springbok Tour commences in New Zealand, amid controversy over the support of apartheid.

title: People's Republic of China
event: July 21 – Tohui The Panda is born in Chapultepec Zoo in Mexico City, the first panda to ever be born and survive in captivity outside of China.

title: London
event: July 29 – A worldwide television audience of over 700 million people watched the  Wedding of Charles, Prince of Wales, and Lady Diana Spencer at St Paul's Cathedral in London.

title: Cleveland Stadium
event: August 9 – Major League Baseball resumes from the strike with the All-Star Game in Cleveland's Municipal Stadium.

title: Vero Beach Florida
event: August 10 – Exactly 2 weeks after his disappearance, the severed head of 6-year-old Hollywood, Florida native Adam Walsh is found in a canal in Vero Beach, Florida; to this day the rest of the boy's body has never been recovered.

title: Gulf of Sidra
event: Gulf of Sidra incident (1981): Libyan leader Muammar al-Gaddafi sends two Sukhoi Su-22 fighter jets to intercept two U.S. fighters over the Gulf of Sidra. The American jets destroy the Libyan fighters.

title: Manhattan
event: August 24 – Mark David Chapman is sentenced to 20 years to life in prison, after being convicted of murdering John Lennon in Manhattan 8 months earlier.

title: South Africa
event: August 28 – South African troops invade Angola.

title: Ramstein Air Base
event: August 31 – A bomb explodes at the U.S. Air Force base in Ramstein, West Germany, injuring 20 people.

title: Záluží (Beroun District)
event: September 4 – An explosion at a mine in Záluží, Czechoslovakia, kills 65 people.

title: Madrid
event: September 10 – Picasso's painting Guernica is moved from New York to Madrid.

title: San Bernardino California
event: September 11 – A small plane crashes into the Swing Auditorium in San Bernardino, California, damaging the venue beyond repair.

title: United Kingdom
event: September 16 – In Britain, the Liberal Party Assembly votes for an electoral pact with the new Social Democratic Party.

title: Kansas City Missouri
event: September 17 – ''Ric Flair'' defeats Dusty Rhodes to win his first World Heavyweight Wrestling Championship in Kansas City.

title: France
event: September 18 – France abolishes capital punishment.

title: New South Wales
event: The second Wranslide occurs in New South Wales, with the Wran government re-elected for a third term with an increased majority, and reducing the Liberal Party of Australia to just 14 members in the Legislative Assembly.

title: Óbidos Brazil
event: September 20 – The Brazilian river boat ''Sobral Santos'' capsizes in the Amazon River, Óbidos, Brazil, killing at least 300.

title: Belize
event: September 21 – Belize becomes independent.

title: Philadelphia
event: The Rolling Stones begin their Tattoo You tour at JFK Stadium in Philadelphia.

title: Sydney Tower
event: The Sydney Tower opens to the public.

title: France
event: TGV high speed rail service between Paris and Lyon, France begins.

title: Israel
event: October 6 – Egyptian president Anwar Sadat is assassinated during a parade by army members who belong to the Egyptian Islamic Jihad organization; they opposed his negotiations with Israel.

title: London
event: A Provisional IRA bomb at Chelsea Barracks in London kills a woman pensioner.

title: London
event: October 26 – An IRA bomb in a Wimpy Bar in Oxford Street, London, kills a bomb disposal expert.

title: Los Angeles
event: October 28 – The thrash metal band ''Metallica'' forms in Los Angeles.

title: United Kingdom
event: November 1 – Antigua and Barbuda gain independence from the United Kingdom.

title: Ontario
event: November 13 – The first Friday the 13th motorcycle event is held in Port Dover, Ontario, Canada.

title: Nicaragua
event: November 23 – Iran-Contra scandal: Ronald Reagan signs the top secret National Security Decision Directive 17 (NSDD-17), authorizing the Central Intelligence Agency to recruit and support Contra rebels in Nicaragua.

title: Mahé Seychelles
event: November 25–November 26 – A group of mercenaries led by Mike Hoare take over Mahe airport in the Seychelles in a coup attempt. Most of the mercenaries escape by a commandeered Air India passenger jet; 6 are later arrested.

title: Crosby (UK Parliament constituency)
event: November 26 – Former cabinet minister Shirley Williams wins the Crosby by-election, becoming the first elected S.D.P. MP.

title: Hollywood
event: November 29 – Hollywood actress Natalie Wood drowns, aged 43. To this day the details leading up to her death remain a mystery.

title: Corsica
event: December 1 – A Yugoslavian McDonnell Douglas DC-9 crashes into a mountain while approaching Ajaccio Airport in Corsica, killing 178.

title: South Africa
event: December 4 – South Africa grants homeland Ciskei independence (not recognized outside South Africa).

title: Whitwell Tennessee
event: The No. 21 Mine explosion in Whitwell, Tennessee kills 13.

title: NATO
event: December 10 – During the Ministerial Session of the North Atlantic Council in Brussels, Spain signs the Protocol of Accession to NATO.

title: El Mozote massacre
event: El Mozote massacre: In El Salvador, army units kill 900 civilians.

title: Beirut
event: December 15 – A car bomb destroys the Iraqi Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, killing 61 people; Syrian intelligence is blamed.

title: Cornwall
event: December 20 – The Penlee lifeboat disaster occurs off the coast of South-West Cornwall.

title: Norfolk Virginia
event: December 28 – The first American test-tube baby, Elizabeth Jordan Carr, is born in Norfolk, Virginia.

title: Ghana
event: December 31 – A coup d'état in Ghana removes President Hilla Limann's PNP government and replaces it with the PNDC led by Flight Lieutenant Jerry Rawlings.

title: Cameroon
event: Number of students graduating university in Cameroon – 10,000.

title: United Kingdom
event: January 10 – The lowest ever United Kingdom temperature of {{Convert-27.2°C°Fabbr=onlk=off}} is recorded at Braemar, in Aberdeenshire. This equals the record set in the same place in 1895 (the record is equalled again at Altnaharra in 1995).

title: Sahara
event: January 11 – Mark Thatcher, son of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, disappears in the Sahara during the Paris-Dakar Rally. He is rescued January 14.

title: Washington Metro
event: January 13 – Shortly after takeoff, Air Florida Flight 90 crashes into Washington, D.C.'s 14th Street Bridge and falls into the Potomac River, killing 78.  On the same day, a Washington Metro train derails to the north, killing 3 (the system's first fatal accident).

title: United Kingdom
event: Unemployment in the United Kingdom increases by 129,918 to 3,070,621, a post-war record.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: January 27 – The Garret FitzGerald government of the Republic of Ireland is defeated 82–81 on its budget; Fitzgerald announces his resignation.

title: Italy
event: January 28 – United States Army Brigadier General James L. Dozier is rescued by the Italian anti-terrorism Nucleo Operativo Centrale di Sicurezza (NOCS) force after being held captive for 42 days by the Red Brigades.

title: Harran
event: February 3 – Syrian president Hafez al-Assad orders the army to purge the city of Harran of the Muslim Brotherhood.

title: London
event: February 5 – London-based Laker Airways collapses, leaving 6,000 stranded passengers and debts of $270 million.

title: Tokyo Bay
event: February 9 – Japan Airlines Flight 350 crashes in Tokyo Bay due to thrust reversal on approach to Tokyo International Airport, killing 24 among the 174 people on board.

title: Newfoundland (island)
event: February 15 – The oil platform ''Ocean Ranger'' sinks during a storm off the coast of Newfoundland, killing all 84 rig workers aboard.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: February 18 – The Republic of Ireland general election gives a boost to Fianna Fáil.

title: Belfast
event: February 19 – The DeLorean Motor Company Car Factory in Belfast is put into receivership.

title: South Africa
event: February 24 – In South Africa, 22 National Party MPs led by Andries Treurnicht vote for no confidence in P. W. Botha.

title: European Court of Human Rights
event: February 25 – The European Court of Human Rights rules that teachers who cane, belt or tase children against the wishes of their parents are in breach of the Human Rights Convention.

title: London
event: March 3 – Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom opens the Barbican Centre in London.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: March 9 – Charles Haughey becomes Taoiseach of the Republic of Ireland.

title: Libya
event: The United States places an embargo on Libyan oil imports, alleging Libyan support for terrorist groups.

title: Newport Rhode Island
event: March 16 – In Newport, Rhode Island, Claus von Bülow is found guilty of the attempted murder of his wife.

title: Argentina
event: An Argentine scrap metal dealer raises the Argentine flag in South Georgia.

title: Dorothy Chandler Pavilion
event: The 54th Academy Awards, hosted by Johnny Carson, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, California. ''Chariots of Fire'' wins Best Picture and three other Academy Awards.

title: Falkland Islands
event: April 2 – The Falklands War begins: Argentina invades and occupies the Falkland Islands.

title: Invasion of South Georgia
event: April 3 – Argentina's Invasion of South Georgia

title: United Kingdom
event: April 17 – By Proclamation of the Queen of Canada on Parliament Hill, Canada patriates its constitution, gaining full political independence from the United Kingdom; included is the country's first entrenched bill of rights.

title: Conch Republic
event: April 23 – Dennis Wardlow, mayor of Key West, Florida, declares the independent Conch Republic for a day.

title: Sinai Peninsula
event: April 25 – Israel completes its withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula in accordance with the Egyptian–Israeli Peace Treaty.

title: Knoxville Tennessee
event: May 1 – A crowd of over 100,000 attends the first day of the 1982 World's Fair in Knoxville, Tennessee.  The fair is kicked off with an address by President Ronald Reagan.  Over 11 million people attend the fair during its 6-month run.

title: ARA General Belgrano
event: Falklands War: The nuclear submarine HMS ''Conqueror'' sinks the Argentine cruiser ''General Belgrano'', killing 323 sailors.

title: HMS Sheffield (D80)
event: May 4 – Falklands War: HMS ''Sheffield'' is hit by an Exocet missile, and burns out of control; 20 sailors are killed. The ship sinks on May 10.

title: Vanderbilt University
event: May 5 – A Unabomber bomb explodes in the computer science department at Vanderbilt University; secretary Janet Smith is injured.

title: Belgian Grand Prix
event: May 8 – French-Canadian racing driver Gilles Villeneuve is killed during qualifying for the Belgian Grand Prix.

title: Battle of San Carlos (1982)
event: May 21 – Falklands War: British landings sparked the Battle of San Carlos

title: HMS Ardent (F184)
event: Falklands War: HMS ''Ardent'' is sunk by Argentine aircraft, killing 22 sailors.

title: HMS Antelope (F170)
event: May 23 – Falklands War: HMS ''Antelope'' is lost

title: Khorramshahr
event: Iranian troops retake Khorramshahr.

title: Falklands War
event: May 25 – British ships HMS ''Coventry'' and Atlantic Conveyor are sunk during the Falklands War

title: Rotterdam
event: Aston Villa wins the European Cup, beating Bayern Munich 1–0 after a 69-minute goal by Peter Withe in Rotterdam.

title: Northumberland
event: Kielder Water, an artificial lake in Northumberland, is opened.

title: Beaconsfield (UK Parliament constituency)
event: Conservative candidate Tim Smith holds the seat of Beaconsfield in a by-election. The Labour Party candidate is future Prime Minister Tony Blair.

title: NATO
event: Spain becomes the 16th member of NATO and the 1st nation to enter the alliance since West Germany's admission in 1955.

title: Indianapolis 500
event: Indianapolis 500: In what Indianapolis Motor Speedway historian Donald Davidson and Speedway public address announcer Tom Carnegie later call the greatest moment in the track's history, 1973 winner Gordon Johncock wins his second race over 1979 winner Rick Mears by 0.16 seconds, the closest finish to that date, after Mears draws alongside Johncock with a lap remaining, after erasing a seemingly insurmountable advantage of more than 11 seconds in the final 10 laps.

title: Beirut
event: The 1982 Lebanon War begins: Forces under Israeli Defense Minister Ariel Sharon invade southern Lebanon in their Operation Peace for the Galilee, eventually reaching as far north as the capital Beirut.

title: Israel
event: The United Nations Security Council votes to demand that Israel withdraw its troops from Lebanon.

title: Bluff Cove Air Attacks
event: Falklands War: British RFA ''Sir Galahad'' is destroyed during the Bluff Cove Air Attacks

title: Fortaleza
event: VASP Flight 168, a Boeing 727 passenger jet, crashes into forest Fortaleza, killing 137.

title: New York City
event: June 12 – A rally against nuclear weapons draws 750,000 to New York City's Central Park.   Jackson Browne, James Taylor, Bruce Springsteen, and Linda Ronstadt attend. An international convocation at The Cathedral of St. John the Divine features prominent peace activists from around the world and afterward participants march on Fifth Avenue to Central Park for the rally.

title: Falklands War
event: June 14 – The Falklands War ends: Formal surrender of Argentine forces.

title: Falklands War
event: June 18 – Argentine military dictator Leopoldo Galtieri resigns, in the wake of his country's defeat in the Falklands War.

title: London
event: June 19 – The body of God's Banker, Roberto Calvi, chairman of Banco Ambrosiano, is found hanging beneath Blackfriars Bridge in London.

title: London
event: June 21 – Prince William is born at St Mary's Hospital in Paddington, West London.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 3 – ASLEF train drivers in the United Kingdom go on strike over hours of work; they return to work on July 18.

title: Israel
event: July 4 – Four Iranian diplomats are kidnapped upon Israel's invasion of Lebanon.

title: Kenner Louisiana
event: Pan Am Flight 759 (Boeing 727) crashes in Kenner, Louisiana, killing all 146 on board and 8 on the ground.

title: New York City
event: July 16 – In New York City, The Reverend Sun Myung Moon is sentenced to 18 months in prison and fined $25,000 for tax fraud and conspiracy to obstruct justice.

title: London
event: July 20 – The Provisional IRA detonates 2 bombs in central London, killing 8 soldiers, wounding 47 people, and leading to the deaths of 7 horses.

title: Portsmouth
event: July 21 – HMS ''Hermes'', the Royal Navy flagship during the Falklands War, returns home to Portsmouth to a hero's welcome.

title: Blackfriars Bridge
event: A coroner's jury returns a verdict of suicide on Roberto Calvi, who was found hanging under Blackfriars Bridge.

title: France
event: July 31 – In Beaune, France, 53 persons, 46 of them children, die in a highway accident (France's worst).

title: Hong Kong
event: August 13 – In Hong Kong, health warnings on cigarette packets are made statutory.

title: Beirut
event: August 20 – Lebanese Civil War: A multinational force lands in Beirut to oversee the PLO withdrawal from Lebanon. French troops arrive August 21, U.S. Marines August 25.

title: Iowa
event: September 5 – Iowa paperboy Johnny Gosch is kidnapped.

title: Beirut
event: September 14 – Lebanese President-elect Bachir Gemayel is assassinated in Beirut.

title: Sabra and Shatila massacre
event: September 18 – The Lebanese Christian Militia (the Phalange) kill thousands of Palestinians in the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps with the overlooking of Israeli troops in West Beirut. The massacre is in retaliation for the assassination of pro-Israel president-elect, Bachir Gemayel, as well as several Palestinian massacres against Lebanese Christians.

title: Epcot
event: In Orlando, Florida, Walt Disney World opens the second largest theme park, EPCOT Center, to the public for the first time.

title: Mary Rose
event: October 11 – The ''Mary Rose'', flagship of Henry VIII of England that sank in 1545, is raised.

title: Thames Barrier
event: November 7 – The Thames Barrier is first publicly demonstrated.

title: Stanford University
event: November 20 – University of California, Berkeley executes The Play in a college football game against Stanford.  Completing a wacky 57-yard kickoff return that includes 5 laterals, Kevin Moen runs through Stanford band members who had prematurely come onto the field. His touchdown stands and California wins 25–20.

title: University of Utah
event: December 2 – At the University of Utah, 61-year-old retired dentist Barney Clark becomes the first person to receive a permanent artificial heart (he lives for 112 days with the device).

title: Times Beach Missouri
event: December 3 – A final soil sample is taken from the site of Times Beach, Missouri.   It is found to contain 300 times the safe level of dioxin.

title: People's Republic of China
event: December 4 – The People's Republic of China adopts its current constitution.

title: Texas
event: December 7 – The first U.S. execution by lethal injection is carried out in Texas.

title: Yemen
event: December 13 – An earthquake (Richter Scale 6.0 magnitude) in Dhamar, northern Yemen, kills at least 1,507.

title: Port Louis
event: December 22 – Indian Ocean Commission (Commission de l'Océan Indien) (COI) created by Port Louis Agreement.

title: Times Beach Missouri
event: December 23 – The United States Environmental Protection Agency recommends the evacuation of Times Beach, Missouri due to dangerous levels of dioxin contamination.

title: Visoko Bosnia and Herzegovina
event: Zlatko Ugljen receives the Aga Khan Award for Architecture for Šerefudin's White Mosque, built in Visoko.

title: Rocky Mountain Institute
event: Leopold Kohr, the people of Belau, Amory and Hunter Lovins / Rocky Mountain Institute and Manfred Max-Neef / CEPAUR win the Right Livelihood Award.

title: South African Border War
event: South African Border War (1965–1989)

title: Hawaii
event: January 3 – Kīlauea begins slowly erupting on the Big Island of Hawaii and is still flowing as of 2010.

title: Bolivia
event: January 19 – High ranking Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie is arrested in Bolivia.

title: Aldo Moro
event: January 24 – Twenty-five members of the Red Brigades are sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of Aldo Moro.

title: United Kingdom
event: January 31 – Seatbelt use for drivers and front seat passengers becomes mandatory in the United Kingdom.

title: Italy
event: February 13 – A cinema fire in Turin, Italy kills 64.

title: Australia
event: February 16 – The Ash Wednesday fires in Victoria and South Australia claim the lives of 76 people, in one of Australia's worst bushfires ever.

title: Times Beach Missouri
event: The United States Environmental Protection Agency announces its intention to buy out and evacuate the dioxin-contaminated community of Times Beach, Missouri.

title: M*A*S*H (TV series)
event: February 28 – The final episode of M*A*S*H is aired and the record of most watched episode is broken.

title: Tokyo Disneyland
event: April 15 – Tokyo Disneyland opens.

title: Beirut
event: April 18 – The April 1983 U.S. Embassy bombing in Beirut kills 63 people.

title: Samantha Smith
event: April 25 – Manchester, Maine schoolgirl Samantha Smith is invited to visit the Soviet Union by its leader Yuri Andropov, after he read her letter in which she expressed fears about nuclear war.

title: Israel
event: May 17 – Lebanon, Israel, and the United States sign an agreement on Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: Phú Quốc
event: June 16 – Cork Graham caught off the Vietnamese island of Phú Quốc looking for treasure buried by Captain Kidd. Convicted and imprisoned for illegal entry.

title: Argentina
event: June 30 – Total loss of coolant at Embalse nuclear power plant, Argentina. It was classified as an Accident With Local Consequences – level 4 at the International Nuclear Event Scale

title: Guinea
event: A North Korean Ilyushin Il-62M jet, en route to Conakry Airport in Guinea, crashes into the Fouta Djall Mountains in Guinea-Bissau, killing all 23 people on board.

title: Tasmania
event: The High Court of Australia blocks construction of the Franklin Dam in Tasmania.

title: Nintendo
event: Nintendo's Family Computer, also known as the Famicom, goes on sale in Japan.

title: Antarctica
event: July 21 – The lowest temperature on earth is recorded in Vostok Station, Antarctica with −89.2 °C (−128.6 °F).

title: Australia
event: July 22 – Australian Dick Smith completes his solo circumnavigation in a helicopter.

title: Gimli Manitoba
event: Gimli Glider: Out of fuel, Air Canada Flight 143 glides in to land in Gimli, Manitoba.

title: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
event: July 28 – New South Wales premier Neville Wran is exonerated by the Street Royal Commission, over claims raised by the ABC (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) programme ''Four Corners'', that he attempted to influence the NSW magistracy.

title: Texas
event: Hurricane Alicia hits the Texas coast, killing 22 and causing over US$3.8 billion (2005 dollars) in damage.

title: Manila
event: August 21 – Benigno Aquino, Jr., Philippines opposition leader, is assassinated in Manila just as he returns from exile.

title: Philadelphia Arena
event: August 24 – The Old Philadelphia Arena is destroyed by arson.

title: Moneron Island
event: September 1 – Cold War: Korean Air Lines Flight 007 is shot down by a Soviet Union jet fighter near Moneron Island when the commercial aircraft enters Soviet airspace. All 269 on board are killed including U.S. Congressman Larry McDonald.

title: New Jersey
event: September 17 – Vanessa Lynn Williams becomes the first African-American to be crowned Miss America, in Atlantic City, New Jersey.

title: Saint Kitts and Nevis
event: September 19 – Saint Kitts and Nevis becomes an independent state.

title: New Caledonia
event: Violence erupts in New Caledonia between native Kanaks and French expatriates. The French government withdraws the promise of independence.

title: Maze Prison escape
event: September 25 – Maze Prison escape: 38 Irish republican prisoners, armed with six handguns, hijack a prison meals lorry and smash their way out of HMP Maze, in the largest prison escape since World War II and in British history.

title: Australia
event: September 26 – The Australian yacht ''Australia II'' wins the America's Cup, the first successful challenge to the New York Yacht Club's 132-year defence of the sailing trophy.

title: Great Britain
event: October 2 – Neil Kinnock is elected leader of the British Labour Party.

title: Nevada
event: October 4 – Richard Noble sets a new land speed record of 633.468 mph, driving Thrust 2 at the Black Rock Desert, Nevada.

title: Grenada
event: October 19 – Maurice Bishop, Prime Minister of Grenada, and 40 others are assassinated in a military coup.

title: Beirut
event: October 23 – Simultaneous suicide truck-bombings destroy both the French and the United States Marine Corps barracks in Beirut, killing 241 U.S. servicemen, 58 French paratroopers and 6 Lebanese civilians.

title: Organization of American States
event: October 25 – United States troops invade Grenada at the behest of Eugenia Charles of Dominica, a member of the Organization of American States.

title: Argentina
event: October 30 – The first democratic elections in Argentina after 7 years of military rule are held.

title: White House
event: Martin Luther King, Jr. Day: At the White House Rose Garden, U.S. President Ronald Reagan signs a bill creating a federal holiday on the third Monday of every January to honor American civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr.

title: NATO
event: Able Archer 83: Many Soviet officials misinterpret this NATO exercise as a nuclear first strike, causing the last nuclear scare of the Cold War.

title: Diet of Japan
event: November 11 – Ronald Reagan becomes the first U.S. President to address the Diet, Japan's national legislature.

title: Gretna Louisiana
event: November 16 – A jury in Gretna, Louisiana acquits Ginny Foat of the murder of Argentine businessman Moses Chaiyo.

title: London
event: November 26 – Brink's-MAT robbery: In London, 6,800 gold bars worth nearly UK£26 million are taken from the Brink's-MAT vault at Heathrow Airport. Only a fraction of the gold is ever recovered, and only 2 men are convicted of the crime.

title: Madrid
event: November 27 – Colombian Avianca Flight 11 crashes near Barajas Airport in Madrid, Spain, killing 181 of the 192 on board.

title: Nepal
event: December 5 – ICIMOD is established and inaugurated with its headquarters in Kathmandu, Nepal, and legitimised through an Act of Parliament in Nepal this same year.

title: Madrid
event: December 7 – Two Spanish passenger planes collide on the foggy runway at a Madrid airport, killing 90.

title: Argentina
event: December 10 – Military rule ends and democracy is restored in Argentina, with the beginning of Raúl Alfonsín first term as President of Argentina

title: Madrid
event: A discotheque fire in Madrid, Spain, kills 83 people.

title: London
event: A Provisional IRA car bomb kills 6 Christmas shoppers and injures 90 outside Harrods in London.

title: United Kingdom
event: Brunei gains independence from the United Kingdom.

title: France
event: Two bombs explode in France; one on the Paris train kills 3 and injures 19. The other at Marseille station kills 2 and injures 34.

title: Cairo
event: December – A peace agreement between Kenya and Somalia is signed in the Egyptian capital Cairo. With this agreement, in which Somalia officially renounces its historical territorial claims, relations between the two countries began to improve.

title: Los Angeles
event: Crack, a smokeable form of cocaine, is first introduced into the Los Angeles area and soon spreads across the United States in what becomes known as the Crack Epidemic.

title: Brunei
event: Brunei becomes a fully independent state.

title: White House
event: January 3 – U.S. President Ronald Reagan meets with Navy Lieutenant Robert Goodman and the Reverend Jesse Jackson at the White House, following Lieutenant Goodman's release from Syrian captivity.

title: Brunei
event: January 7 – Brunei becomes the 6th member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

title: Vatican City
event: The United States and the Vatican establish full diplomatic relations.

title: Victoria Seychelles
event: Victoria Agreement signed.

title: Australia
event: February 1 – Medicare comes into effect in Australia.

title: Sarajevo
event: February 8 – The 1984 Winter Olympics open in Sarajevo, SFRY.

title: Sarajevo
event: February 19 – The 1984 Winter Olympics close in Sarajevo.

title: Beirut
event: February 26 – United States Marines pull out of Beirut, Lebanon.

title: Iraq
event: March 5 – Iran accuses Iraq of using chemical weapons; the United Nations condemns their use on March 30.

title: Beirut
event: March 16 – The CIA station chief in Beirut, William Francis Buckley, is kidnapped by Islamic Jihad and later dies in captivity.

title: Manhattan Beach California
event: March 22 – Teachers at the McMartin Preschool in Manhattan Beach, California are charged with Satanic ritual abuse of the schoolchildren (the charges are later dropped as completely unfounded).

title: India
event: April 2 – Indian Squadron Leader Rakesh Sharma is launched into space, aboard the ''Soyuz T-11''.

title: Dorothy Chandler Pavilion
event: April 6 – The 56th Academy Awards, hosted by Jack Lemmon, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion.

title: Israel
event: April 12 – Palestinian gunmen take Israeli Bus Number 300 hostage.   Israeli special forces storm the bus, freeing the hostages (1 hostage, 2 hijackers killed).

title: Kashmir
event: April 13 – India launches Operation Meghdoot, as most of the Siachen Glacier in Kashmir comes under Indian control.

title: London
event: April 17 – WPC Yvonne Fletcher is shot and killed by a secluded gunman leading to a police siege of the Libyan Embassy in London.

title: Australia
event: April 19 – ''Advance Australia Fair'' is proclaimed as Australia's national anthem, and green and gold as the national colours.

title: Liverpool
event: May 2 – The Liverpool International Garden Festival opens in Liverpool.

title: Australia
event: May 14 – The one dollar coin is introduced in Australia.

title: Lancashire
event: May 23 – Methane gas explosion at Abbeystead water treatment works in Lancashire, England kills 16 people.

title: Tulsa Oklahoma
event: May 27 – An overnight flash flood rages through neighborhoods in Tulsa, Oklahoma. Nearly 15 inches of rain falls in some areas over a four-hour period. 14 persons are killed.

title: Mecklenburg Correctional Center
event: May 31 – Mecklenburg Correctional Center - 6 inmates - including James and Linwood Briley escape from a death row facility, the first and only occasion this has ever happened in the US.

title: Amritsar
event: June 5 – The Indian government begins Operation Blue Star, the planned attack on the Golden Temple in Amritsar.

title: Amritsar
event: June 6 – Indian troops storm the Golden Temple at Amritsar, the Sikhs' holiest shrine, killing an estimated 2,000 people.

title: Barneveld Wisconsin
event: June 8 – A deadly F5 tornado nearly destroys the town of Barneveld, Wisconsin, killing 9 people, injuring nearly 200, and causing over $25,000,000 in damage.

title: United Kingdom
event: June 20 – The biggest exam shake-up in the British education system in over 10 years is announced, with O-level and CSE exams to be replaced by a new exam, the GCSE.

title: Şanlıurfa
event: The official name of the Turkish city Urfa is changed into Şanlıurfa.

title: New Zealand
event: July 14 – New Zealand Prime Minister Robert Muldoon calls a snap election and is heavily defeated by opposition Labour leader David Lange.

title: Los Angeles
event: July 28–August 12 – The 1984 Summer Olympics are held in Los Angeles, California.

title: Australia
event: August 1 – Australian banks are deregulated.

title: Manila
event: August 21 – Half a million people in Manila demonstrate against the regime of Ferdinand Marcos.

title: Sydney
event: September 2 – Seven people are shot and killed and 12 wounded in the Milperra massacre, a shootout between the rival motorcycle gangs Bandidos and Comancheros in Sydney.

title: Nicaragua
event: The Sandinista Front wins the Nicaraguan general elections.

title: Australia
event: Western Australia becomes the last Australian state to abolish capital punishment.

title: Hong Kong
event: September 26 – The United Kingdom and the People's Republic of China sign the initial agreement to return Hong Kong to China in 1997.

title: Australia
event: October 4 – Tim Macartney-Snape and Greg Mortimer become the first Australians to summit Mount Everest.

title: Brighton hotel bombing
event: October 12 – The Provisional Irish Republican Army (PIRA) attempts to assassinate Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and the British Cabinet in the Brighton hotel bombing.

title: India
event: October 31 – Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is assassinated by her 2 Sikh security guards. Anti-Sikh riots break out. Rajiv Gandhi becomes prime minister of India.

title: Minnesota
event: November 6 – United States presidential election, 1984: Ronald Reagan defeats Walter F. Mondale with 59% of the popular vote, the highest since Richard Nixon's 61% victory in 1972.  Reagan carries 49 states in the electoral college; Mondale wins only his home state of Minnesota by a mere 3,761 vote margin and the District of Columbia.

title: Zamboanga City
event: November 14 – Zamboanga City mayor Cesar Climaco, a prominent critic of the government of Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos, is assassinated in his home city.

title: Hong Kong
event: An East Rail train derails between Sheung Shui and Fanling stations, Hong Kong.

title: NASA
event: December 1 – Controlled Impact Demonstration: NASA crashes a remote controlled Boeing 720.

title: Australia
event: December 2 – Bob Hawke's government is re-elected in Australia with a reduced majority.

title: India
event: Bhopal Disaster: A methyl isocyanate leak from a Union Carbide pesticide plant in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, India, kills more than 8,000 people outright and injures over half a million (with more later dying from their injuries the death toll is now 23,000+) in the worst industrial disaster in history.

title: Hong Kong
event: December 19 – The People's Republic of China and United Kingdom sign the Sino-British Joint Declaration on the future of Hong Kong.

title: New York City
event: Four African-American youths (Barry Allen, Troy Canty, James Ramseur, and Darrell Cabey) board an express train in The Bronx borough of New York City. They attempt to rob Bernhard Goetz, who shoots them. The event starts a national debate about urban crime in the United States.

title: Malta
event: In Malta, Prime Minister Dom Mintoff resigns.

title: Finland
event: December 28 – A Soviet cruise missile plunges into Inarinjärvi lake in Finnish Lapland. Finnish authorities announce the fact in public on January 3, 1985.

title: Victoria (Australia)
event: The Australian state of Victoria celebrates its 150th anniversary.

title: Australia
event: The capital gains tax is introduced to Australia.

title: Western Sahara
event: Western Sahara is admitted to the Organization of African Unity; Morocco, which claims Western Sahara, leaves in protest.

title: ATI Technologies
event: ATI Technologies is founded.

title: Brazil
event: January 15 –  Tancredo Neves is elected president of Brazil by the Congress, ending the 21-year military rule.

title: California
event: January 28 – In Hollywood, California, the charity single We Are the World is recorded by USA for Africa.

title: Australia
event: February 5 – Australia cancels its involvement in U.S.-led MX missile tests.

title: South Africa
event: February 10 – Nelson Mandela rejects an offer of freedom from the South African government.

title: Israel
event: February 16 – Israel begins withdrawing troops from Lebanon.

title: 1985 Santiago earthquake
event: March 3 – An 8.0 on the Richter magnitude scale earthquake hits Santiago and Valparaíso leaving 177 dead, 2,575 hurt, 142,489 destroyed houses and about a million people houseless

title: Harrods
event: Mohammed Al Fayed buys the London-based department store company ''Harrods''.

title: Singapore Zoo
event: March 14 – Five lionesses at the Singapore Zoo are put on birth control after the lion population increases from 2 to 16.

title: Brazil
event: March 15 – Vice-President Jose Sarney takes the oath as the first civilian president of Brazil in 21 years, as the elected president Tancredo Neves had become severely ill on the day before.

title: Beirut
event: March 16 – Associated Press newsman Terry Anderson is taken hostage in Beirut (he is eventually released on December 4, 1991).

title: Madison Square Garden
event: March 31 – WrestleMania debuts at Madison Square Garden.

title: Madrid-Torrejón Airport
event: April 12 – 1985 El Descanso bombing: A terrorist bombing attributed to the Islamic Jihad Organization in the ''El Descanso'' restaurant near Madrid, Spain, mostly attended by U.S. personnel of the Torrejon Air Force Base, causes 18 dead (all Spaniards) and 82 injured.

title: South Africa
event: April 15 – South Africa ends its ban on interracial marriages.

title: United Kingdom
event: April 18 – The United Kingdom has its first ever national Glow-worm day.

title: Kazakhstan
event: April 19 – The U.S.S.R performs a nuclear test at Eastern Kazakhstan.

title: Australia
event: April 28 – The Australian Nuclear Disarmament Party (NDP) splits.

title: New York City
event: The FBI brings charges against the suspected heads of the 5 Mafia families in New York City.

title: Bradford
event: Fire engulfs a wooden stand in the Valley Parade stadium in Bradford, England during a football match, killing 56.

title: University of California Berkeley
event: May 15 – An explosive device sent by the Unabomber injures John Hauser at UC Berkeley.

title: Bangladesh
event: May 25 – Bangladesh is hit by a tropical cyclone and storm surge, which kills approximately 10,000 people.

title: Brussels
event: May 29 – Heysel Disaster: 38 spectators are killed in rioting on the terraces during the European Cup final between Liverpool F.C. and Juventus at Heysel Stadium in Brussels, Belgium.

title: Ontario
event: May 31 – Forty-one tornadoes hit in Ohio, Pennsylvania, New York and Ontario, killing 76.

title: Auburn Washington
event: June 13 – In Auburn, Washington, police defuse a Unabomber bomb sent to Boeing.

title: Ireland
event: June 23 – Air India Flight 182, a Boeing 747, blows up 31,000 feet (9,500 m) above the Atlantic Ocean, south of Ireland, killing all 329 aboard.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 4 – Ruth Lawrence, 13, achieves a first in mathematics at Oxford University, becoming the youngest British person ever to earn a first-class degree and the youngest known graduate of Oxford University.

title: France
event: July 10 – The Greenpeace vessel ''Rainbow Warrior'' is bombed and sunk in Auckland harbour by French DGSE agents.

title: London
event: ''Live Aid'' pop concerts in London and Philadelphia raise over £50 million for famine relief in Ethiopia.

title: New Hampshire
event: U.S. Vice President George H.W. Bush announces that New Hampshire teacher Christa McAuliffe will become the first schoolteacher to ride aboard the Space Shuttle ''Challenger''.

title: Key West Florida
event: July 20 – The main ship wreck site of the Spanish galleon ''Nuestra Señora de Atocha'' (which sank in 1622) is found 40 miles off the coast of Key West, Florida by treasure hunters who begin to excavate $400 million in coins and silver.

title: New York
event: July 23 – Commodore launches the Amiga personal computer at the Lincoln Center in New York.

title: Delta Air Lines Flight 191
event: August 2 – Delta Air Lines Flight 191 crashes near Dallas, Texas, killing 137 people.

title: Japan Airlines Flight 123
event: August 12 – Japan Airlines Flight 123 crashes in Japan, killing 520 people (the worst single-aircraft disaster in history).

title: British Airtours Flight 28M
event: August 22 – British Airtours Flight 28M The 737's left engine caught fire while on its take off roll, 55 people are killed while trying to evacuate the aircraft.

title: Samantha Smith
event: August 25 – Samantha Smith, Goodwill Ambassador between the Soviet Union and the United States for writing a letter to Yuri Andropov about nuclear war, and eventually visiting the Soviet Union at Andropov's request, dies in the Bar Harbor Airlines Flight 1808 plane crash. She was 13.

title: RMS Titanic
event: ''Knorr'', Robert Ballard, Jean-Louis Michel, and crew, find the wreck of ''R.M.S. Titanic''.

title: Los Angeles
event: Richard Ramirez, the serial killer known as the Night Stalker, is captured in Los Angeles.

title: 1985 Mexico City earthquake
event: September 19 – An 8.1 Richter scale earthquake strikes Mexico City. Around 10,000 people are killed, 30,000 injured, and 95,000 left homeless.

title: Israel
event: October 1 – The Israeli air force bombs PLO Headquarters near Tunis.

title: Massachusetts
event: October 4 – The Free Software Foundation is founded in Massachusetts, USA.

title: Antarctica
event: November 12 – A total solar eclipse occurs over Antarctica at 14:11:22 UTC.

title: Armero tragedy
event: November 13 – Nevado del Ruiz volcano erupts, killing an estimated 23,000 people, including 21,000 killed by lahars in the town of Armero, Colombia.

title: Malta
event: November 23 – EgyptAir Flight 648 is hijacked by the Abu Nidal group and flown to Malta, where Egyptian commandos storm the plane; 60 are killed by gunfire and explosions.

title: London
event: Gerard Hoarau, exiled political leader from the Seychelles, is assassinated in London.

title: SM City North EDSA
event: The SM City North EDSA shopping mall is the country's first SM Supermall owned by Henry Sy.

title: Sinai Peninsula
event: December 12 – Arrow Air Flight 1285, a Douglas DC-8, crashes after takeoff in Gander, Newfoundland, killing 256, 248 of whom were U.S. servicemen returning to Fort Campbell, Kentucky from overseeing a peacekeeping force in Sinai.

title: New York City
event: December 16 – In New York City, Mafia bosses Paul Castellano and Thomas Bilotti are shot dead in front of Spark's Steak House, making hit organizer John Gotti the leader of the powerful Gambino organized crime family.

title: Vienna
event: Rome and Vienna airport attacks: Abu Nidal terrorists open fire in the airports of Rome and Vienna, leaving 18 dead and 120 injured.

title: Rwanda
event: American naturalist Dian Fossey is found murdered in Rwanda.

title: Bangladesh
event: The Bangladeshi double decked ferry ''Shamia'' capsizes in the Meghna River, southern Barisal, Bangladesh, killing at least 600.

title: Portugal
event: Spain and Portugal enter the ''European Community'', which later becomes the European Union.

title: Aruba
event: Aruba gains increased autonomy from the Netherlands and is separated from the Netherlands Antilles.{{Clarifymedate=February 2009}}

title: Channel Tunnel
event: The United Kingdom and France announce plans to construct the Channel Tunnel.

title: Uganda
event: January 25—Yoweri Museveni's National Resistance Army Rebel group takes over Uganda after leading a successful 5-year guerrilla war in which up to half a million people are believed to have been killed. They will later use January 26 as the official date to avoid a coincidence of dates with Dictator Idi Amin's 1971 coup.

title: Uganda
event: January 29—Yoweri Museveni is sworn in as President of Uganda after leading a successful 5-year guerrilla war.

title: New Zealand
event: The Soviet liner ''Mikhail Lermontov'' sinks in the Marlborough Sounds, New Zealand.

title: French Air Force
event: The French Air Force raids the Libyan Ouadi Doum airbase in northern Chad.

title: Mir
event: The Soviet Union launches the Mir space station.

title: Hawaii
event: People Power Revolution: President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines goes into exile in Hawaii after 20 years of rule; Corazon Aquino becomes the first Filipino woman president, first as an interim president. Salvador Laurel becomes her Vice President.

title: Philippines
event: February 26—People Power Revolution in the Philippines.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 4—The ''Today'' national tabloid newspaper is launched in the United Kingdom, pioneering the use of computer photosetting and full-colour offset printing, at a time when British national newspapers still use Linotype machines and letterpress.

title: Melbourne
event: March 27—A car bomb explodes at Russell Street Police HQ in Melbourne, killing a police officer.

title: Surrey
event: A fire devastates Hampton Court Palace in Surrey, England.

title: Santiago Maravatío
event: A Mexicana Boeing 727 jetliner crashes at Maravatio, Mexico, killing 173.

title: Libya
event: April 5—1986 Berlin discotheque bombing: The West Berlin discothèque, a known hangout for United States soldiers, is bombed, killing 3 and injuring 230; Libya is held responsible.

title: Bangladesh
event: April 14—Hailstones weighing 2.2 lb (1 kg) fall on the Gopalganj district of Bangladesh, killing 92.

title: Benghazi
event: April 15—Operation El Dorado Canyon: At least 15 people die after United States planes bomb targets in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, and the Benghazi region

title: Isles of Scilly
event: A treaty ends the Three Hundred and Thirty Five Years' War between the Netherlands and the Isles of Scilly.

title: Tel Aviv
event: The Hindawi Affair begins when an Irishwoman is found unknowingly carrying explosives onto an El Al flight from London to Tel Aviv.

title: Chernobyl disaster
event: April 26— The Chernobyl disaster: A mishandled safety test at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in Pripyat, Ukrainian SSR, Soviet Union killed at least 4056 people and damaged almost $7 billion of property.Benjamin K. Sovacool. The costs of failure: A preliminary assessment of major energy accidents, 1907–2007, ''Energy Policy'' 36 (2008), p. 1806.<

title: Tokyo
event: Diamond Jubilee of Emperor Showa is held at the Kokugikan in Tokyo

title: British Columbia
event: May 2—The 1986 World Exposition opens in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada.

title: UNESCO
event: May 16—The Seville Statement on Violence is adopted by an international meeting of scientists, convened by the Spanish National Commission for UNESCO, in Seville, Spain.

title: New York City
event: May 25—''Hands Across America'': At least 5,000,000 people form a human chain from New York City to Long Beach, California, to raise money to fight hunger and homelessness.

title: Israel
event: June 4—Jonathan Pollard pleads guilty to espionage for selling top secret United States military intelligence to Israel.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: July 23—In London, Prince Andrew, Duke of York marries Sarah Ferguson at Westminster Abbey.

title: Sydney
event: A low-pressure system moving from South Australia and redeveloping off the New South Wales coast dumps a record {{convert328mmin1}} of rain in a day on Sydney.

title: Louisville Kentucky
event: In Louisville, Kentucky, William J. Schroeder, the second artificial heart recipient, dies after 620 days.

title: Australia
event: August 19—Two weeks after it was stolen, the Picasso painting ''Weeping Woman'' is found in a locker at the Spencer Street Station in Melbourne, Australia.

title: Cameroon
event: August 21—The Lake Nyos disaster occurs in Cameroon, killing nearly 2,000 people.

title: Black Sea
event: The Soviet passenger liner ''Admiral Nakhimov'' collides with the bulk carrier ''Pyotr Vasev'' in the Black Sea and sinks almost immediately, killing 398.

title: Cerritos California
event: Aeroméxico Flight 498, a Douglas DC-9, collides with a Piper PA-28 over Cerritos, California, killing 67 on both aircraft and 15 on the ground.

title: Jordan University of Science and Technology
event: September 1—Establishment of  Jordan University of Science and Technology in Jordan.

title: Jinnah International Airport
event: September 5—Pan Am Flight 73, with 358 people on board, is hijacked at Karachi International Airport by 4 Abu Nidal terrorists.

title: Istanbul
event: September 6—In Istanbul, 2 Abu Nidal terrorists kill 22 and wound 6 inside the Neve Shalom synagogue during Sabbath services.

title: South Africa
event: Desmond Tutu becomes the first black Anglican Church bishop in South Africa.

title: Greece
event: September 13—A magnitude 6.0 earthquake rocks the city of Kalamata in southern Greece, killing 20 people, injuring 80 and completely destroying 1/5 of the city.

title: Chalk River Laboratories
event: October 3—TASCC, a superconducting cyclotron, officially opens at Chalk River Laboratories.

title: London
event: ''The Phantom of the Opera'', the longest running Broadway show in history, opens at Her Majesty's Theatre in London.

title: Reykjavík
event: October 11—Cold War: Ronald Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev meet in Reykjavík, Iceland, to continue discussions about scaling back their intermediate missile arsenals in Europe (the talks break down in failure).

title: People's Republic of China
event: October 12—Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh visit the People's Republic of China.

title: 1992 Summer Olympics
event: October 16—The International Olympic Committee chooses Albertville, France to be the host city of the 1992 Winter Olympics and Barcelona, Spain to be the host city of the 1992 Summer Olympics.

title: Marshall Islands
event: October 21—The Marshall Islands become an associated state under the Compact of Free Association.

title: WFAN
event: October 22—In New York City WNBC Radio's traffic helicopter crashes into the Hudson River, killing traffic reporter Jane Dornacker. The last words heard on-the-air were Dornacker's screams of terror, Hit the water! Hit the water! Hit the water!

title: London Stock Exchange
event: The Big Bang in the London Stock Exchange abolishes fixed commission charges, paving the way for electronic trading.

title: New York Harbor
event: The centennial of the Statue of Liberty's dedication is celebrated in New York Harbor.

title: London
event: In London, Jeremy Bamber is found guilty of the murder of his parents, sister and twin nephews, and sentenced to life imprisonment, with a recommendation by the trial judge that he should serve at least 25 years before being considered for parole.

title: Australia
event: November 1—Queensland, Australia: Joh Bjelke-Petersen wins his final election as Premier of Queensland with 38.6% of the vote. He resigns on December 1, 1987 following revelations of his involvement with corruption released in the Fitzgerald Inquiry.

title: Iran
event: November 3—Iran–Contra affair: The Lebanese magazine ''Ash-Shiraa'' reports that the United States has been selling weapons to Iran in secret, in order to secure the release of 7 American hostages held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon.

title: Supreme Court of California
event: November 4—Democrats regain control of the United States Senate for the first time in 6 years.  In California, Chief Justice Rose Bird and two colleagues are removed by voters from the Supreme Court of California for opposing capital punishment.

title: Sumburgh Airport
event: November 6—Sumburgh disaster: A British International Helicopters Boeing 234LR Chinook crashes 2.5 miles east of Sumburgh Airport, killing 45 people (the deadliest civilian helicopter crash on record).

title: Nicaragua
event: November 21—Iran-Contra Affair: National Security Council member Oliver North and his secretary, Fawn Hall, start shredding documents implicating them in selling weapons to Iran and channeling the proceeds to help fund the Contra rebels in Nicaragua.

title: Nicaragua
event: November 25—Iran-Contra Affair: U.S. Attorney General Edwin Meese announces that profits from covert weapons sales to Iran were illegally diverted to the anti-communist Contra rebels in Nicaragua.

title: Howard Beach Queens
event: December 20—Three African Americans are assaulted by a group of white teens in the Howard Beach neighborhood of Queens, New York.  One of the victims, Michael Griffith, is run over and killed by a motorist while attempting to flee the attackers.

title: Cornwall
event: December 22—British Liberal Party Member of Parliament David Penhaligon, 42, is killed in a car crash near Truro in Cornwall, England.

title: Minnesota
event: ''Fargo'' (1996): The film takes place in Minnesota, 1987

title: Pennsylvania
event: ''Adventureland'' (2009): The film takes place in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, summer 1987

title: Harlem
event: ''Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire'' (2009): The film takes place in Harlem, New York in 1987.

title: NASA
event: ''Buck Rogers in the 25th Century'' (1979): NASA launches the last of America's deep-space probes, the Space Shuttle ''Ranger 3'', which is piloted by Captain William Buck Rogers.

title: Nunavut
event: January 1 – Frobisher Bay, Northwest Territories, changes its name to Iqaluit. In 1999, it becomes the capital of Nunavut.

title: Libya
event: January 2 – Chadian–Libyan conflict – Battle of Fada: The Chadian army destroys a Libyan armoured brigade.

title: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame
event: January 3 – Aretha Franklin becomes the first woman inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

title: Chase Maryland
event: January 4 – 1987 Maryland train collision: An Amtrak train en route from  Washington, D.C. to Boston, Massachusetts collides with Conrail engines at Chase, Maryland, killing 16.

title: Beirut
event: January 20 – Terry Waite, the special envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury in Lebanon, is kidnapped in Beirut (released November 1991).

title: London Stock Exchange
event: February 11 – British Airways is privatised and listed on the London Stock Exchange.

title: Salt Lake City
event: February 20 – A second Unabomber bomb explodes at the Salt Lake City computer store, injuring the owner.

title: American Motors
event: March 2 – American Motors Corporation is acquired by the Chrysler Corporation

title: Iran
event: March 4 – U.S. President Ronald Reagan addresses the American people on the Iran-Contra Affair, acknowledging that his overtures to Iran had 'deteriorated' into an arms-for-hostages deal.

title: Zeebrugge
event: March 6 – Zeebrugge Disaster: A cross-channel ferry capsizes outside the harbor off Zeebrugge, Belgium; 180 drown.

title: Marne-la-Vallée
event: March 24 Michael Eisner, CEO of The Walt Disney Company, and French Prime Minister and future President of France, Jacques Chirac, sign the agreement to construct the 4,800 acre Euro Disney Resort (now called Disneyland Paris) and to develop the Val d'Europe area of the new town Marne-la-Vallée in Paris, France.

title: Macau
event: April 13 – Portugal and the People's Republic of China sign an agreement in which Macau will be returned to China in 1999.

title: Quebec
event: April 30 – Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and the Provincial Premiers agree on principle to the Meech Lake Accord which would bring Quebec into the constitution.

title: Fiji
event: May 14 – Lieutenant Colonel Sitiveni Rabuka executes a bloodless coup in Fiji.

title: Iraq
event: May 17 – U.S.S. Stark is hit by two Iraqi-owned Exocet AM39 air-to-surface missiles killing 37 sailors.

title: Red Square
event: May 28 – Nineteen year-old West German pilot Mathias Rust evades Soviet air defenses and lands a private plane on Red Square in Moscow. He is immediately detained (released on August 3, 1988).

title: Berlin Wall
event: June 12 – During a visit to Berlin, Germany, U.S. President Ronald Reagan challenges Soviet Premier Mikhail Gorbachev to tear down the Berlin Wall.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: June 19 – Edwards v. Aguillard: The Supreme Court of the United States rules that a Louisiana law requiring that creation science be taught in public schools whenever evolution is taught is unconstitutional.

title: Philippines
event: June 27 – A commercial HS 748 (Philippine Airlines Flight 206) crashes near Baguio City, Philippines, killing 50.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: July 1 – U.S. President Ronald Reagan nominates former Solicitor General Robert Bork to the Supreme Court. The nomination is later rejected by the Senate, the first and only nominee rejection to date.

title: Saddleworth Moor
event: July 3 – Greater Manchester Police recover the body of 16-year-old Pauline Reade from Saddleworth Moor, after her killers Ian Brady and Myra Hindley helped them in their search, almost exactly 24 years since Pauline was last seen alive.

title: East Lancashire Railway
event: July 25 – The East Lancashire Railway, a heritage railway in the North West of England, is opened between Bury and Ramsbottom.

title: Iran
event: July 31 – Four hundred Iranian pilgrims are killed in clashes with Saudi Arabian security forces in Mecca.

title: Alberta
event: July 31 – An F4-rated tornado devastates eastern Edmonton, Alberta. Hardest hit are an industrial park and a trailer park. 27 people are killed and hundreds injured, with hundreds more left homeless and jobless.

title: Los Monjes Archipelago
event: August 7 – The Colombian frigate ''Caldas'' enters Venezuelan waters near the Los Monjes Archipelago, sparking the Caldas frigate crisis between both nations.

title: Melbourne
event: August 9 – Hoddle Street Massacre: Julian Knight, 19, goes on a shooting rampage in Melbourne, killing seven people and injuring 19 before surrendering to police.

title: Lake Eildon
event: August 14 – All the children held at Kia Lama, a rural property on Lake Eildon, Australia, run by the Santiniketan Park Association, are released after a police raid.

title: Romulus Michigan
event: August 16 – Northwest Airlines Flight 255 (a McDonnell Douglas MD-82) crashes on takeoff from Detroit Metropolitan Airport in Romulus, Michigan just West of Detroit killing all but one (4-year old Cecelia Cichan) of the 156 people on-board.

title: Spandau Prison
event: August 17 – Rudolf Hess is found dead in his cell in Spandau Prison. Hess, 93, is believed to have committed suicide by hanging himself with an electrical flex. He was the last remaining prisoner at the complex, which is soon demolished.

title: Red Square
event: September 2 – In Moscow, the trial begins for 19-year-old pilot Mathias Rust, who flew his Cessna airplane into Red Square in May.

title: Los Alamos National Laboratory
event: September 7–21 – The world's first conference on artificial life is held at Los Alamos National Laboratory.

title: Goiânia accident
event: September 13 – Scavengers open an old radiation source abandoned in a hospital in Goiânia, causing the worst radiation accident ever in an urban area.

title: Harlem
event: September 17 – At a small rally in Harlem, televangelist Pat Robertson announces his candidacy for the 1988 Republican presidential nomination.

title: Texas
event: October 14–16 – The United States is caught up in a drama that unfolds on television as a young child, Jessica McClure, falls down a well in Midland, Texas, and is later rescued.

title: Persian Gulf
event: October 19 – U.S. warships destroy 2 Iranian oil platforms in the Persian Gulf

title: Irish Sea
event: October 22 – The pilot of a British Aerospace BAE Harrier GR5 registered ZD325 accidentally ejects his aircraft. The jet continues to fly until it runs out of fuel and crashes into the Irish Sea.

title: Gulf of Alaska
event: November 17 – A tsunami hits the Gulf of Alaska.

title: King's Cross fire
event: November 18 – The King's Cross fire on the London Underground kills 31.

title: WTTW
event: November 22 – Max Headroom broadcast signal intrusion incident – unknown perpetrators hijack the signal of WGN-TV for about 20 seconds, and WTTW for about 90 seconds, and displays a strange video of a man in a Max Headroom mask.

title: Philippines
event: November 25 – Category 5 Typhoon Nina smashes the Philippines with {{convert165mphkm/h}} winds and a devastating storm surge, causing destruction and 1,036 deaths.

title: Mauritius
event: November 28 – South African Airways Flight 295 crashes into the Indian ocean off Mauritius due to a fire in the cargo hold; the 159 passengers and crew perish.

title: Andaman Sea
event: November 29 – Korean Air Flight 858 is blown up over the Andaman Sea, killing 115 crew and passengers (North Korean agents are suspected).

title: NASA
event: December 1 – NASA announces the names of 4 companies awarded contracts to help build Space Station Freedom: Boeing Aerospace, General Electric's Astro-Space Division, McDonnell Douglas, and the Rocketdyne Division of Rockwell.

title: Channel Tunnel
event: December 1 – Construction of the Channel Tunnel is initiated.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: December 2 – ''Hustler Magazine v. Falwell'' is argued before the U.S. Supreme Court.

title: Paso Robles California
event: December 7 – Pacific Southwest Airlines Flight 1771 crashes near Paso Robles, California, killing all 43 on board, after a disgruntled passenger shoots his ex-supervisor on the flight, then shoots both pilots and himself.

title: West Bank
event: December 8 – Israeli-Palestinian conflict: First Intifada begins in the Gaza Strip and West Bank.

title: Melbourne
event: December 8 – Queen Street massacre: In Melbourne, Australia, 22-year-old Frank Vitkovic kills 8 and injures another 5 in a Post Office building before committing suicide by jumping from the eleventh floor.

title: Microsoft
event: December 9 – Microsoft releases Windows 2.0.

title: Persian Gulf
event: The ''USS Samuel B. Roberts (FFG-58)'' strikes a naval mine in the Persian Gulf, while deployed on Operation Earnest Will, during the Tanker War phase of the Iran–Iraq War.

title: Taiwan
event: January 13 – Taiwan President Chiang Ching-kuo dies in Taipei; Vice-President Lee Teng-hui becomes president.

title: Dome of the Rock
event: January 15 – In Jerusalem, Israeli police and Palestinian protestors clash at the Dome of the Rock; several police and at least 70 Palestinians are injured.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: February 12 – Anthony M. Kennedy is appointed to the Supreme Court of the United States.

title: Alberta
event: February 13–28 – The 1988 Winter Olympics are held in Calgary, Alberta, Canada.

title: Namibia
event: A bomb explodes outside of the First National Bank in Oshakati, Namibia, killing 27 and injuring 70 others.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: February 24 – ''Hustler Magazine v. Falwell'': The Supreme Court of the United States sides with ''Hustler'' magazine by overturning a lower court decision to award Jerry Falwell $200,000 for defamation.

title: Gibraltar
event: March 7 – Operation Flavius: The Special Air Service fatally shoots 3 unarmed Provisional Irish Republican Army members in Gibraltar.

title: Kentucky
event: Two U.S. Army helicopters collide in Fort Campbell, Kentucky, killing 17 servicemen.

title: Gallaudet University
event: March 13 – Gallaudet University, a Deaf university in Washington D.C. elects Dr. I King Jordan as the first Deaf president in its history. This event is a turning point in the Deaf civil rights movement.

title: Iraq
event: The Halabja poison gas attack is carried out by Iraqi government forces.

title: Belfast
event: Milltown Cemetery Attack: During the funeral of three Provisional IRA volunteers in Milltown Cemetery in Belfast, Northern Ireland, Ulster Defence Association (UDA)  member Michael Stone attacked the crowd with grenades and pistols, killing three and wounding over sixty. They were murdered because they were likely to be Catholic.

title: Belfast
event: March 19 – Corporals killings: In Belfast, Northern Ireland, British Army Corporals Woods and Howes were attacked after driving straight into a funeral for the victims of the Milltown Cemetery Attack just three days earlier, after they were mistakenly thought to be carrying out a similar attack to the one by Ulster Defence Association (UDA) member Michael Stone, in which he killed three Catholics attending the funeral.

title: Afabet
event: March 20 – Eritrean War of Independence: Having defeated the Nadew Command, the EPLF enters the town of Afabet, victoriously concluding the Battle of Afabet.

title: Israel
event: March 24 – An Israeli court sentences Mordechai Vanunu to 18 years in prison for disclosing Israel's nuclear program to ''The Sunday Times''.

title: Michigan
event: March 26 – U.S. presidential candidate Jesse Jackson defeats Michael Dukakis in the Michigan Democratic caucuses, becoming the temporary front-runner for the party's nomination.  Richard Gephardt withdraws his candidacy after his campaign speeches against imported automobiles fail to earn him much support in Detroit.

title: Arizona
event: April 4 – Governor Evan Mecham of Arizona is convicted in his impeachment trial and removed from office.

title: Wisconsin
event: April 5 –  Massachusetts Governor Michael Dukakis wins the Wisconsin Democratic presidential primary.

title: Islamabad
event: The Ojhri Camp Disaster occurs in Islamabad and Rawalpindi.

title: Great Seto Bridge
event: The Great Seto Bridge opens to traffic in Japan.

title: Palm Springs California
event: April 12 – Former pop singer Sonny Bono is elected mayor of Palm Springs, California.

title: Israel
event: Israeli commandos kill the PLO's Abu Jihad in Tunisia.

title: Italy
event: In Forlì, Italy, the brigate rosse kill Senator Roberto Ruffilli, an advisor of Prime Minister Ciriaco de Mita.

title: Iran
event: April 18 – The United States Navy retaliates for the ''Roberts'' mining with Operation Praying Mantis, in a day of strikes against Iranian oil platforms and naval vessels.

title: Israel
event: April 25 – In Israel, Ivan Demjanjuk is sentenced to death for war crimes committed in World War II.   He was accused by survivors of being the notorious guard at the Treblinka extermination camp known as Ivan the Terrible. The conviction is later overturned by the Israeli Supreme Court.

title: Australia
event: World Expo '88 opens in Brisbane Queensland, Australia.

title: Paradise Nevada
event: May 4 – PEPCON disaster in Henderson, Nevada: A major explosion at an industrial solid-fuel rocket plant causes damage extending up to 10 miles away, including Las Vegas' McCarran International Airport.

title: Radcliff Kentucky
event: May 14 – Bus collision near Carrollton, Kentucky: A drunk driver going the wrong way on Interstate 71, hits a converted school bus carrying a church youth group from Radcliff, Kentucky.   The resulting fire kills 27, making it tied for 1st in the U.S. for most fatalities involving 2 vehicles to the present day. Coincidentally, the other 2-vehicle accident involving a bus that also killed 27 occurred in Prestonsburg, KY 30 years prior.

title: United Kingdom
event: May 24 – Section 28 (outlawing promotion of homosexuality in schools) is passed as law by Parliament in the United Kingdom.

title: Microsoft
event: May 27 – Microsoft releases Windows 2.1

title: Moscow State University
event: May 31 – U.S. President Ronald Reagan addresses 600 Moscow State University students, during his visit to the Soviet Union.

title: France
event: June 26 – Air France Flight 296 crashes into the tops of trees beyond the runway on a demonstration flight at Habsheim, France; three passengers are killed.

title: Auburn Indiana
event: June 28 – Four workers are asphyxiated at a metal-plating plant in Auburn, Indiana, in the worst confined-space industrial accident in U.S. history. A fifth victim dies two days later).

title: Switzerland
event: June 30 – Roman Catholic Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre consecrates four bishops at Ecône, Switzerland for his apostolate, along with Bishop Antonio de Castro Mayer, without a papal mandate.

title: Istanbul
event: The Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge in Istanbul, Turkey is completed, providing the second connection between the continents of Europe and Asia over the Bosporus.

title: Iran Air Flight 655
