event: Iran Air Flight 655 is shot down by a missile launched from the USS ''Vincennes''.

title: North Sea
event: The Piper Alpha drilling platform in the North Sea is destroyed by explosions and fires, killing 165 oil workers and 2 rescue mariners.

title: Monmouth County New Jersey
event: The first reported medical waste on beaches in the Greater New York area (including hypodermic needles and syringes possibly infected with the AIDS virus) washes ashore on Long Island.  Subsequent medical waste discoveries on beaches in Coney Island and in Monmouth County, New Jersey force the closure of numerous New York–area beaches in the middle of one of the hottest summers on record in the American Northeast.

title: Westmoreland County Pennsylvania
event: July 14 – Volkswagen closes its Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania plant after 10 years of operation (the first factory built by a non-American automaker in the U.S.).

title: Georgia (U.S. state)
event: July 20 – The Democratic National Convention in Atlanta, Georgia nominates Michael Dukakis for U.S. President and Lloyd Bentsen for Vice President.

title: Tompkins Square Park
event: August 6–7 – Tompkins Square Park Police Riot in New York City:  A riot erupts in Tompkins Square Park when police attempt to enforce a newly passed curfew for the park.   Bystanders, artists, residents, homeless people and political activists are caught up in the police action which takes place during the night of August 6 and into the early morning of August 7.

title: Ferrari
event: August 14 –  Enzo Ferrari, founder of the Italian automobile manufacturer Ferrari, dies at the age of 90, after a long illness.

title: Louisiana
event: August 18 – The Republican National Convention in New Orleans, Louisiana nominates George H.W. Bush for President and Dan Quayle for Vice President of the United States of America.

title: Lisbon
event: August 25 – A fire destroys part of Chiado quarter, in Lisbon's historical center.

title: Frecce Tricolori
event: August 28 – Seventy-five people are killed and 346 injured in one of the worst airshow disasters in history at Germany's Ramstein Air Base, when three jets from the Italian air demonstration team, ''Frecce Tricolori'', collide, sending one of the aircraft crashing into the crowd of spectators.

title: Estonia
event: September 11 – In Estonia, 300,000 demonstrate for independence.

title: Yucatán Peninsula
event: September 12 – Hurricane Gilbert devastates Jamaica; it turns towards Mexico's Yucatán Peninsula 2 days later, causing an estimated $5 billion in damage.

title: NASA
event: September 29 – ''STS-26'': NASA resumes space shuttle flights, grounded after the ''Challenger'' disaster, with Space Shuttle ''Discovery''.

title: Texas
event: In Omaha, Nebraska, in the only vice presidential debate of the 1988 U.S. presidential election, the Republican vice presidential nominee, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, insists he has as much experience in government as John F. Kennedy did when he sought the presidency in 1960.  His Democratic opponent, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, replies, Senator, I knew Jack Kennedy. I served with Jack Kennedy. Jack Kennedy was a friend of mine. Senator, you're no Jack Kennedy. The audience response to Sen. Bentsen's remark is overwhelmingly positive.

title: Magdalene College Cambridge
event: October 11 – Women are allowed to study at Magdalene College, Cambridge, for the first time.  Male students wear black armbands and the porter flies a black flag.

title: Australia
event: October 12 – Walsh Street police shootings: Two Victoria Police officers are gunned down, execution style, in Australia.

title: White House
event: October 13 – In the second U.S. presidential debate, held by U.C.L.A., the Democratic party nominee, Michael Dukakis, is asked by journalist Bernard Shaw of CNN if he would support the death penalty if his wife, Kitty, were to be raped and murdered.  Gov. Dukakis' reply, voicing his opposition to capital punishment in any and all circumstances, is later said to have been a major reason for the eventual failure of his campaign for the White House.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 19 – The United Kingdom bans broadcast interviews with IRA members.  The BBC gets around this stricture through the use of professional actors.

title: Australia
event: Expo '88 in Brisbane, Australia draws to a close.

title: Massachusetts Institute of Technology
event: November 2 – The Morris worm, the first computer worm distributed via the Internet, written by Robert Tappan Morris, is launched from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the U.S.

title: Sacramento California
event: November 11 – In Sacramento, California, police find a body buried in the lawn of 60-year-old boardinghouse landlady Dorothea Puente (7 bodies are eventually found and Puente is convicted of 3 murders and sentenced to life in prison).

title: Estonia
event: The Supreme Soviet of the Estonian SSR declares that Estonia is sovereign but stops short of declaring independence.

title: Palmdale California
event: November 22 – In Palmdale, California, the first prototype B-2 Spirit stealth bomber is revealed.

title: Bangladesh
event: December 2 – A cyclone in Bangladesh leaves 5 million homeless and thousands dead.

title: Estonia
event: Estonian becomes the official language of Estonia.

title: Clapham Junction rail crash
event: December 12 – The Clapham Junction rail crash kills 35 and injures 132.

title: Vienna
event: December 20 – The United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances is signed at Vienna.

title: Libya
event: December 21 – Pan Am Flight 103 is blown up over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing a total of 270 people. Those responsible are believed to be Libyans.

title: Brazil
event: December 22 – Brazilian union and environmental activist Chico Mendes is assassinated.

title: Western Australia
event: Homosexual acts between consenting adults are decriminalized in Western Australia.

title: Schiermonnikoog
event: The first national park in the Netherlands is established in Schiermonnikoog.

title: Highland Park Illinois
event: The wreck of the ''Lady Elgin'' is discovered off Highland Park, Illinois by Harry Zych.

title: Culver City California
event: The Museum of Jurassic Technology is founded in Culver City, California by David and Diana Wilson.

title: Libya
event: January 4 – Gulf of Sidra incident (1989): Two Libyan MiG-23 Floggers are engaged and shot down by 2 US Navy F-14 Tomcats.

title: East Midlands Airport
event: January 8 – Kegworth Air Disaster: A British Midland Boeing 737 crashes on approach to East Midlands Airport, leaving 47 dead.

title: Florida
event: January 24 – Serial killer Ted Bundy is executed in Florida's electric chair.

title: Victoria (Australia)
event: February 1 – Joan Kirner becomes Victoria's first female Deputy Premier, after the resignation of Robert Fordham over the VEDC (Victorian Economic Development Co-operation) Crisis.

title: South Africa
event: After a stroke, Pieter Willem Botha resigns his party's leadership and the presidency of South Africa.

title: India
event: Union Carbide agrees to pay USD $470 million to the Indian government for damages it caused in the 1984 Bhopal Disaster.

title: Iran
event: Iranian leader Ruhollah Khomeini encourages Muslims to kill ''The Satanic Verses'' author Salman Rushdie.

title: Pikk Hermann
event: After 44 years, Estonian flag is raised to the Pikk Hermann Castle tower.

title: Finland
event: Jammu Siltavuori abducts and murders two 8-year-old girls in the Myllypuro suburb of Helsinki, Finland.

title: Riyadh
event: Portugal wins the FIFA U-20 World Cup, defeating Nigeria on the final by 2–0 in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

title: London
event: The Purley Station rail crash in London leaves 5 dead and 94 injured.

title: Australian Capital Territory
event: The first ACT (Australian Capital Territory) elections are held.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 7 – Iran breaks off diplomatic relations with the United Kingdom over Salman Rushdie's ''The Satanic Verses''.

title: Texas
event: March 13 – A geomagnetic storm causes the collapse of the Hydro-Québec power grid. Six million people are left without power for 9 hours. Some areas in the northeastern U.S. and in Sweden also lose power, and aurorae are seen as far as Texas.

title: University of Utah
event: March 23 – Stanley Pons and Martin Fleischmann announce that they have achieved cold fusion at the University of Utah.

title: Prince William Sound
event: March 24 – Exxon Valdez oil spill: In Alaska's Prince William Sound the ''Exxon Valdez'' spills 240,000 barrels (11 million gallons) of oil after running aground.

title: NATO
event: April 4 – In Brussels, Belgium, NATO celebrates its 40th anniversary.

title: Barents Sea
event: April 7 – The Soviet submarine K-278 Komsomolets sinks in the Barents Sea, killing 41.

title: Tbilisi
event: April 9 – Georgian demonstrators are massacred by Red Army soldiers in Tbilisi's central square during a peaceful rally; 20 citizens are killed, many injured.

title: Hillsborough disaster
event: April 15 – The Hillsborough disaster, one of the biggest tragedies in European football, claims the life of 96 Liverpool supporters.

title: New York City
event: Trisha Meili is attacked while jogging in New York City's Central Park; as her identity remains secret for years, she becomes known as the Central Park Jogger.

title: USS Iowa (BB-61)
event: A gun turret explodes on the U.S. battleship ''Iowa'', killing 47 crew members.

title: United Kingdom
event: April 20 – NATO debates modernising short range missiles; although the U.S. and UK are in favour, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl obtains a concession deferring a decision.

title: Tiananmen Square protests of 1989
event: April 21 – Students from Beijing, Shanghai, Xian, and Nanjing begin protesting in Tiananmen Square.

title: Disney's Hollywood Studios
event: May 1 – Disney-MGM Studios at Walt Disney World opens to the public for the first time.

title: Iron Curtain
event: May 2 – The first crack in the Iron Curtain: Hungary dismantles {{convert150mikm}} of barbed wire fencing along the border with Austria.

title: Yugoslavia
event: May 6 – Yugoslavia wins the Eurovision Song Contest in Lausanne with the song ''Rock me'' performed by Riva.

title: Australian Capital Territory
event: May 11 – The ACT (Australian Capital Territory) Legislative Assembly meets for the first time.

title: San Bernardino California
event: May 12 – A Southern Pacific Railroad freight train crashes on Duffy Street in San Bernardino, California.

title: China
event: May 14 – Mikhail Gorbachev visits China, the first Soviet leader to do so since the 1960s.

title: Bond University
event: May 15 – Australia's first private tertiary institution, Bond University, opens on the Gold Coast.

title: Tiananmen Square
event: May 19 – Tiananmen Square protests of 1989: Zhao Ziyang meets the demonstrators in Tiananmen Square.

title: Beijing
event: May 20 – Tiananmen Square protests of 1989: The Chinese government declares martial law in Beijing.

title: Nordland
event: May 22 – The Nordland Days in Leningrad region (Leningrad oblast) open.

title: Tiananmen Square
event: Tiananmen Square protests of 1989: The 10 m (33 ft) high ''Goddess of Democracy'' statue is unveiled in Tiananmen Square by student demonstrators.

title: Bogotá
event: An attempted assassination of Miguel Maza Marquez, director of the Departamento Administrativo de Seguridad (DAS) in Bogotá, Colombia is committed by members of the Medellín Cartel, who kill 4 and injure 37.

title: Rogers Centre
event: The SkyDome (now known as Rogers Centre) is opened in Toronto.

title: Iran
event: The Ayatollah Khomeini dies in Iran.

title: Beijing
event: The Tiananmen Square massacre takes place in Beijing on the army's approach to the square, and the final stand-off in the square is covered live on television.

title: Ufa train disaster
event: Ufa train disaster: A natural gas explosion near Ufa, Russia kills 645 as 2 trains passing each other throw sparks near a leaky pipeline.

title: German battleship Bismarck
event: June 13 – The wreck of the German battleship ''Bismarck'', which was sunk in 1941, is located {{convert600mikm}} west of Brest, France.

title: Stonehenge
event: June 21 – British police arrest 250 people for celebrating the summer solstice at Stonehenge.

title: University of Limerick
event: June 22 – Ireland's first universities established since independence in 1922, Dublin City University and the University of Limerick, open.

title: Sioux City Iowa
event: July 19 – United Airlines Flight 232 (Douglas DC-10) crashes in Sioux City, Iowa, killing 112; 184 on board survive.

title: Aung San Suu Kyi
event: July 20 – Burmese opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi is placed under house arrest.

title: Cornell University
event: July 26 – A federal grand jury indicts Cornell University student Robert Tappan Morris, Jr. for releasing a computer virus, making him the first person to be prosecuted under the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.

title: Alice Springs
event: August 13 – A hot air balloon accident near Alice Springs, Australia kills 13.

title: Bogotá
event: August 18 – Leading presidential hopeful Luis Carlos Galán is assassinated near Bogotá in Colombia.

title: Pan-European Picnic
event: The Pan-European Picnic, a peace demonstration held on the Austrian-Hungarian border.

title: Southwark Bridge
event: Fifty-one people die when the Marchioness pleasure boat collides with a barge on the River Thames adjacent to Southwark Bridge.

title: Latvia
event: Two million indigenous people of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, then still occupied by the Soviet Union, join hands to demand freedom and independence, forming an uninterrupted 600 km human chain called the Baltic Way.

title: Australia
event: All of Australia's 1,645 domestic airline pilots resign over an airline's move to sack and sue them over a dispute.

title: New York
event: August 23 – Yusef Hawkins is shot in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, New York, sparking racial tensions between African Americans and Italian Americans.

title: 1990 FIFA World Cup
event: England holds Sweden to a 0–0 draw in Sweden, qualifying for the 1990 FIFA World Cup. The game becomes famous after Terry Butcher sustains a deep cut to his forehead early in the game. He receives stitches but plays on the entire game. By the end of the game, the front of Butcher's white shirt and shorts are almost entirely covered in blood.

title: Nordland
event: September 14 – An agreement of cooperation between Leningrad oblast (Russia) and Nordland County (Norway) is signed in Leningrad, by chairmen Lev Kojkolainen and Sigbjørn Eriksen.

title: South Africa
event: September 20 – F. W. de Klerk is sworn in as State President of South Africa.

title: South Carolina
event: September 21 – Hurricane Hugo makes landfall in South Carolina, causing $7 billion in damage.

title: United Kingdom
event: September 22 – 1989 Deal barracks bombing: An IRA bomb explodes at the Royal Marine School of Music in Deal, Kent, United Kingdom, leaving 11 dead and 22 injured.

title: Oakland California
event: October 17 – The Loma Prieta earthquake, measuring 7.1 on the Richter scale, strikes the San Francisco–Oakland region of Northern California, killing 67 people and delaying the 1989 World Series for ten days

title: Florida
event: October 19 – The Wonders of Life pavilion opens at Epcot in Walt Disney World, Florida.

title: Grand National Assembly of Turkey
event: October 31 – The Grand National Assembly of Turkey elects Prime Minister Turgut Özal as the eighth President of Turkey.

title: South Dakota
event: November 2 – North Dakota and South Dakota celebrate their 100th Birthdays.

title: Chumphon Province
event: November 4 – Typhoon Gay devastates Thailand's Chumphon Province.

title: Virginia
event: Douglas Wilder wins the Virginia governor's race, becoming the first elected African American governor in the United States.

title: New York City
event: David Dinkins becomes the first African American mayor of New York City.

title: Berlin Wall
event: Cold War: Günter Schabowski accidentally states in live broadcast press conference that new rules for traveling from East Germany to West Germany will be put in effect immediately. East Germany opens checkpoints in the Berlin Wall, allowing its citizens to travel freely to West Germany for the first time in decades (November 17 celebrates Germans began tearing the wall down).

title: Australia
event: Gaby Kennard becomes the first Australian woman to fly non-stop around the world.

title: Brazil
event: November 12 – Brazil holds its first free presidential election since 1960. This marks the first time that all Ibero-American nations, excepting Cuba, have elected constitutional governments simultaneously.

title: Society of Jesus
event: Six Jesuit priests—among them Ignacio Ellacuría, Segundo Montes, and Ignacio Martín-Baró—their housekeeper, and her teenage daughter, are murdered by U.S. trained Salvadoran soldiers.

title: South Africa
event: South African President F.W. de Klerk announces the scrapping of the Separate Amenities Act.

title: UNESCO
event: UNESCO adopts the Seville Statement on Violence at the 25th session of its General Conference.

title: North Carolina
event: November 21 – North Carolina celebrates its bicentennial statehood.

title: Beirut
event: November 22 – In West Beirut, a bomb explodes near the motorcade of Lebanese President Rene Moawad and kills him.

title: Philippines
event: A military coup attempt begins in the Philippines against the government of   Philippine President Corazon C. Aquino, ending by December 9.

title: Malta
event: December 3 – Cold War: In a meeting off the coast of Malta, U.S. President George H. W. Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev release statements indicating that the Cold War between their nations may be coming to an end.

title: Montreal
event: December 6 – École Polytechnique Massacre (or Montreal Massacre): Marc Lépine, an anti-feminist gunman, murders 14 young women at the École Polytechnique in Montreal.

title: Brazil
event: Brazil holds the second round of its first free election in 29 years; Fernando Collor de Mello wins.

title: Bucharest
event: December 21 – Nicolae Ceausescu addresses an assembly of some 110,000 people outside the Romanian Communist Party HQ in Bucharest. The crowd begin to protest against Ceausescu and he orders in the army to attack the protesters.

title: Kempsey New South Wales
event: Two tourist coaches collide on the Pacific highway north of Kempsey, Australia, killing 35.

title: Bank of Japan
event: Bank of Japan governors announce a major interest rate hike, eventually leading to the peak and fall of the ''bubble economy''.

title: Australia
event: December 28 – A magnitude 5.6 earthquake hits Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia, killing 13 people.

title: Hong Kong
event: Riots break out after Hong Kong decides to forcibly repatriate Vietnamese refugees.

title: Tokyo Stock Exchange
event: Nikkei 225 for Tokyo Stock Exchange hits its all-time intra-day high of 38,957.44 and closing high at 38,915.87.

title: Queensland
event: Homosexual acts between consenting adults are decriminalized in Queensland.

title: Leaning Tower of Pisa
event: January 7 – The Leaning Tower of Pisa is closed to the public because of safety concerns.

title: Sudan
event: January 9 – Ugandan Lt. Gen. Bazilio Olara-Okello, who led a coup against Dr. Apolo Milton Obote's government, dies in Ormduruman Hospital in Khartoum, Sudan.

title: Azerbaijan
event: January 20 – Cold War: Soviet troops occupy Baku, Azerbaijan, under the state of emergency decree issued by Gorbachev and kill over 130 and wound over 700 protesters for national independence.

title: Avianca Flight 52
event: January 25 – Avianca Flight 52 crashes into Cove Neck, Long Island, after a miscommunication between the flight crew and JFK Airport officials.

title: Tiraspol
event: January 27 – The city of Tiraspol in the Moldavian SSR briefly declares independence.

title: Exxon Valdez oil spill
event: January 29 – The trial of Joseph Hazelwood, former skipper of the Exxon ''Valdez'', begins in Anchorage, Alaska. He is accused of negligence that resulted in America's second worst oil spill to date.

title: South Africa
event: February 2 – Apartheid: In South Africa, President F.W. de Klerk allows the African National Congress to legally function again and promises to free Nelson Mandela.

title: South Africa
event: February 10 – South African President F.W. de Klerk announces that Nelson Mandela will be released the next day.

title: South Africa
event: Nelson Mandela is released from Victor Verster Prison, near Cape Town, South Africa, after 27 years behind bars.

title: Falkland Islands
event: February 15 – The United Kingdom and Argentina restore diplomatic relations after 8 years. The UK had severed ties in response to Argentina's invasion of the Falkland Islands, a British Dependent Territory, in 1982.

title: Nicaragua
event: The Sandinistas are defeated in the Nicaraguan elections.

title: Exxon Valdez oil spill
event: February 27 – Exxon ''Valdez'' oil spill: Exxon and its shipping company are indicted on 5 criminal counts.

title: Cairo
event: A fire at the Sheraton Hotel in Cairo, Egypt, kills 16 people.

title: London
event: Police seal off Brixton in South London after another night of protests against the poll tax.

title: Newfoundland and Labrador
event: Newfoundland and Labrador Premier Clyde Wells confirms he will rescind Newfoundland's approval of the Meech Lake Accord.

title: United Kingdom
event: Iraq hangs British journalist Farzad Bazoft for spying.  Daphne Parish, a British nurse, is sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment as an accomplice.

title: Massachusetts
event: Twelve paintings, collectively worth $100 to $300 million, are stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, Massachusetts by 2 thieves posing as police officers. This is the largest art theft in US history, and the paintings ({{As of2007lc=on}}) have not been recovered.

title: Namibia
event: March 21 – After 75 years of South African rule, Namibia becomes independent.

title: Happy Land fire
event: In New York City, a fire due to arson at an illegal social club called Happy Land kills 87.

title: California
event: March 26 – The 62nd Academy Awards, hosted by Billy Crystal, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, California, with ''Driving Miss Daisy'' winning Best Picture.

title: London
event: March 31 – The Second Battle of Trafalgar: A massive anti-poll tax demonstration in Trafalgar Square, London, turns into a riot; 471 people are injured, and 341 arrested.

title: Manchester
event: April 1 – Strangeways Prison riot: The longest prison riot in Britain's history begins at Strangeways Prison in Manchester, and continues for 3 weeks and 3 days, until April 25.

title: Denmark
event: April 8 – ''Scandinavian Star'', a Bahamas-registered ferry, catches fire en route from Norway to Denmark, leaving 158 dead.

title: Nicaragua
event: April 25 – Violeta Chamorro is elected President of Nicaragua.

title: London
event: May 2 – In London, a man brandishing a knife robs a courier of bearer bonds worth £292 million (the largest mugging to date).

title: Latvia
event: May 4 – Cold War: Latvia declares independence from the Soviet Union.

title: Yemen Arab Republic
event: Cold War: The leaders of the Yemen Arab Republic and the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen announce the unification of their countries as the Republic of Yemen.

title: Microsoft
event: Microsoft releases Windows 3.0.

title: 1990 FIFA World Cup
event: June 8 – The 1990 FIFA World Cup begins in Italy.

title: Manjil
event: June 21 – An earthquake measuring 7.3 on the Richter Scale kills thousands in the Iranian city of Manjil.

title: Philippines
event: June 22 – Underwater volcano Mount Didicas erupts in the Philippines.

title: United Kingdom
event: June 24 – Kathleen Young and Irene Templeton are ordained as priests in St Anne's Cathedral, Belfast, becoming the first Anglican women priests in the United Kingdom.

title: 1990 FIFA World Cup
event: July 8 – West Germany defeats Argentina 1–0 to win the 1990 FIFA World Cup.

title: Colombo
event: July 15 – Tamil Tigers kill 168 Muslims in Colombo, Sri Lanka.

title: Philippines
event: July 16 – An earthquake measuring 7.7 on the Richter Scale kills more than 1,600 in the Philippines.

title: Trinidad and Tobago
event: The parliament building and a government television house in Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago are stormed by the Jamaat al Muslimeen in a coup d'état attempt which lasts 5 days. Approximately 26 to 30 people are killed and several wounded (including then Prime Minister, A. N. R. Robinson, who is shot in the leg).

title: Iraq
event: August 2 – Gulf War: Iraq invades Kuwait, eventually leading to the Gulf War.

title: Iraq
event: August 6 – Gulf War: The United Nations Security Council orders a global trade embargo against Iraq in response to its invasion of Kuwait.

title: South Dakota
event: August 12 – Sue, the best preserved ''Tyrannosaurus rex'' specimen ever found, is discovered in South Dakota.

title: Joliet Illinois
event: August 28 – The Plainfield Tornado (F5 on the Fujita scale) strikes the towns of Plainfield, Crest Hill, and Joliet, Illinois, killing 29 people (the strongest tornado to date to strike the Chicago Metropolitan Area).

title: Azerbaijan
event: August 30 – Collapse of the Soviet Union: Azerbaijan declares independence from Soviet Union.

title: Liberia
event: September 9 – First Liberian Civil War: Liberian president Samuel Doe is captured by rebel leader Prince Johnson and killed in a filmed execution.

title: Iraq
event: September 11 – Gulf War: President George H. W. Bush delivers a nationally televised speech in which he threatens the use of force to remove Iraqi soldiers from Kuwait.

title: Georgia (U.S. state)
event: September 18 – The International Olympic Committee awards the 1996 Summer Olympics to Atlanta, Georgia.

title: Dome of the Rock
event: October 8 – Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: In Jerusalem, Israeli police kill 17 Palestinians and wound over 100 near the Dome of the Rock mosque on the Temple Mount.

title: Mount Lebanon
event: October 13 – Lebanese Civil War: Syrian military forces invade and occupy Mount Lebanon, ousting General Michel Aoun's government.  This effectively consolidates Syria's 14 year occupation of Lebanese soil.

title: New York City
event: October 14 – Leonard Bernstein dies of a heart attack at his home in New York City. He is 72 years old.

title: Nobel Peace Prize
event: October 15 – Cold War: Soviet Union leader Mikhail Gorbachev is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts to lessen Cold War tensions and reform his nation.

title: New York City
event: November 5 – Rabbi Meir Kahane, founder of the far-right Kach movement, is shot dead after a speech at a New York City hotel.

title: Oder-Neisse line
event: November 14 – Germany and Poland sign a treaty confirming the border at the Oder-Neisse line.

title: Iraq
event: November 29 – Gulf War: The United Nations Security Council passes UN Security Council Resolution 678, authorizing military intervention in Iraq if that nation does not withdraw its forces from Kuwait and free all foreign hostages by Tuesday, January 15, 1991.

title: English Channel
event: December 1 – Establishing the first land connection between the United Kingdom and the mainland of Europe for around 8,000 years, Channel Tunnel workers from the United Kingdom and France meet 40 metres beneath the English Channel seabed.

title: Bangladesh
event: President Hossain Mohammad Ershad of Bangladesh is forced to resign following massive protests.

title: Federated States of Micronesia
event: The Marshall Islands and Federated States of Micronesia become independent, after the termination of their trusteeship.

title: University of South Australia
event: The University of South Australia is founded.

title: Princeton University
event: Impostor James Hogue is exposed at Princeton University.

title: Israel
event: January 4 – The United Nations Security Council votes unanimously to condemn Israel's treatment of the Palestinians.

title: Vilnius
event: January 11 – Soviet forces storm Vilnius to stop Lithuanian independence. January Events (Lithuania).

title: South Africa
event: January 13 – A fight and stampede at a pre-season exhibition match between South African football teams Kaizer Chiefs and Orlando Pirates in the town of Orkney near Johannesburg, South Africa leaves 42 dead.

title: Iraq
event: January 15 – The United Nations deadline for the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from occupied Kuwait expires, preparing the way for the start of Operation Desert Storm.

title: Tel Aviv
event: January 19 – A SCUD attack on Tel Aviv injures 15 people.

title: Luanda
event: January 19 – The Party of the Alliance of Youth, Workers and Farmers of Angola is founded in Luanda, Angola.

title: Israel
event: January 22 – Three SCUDs and one Patriot missile hit Ramat Gan in Israel, injuring 96 people; 3 elderly people die of heart attacks.

title: Special Air Service
event: January 22 – British Army SAS patrol, Bravo Two Zero is deployed in Iraq during the Gulf War. All but one of eight members are killed or captured.

title: USAir Flight 1493
event: February 1 – A USAir Boeing 737-300, Flight 1493 collides with a SkyWest Airlines Fairchild Metroliner, Flight 5569 at Los Angeles International Airport, killing 34.

title: Michigan
event: February 5 – A Michigan court bars Dr. Jack Kevorkian from assisting in suicides.

title: Downing Street mortar attack
event: February 7 – The Provisional Irish Republican Army launches a mortar attack on 10 Downing Street during a cabinet meeting.

title: Baghdad
event: February 13 – Gulf War: Two laser-guided smart bombs destroy an underground bunker in Baghdad, killing hundreds of Iraqis. United States military intelligence claims it was a military facility but Iraqi officials identify it as a bomb shelter.

title: Iran
event: March–April – Iraqi forces suppress rebellions in the southern and northern parts of the country, creating a humanitarian disaster on the borders of Turkey and Iran.

title: Estonia
event: March 3 – Latvia and Estonia vote for independence from the Soviet Union.

title: United Airlines Flight 585
event: March 3 – United Airlines Flight 585 crashes in Colorado Springs, Colorado, killing all 25 people on board.

title: Persian Gulf
event: March 10 – Gulf War – Operation Phase Echo: 540,000 American troops begin to leave the Persian Gulf.

title: South Africa
event: March 11 – A curfew is imposed on black townships in South Africa, after fighting between rival political gangs kills 49.

title: Alaska
event: March 13 – The United States Department of Justice announces that Exxon has agreed to pay $1 billion for the clean-up of the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 15 – Germany formally regains complete independence after the 4 post-World War II occupying powers (France, the United Kingdom, the United States and the Soviet Union) relinquish all remaining rights.

title: Brazil
event: March 26 – Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay signed the Treaty of Asunción, establishing South Common Market (Mercosur its acronym in Spanish)

title: Boston University
event: March 30 – Northern Michigan University wins the NCAA Division I title in hockey, 8–7 in the third overtime against Boston University.

title: Albania
event: March 31 – Albania has its first multi-party elections.

title: Pennsylvania
event: April 4 – Senator John Heinz of Pennsylvania and 6 others are killed when a helicopter collides with their plane over Merion, Pennsylvania.

title: Southern Hemisphere
event: April 10 – A South Atlantic tropical cyclone develops in the Southern Hemisphere off the coast of Angola (the first of its kind to be documented by weather satellites).

title: Italy
event: April 10 – The Italian ferry ''Moby Prince'' collides with an oil tanker in dense fog off Livorno, Italy killing 140.

title: Andover Kansas
event: April 26 – 70 tornadoes break out in the central United States, killing 17. The most notable tornado of the day strikes Andover, Kansas.

title: Bangladesh
event: April 29 – A tropical cyclone hits Bangladesh, killing an estimated 138,000 people.

title: France
event: May 15 – Édith Cresson becomes France's first female premier.

title: India
event: May 21 – In Sriperumbudur, India, former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi is assassinated.

title: Bangkok
event: May 26 – In Thailand, a Lauda Air Boeing 767 crashes near Bangkok, killing all 223 people on-board.

title: Mount Unzen
event: June 3 – Mount Unzen erupts, killing 43 people as a result of pyroclastic flow.

title: Mount Pinatubo
event: June 15 – In the Philippines, Mount Pinatubo erupts in what will be the second largest terrestrial eruption of the 20th century; the final death toll tops 800.

title: South Africa
event: June 17 – Apartheid: The South African Parliament repeals the Population Registration Act, which had required racial classification of all South Africans at birth.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: June 25 – Collapse of Yugoslavia: Croatia and Slovenia declare their independence from Yugoslavia.

title: Cabo San Lucas
event: July 11 – A solar Eclipse of record totality occurs, seen first in Hawaii then enters Mexico with the path directly crosses Cabo San Lucas and Mexico City seen by 20 million inhabitants, and finally ends in Colombia in South America.

title: Indiana
event: July 22 – Boxer Mike Tyson is arrested and charged with raping Miss Black America contestant Desiree Washington 3 days earlier, in Indianapolis, Indiana.

title: Milwaukee
event: July 22 – Serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer is arrested after the remains of 11 men and boys are found in his Milwaukee, Wisconsin apartment. Police soon find out that he is involved in 6 more murders.

title: India
event: July 24 – The government of India announces its New Industrial Policy, marking the start of India's economic reforms.

title: South Africa
event: August 4 – The Cruise Liner MTS Oceanos sinks off the coast of South Africa and all 571 passengers onboard are safely evacuated.

title: Iran
event: August 7 – Shapour Bakhtiar, former prime minister of Iran, is assassinated.

title: Warsaw radio mast
event: August 8 – The Warsaw radio mast, the tallest construction ever built, collapses.

title: Australia
event: August 17 – Strathfield Massacre: In Sydney, Australia, taxi driver Wade Frankum shoots 7 people and injures 6 others before turning the gun on himself.

title: Estonia
event: August 20 – Collapse of the Soviet Union: Estonia declares its independence from the Soviet Union, and more than 100,000 people rally outside the Soviet Union's parliament building protesting the coup that deposed President Mikhail Gorbachev.

title: Latvia
event: August 21 – Collapse of the Soviet Union: Latvia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.

title: Azerbaijan
event: August 30 – Collapse of the Soviet Union: Azerbaijan declares independence from Soviet Union.

title: Hamlet chicken processing plant fire
event: September 3 – In Hamlet, North Carolina, a grease fire breaks out at the Imperial Foods chicken processing plant, killing 25 people.

title: Las Vegas Strip
event: September 5–7 – At the 35th Annual Tailhook Symposium in Las Vegas, 83 women and seven men are assaulted.

title: Republic of Macedonia
event: September 8 – The Republic of Macedonia becomes independent.

title: Federated States of Micronesia
event: September 17 – North Korea, South Korea, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, the Marshall Islands and Micronesia join the United Nations.

title: Ötzi the Iceman
event: September 19 – Ötzi the Iceman is found in the Alps.

title: Sandy Utah
event: September 20–21 – In Sandy, Utah, several patients are held hostage and a nurse is killed in the Alta View Hospital hostage incident.

title: AFL Grand Final
event: September 21 – AFL Grand Final: Hawthorn Hawks defeat West Coast Eagles by 53 points at Waverley Park, the final score 20.19.139 – 13.8.86.

title: Brazil
event: September 30 – A twister destroys parts of Itu, a city in southeastern Brazil, killing 16 and leaving 176 injured.

title: Arkansas
event: October 2 – Arkansas Governor Bill Clinton announces he will seek the 1992 Democratic nomination for President of the United States.

title: Foreign Intelligence Service (Russia)
event: October 11 – In Russia, the KGB is replaced by the SVR.{{Citation neededdate=September 2010}}

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: October 15 – United States Senate votes 52–48 to confirm Judge Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court of the United States.

title: Killeen Texas
event: October 16 – George Hennard guns down 24 people in Killeen, Texas before killing himself.

title: 1991 Perfect Storm
event: October 28 – The 1991 Perfect Storm Strikes the northeastern United States, causing over 200 million dollars of damage and resulting in 12 direct fatalities.

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: November 5 – The body of publishing tycoon Robert Maxwell is found floating in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: United Kingdom
event: November 9 – The British JET fusion reactor generates 1.5 MW output power.

title: Pan Am Flight 103
event: November 14 – American and British authorities announce indictments against 2 Libyan intelligence officials, in connection with the downing of the Pan Am Flight 103.

title: Phnom Penh
event: November 14 – Cambodian Prince Norodom Sihanouk returns to Phnom Penh after 13 years of exile.

title: Vukovar massacre
event: November 18 – Serb troops take Vukovar after an 87-day siege, and commit the worst massacre in Croatian history.

title: Azerbaijan
event: November 20 – An Azerbaijani MI-8 helicopter carrying 19 peacekeeping mission team with officials and journalists from Russia, Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan is shot down by Armenian military forces in Khojavend district of Azerbaijan.

title: Beirut
event: December 4 – Journalist Terry A. Anderson is released after 7 years' captivity as a hostage in Beirut (the last and longest-held American hostage in Lebanon).

title: Belavezha Accords
event: December 12 – Supreme Soviet of the Russian SFSR denounced Union Treaty of 1922 and ratified Belavezha Accords instead.

title: Red Sea
event: December 15 – The Egyptian ferry ''Salem Express'' sinks in the Red Sea, killing more than 450.

title: Australia
event: December 19 – Paul Keating replaces Bob Hawke as the new prime minister of Australia.

title: Khojaly Massacre
event: February 25–26  – 613 Azerbaijani civilians are massacred in Khojaly.

title: People's Republic of China
event: Deng Xiaoping accelerates market reforms to establish a socialist market economy in the People's Republic of China.

title: United Kingdom
event: The Council for National Academic Awards, UK is wound up.

title: Cameroon
event: Number of students graduating university in Cameroon – 41,000.

title: South Africa
event: January 11 – Singer Paul Simon is the first major artist to tour South Africa after the end of the cultural boycott.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: January 15 – The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia begins to break up. Slovenia and Croatia gain independence and international recognition in some Western countries.

title: Kinshasa
event: January 22 – Rebel forces occupy Zaire's national radio station in Kinshasa and broadcast a demand for the government's resignation.

title: Minnesota
event: January 26 – Super Bowl XXVI: The Washington Redskins defeat the Buffalo Bills 37–24 at the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

title: France
event: February 8 – The opening ceremony for the 1992 Winter Olympics is held in Albertville, France.

title: Iowa
event: February 10 – Tom Harkin wins the Iowa Democratic Caucus.

title: Hengelo
event: February 11 – An F-16 jet crashes into a residential district of Hengelo, the Netherlands; no casualties are reported.

title: Iraq
event: February 18 – Iraq disarmament crisis: The Executive Chairman of UNSCOM details Iraq's refusal to abide by UN Security Council disarmament resolutions.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: February 21 – The United Nations Security Council approves Resolution 743 to send a UNPROFOR peacekeeping force to Yugoslavia.

title: Supreme Court of Ireland
event: February 26 – The Supreme Court of Ireland rules that a 14-year-old rape victim may travel to England to have an abortion.

title: Zonguldak
event: March 3 – Turkey's worst coal mine disaster leaves 263 dead near Zonguldak.

title: People's Republic of China
event: March 9 – The People's Republic of China ratifies the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

title: Mauritius
event: March 12 – Mauritius becomes a republic while remaining a member of the Commonwealth of Nations.

title: Buenos Aires
event: March 17 – A suicide car-bomb goes off in the Israeli Embassy in Buenos Aires, killing 29 and injuring 242.

title: Dorothy Chandler Pavilion
event: March 30 – The 64th Academy Awards, hosted by Billy Crystal, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, California, with ''The Silence of the Lambs'' winning Best Picture.

title: New York
event: April 2 – In New York, Mafia boss John Gotti is convicted of the murder of mob boss Paul Castellano and of racketeering, and is later sentenced to life in prison.

title: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
event: April 5 – The Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina (without the presence of Serb political delegates) proclaims independence from the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.

title: Sarajevo
event: Bosnian War: Serb troops, following a mass rebellion of Serbs in Bosnia and Herzegovina against the Bosnian declaration of independence from Yugoslavia, besiege the city of Sarajevo.

title: Microsoft
event: April 6 – Microsoft releases Windows 3.1

title: Florida
event: April 9 – A Miami, Florida jury convicts former Panamanian ruler Manuel Noriega of assisting Colombia's cocaine cartel.

title: Baltic Exchange
event: April 10 – A Provisional Irish Republican Army bomb explodes in the Baltic Exchange in the City of London; 3 are killed, 91 injured.

title: Disneyland Paris
event: April 12 – The ''Euro Disney Resort'' officially opens with its theme park ''Euro Disneyland''. The resort and  its park's name were subsequently changed to Disneyland Paris.

title: Wembley Stadium (1923)
event: April 20 – The Freddie Mercury Tribute Concert, held at Wembley Stadium, is televised live to over 1 billion people and raises millions of dollars for AIDS research.

title: Serbia and Montenegro
event: April 28 – The two remaining constituent republics of the former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia – Serbia and Montenegro – form a new state, named the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (after 2003, Serbia and Montenegro), bringing to an end the official union of Serbs, Croats, Slovenes, Montenegrins, Bosnian Muslims and Macedonians that existed from 1918 (with the exception of the period during World War II).

title: Olivehurst California
event: May 1 – Eric Houston of Yuba County kills 4, injures 9, and holds many others hostage at Lindhurst High School, Olivehurst, California.

title: People's Republic of China
event: May 13 – Falun Gong is introduced by Li Hongzhi in China.

title: Italy
event: May 15 – The Genoa Expo '92 World's Fair opens in Genoa, Italy.

title: New York
event: May 19 – In Massapequa, New York, Amy Fisher shoots Mary Jo Buttafuoco, wife of Joey Buttafuoco.

title: Giovanni Falcone
event: May 23 – A Mafia bomb kills Italian anti-Mafia judge Giovanni Falcone.

title: Kentucky
event: June 1 – Kentucky celebrates its bicentennial statehood.

title: Denmark
event: June 2 – In a national referendum Denmark rejects the Maastricht Treaty by a thin margin.

title: Brazil
event: June 8 – The first World Ocean Day is celebrated, coinciding with the Earth Summit held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

title: Trenton New Jersey
event: June 15 – During a spelling bee at a Trenton, New Jersey elementary school, U.S. Vice President Dan Quayle erroneously corrects a student's spelling of the word ''potato'', indicating it should have an ''e'' at the end.

title: Estonia
event: June 20 – In Estonia, the kroon replaces the Soviet ruble.

title: Ullevi
event: June 26 – Denmark beats Germany 2–0 to win the 1992 UEFA European Football Championship at Ullevi Stadium in Gothenburg, Sweden.

title: Big Bear Lake California
event: June 28 – A magnitude 7.3 earthquake strikes Landers, California, followed by a magnitude 6.4 aftershock 8 km south-east of Big Bear Lake, California.

title: Estonia
event: June 28 – Estonia holds a referendum on its constitution.

title: Philippines
event: June 30 – Retired general and Defense Secretary Fidel V. Ramos is sworn in as the 12th President of the Philippines, having won elections held the previous month.

title: Iraq
event: July 6–29 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq refuses a U.N. inspection team access to the Iraqi Ministry of Agriculture.   UNSCOM claims that it has reliable information that the site contains archives related to illegal weapons activities. U.N. Inspectors stage a 17-day sit-in outside of the building, but leave when their safety is threatened by Iraqi soldiers.

title: Israel
event: July 13 – Yitzhak Rabin becomes prime minister of Israel.

title: 1992 Summer Olympics
event: July 25 – August 9 – The 1992 Summer Olympics are held in Barcelona, Spain.

title: Mall of America
event: August 11 – The largest shopping mall in the US, Minnesota's Mall of America is constructed on 78 acres (316,000 m²).

title: Idaho
event: August 21–22 – Events at Ruby Ridge, Idaho are sparked by a Federal Marshal surveillance team, resulting in the death of a Marshal, Sam Weaver and his dog and the next day the wounding of Randy Weaver, the death of his wife Vicki and the wounding of Kevin Harris.

title: Bahama Banks
event: August 23 – Hurricane Andrew attains Category 5 status on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale , and at 2100 UTC hits Eleuthera and the Bahama Banks

title: Florida
event: August 24–28 – Hurricane Andrew hits south Florida and dissipates over the Tennessee valley when it merges with a storm system; 23 are killed.

title: 1992 Nicaragua earthquake
event: September 2 – An earthquake in Nicaragua kills at least 116 people

title: Oahu
event: September 11 – Hurricane Iniki hits the Hawaiian Islands, Kauai and Oahu.

title: Lira
event: September 16 – Black Wednesday: The Pound Sterling and the Italian Lira are forced out of the European Exchange Rate Mechanism.

title: Iran
event: September 17 – Two Kurdish opposition leaders are assassinated by the Iranian Kazem Darabi and the Lebanese Abbas Rhayel.

title: Belfast
event: September 23 – A large Provisional Irish Republican Army bomb destroys the forensic laboratories in Belfast.

title: Kentucky Supreme Court
event: September 24 – The Kentucky Supreme Court, in ''Kentucky v. Wasson'', holds that laws criminalizing same-sex sodomy are unconstitutional, and accurately predicts that other state and the nation will eventually rule the same way.

title: Pittsburgh International Airport
event: October 1 – Pittsburgh International Airport's new facility opens in Findlay Township, near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.  The new terminal is built as an expansion for USAir and an upgrade from the older Pittsburgh International Airport facility.

title: Brazil
event: October 2 – A riot breaks out in the Carandiru Penitentiary in São Paulo, Brazil, resulting in the Carandiru Massacre.

title: Estonia
event: October 6 – Lennart Meri becomes the first president of newly independent Estonia.

title: Peekskill meteorite
event: October 9 – A 13-kilogram (29-pound) meteorite lands in the driveway of the Knapp residence in Peekskill, New York, destroying the family's Chevrolet Malibu. It becomes known as the Peekskill meteorite.

title: Baton Rouge Louisiana
event: October 17 – Yoshihiro Hattori, a 16-year-old Japanese exchange student, mistakes the address of a party and is shot dead after knocking on the wrong door in Baton Rouge, Louisiana.   The shooter, Rodney Peairs, is later acquitted, sparking outrage in Japan.

title: 1992 Windsor Castle fire
event: November 20 – In England, a fire breaks out in Windsor Castle, causing over £50 million worth of damage.

title: People's Republic of China
event: November 24 – In the People's Republic of China, a China Southern Airlines domestic flight crashes, killing all 141 people on-board.

title: Czech Republic
event: November 25 – The Czechoslovakia Federal Assembly votes to split the country into the Czech Republic and Slovakia, starting on January 1, 1993.

title: Hong Kong
event: November 30 – The trial of 14 South Vietnamese accused of murdering 24 North Vietnamese begins in Hong Kong (ends November 29, 1994).

title: North Dakota
event: December 5 – Kent Conrad of North Dakota resigns his seat in the United States Senate and is sworn into the other seat from North Dakota, becoming the only U.S. Senator ever to have held 2 seats on the same day.

title: India
event: December 6 – Extremist Hindu activists demolish Babri Masjid – a 16th century mosque in Ayodhya, India which had been used as a temple since 1949, leading to widespread communal violence, including the Mumbai Riots, in all killing over 1500 people.

title: Flores
event: December 12 – An earthquake hits Flores, Indonesia, leaving 2,500 dead.

title: France
event: December 20 – The Folies Bergère music hall in Paris, France closes.

title: Faro Airport
event: December 21 –  A Dutch DC-10, flight Martinair MP 495, crashes at Faro Airport, killing 56 people.

title: Brazil
event: December 29 – Brazil's president Fernando Collor de Mello is found guilty on charges that he stole more than $32 million from the government, preventing him from holding any elected office for 8 years.

title: Nepal
event: Severe floods hit South Asia, killing over 4,000 people in Bangladesh, India and Nepal.

title: California
event: Wildfires in California destroy over {{convert16000acrekm2}} and 700 homes.

title: Czech Republic
event: January 1 – Dissolution of Czechoslovakia: Slovakia and the Czech Republic separate in the so-called Velvet Divorce.

title: Washington (U.S. state)
event: January 5 – The state of Washington executes Westley Allan Dodd by hanging (the first legal hanging in America since 1965).

title: New York
event: January 5 – $7.4 million USD is stolen from Brinks Armored Car Depot in Rochester, New York in the 5th largest robbery in U.S. history.  Four men, Samuel Millar, Father Patrick Moloney, former Rochester Police officer Thomas O'Connor, and Charles McCormick, all of whom have ties to the Provisional Irish Republican Army, are accused.

title: Mainland Shetland
event: January 5 – M/V ''Braer'', a Liberian oil tanker, runs aground off the Scottish island of Mainland, causing a massive oil spill.

title: Falklands War
event: January 6 – Douglas Hurd is the first high-ranking British official to visit Argentina since the Falklands War.

title: Ghana
event: January 7 – The Fourth Republic of Ghana is inaugurated, with Jerry Rawlings as president.

title: Baltic Sea
event: January 14 – The Polish ferry M/S ''Jan Heweliusz'' sinks off the coast of Rügen in the Baltic Sea, killing 54 people.

title: Baghdad
event: January 19 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq refuses to allow UNSCOM inspectors to use its own aircraft to fly into Iraq, and begins military operations in the demilitarized zone between Iraq and Kuwait, and the northern Iraqi no-fly zones. U.S. forces fire approximately 40 Tomahawk cruise missiles at Baghdad factories linked to Iraq's illegal nuclear weapons program. Iraq then informs UNSCOM that it will be able to resume its flights.

title: Yugoslavia
event: February 22 – UN Security Council Resolution 808 is voted on, deciding that an international tribunal shall be established to prosecute violations of international law in Yugoslavia. The tribunal will is established on May 25 by Resolution 827.

title: World Trade Center
event: February 26 – World Trade Center bombing: In New York City, a van bomb parked below the North Tower of the World Trade Center explodes, killing 6 and injuring over 1,000.

title: Republic of Macedonia
event: March 5 – A Macedonian Palair Flight 305, a F-100 on a flight to Zurich, crashes shortly after take-off from Skopje killing 83 of the 97 on board.

title: India
event: March 12 – 1993 Bombay bombings: Several bombs explode in Bombay, India, killing 257 and injuring hundreds more.

title: North Korea
event: March 12 – North Korea nuclear weapons program: North Korea announces that it plans to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and refuses to allow inspectors access to nuclear sites.

title: Quebec
event: March 13–15 – The Great Blizzard of 1993 strikes the eastern U.S., bringing record snowfall and other severe weather all the way from Cuba to Quebec; it reportedly kills 184.

title: Iraq
event: March 17 – The PKK announces a unilateral ceasefire in Iraq.

title: Warrington
event: March 20 – Warrington bomb attacks: An IRA bomb explodes in Warrington Town Centre and kills 2 children, Jonathan Ball and Tim Parry.

title: Knesset
event: March 24 – The Israeli Knesset elects Ezer Weizman as President of Israel.

title: South Africa
event: March 24 – South Africa officially abandons its nuclear weapons programme. President de Klerk announces that the country's 6 warheads had already been dismantled in 1990.

title: Iran
event: March 27 – Following a rash of integrist murders, Algeria breaks diplomatic relations with Iran, accusing the country of interfering in its interior affairs.

title: Dorothy Chandler Pavilion
event: March 29 – The 65th Academy Awards, hosted by Billy Crystal, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, California, with ''Unforgiven'' winning Best Picture.

title: Republic of Macedonia
event: April 8 – The Republic of Macedonia is admitted to the United Nations.

title: South Africa
event: April 10 – African National Congress activist Chris Hani is assassinated in South Africa.

title: Srebrenica
event: April 16 – Bosnian War: Srebrenica falls.

title: Texas
event: April 19 – A 51-day stand-off at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Texas, ends with a fire that kills 76 people, including David Koresh.

title: South Dakota
event: April 19 – South Dakota governor George Mickelson and seven others are killed when a state-owned aircraft crashes in Iowa.

title: London
event: April 22 – 18-year-old student Stephen Lawrence is stabbed to death in London, England; the attack is believed to have been racially motivated.

title: France
event: May 1 – Pierre Bérégovoy, former prime minister of France, commits suicide.

title: Grand National Assembly of Turkey
event: May 16 – The Grand National Assembly of Turkey elects Prime Minister Süleyman Demirel as President of Turkey.

title: Monaco
event: May 28 – Eritrea and Monaco gain entry to the United Nations.

title: National Assembly of Venezuela
event: June 5 – The National Assembly of Venezuela designates Ramón José Velásquez as successor of suspended President Carlos Andrés Pérez.

title: Mogadishu
event: June 5 – 24 Pakistani troops in the UN forces are killed in Mogadishu, Somalia.

title: Iraq
event: June 8 – The PKK-declared ceasefire ends in Iraq.

title: Malawi
event: June 14 – Multipartyists win a referendum on the future of the one-party system in Malawi.

title: Manassas Virginia
event: June 23 – In Manassas, Virginia, Lorena Bobbitt cuts off the penis of her husband John Wayne Bobbitt.

title: Yale University
event: June 24 – A Unabomber bomb injures computer scientist David Gelernter at Yale University.

title: Macau
event: June 26–28 – Typhoon Koryn causes important damages in the Philippines, China and Macau.

title: Baghdad
event: June 27 – U.S. President Bill Clinton orders a cruise missile attack on Iraqi intelligence headquarters in the Al-Mansur District of Baghdad, in response to the attempted assassination of former U.S. President George H. W. Bush during his visit to Kuwait in mid-April.

title: Tokyo
event: July 7–9 – The 19th G7 summit is held in Tokyo, Japan.

title: 1993 Hokkaidō earthquake
event: July 12 – A magnitude 7.8 earthquake off Hokkaidō, Japan launches a devastating tsunami that kills 202 on the small island of Okushiri, Hokkaido.

title: Estonia
event: July 16–17 – In Estonia, the majority Russian cities of Narva and Sillamäe organize illegal referendums on territorial autonomy to protest new citizenship laws.

title: White House
event: July 20 – White House deputy counsel Vince Foster commits suicide in Virginia.

title: Rio de Janeiro
event: July 23 – Candelária massacre: Brazilian police officers kill 8 street kids in Rio de Janeiro.

title: Haenam
event: July 26 – Asiana Airlines Flight 733 crashes into Mt. Ungeo in Haenam, South Korea; 68 die.

title: Microsoft
event: July 27 – Windows NT 3.1, the first version of Microsoft's line of Windows NT operating systems, is released to manufacturing.

title: Tokyo Broadcasting System
event: August 6 – According to Japanese government and TBS networks reports, torrential rain and mudslides kill 72 in Kagoshima, Japan.

title: Nakhon Ratchasima
event: August 13 – Over 130 die in the collapse of Royal Plaza Hotel at Nakhon Ratchasima in Thailand's worst hotel disaster.

title: Buckingham Palace
event: August 17 – For the first time, the public is allowed inside Buckingham Palace.

title: Mars Observer
event: August 21 – NASA loses radio contact with the Mars Observer orbiter 3 days before the spacecraft is scheduled to enter orbit around Mars.

title: Israel
event: September 13 – PLO leader Yasser Arafat and Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin shake hands in Washington D.C., after signing a peace accord.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: September 15–21 – Hurricane Gert (1993) crosses from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean through Central America and Mexico.

title: Australia
event: September 23 – The International Olympic Committee selects Sydney, Australia to host the 2000 Summer Olympics.

title: Biosphere 2
event: September 26 – The first mission in Biosphere 2 ends after 2 years.

title: Portugal
event: September 26 – PoSAT-1 (the first Portuguese satellite) is launched on board French rocket Ariane 4.

title: India
event: September 30 – An earthquake centered in Killari, Maharashtra, India kills over 10,000.

title: People's Republic of China
event: October 5 – China performs a nuclear test, ending a worldwide ''de facto'' moratorium.

title: Mauritius
event: October 13 – The fifth summit of the Francophonie opens in Mauritius.

title: Greysteel
event: October 30 – Greysteel massacre: Three members of the UDA, a loyalist paramilitary group, attacked a crowded bar in Greysteel, Northern Ireland with firearms, killing eight civilians and wounding thirteen. The bar was targeted because it was in an Irish nationalist and Catholic area.

title: Parliament of the United Kingdom
event: November 5 – The  Parliament of the United Kingdom passes the Railways Act, setting out the procedures for privatisation of British Rail.

title: Microsoft
event: November 11 – Microsoft releases Windows 3.11 for Workgroups to manufacturing.

title: South Africa
event: November 18 – In South Africa, 21 political parties approve a new constitution.

title: California
event: November 20 – Savings and loan crisis: The United States Senate Ethics Committee issues a stern censure of California senator Alan Cranston for his dealings with savings-and-loan executive Charles Keating.

title: Ohrid
event: November 20 – An Avioimpex Yakovlev Yak-42D crashes into Mount Trojani near Ohrid, Macedonia. The aircraft was on a flight from Geneva, Switzerland to Skopje, but had been diverted to Ohrid due to poor weather conditions at the Skopje airport. All 8 crew members and 115 of the 116 passengers are killed.

title: Tattenham Corner railway station
event: December 1 – A train crash at Tattenham Corner railway station lead to the introduction of the current drugs and alcohol policy for railways in the UK.

title: NASA
event: December 2 – ''STS-61'': NASA launches the Space Shuttle ''Endeavour'' on a mission to repair an optical flaw in the Hubble Space Telescope.

title: South Africa
event: December 7 – The 32-member Transitional Executive Committee holds its first meeting in Cape Town, marking the first meeting of an official government body in South Africa with Black members.

title: Lunokhod 1
event: December 11 – A variety of Soviet space program paraphernalia are put to auction in Sotheby's New York, and sell for a total of US$6.8M. One of the items is Lunokhod 1 and its spacecraft Luna 17; they sell for $68,500.

title: Kazakhstan
event: December 13 – The Majilis of Kazakhstan approves the nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, and agrees to dismantle the more than 100 missiles left on its territory by the fall of the USSR.

title: Brazil
event: December 16 – Brazil's Supreme Court rules that former President Fernando Collor de Mello may not hold elected office again until 2000 due to political corruption.

title: Parliament of South Africa
event: December 22 – The interim South African constitution is approved by Parliament 237–45.

title: Argentina
event: December 29 – Argentina passes a measure allowing President Carlos Saul Menem and all future presidents to run for a second term.  It also shortens presidential terms to 4 years and removes the requirement for the president to be Roman Catholic.

title: Israel
event: December 30 – Israel and the Vatican establish diplomatic relations.

title: India
event: December 30 – The Congress Party gains a parliamentary majority in India after the defection of 10 Janata Dal party lawmakers.

title: Australia
event: August – ''Wollemia nobilis'', a fossil tree, is discovered by bushwalker David Noble, only 150 km from the largest city in Australia.

title: Iraq
event: September–October – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq threatens to stop cooperating with UNSCOM inspectors and begins to once again deploy troops near its border with Kuwait. In response, the U.S. begins to deploy troops to Kuwait.

title: Ireland
event: The Irish government announces the end of a 15-year broadcasting ban on the Provisional Irish Republican Army and its political arm Sinn Féin.

title: Canary Islands
event: January 15 – The ''SS American Star'' breaks tow in the Atlantic Ocean and is beached at Fuerteventura in the Canary Islands a few days later.

title: San Fernando Valley
event: January 17 – The 1994 Northridge earthquake, magnitude 6.7, hits the San Fernando Valley of Los Angeles at 4:31 a.m., killing 72 and leaving 26,029 homeless.

title: New Whiteland Indiana
event: January 19 – Record cold temperatures hit the eastern United States.  The coldest temperature ever measured in Indiana state history, −36°F (−38°C), is recorded in New Whiteland, Indiana.

title: South Carolina
event: January 20 – In South Carolina, Shannon Faulkner becomes the first female cadet to attend The Citadel, but soon drops out.

title: Australia
event: January 26 – A man fires 2 blank shots at Charles, Prince of Wales in Sydney, Australia.

title: West Bank
event: February 25 – Israeli Kahanist Baruch Goldstein opens fire inside the Cave of the Patriarchs in the West Bank; he kills 29 Muslims before worshippers beat him to death.

title: New York City
event: A lone terrorist kills Ari Halberstam during an attack on 14 Jewish students on the Brooklyn Bridge in New York City. [http://www.arihalberstam.com]

title: Namibia
event: South Africa cedes Walvis Bay to Namibia.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: March 7 – ''Campbell v. Acuff-Rose Music, Inc.'': The Supreme Court of the United States rules that parodies of an original work are generally covered by the doctrine of fair use.

title: Dorothy Chandler Pavilion
event: March 21 – The 66th Academy Awards, hosted by Whoopi Goldberg, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, California. Steven Spielberg's Holocaust drama, ''Schindler's List'', wins 7 Oscars including Best Picture and Best Director (Spielberg).

title: North Carolina
event: March 23 – Green Ramp disaster: Two military aircraft collide over Pope Air Force Base, North Carolina causing dozens of fatalities.

title: Piedmont Alabama
event: The biggest tornado outbreak in 1994 occurs in the southeastern United States; 1 tornado hits a Goshen United Methodist Church in Piedmont, Alabama, killing 22 people.

title: South Africa
event: March 28 – Shell House Massacre: Inkatha Freedom Party and ANC supporters battle in central Johannesburg South Africa.

title: Rwanda
event: April 6 – Rwandan President Juvénal Habyarimana and Burundi President Cyprien Ntaryamira die when a missile shoots down their jet near Kigali, Rwanda. This is taken as a pretext to begin the Rwandan Genocide.

title: Rwanda
event: The Rwandan Genocide begins in Kigali, Rwanda.

title: Sistine Chapel
event: Michelangelo's ''Universal Judgement'' is reopened to the public after 10 years of restorations.

title: Finland
event: April 16 – Voters in Finland decide to join the European Union in a referendum.

title: Rwanda
event: April 21 – The Red Cross estimates that hundreds of thousands of Tutsi have been killed in Rwanda.

title: Burnsville High School
event: The largest high school arson ever in the United States is started at Burnsville High School, in Burnsville, Minnesota, resulting in over 15 million dollars in damages.  The same arsonist also goes on to set arsons at Edina High School and Minnetonka High School. [http://www.olafire.com/AFSAContest.asp]

title: China Airlines Flight 140
event: China Airlines Flight 140, an Airbus A300, crashes while landing at Nagoya, Japan, killing 264 people.

title: South Africa
event: April 27 – South Africa holds its first fully multiracial elections, marking the final end of apartheid.

title: Autodromo Enzo e Dino Ferrari
event: May 1 – Three-time Formula One world champion Ayrton Senna is killed in an accident during the San Marino Grand Prix in Imola, Italy.

title: Azerbaijan
event: May 5 – The Bishkek Protocol between Armenia and Azerbaijan was signed, effectively freezing the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict.

title: France
event: May 6 – The Channel Tunnel, which took 15,000 workers over 7 years to complete, opens between England and France, enabling passengers to travel between the 2 countries in 35 minutes.

title: South Africa
event: Nelson Mandela is inaugurated as South Africa's first black president.

title: Illinois
event: Illinois executes serial killer John Wayne Gacy by lethal injection for the murder of 33 young men and boys.

title: North America
event: An annular eclipse of the sun is visible across much of North America.

title: Malawi
event: May 17 – Malawi holds its first multiparty elections.

title: Iona
event: May 20 - After a funeral in Cluny Parish Church, Edinburgh attended by 900 people and after which 3,000 people lined the streets, John Smith is buried in a private family funeral on the island of Iona, at the sacred burial ground of Reilig Odhráin, which contains the graves of several Scottish kings as well as monarchs of Ireland, Norway and France.

title: Vatican City
event: May 22 – Pope John Paul II issues the Apostolic Letter ''Ordinatio Sacerdotalis'' from the Vatican, expounding the the Catholic Church's position requiring the reservation of priestly ordination to men alone.

title: Israel
event: June 15 – Israel and the Vatican establish full diplomatic relations.

title: International Olympic Committee
event: June 23 – The International Olympic Committee celebrates their first centennial.

title: Washington (U.S. state)
event: June 24 – U.S. Air Force pilot Bud Holland crashes a B-52 in Fairchild Air Force Base, Washington as a result of pilot error.

title: Airbus
event: June 30 – An Airbus A330 crashes during a test flight near Toulouse, France, where Airbus is based, killing the seven-person crew. The test was meant to simulate an engine failure at low speed with maximum angle of climb.

title: 1994 FIFA World Cup
event: July 2 – Colombian footballer Andrés Escobar, 27, is shot dead in Medellín. His murder is commonly attributed as retaliation for the own goal Escobar scored in the 1994 FIFA World Cup against the United States.

title: Colorado
event: July 6 – Fourteen firefighters die in the South Canyon wildfire on Storm King Mountain in Colorado. The event inspires the 1999 book ''Fire on the Mountain''.

title: Yemen
event: July 7 – 1994 civil war in Yemen: Aden is occupied by troops from North Yemen.

title: 1994 FIFA World Cup
event: July 17 – Brazil wins the 1994 FIFA World Cup, defeating Italy by 3–2 in penalties (full time 0–0).

title: 1994 AMIA bombing
event: July 18 – In Buenos Aires, a terrorist attack destroys a building housing several Jewish organizations, killing 85 and injuring many more (see AMIA Bombing).

title: Israel
event: July 25 – Israel and Jordan sign the Israel-Jordan Treaty of Peace, which formally ends the state of war that has existed between the nations since 1948.

title: United Kingdom
event: Fire destroys the Norwich Central Library in the United Kingdom, including most of its historical records.

title: University of London
event: The University of London founds the School of Advanced Study, a group of postgraduate research institutes.

title: Havana
event: August 5 – Groups of protesters spread from Havana, Cuba's Castillo de la Punta (Point Castle), creating the first protests against Fidel Castro's government since 1959.

title: Woodstock Festival
event: Woodstock '94 begins in Saugerties, New York. It is the 25-year anniversary of Woodstock in 1969.

title: Estonia
event: The Russian army leaves Estonia.

title: People's Republic of China
event: September 3 – Cold War: Russia and the People's Republic of China agree to de-target their nuclear weapons against each other.

title: Kansai International Airport
event: September 4 – Kansai International Airport in Osaka, Japan opens. All international services are transferred from Itami to Kansai.

title: Australia
event: September 5 – New South Wales State MP for Cabramatta John Newman is shot outside his home, in Australia's first political assassination since 1977.

title: Pittsburgh International Airport
event: September 8 – USAir Flight 427, a Boeing 737 with 132 people on board, crashes on approach to Pittsburgh International Airport; there are no survivors.

title: Baltic Sea
event: September 28 – The car ferry ''MS Estonia'' sinks in the Baltic Sea, killing 852 people.

title: Quebec
event: October 4 – In Switzerland, 23 members of the Order of the Solar Temple cult are found dead, a day after 25 of their fellow cultists are similarly discovered in Morin Heights, Quebec.

title: UNESCO
event: October 5 – UNESCO inaugurates World Teachers' Day to celebrate and commemorate the signing of the Recommendation Concerning the Status of Teachers on October 5, 1966.

title: Iraq
event: October 8 – Iraq disarmament crisis: The President of the United Nations Security Council says that Iraq must withdraw its troops from the Kuwait border, and immediately cooperate with weapons inspectors.

title: NASA
event: October 12 – NASA loses radio contact with the Magellan spacecraft as the probe descends into the thick atmosphere of Venus (the spacecraft presumably burned up in the atmosphere either October 13 or October 14).

title: White House
event: October 29 – Francisco Martin Duran fires over 2 dozen shots at the White House; he is later convicted of trying to kill President Bill Clinton.

title: Roselawn Indiana
event: An American Eagle Airlines ATR 72 crashes in Roselawn, Indiana, after circling in icy weather, killing 64 passengers.

title: Israel
event: The Duke of Edinburgh attends a ceremony in Israel, where his late mother, Princess Alice of Battenberg, is honoured as Righteous among the Nations for sheltering Jewish families from the Nazis in Athens, during World War II.

title: Sydney
event: Sydney's third runway opens, ensuring protests about noise levels.

title: Italy
event: November 6 – A flood in Piedmont, Italy, kills dozens of people.

title: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
event: November 7 – WXYC, the student radio station of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, provides the world's first internet radio broadcast.

title: Georgia (U.S. state)
event: November 8 – Georgia Representative Newt Gingrich leads the United States Republican Party in taking control of both the House of Representatives and the Senate in midterm congressional elections, the first time in 40 years the Republicans secure control of both houses of Congress.  George W. Bush is elected Governor of Texas.

title: Channel Tunnel
event: The first passengers travel through the Channel Tunnel.

title: California
event: November 16 – A Federal judge issues a temporary restraining order, prohibiting the State of California from implementing Proposition 187, that would have denied most public services to illegal aliens.

title: Australia
event: December 2 – The Australian government agrees to pay reparations to indigenous Australians who were displaced during the nuclear tests at Maralinga in the 1950s and 1960s.

title: Fresno California
event: A Learjet piloted by Richard Anderson and Brad Sexton misses an elementary school and crashes into an apartment complex in Fresno, California, killing both pilots and injuring several apartment residents.

title: California
event: A runaway Santa Fe freight train rear ends a Union Pacific train at the bottom of Cajon Pass, California.

title: United Kingdom
event: British Home Secretary Michael Howard announces that Myra Hindley will serve a whole life tariff for the Moors Murders of the 1960s.

title: Hawaii
event: December 31 is skipped by the Phoenix Islands to switch from the UTC−11 time zone to UTC+13, and by the Line Islands to switch from UTC−10 to UTC+14. The latter becomes the earliest time zone in the world, one full day ahead of Hawaii.

title: Tashilhunpo Monastery
event: December 8 – 6-year-old Gyaincain Norbu is enthroned as the 11th reincarnation of the Panchen Lama at Tashilhunpo Monastery.

title: Texas
event: The Republic of Texas group claims to have formed a provisional government in Texas.

title: Italy
event: In ''Command & Conquer'', the fictional alien substance Tiberium first appears on Earth in Italy.

title: Finland
event: January 1 – Austria, Finland & Sweden act to join the European Union.

title: North Sea
event: January 1 – The Draupner wave in the North Sea in Norway is detected, confirming the existence of freak waves.

title: Mir
event: January 9 – Valeri Polyakov completes 366 days in space while aboard the Mir space station, breaking a duration record.

title: Súðavík
event: January 16 – An avalanche hits the village Súðavík in Iceland, killing 14 people.

title: Great Hanshin earthquake
event: January 17 – A magnitude 6.8 earthquake called the Great Hanshin earthquake occurs near Kobe, Japan, causing great property damage and killing 6,434 people.

title: Andøya
event: January 25 – Norwegian rocket incident: A rocket launched from the space exploration centre at Andøya, Norway is briefly interpreted by the Russians as an incoming attack.

title: Aust
event: February 1 – Lyricist/guitarist Richey Edwards of the Welsh alternative rock band Manic Street Preachers goes missing from a hotel in Bayswater, London on the eve of a planned tour of the United States. His car is found 2 weeks later at Severn View services in Aust.

title: United Kingdom
event: February 9 – ''STS-63'': Dr. Bernard A. Harris, Jr. and Michael Foale became the first African American and Briton, respectively, to walk in space.

title: Taiwan
event: February 15 – Taiwan's deadliest fire, at a karaoke restaurant in Taichung, kills 64.

title: Lansdowne Road
event: February 15 – In Dublin, a Republic of Ireland vs. England football match in Lansdowne Road is abandoned, due to violence and rioting.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: February 21 – Steve Fossett lands in Leader, Saskatchewan, Canada, becoming the first person to make a solo flight across the Pacific Ocean in a balloon.

title: Tokyo Stock Exchange
event: February 26 – The United Kingdom's oldest investment banking firm, Barings Bank, collapses after securities broker Nick Leeson loses $1.4 billion by speculating on the Tokyo Stock Exchange

title: Minnesota
event: February 28 – Members of the group Patriot's Council are convicted in Minnesota of manufacturing ricin.

title: Iraq
event: March 13 – David Daliberti and William Barloon, two Americans working for a military contractor in Kuwait, are arrested after straying into Iraq.

title: Kazakhstan
event: March 14 – Astronaut Norman Thagard becomes the first American to ride into space aboard a Russian launch vehicle (the ''Soyuz TM-21''), lifting off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.

title: Mississippi
event: March 16 – Mississippi ratifies the Thirteenth Amendment, becoming the last state to approve the abolition of slavery. The amendment was nationally ratified in 1865.

title: Tokyo
event: March 20 – Sarin gas attack on the Tokyo subway. Members of the Aum Shinrikyo religious cult release sarin gas on 5 subway trains in Tokyo, killing 12 and injuring 5,510.

title: Belfast
event: March 24 – For the first time in 26 years, no British soldiers patrol the streets of Belfast, Northern Ireland.

title: Oklahoma City bombing
event: April 19 – Oklahoma City bombing: 168 people, including 8 Federal Marshals and 19 children, are killed at the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building. Timothy McVeigh and one of his accomplices, Terry Nichols, set off the bomb.

title: Sacramento California
event: April 24 – A Unabomber bomb kills lobbyist Gilbert Murray in Sacramento, California.

title: Daegu
event: April 28 – In Daegu, South Korea, a gas explosion at a subway construction site kills 101 persons, mostly teenage schoolboys.

title: France
event: May 1 – Jacques Chirac is elected president of France

title: Finland
event: May 7 – Finland wins the ice hockey world championship.

title: Greece
event: May 13 – An earthquake hits the regions of Kozani and Grevena in Greece, with an intensity of 6.6 on the Richter scale.

title: Mount Fuji
event: May 16 – Japanese police besiege the headquarters of Aum Shinrikyo near Mount Fuji and arrest cult leader Shoko Asahara.

title: Oklahoma City bombing
event: May 20 – U.S. President Bill Clinton indefinitely closes part of the street in front of the White House, Pennsylvania Avenue, to vehicular traffic in response to the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Czech Republic
event: May 21 – Pope John Paul II canonizes John Sarkander during his visit to Olomouc, the Czech Republic.

title: Vienna
event: May 24 – AFC Ajax wins the UEFA Champions League in  the Ernst Happel Stadium in Vienna by defeating AC Milan 0–1 by a goal of Patrick Kluivert. This was the third consecutive win of AFC Ajax over AC Milan that season, ranking AFC Ajax on the 4th place on the list of European Cup and UEFA Champions League winners.

title: Supreme Court of Canada
event: May 25 – Egan v. Canada: The Supreme Court of Canada rules that discrimination based on sexual orientation is prohibited under the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
