title: Culpeper Virginia
event: May 27 – In Culpeper, Virginia, actor Christopher Reeve is paralyzed from the neck down after falling from his horse in a riding competition.

title: Neftegorsk Sakhalin Oblast
event: May 28 – A 7.6 magnitude earthquake in Neftegorsk, Russia kills at least 2,000.

title: NATO
event: June 2 – Mrkonjić Grad incident: A United States Air Force F-16 piloted by Captain Scott O'Grady is shot down over Bosnia and Herzegovina while patrolling the NATO no-fly zone. O'Grady is rescued by U.S. Marines six days later.

title: Italy
event: June 2 – Waffen-SS Hauptsturmführer Erich Priebke is extradited from Argentina to Italy.

title: Mir
event: June 6 – U.S. astronaut Norman Thagard breaks NASA's space endurance record of 14 days, 1 hour and 16 minutes, aboard the Russian space station Mir.

title: French Polynesia
event: June 13 – French President Jacques Chirac announces the resumption of nuclear tests in French Polynesia.

title: Salt Lake City
event: June 16 – The IOC selects Salt Lake City to host the 2002 Winter Olympics.

title: Sampoong Department Store collapse
event: June 29 – The Sampoong Department Store collapses in the Seocho-gu district of Seoul, South Korea, killing 501 and injuring 937.

title: Iraq
event: June 29 – Iraq disarmament crisis: According to UNSCOM, the unity of the UN Security Council begins to fray, as a few countries, particularly France and Russia, become more interested in making financial deals with Iraq than in disarming the country.

title: Aung San Suu Kyi
event: July 10 – Burmese dissident Aung San Suu Kyi is freed from house arrest.

title: Srebrenica massacre
event: July 11 – Bosnian Serbs march into Srebrenica while UN Dutch peacekeepers leave. Large numbers of Bosniak men and boys are killed in the Srebrenica massacre.

title: Montserrat
event: July 18 – A series of huge eruptions by the Soufrière Hills volcano sends lava flows and ash falls across a wide area of southern Montserrat.

title: Taiwan
event: July 21–26 – Third Taiwan Strait Crisis: The People's Liberation Army fires missiles into the waters north of Taiwan.

title: Knin
event: August 5 – Croatian forces take Knin and continue to advance.

title: Tokyo
event: August 6 – Hundreds in Hiroshima, Nagasaki, Washington, D.C., and Tokyo mark the 50th anniversary of the dropping of the atomic bomb.

title: Microsoft
event: August 24 – Microsoft releases Windows 95.

title: Sarajevo
event: August 28 – A Serbian mortar bomb near a Sarajevo market square kills 38 civilians.

title: Tbilisi
event: August 29 – Eduard Shevardnadze, the Georgian head of state, survives an assassination attempt in Tbilisi.

title: NATO
event: August 30 – The NATO bombing campaign against Serb artillery positions begins in Bosnia and Herzegovina, continuing into October. At the same time, ARBiH forces begin an offensive against the Bosnian Serb Army around Sarajevo, central Bosnia, and Bosnian Krajina.

title: Beijing
event: September 4 – The Fourth World Conference on Women opens in Beijing with over 4,750 delegates from 181 countries in attendance.

title: Iran
event: September 23 – Argentine national Guillermo Bill Gaede is arrested in Phoenix, Arizona on charges of industrial espionage. His sales to Cuba, China, North Korea and Iran are believed to have involved Intel and AMD trade secrets worth USD$10–20 million.

title: World Trade Center
event: October 1 – Ten people are convicted of bombing the World Trade Center in 1993.

title: France
event: October 4 – France launches a counter-coup in the Comoros with 600 soldiers. They arrest Bob Denard and his mercenaries and take Denard to France; Caabi el-Yachroutu becomes the interim president.

title: Pensacola Beach Florida
event: October 4 – Hurricane Opal makes landfall at Pensacola Beach, Florida as a Category 3 hurricane with 115 mph winds.

title: South Carolina
event: October 15 – The Carolina Panthers win their first-ever regular season game by defeating the New York Jets at Clemson Memorial Stadium in South Carolina.

title: Texas
event: October 23 – In Houston, Texas, Yolanda Saldivar is convicted of first degree murder in the shooting death of Selena Quintanilla Perez and three days later is sentenced to life in prison.

title: Flateyri
event: October 26 – An avalanche hits the village Flateyri in Iceland, killing 20 people.

title: Azerbaijan
event: October 28 – A fire in Baku Metro, Azerbaijan, kills 289 passengers (the world's worst subway disaster).

title: Quebec
event: October 30 – Quebec independentists narrowly lose a referendum for a mandate to negotiate independence from Canada.

title: NASA
event: November 1 – NASA loses contact with the Pioneer 11 probe.

title: Wright-Patterson Air Force Base
event: November 1 – Participants in the Yugoslav War begin negotiations at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio.

title: Supreme Court of Argentina
event: November 2 – The Supreme Court of Argentina orders the extradition of Erich Priebke, ex-S.S. captain.

title: Pan Am Flight 103
event: November 3 – At Arlington National Cemetery, U.S. President Bill Clinton dedicates a memorial to the victims of the Pan Am Flight 103 bombing.

title: Israel
event: November 4 – Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin is assassinated at a peace rally in Tel Aviv.

title: Philippines
event: November 7 – Typhoon Angela leaves the Philippines and Vietnam devastated, with 882 deaths and damage of P 10,829,000,000. The typhoon was the strongest ever to strike the Philippines in 25 years, with wind speeds of 130 mph and gusts of 180 mph.

title: Nigeria
event: November 10 – In Nigeria, playwright and environmental activist Ken Saro-Wiwa, along with 8 others from the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People, are hanged by government forces.

title: Wright-Patterson Air Force Base
event: November 21 – The Dayton Agreement to end the Bosnian War is reached at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near Dayton, Ohio (signed December 14).

title: New York City
event: November 22 – Six-year-old Elisa Izquierdo's child abuse-related death at the hands of her mother makes headlines, and instigates major reform in New York City's child welfare system.

title: NATO
event: November 30 – Javier Solana becomes the new NATO General Secretary; Operation Desert Storm officially ends.

title: European Court of Justice
event: December 15 – The European Court of Justice rules that all EU football players have the right to a free transfer among member states at the end of their contracts.

title: Baghdad
event: December 16 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraqi scuba divers, under the direction of the United Nations Special Commission, dredge the Tigris near Baghdad. The divers find over 200 prohibited Russian-made missile instruments and components.

title: Buga Valle del Cauca
event: December 20 – American Airlines Flight 965 (Boeing 757) crashes into a mountain near Buga, Valle del Cauca, Colombia after veering off its course en route to Cali, Colombia. Of the 164 people on board, four passengers and a dog are the only survivors.

title: Aberdeenshire
event: December 30 – The lowest ever United Kingdom temperature of {{Convert-27.2°C°Fabbr=onlk=off}} is recorded at Altnaharra in the Scottish Highlands. This equals the record set at Braemar, Aberdeenshire in 1895 and 1982.

title: Iraq
event: Iraq disarmament crisis: U.N. Inspector Scott Ritter attempts to conduct surprise inspections on the Republican Guard facility at the airport, but is blocked by Iraqi officials.

title: Drumcree Church
event: Confrontations occur in Northern Ireland between police and Orange Order protestors at Drumcree Church (see Drumcree conflict).

title: Philadelphia
event: In 12 Monkeys, a virus is released into Philadelphia on December 13, 1996.

title: Los Angeles
event: The story for Demolition Man begins in 1996, by which time the entire city of Los Angeles is completely at the mercy of criminal warlords.

title: New York
event: The invasive species Asian long-horned beetle is found in New York.

title: Kinshasa
event: January 8 – A Zairean cargo plane crashes into a crowded market in the center of the capital Kinshasa, killing 350.

title: Italy
event: January 9 – Art forger Eric Hebborn is assassinated in Rome, Italy.

title: Italy
event: January 13 – Italy's prime minister, Lamberto Dini, resigns after the failure of all-party talks to confirm him. New talks are initiated by president Oscar Luigi Scalfaro to form a new government.

title: Portugal
event: January 14 – Jorge Sampaio is elected president of Portugal.

title: Sierra Leone
event: January 16 – President of Sierra Leone Valentine Strasser is deposed by the chief of defence, Julius Maada Bio. Bio promises to restore power following elections scheduled for February.

title: Rhode Island
event: January 19 – The ''North Cape'' Oil Spill occurs as an engine fire forces the tugboat ''Scandia'' ashore on Moonstone Beach in South Kingstown, Rhode Island.  The ''North Cape'' Barge is pulled along with it and leaks 820,000 gallons of home heating oil.

title: Sumatra
event: January 19 – An Indonesian ferry sinks off the northern tip of Sumatra, drowning more than 100 people.

title: La Fenice
event: January 29 – Fire destroys La Fenice, Venice's opera house.

title: Colombo
event: January 31 – An explosives-filled truck rams into the gates of the Central Bank in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing at least 86 and injuring 1,400.

title: People's Republic of China
event: January 31 – An explosion in Shaoyang, China kills 122 and injures over 400 when 10 tons of dynamite in an illegal explosives warehouse underneath an apartment building detonate.

title: Colombo
event: January 31 – A bomb planted by the Tamil Tigers explodes in Colombo, killing 88 and injuring hundreds more.

title: People's Republic of China
event: February 4 – An earthquake near Lijiang in southwest China, measuring up to 7 on the Richter scale, kills at least 240 people, injures more than 14,000 and makes hundreds of thousands homeless.

title: Birgenair Flight 301
event: February 6   – A Birgenair Boeing 757, on an unauthorised charter flight from the Caribbean to Germany, crashes into the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of the Dominican Republic, killing all 189 passengers and crew (see Birgenair Flight 301).

title: 1996 Docklands bombing
event: February 8 – An IRA ceasefire ends with a half-tonne bomb in London's Canary Wharf District, killing 2 and causing over £85 million worth of damage.

title: NATO
event: February 10 – Bosnian Serbs break off contact with the Bosnian government and with representatives of Ifor, the NATO localised force, in reaction to the arrest of several Bosnian Serb war criminals.

title: Philippines
event: February 14 – Violent clashes erupt between Filipino soldiers and Vietnamese boat people, as the Philippines government attempts to forcibly repatriate hundreds of Vietnamese asylum seekers.

title: People's Republic of China
event: February 15 – A Long March 3 rocket at the Xichang Satellite Launch Center in China crashes into a rural village after liftoff, killing as many as 500.{{Citation neededdate=January 2009}}

title: Bangladesh
event: February 15 – Begum Khaleda Zia is reelected as prime minister of Bangladesh. The country's second democratic election is marred by low voter turnout, due to several  boycotts and pre-election violence, which result in at least 13 deaths.

title: United Kingdom
event: February 15 – The UK government publishes the Scott Report.

title: West End of London
event: February 18 – An IRA briefcase bomb in a bus kills the bomber and injures 9 in the West End of London.

title: Philippines
event: February 19 – A wooden ferry capsizes as it enters the port of Cádiz in the Philippines, killing 54 people.

title: Lumberton North Carolina
event: February 29 – In Lumberton, North Carolina, Daniel Green is convicted of the murder of James Jordan, the father of basketball star Michael Jordan.

title: Arequipa
event: February 29 – A Boeing 737 flying for Faucett Airlines in route from Lima to Rodriguez Ballon airport crashes into a mountain near Arequipa; all 123 people on board are killed (see Faucett Flight 251).

title: Uganda
event: February 29 – At least 81 people drown when a boat capsizes 120 kilometres east of Kampala, Uganda.

title: Israel
event: March 3–4 – Two more suicide bombs explode in Israel, killing 32. The Yahya Ayyash Units admit responsibility, and Palestinian president Yasser Arafat condemns the killings in a televised address. Israel warns of retaliation.

title: Sierra Leone
event: March 6 – A boat carrying market traders capsizes outside Freetown harbour, in Sierra Leone, killing at least 86.

title: Taiwan
event: March 8 – The People's Republic of China begins surface-to-surface missile testing and military exercises off Taiwanese coastal areas. The United States government condemns the act as provocation, and the Taiwanese government warns of retaliation.

title: Portugal
event: March 9 – Jorge Sampaio is the new Portuguese president.

title: Australia
event: March 17 – Sri Lanka wins the Cricket World Cup by storming to a famous victory against the tournament favourite Australia.

title: Philippines
event: March 18 – The Ozone Disco Club fire in Quezon City, Philippines kills 163.

title: Taiwan
event: March 23 – The Republic of China or Taiwan holds its first direct elections for president; Lee Teng-hui is re-elected.

title: Kashmir
event: March 24 – Islamists clash with security forces in Kashmir, killing 11.

title: Philippines
event: March 24 – The devastating Marcopper mining disaster on the island of Marinduque, Philippines takes place.

title: Jordan Montana
event: March 25 – An 81-day long standoff begins between antigovernment Freemen and federal officers in Jordan, Montana.

title: Dorothy Chandler Pavilion
event: March 25 – The 68th Academy Awards, hosted by Whoopi Goldberg, are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, California with ''Braveheart'' winning Best Picture.

title: United Kingdom
event: March 28 – Three British soldiers are found guilty of the manslaughter of Danish tour guide Louise Jensen in Cyprus. Allan Ford, Justin Fowler and Geoffrey Pernell receive life sentences for their crime, which was committed in September 1994.

title: Nova Scotia
event: April 1 – The Halifax Regional Municipality in Nova Scotia is created.

title: 1996 Croatia USAF CT-43 crash
event: April 3 – A Boeing 737 military jet crashes into a mountain north of Dubrovnik, Croatia. All 35 people on board die, including United States Secretary of Commerce Ron Brown (see 1996 Croatia USAF CT-43 crash).

title: Montana
event: April 3 – Suspected Unabomber Theodore Kaczynski is arrested at his Montana cabin.

title: Liberia
event: April 6 – Fighting breaks out in Monrovia, Liberia between various rebel factions struggling for power in the country's interrupted civil war. Several foreign nationals leave the nation.

title: Spartan Stadium (San Jose)
event: April 6 – Major League Soccer kicks off in front of an overflow crowd of 31,683 packed in Spartan Stadium, to witness the historic first game. San Jose Clash forward Eric Wynalda scores the league's first goal in a 1–0 victory over D.C. United.

title: Israel
event: April 11 – The Israeli government launches Operation Grapes of Wrath, consisting of massive attacks on Lebanon, in retaliation for prior terrorist attacks, and sparking off a violent series of retaliations.

title: Qana
event: April 18 – Qana Massacre: Over 100 Lebanese civilians are killed after Israel shells the UN compound in Qana.

title: Italy
event: April 21 – A general election in Italy proclaims a new government headed by Romano Prodi and his Olive Tree coalition, replacing Silvio Berlusconi.

title: Israel
event: April 24 – At the urging of Yasser Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization drops its clause calling for the removal of Israel. The Israeli government responds by dropping a similar clause concerning the existence of Palestine.

title: Australia
event: April 28 – Port Arthur massacre: Martin Bryant kills 35 people at the Port Arthur, Tasmania tourist site, Australia.

title: Khartoum
event: May 4 – A Sudanese Federal Airlines jet crashes on a domestic flight in a severe dust storm, while making an emergency landing 325 kilometres northeast of Khartoum, killing all 53 passengers and crew.

title: Hawaii
event: May 8 – The Keck II telescope is dedicated in Hawaii.

title: South Africa
event: May 9 – South Africa's National Party pulls out of the 2-year-old coalition government, and the African National Congress assumes full political control.

title: Uganda
event: May 9 – Ugandan president Yoweri Museveni wins a landslide victory in the country's first direct presidential elections, securing 75% of the vote.

title: Port Arthur massacre (Australia)
event: May 10 – The Australian government introduces a nationwide ban on the private possession of both automatic and semi-automatic rifles, in response to the Port Arthur massacre.

title: Hong Kong
event: May 10 – Vietnamese boat people in Hong Kong, facing forced repatriation due to their classification as economic migrants rather than refugees, stage a protest at the Whitehead Detention Centre.

title: Everglades
event: May 11 – After takeoff from Miami, Florida, a fire started by improperly handled oxygen canisters in the cargo hold of Atlanta-bound ValuJet Flight 592, causes the Douglas DC-9 to crash in the Florida Everglades, killing all 110 on board.

title: Bangladesh
event: May 13 – Severe thunderstorms and a tornado in Bangladesh kill 600.

title: India
event: May 17–28 – Atal Bihari Vajpayee, leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party, is elected the new prime minister of India, replacing P. V. Narasimha Rao of the Indian National Congress. However, the party does not receive an overall majority and Vajpayee resigns 13 days later rather than face a no confidence vote, and is replaced by the United Front, led Deve Gowda.

title: Colorado
event: May 20 – Gay rights – ''Romer v. Evans'': The Supreme Court of the United States rules against a law that prevents any city, town or county in the state of Colorado from taking any legislative, executive, or judicial action to protect the rights of homosexuals.

title: Lake Victoria
event: May 21 – The ''MV Bukoba'' sinks in Tanzanian waters in Lake Victoria, killing nearly 1,000 in one of Africa's worst maritime disasters.

title: France
event: May 23 – Members of the Armed Islamic Group in Algeria kill 7 French Trappist monks, after talks with French government concerning the imprisonment of several GIA sympathisers break down.

title: Tirana
event: May 28 – Albania's general election of May 26 is declared unfair by international monitors, and the ruling Democratic Party under President Sali Berisha is charged by the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe with rigging the elections. Several hundred protestors gather in Tirana to demonstrate against the election result.

title: Israel
event: May 30 – The Likud Party, led by Benjamin Netanyahu, wins a narrow victory in the Israeli general election.

title: FIFA
event: May 31 – FIFA decides to give the FIFA World Cup 2002, the first World Cup in Asia, to Japan and South Korea, becoming the first World Cup with co-host countries in the history of the event.

title: Czech Republic
event: June 1–3 – The Czech Republic's first general election ends inconclusively. Prime Minister Václav Klaus and his incumbent Civic Democratic Party emerge as the winners, but are unable to form a majority government. President Václav Havel refuses to invite Klaus to form a coalition.

title: French Guiana
event: June 4 – The space rocket Ariane 5 explodes 40 seconds after takeoff in French Guiana. The project costs European governments 7.5 billion US dollars over 11 years.

title: NATO
event: June 6 – Leighton W. Smith, Jr. resigns as NATO commander in the face of increasing criticism.

title: County Limerick
event: June 7 – An IRA gang murders Detective Garda Jerry McCabe during a botched armed robbery in Adare, County Limerick.

title: French Open
event: June 8 – Steffi Graf defeats Arantxa Sánchez Vicario in the longest ever women's final at the French Open, to win her 19th Grand Slam title.

title: São Paulo
event: June 11 – An explosion in a São Paulo suburban shopping centre kills 44 and injures more than 100.

title: Montana
event: June 13 – An 81-day standoff between the Montana Freemen and FBI agents ends with their surrender in Montana.

title: United Kingdom
event: June 15 – In Manchester, UK, a massive IRA bomb injures over 200 people and devastates a large part of the city centre.

title: Khobar Towers bombing
event: June 25 – The Khobar Towers bombing in Saudi Arabia kills 19 U.S. servicemen.

title: Hyde Park London
event: June 29 – The Prince's Trust concert is held in Hyde Park, London, and is attended by 150,000 people. The Who headlines the event in their first performance since 1989.

title: People's Republic of China
event: June 29 – An explosion in a firecrackers factory in Sichuan Province, China kills at least 36 people and injures another 52.

title: Greece
event: June 30 – Costas Simitis is elected President of the Panhellenic Socialist Movement of Greece.

title: UEFA Euro 1996
event: June 30 – Germany defeats the Czech Republic 2-1 after extra time in the final of the European Championships.

title: Australia
event: July 1 – The Northern Territory in Australia legalises voluntary euthanasia.

title: Midlothian
event: July 5 – Dolly the sheep, the first mammal to be successfully cloned from an adult cell, is born at the Roslin Institute in Midlothian, Scotland.

title: Ratko Mladić
event: July 11 – Arrest warrants are issued for Bosnian Serb war criminals Radovan Karadžić and Ratko Mladić by the Russell Tribunal in The Hague.

title: North Carolina
event: July 12 – Hurricane Bertha: made landfall in North Carolina as a Category 2 storm, causing $270 million in damage to the United States and its possessions and many indirect deaths.

title: TWA Flight 800
event: July 17 – Paris and Rome-bound TWA Flight 800 (Boeing 747) explodes off the coast of Long Island, New York, killing all 230 on board.

title: Westminster Maryland
event: July 19 – An F3 tornado {{convert5.5mikm}} away from the Westminster, Maryland city center injures 3 people and causes $5 million in damages.]<

title: Georgia (U.S. state)
event: July 19 – The 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, Georgia, United States, begin.

title: Quebec
event: July 21 – Storms provoke severe flooding on Saguenay River in Quebec, in one of Canada's most costly natural disasters.

title: Colombo
event: July 24 – The Dehiwala train bombing kills 56 commuters outside Colombo.

title: Centennial Olympic Park bombing
event: July 27 – The Centennial Olympic Park bombing at the 1996 Summer Olympics kills 1 and injures 111.

title: Philippines
event: August 1 – Sarah Balabagan returns to the Philippines.

title: NASA
event: August 6 – NASA announces that the ALH 84001 meteorite, thought to originate from Mars, contains evidence of primitive life-forms.

title: Australia
event: August 6 – The Australian census is conducted.

title: Arequipa
event: August 14 – A rocket ignited during a fireworks display in Arequipa, Peru knocks down a high-tension power cable into a dense crowd, electrocuting 35 people.

title: California
event: August 15 – Bob Dole is nominated for President of the United States, and Jack Kemp for Vice President, at the Republican National Convention in San Diego, California.

title: Brookfield Zoo
event: August 16 Binti Jua, a world famous gorilla after this incident, saves a three year old boy who fell into the {{convert20ftmadj=on}} deep gorilla inclosure. Brookfield Zoo, Chicago Illinois

title: North Korea
event: August 20 – A thousands-large protest in Seoul, calling for reunification with North Korea, is broken up by riot police.

title: South Africa
event: August 21 – Former president of South Africa, F. W. de Klerk, makes an official policy for crimes committed under Apartheid to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in Cape Town.

title: Amman
event: August 26 – Iraqi expatriates seeking refuge hijack a Sudanese airliner en route from Khartoum to Amman.

title: London
event: August 28 – Their Royal Highnesses, the Prince and Princess of Wales, are formally divorced at the High Court of Justice in London.   Her Royal Highness The Princess of Wales is restyled Diana, Princess of Wales.

title: Spitsbergen
event: August 29 – A Russian Tupolev 143 jetliner crashes into a mountain as it approaches the airport at Spitsbergen, Norway, killing all 141 people on board.

title: RMS Titanic
event: August 30 – Attempted raising of a 15 tonne section of the RMS Titanic failed as 1,700 spectators, including survivors of the wreck watched.

title: Manhattan Kansas
event: August 31 – The Big 12 Conference is inaugurated with a football game between Kansas State University and Texas Tech University in Manhattan, Kansas.

title: Iraq
event: September 3 – The U.S. launches Operation Desert Strike against Iraq in reaction to the attack on Arbil.

title: HSBC Arena (Buffalo)
event: September 19 – The scoreboard at Buffalo's $127.5 million dollar HSBC Arena falls to the ice just hours before a National Hockey League game; no one is injured.

title: Ireland
event: September 25 – The last of the Magdalene Asylums is closed in Ireland.

title: Lima
event: October 2 – An Aeroperú Boeing 757 crashes into the Pacific Ocean when the instruments fail just after takeoff from Lima Airport, killing all 70 on board.

title: New Zealand
event: October 6 – The government of New Zealand agrees to pay $130 million dollars worth of compensation for the loss of land suffered by the Māori population between the years of 1844 and 1864.

title: Santa Monica California
event: October 23 – The O. J. Simpson civil trial begins in Santa Monica, California.

title: Uvira
event: October 30 – Fighting erupts when Banyamulenga Tutsis of Laurent Kabila in Zaire seize Uvira and proceed to kill Hutu refugees.

title: São Paulo
event: October 31 – A Brazilian TAM Fokker airliner crashes into a densely populated area of São Paulo, killing 103.

title: India
event: November 7 – A devastating category 4 Cyclone strikes Andhra Pradesh, India. The storm surge sweeps fishing villages out to sea, over 2,000 people die. 95 percent of the crops are completely destroyed.

title: NASA
event: November 7 – NASA launches the Mars Global Surveyor.

title: Lagos
event: November 8 – All 141 people on board a Nigerian-owned Boeing 727 die when the aircraft crashes into the Atlantic Ocean  while approaching Lagos airport.

title: 1996 Charkhi Dadri mid-air collision
event: November 12 – Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 collides in mid-air with Kazakhstan Airlines Il-76, resulting in the loss of 349 lives.

title: State Street (Chicago)
event: November 15 – State Street in Chicago is re-opened to pedestrian traffic.

title: Kaspiysk
event: November 17 – A bomb explosion in Kaspiysk, Russia kills 32 people.

title: Tasmania
event: November 19 – Martin Bryant is sentenced to 35 consecutive sentences of life imprisonment plus 1035 years without parole for murdering 35 people in a shooting spree in Tasmania earlier this year.

title: Humberto Vidal Explosion
event: November 21 – A propane explosion at the Humberto Vidal shoe store and office building in San Juan, Puerto Rico kills 33.

title: Indian Ocean
event: November 23 – Ethiopian Airlines Flight 961 is hijacked, then crashes into the Indian Ocean off the coast of Comoros after running out of fuel, killing 125.

title: Florida
event: November 25 – An ice storm strikes the U.S., killing 26 directly, hundreds more from accidents.   A powerful windstorm blasts Florida; winds gust to 90 mph.

title: Philippines
event: November 25 – The APEC Summit opens in the Philippines.

title: Las Vegas Strip
event: November 26 – The Sands Hotel in Las Vegas is imploded to make way for the Venetian Hotel.

title: Burma
event: December 2 – Widespread student pro-democracy protests are broken up in Burma.

title: Ghana
event: December 9 – Jerry Rawlings is reelected president of Ghana.

title: Hong Kong
event: December 11 – Tung Chee Hwa is appointed to become the new leader of Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese rule in 1997.

title: Lima
event: December 17 – The Túpac Amaru Revolutionary Movement takes 72 hostages in the Japanese Embassy in Lima, Peru.

title: Boulder Colorado
event: December 25 – JonBenét Ramsey, 6, is murdered in the basement of her parents' home in Boulder, Colorado.

title: India
event: December 30 – In the Indian state of Assam, a passenger train is bombed by Bodo separatists, killing 26.

title: Israel
event: December 30 – Proposed budget cuts by Benjamin Netanyahu spark protests from 250,000 workers, who shut down services across Israel.

title: Las Vegas Strip
event: December 31 – The Hacienda in Las Vegas is imploded to make way for the Mandalay Bay.

title: Los Angeles
event: The 1990 film ''Predator 2'' takes place in 1997 Los Angeles.

title: Tokyo
event: The manga and anime ''InuYasha'' takes place in 1997 in Tokyo.

title: Southern Ocean
event: January 9  – Yachtsman Tony Bullimore is found alive, 5 days after his boat capsized in the Southern Ocean.Bill Clinton, the President of the United States, began his second term on January 20

title: Cape Canaveral
event: January 17 – A Delta II rocket carrying a military GPS payload explodes, shortly after liftoff from Cape Canaveral.

title: Rwanda
event: January 18 – In northwest Rwanda, Hutu militia members kill 3 Spanish aid workers, 3 soldiers, and seriously wound another.

title: West Bank
event: January 19 – Yasser Arafat returns to Hebron after more than 30 years, and joins celebrations over the handover of the last Israeli-controlled West Bank city.

title: France
event: January 27 – It is revealed that French museums had nearly 2,000 pieces of art that had been stolen by Nazis.

title: United Kingdom
event: February 4 – British Home Secretary Michael Howard informs Moors Murderer Myra Hindley that she will never be released from prison. Mr. Howard has made the decision in agreement with a recommendation made by his predecessor David Waddington in 1990.

title: Switzerland
event: February 5 – The so-called Big Three banks in Switzerland announced the creation of a $71 million fund to aid Holocaust survivors and their families.

title: Bougainville Island
event: February 10 – Sandline affair: Australian newspapers publish stories that the government of Papua New Guinea has brought mercenaries onto Bougainville Island.

title: Mir
event: February 23 – A small fire occurs on the Russian space station Mir.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: February 27 – Divorce becomes legal in the Republic of Ireland.

title: North Hollywood shootout
event: February 28 – North Hollywood shootout: Two robbers wearing kevlar body armor armed with AKMs containing armor-piercing bullets injure 17 police officers and civilians in a gun battle. The incident sparked debate on the appropriate firepower for United States patrol officers to have available in similar situations in the future.

title: London
event: March 6 – Pablo Picasso's ''Tête de Femme'' is stolen from a London gallery (recovered a week later).

title: India
event: March 13 – India's Missionaries of Charity chooses Sister Nirmala to succeed Mother Teresa as its leader.

title: Sichuan
event: March 13 – The National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China creates a new Chongqing Municipality, out of part of Sichuan.

title: Zaire
event: March 21 – In Zaire, Etienne Tshiksekedi is appointed prime minister; he ejects supporters of Mobutu Sese Seko from his cabinet.

title: Italy
event: April 11 – Fire damages the Turin Cathedral in Italy.

title: Texas
event: April 16 – Houston, Texas socialite Doris Angleton is murdered in her River Oaks home. Roger Angleton later admits to the crime in his suicide note. Despite being found innocent of the crime by a Texas jury, he is later arrested by the United States Department of Justice on similar charges.

title: Red River of the North
event: April 18 – The Red River of the North breaks through dikes and floods Grand Forks, North Dakota and East Grand Forks, Minnesota, causing US$ 2 billion in damage.

title: France
event: April 22 – France supports the new transitional government in Zaire, withdrawing its support of Mobutu Sese Seko.

title: People's Republic of China
event: April 29 – Two trains crash at Hunan, China; 126 are killed.

title: United Kingdom
event: May 3 – Katrina and the Waves win the Eurovision Song Contest 1997 for the UK with ''Love Shine a Light'', the most successful Eurovision entry ever.

title: Iran
event: May 10 – An earthquake near Ardekul, in northeastern Iran, kills at least 2,400.

title: Lufthansa
event: May 14 – The Star Alliance is formed between Air Canada, Lufthansa, Scandinavian Airlines System, Thai Airways International and United Airlines.

title: Kinshasa
event: May 16 – Mobutu Sese Seko leaves Kinshasa, eventually settling in Morocco.

title: Kinshasa
event: May 17 – Troops of Laurent Kabila march into Kinshasa.

title: Iran
event: May 23 – Mohammad Khatami won at 1997 Iranian presidential election and became first Iranian Reformist President.

title: Sierra Leone
event: May 25 – A military coup in Sierra Leone replaces President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah with Major Johnny Paul Koromah.

title: New Brunswick
event: May 31 – The 13-kilometer Confederation Bridge, the world's longest bridge spanning ice covered waters, opens between Prince Edward Island and New Brunswick, Canada.

title: Iraq
event: June 1 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraqi military escorts on board an UNSCOM helicopter try to physically prevent the UNSCOM pilot from flying the helicopter in the direction of its planned destination, threatening the safety of the aircraft and their crews.

title: Bolivia
event: June 1 – Hugo Banzer wins the Presidential elections in Bolivia.

title: Oklahoma City bombing
event: June 2 – In Denver, Colorado, Timothy McVeigh is convicted on 15 counts of murder and conspiracy for his role in the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing.

title: New Jersey
event: June 6 – In Lacey Township, New Jersey, high school senior Melissa Drexler kills her newborn baby in a toilet.

title: Microsoft
event: June 7 – A computer user known as _eci publishes his Microsoft C source code on a Windows 95 and Windows NT exploit, which later becomes WinNuke. The source code gets wide distribution across the internet, and Microsoft is forced to release a security patch.

title: California
event: June 8 – A United States Coast Guard helicopter crashes near Humboldt Bay, California; all 4 crewmembers perish.

title: House of Commons of the United Kingdom
event: June 11 – In the United Kingdom, the House of Commons votes for a total ban on handguns.

title: Plymouth Montserrat
event: June 25 – A massive eruption of the Soufrière Hills volcano on the island of Montserrat leads to evacuation and eventual abandonment of the capital, Plymouth.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: June 26 – Bertie Ahern is appointed as the 10th Taoiseach of the Republic of Ireland and Mary Harney is appointed as the 16th, and first female, Tánaiste, after their parties, Fianna Fáil and the Progressive Democrats respectively, win the 1997 General Election.

title: Hong Kong
event: July 1 – The United Kingdom hands sovereignty of Hong Kong to the People's Republic of China.

title: Mars Pathfinder
event: July 4 – NASA's Pathfinder space probe lands on the surface of Mars.

title: Mayo Clinic
event: July 8 – Mayo Clinic researchers warn that the dieting drug fen-phen can cause severe heart and lung damage.

title: Czech Republic
event: July 8 – NATO invites the Czech Republic, Hungary, and Poland to join the alliance in 1999.

title: London
event: July 10 – In London, scientists report their DNA analysis findings from a Neanderthal skeleton, which support the out of Africa theory of human evolution, placing an African Eve at 100,000 to 200,000 years ago.

title: Ermua
event: July 10 – Miguel Ángel Blanco is kidnapped in Ermua, Spain and murdered by the ETA.

title: USS Constitution
event: July 21 – On her 200th birthday, the fully restored USS Constitution (aka Old Ironsides) sets sail for the first time in 116 years.

title: India
event: July 25 – K.R. Narayanan is sworn in as India's 10th president and the first member of the Dalit caste to hold this office.

title: Australia
event: July 30 – 18 people are killed in the Thredbo landslide in the Snowy Mountains resort in Australia. Stuart Diver is the only survivor.

title: New South Wales
event: August 2 – Australian ski instructor Stuart Diver is rescued as the sole survivor from the Thredbo landslide in New South Wales, in which 18 die.

title: United Parcel Service
event: August 4 – 185,000 Teamsters Union United Parcel Service drivers walk off the job.

title: Microsoft
event: August 6 – Microsoft buys a $150 million share of financially troubled Apple Computer.

title: Antonio B. Won Pat International Airport
event: August 6 – Korean Air Flight 801 crash lands west of Guam International Airport, resulting in the deaths of 228 people.

title: Brazil
event: August 13 – In Belo Horizonte, Brazil, Cruzeiro defeat Sporting Cristal of Peru 1–0, becoming the Copa Libertadores de América champions for the second time.

title: Lorain Ohio
event: September 4 – In Lorain, Ohio, the last Ford Thunderbird for 3 years rolls off the assembly line.

title: International Olympic Committee
event: September 5 – The International Olympic Committee picks Athens, Greece to be the host city for the 2004 Summer Olympics.

title: Westminster Abbey
event: September 6 – The funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales takes place at Westminster Abbey, watched by over 2 billion people worldwide.

title: Garuda Indonesia Flight 152
event: September 26 – An air crash in Indonesia (likely caused by smoke rising from numerous forest fires in the area) kills 235 people (see Garuda Indonesia Flight 152).

title: Basilica of San Francesco d'Assisi
event: September 26 – An earthquake strikes the Italian regions of Umbria and Marche, causing part of the Basilica of St. Francis at Assisi to collapse.

title: Pearl Mississippi
event: October 1 – Luke Woodham walks into Pearl High School in Pearl, Mississippi and opens fire, killing 2 girls, after killing his mother earlier that morning.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 2 – British scientists Moira Bruce and John Collinge, with their colleagues, independently show that the new variant form of the Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is the same disease as Bovine spongiform encephalopathy.

title: NASA
event: October 15 – NASA launches the Cassini-Huygens probe to Saturn.

title: Newton Massachusetts
event: October 30 – In Newton, Massachusetts, British au pair Louise Woodward is found guilty of the baby-shaking death of 8-month-old Matthew Eappen.

title: France
event: November 3 – In France, striking truck drivers blockade ports during a pay dispute.

title: Fairfax Virginia
event: November 10 – A Fairfax, Virginia jury finds Mir Aimal Kasi guilty of murdering 2 CIA employees in 1993.

title: Des Moines Iowa
event: November 19 – In Des Moines, Iowa, Bobbi McCaughey gives birth to septuplets in the second known case where all 7 babies are born alive, and the first in which all survive infancy.

title: NASA
event: November 27 – NASA's Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission is launched, the start of the satellite component of the Clouds and the Earth's Radiant Energy System.

title: Ottawa
event: December 3 – In Ottawa, Canada, representatives from 121 countries sign a treaty prohibiting the manufacture and deployment of anti-personnel land mines. However, the United States, the People's Republic of China, and Russia do not sign the treaty.

title: High Court of Justice
event: December 8 – Myra Hindley, one of the Moors murderers, arrives at the High Court of Justice, to contest a recent Home Secretary's decision that she should remain in prison until she dies.

title: Guyana
event: December 19 – Janet Jagan the former wife of Cheddi Jagan took office in Guyana.

title: Maze (HM Prison)
event: December 27 – Ulster loyalist paramilitary leader Billy Wright is assassinated in Northern Ireland, inside Long Kesh prison.

title: Hong Kong
event: December 29 – Hong Kong begins to kill all the chickens within its territory (1.25 million) to stop the spread of a potentially deadly influenza strain.

title: Relizane
event: December 30 – Wilaya of Relizane massacres of December 30, 1997: In the worst incident in Algeria's insurgency, 400 are killed from four villages in the ''wilaya'' of Relizane.

title: Iraq
event: February – Iraq disarmament crisis: The United States Senate passes Resolution 71, urging U.S. President Bill Clinton to take all necessary and appropriate actions to respond to the threat posed by Iraq's refusal to end its weapons of mass destruction programs.

title: People's Republic of China
event: July – The Yangtze River experiences massive flooding as the government of the People's Republic of China sends in the Army for flood relief efforts.

title: North America
event: The fourth generation of VW's Passat automobile goes on sale in North America.

title: California
event: January 1 – Smoking is banned in all California bars and restaurants.

title: New Brunswick
event: January 4 – January 10 – A massive winter storm, partly caused by El Niño, strikes New England, southern Ontario, Quebec, and New Brunswick, resulting in widespread power failures, severe damage to forests, and numerous deaths.

title: Nepal
event: January 20 – Nepalese police intercept a shipment of 272 human Skulls in Kathmandu.

title: Temple of the Tooth
event: January 25 – The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) suicide attack Sri Lanka's Temple of the Tooth, killing 8 people, injuring 25 others.

title: White House
event: January 26 – Lewinsky scandal: On American television, President Bill Clinton denies he had sexual relations with former White House intern Monica Lewinsky.

title: Philippines
event: January 28 – Gunmen hold at least 400 children and teachers hostage for several hours, at an elementary school in Manila, Philippines.

title: Italy
event: February 3 – Cavalese cable-car disaster: a United States Military pilot causes the deaths of 20 people near Trento, Italy, when his low-flying plane severs the cable of a cable-car.

title: France
event: February 6 – The French prefect Claude Erignac is assassinated in the streets of Ajaccio, Corse.

title: Tbilisi
event: February 9 – Eduard Shevardnadze, the Georgian head of state, survives an assassination attempt in Tbilisi.

title: Maine
event: February 10 – Voters in Maine repeal a gay rights law passed in 1997, becoming the first U.S. state to abandon such a law.

title: China Airlines Flight 676
event: February 16 – China Airlines Flight 676 crashes into a residential area near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing 202 people (all 196 on board and 6 on the ground).

title: New York City
event: February 18 – Two white separatists are arrested in Nevada, accused of plotting biological warfare on New York City subways.

title: New Zealand
event: February 19 – 1998 Auckland power crisis: A 66-day blackout begins in Auckland, New Zealand.

title: Henderson New York
event: February 19 – Larry Wayne Harris of the Aryan Nations and William Leavitt are arrested in Henderson, New York, for possession of military grade anthrax.

title: United Kingdom
event: February 20 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein negotiates a deal with U.N. Secretary General Kofi Annan, allowing weapons inspectors to return to Baghdad, preventing military action by the United States and Britain.

title: Brazil
event: February 22 – One third of the Tower block Palace II collapses in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.]<

title: Florida
event: February 23 – Florida El Niño Outbreak: Tornadoes in central Florida destroy or damage 2,600 structures and kill 42.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: March 4 – Gay rights: ''Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services'': The Supreme Court of the United States rules that federal laws banning on-the-job sexual harassment also apply when both parties are the same sex.

title: NASA
event: March 5 – NASA announces that the Clementine probe orbiting the Moon has found enough water in polar craters to support a human colony and rocket fueling station.

title: Persian Gulf
event: March 10 – United States troops stationed in the Persian Gulf begin to receive the first anthrax vaccine.

title: Iran
event: March 14 – An earthquake measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale hits southeastern Iran.

title: Shikoku
event: April 5 – In Japan, the Akashi-Kaikyo Bridge linking Shikoku with Honshū and costing about US$3.8 billion, opens to traffic, becoming the largest suspension bridge in the world.

title: India
event: April 6 – Pakistan tests medium-range missiles capable of hitting India.

title: Birmingham Alabama
event: April 8 – April 1998 Birmingham tornado: An F5 tornado strikes the western portion of the Birmingham, Alabama area, killing 32 people.

title: Nashville Tennessee
event: April 16 – An F3 tornado passes through downtown Nashville, Tennessee, the first significant tornado in 11 years to directly hit a major city. An F5 tornado travels through rural portions south of Nashville (see 1998 Nashville tornado outbreak).

title: Disney's Animal Kingdom
event: April 22 – The Disney's Animal Kingdom theme park at Walt Disney World opens to the public for the first time.

title: Birmingham
event: May 9 – Dana International, a transsexual singer from Israel, wins the Eurovision Song Contest 1998 in Birmingham, UK.

title: Pokhran
event: May 11 – India conducts 3 underground nuclear tests in Pokhran, including 1 thermonuclear device.

title: Pokhran
event: May 13 – India carries out 2 more nuclear tests at Pokhran.  The United States and Japan impose economic sanctions on India.

title: Bucharest
event: May 15 – Iraq disarmament crisis: UNSCOM learns that an Iraqi delegation has travelled to Bucharest, to meet with scientists who can provide the country with missile guidance systems.

title: Microsoft
event: May 18 – ''United States v. Microsoft'': The United States Department of Justice and 20 U.S. states file an antitrust case against Microsoft.

title: UNESCO
event: May 21 – September 30 – Expo '98 is held in Lisbon, Portugal, with the title Oceans, an Heritage for the Future. UNESCO had previously declared 1998 to be the International Year of the Oceans due to the Expo, which 12 million people attend.

title: Oklahoma City bombing
event: May 27 – Oklahoma City bombing: Michael Fortier is sentenced to 14 years in prison and fined $200,000 for failing to warn authorities about the terrorist plot.

title: Taiwan
event: June 2 – The CIH virus is discovered in Taiwan.

title: California
event: June 2 – California voters approve Proposition 227, abolishing the state's bilingual education program.

title: Eschede train disaster
event: June 3 – Eschede train disaster: An InterCityExpress high speed train derails between Hannover and Hamburg, Germany, causing 101 deaths.

title: Oklahoma City bombing
event: June 4 – Terry Nichols is sentenced to life in prison for his role in the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: National Rifle Association
event: June 8 – Actor Charlton Heston becomes president of the National Rifle Association

title: Philippines
event: June 30 – Philippine Vice President Joseph Estrada was sworn in as the 13th President of The Philippines.

title: Chek Lap Kok
event: July 6 – The new Hong Kong International Airport at Chek Lap Kok opens, while the historic Hong Kong Kai Tak Airport closes.

title: Tomb of the Unknowns
event: July 10 – The DNA-identified remains of United States Air Force 1st Lt. Michael Joseph Blassie arrive home to his family in St. Louis, Missouri, after being in the Tomb of the Unknowns since 1984.

title: 1998 FIFA World Cup
event: July 12 – France beats Brazil 3-0 in the World Cup final, with the first two goals scored by Zinedine Zidane.

title: International Criminal Court
event: July 17 – At a conference in Rome, 120 countries vote to create a permanent International Criminal Court to prosecute individuals for genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, and the crime of aggression.

title: United States Capitol
event: July 24 – Russell Eugene Weston Jr. bursts into the United States Capitol and opens fire, killing 2 police officers.   He is later ruled incompetent to stand trial.

title: Wakayama Prefecture
event: July 25 – Wakayama Arsenic poison case: 63 are sickened and 4 killed by arsenic in a festival in the town in Wakayama Prefecture in Japan; Masumi Hayashi is arrested for murder.

title: White House
event: July 28 – Monica Lewinsky scandal: Ex-White House intern Monica Lewinsky receives transactional immunity, in exchange for her grand jury testimony concerning her relationship with U.S. President Bill Clinton.

title: Yangtze River
event: August 7 – Yangtze River Floods: In China the Yangtze River breaks through the main bank; before this, from August 1–5, periphery levees collapsed consecutively in Jiayu County Baizhou Bay. The death toll exceeds 12,000, with many thousands more injured.

title: Kenya
event: August 7 – 1998 U.S. embassy bombings: The bombings of the United States embassies in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, and Nairobi, Kenya kill 224 people and injure over 4,500; they are linked to terrorist Osama Bin Laden, an exile of Saudi Arabia.

title: Omagh bombing
event: August 15 – Omagh bombing: The Real IRA detonates a car bomb in Omagh, County Tyrone, Northern Ireland, killing 29 and injuring over 200 (the greatest loss of life in a single incident of The Troubles).

title: Australia
event: August 16 – Silk-Miller police murders: Australian police officers are murdered in Moorabbin, Victoria.

title: White House
event: August 19 – Monica Lewinsky scandal: On the day of his 52nd birthday, U.S. President Bill Clinton admits in taped testimony that he had an improper physical relationship with White House intern Monica Lewinsky. He also admits before the nation that night in a nationally televised address that he misled people about his sexual affair with Lewinsky.

title: Quebec
event: August 20 – The Supreme Court of Canada rules Quebec cannot legally secede from Canada without the federal government's approval.

title: Khartoum
event: August 20 – 1998 U.S. embassy bombings: The United States military launches cruise missile attacks against alleged Al-Qaeda camps in Afghanistan and a suspected chemical plant in Sudan in retaliation for the August 7 bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. The al-Shifa pharmaceutical factory in Khartoum is destroyed in the attack.

title: North American Aerospace Defense Command
event: August 31 – North Korea reportedly launches Kwangmyongsong, their first satellite. Although North Korea reports that it reached stable orbit, NORAD has never been able to confirm this assertion.

title: New York City
event: September 2 – A McDonnell Douglas MD-11 airliner (Swissair Flight 111) crashes near Peggys Cove, Nova Scotia, after taking off from New York City en-route to Geneva; all 229 people on board are killed.

title: Rwanda
event: September 2 – A United Nations court finds Jean-Paul Akayesu, the former mayor of a small town in Rwanda, guilty of 9 counts of genocide, marking the first time that the 1948 law banning genocide is enforced.

title: Jubaland
event: September 3 – In Somalia, the southern port of Kismayo is declared the capital of independent Jubaland under Muhamed Said Hersi.

title: Stanford University
event: September 4 – Google, Inc. is founded in Menlo Park, California, by Stanford University Ph.D. candidates Larry Page and Sergey Brin.

title: Fornebu
event: October 7 – Oslo's Fornebu Airport closes.

title: Oslo Airport Gardermoen
event: October 8 – Oslo Airport (Gardermoen) opens.

title: Nigeria
event: October 17 – A pipeline explosion in Jesse, Nigeria results in 1,082 deaths.

title: Taiwan
event: October 28 – An Air China jetliner is hijacked by disgruntled pilot Yuan Bin and flown to Taiwan. After landing the plane safely, Yuan Bin is arrested.

title: South Africa
event: October 29 – Apartheid: In South Africa, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission presents its report, which condemns both sides for committing atrocities.

title: Switzerland
event: October 29 – While en route from Adana to Ankara, a Turkish Airlines flight with a crew of 6 and 33 passengers is hijacked by a Kurdish militant, who orders the pilot to fly to Switzerland. The plane instead lands in Ankara after the pilot tricks the hijacker into thinking that he was landing in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia to refuel.

title: Iraq
event: October 31 – Iraq disarmament crisis begins: Iraq announces it will no longer cooperate with United Nations weapons inspectors.

title: European Court of Human Rights
event: November 1 – The European Court of Human Rights is instituted.

title: Wonju
event: November 3 – Edmonton, Canada and Wonju, South Korea are declared as sister cities.

title: Iraq
event: November 13–14 – Iraq disarmament crisis: U.S. President Bill Clinton orders airstrikes on Iraq, then calls them off at the last minute when Iraq promises once again to unconditionally cooperate with UNSCOM.

title: Tanzania
event: November 20 – A court in Taliban-controlled Afghanistan declares accused terrorist Osama bin Laden a man without a sin in regard to the 1998 U.S. embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania.

title: Kazakhstan
event: November 20 – At the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, the first component for the International Space Station (''Zarya'', or sunrise,) is launched.

title: Iraq
event: November 23–26 – Iraq disarmament crisis: According to UNSCOM, Iraq once again ends cooperation with the United Nations inspectors, alternately intimidating and withholding information from them.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: November 26 – Tony Blair becomes the first Prime Minister of the United Kingdom to address the Dáil Éireann, the Republic of Ireland's parliament.

title: Vasco da Gama
event: December 5 – D.C. United defeats Vasco da Gama 2–1 on aggregate to win the Interamerican Cup (one of the greatest triumphs in the history of U.S. club soccer).

title: Iraq
event: December 11 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq announces that United Nations weapons inspections will no longer take place on Friday, the Muslim day of rest. Iraq also refuses to provide test data from the production of missiles and engines.

title: Iraq
event: December 16–19 – Iraq disarmament crisis: U.S. President Bill Clinton orders  and  airstrikes on Iraq. UNSCOM withdraws all weapons inspectors from Iraq.

title: Texas
event: December 17 – Claudia Benton, of West University Place, Texas, is murdered in her house by Angel Maturino Resendiz (his third victim in his third incident).

title: Iraq
event: December 19 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraqi Vice-President Taha Yassin Ramadan announces that Iraq will no longer cooperate and declares that UNSCOM's mission is over.

title: Iraq
event: December 21 – Iraq disarmament crisis: UN Security Council members France, Germany and Russia call for sanctions to end against Iraq. The 3 Security Council members also call for UNSCOM to either be disbanded or for its role to be recast. The U.S. says it will veto any such proposal.

title: Iraq
event: December 26 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq announces its intention to fire upon U.S. and British warplanes that patrol the northern and southern no-fly zones.

title: 1998 Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race
event: December 26 – Six sailors die and 5 yachts are lost in the Sydney to Hobart yacht race, the biggest disaster in the race's history

title: London
event: 1 July – The Scottish Parliament is officially opened by Queen Elizabeth on the day that legislative powers are officially transferred from the old Scottish Office in London to the new devolved Scottish Executive in Edinburgh.

title: Islamabad
event: January 4 – Gunmen open fire on Shia Muslims worshiping in a mosque in Islamabad, Pakistan, killing 16 and injuring 25.

title: Finland
event: February 21 – The Albertinkatu shootings in Helsinki, Finland: Three men are killed and 1 wounded at a shooting range.

title: Iraq
event: February 22 – Moderate Iraqi Shiite cleric Mohammad Mohammad Sadeq al-Sadr is assassinated.

title: Ankara
event: February 23 – Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Öcalan is charged with treason in Ankara, Turkey.

title: International Court of Justice
event: February 24 – LaGrand Case: The State of Arizona executes Karl LaGrand, a German national involved in an armed robbery that led to a death. Karl's brother Walter is executed a week later, in spite of Germany's legal action in the International Court of Justice to attempt to save him.

title: Uganda
event: March 1 – Rwandan Hutu rebels kill and dismember 8 foreign tourists at the Buhoma homestead, Uganda.

title: Las Vegas Strip
event: March 2 – The brand new Mandalay Bay hotel and casino opens in Las Vegas.

title: Arizona
event: March 3 – Walter LaGrand is executed in the gas chamber in Arizona.

title: NATO
event: March 12 – Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic join NATO.

title: Dorothy Chandler Pavilion
event: March 21 – The 71st Academy Awards are held at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, California with ''Shakespeare in Love'' winning Best Picture.

title: NATO
event: March 24 – NATO launches air strikes against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, which refused to sign a peace treaty. This marks the first time NATO has attacked a sovereign country.

title: Mont Blanc Tunnel
event: March 24 – Fire in the Mont Blanc Tunnel kills 39 people, closing the tunnel for nearly 3 years.

title: California
event: March 25 – Enron energy traders allegedly route 2,900 megawatts of electricity destined for California to the town of Silver Peak, Nevada, population 200.

title: Michigan
event: March 26 – A Michigan jury finds Dr. Jack Kevorkian guilty of second-degree murder for administering a lethal injection to a terminally ill man.

title: Northwest Territories
event: April 1 – Nunavut, an Inuit homeland, is created from the eastern portion of the Northwest Territories to become Canada's third territory.

title: Libya
event: April 5 – Two Libyans suspected of bringing down Pan Am flight 103 in 1988 are handed over to Scottish authorities for eventual trial in the Netherlands. The United Nations suspends sanctions against Libya.

title: Laramie Wyoming
event: April 5 – In Laramie, Wyoming, Russell Henderson pleads guilty to kidnapping and felony murder, in order to avoid a possible death penalty conviction for the apparent hate crime killing of Matthew Shepard.

title: Albania
event: April 7 – Kosovo War: Kosovo's main border crossings are closed by Serbian forces to prevent ethnic Albanians from leaving.

title: London
event: April 17 – A nail bomb explodes in the middle of a busy market in Brixton, South London.

title: Littleton Colorado
event: April 20 – Columbine High School massacre: Two Littleton, Colorado teenagers, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, open fire on their teachers and classmates, killing 12 students and 1 teacher, and then themselves.

title: London
event: April 26 – British T.V presenter Jill Dando, 37, is shot dead on the doorstep of her home in Fulham, London.

title: Admiral Duncan pub
event: April 30 – A third nail bomb (see April 17) explodes in the Admiral Duncan pub in Old Compton Street, Soho, London, killing a pregnant woman and two friends and injuring 70 others, including her husband. This is part of a hate campaign against ethnic minorities and gay people by David Copeland.{{Citation neededdate=April 2008}}

title: Weimar Texas
event: May 2 – Norman J. Sirnic and Karen Sirnic are murdered by serial killer Angel Maturino Resendiz in Weimar, Texas.

title: Moore Oklahoma
event: May 3 – 1999 Oklahoma tornado outbreak: An F5 tornado slams into Moore, Oklahoma, killing 38 people (the strongest tornado ever recorded in world history).

title: Scottish Parliament
event: May 6 – Elections are held in Scotland and Wales for the new Scottish Parliament and National Assembly for Wales.

title: NATO
event: May 7 – Kosovo War: In the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, 3 Chinese embassy workers are killed and 20 wounded, when a NATO aircraft mistakenly bombs the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.

title: Scottish Parliament
event: May 12 – David Steel becomes the first Presiding Officer (Speaker) of the modern Scottish Parliament.

title: Italy
event: May 13 – Carlo Azeglio Ciampi is elected President of Italy.

title: Israel
event: May 17 – Ehud Barak is elected prime minister of Israel.

title: Kashmir
event: May 26 – The Indian Air Force launches an attack on intruding Pakistan Army troops and mujahadeen militants in Kashmir.

title: Italy
event: May 28 – After 22 years of restoration work, Leonardo de Vinci’s ''The Last Supper'' is placed back on display in Milan, Italy.

title: Nigeria
event: May 29 – Nigeria terminates military rule, and the Nigerian Fourth Republic is established with Olusegun Obasanjo as president.

title: Little Rock Arkansas
event: June 1 American Airlines Flight 1420 overruns the runway in Little Rock, Arkansas killing 11 people.

title: Bhutan
event: June 2 – After decades of fighting off outside technological influences like television, the King of Bhutan allows television transmissions to commence in the Kingdom for the first time, coinciding with the King's Silver Jubilee (see Bhutan Broadcasting Service).

title: Brazil
event: June 6 – In Brazil, 345 prisoners escape from Putim prison through the front gate.

title: NATO
event: June 9 – Kosovo War: The Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and NATO sign a peace treaty.

title: NATO
event: June 10 – Kosovo War: NATO suspends its air strikes after Slobodan Milošević agrees to withdraw Serbian forces from Kosovo.

title: NATO
event: June 12 – Kosovo War – Operation Joint Guardian/''Operation Agricola'' begins: NATO-led United Nations peacekeeping forces KFOR enter the province of Kosovo in the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.

title: Texas
event: June 12 – Texas Governor George W. Bush announces he will seek the Republican Party nomination for President of the United States.

title: Italy
event: June 19 – Turin, Italy is awarded the 2006 Winter Olympics.

title: Kentucky
event: July 5 – U.S. Army Pfc. Barry Winchell is bludgeoned in his sleep at Fort Campbell, Kentucky by fellow soldiers; he dies the next day from his injuries.

title: India
event: July 11 – India recaptures Kargil, forcing the Pakistan Army to retreat. India announces victory, ending the 2-month conflict.

title: Martha's Vineyard
event: July 16 – Off the coast of Martha's Vineyard, a plane piloted by John F. Kennedy Jr. crashes, killing him and his wife Carolyn Bessette Kennedy and her sister Lauren Bessette.

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: July 20 – Mercury program: Liberty Bell 7 is raised from the Atlantic Ocean.

title: People's Republic of China
event: July 20 – Falun Gong is banned in the People's Republic of China under Jiang Zemin.

title: Microsoft
event: July 22 – The first version of MSN Messenger is released by Microsoft.

title: Tokyo
event: July 23 – ANA Flight 61 is hijacked in Tokyo.

title: New York
event: July 23–25 – The Woodstock 99 festival is held in New York.

title: New York City
event: July 26 – The last Checker taxi cab is retired in New York City and auctioned off for approximately $135,000.

title: Switzerland
event: July 27 – Twenty-one people die in a canyoning disaster near Interlaken, Switzerland.

title: NASA
event: July 31 – NASA intentionally crashes the Lunar Prospector spacecraft into the Moon, thus ending its mission to detect frozen water on the lunar surface.

title: India
event: August 10 – The Atlantique Incident occurs as an intruding Pakistan Navy plane is shot down in India. The incident sparks tensions between the 2 nations, coming just a month after the end of the Kargil War.

title: Solar eclipse of August 11 1999
event: August 11 – A total solar eclipse is seen in Europe and Asia.

title: İzmit
event: August 17 – 1999 İzmit earthquake: A 7.6-magnitude earthquake strikes İzmit and levels much of northwestern Turkey, killing more than 17,000 and injuring 44,000. This is the first of a long series of unrelated but frequent earthquakes throughout the world during the years 1999 and 2000.

title: Hong Kong
event: August 22 – Mandarin Airlines Flight 642 crashes in Hong Kong.

title: 1999 Athens earthquake
event: September 7 – A magnitude 5.9 earthquake hits Athens, killing 143 and injuring more than 2,000.

title: Nauru
event: September 14 – Kiribati, Nauru and Tonga join the United Nations.

title: Taiwan
event: September 21 – The 921 earthquake, also known as the Jiji earthquake,(magnitude 7.6 on the Richter scale) kills about 2,400 people in Taiwan.

title: NASA
event: October – NASA loses one of its probes, the Mars Climate Orbiter.

title: Shanghai
event: October 1 – Pudong International Airport opens in Shanghai, China, taking over all international flights to Hongqiao.

title: London
event: October 5 – Thirty-one people die in the Ladbroke Grove rail crash, west of London, England.

title: Portugal
event: October 10 – Elections are held in Portugal.

title: Sarajevo
event: October 12 – World population reaches 6 billion people, as the 6 billionth person (according to the UN) is born in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: National Geographic Society
event: October 15 – A National Geographic Society press conference reveals the fossil of ''Archaeoraptor'' (which is later found to be a forgery).

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: October 31 – EgyptAir Flight 990, travelling from New York City to Cairo, crashes off the coast of Nantucket, Massachusetts, killing all 217 on board. When the pilot leaves the cockpit, the co-pilot causes the Boeing 767 to enter a steep dive, resulting in impact with the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Uruapan International Airport
event: November 9 – TAESA Flight 725, covering the route Tijuana–Guadalajara–Uruapan–Mexico City, crashes a few minutes after takeoff from Uruapan International Airport, killing 18 people on board. This event causes the bankruptcy of the Mexican airline a few months later.

title: People's Republic of China
event: November 20 – The People's Republic of China launches the first Shenzhou spacecraft.

title: New Zealand
event: November 27 – The left-wing Labour Party takes control of the New Zealand government, with leader Helen Clark becoming the second female Prime Minister in New Zealand's history.

title: Canary Islands
event: December 3 – After rowing for 81 days and 2,962 nautical miles (5486 km), Tori Murden becomes the first woman to cross the Atlantic Ocean by rowboat alone, when she reaches Guadeloupe from the Canary Islands.

title: People's Republic of China
event: December 20 – The sovereignty of Macau is transferred from the Portuguese Republic to the People's Republic of China after 422 years of Portuguese rule.

title: London Stansted Airport
event: December 22 – Korean Air Cargo Flight 8509, a Boeing 747-200F crashes shortly after take-off from London Stansted Airport due to pilot error. All 4 crew members were killed.

title: Panama Canal
event: December 31 – The U.S. turns over complete administration of the Panama Canal to the Panamanian Government, as stipulated in the Torrijos-Carter Treaty of 1977.

title: Israel
event: January 3–10 – Israel and Syria hold inconclusive peace talks.

title: Kuala Lumpur
event: January 5–8 – The 2000 al-Qaeda Summit of several high-level al-Qaeda members (including 2 9/11 American Airlines hijackers) is held in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

title: Isle of Man
event: January 11 – The trawler ''Solway Harvester'' sinks off the Isle of Man.

title: Tagish Lake (meteorite)
event: January 18 – The Tagish Lake meteorite impacts the Earth.

title: Alaska Airlines Flight 261
event: January 31 – Alaska Airlines Flight 261 crashes off the California coast into the Pacific Ocean, killing 88.

title: Finland
event: February 6 – Tarja Halonen is elected the first female president of Finland.

title: UNESCO
event: February 21 – UNESCO holds the inaugural celebration of International Mother Language Day.

title: Tokyo
event: March 4 – Sony launches a PlayStation 2 in Tokyo.

title: Israel
event: March 21 – Pope John Paul II begins the first official visit by a Roman Catholic pontiff to Israel.

title: High Court of Justice
event: March 31 – Myra Hindley loses a British High Court appeal against her life imprisonment sentence.

title: Microsoft
event: April 3 – ''United States v. Microsoft'': Microsoft is ruled to have violated United States antitrust laws by keeping an oppressive thumb on its competitors.

title: Brazil
event: April 22 – Brazil officially celebrates its 500th anniversary, with protests, especially from native and black populations.

title: Texas
event: May 3 – In San Antonio, Texas, computer pioneer Datapoint files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

title: Philippines
event: May 4 – After originating in The Philippines, the ILOVEYOU computer virus spreads quickly throughout the world.

title: Banggai
event: May 4 – An earthquake hits Banggai, Indonesia, leaving 54 dead.

title: India
event: May 11 – The billionth living person in India is born.

title: London
event: May 12 – The Tate Modern Gallery opens in London.

title: Enschede
event: May 13 – A fireworks factory disaster in Enschede Netherlands, kills 23.

title: Grand National Assembly of Turkey
event: May 16 – The Grand National Assembly of Turkey elects Ahmet Necdet Sezer  as the tenth President of Turkey.

title: Glorietta
event: May 17 – A bomb in Glorietta Mall in Makati City, Philippines injures 13.

title: Taiwan
event: May 20 – Chinese (ROC) president Chen Shui-bian makes the Four Noes and One Without pledge to Taiwan.

title: Israel
event: May 25 – Israel withdraws IDF forces from southern Lebanon after 22 years.

title: Scottish Parliament
event: June 21 – Section 28, a law preventing the promotion of homosexuality, is repealed by the Scottish Parliament.

title: Denmark
event: June 30 – At the Roskilde Festival near Copenhagen, Denmark, 9 die and 26 are injured on a set while the rock group Pearl Jam performs.

title: Nigeria
event: July 10 – In southern Nigeria, a leaking petroleum pipeline explodes, killing about 250 villagers who were scavenging gasoline.

title: Air France Flight 4590
event: July 25 – Air France Flight 4590, a Concorde aircraft, crashes into a hotel in Gonesse just after takeoff from Paris, killing all 109 aboard and 4 in the hotel.

title: Portsmouth
event: August 3 – Rioting erupts on the Paulsgrove estate in Portsmouth, Hampshire, England, after more than 100 people besiege the home of a block of flats allegedly housing a convicted paedophile. This is the latest vigilante violence against suspected sex offenders since the beginning of the naming and shaming anti-paedophile campaign by the tabloid newspaper ''News of the World''.

title: Barents Sea
event: August 12 – The ''Russian submarine K-141 Kursk'' sinks in the Barents Sea, resulting in the deaths of all 118 men on board.

title: Los Angeles
event: August 14–17 – The Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles nominates U.S. Vice President Al Gore for President and Senator Joe Lieberman for Vice President.

title: Ostankino Tower
event: August 27 – The Ostankino Tower fire in Moscow kills 3.

title: Albania
event: September 8 – Albania officially joins the World Trade Organization.

title: New York
event: September 8 – United Nations Millennium Declaration is made in New York

title: Australia
event: September 15 – October 1 – The 2000 Summer Olympics are held in Sydney, Australia.

title: Paros
event: September 26 – The Greek ferry ''Express Samina'' sinks off the coast of the island of Paros; 80 out of a total of over 500 passengers perish in one of Greece's worst sea disasters.

title: Maze (HM Prison)
event: September 29 – The Long Kesh prison in Northern Ireland is closed.

title: Australia
event: October 1 – The 2000 Summer Olympics close in Sydney, Australia.

title: Exxon Valdez oil spill
event: October 11 – 250 million gallons of coal sludge spill in Martin County, Kentucky  (considered a greater environmental disaster than the Exxon Valdez oil spill).

title: Yemen
event: October 12 – In Aden, Yemen, the ''USS Cole'' is badly damaged by two Al-Qaeda suicide bombers, who place a small boat laden with explosives alongside the United States Navy destroyer, killing 17 crew members and wounding at least 39.

title: Israel
event: October 21 – Fifteen Arab leaders convene in Cairo, Egypt, for their first summit in 4 years; the Libyan delegation walks out, angry over signs the summit will stop short of calling for breaking ties with Israel.

title: Iran
event: October 26 – Pakistani authorities announce that their police have found an apparently ancient mummy of a Persian princess in the province of Balochistan. Iran, Pakistan and the Taliban all claim the mummy until Pakistan announces it is a forgery on April 17, 2001.

title: Singapore Airlines Flight 006
event: October 31 – Singapore Airlines Flight 006 collides with construction equipment in the Chiang Kai Shek International Airport, resulting in 83 deaths.

title: Iraq
event: November – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq rejects new U.N. Security Council weapons inspections proposals.

title: Florida
event: November 7 – United States presidential election, 2000: Republican candidate Texas Governor George W. Bush defeats Democratic Vice President Al Gore in one of the closest elections in history, but the final outcome is not known for over a month because of disputed votes in Florida.

title: London
event: November 7 – In London, a criminal gang raids the Millennium Dome to steal The Millennium Star diamond, but police surveillance catches them in the act.

title: Kaprun disaster
event: November 11 – Kaprun disaster, Austria: A funicular fire in an Alpine tunnel kills 155 skiers and snowboarders.

title: India
event: November 15 – A new Indian state called Jharkhand is formed, carving out the South Chhota Nagpur area from Bihar in India.

title: Florida
event: December 13 – ''Bush v. Gore'': The U.S. Supreme Court stops the Florida presidential recount, effectively giving the state, and the Presidency, to George W. Bush.

title: People's Republic of China
event: December 25 – A shopping center fire at Luoyang, Henan, China kills 309.

title: Philippines
event: December 30 – Rizal Day bombings: A series of bombs explode in various places in Metro Manila, Philippines, within a span of a few hours, killing 22 and injuring about 100.

title: Millennium Dome
event: December 31 – The Millennium Dome closes its doors one year to the day of its opening.

title: Magnuson Park (Seattle)
event: January 1 – A black monolith measuring approximately {{convert9ftm}} tall appears in Seattle, Washington's Magnuson Park, placed by an anonymous artist in reference to the movie ''2001: A Space Odyssey''.

title: 2001 El Salvador earthquakes
event: January 13 – A 7.6 magnitude earthquake hits all of El Salvador, killing at least 800 people and leaving thousands homeless.

title: India
event: January 26 – An earthquake hits Gujarat, India, killing more than 12,000.

title: Hawaii
event: February 9 – The submarine USS ''Greeneville'' accidentally strikes and sinks the Japanese fishing vessel ''Ehime-Maru'' near Hawaii.

title: 2001 El Salvador earthquakes
event: February 13 – A 6.6 magnitude earthquake hits El Salvador, killing at least 400.

title: Iraq
event: February 16 – Iraq disarmament crisis: British and U.S. forces carry out bombing raids, attempting to disable Iraq's air defense network.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: March 23 – The Russian space station Mir re-enters the atmosphere near Nadi, Fiji, and falls into the Pacific Ocean.

title: People's Republic of China
event: April 1 – Hainan Island incident: A Chinese fighter jet bumps into a U.S. EP-3E surveillance aircraft, which is forced to make an emergency landing in Hainan, China. The U.S. crew is detained for 10 days and the F-8 Chinese pilot, Wang Wei, goes missing and is presumed dead.

title: Soyuz TM-32
event: April 28 – ''Soyuz TM-32'' lifts off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome, carrying the first space tourist, American Dennis Tito

title: Soyuz TM-32
event: May 6 – Space tourist Dennis Tito returns to Earth aboard ''Soyuz TM-31''. (''Soyuz TM-32'' is left docked at the International Space Station as a new lifeboat.)

title: Banja Luka
event: May 7 – In Banja Luka, Bosnia and Herzegovina, an attempt is made to reconstruct the Ferhadija mosque. However, the ceremony results in mass riots by Serb nationalists, who beat and stone 300 elderly Bosnian Muslims.

title: Italy
event: May 13 – Silvio Berlusconi and the Italian House of the Liberties coalition win the general elections.

title: Bahá'í World Centre
event: May 22–23 – The Bahá'í Terraces officially open on Mount Carmel in Haifa, Israel (site of the Shrine of the Báb and the Bahá'í World Centre).

title: Israel
event: May 24 – The Versailles wedding hall disaster kills 23 in Jerusalem, Israel.

title: Vermont
event: May 24 – Jim Jeffords, the United States Senator for Vermont, leaves the Republican Party and becomes an Independent. He joins the Democratic caucus, giving them a 51-49 majority for the remainder of 107th United States Congress.

title: Israel
event: June 1 – A Hamas suicide bomber kills 21, mostly teenagers, in the Dolphinarium disco in Tel Aviv, Israel.

title: Texas Medical Center
event: June 5–9 – Tropical Storm Allison produces 36 inches (900 mm) of rain in Houston, Texas, killing 22, damaging the Texas Medical Center, and causing more than 5 billion American dollars of damage overall.

title: Oklahoma City bombing
event: June 11 – In Terre Haute, Indiana, Timothy McVeigh is executed for the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Iraq
event: June 19 – An American missile hits a soccer field in northern Iraq (Tel Afr County), killing 23 and wounding 11. According to U.S. officials, it was actually an Iraqi missile that malfunctioned.

title: Beijing
event: July 13 – Beijing wins the bid to host the 2008 Summer Olympics.

title: People's Republic of China
event: July 16 – The People's Republic of China and the Russian Federation sign the Treaty of Good-Neighborliness and Friendly Cooperation.

title: United Kingdom
event: July 19 – UK politician and novelist Jeffrey Archer is sentenced to 4 years in prison for perjury and perverting the course of justice.

title: Italy
event: July 20–22 – The 27th G8 summit takes place in Genoa, Italy. Massive demonstrations are held against the meeting by anti-globalisation groups. One demonstrator, Carlo Giuliani, is shot dead by a carabiniere.  Several others are badly injured during a police attack on a school used by the protesters as their headquarters.

title: Anjouan
event: August 9 – In the Comoros, the Military Committee of Major Mohamad Bacar seizes power in the island of Anjouan, which had declared independence. They plan to rejoin the Comoros.

title: Microsoft
event: September 6 – ''United States v. Microsoft'': The United States Justice Department announces that it no longer seeks to break up software maker Microsoft, and will instead seek a lesser antitrust penalty.
