title: United Airlines Flight 93
event: September 11 – Almost 3,000 are killed in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center in New York City; the Pentagon in Arlington, Virginia; and in rural Shanksville, Pennsylvania after American Airlines Flight 11 and United Airlines Flight 175 crash into the World Trade Center's Twin Towers, American Airlines Flight 77 crashes into the Pentagon, and United Airlines Flight 93 crashes into grassland in Shanksville.

title: Princeton New Jersey
event: September 18 – The 2001 anthrax attacks commence as letters containing anthrax spores are mailed from Princeton, New Jersey to ABC News, CBS News, NBC News, the ''New York Post'', and the ''National Enquirer''. 22 in total are exposed; 5 of them die.

title: France
event: September 21 – In Toulouse, France, the AZote Fertilisant chemical factory explodes, killing 29 and seriously wounding over 2,500.

title: Israel
event: October 4 – Siberia Airlines Flight 1812 crashes over the Black Sea en route from Tel Aviv, Israel to Novosibirsk, Russia; 78 are killed.

title: Linate Airport disaster
event: October 8 – Flight SK686 of SAS collides first with a private plane and then a building in Milano Airport; 100 are killed.

title: NASA
event: October 15 – NASA's Galileo spacecraft passes within {{convert112mikm}} of Jupiter's moon Io.

title: Christmas Island
event: October 19 – ''SIEV-X'' sinks en route to Christmas Island.

title: People's Republic of China
event: November 10 – The People's Republic of China is admitted to the World Trade Organization after 15 years of negotiations.

title: Australia
event: November 10 – Australian Prime Minister John Howard is elected to a third term.

title: American Airlines Flight 587
event: November 12 – In New York City, American Airlines Flight 587, headed to the Dominican Republic, crashes in Queens minutes after takeoff from John F. Kennedy International Airport, killing all 260 on board.

title: Massachusetts
event: December 22 – A Paris–Miami, Florida flight is diverted to Boston, Massachusetts after passenger Richard Reid attempts to set his shoe, filled with explosives, on fire.

title: People's Republic of China
event: December 27 – The People's Republic of China is granted permanent normal trade status with the United States.

title: Nicaragua
event: January 10 – Enrique Bolaños begins his 5-year term as President of the Republic of Nicaragua.

title: New York
event: January 14 – The asylum case of Adelaide Abankwah is heard in New York.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: January 17 – The eruption of Mount Nyiragongo in the Democratic Republic of the Congo displaces an estimated 400,000 people.

title: Nigeria
event: January 27 – Several explosions at a military dump in Lagos, Nigeria kill more than 1,000.{{noMention}}

title: Larsen Ice Shelf
event: January 31 – A large section of the Antarctic Larsen Ice Shelf begins disintegrating, consuming about 3,250 km (1,254 miles) over 35 days.

title: New York City
event: February 13 – Queen Elizabeth gives former New York City mayor Rudolph Giuliani an honorary knighthood.

title: NASA
event: February 19 – NASA's Mars Odyssey space probe begins to map the surface of Mars using its thermal emission imaging system.

title: India
event: February 27 – A series of riots leaves hundreds dead, after 59 Hindu pilgrims die aboard a train burned by a Muslim mob in Godhra, India.

title: Ahmedabad
event: February 28 – Gujarat communal riots begin, wherein the Gulbarg Society massacre takes place in Ahmedabad, in which 69 people were burnt alive or killed.

title: Operation Anaconda
event: March 1 – U.S. invasion of Afghanistan: In eastern Afghanistan, Operation Anaconda begins.

title: India
event: March 1 – Continuing violence in Ahmedabad, India kills 28; police shoot and kill 5 rioters.

title: Australia
event: March 4 – Ansett Australia, one of the oldest airlines in the world and the second largest in Australia, ceases operation after collapsing financially. This event also marks the largest job loss in Australian history.

title: South Africa
event: March 6 – France agrees to return the remains of Saartjie Baartman to South Africa.

title: Texas
event: March 12 – In Houston, Texas, Andrea Yates is found guilty of drowning her 5 children on June 20, 2001. She is later sentenced to life in prison.

title: Ringgold Georgia
event: March 14 – 125 vehicles are involved in a massive pile up on Interstate 75 in Ringgold, Georgia.

title: Portugal
event: March 17 – Portugal holds parliamentary elections.

title: Islamabad
event: March 17 – In Islamabad, Pakistan, the International Protestant Church attack occurs.

title: Operation Anaconda
event: March 19 – US war in Afghanistan: Operation Anaconda ends (started on March 1) after killing 500 Taliban and al Qaeda fighters, with 11 allied troop fatalities.

title: Kodak Theatre
event: March 24 – The  74th Academy Awards, hosted by Whoopi Goldberg, are held at the Kodak Theatre in Hollywood, California with the film ''A Beautiful Mind'' winning Best Picture.

title: West Bank
event: March 27 – A Palestinian suicide bomber '''killed''' 30 Israeli civilians and injured 140 othersHolocaust survivors, at the Park Hotel in Netanya, triggering Operation Defensive Shield, a large-scale counter-terrorist Israeli military incursion into the West Bank, two days later.

title: Bethlehem
event: April 2 – Israeli forces besiege the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, when militants take shelter there.

title: London
event: April 9 – The funeral of Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother takes place in Westminster Abbey, London.

title: Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
event: April 22 – At a special session of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, Director-General Jose Bustani is fired.

title: Baikonur Cosmodrome
event: April 25 – ''Soyuz TM-34'': South African Mark Shuttleworth blasts off from the Baikonur Cosmodrome; he had paid £15 million for the trip.

title: Laughlin Nevada
event: April 27 – The Laughlin, Nevada River Run Riot kills 3.

title: Bethlehem
event: May 9 – A 38-day stand-off in the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem ends, when the Palestinians inside agree to have 13 suspected militants among them deported to several different countries.

title: Sudan
event: May 21 – The US State Department releases a report naming 7 state sponsors of terrorism: Iran, Iraq, Cuba, Libya, North Korea, Sudan, and Syria.

title: Birmingham Alabama
event: May 22 – 16th Street Baptist Church bombing: A jury in Birmingham, Alabama convicts former Ku Klux Klan member Bobby Frank Cherry of the 1963 murders of 4 girls.

title: Estonia
event: May 25 – Estonia hosts the first Eurovision Song Contest in a former Soviet republic.

title: Taiwan Strait
event: May 25 – China Airlines Flight 611 disintegrates near the Penghu Islands at Taiwan Strait, killing all 225 people on board.

title: London
event: June 3 – The ''Party in the Palace'' takes place at Buckingham Palace, London for Queen Elizabeth II's Golden Jubilee celebrations.

title: Mediterranean Sea
event: June 6 – Eastern Mediterranean Event: An object with an estimated diameter of 10 meters collides with Earth, over the Mediterranean Sea, and detonates in mid-air.

title: French Open
event: June 8 – Serena Williams defeats her sister Venus Williams in straight sets to win the 2002 French Open.

title: United Kingdom
event: June 10 – The first direct electronic communication experiment between the nervous systems of 2 humans, is carried out by Kevin Warwick in the United Kingdom.

title: Tanzania
event: June 24 – The Igandu train disaster in Dodoma Region, Tanzania, kills 281 people in the worst rail accident in African history.

title: International Criminal Court
event: July 1 – The International Criminal Court is established to prosecute individuals for genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, and the crime of aggression.  Crimes committed on or after this date may be prosecuted by the court.

title: Sotheby's
event: July 10 – At a Sotheby's auction, Peter Paul Rubens' painting The Massacre of the Innocents (first version) is sold for £49.5million (US$76.2 million) to Kenneth Thomson, 2nd Baron Thomson of Fleet.

title: People's Republic of China
event: July 19 – Hail kills 25 and injures hundreds in the Chinese province of Henan.

title: Sknyliv airshow disaster
event: July 27 – A Sukhoi Su-27 fighter crashes at an air show in Ukraine, killing 85 and injuring more than 100, making it the worst air show disaster in history (see Sknyliv airshow disaster).

title: Switzerland
event: September 10 – Switzerland joins the United Nations.

title: Kolka-Karmadon rock ice slide
event: September 20 – The Kolka-Karmadon rock ice slide occurs.

title: Siberia
event: September 25 – The Vitim event, a possible bolide impact, occurs in Siberia, Russia.

title: Iraq
event: October 2 – The Congress of the United States passes a joint resolution, which authorizes the President to use the United States Armed Forces as he deems necessary and appropriate, against Iraq.

title: Montgomery County Maryland
event: October 2 – The Beltway sniper attacks begin with 5 shootings in Montgomery County, Maryland.

title: Finland
event: October 11 – Myyrmanni bombing: A lone bomber explodes a home-made bomb in the Myyrmanni shopping mall north of Helsinki, Finland; the casualties include himself.

title: Eveleth Minnesota
event: October 25 – U.S. Senator Paul Wellstone, his family, and his staff are killed in a plane accident at Eveleth, Minnesota.

title: National Mall
event: November 2 – The Godless Americans March on Washington brings together 2,000 atheists, freethinkers, and humanists in a mile-long parade down the National Mall.

title: Iran
event: November 7 – Iran bans the advertising of United States products.

title: Iraq
event: November 13 – Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq agrees to the terms of UN Security Council Resolution 1441.

title: Argentina
event: November 14 – Argentina defaults on a US $805 million World Bank loan payment.

title: Lincoln's Inn Fields
event: November 16 – A Campaign against Climate Change march takes place in London from Lincoln's Inn Fields, past Esso offices to the United States Embassy.

title: Iraq
event: November 18 – Iraq disarmament crisis: United Nations weapons inspectors led by Hans Blix arrive in Iraq.

title: Latvia
event: November 21 – At the NATO Summit in Prague, Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia, and Slovenia are invited to join the organization.

title: Nigeria
event: November 22 – In Nigeria, more than 100 are killed at an attack aimed at the Miss World contestants.

title: European Court of Human Rights
event: November 26 – Legislation by the European Court of Human Rights and Law Lords, ruling in favour of convicted murderer Anthony Anderson, ends the right of the Home Secretary to set minimum terms for convicted murderers.

title: Iraq
event: December 7 – As required by the recently passed U.N. resolution, Iraq files a 12,000 page weapons declaration with the U.N. Security Council.

title: High Court of Australia
event: December 10 – The High Court of Australia hands down its judgement in the Internet defamation dispute in the case of Gutnick v Dow Jones.

title: Philippines
event: December 29 – The Communist New People's Army blows up a bust of Ferdinand Marcos in Benguet, Philippines.

title: Stromboli
event: December 30 – An eruption on the volcanic island Stromboli off the coast of Sicily causes a flank failure and tsunami. The island is later evacuated.

title: Switzerland
event: January 1 – Pascal Couchepin becomes President of the Confederation in Switzerland.

title: Wood Green ricin plot
event: January 5 – Police arrest seven suspects in connection with Wood Green ricin plot.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: January 15 – ''Eldred v. Ashcroft'': The Supreme Court of the United States allows the extension of copyright terms in the U.S.

title: London
event: January 25 – A Central Line train crashes into the tunnel wall at Chancery Lane tube station in London, injuring 34 people.

title: Baghdad
event: January 25 – An international group of volunteers leaves London for Baghdad to act as voluntary human shields, hoping to avert a U.S. invasion.

title: Phnom Penh
event: January 29 – 2003 Phnom Penh riots: In Phnom Penh, Cambodia, the Thai Embassy is burned and commercial properties of Thai businesses are vandalized.

title: Texas
event: February 1 – At the conclusion of the ''STS-107'' mission, the Space Shuttle ''Columbia'' disintegrates during reentry over Texas, killing all 7 astronauts onboard.

title: South Africa
event: February 9 – The Cricket World Cup begins in South Africa.

title: Daegu subway fire
event: February 18 – An arsonist destroys a train in Daegu, South Korea, killing more than 190.

title: The Station nightclub fire
event: February 20 – The Station nightclub fire in West Warwick, Rhode Island claims the lives of 100 people.

title: Italy
event: March 13 – Human evolution: The journal ''Nature'' reports that 350,000-year-old upright-walking human footprints had been found in Italy.

title: South Africa
event: March 23 – The 2003 Cricket World Cup ends as Australia beats India by 125 runs in Johannesburg, South Africa.

title: Baghdad International Airport
event: April 3 – U.S. forces seize control of Saddam International Airport, changing the airport's name to Baghdad International Airport.

title: Al Udeid Air Base
event: April 29 – The United States announces the withdrawal of troops stationed in Saudi Arabia, and the redeployment of some at the Al Udeid Air Base in Qatar.

title: Kent
event: May 2 – The Monkeyman superhero hoax begins in Tunbridge Wells, Kent, UK.

title: New Hampshire
event: May 3 – The Old Man of the Mountain, a rock formation in New Hampshire, crumbles after heavy rain.

title: Sandusky Ohio
event: May 4 – Top Thrill Dragster opens in Cedar Point in Sandusky, Ohio as the world's tallest, fastest roller coaster.

title: Vienna
event: May 11 – Benvenuto Cellini's ''Saliera'' is stolen from the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna.

title: Riyadh
event: May 12 – In Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, 26 people are killed in the Riyadh Compound Bombings.

title: Casablanca
event: May 16 – In Casablanca, Morocco, 33 civilians are killed and more than 100 injured in the Casablanca terrorist attacks.

title: North Pole
event: May 19 – Pen Hadow becomes the first person to walk alone, without any outside help, from Canada to the North Pole.

title: Boumerdès
event: May 21 – An earthquake in the Boumerdès region of northern Algeria kills 2,200.

title: Texas A&M University
event: May 23 – Dewey, the first deer cloned by scientists at Texas A&M University, is born.

title: Latvia
event: May 24 – Sertab Erener wins the Eurovision Song Contest 2003 for Turkey with the song ''Every Way That I Can'', in Riga, Latvia.

title: Miami
event: May 25 – After docking in Miami at 05:00, the ''SS Norway'' (old ''SS France'') is severely damaged by a boiler explosion at 06:30, that kills 7, and injures 17 crew members. A few weeks later it is announced by NCL that she will never sail again as a commercial ocean liner.

title: Murphy North Carolina
event: May 31 – Eric Rudolph, suspected in the Centennial Olympic Park bombing in 1996, is captured in Murphy, North Carolina.

title: France
event: June 1 – The 29th G8 summit opens in Évian-les-Bains, France, to tight security and tens of thousands of protesters.

title: People's Republic of China
event: June 1 – The People's Republic of China begins filling the lake behind the massive Three Gorges Dam, raising the water level near the dam over 100 metres.

title: Mozdok Republic of North Ossetia-Alania
event: June 5 – A female suicide bomber detonates a bomb near a bus carrying soldiers and civilians to a military airfield in Mozdok, a major staging point for Russian troops in Chechnya, killing at least 16.

title: Aurora Nebraska
event: June 22 – The largest hailstone ever recorded falls in Aurora, Nebraska.

title: Supreme Court of the United States
event: June 23 – ''Grutter v. Bollinger'': The Supreme Court of the United States upholds affirmative action in university admissions.

title: 2003 Chicago balcony collapse
event: June 29 – A balcony collapse in Chicago kills 13.

title: British Columbia
event: July 2 – At the International Olympic Committee session in Prague, Vancouver, British Columbia is declared the host city for the XXI Olympic Winter Games in 2010.

title: France
event: July 7 – Corsica voters reject a referendum for increased autonomy from France by a very narrow margin.

title: Sudan
event: July 8 – Sudan Airways Flight 39, with 117 people on board, crashes in Sudan; the only survivor is a 2-year-old child.

title: Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)
event: July 18 – The body of David Kelly, a scientist at the Ministry of Defence, is found a few miles from his home, leading to the Hutton inquiry.

title: Iraq
event: July 22 – Uday and Qusay Hussein, sons of Saddam Hussein, are killed by the U.S. military in Iraq, after being tipped off by an informant.

title: Australia
event: July 24 – The Regional Assistance Mission to the Solomon Islands, Operation Helpem Fren, led by Australia, begins.

title: Puebla Puebla
event: July 30 – The last Volkswagen Type 1 rolls off its production line in Puebla, Puebla, Mexico.

title: Liberia
event: August 2 – The United Nations authorizes an international peacekeeping force for Liberia.

title: Kent
event: August 10 – The highest temperature ever recorded in the UK; 38.5°C (101.3°F) at Brogdale near Faversham in Kent.]<

title: NATO
event: August 11 – NATO takes over command of the peacekeeping force in Afghanistan, marking its first major operation outside Europe in its 54-year-history.

title: Bangkok
event: August 11 – Jemaah Islamiah leader Riduan Isamuddin, better known as Hambali, is arrested in Bangkok, Thailand.

title: Lefkada
event: August 14 – A 6.4 Richter scale earthquake occurs near the Greek Ionian island of Lefkada; 24 are injured.

title: Brazil
event: August 22 – A rocket explosion kills 21 at the Brazilian rocket complex in Alcântara, Brazil, due to the premature ignition of a solid rocket booster.

title: India
event: August 25 – Two bomb blasts in Mumbai, India kill 52.

title: Florida
event: August 25 – The Spitzer Space Telescope was launched from Cape Canaveral, Florida, during Delta II.

title: Birmingham
event: September 4 – Europe's busiest shopping centre, the Bullring in Birmingham, is officially opened by Sir Albert Bore.

title: Estonia
event: September 10 – Estonia approves joining the European Union in a referendum.

title: Ciudad Perdida
event: September 15 – The ELN kidnaps 8 foreign tourists in the Ciudad Perdida in Colombia; they demand a human rights investigation and release the last hostages 3 months later.

title: French Guiana
event: September 27 – Smart 1, a European Space Agency satellite, is launched from French Guiana.

title: Italy
event: September 28 – A power failure affects all of Italy except Sardinia, cutting service to more than 56 million people.

title: Nova Scotia
event: September 29 – Hurricane Juan lands at Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada as a category 2 storm, killing 2 directly and 5 indirectly.

title: Israel
event: October 5 – Israeli warplanes strike inside Syrian territory.

title: People's Republic of China
event: October 15 – China launches Shenzhou 5, their first manned space mission.

title: Cedar Fire
event: October 25 – The Cedar Fire begins in San Diego County, burning 280,000 acres (1,100 km²), 2,232 homes and killing 14.

title: Istanbul
event: November 15 – Two car bombs explode simultaneously in Istanbul, Turkey, targeting 2 synagogues, killing at least 25 people and wounding more than 300; Al-Qaida claims responsibility.

title: London
event: November 18 – U.S. President George W. Bush makes a state visit to London in the midst of massive protests.

title: Massachusetts
event: November 18 – The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, in Goodridge v. Department of Public Health, rules anti-same-sex marriage laws unconstitutional in Massachusetts.

title: United Kingdom
event: November 20 – Several bombs explode in Istanbul, Turkey, destroying the Turkish head office of HSBC and the British consulate.

title: Antarctica
event: November 23 – A total solar eclipse is seen over Antarctica.

title: Pan Am Flight 103
event: November 24 – The High Court in Glasgow imposes a minimum sentence of 27 years for Al Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi, the Libyan convicted of bombing Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.

title: United Kingdom
event: December 1 – The use of hand-held cell phones while driving is made illegal in the United Kingdom.

title: Nigeria
event: December 5 – The eighteenth Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting opens in Abuja, Nigeria.

title: Sunshine Coast Queensland
event: December 7 – Australian schoolboy Daniel Morcombe disappears from a bus stop on the Sunshine Coast, Queensland, Australia. It is one of the country's highest profile mysteries.

title: Red Square
event: December 9 – A female suicide bomber detonates outside Moscow's National Hotel, across from the Kremlin and Red Square, killing 5 bystanders.

title: Greece
event: December 12 – Olympic Airlines, Greece's new flag carrier, is launched.

title: Tikrit
event: December 13 – Saddam Hussein, former President of Iraq, is captured in Tikrit by the U.S. 4th Infantry Division.

title: London Stansted Airport
event: December 16 – The United Kingdom announces plans to build a new runway at Stansted Airport in Essex and a short-haul runway at Heathrow Airport, sparking anger from environmental groups.

title: London
event: December 18 – The Soham Murder Trial ends at the Old Bailey in London, with Ian Huntley found guilty of two counts of murder. His girlfriend Maxine Carr is found guilty of perverting the course of justice.

title: Libya
event: December 20 – Libya admits to building a nuclear bomb.

title: California
event: December 22 – An earthquake in California kills 2.

title: People's Republic of China
event: December 23 – A PetroChina Chuandongbei natural gas field explosion in Guoqiao, Kai County, Chongqing, China kills 234.

title: Republic of China
event: December 24 – A BSE (mad cow disease) outbreak in Washington State is announced. Several countries including Brazil, Australia and Taiwan ban the import of beef from the United States.

title: France
event: December 24 – At the request of the U.S. Embassy in Paris, the French Government orders Air France to cancel several flights between France and the U.S. in response to terrorist concerns.

title: Madrid
event: December 24 – The Spanish police thwart an attempt by ETA to detonate 50 kg of explosives at 3:55 p.m. on Christmas Eve inside Madrid's busy Chamartín Station.

title: Bam Iran
event: December 26 – A massive earthquake devastates southeastern Iran; over 40,000 people are reported killed in the city of Bam.

title: Leeds
event: December 31 – David Bieber is arrested on suspicion of the Boxing Day police shootings in Leeds.

title: Red Sea
event: January 3 – Flash Airlines Flight 604 crashes into the Red Sea off the coast of Egypt, killing all 148 aboard.

title: NASA
event: January 4 – NASA's MER-A (''Spirit'') lands on Mars at 04:35 UTC.

title: Cheshire
event: January 13 – Serial killer Harold Shipman is found hanged in his cell at Wakefield Prison, 4 years after being convicted of murdering 15 patients in Cheshire, England.

title: NASA
event: January 24 – NASA's MER-B (''Opportunity'') lands on Mars at 05:05 UTC.

title: Taiwan
event: January 26 – A whale explodes in Tainan City, Taiwan, while being transported through the town to a university for a necropsy.]<

title: Iraq
event: January 28 – The findings of the Hutton Inquiry are published in London. The British Government is found not to have falsified information in the sexed up dossier. The report criticizes the BBC's role in the death of David Kelly, a weapons expert on Iraq.

title: Faroe Islands
event: February 3 – Jóannes Eidesgaard becomes prime minister of the Faroe Islands.

title: Massachusetts
event: February 4 – Facebook was founded at Cambridge, Massachusetts.

title: Israel
event: February 7 – Several leaders of Abnaa el-Balad are arrested in Israel.

title: Baghdad
event: February 10 – At least 50 people are killed in a car bomb attack on a police recruitment centre south of Baghdad.

title: Australia
event: February 14 – Riots break out between New South Wales Police and Aboriginal residents of Redfern, New South Wales, a suburb of Sydney, Australia.

title: Transvaal Park
event: February 14 – The roof of the Transvaal water park in Moscow collapses, killing 25 and injuring more than 100.

title: Iran
event: February 18 – A train carrying a convoy of petrol, fertiliser, and sulfur derails and explodes in Iran, killing 320 people.

title: Al Hoceima
event: February 24 – A 6.5 Richter scale earthquake in Northern Morocco hits in the Rif mountains near the city of Al Hoceima, killing 400. Ait Kamara is destroyed; 517 are killed.

title: Libya
event: February 26 – The United States lifts a 23-year travel ban against Libya.

title: Republic of Macedonia
event: February 26 – Macedonian President Boris Trajkovski is killed in a plane crash near Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Philippines
event: February 27 – 2004 SuperFerry 14 bombing: The Abu Sayyaf guerrilla group is blamed for the deadliest terrorist attack at sea in world history, which kills 116 in the Philippines.

title: 228 Incident
event: February 28 – Over 1 million Taiwanese participating in the 228 Hand-in-Hand Rally form a 500-kilometre (300-mile) long human chain to commemorate the 228 Incident in 1947.

title: NASA
event: March 2 – NASA announces that the Mars rover MER-B (Opportunity) has confirmed that its landing area was once drenched in water.

title: RAF Brize Norton
event: March 10 – Five British men are released from detention at Camp Delta, Guantanamo Bay. After they land at RAF Brize Norton, 4 of them are immediately arrested for questioning.

title: Iraq
event: March 15 – The new Spanish Government announces that it will withdraw Spain's 1,300 troops in Iraq.

title: Iraq
event: March 19 – The United Nations launches a political corruption investigation due to the scandal over its Iraqi Oil for Food program.

title: People's Republic of China
event: March 20 – President Chen Shui-bian wins the Taiwanese presidential election by 0.2% of the vote. The day before, he and Vice President Annette Lu were shot. Lien Chan refuses to concede and demands a recount. A controversial peace referendum opposed by the People's Republic of China is invalidated.

title: Israel
event: March 22 – Palestinians protest in the streets after an Israeli helicopter gunship fires a missile at the entourage of Sheikh Ahmed Yassin in Gaza City, killing him and 7 others.

title: Libya
event: March 25 –  British prime minister Tony Blair visits Libyan leader Colonel Muammar al-Gaddafi, in return for the dismantling of Libya's Weapons of mass destruction programme in December 2003 (the first time a major western leader had visited the nation in several decades).

title: France
event: March 28 – In France, the government of prime minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin suffers a stunning and unprecedented defeat in regional elections.

title: Atlantic Ocean
event: March 28 – The first ever reported South Atlantic hurricane makes landfall in South Brazil in the state of Santa Catarina – the hurricane is dubbed Hurricane Catarina.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: March 29 – The Republic of Ireland bans smoking in all enclosed work places, including restaurants, pubs and bars.

title: Latvia
event: March 29 – The largest expansion of NATO to date takes place, allowing Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia into the organization.

title: Iraq
event: March 31 – Four American private military contractors working for Blackwater USA are killed, and their bodies mutilated, after being ambushed in Fallujah, Iraq.

title: France
event: April 5 – Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom begins a state visit to France to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Entente Cordiale.

title: Sudan
event: April 8 – Darfur conflict: The Humanitarian Ceasefire Agreement is signed by the Sudanese government and 2 rebel groups.

title: Gaza Strip
event: April 17 – Israeli helicopters fire missiles at a convoy of vehicles in the Gaza Strip, killing the Gaza leader of Hamas, Abdel Aziz al-Rantissi.

title: Israel
event: April 21 – Mordechai Vanunu, who revealed an Israeli nuclear weapons program in the 1980s, is released from prison in Israel after serving 18 years for treason.

title: North Korea
event: April 22 – Ryongchon disaster: Two trains carrying explosives and fuel collide in Ryongchon, North Korea, killing 161 people, injuring 1,300 and destroying thousands of homes.

title: France
event: April 22 – The last coal mine in France closes, ending nearly 300 years of coal mining.

title: Iraq
event: April 28 – Abu Ghraib prisoner abuse in Iraq is revealed on the television show ''60 Minutes II''.

title: Malta
event: May 1 – The largest expansion to date of the European Union takes place, extending the Union by 10 member-states: Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Slovenia, Hungary, Malta and Cyprus.

title: New York City
event: May 8 – Would-be Saudi Princess Antoinette Millard surfaces in New York City, claiming that muggers had stolen jewels worth of $262,000 from her (she later proves to be an impostor).

title: 2010 FIFA World Cup
event: May 15 – South Africa is awarded the 2010 FIFA World Cup.

title: Istanbul
event: May 15 – Ruslana wins the Eurovision Song Contest 2004 for Ukraine, with the song ''Wild Dances'' in Istanbul, Turkey.

title: Baghdad
event: May 17 – Ezzedine Salim, holder of the rotating leadership of the Iraq Interim Governing Council, is killed in a bomb blast in Baghdad.

title: Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court
event: May 17 – Massachusetts legalizes same-sex marriage, in compliance with a ruling from the state's Supreme Judicial Court (''Goodridge v. Department of Public Health'').

title: Baghdad
event: May 19 – Jeremy Sivits pleads guilty in a court-martial in connection with alleged abuse of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison in Baghdad.

title: North Korea
event: May 23 – Japanese prime minister Junichiro Koizumi visits North Korea, to secure the release of the families of the 9 abducted Japanese citizens returned earlier.

title: North Korea
event: May 24 – North Korea bans mobile phones (see Communications in North Korea).

title: Oklahoma City bombing
event: May 26 – Terry Nichols is convicted by an Oklahoma state court on murder charges stemming from the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Tiananmen Square protests of 1989
event: May 30 – Thousands of people in Hong Kong take to the streets to commemorate the 15th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre.

title: United Kingdom
event: June 3 – All outgoing flights from the UK are temporarily grounded following an air traffic control computer failure. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/3772077.stm BBC NEWS]

title: Central Intelligence Agency
event: June 3 – Central Intelligence Agency director George Tenet tenders his resignation, citing personal reasons. John E. McLaughlin, CIA Deputy Director, becomes the acting Director until a permanent Director is chosen and confirmed by Congress.

title: Granby Colorado
event: June 4 – Marvin Heemeyer destroys many local buildings with a home-made tank in Granby, Colorado.

title: Georgia (U.S. state)
event: June 8 – The 30th G8 summit takes place over the next 2 days on Sea Island, in Georgia, USA.

title: Indiana
event: June 11 – Terry Nichols is spared the death penalty by an Oklahoma state court on murder charges stemming from the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing. The decision comes on the third anniversary of the execution of his co-defendant, Timothy McVeigh, in Terre Haute, Indiana.

title: Ellerslie New Zealand
event: June 12 – A 1.3 kg chondrite type meteorite strikes a house in Ellerslie, New Zealand, causing serious damage but no injuries.

title: Mojave California
event: June 21 – In Mojave, California, SpaceShipOne becomes the first privately funded spaceplane to achieve spaceflight.

title: Texas
event: June 28 – Union Pacific and Burlington Northern Santa Fe trains collide in a rural area outside of San Antonio, Texas; 40 cars are derailed, including one chlorine car. Three people die, another 50 people are hospitalized because of exposure to the gas.

title: Iraq
event: June 30 – Preliminary hearings begin in Iraq in the trial of former president Saddam Hussein, for war crimes and crimes against humanity.

title: New York City
event: July 4 – Groundbreaking for the Freedom Tower begins at Ground Zero in New York City.

title: Gush Katif
event: July 25 – Over 100,000 opponents of Israel's unilateral disengagement plan of 2004 participate in a human chain from Gush Katif, to the Western Wall, Jerusalem (90 kilometers).

title: Asunción
event: August 1 – A supermarket fire in Asunción, Paraguay, kills about 400 and leaves over 100 missing.

title: NASA
event: August 3 – NASA's MESSENGER is launched (it will be captured into Mercury's orbit on March 18, 2011).

title: Darfur
event: August 6 – A United Nations report blaming the government of Sudan for crimes against humanity in Darfur is released.

title: Mihama Nuclear Power Plant
event: August 9 – At the Mihama Nuclear Power Plant, a pipe leaking hot water and steam kills 5 and injures 6 others, in the 2nd worst nuclear disaster in Japan.

title: Singapore
event: August 12 – Singapore's prime minister Goh Chok Tong hands over his position to Lee Hsien Loong.

title: New Jersey
event: August 12 – New Jersey Governor James McGreevey announces that he is a gay American and will resign effective November 15, 2004.

title: Jamaica
event: August 13 – Hurricane Charley kills 27 people in Florida, after killing 4 in Cuba and 1 in Jamaica. Charley makes landfall near Cayo Costa, FL as a Category 4 hurricane. Charley is the most intense hurricane to strike the United States since Hurricane Andrew in 1992.

title: Cornwall
event: August 16 – Severe flooding occurs in the village of Boscastle in Cornwall.

title: Dublin Port Tunnel
event: August 18 – In Dublin, Ireland, the Dublin Port Tunnel excavation works are completed and the final tunnel boring machine breakthrough ceremony takes place.

title: Bangladesh
event: August 21 – A series of blasts rocks an opposition party rally in Dhaka, Bangladesh, killing at least 13 people.

title: Domodedovo International Airport
event: August 24 – Two airliners in Russia, carrying a total of 89 passengers, crash within minutes of each other after flying out of Domodedovo International Airport, leaving no survivors. Authorities suspect suicide attacks by rebels from Chechnya to be the cause of the crashes.

title: New York City
event: August 29 – Around 200,000 protesters demonstrate in New York City against U.S. President George W. Bush and his government, ahead of the 2004 Republican National Convention.

title: New York City
event: August 30 – September 2 – U.S. President George W. Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney are renominated at the Republican National Convention in New York City.

title: Israel
event: August 31 – Two suicide attacks on buses in Beer Sheva, Israel, kill at least 16 people and injure at least 60. Hamas claims responsibility for the attacks.

title: Beslan school hostage crisis
event: September 1 – Chechen terrorists take between 1,000 and 1,500 people hostage, mostly children, in a school in the Beslan school hostage crisis. The hostage-takers demand the release of Chechen rebels imprisoned in neighbouring Ingushetia and the independence of Chechnya from Russia.

title: Beslan
event: September 3 – Russian forces end the siege at a school in Beslan, Northern Ossetia. At least 335 people (among which are 32 of the approximately 40 hostage-takers) are killed and at least 700 people injured.

title: South Carolina
event: September 3 – Hurricane Frances makes landfall in Florida. After killing 2 people in the Bahamas, Hurricane Frances kills 10 people in Florida, 2 in Georgia and 1 in South Carolina.

title: Jamaica
event: September 7 – Hurricane Ivan passes directly over Grenada, killing 37 people. It passes over other Caribbean islands over the next 2 days, killing 5 people in Venezuela, 4 in the Dominican Republic, 1 in Tobago and 20 in Jamaica.

title: Australia
event: September 9 – A bomb blast outside the Australian embassy in Jakarta, Indonesia, kills 11 and injures up to 100 people.

title: Palace of Westminster
event: September 15 – Security at the Palace of Westminster is compromised, when the House of Commons is stormed by a small group of protestors during a debate about fox hunting.

title: Florida
event: September 16 – Hurricane Ivan strikes Gulf Shores, Alabama, as a Category 3 storm, killing 25 in Alabama and Florida, becoming the 3rd costliest hurricane in American history (currently the 4th following the destruction of 2005's Hurricane Katrina).

title: Burj Khalifa
event: September 21 – Construction of the Burj Khalifa begins.

title: Mount St. Helens
event: September 23 – Mount St. Helens becomes active again.

title: Cameron Louisiana
event: September 23 – Tropical Storm Ivan, having come around and reformed in the Gulf of Mexico, makes its final landfall near Cameron, Louisiana, to little effect. In total, the storm kills 92 people.

title: Mojave California
event: September 29 – In Mojave, California, the first Ansari X-Prize flight takes place of SpaceShipOne, which is competing with a number of spacecraft (including Canada's Da Vinci Project, claimed to be its closest rival) and goes on to win the prize on October 4.

title: Baghdad
event: October 4 – Two car bombs kill at least 16 people and injure dozens more in Baghdad.

title: Ireland
event: October 5 – A fire breaks out on the Canadian submarine ''HMCS ''Chicoutimi'''', leaving it stranded without power in the North Atlantic ocean, off the north coast of Ireland; 1 crewmember is killed.

title: Red Sea
event: October 8 – Suicide bombers detonate 2 bombs at the Red Sea resort of Taba, Egypt, killing 34 people, mainly Israeli tourists and Egyptian workers.

title: Missouri
event: October 20 – Corporate Airlines Flight 5966 crashes in Missouri, killing 13 people and injuring 2.

title: Iraq
event: October 21 – The Ministry of Defence approves the deployment of the Black Watch regiment of the British Army to Baghdad, Iraq, after a request for assistance by the U.S. government.

title: Brazil
event: October 24 – Brazil successfully launches its first rocket into space.

title: Flores
event: October 27 – Details of the discovery of a new, recent species of fossil hominid, ''Homo floresiensis'', from the island of Flores, Indonesia, are published.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 30 – A 163-metre-high radio mast in Peterborough, UK collapses at a fire.

title: Mohammed Bouyeri
event: November 2 – Dutch film maker Theo van Gogh is assassinated in Amsterdam, Netherlands by Mohammed Bouyeri.

title: Berkshire
event: November 6 – The Ufton Nervet rail crash in Berkshire, England kills 7 people.

title: Fallujah
event: November 7 – U.S. forces launch a major assault on the Iraqi town of Fallujah, in an effort to rid the area of insurgents before the Iraqi elections in January.

title: Fallujah
event: November 13 – After six days of intense battles, the Iraqi town of Fallujah is fully occupied by U.S. forces.

title: European Space Agency
event: November 16 – The European Space Agency probe, Smart 1, passes from Earth orbit into the orbit of the Moon.

title: Australia
event: November 16 – A train crash near Bundaberg, Queensland, Australia, injures 150 people.

title: Argentina
event: November 16 – The People's Republic of China agrees to invest $20 billion dollars in Argentina, a deal signed days before the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum to be held in Santiago, Chile.

title: NASA
event: November 16 – NASA's hypersonic ''Scramjet'' breaks a record by reaching a velocity of about 7,000 mph in an unmanned experimental flight. It obtains a speed of Mach 9.6, almost 10 times the speed of sound.

title: India
event: November 25 – The Indian political party Congress Jananayaka Peravai merges into the Indian National Congress.

title: People's Republic of China
event: November 28 – An coal mine explosion in China kills over 150.

title: Maui
event: November 28 – A male Po'o-uli dies of avian malaria at the Maui Bird Conservation Center in Olinda before it can breed, making the species in all probability extinct.

title: Jeddah
event: December 6 – Terrorists attack the U.S. Consulate in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, killing several people.

title: Hewlett-Packard
event: December 8 – The biggest Chinese PC producer Lenovo announces its plan to purchase IBM's global PC business, making it the third largest world PC maker after Dell and Hewlett-Packard.

title: New Zealand
event: December 10 – New Zealand bans smoking in all public places, including bars.

title: France
event: December 14 – The world's tallest bridge, the Millau bridge over the River Tarn in the Massif Central mountains, France, is opened by President Jacques Chirac.

title: Greece
event: December 15 – Albanian terrorists take a bus and its passengers hostage in Athens, Greece and demand 1 million euros in ransom money.

title: House of Lords
event: December 16 – The House of Lords rules that the British Government breaches human rights legislation, by detaining without trial foreign nationals suspected of being terrorists.

title: Busan
event: December 16 – The South Korean high-speed rail system, Korea Train Express, opens between Seoul and Busan.

title: Mosul
event: December 21 – Iraqi insurgents attack a U.S. military base in the city of Mosul, killing 22 people.

title: Bangladesh
event: December 26 – One of the worst natural disasters in recorded history hits Southeast Asia, when the strongest earthquake in 40 years hits the entire Indian Ocean region. The massive 9.3 magnitude earthquake, epicentered just off the west coast of the Indonesian island of Sumatra, generates enormous tsunami waves that crash into the coastal areas of a number of nations including Thailand, India, Sri Lanka, the Maldives, Malaysia, Myanmar, Bangladesh, and Indonesia. The official death toll in the affected countries stands at 186,983 while more than 40,000 people are still missing.

title: Buenos Aires
event: December 30 – A fire in a Buenos Aires night club (República Cromagnon) kills 194 people during a rock concert.

title: Taipei 101
event: December 31 – Taipei 101, at the time tallest skyscraper in the world, standing at a height of 1,670 feet (509 metres ), officially opens.

title: Atlantic Canada
event: February 17–20 – A nor'easter blizzard devastates Atlantic Canada, dumping more than 37.4 in. (95 cm.) on some areas.

title: Madrid
event: March 11 – Terrorists execute simultaneous attacks, with bombs in 4 rush-hour trains in Madrid, killing 191 people.

title: Isle of Man
event: September – The Great Laxey Mine Railway of the Isle of Man is re-opened.

title: Xinhua News Agency
event: January 4 – Gunmen assassinate the Governor of Baghdad, Ali Al-Haidri.Xinhua News Agencydate=2005-01-05accessdate=2009-10-14}}<

title: Cape Canaveral
event: January 12 – Deep Impact is launched from Cape Canaveral by a Delta 2 rocket.

title: India
event: January 25 – A stampede at the Mandher Devi temple in Mandhradevi during a religious pilgrimage in India kills at least 250.

title: Madrid
event: February 9 – An ETA car bomb injures at least 40 people at a conference centre in Madrid.

title: North Korea
event: February 10 – North Korea announces that it possesses nuclear weapons as a protection against the hostility it feels from the United States.

title: Beirut
event: February 14 – Former Prime Minister of Lebanon Rafik Hariri is killed in Beirut after an assassination attempt by suicide bombing, it also kills at least 16 other people and injures 120 others.

title: Iran
event: February 14 – 59 people are killed and 200 injured after a fire breaks out in a mosque in Tehran, Iran.

title: Australia
event: February 16 – The Kyoto Protocol goes into effect, without the support of the United States and Australia.CBCaccessdate=2009-10-15date=2005-02-16}}<

title: Iraq
event: February 19 – Suicide bombers kill more than 30 people in Iraq as Shia Muslims mark Ashura, their holiest day.

title: Iran
event: February 22 – More than 500 people are killed and over 1,000 injured, after entire villages are flattened in an earthquake (6.4 on the Richter scale) in the Zarand region of Kerman province in southern Iran.

title: Denmark
event: March 3 – The freighter ''M/V Karen Danielsen'' crashes into the Great Belt Bridge of Denmark. All traffic across the bridge is closed, effectively separating Denmark in two.News24date=2005-03-07accessdate=2009-10-16}}<

title: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
event: March 3 – Millionaire Steve Fossett breaks a world record by completing the first non-stop, non-refueled, solo flight around the world in the Virgin Atlantic GlobalFlyer.Australian Broadcasting Corporationaccessdate=2009-10-16date=2005-03-04first=Tonylast-Eastley}}<

title: Alberta
event: March 3 – Four Royal Canadian Mounted Police officers are gunned down in Mayerthorpe, Alberta, Canada. It is deadliest day in Canadian law enforcement in over 120 years.

title: Iraq
event: March 4 – The car of released Italian hostage Giuliana Sgrena is fired on by U.S. soldiers in Iraq, causing the death of 1 passenger and injuring 2 more.CTV Newsaccessdate=2009-10-17date=2005-03-05}}<

title: Taiwan
event: March 14 – The People's Republic of China ratifies an anti-secession law, aimed at preventing Taiwan from declaring independence.

title: Beirut
event: March 14 – 800,000 people gather for an opposition rally in Beirut, a month after the death of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri. It is the largest rally in Lebanon's history.Sydney Morning Heraldaccessdate=2009-10-21date=2005-03-15}}<

title: Taiwan
event: March 26 – The Taiwanese government calls on 1 million Taiwanese to demonstrate in Taipei, in opposition to the Anti-Secession Law of the People's Republic of China. Between 200,000 and 300,000 attend the walk.

title: Curaçao
event: April 8 – A referendum is held in Curaçao on independence vs. integration with the Netherlands.NRC Handelsbladfirst=Miriamlast=Sluisdate=April 9, 2005accessdate=October 27, 2009}}<

title: Baghdad
event: April 9 – Tens of thousands of demonstrators, many of them supporters of Shia cleric Moqtada Sadr, march through Baghdad denouncing the U.S. occupation of Iraq, 2 years after the fall of Saddam Hussein, and rally in the square where his statue was toppled in 2003.

title: Switzerland
event: April 17 – Twelve holidaymakers are killed in southern Switzerland when a bus carrying 27 people plunges {{convert656ftm}} into a ravine.

title: Iran
event: April 18 – Five people die in ethnic clashes in Iran's south-west Khuzestan province.

title: Hyōgo Prefecture
event: April 25 – Amagasaki rail crash: A passenger train derails in Amagasaki Hyōgo Prefecture, Japan, killing 104 people and injuring at least another 450.

title: Lahore
event: May 3 – At least 32 people are killed and 9 others injured when 3 two-story buildings in the eastern Pakistani city of Lahore collapse after gas cylinders stored in one of them explode.

title: Bangladesh
event: May 15 – A passenger ferry capsizes and sinks in strong winds in the Bura Gauranga River in Bangladesh, leaving 200 people missing.

title: Solent
event: June 28 – Queen Elizabeth II conducts the International Fleet Review of 167 international warships in the Solent, as part of the Trafalgar 200 celebrations.Eastern Daily Pressaccessdate=November 1, 2009date=June 28, 2005}}<

title: NASA
event: July 4 – NASA's Copper bullet from the Deep Impact spacecraft hits Comet Tempel 1, creating a crater for scientific studies.

title: Gleneagles Scotland
event: July 4 – Violent anti-G8 demonstrations occur in Gleneagles, Scotland.

title: Italy
event: July 4 – The Italy-USA Foundation is established in Rome, Italy.

title: European Parliament
event: July 6 – The European Parliament rejects the Directive on the patentability of computer-implemented inventions in its second reading in the codecision procedure.

title: London
event: July 6 – The International Olympic Committee awards the 2012 Summer Olympics to London.

title: Xinhua News Agency
event: July 23 – A series of blasts hits a resort town in Egypt.Xinhua News Agencyaccessdate=November 9, 2009date=July 23, 2005}}<

title: Greece
event: August 14 - Helios Airways Flight 522 crashes near the town of Grammatiko in Greece, killing 121 people. Observations from fighter jet aircraft indicate a decompression problem.

title: West Caribbean Airways Flight 708
event: August 16 – West Caribbean Airways Flight 708 crashes into a mountain in Venezuela, killing 152 passengers.

title: People's Republic of China
event: August 18 – Peace Mission 2005, the first joint China–Russia military exercise, begins its 8-day training on the Shandong peninsula.

title: Zambezi Escarpment
event: August 22 – A {{convert4.1kg}} meteorite crashes into the Dotito area of Zambezi Escarpment in Zimbabwe, leaving a {{convert150mmsp=us}} crater.

title: West Bank
event: August 23 – Israel's unilateral disengagement from 25 Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip and West Bank ends.

title: Baghdad
event: August 31 – A crowd crush on the Al-Aaimmah bridge in Baghdad kills several hundred civilians (see Baghdad bridge stampede).

title: New York City
event: September 14–16 – The largest UN World Summit in history is held in New York City.

title: North Korea
event: September 19 – North Korea agrees to stop building nuclear weapons in exchange for aid and cooperation.

title: Federal Bureau of Investigation
event: September 23 – Convicted bank thief and Boricua Popular Army leader, Filiberto Ojeda Ríos, is killed in his home in Hormigueros, Puerto Rico when members of the FBI attempt to serve an arrest warrant.

title: Denmark
event: September 30 – Controversial drawings of Muhammad are printed in the Danish newspaper Jyllands-Posten.

title: Australia
event: October 1 – An Australian photojournalist in Afghanistan, Stephen Dupont, films U.S. soldiers burning 2 dead Taliban militias' bodies.

title: 2005 Kashmir earthquake
event: October 8 – The 2005 Kashmir earthquake kills about 80,000 people.

title: People's Republic of China
event: October 12 – The second Chinese spacecraft, ''Shenzhou 6'', is launched, carrying Fei Junlong and Nie Haisheng for 5 days in orbit.

title: United Kingdom
event: October 21 – The 200th Anniversary of the Battle of Trafalgar is observed, with celebrations held around the United Kingdom.

title: Delhi
event: October 29 – At least 61 people are killed and many others wounded in 3 powerful blasts in the Indian capital, Delhi (see 29 October 2005 Delhi bombings).

title: Congress of Deputies (Spain)
event: November 2 – The Spanish Congress of Deputies approves the admission to formality of the new Catalan Statute of Autonomy with the support of all the groups except the People's Party (PP), which the same day files an objection of unconstitutionality.

title: Amman
event: November 9 – At least 50 people are killed and more than 120 injured in a series of coordinated suicide bombings in Amman, Jordan (See 2005 Amman bombings).

title: United Kingdom
event: November 13 – Andrew Stimpson, a 25-year old British man, is reported as the first person proven to have been 'cured' of HIV.

title: Malta
event: November 25 – The 20th Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting opens in Valletta, Malta.

title: Quebec
event: November 28 – December 9 – The United Nations Climate Change Conference is held in Montreal, Quebec.

title: France
event: November 30 – Surgeons in France carry out the first human face transplant.

title: Iran
event: December 6 – An Iranian C-130 Hercules airplane crashes into a ten-story building in a civilian area of Tehran, the capital of Iran, killing all 94 people aboard and 34 residents of the building (128 total).

title: Australia
event: December 11 – The 2005 Cronulla riots occur in Sydney, Australia, involving up to 5,000 youths.

title: Sudan
event: December 23 – Chad declares a state of war with Sudan, following a December 18 attack on Adre, which left about 100 people dead.

title: Mina Saudi Arabia
event: January 12 – A stampede during the Stoning of the devil ritual on the last day at the Hajj in Mina, Saudi Arabia, kills 362 pilgrims.The Independentfirst=Justinlast=Huggler  location=London}}<CBC Newsaccessdate=2009-07-06quote=It's the same place where 362 people died in a stampede on Jan. 12, 2006}}<

title: Stardust (spacecraft)
event: January 15 – NASA's Stardust mission successfully ends, the first to return dust from a comet.Associated Press}}<

title: Red Sea
event: February 3 – An Egyptian passenger ferry carrying more than 1,400 people, sinks in the Red Sea off the Saudi coast.Associated Pressdate=2006-02-06accessdate=2009-07-05}}<

title: Philippines
event: February 4 – The Wowowee stampede at the PhilSports Arena in Pasig City, Philippines kills 74 people and leaves 600 injured.Filipino Reporterdate=2006-02-23accessdate=2009-07-05}}<

title: Italy
event: February 10–26 – The 2006 Winter Olympics are held in Turin, Italy.

title: International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement
event: February 17 – A massive mudslide occurs in Southern Leyte, Philippines; the official death toll is set at 1,126.Red Crossdate=2007-08-31accessdate=2009-07-06format=PDF}}<

title: Nueva Rosita
event: February 19 – Pasta de Conchos mine disaster: Sixty-five miners die after becoming trapped underground, following an explosion in Nueva Rosita, Mexico.Los Angeles Timesdate=2006-02-20accessdate=2009-07-06first=Samlast=Enriquez}}<

title: National Geographic Society
event: March 9 – NASA's Cassini-Huygens spacecraft discovers geysers of a liquid substance shooting from Saturn's moon Enceladus, signaling a possible presence of water.National Geographic Societydate=2006-03-10accessdate=2009-07-06first=Elizabethlast=Svoboda}}<

title: National Geographic Society
event: March 10 – NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter enters Mars orbit.CNNdate=2006-03-10accessdate=2009-07-06first=Peggylast=Mihelich}}<National Geographic Societydate=2006-03-10first=Johnlast=Roach}}<

title: NASA
event: March 28 – A scramjet jet engine, Hyshot III, designed to fly at 7 times the speed of sound, is successfully tested at Woomera, South Australia.Australian Broadcasting Corporationdate=2006-03-25accessdate=2009-07-07}}<NASA}}<

title: United Kingdom
event: April 5 – A swan with Avian Flu is discovered in Cellardyke in Fife, Scotland (the first case in the United Kingdom).British Broadcasting Corporationdate=2006-04-06accessdate=2009-07-07first=Rebeccalast=Morelle}}<

title: India
event: April 10 – A fire at the Brand India Fair, Victoria Park, Meerut, Uttar Pradesh, India, kills at least 100.The Timesaccessdate=2009-07-09date=2006-04-10  location=London  first1=Simon  last1=Freeman}}<

title: European Space Agency
event: April 11 – The European Space Agency's Venus Express spaceprobe enters Venus' orbit.Associated Pressdate=2006-04-12accessdate=2009-07-09archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iTJI8zKGarchivedate=2009-07-22deadurl=no}}<

title: Iran
event: April 20 – Iran announces a deal with Russia, involving a joint uranium enrichment firm on Russian soil;The Timesfirst=Jennylast=Boothdate=2006-04-21accessdate=2009-07-09  location=London}}< 9 days later Iran announces that it will not move all activity to Russia, thus leading to a de-facto termination of the deal.

title: Xinhua News Agency
event: May 24 – East Timor's Foreign Minister José Ramos-Horta officially requests military assistance from the governments of Australia, New Zealand, Malaysia and Portugal.Xinhua News Agencydate=2006-05-24accessdate=2009-07-25first=Zhulast=Jinarchiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iZFytiSbarchivedate=2009-07-26deadurl=no}}<

title: May 2006 Java earthquake
event: May 27 – A 6.3 magnitude earthquake strikes central Java in Indonesia, killing more than 6,000, injuring at least 36,000 and leaving some 1.5 million people homeless.CNN}}<

title: Xinhua News Agency
event: June 3 – Montenegro declares independence after a May 21 referendum. The state union of Serbia and Montenegro is dissolved on June 5, leaving Serbia as the successor state.USA Todaydate=2006-06-03accessdate=2009-07-25}}<Xinhua News Agencydate=2006-06-04first=Mulast=Xuequanaccessdate=2009-07-25archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iappCegNarchivedate=2009-07-27deadurl=no}}<

title: 2006 FIFA World Cup
event: June 9 – July 9 – The 2006 FIFA World Cup begins in Germany.

title: Kazakhstan
event: June 18 – The first Kazakh space satellite ''KazSat'' is launched.The Associated Pressdate=2006-06-18accessdate=2009-07-25}}<

title: Israel
event: June 28 – Operation Summer Rains: Israel launches an offensive against militants in Gaza.The Daily Telegraphfirst=Timlast=Butcherdate=2006-06-29accessdate=2009-07-25  location=London}}<

title: People's Republic of China
event: July 1 – The Qingzang railway launches a trial operation, making Tibet the last province-level entity of China to have a conventional railway.The Associated Pressdate=2006-07-02accessdate=2009-07-31first=Alexalast=Olesen}}<

title: Xinhua News Agency
event: July 6 – The Nathula Pass between India and China, sealed during the Sino-Indian War, re-opens for trade after 44 years.Xinhua News Agencydate=2006-07-07first=Lilast=Baodongcoauthors=Shuangqi, Fuaccessdate=2009-08-05archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5ix2y1B6yarchivedate=2009-08-11deadurl=no}}<

title: PIA Flight 688
event: July 10 – Pakistan International Airlines Flight 688 crashes in Multan, Pakistan shortly after takeoff.BBCdate=2006-07-10accessdate=2009-08-05}}<

title: India
event: July 11 – A series of coordinated bomb attacks strikes several commuter trains in Mumbai, India during the evening rush hour.New Zealand Heralddate=2006-07-12accessdate=2009-10-09}}<

title: Israel
event: July 12 – 2006 Lebanon War: Israeli troops invade Lebanon in response to Hezbollah kidnapping two Israeli soldiers and killing 3. Hezbollah declares open war against Israel 2 days later.CTV Television Networkaccessdate=2009-10-09date=2006-07-14}}<

title: RMS Titanic
event: July 18 – The ''SS Nomadic'', the last floating link to ''Titanic'', returns home to a large reception in Belfast.BBCdate=2006-07-16accessdate=2009-10-09}}<

title: Xinhua News Agency
event: September 19 – Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra of Thailand declares a state of emergency in Bangkok as members of the Royal Thai Army stage a coup d'état. The army announces the removal of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra from power.Xinhua News Agencyaccessdate=2009-10-10date=2006-09-20first=Sunlast=Luying}}<

title: 2006 North Korean nuclear test
event: October 9 – North Korea claims to have conducted its first-ever nuclear test.The Guardiandate=2006-10-09accessdate=2009-10-11  location=London}}<

title: Nigeria
event: October 29 – Aviation Development Company Flight 53 crashes shortly after takeoff in Nigeria killing 96 people.The Associated Pressaccessdate=2009-10-11}}<

title: Baghdad
event: November 23 – A series of car bombs and mortar attacks in Sadr City, Baghdad, kill at least 215 people and injure 257 other people.The Associated Pressaccessdate=2009-10-12date=2006-11-25}}<

title: Philippines
event: November 30 – Typhoon Durian triggers a massive mudslide and kills at least 720 people in Albay province on the island of Luzon in the Philippines.ReliefWebaccessdate=2009-10-12date=2006-12-13}} {{Dead linkdate=September 2010bot=H3llBot}}<

title: Fiji
event: December 5 – The military seizes power in Fiji, in a coup d'état led by Commodore Josaia Voreqe Frank Bainimarama.China Central Televisionfirst=Dulast=Xiaodan}}<

title: Lagos
event: December 26 – An oil pipeline explodes in Nigeria's commercial capital, Lagos, killing at least 200 people.Bloombergaccessdate=2009-10-13date=2006-12-26first=Helenelast=Fouquet}}<

title: Madrid
event: December 30 – Basque nationalist group ETA detonates a van bomb at Madrid-Barajas Airport in Madrid, Spain, ending a nine-month ceasefire.

title: Xinjiang
event: January 3 – China conducts an anti-terror raid in Xinjiang.

title: International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement
event: January 14 – The International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement adopts the Red Crystal as a non-religious emblem for use in its overseas operations.

title: Celebrity Big Brother 2007 (UK)
event: January 17 – Protests occur in India and the United Kingdom against the British series of ''Celebrity Big Brother'', after Jade Goody, Danielle Lloyd and Jo O'Meara were allegedly racially abusive towards Bollywood star Shilpa Shetty.

title: Israel
event: January 19 – Israel releases $100 million in frozen assets to President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian National Authority, in order to bolster the president's position.

title: Sudan
event: February 2–Chinese President Hu Jintao signs a series of economic deals with Sudan.

title: North Korea
event: February 13–North Korea agrees to shut down its nuclear facilities in Yongbyon by April 14 as a first step towards complete denuclearization, receiving in return energy aid equivalent to 50,000 tons of heavy fuel oil.

title: Srebrenica massacre
event: February 26–The International Court of Justice finds Serbia guilty of failing to prevent genocide in the Srebrenica massacre, but clears it of direct responsibility and complicity in the case.

title: South Pole
event: March 1–The International Polar Year, a $1.5 billion research program to study both the North Pole and South Pole, is launched in Paris.

title: Israel
event: March 8–Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert admits that Israel had planned an attack on Lebanon in the event of kidnapped soldiers on the border, months before Hezbollah carried out its kidnapping.

title: 2007 Iranian seizure of Royal Navy personnel
event: March 23–Naval forces of Iran's Revolutionary Guard seize Royal Navy personnel in disputed Iran-Iraq waters.

title: Latvia
event: March 27–Prime Minister of Latvia Aigars Kalvitis and Prime minister of Russia Mikhail Fradkov finally sign a border treaty between Latvia and Russia.

title: 2007 Iranian seizure of Royal Navy personnel
event: April 4–Iran announces it will release the British sailors and marines that they captured on March 23.

title: Bronze Soldier of Tallinn
event: April 26–Russians riot in Tallinn, Estonia, about moving the Bronze Soldier; 2 nights of rioting leave 1 dead.

title: Dubai
event: May 20–Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum of Dubai makes the largest single charitable donation in modern history, committing €7.41 billion to an educational foundation in the Middle East.

title: NASA
event: June 5–NASA's MESSENGER spacecraft makes its second fly-by of Venus en route to Mercury.

title: Greece
event: June 28–In the aftermath of Greece's worst heatwave in a century, at least 11 people are reported dead from heatstroke, approximately 200 wildfires break out nationwide, and the country's electricity grid nearly collapses due to record breaking demand.

title: Gaza Strip
event: August 6–Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert arrives in the historic Palestinian town of Jericho, becoming the first Prime Minister of Israel to visit the West Bank or Gaza Strip in more than 7 years. Olmert meets with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas.

title: Iraq
event: August 14–Multiple suicide bombings kill 572 people in Qahtaniya, northern Iraq.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: August 15–An 8.0 earthquake strikes Peru, killing 512 people, injuring more than 1,500, and causing tsunami warnings in the Pacific Ocean.

title: Sydney
event: September 2–9–The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit hosts its 19th annual city meeting in Sydney.

title: Operation Orchard
event: September 6–''Operation Orchard'': Israeli airplanes strike a suspected nuclear site in Syria.

title: One-Two-GO Airlines Flight 269
event: September 16–One-Two-GO Airlines Flight 269 crashes in Phuket, Thailand, killing 89 passengers and crew.

title: Monterrey
event: September 20–The 2007 Universal Forum of Cultures opens in Monterrey, Mexico.

title: South Yemen
event: October 14–Al-habileen/lahij: Four citizens are killed on the 44th anniversary of the revolution against British colonial rule in South Yemen.

title: Basilan
event: November 13–An explosion hits the south wing of the House of Representatives of the Philippines in Quezon City, north of Manila, killing 4 people, including Basilan Congressman Wahab Akbar, and wounding 6 others.

title: Channel Tunnel
event: November 14–High Speed 1 from London to the Channel Tunnel is opened to passengers.

title: Bangladesh
event: November 16–Approximately 10,000 people are believed to have died after Cyclone Sidr hits Bangladesh.

title: 2007 Zasyadko mine disaster
event: November 18–The Zasyadko mine disaster in eastern Ukraine claims the lives of 101 miners.

title: Nusa Dua
event: December 3–14–The United Nations Climate Change Conference is held at Nusa Dua in Bali, Indonesia.

title: Czech Republic
event: December 8–The 2007 Africa-EU Summit takes place as European Union and African Union leaders gather in Lisbon, Portugal, for their first joint summit in 7 years. The British and Czech prime ministers boycott the event due to the presence of Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe.

title: São Paulo Museum of Art
event: December 20–The Pablo Picasso painting ''Portrait of Suzanne Bloch'', together with Candido Portinari's ''O Lavrador de Café'', is stolen from the São Paulo Museum of Art.

title: Malta
event: December 21–The Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia, and Slovenia join the Schengen border-free zone.

title: Nepal
event: December 24–The Nepalese government announces that the country's 240-year-old monarchy will be abolished in 2008 and a new republic will be declared.

title: Assassination of Benazir Bhutto
event: December 27–Former Pakistani prime minister Benazir Bhutto is assassinated, and at least 20 others are killed by a bomb blast at an election rally in Rawalpindi.

title: Kenya
event: December 31–Over 200 people are killed in Kenya, due to riots over the results of the December 27 presidential election.

title: Malta
event: January 1 – Cyprus and Malta adopt the euro.ISO 4217 code: VEF).<

title: Baghdad
event: January 1 – A suicide bombing occurs in Zayouna, Baghdad, killing over 25 people during a funeral over the deaths from the preceding attack.

title: Diyarbakır
event: January 3 – A car bomb detonates, killing at least 4 and injuring 68, in Diyarbakır, Turkey. Police blame Kurdish rebels.

title: Maldives
event: January 8 – An attempted assassination of Maldivian president Maumoon Abdul Gayoom is thwarted after a Boy Scout grabs the attacker's knife. The Boy Scout is injured, but after a scuffle police arrest the attacker.

title: Republic of Macedonia
event: January 12 – A Macedonian Army Mil Mi-17 helicopter crashes in thick fog southeast of Skopje, killing all 11 military personnel on board.

title: Federal Court of Australia
event: January 15 – The Federal Court of Australia orders a Japanese whaling company to stop research whaling within their Exclusive Economic Zone.

title: France
event: January 22 – Russia stages the largest naval exercise since the fall of the Soviet Union in the Bay of Biscay. The Russian aircraft carrier Admiral Kuznetsov, along with 11 support vessels and 47 long-range bomber aircraft, practises strike tactics off the coast of France and Spain, and test-launches nuclear-capable missiles in foreign waters.

title: Mirosławiec
event: January 23 – Polish Air Force EADS CASA C-295 crashes on approach to the 12th Air Base near Mirosławiec. All 20 personnel on board die.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: January 24 – A peace deal ends the Kivu war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

title: People's Republic of China
event: January 25 – China's worst snowstorm since 1954 kills 133, delays traffic, and causes massive power outages in central and southern parts of the country.

title: Iran
event: January 29 – Iran's judiciary sentences to prison 54 Bahá'í Faith followers for anti-regime propaganda.

title: N'Djamena
event: February 2 – Rebels attack the capital of Chad, N'Djamena.

title: Iran
event: February 4 – Iran opens its first space center and launches a rocket into space.

title: Namdaemun
event: February 10 – The 2008 Namdaemun fire severely damages Namdaemun, the first National Treasure of South Korea.

title: Australia
event: February 13 – Prime Minister Kevin Rudd of Australia delivers a formal apology to the Stolen Generations.

title: Northern Rock
event: February 18 – The British government introduces emergency legislation temporarily to nationalize Northern Rock, the 5th largest mortgage bank in the UK, due to the bank's financial crisis.

title: Pacific Ocean
event: February 20 – The United States Navy destroys a spy satellite containing toxic fuel, by shooting it down with a missile launched from the ''USS Lake Erie'' in the Pacific Ocean.

title: North America
event: February 20 – A total lunar eclipse crosses North and South America, Europe, Africa, and Southwest Asia.

title: Northern Rock
event: February 22 – Former building society Northern Rock is the first bank in Europe to be taken into state control, due to the U.S. subprime mortgage financial crisis.

title: Santa Bárbara Airlines Flight 518
event: February 22 – No survivors are found after a rescue helicopter discovers the wreckage of Santa Bárbara Airlines Flight 518 just northeast of Mérida, Venezuela. The commercial plane had 46 people on board, including crew.

title: Gaza Strip
event: March 1 – In Gaza Strip, at least 52 Palestinians and 2 Israeli soldiers are killed in the most intense Israeli air strikes since 2005.

title: 2008 Andean diplomatic crisis
event: March 2 – 2008 Andean diplomatic crisis: Venezuela and Ecuador move troops to the Colombian border, following a Colombian raid against FARC guerrillas inside Ecuador's national territory, in which senior commander Raúl Reyes is killed.

title: Mercaz HaRav massacre
event: March 6 – Eight Israeli civilians are killed and 9 wounded when a Palestinian attacker opens fire at a Jewish seminary in Jerusalem.

title: French Guiana
event: March 9 – The first European Space Agency Automated Transfer Vehicle, a cargo spacecraft for the International Space Station, launches from Guiana Space Centre in French Guiana.

title: Gërdec
event: March 15 – A gun factory explosion in Gërdec, Albania kills more than 30. Over the following week, Albania, Kosovo, and some surrounding countries supply and support Gërdec's population with food, blood, etc.

title: Bhutan
event: March 24 – Bhutan holds its first-ever general elections.France 24, March 24, 2008<

title: Wilkins Sound
event: March 25 – A 414 square kilometer (160 sq. mi.<sup>2</sup>) chunk of Antarctica's Wilkins Ice Shelf disintegrates, leaving the entire shelf at risk.

title: Anjouan
event: March 25 – African Union and Comoros forces invade the rebel-held island of Anjouan.

title: Sark
event: April 8 – Privy Council of Sark dismantles its feudal system to comply with the European Convention on Human Rights. and the first elections under the new law will be held in December 2008 and the new chamber will first convene in January 2009.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
event: April 15 – A Hewa Bora Airways DC-9 crashes into a residential area of Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo.

title: Kenya
event: April 17 – Raila Odinga becomes the new Prime Minister of Kenya after the formation of a coalition government, ending the political crisis in Kenya.

title: India
event: April 28 – India sets a world record by sending 10 satellites into orbit in a single launch.

title: People's Republic of China
event: April 28 – 71 die in a train crash in Shandong, China.

title: Burma
event: May 3 – Over 133,000 in Burma/Myanmar are killed by Cyclone Nargis, the deadliest natural disaster since the Boxing Day Tsunami in 2004.

title: Burma
event: May 11 – Burma/Myanmar holds a constitutional referendum.

title: Sichuan
event: May 12 – Over 69,000 are killed in central south-west China by the Wenchuan quake, an earthquake measuring 7.9 Moment magnitude scale. The epicenter is 90 kilometers (55 miles) west-northwest of the provincial capital Chengdu, Sichuan province.

title: India
event: May 13 – A series of bomb blasts kills at least 63 and injures 216 in Jaipur, India.

title: Nigeria
event: May 15 – An oil pipeline explosion in Ijegun, Nigeria kills 100.

title: Pedra Branca dispute
event: May 23 – The International Court of Justice awards Middle Rocks to Malaysia and Pedra Branca to Singapore, ending a 29-year territorial dispute between the 2 countries.

title: Phoenix (spacecraft)
event: May 25 – NASA's Phoenix spacecraft becomes the first to land on the northern polar region of Mars.

title: Nepal
event: May 28 – The Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal is established after the Assembly votes overwhelmingly in favor of abolishing the country's 240-year-old monarchy. Girija Prasad Koirala becomes temporary head of state.

title: Islamabad
event: June 2 – A car bomb explodes outside the Danish embassy in Islamabad, Pakistan, killing at least five.

title: Akihabara massacre
event: June 8 – In the Akihabara area of Tokyo, Japan, a 25-year-old man stabs seven to death and wounds 10, before being arrested.

title: Khartoum
event: June 10 – Fire engulfs Sudan Airways Flight 109 after it lands in Khartoum, killing 44.

title: Republic of Ireland
event: June 12 – Ireland votes to reject the Treaty of Lisbon, in the only referendum to be held by a European Union member state on the treaty.

title: Iwate Prefecture
event: June 14 – A 6.9 magnitude earthquake in Iwate Prefecture, Japan, kills 12 and injures more than 400.

title: Expo 2008
event: June 14 – September 14 – Expo 2008 is held in Zaragoza, Spain, with the topic of ''Water and sustainable development''.

title: Philippines
event: June 22 – Typhoon Fengshen hits the Philippines and capsizes the ferry ''MV Princess of the Stars'', leaving hundreds dead or missing.

title: Microsoft
event: June 27 – After three decades as the Chairman of Microsoft Corporation, Bill Gates steps down from daily duties to concentrate on philanthropy.

title: Operation Jaque
event: July 2 – Íngrid Betancourt and 14 other hostages are rescued from FARC by Colombian security forces.

title: India
event: July 7 – A suicide-bomber drives an explosives-laden automobile into the front gates of the Indian embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, killing 58 and injuring over 150.

title: Tōyako Hokkaidō
event: July 7–9 – The 34th G8 summit is held in Tōyako, Hokkaidō, Japan.

title: Republic of Macedonia
event: July 10 – Former Macedonian Interior Minister Ljube Boškoski is acquitted of all charges, by a UN Tribunal accusing him of war crimes.

title: Australia
event: July 15–20 – World Youth Day takes place in Sydney, Australia. Pope Benedict XVI appears at the event.

title: India
event: July 25 – A series of seven bomb blasts rock Bangalore, India, killing two and injuring 20; the next day, a series of bomb blasts in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India, kills 45 and injures over 160 people.

title: Istanbul
event: July 27 – At least 17 are killed and over 154 wounded in 2 blasts in Istanbul.

title: Iraq
event: July 28 – At least 48 are dead and over 287 injured after bombs explode in Baghdad and Kirkuk, Iraq.

title: 2006 Nuku'alofa riots
event: August 1 – George Tupou V is crowned as the new King of Tonga, an event that had been delayed for over two years following the 2006 Nuku'alofa riots.

title: India
event: August 3 – A stampede at a Hindu temple at Naina Devi in Bilaspur, Himachal Pradesh, India kills 162 and injures 400.

title: People's Republic of China
event: August 4 – Two members of the East Turkestan Islamic Movement, which had threatened to attack the Beijing Olympics, kill 16 and injure another 16 officers at a police station in Kashgar, Xinjiang, China.

title: 2008 South Ossetia war
event: August 7 – The 2008 South Ossetia war begins, as Georgia and Russia launch a major offensive inside the separatist region of South Ossetia after days of border skirmishes between the two sides.

title: People's Republic of China
event: August 8–24 – The 2008 Summer Olympics take place in Beijing, China.

title: 2008 Toronto propane explosion
event: August 10 – A propane facility explodes in Toronto overnight and causes a large-scale evacuation, resulting in 2 deaths.

title: Nepal
event: August 15 – Pushpa Kamal Dahal (known as Prachanda) is sworn in as the first Prime Minister of the Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal, after the Nepalese monarchy was abolished in May.

title: Madrid
event: August 20 – Spanair Flight 5022, from Madrid to Gran Canaria, skids off the runway and crashes at Barajas Airport with 172 on board. Of them, 154 die and 18 survive.

title: Wah
event: August 21 – At least 60 die following twin suicide bombings outside the Pakistan Ordnance Factories in Wah, Pakistan.

title: Iran
event: August 22 – Pirates hijack German, Iranian, and Japanese cargo ships off the coast of Somalia, in seven such attacks since June 20.

title: Bishkek
event: August 24 – Iran Aseman Airlines Flight 6895 crashes upon takeoff near Manas International Airport in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, killing 68.

title: Jamaica
event: August 26 – September 1 – Hurricane Gustav makes landfall on Louisiana as Category 2 and kills seven in the United States, after making landfall on western Cuba as Category 4, and killing 66 in Haiti, eight in the Dominican Republic, and 11 in Jamaica.

title: Texas
event: September 1–14 – Hurricane Ike makes landfall on Texas as Category 2 and kills 27 in the United States, after killing four in Cuba, one in the Dominican Republic, and 75 in Haiti.

title: Bangkok
event: September 2 – Political crisis in Thailand: Prime Minister Samak Sundaravej of Thailand declares a state of emergency in Bangkok.

title: Islamabad
event: September 3 – Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gillani of Pakistan survives an assassination attempt near Islamabad, while on his way to meet British Leader of the Opposition David Cameron.

title: Nicosia
event: September 3 – President's Dimitris Christofias and Mehmet Ali Talat hold peace talks in Nicosia, aimed at reunifying Cyprus.

title: Cairo
event: September 6 – At least eight boulders dislodge from a cliff near Cairo, Egypt, killing at least 90 and burying an estimated 500 people.

title: CERN
event: September 10 – The proton beam is circulated for the first time in the Large Hadron Collider, the world's largest and highest-energy particle accelerator, located at CERN, near Geneva, under the Franco-Swiss border.

title: 2008 Bandar Abbas earthquake
event: September 10 – The 2008 Bandar Abbas earthquake strikes southern Iran, killing 7 and injuring 45 people.BBCwork=BBC Newsdate=September 10, 2008accessdate=February 10, 2010}}<

title: 2008 Chatsworth train collision
